There's nothing wrong with the product. It will keep your zippers together, but that may not matter. In case amazon doesn't like my link to an outside webpage, go on youtube and look up breaking into a checked bag with a ballpoint pen.https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wpIJVWXsBBI

For the record I know this will be down voted into oblivion, but you should know...I wanted to like this product so much, but it didn’t and tech support from the company was far from satisfactory.Let me explainI was gifted a unit to review and thought highly enough of the concept to go out and purchase a pair of high capacity (3TB) drives. In retrospect, the drives were not the recommended choices for long term use (as they were consumer level drives not meant to be in continuous use), but they were drives that should have worked at the very least in the short term and they weren’t cheap.I installed the drives, downloaded the software, and nothing. I re-downloaded the drivers; I replaced the Ethernet cable; I reset the factory device settings.  All to no avail.Next I contacted customer support. Customer support started though email and was very structured, standardized, and limited. After asking if I had checked the connection I was asked to add customer support on Skype…weird…but ok I’ll try it…. After adding the address on Skype the address was inactive (I didn’t see it online for several days) It didn’t help… from Skype I was asked to download a desktop sharing software. The tech support member asked if I had downloaded the appropriate software (we’d already confirmed I had), pressed the search for device button…which I’d done, and asked me to reset the device again. Each request was separated by 3-5 minutes of silence. After 45 minutes I was no closer to a solution and ready for bed. I promised to keep trying, but haven’t figured it out yet after a week and therefore can’t give a positive review. If and when it works I’ll give it a new review, but for now 1 star.

uNu sent me one of their new wireless chargers to try out and it works. Everything it claims to do it does, but it wasn't anything special to me and I felt like there were some easily avoidable oversights (but we'll get to those in due time).Lets start with the good. The case is nice. I like the matte black finish and the "soft" sort of texture it has. Its reasonably grippy and doesn't collect finger prints.The case is thinner than I had expected given that it has a battery in it, but it is about a centimeter longer than the phone itself. Since the iPhone 5(s) is quite long and thin already this exsentuates it and makes it feel a little akward in my hand (maybe its something I would get used to with time but for now its a bit off). The length also causes a problem with the headphone jack not accepting wide headphone plugs. The manufacturer "fixes" this by throwing in a cheap extension wire, but for the price I feel like they should have built the extension into the case. I don't want to carry an extra wire.The battery feature works well. It doesn't turn on unless you tell it to which I didn't realize at first and my phone was near dead (~1%) when I finally activated the battery by holding the button on the case. The battery isn't huge. It charged the phone to roughly 80% from dead which got me through the day, but might not be enough for a true power user (yay puns) and definitely won't let you go days without the charger.The charging pad is small (maybe too small). I found it to be light enough that the kinked corder could flip it over when the phone wasn't on it. Its an interesting design, but when it comes down to it, its really an extension cord more than it is a wireless charger. The contacts on the back of the case sit up against the metal plate to allow the phone to charge. The whole thing works and seems relatively safe. I licked both contacts of the plate (... you know... for science) and didn't die or really even get much of a shock, but it wasn't the fancy induction style charging you see in electric toothbrushes.Lastly, while my phone didn't give the "charging not supported with this accessory" message that is common with third party unbranded chargers, I didn't see the "made for iPhone" logo on any of the packaging which makes me a bit wary. The lightning connector, Apple can block chargers from charging your device if the manufacturer hasn't paid a royalty. Again I have had no issue with this to date and I'll update if I run into any issues with this.If all you want is a no frills wireless charger/battery combo I don't want to dissuade you from this one, but its got its quirks and sits at 3 stars in my book

I'm a graduate student. I give a fair number of presentations and a fair number of them are somewhat impromptu. When I end up giving a talk I hadn't expected I used to be without a pointer or would have to quickly learn a new remote. With the X-Presenter app and pointer, I've always got my pointer on my keys. All I have to do is launch the app, pull the pointer from its holder, plug it into the phone jack and go.The app seems to work correctly on both iPhone 4 and iPhone 5 (the iPhone 5 had the headphone jack moved to the other end and the app orients so that the jack and thus the pointer are at the top), has an intuitive layout and of nice features. I particularly like the built in timer which has helped me keep on pace and timed talks. The app also features a mouse mode that lets you control the cursor on the screen, but I found it to be a little cumbersome to use in the middle of a talk and it it was an option I'd probably just walk back to the computer if I needed to use the mouse.The laser is every bit as bright as stand alone pointers I've used in the past and the dongle for the remote is small enough that I can leave it in my laptop's usb slot without too much fear of it catching on anything.When I'm done the pointer slips back into its rubberized sheath that I attach to my keys with the provided nylon loop. The rubberized sheath is designed to be used as a stylus on your phone and it does a fair job and strikes a nice balance between being big enough to use comfortably and small enough to not overwhelm my keys.Overall 4 stars

I like (maybe love) my apple products. The form factor, the power, the interface...I could go on, but they have always failed at making cables. From expensive macbook charging bricks to  over priced and quick to fail iPod and iPhone cables, they just don't seem to have a handle on what customers want.Enter zeetron.The Zeetron light up cable for iPhone is fantastic. It is well built (the plastic holding the adapter and LEDs is attractive, has a nice matte finish, and feels like it should hold up over time) and the cable delivers value both with its price and its bonus light up feature.The light works well. Its bright enough to find the end of the cable in the dark and help illuminate the charger port on your device, but not so bright that it will keep you up at night. I would have preferred that the cable light shut off after some period of time (it stays on all night to show you how charged your phone is), but it doesn't seem like a big deal.I've been using mine with an iPhone 5 in a Pad and Quill Handmade Little Pocket Book case and haven't had too much of an issue with fitting the plug into the phone although I do have to lift the phone just slightly off of the back panel of the case to allow for plug clearance. I don't think this cord is obnoxiously large and I like the light feature enough that I would probably find a new case or deal with removing the case in order to use it.One last note is on the "made for iPhone" branding.  I did not see the official "made for iPhone" logo on this packaging  which suggests that Zeetron may not be paying Apple's royalty for the use of the lightning head (If I'm wrong in thinking this please correct me). If that is true these cables may not always work with apple devices. Lightning connectors have a chip in them that allows your iDevice to detect licensed cables and can block unlicensed third party cables from working. I've reviewed off brand cables in the past that seemed to have been bricked by the iOS 7 update and quit working outright. That said, with other off brand cables I usually get a warning message about from my phone explaining that an off brand accessory has been detected and that it is not guaranteed to work and I haven't had that experience with these. So it seems that my phone is not detecting a problem.Overall I think this is the best cable I've used with my iPhone 5. Its as well made as apples cable with added functionality and at a price competitive with some of the lesser cables that many people (myself included) seem to have issues with.

I've always thought that when food looks good it tastes better and the same can be said about cocktails. These ice balls give a little bit of much needed interest to the look of my old fashioned cocktails and as a bonus they actually work better than small cubes. They are roughly the same size as Tovolo King Cubes and melt about as slowly (you can probably use one cube for a couple of drinks or sip more slowly and have one cold drink most of the night.The molds themselves seem well made. I haven't have any issues with silicone smell which can be a problem with some silicone ice trays.Using the product is easy, just fill to a little above the fill line (I found that the ball did not quite fill if I filled to exactly the fill line) and pop in the freezer. The spherical shape makes finding a spot for them a little difficult if you're low on room or have things stacked up, but I found that I could get a nice level surface by using an old egg carton as a base to hold the molds.After a few hours (6 seemed to get them most of the way frozen for me) you can pop the ice out and use it. I did find that I got a seam around the edge of the ice sphere where the mold came together. This wasn't a huge deal (the seam and the little bump left from the fill hole melted off first), but if I had to mark one are for improvement it would be to make the mold pieces fit a it better so that they come out perfectly round.That said I think this is a product that's worth your consideration. With a lifetime guarantee and at half the price of competitors I'd definitely recommend these.

I bought these cables a few months after purchasing my iPhone 5 back in  November 2012. At the time they worked reasonably well (which was a surprise since apple had claimed their new cables contained a proprietary chip that would block unlicensed third party cables from working).The quality was reasonable (although the materials felt a bit cheaper than original apple cables. Each cable would last a few months before breaking (the usb connector would pull back, exposing the wires, if I wasn't careful, but for the price this was ok. I got a bunch of cables for very little money.THEN...This week I updated to iOS7. My car charger no longer works. The cord in my office no longer works. The extra cord I carry in my back pack no longer works. The only cord I have that works is the charger by my bed (which is the one charger that came with my phone).Apple has made their play. They included a chip in all of their cables. The chip allows apple devices to detect un-liscened third party cables and block them from charging the phone or passing data. For a long time they have let these third party cables work, but with iOS 7 (and it wouldn't surprise me if older versions of iOS get updated to block third party cables as well) apple has blocked the use of many thrid party cables including these.I have heard that some iOS7 users have had luck by:1. Turn on USB power.2. Plug in Lightning cable to iPhone.3. Dismiss any warnings.4. Unlock your iPhone.5. Dismiss any remaining warnings.6. Now with the screen turned on, unplug the Lightning cable.7. Plug it back in.8.Dismiss warning again. It should now charge.If you want the latest updates do a search for iOS 7 kills un-liscened cables workaround. It may be that someone overcomes this security. It may be that unlocking your phone or avoiding the OS upgrade will allow you to use any cable...but until that news comes out I'd hold off on making a big purchase (multi cable pack) on third party charging cables for apple devices.If you're desperate and can't/don't want to pay apple for an original cable consider buying a single cable and testing it out. For now proceed with caution. For me these are done.

I like (love) my bike and I can't live without my tech. I like to know how fast I've gone, what the elevation change was, what my heart rate was during the big climb, and where I'm going. But I've found that integrating tech and riding isn't always easy so I'm always looking for the easiest way to access my phone while on my bike.I've tried my own homebrewed mounting system (Bicycle Handle Bar Mount plus this universal phone mount). It had three major problems1) I needed a screw driver to take the mount on and off2) The phone couldn't rotate a full 3603) I needed a seperate case just to mount the phone (and it wasn't provided)So I kept looking and started using Weanas Roswheel Cycling Top Tube Bag. It was purpose built and had a lot of things I liked (including a bit of easily accessible storage for extra phone batteries, gels, and bars on long rides, but I had issues with my phone overheating due to the lack of airflow (the bag hid behind the headset, but was still in direct sunlight).So I kept looking and when I got the opportunity to review the RideMate (thank you Satechi for providing a review sample) I jumped at the chance. I've had the product a couple of weeks now and I've been quite happy with it so far. It remedied all of the issues I had with my home brewed case.1) The clamping mechanism uses a quick release lever to clamp and unclamp2) The case can be rotated 360 degrees to fit how you mount the phone (or phablet) and how your map or cycling app is set up3) The product is essentially an envelope (neoprene and touch sensitive plastic) so it will fit the phone I have today and whatever they come up with in the futureAdditionally I haven't had any issues with overheating. I'd attribute this mostly to the breathable materials and the superior air flow (a thin packet mounted on the handle bars cools off more readily than a larger bag hidden behind the headset).Cords for both earbuds and charging (although you'll need a separate bag to hold an external battery; I'd suggest the Roswheel linked above) are easily accessible and can be removed or added without pulling the phone out of the mount. I've found the plastic on the front of the holder to be both glare resistant (even in the noon sun I can see the screen as long as it is on full brightness; set your screen to full brightness and turn off auto-dimming if you have issues).Mounting wise I had a bit of difficulty. My bike (a diamondback podium 3) came with 31.8 mm or just over 1.25" handle bars and stem. The Satechi mount claims to fit 1.43" bars (and it probably does) but it would be a tight tight fit and you might have to go without the mounting strip. This shouldn't be a problem as 31.8mm is the new thicker standard for handlebars (so yours likely aren't any thicker), but it was close enough that I had a bit of trouble getting the mount on without scratching the bars or rolling the rubber spacer (that is inside the clamp that grabs the bar) under itself. All and all it should fit your bike and even with the difficulty it's still a better mounting system than anything I've tried. It's secure, unobtrusive, and moves with you as you ride.So I'm still not set with a single perfect bag. This one is great for shorter rides, but isn't quite perfect in terms of storage and the mounting system could be just a touch more universal, but its as good as I've found so far (and this is coming from someone who does his research before buying) and its even better if all you want to carry is your phone.Four well deserved stars****

I've been able to review several batteries in the last year including the iTorch IMP52D by New Trent and the Sendy 5200mAh  by Sendy. These batteries were small, densely constructed, and worked well as a backup incase you spent a few too many hours on your phone during the day, but they weren't optimized for use outdoors and they weren't built to be your sole source of power over a long weekend or even a day of battery intensive usage.The New Trent PowerPak Xtreme fills those roles a lot better. The size is reasonable for a longer trip (a few times thicker than an iPhone, but roughly the same area on the largest side). Its probably not something you'll want in your pocket, but it was small enough for me to put in a small bag on the top tube of my bicycle allowing several hours of riding with my iPhone 5 (with full screen brightness and constant GPS tracking) without draining the phone battery at all. The four hour ride took the PowerPak from 4 charge indicator lights to 3 lights. I've also used the PowerPak around the house when I know I'll be using my phone for internet and games. Based on  my experience so far I'd be comfortable taking the battery with me for up to 3 or 4 days when I know I'll be without an outlet.I actually have gotten in the habit of using the charger so regularly that I keep it plugged into the power block when not in use and charge my phone through it at night.The block has two ports one 2.1 amp port and one 1 amp port. I'm using the charger mostly with the 2.1 amp port to charge up a bit faster, but its nice to have the option in case I pick up a device that demands a lower (trickle) charging rate.The build quality on the device looks pretty good, but if you have used some of the smaller external batteries in the past you may be a bit confused when you pull it out for the first time. The battery is not densely packed. Granted the unit packs some weight (11.5oz), but it doesn't feel like the entire case is full (the feeling I got with the smaller capacity batteries). The plastic case is mostly hard molded plastic (although some of the pictures make it look more rubberized and I had hoped it would be similar to this type of casing). I would imagine that this empty space may have to do with building in shock protection and water resistance, but I won't know for sure until I see how it holds up over a few years.For now the battery has become part of my daily life. There is always room to improve a product and I think the casing materials and possible added size make up that potential for improvement here, but the battery is solid, it does its job reliably, and if you're looking for a battery that can power you through more than just an extra few levels of angry birds this one is for you.4 stars****

How do you rate a product that promises more than it provides, but still provides more than most?I was asked to review the Satechi Active Case i5 and have struggled to nail down exactly how I feel about it.On the one hand the case in solidly built. The materials are nice (the back is a black satin finish that provides just the right amount of grip while avoiding fingerprints and the front half is a vert attractive, shiny, and at least so far scratch resistant plastic). The case has "real" buttons that look more or less like the phone buttons they cover and feel like them too (you still get the little click when you press in the buttons like you do right on the phone). I particularly like this over the TPU cases that I've tried in the past that use a little nub thats really just part of the plastic case to "tell" you where to press.The phone fits nicely and is easy to take in and out if you use the little gaps near the base (perfect for a thumb nail if you don't have a coin). The camera is unobstructed, the case in general adds very little bulk, and it looks cool.But on the other hand two selling points for the case are the special shield to keep your phone from demagnetizing a credit card you store in the case and increased battery life based on improved reception and I wasn't very impressed with either function.You can fit a single credit card, room key, or ID behind your phone and the manufacturer provides a thing sheet to separate your phone from the card. The sheet is supposed to keep the card from interacting with your phone and demagnetizing. I use an iPhone wallet almost daily (and have for almost a year now) It doesn't have a fancy piece of bendable material that blocks the phone from the credit cards and I've never had a card demagnetized. Before that I would use regular cases but could squeeze a credit card in behind the phone if I was going out. It wasn't an every day thing, but I did it probably once a week for 4ish years and never had a card demagnetize. Now, I'm a scientist and I know I shouldn't rely on my anecdotal evidence (maybe other people with older cards or people that carry hotel room keys often will understand this feature), but for now its not a selling point for me. In addition if you do keep the thin anti interference film in place, removing your card means you detach the front and back of the case, remove the phone, remove the sheet, and remove the card. Its not necessarily a fast process and unless you have a table or extra hands you're pretty likely to drop something.Then there is the claim of improved battery life (10-15% based on the packaging) through increased reception. In theory this makes sense. Your phone constantly sends out little signals to find the closest tower. If it doesn't hear back it pings a bit louder (using more energy) in hopes a tower will respond. If you have better reception you can use less energy to look for signals (if you've ever left your phone on while on a train ride through the middle of nowhere you can attest to how this might drain your battery). My problem though was two fold. First, I tried to map my signal strength with and without the case (I even used the developer mode where you can look at the signal in decibels which is more accurate than bars) and I didn't see an appreciable difference. No difference in signal would mean no difference in battery life. Second, to claim 10-15% you'd have to assume a standard way of interacting with a phone. I use a lot of wifi for internet browsing, I play games, I watch the occasional video from my local itunes library, and sometimes I stream from netflix. I also make the occasional call and text, but some days I'd be surprised if 10% of my total power usage went to searching for signal. I would not expect to see the same improvement in battery life as say my dad who uses his phone just to make calls and probably goes through 90% of a charge over a couple of days with the phone in his pocket. Again here my anecdotal evidence isn't the end all be all and you may see a small increase in battery life, but don't expect miracles here.And that brings me back to struggling with how to rate a product that makes claims you aren't sure hold up, but is all and all a well built product that will work well if you weren't all that interested in some of the claims in the first place. How do you rate an delicious, fresh apple if you can't verify that an apple a day keeps the doctor away? In the end I would rate it based on its taste and ignore the health claim for now and that's what I've done hereMy four star rating is based on what the product is at its core, a case (and a good one). It's light, attractive, well built, and a joy to use. At its price point I wouldn't have had any trouble making this rating had it avoided the add on claims. If you like the look and just want a well built case this is a great choice, but don't expect it to replace your backup charger or your wallet.Four Stars as a case ****

Windshield mounts are a dime a dozen, but they have to be because you'll need to shell out cash for a new one for each new phone or tablet you buy (and that can get awfully expensive), but this ones different; its one of the only mounts that is guaranteed to work with your device.The reason they can guarantee this is the smart clip. By using a glue patch to mount the clip to a your phone or tablet's case you're able to mount just about anything to the smart mount which in this configuration is used with the suction mount (but it will also work with any screw on to any standard tripod (or Joby Gorillapod Original Black/Charcoal - Joby GP1-B1AM) as well as some bike mounts).The glue pad that comes with the kit is "one time use" and it sticks very well, but I suspect that you could scrape it off with a razor blade or a kitchen knife. Then you could mount it to your next phone's case. I don't see it here, but the manufacturer seems to also sell the smart clip separately on its website so you could buy a few if you have multiple devices that you'd want to use without pulling them off the case.The only possible drawback that I see is that the clip is a little large, so you won't want to mount it to your phone's case if you like to keep your phone in a pocket (it could work on your belt though). I have seen a few other mounts that grasp the device and consider themselves "universal." You'll have to weigh your options here, but I would feel a little limited with the "grasping" mount. Most  are designed for normal phones, but with new form factors like tablets and phablets (giant phone-tablets) becoming popular you're likely to want something that really is universal.Enough about the universalness though. I like the mount in general. The build is great and the two adjustment knobs let it be positioned at just about any angle. It will work sitting on your dash (if you have a smooth surface). or hanging down from your windshield. The build quality is great. It feels like it will last through several phones/tablets/ or whatever they invent next. If you're looking for a mount that will work great today and just as well in 5 years this is it.5 Stars

I was approached by Satechi to review their 10-Port USB 3.0 Hub and have been quite impressed by it so far. The build quality seems solid, it looks great on a desk with other shiny modern tech, and its got some really unique and useful features. I may not be the exact target audience for a product like this (I'm not sure I even own 10 USB peripherals), but I am getting much more milage out of it than I had expected. When the device arrived I brought it into the office and set it up with my desktop (although sometimes I'll plug it into my Macbook Pro). I've got the normal keyboard and mouse and a few usb drives, but not a ton of items.What I really like this for is charging. I've got a limited number of plugs available to me and AC adaptors for iPods,iPhones, kindles etc can be a bit bulky and more than a bit expensive, but over the years I've built up quite the stash of extra USB charging cables and this hub has let me put them to good use. Charging from this hub is fast, much faster than a car charger and somewhat faster than charging directly from my laptop. Since it is a powered hub it fully powers each port (where the USB ports on my laptop have to split power between them when I am trying to charge more than one device). I also like that the last port (on the end of the unit) is not a data port. This port is designed for charging only and will not connect to your computer. Some reviewers don't seem to like this, but I've always been annoyed that connecting apple devices opens iTunes when all I was trying to do was charge. By using this port I avoid that even when the strip itself is still connected to the computer.I was a little afraid that having heavy cords hanging off of the hub would cause it to tip over. I had noticed when I pulled it from the box, that it is not particularly heavy, but it does ship with a piece of double sided tape and with it fixed to the desk it doesn't seem to matter how many cords I have pulling on it, it stays put.The last feature that I'm slowly growing to really like is the ability to switch ports on and off. The hub comes with three banks of three USB ports each. Each bank of ports can be independently turned on or off. The little bit of environmentalist in me likes to think I'm limiting phantom power usage by switching off unused chargers and peripherals (although I'm not totally sure turning off the ports stops power from flowing to the strip). Organizing the USB ports into banks has lead me towards organizing my peripherals by task. I will normally keep my mouse and keyboard on one bank, my data (usb sticks or drives if I'm using one) on the second bank, and several gadget chargers on the last one (and on the charger only port). When I come in in the morning I'll flick on the mouse/keyboard bank and only turn the others on when I need them.I didn't know how often I would use this hub, but its becoming more and more a part of my daily life and my workflow. It makes keeping all of my devices charged easy and keeps me connected to the few peripherals I need to survive. Its well built, well designed, and has features that set it apart from some of the smaller (unpowered) usb hubs I have used in the past. If you're in the market for a powered USB hub I don't see a better alternative.Five Stars

There are hundreds of good reviews that comment on the great sound and build quality on these headphones. I don't pretend to think that I'm going to add anything there, but I do have a big head and shallow headphone cups press on my ears and get uncomfortable after a while, so I thought I'd throw out my suggestion for that in hopes it might help someone.The cups on these are relatively shallow when they come out of the package, but there is a fair amount of "extra" material in them and you can stuff something into the ear pad to puff them out creating a larger space for your ear. I rolled cotton balls into a snake and wrapped that in black duct tape. The ring I fashioned fit in the pocket between the plastic ear body and the pleather cushion that presses against your head. This lets me wear them for much longer periods of time without discomfort.

Ok lets start with the good. This is a piece of FUR!!Cats love chasing fur. It doesn't matter if its full of jingle bells, or cat nip, or juicy bits that you'd rather not think about too hard. Fur is Fur.So its got that. You can attach it to your Da Bird stick (Da Bird Cat Catcher Cat Toy by Go Cat Feather Toys) your cat will chase it, "kill" it, and if your cat is like my cat, attempt to eat it (and repeat until I give up and try to hide it).But then there is the bad. This toy will brake. The fur is just glued onto the rubber top. Its not epoxy glue or super glue it really just looks like hot glue and thats disappointing because it will pull off. My cat managed to pull it off before I even got the toy put on the stick.So how do you fix it?Grab the toy. Throw it on a cutting board. Use a paring knife to poke a small hole through the leather sort of in the middle and at one end. Poke the fishing lure connector on the end of the Da Bird stick string through the hole and connect it to itself (the string). This will connect the toy to the string and you're on your way.The last time I did this it lasted for several weeks of near constant play. When it eventually did tear through the toy I was able to cut a new hole and start over. Eventually the thin just looked so sad (missing most of its fur) that I chose to replace it.So if you've already bought this all is not lost. You can get your money's worth out of this toy, but don't expect it to work "as advertised" and be ready to improvise.If you're still debating I'd consider your alternatives or maybe buy just one and see if it holds up to your liking.3 stars

He's a mouse. She's a cat. Could it get any better?My cat Meeko loves mice. Stuffed mice, jingle mice, squeek mice, probably live mice if given the chance but this one drives her WILD.We use it on the end of her Da Bird pole (Da Bird Cat Catcher Cat Toy by Go Cat Feather Toys) and she will chase it anywhere. She drags it around the house to try to get someone to play with her and more than once I've walked in on her tangled up in the string batting the mouse up in the air by herself (she always tries to pretend she wasn't, but I know what's going on).This mouse is really well built. I'm not sure if the leather tale is directly connected to the nose loop or if its just very well secured, but it has not shown ANY sign that its going to come off despite Meeko's nearly ritualistic gnawing and pulling on it. The nose loop is very secure as well and has not come off of the fishing lure connector that comes on the Da Bird pole once and shows no signs of getting ready to detach from the body (which is more than I can say for most of the name brand Da Bird refills we've tried).The only little bit of mess you get from this one is the bristles that make up the body. They certainly don't litter the floor like an over-loved catnip mouse, but they do pull off at a pretty constant rate (pretty much from the first catch you'll see a few on your cat's face). They aren't bad and in a few weeks haven't made the toy any less mouse like (although the body is getting a little more sparse), but if you're a neat freak you might need to stick to your laser pointer or a jingle ball (but where's the fun in that).For my money I'll certainly be back. This is the best refill I've come across for Da Bird and an excellent buy.*****Five Well Earned Stars

I received my CISS unit a couple of weeks ago and was really excited to try to get it installed on my Epson WorkForce-3520. Having read the other reviews I was hoping for an easy setup and had even taken the advise of other reviewers and watched the installation video in advance on XPRO's youtube channel.Despite my efforts this planning didn't lead to the easiest setup. First, there are NO instructions in the box. If you go to the website they will direct you to videos on installing your system and on priming your system (getting air bubbles out of the air ink lines), but having only found the installation video on youtube I was blissfully unaware that I would need to prime the system. So after breaking off my printer ink cartridge door, installing the cartridge block, and taping in the lines to allow the printer head to move (for this I had to use my own tape as the foam tape provided was too thick) I got nothing. My printer produced only blank sheets.I knew something hadn't gone right so I checked through the comment threads on youtube CISS videos and found this "priming" which wasn't mentioned in the original video. So I went about finding the priming video for this CISS system. In the end I did find it on the XPRO website, but I wouldn't say it was the most obvious thing ever.From there I went about priming the cartridges, but I couldn't seem to get the ink to flow. Eventually I realized that in the priming video they had removed the ink tanks from the holder. It wasn't clear why they had done this and I had assumed that it was just to show more clearly what they were doing, but when I removed my tanks I found that the ink lines were doubled under and kinked (blocking the flow). On a side note this was the first thing I was asked to check for when I contacted customer support (if its that common of a problem then mention it in your instructional video). I fixed this, re-primed the cartridges AND... printed a beautiful test sheet ENTIRELY in blue ink. This is dragging on, but in short it had taken several hours of my time to try to prime the cartridges and the ink heads had dried out. After spending a few more hours troubleshooting thinking that maybe I needed to position the tank better (above or below the level of the printer cartridges) I washed the print heads with rubbing alcohol and distilled water and now I get full color prints.My hands were stained, my printer was more or less covered with drops of ink, I was more than a little frustrated, but it worked.Now that its installed it seems to work well. I feel like I'm actually saving ink (despite having to dump several syringes full of ink during the priming process and mishaps). The prints are near the quality of the original epson cartridges (maybe the pigment ink system would be even closer since Epson uses pigment ink in their cartridges).The build quality isn't great. Most of the parts feel like cheap Chinese manufacturing. The chip that connects the cartridges to the printer software is built so that it blocks the vent plugs you need access to during priming. The syringes provided for priming are incredibly cheap, thin plastic both broke by the time I was finished. The air vents they provide for the ink tanks didn't fit initially with the ink tank cover closed so I had to trim them (in retrospect this may have been because of the folded under tubing that raised the ink tanks 1/16").Time will tell if I come back and upgrade the ranking on this system. If it runs perfectly from here out then my frustration was worth while and its probably a 4 star product, but if I end up needing to tweak and adjust it every time I want to print I will probably stick with my initial feelings and leave it here at 3 stars.If you really do your homework and saving money is important to you this CISS system could work well for you, but don't expect it to be hassle free. You are "hacking" your printer to work with bulk ink systems and the company that sold you the printer (and wants you to buy the ink) would really rather you not do this.So think before you jump.Realize that you are potentially risking both your printer and your money here (I don't think epson will cover bulk ink spills or a broken off printer cartridge door warranty or not).And then decide how you value your time and whether the potential hassle (and mess) is worth the savings.3 stars

I was approached by Satechi to review their BT Touch Speaker. I have reviewed a few speakers in the past, but for the most part they have been high end home theater and music setups. I assume that this may be why I was approached, but it gives me a little different perspective as while I don't use a lot of small bluetooth speakers, I do have quite a bit of audio experience.So lets start with what I don't know a ton about. The bluetooth component. This speaker was easy to set up. I was using an iPhone 5 (which I had previously paired with a Garmin Nuvi, so I wasn't totally clueless), but the little instruction booklet was very helpful in getting going. The speaker automatically searches out detectable devices the first time you turn it on, and if you miss that opportunity you can just hold down the bluetooth button, it beeps and you get to try again. And thats pretty much it. The speaker shows up in your discoverable devices library on your bluetooth enabled device, you click it, and you can start playing music and making calls.The connection seems stable as long as you're in the room or maybe a room over (depending on what is in between you; my bathroom is next to the kitchen, but putting a large refrigerator and a few pipes between the unit and my phone did give it some issues).I was able to stream both my itunes library as well as pandora. The unit is also set up to make calls and that works reasonably well although I don't think its a function I will use often. It might work well for small conference calls and people on the other end of the line said I was easy to understand. Its just not a feature I'll use on a daily basis, but it could be a nice in certain circumstances.The battery life on the unit seems very good. For now I keep it plugged in by my bed (it comes with a usb charging cord that will fit any old iphone/kindle/and USB device brick you have lying around), but have taken it around the house as well as outside for a few hours without killing the battery. The company claims a 4 hour battery life and I'd say that they're being fairly accurate.The audio component is where I'm a little more comfortable, but that doesn't make this an easy review. On the one hand I am impressed by the sound that can come out of a speaker this size. The whole thing is about the size of a large baked potato and for the size it does incredibly well. But on the other hand its not a super high end setup and won't replace my Klipsch speakers (which cost 10x as much and don't have bluetooth connectivity). The bass is pleasant, although certainly not booming (if you're looking for club base you can feel you need a much bigger setup). The distortion is quite low even at the highest volume settings. The mids and highs feel tight and crisp although occasionally a little tinny. There is no equalizer setting on the speaker itself. The way it comes (and interacts with my iPhone) seem to be a pretty middle of the road setup. It sounds pretty good with any music, but does best with music with clear vocals and tighter bass notes (think rock over rap). You might be able to get a little more out of it if you played your music through an app with a built in equalizer.The volume range is pretty good, but unlike other reviewers I wouldn't say that it "fills any room" if you're hanging out at your desk or listening to some quieter music its going to be great for you. Yes you can hear the speaker in any room (so in that respect it does fill a room), but if you are looking for a speaker to use at your next house party or something to listen to while you're at the park playing basketball you'll need something with more power.Overall I'm pretty impressed with this little guy. It gets the job done and is a joy to use. Its certainly portable, the build looks like great quality (I'll let you know if I have any issues over time), but its not the highest quality sound you can get (and I don't think I can compare to many bluetooth speakers so I'll leave that determination for someone else), but its pretty good and for a speaker I can throw in a backpack (or any much smaller bag) I can't help but be impressedFour well earned stars

I bought this drive for my early 2011 macbook pro and installed it in the space that used to hold the optical disk drive. I used this (Hard Drive Caddy Tray for Apple Unibody MacBook / MacBook Pro 13 15 17 SuperDrive (Replacement Only)) mounting bracket. The physical install was relatively easy although if you haven't opened up your laptop before I'd read through the directions on ifixit a few times just so you don't get flustered and lose a screw.The drive is fast. I've uploaded a picture of the blackmagic (free drive speed testing app in the apple app store) showing full read and write stats, but in summary it came in at 262 MB/s read speed and 225 MB/s write speed. The package claims 550 read and 530 write (and the drive may well do that under absolutely optimal conditions), but I think the numbers I got are more realistic for the real world and they seem to be right in line with the read/write speeds of some of the more high end and well known drives (crucial, samsung, etc).In "real world" testing (ie when I take an unscientific approach and launch applications that are currently stored on both the ssd and on the regular hard drive) I see drastic improvement with the SSD. Excel takes about 12 seconds to launch from the HDD, but under 2 seconds to launch from the SSD. Restarts take significantly less time when booting from the SSD and compiling and running computationally heavy modeling software (my lab uses a lot of Matlab, Simile, GAMS, super pro modeler, etc) is greatly improved. Granted you'll likely see this sort of improvement no matter what SSD you end up buying, but its nice to know that even though this drive is priced like a budget model it runs as well if not better than the well known brands.My advice would be to get a drive thats big enough for at least all of your applications and your operating system and unless you really think you're in the top 1% of users who really need the extra few MB/s in the read and write stats, don't go for the super high end drives. This drive (at least at the time of this review) is reasonably priced with respectable speed if it looks like its going to fit your needs buy it. If other drives eventually end up being cheaper then go for the cheaper model. This is a nice drive, but very few drives really deserve a premium price and very few buyers will notice the difference in speed.

Strange (and perhaps mildly nerdy) as it may sound I've had my eye on the Missing Manual Windows 8 guide since before Christmas (it finally came out in March). I knew I wanted to upgrade my operating system and would want a guide to help me get up to speed quickly. Having read some of David Pogue's other books before so I knew that his sense of humor, his ability to distill instructions and explanations into everyday language, and the general approachability of his work really appealed to me. Because of that I really wanted to use this book to learn Windows 8.In the end I upgraded earlier than I had originally intended to and bought Windows 8 For Seniors For Dummies to help fill in the gap between when I got Windows 8 and when this book would eventually released. That book was good. It was approachable, it was a start, but it was shallow. So I kept waiting. I knew how to use basic Windows 8 features and I knew where the gaps in my knowledge were.That's where I came into this book, fully expecting to learn some new, more "advanced" tips on features that may not pertain to the everyday user. I've certainly gotten that, but I've also gotten great little hints and tips that speed up some of the most common ways I interact with my PC computer, from the new Windows 8 interface that Pogue names the "TileWorld" through my desktop and settings.If you come in with a similar skill set you could probably skip Part One, but then again you may not want to as this section covers some of the most common ways you will interact with your PC and every half second saving tip you pick up could save you hours in the long run. Part One's main focus is on getting you comfortable with the new TileWorld interface. Through it I picked up dozens of little tricks that improve my workflow (apparently my knowledge on even the basics was not as deep as I thought). As with all of the sections I've read it was well written, highly illustrated, conversational in tone, and easy to understand (I'm through about 375 pages of actual reading/trying out, but I've also browsed most all of the sections).It should also be noted that if you're running a windows-RT device this is your section. While the remainder book does cover more functions applicable to windows-RT users this is the most important section for you because almost everything you do will launch from the TileWorld.From there Pogue advances through eight total parts:Part Two: The Windows Desktop; this sections covers interactions on your desktop (dealing with files, programs, the task bar, control panel etc.)Part Three: Windows Online; this section covers the internet and everything that goes with it including your initial setup, protecting yourself online, and the provided internet browser and email applications.Part Four: Pictures & Music; this is the multimedia section covering videos, pictures, and music.Part Five: Hardware & Peripherals; this section is a quick 30 pages on tips and tricks for hooking up and running printers, scanners, and other devices through the sometimes dizzying array of ports on your PC.Part Six: PC Health; this section covers tips, tricks, and a bit of common sense to help you keep your hard drive from filling up, your computer running fast, and your data safe.Part Seven: The Windows Network; this section covers the different types of networks and accounts that you can set up, why you might want to set these networks up, and exactly how to do it.Part Eight: Appendixes; the book has four appendixes which cover windows installation, a quick introduction to the registry (more to ease your fears of it than to tell you how to do everything with it), features that were dropped in Windows 8 (or aren't in their old location), and a handy list of keyboard shortcuts.While I haven't finished reading each section I have browsed them quite a bit and picked out topics to fill in things that I already knew I didn't understand well. Each topic has been approached with the same clearly defined style and attention to detail as the first 375 pages were. I'm yet to read a topic that didn't teach me something new and I'm also yet to find a topic I couldn't understand.I give a lot of credit to Pogue for limiting jargon to an absolute minimum, but since I've jumped around a bit I do occasionally see a bit of lingo that I haven't been introduced to, but when that happens I've found that searching the index leads me almost without fail to the first uses of the lingo in question. This makes this a fantastic guide for someone who's not interested in reading a 900+ page manual cover-to-cover. Pogue realizes that nearly no one will use all of the features in Windows 8. He points it out in the book's introduction and acknowledges that because people won't use all of the features, they will skip around in the book (and that's ok). The book is designed for that and the time spent in the index and detailed table of contents to make the book highly searchable make that obvious.With superbly deep content, a refined teaching style, and an approachability not commonly found in tech manuals approaching 1000 pages, The Missing Manual for Windows 8 is an absolute gem. I cannot recommend it highly enough to those who are planning an upgrade to Windows 8, have just bought a device that came with Windows 8, those that are struggling, and even those that feel like they have a handle on everything. You will learn, you will work faster and smarter, and you will spend more time doing what you want instead of wallowing in frustration.*****Five Hugely Enthusiastic Stars

About 3 years ago I was having back, knee, ankle, and foot pain so I went to see a podiatrist. He convinced me that the insoles that came with my shoes weren't providing enough support. In his opinion the best thing I could do was get a pair of custom insoles made. At the time I had insurance that would cover it so I did. They were hard plastic and molded to my feet. They fit well and did fix my pain problems. I switched them out every time I switched shoes for over 2 years. I was tired of that. I wanted insoles to put in each pair of shoes I owned so I bought a few pairs of these.I was pretty scared that the pain was going to come back. I couldn't imagine that a $10 pair of insoles would ward off pain the way my $300 (before insurance) pair would, but I have been pleasantly surprised. I've been using these for about 6 months and haven't had any of my former pain return.These don't provide the support of a molded prescription insole. In fact they aren't even as thick as some of the other off the shelf insoles I've tried, but they're better than the thin foam insoles that come in my shoes (mostly Adidas) and apparently they're enough for me. These do provide some (somewhat malleable) arch support and the heal cup does work to absorb shock when I'm on my feet all day.The recommendation I can make here is two fold. First these insoles are far better than what comes in your standard sneakers and they can provide pain relief. Second, if you've been sold on high end insoles but never tried (or haven't tried in several years) the off the shelf insoles, do yourself a favor and find out whether you need to be spending that money. You may find that off the shelf insoles are all you need.Final thoughts:These are reasonable off the shelf insoles for a very reasonable priceThey aren't prescription insolesThey aren't the $70 off the shelf insolesBut they're a quality product that are going to be perfect for a lot of people

These cubes are near perfect. They are plenty big enough to cool down a glass of scotch and since they have a low surface area to volume ratio they are going to take longer to melt and dilute your drink. They may also not cool it quite as quickly, but for my application that wasn't the point.A lot of people have commented on the off flavor that these can provide. I agree in that when I received my package they didn't smell the freshest. They definitely had some kind of lubricant from the manufacturing process on them. I rinsed them with blue dawn and then let them soak with some dilute vinegar solution (roughly 1:10 vinegar:water). I used apple cider vinegar because its what I had on hand. After a 10 minute soak and a quick rinse the tray had no discernible off odor and the cubes came out tasting like regular ice.I'd also heard that the cubes were difficult to remove, but I didn't have quite that experience. They don't fall out of the tray like an old school plastic tray, but I think thats done on purpose a bit. If you're going to take the time to make perfectly shaped cubes would you want to let them tumble out and chip corners off? A little push up on the bottom of each cube gets it out far enough that I can grab it and lift it out and the mold snaps right back to shape.Overall I'd say these are as close to perfect as you're going to get especially if you fixate on making pretty drinks. The cubes are not only functional, but look amazing and to me thats well worth a quick vinegar rinse and a few extra seconds to take them out of the tray.5 stars!

This is a great manual. Its absolutely comprehensive. It focuses on many of the newer features of the iPhone 5 and iOS 6, but touches on nearly every conceivable thing that your phone can do and every conceivable way that you would want to interact with it.I would consider myself an avid iPhone user. I've owned pretty much every other model since the first and would have considered myself extremely iPhone proficient. Apparently I wasn't close. I had no idea that there were multiple ways to change appointment times or that I could customize the notifications center. While I had a general understanding about the icons on the top bar I couldn't have told you the complete hierarchy of cellular networks. When apple launches a new product or OS they add hundreds of features, but the media picks maybe 10 to drool over and you never hear about the rest. To take the time to search out and understand each one could take days, but its all here with full color pictures and easy to follow explanations that both explain functionality and walk you through using it.I found this to be an interesting cover to cover read, but then I'm probably a bit of a nerd. You certainly don't need to use it like that, but I suspect many people will just because its fun to know what your phone is capable of and to discover functionality you didn't know existed. If you don't read it cover to cover or if you do and then need to reference something later, fear not, the index of this book (which is hefty by the way at over 500 pages) is fantastic. If you've heard about a feature you can look it up by name. If you've got an icon you can't decipher the index will direct you to it. If all you know is that you want more functionality with a specific built in app like iBooks or iTunes you'll find where to go quickly and easily.Whether you enjoy learning about the features of your new iDevice or you've got a parent or grandparent that struggling to use the iPhone this book would be more than adequate. Great pictures, great descriptions, easy to use, and well worth the money.*******UPDATE: COMPARATIVE RANKINGSI never intended to read enough iPhone 5 "manuals" to truly compare them. First I just like learning about the phone. Then I got interested in the differences in teaching styles and ended up reading 5 really well put together books. I ended up rating them all relatively highly simply because they were all great books that will serve their target audiences very well. But since they're all great books you deciding on star ranking alone may not get you the right book so I'm adding a comparative ranking to each of my reviews to help you identify which target audience you might be in.I still stand by my initial reviews, but with more background my perspective has definitely grown.Overall Comprehensiveness:1) The Missing Manual (iPhone: The Missing Manual) - Covers from the tech in the phone to multiple ways to do almost everything2) My iPhone (My iPhone (Covers iPhone 4, 4S and 5 running iOS 6) (6th Edition)) - Maybe a touch less tech coverage than The Missing Manual, but not by much3) iPhone 5 for Dummies (iPhone 5 For Dummies (For Dummies (Computer/Tech)))- A reasonably comprehensive guide that doesn't bog down in tech detail and covers fewer ways to do things than the missing manual4) Teach Yourself Visually (Teach Yourself VISUALLY iPhone 5 (Teach Yourself VISUALLY (Tech))) - just a how-to usually one method per function5*) iPhone 5 for Dummies for Seniors (iPhone 5 For Seniors For Dummies (For Dummies (Computer/Tech))) - A moderately distilled version of the dummies book with more focus on "senior specific" topics(*I thought this should be singled out for its special topics of interest which my override total comprehensiveness for some buyers)Readability and Narrative:1) The Missing Manual - Reads well and the author has a bit of a sense of humor. The lack of walk throughs actually tends to make reading flow more naturally2) My iPhone - The narrative in this book made it accessible and helped disperse any nervousness you might have about learning a new tech device2) iPhone 5 for Dummies - A readable book, but certainly not my favorite read and probably not something I'd read for fun (even if I am a bit of a tech geek)4) iPhone 5 for Dummies for Seniors - Big text make this book "readable," but I wasn't engaged with the narrative5) Teach Yourself Visually - This book is walk throughs its not for light readingWalk throughs and step-by-step instructions:1) Teach Yourself Visually - Tons of brilliantly detailed instructions with pictures that point out exactly where to press2) My iPhone - Nice guides offset from the narrative in distinctive blue boxes with helpful pictures.3) iPhone 5 for Dummies for Seniors - More guided instructions than the regular Dummies iPhone book, but not close to the Teach Yourself Visually book that I would recommend to my parents in terms of quantity or quality4) iPhone 5 for Dummies5) The Missing Manual - Step by step, button-by-button guides are not emphasized. The book isn't void of all instructions, but they are imbedded in text and assume that you read the first chapters and can find the appropriate buttons.

This is a good thief for however you want to use it. I generally use it to take liquid out for testing, pH adjustment, back sweetening etc, but it is possible to use it for taking a hydrometer reading and I think that would be more apparent if it came with directions. Its faster than using a siphon for small volumes and I think its less likely to cause contamination just because its simpler and has less little places for nasties to hide. Ive used it with buckets, 5, and 7 gallon carboys. I probably wouldn't recommend it for gallon jugs just because its a little tall and the time to sanitize something so large wouldn't be worth the volume you'd get out.If it had with directions I'd hope they had 2 sections#1 CLEANINGThis is a big item and unless you want to make several gallons of sanitizer or have a very large shallow pan you aren't going to submerge it (but if you can thats certainly the safest route). So how do you clean it? I've found that I can get decent exterior sanitizer contact just scooping sanitizer up with a hand and pouring it on. I think the tip is more likely to harbor bacteria than the smooth tube so I keep it submerged in sanitizer for a few minutes. To sanitize the inside I either scoop sanitizer up and pour it into the top of the tube or apply suction to the top while the bottom is submerged and suck sanitizer up into it like a giant straw. Once you lift the thief up so that the button isn't depressed the sanitizer is trapped in the tube allowing plenty of contact time. If you don't think you got quite enough contact time before it drained just repeat. After a few minutes dump and you're ready to go (at least for all no rinse sanitizers).#2 IF YOU WANT TO USE IT FOR HYDROMETER READINGSThis thief leaks a bit so I wouldn't use it over white carpet, but its not terrible and its about the best you could hope for with a gravity controlled valve. So if you want to use it for hydrometer readings: First make sure your hydrometer is going to fit in the top. Dip the thief into your carboy or bucket and fill it as full as possible. Drop in your hydrometer while you're still in the bucket. Lift the thief out high enough to take your reading. It may leak a little, but its slowly and its going right back into your fermenter. You should have plenty of time to take the reading if you run out of time and the level drops so far that the hydrometer hits the bottom of the jar just lower the thief, refill, and try again. Problem solved.Overall a good product better than anything else on the market, but it could benefit from some education PR.

I bought this corker when I did my fist batch of homemade mead. I've used it with normal wine bottles of all shapes and sizes including thin ice wine bottles. Once you get the hang of it it goes very quickly. All you do is:-1) make sure you have your own glass of wine poured. Bottling is always a little more fun that way1) flip the corker over and put in a cork (has worked fine with both synthetic and natural corks)2)pull the two red handles together to compress the cork (this is very similar to a floor corker and where this differentiates from the double leaver corkers which don't compress the cork3) with the cork compressed into a thin cylinder position the bottle beneath the corker4) use one hand to keep the red handles close together (they don't have to touch all the way) and use your free hand to push the leaver down ejecting the cork into the neck of the bottle.It seems to take about the right amount of time to have a friend filling bottles while you cork them and after a couple tries you'll probably even have a few sips from your glass in between corkings.Beyond the ease of use the product seems to be exceptionally well made. The plastic is very thick as is the metal leaver. It has a fair number of moving parts, but they all seem sturdy through several batches.The one thing I did have a little trouble with and the reason I'm giving 4 stars and not 5 is that it can sometimes be hard to get a perfect finish height. There is an adjustment if you're going too deep, but I had much more of an issue with not getting the corks quite all the way in. I had several bottles come out with a 1/4 inch cork sticking out because just as the last bit of cork is ejected from the compression section of the corker it expands and doesn't quite make it into the bottle. Not a huge deal it even makes it look a little more home made, but if you're a perfectionist it could bother you.

I had the first Aperture 3 Pro Series training book and I thought it was incredibly thorough. Sometime more thorough than a hobby photographer really needs, but perfect for anyone hoping to gain a very strong understanding of Aperture. The book was designed as a class and not a reference guide so the best way to use it was to read the chapters in order and go through the accompanying examples so that you could not only read about the features, but also test them out and see exactly how they should affect the picture you're working on if you are using them correctly. If you try to use it to look up individual features (I tried to use it that way the first time) it will not be very helpful because the book builds a skill base in each chapter and expects you to have some understanding of those skills in later chapters. Without that base the book can be down right confusing.I got a chance to check out the new edition and have found it to be much the same. It is every bit as thorough as the original was for the first version of Aperture 3 and covers the new features that were released up until 3.3 such as the improved highlighting and shadowing tools and the improved white balance tool. (On a side note the amazon description says that this version was optimized for 3.3 while the Peachpit site description says it is optimized for 3.4. A little confusing, but since 3.4 didn't contain many new user features this probably isn't an issue). Having continued to use Aperture for a while before this guide came out I had a decent grasp on the new features, but my learning curve would have been improved with the new guide and my technique did get a little fine tuning.So is the new guide worth the few extra dollars over the old guide?  ABSOLUTELY.  If you're learning the product for the first time go with the new guide. Some of the menus have changed since the software first came out so your learning experience is going to go a lot smoother with the updated guide and its the only way to get the complete run down on the new features.If you have the old guide do you absolutely need to upgrade?  I don't think so (unless you're applying for the certification)... If you weren't baffled when 3.3 came out and/or you have access to an internet connection you should be fine. When new features come out people are only too eager to try them out and post their experiences. You've already got a strong base and are going to be able to digest whatever directions you find online. So save yourself a few dollars, run a google search, and learn what you can about the new features.With all that said...This is still the definitive book for those looking to learn the ENTIRE Aperture programThere is no more complete guideThere is no guide with better step by step examplesIf you're serious about photography and have settled on Aperture to edit and manage your photos this is the book to buy hands down

I'm not a professional by any means, but I like to tinker and always seem to have a home improvement project or two going. So my review is probably going to be most relevant to people that get their tools out a few times a month and just want something thats comfortable to use and that will get the job done.That said... I REALLY like the FatMax Line. The FatMax grips are a little chunkier and for my hands that makes them a little more comfortable than standard tools. If you have smaller hands the larger pliers could be a little intimidating, but my girlfriend hasn't had any trouble handling them so I don't think it is much of a problem. I don't know why they didn't continue that grip coating on the adjustable wrench and the locking pliers but I haven't had any blister issues with those either. Beyond the grips the tools seem incredibly sturdy. I've been known to use the closest tool at hand as a hammer when I'm in a pinch and even with that these show virtually no wear in almost a year in service.In addition to the great build, I think this is just a well thought out starter set. If you're not really sure what kind of pliers you're going to need or if you're buying this for someone thats just putting together their tool box you're going to be pleased with this. The blunt nose pliers cover a lot of prying jobs for me. The needle nose and wire cutters get used when I'm tinkering with household wiring. The crescent wrench is a great all around wrench for nuts and bolts (I pulled apart an old steelcase tanker desk with just it and a screwdriver). And the vice-grip (locking pliers) are my fall back tool to get me out of a jam (broke the hose nob off...stripped a screw half way in...can't get a tight grip on a smooth pipe? locking pliers to the rescue!!). Sometimes I need to borrow an extra wrench to get a job done, but for the most part (at least pliers and wrench wise) this kit has me covered. Everything gets used nothing's really missing. Just a really well put together starter kit.So wrapping up/recap:If you're looking for a sturdy, comfortable, well rounded pliers set thats gonna cover 90% of the around the house needs this is it. Highly Recommended

I'm no professional. I don't have a professional tool set budget. Most of the building and repairs I do aren't huge undertakings, but I think I represent a lot of do it yourselfers and to them I would highly recommend the Ryobi JobPlus.This is a great tool and its what I've started building my cordless toolset around. Originally I wanted a simple sander. I was going to buy a single purpose tool, but for a few dollars more I've been able to get a multi function tool body with the ability to adapt to my needs as time goes on.Essentially the JobPlus is a vibrating handle that can be connected to one of several "heads" with different functions. It seems to be sturdily built, powerful, and it runs for over an hour on one of the smaller Ryobi 18v batteries.The tool comes with a sanding head and 2 saw heads. The sanding head was why I purchased it originally and it works great. I was able to strip the paint off an old steel tanker desk in an afternoon without tiring myself out.They can cut through plywood, but they basically sand through it the wood gets very hot and sometimes even starts to smoke.The saws are less amazing.I've only used them for a few small cutting chores, but I can say that I wouldn't want to have to cut anything thicker than a 3/4" dowel with them, but the great thing is that I won't have to because this tool fits all of the Rigid Jobmax heads. If I have a project that needs cutting power I can choose between the jigsaw head or the reciprocating saw head. These heads were originally designed to work with the 12v so this 18v JobPlus should be able to provide plenty of power to them.The heads are really what has sold me on the product there are drills, hammers, ratchets, and saws and new compatible heads are always being designed.A cordless drill would be nice. I cordless saw would be helpful. A cordless sander would serve a purpose, but if I had to pick a single tool to own for my decidedly non professional home improvement projects I'd go with the JobPlus.

I got this set for christmas almost a year ago and they have worked out wonderfully. I'm no professional, but I am pretty active with home improvement projects and furniture refinishing projects.I've gone through a fair number of cheap screw drivers who's bits seemed just as likely to strip as a stuck screws. I haven't had that problem with these at all. I used the set to tear apart an old rusty steel case tanker desk without any problems. The handles are on the larger side which might make them less comfortable for someone with small hands, but if your hands are on the average or larger side they'll fit well. The large grips make providing enough torque to break loose a rusty stuck screw relatively easy and having the proper bit sizes on hand makes you less likely to strip it. The kit comes with 3 philips and 3 flat head screw drivers (1 thick, 1 fine, and 1 medium short handle) and one universal handle that fits the accompanying bits. This bit set covers almost all of my needs, but the handle looks to be compatible with bits that have come with some other tools I've bought in the past so I don't think I'll ever have a problem with not having the right bit.I store them inside so I wouldn't expect any rust and I haven't seen any (so no complaints there).This would be a great starter kit for someone just getting into any kind of building project or really anyone looking for a strong base to build a tool set around. Stanley does sell a larger set for the fatmax line (Stanley 62-502 11-Piece FatMax Screwdriver Set) if you think you'll need it, but I haven't felt the need to upgrade yet.

To start the kit contains the following:1/2" 5/8" 3/4" and 1" Spade bits (used for drilling large holes in wood)5/16" 1/4" 3/16" 5/32" 9/64" 1/8" 7/64" 3/32" 5/64" and 1/16" multi purpose titanium nitride coated high speed steel bits (used for many jobs the titanium coating helps keep them sharper longer)5/32" 3/16" 1/4" and 5/16" masonry bits (for drilling brick cinder block etc)1/4" 7/32" and 5/32" brad point wood bits (W-point) (these produce a very clean hole when drilling wood and some plastics)The kit also includes a screw head adapter and several screw bitsWith that out of the way...This is a good kit. I'm not a professional by any means. I do mostly little home improvement jobs, but for the most part this kit has me covered. Occasionally I'll need to buy a specialty bit (like a hole saw or other larger diameter bit), but I wouldn't expect those types of bits to be included in a starter kit. If they were included, the kit would have to be entirely bloated and very expensive and 90% of the kit would never get used. For home improvement projects and general handy man type jobs this kit is going to work well for you. It would also make a great kit for a college student or renter to have on hand. Not to big to be a burden and not so small you'd be wanting for more.As for the durability, I have been quite impressed. I am generally quite hard on my drill bits and do tend to break one every now and again, but this kit is holding up great. After more than a year of occasional use (I'm not pounding on the bits every day) not only have I not broken any of the bits, but they all seem as sharp as when they were purchased and continue to make great cuts.I don't see this set wearing out any time soon, but would certainly consider it again if it ever does.

I've been using the brewer daily at work for over 6 months now and I'd like to think I have a pretty good handle on where it falls on the coffee maker spectrum.Lets start with the pros.No potSmall basket for just a single cupQuick heating (coffee in 2-3 minutes)Adjustable for use with short mugs and tall travel mugsEasy to clean basket and scoop assemblyGreat if I need something to pick me up before walking into a meetingThen the less goods.It splashes a little even when you set it to the correct hight for your mug, I've found you can fix this by propping your travel mug up on the extra coffee filter basket to limit the space between the drip head and your cupIts not the greatest coffee in the world. The coffee itself isn't bad, but it does tend to let a fair amount of sediment through that can make the end of the cup a little grittyI can't tell the difference between bold and regular brew. Maybe I'm not sophisticated enough when it comes to coffee (thus giving a gritty cup 4 stars) but I couldn't pick the bold cup from the regular cup in a blind test. I guess its not really a negative for the brewer as not all brewers have the option, but it'd be nice if it did something noticeably differentAnd end with the overall.I like this brewer and thats why I continue to use it at work. If you don't have an office pot going or if you like to use your own special roast you'll want your own brewer for your desk. If what you're looking for is an enjoyable cup of coffee to get you through your morning you'll get it here. If you're looking to recreate the cup of coffee you had while backpacking through Italy look elsewhere.For me this is what I was looking for

Zicam is a confusing group of products. (If you'd rather read only about this product skip to the bottom)Maybe I just think that because I write this review while taking a day off work with the mother of all colds, but the marketing team at Zicam seems like they're out to catch cold sufferers with buzz words. Things like ULTRA, PLUS, and original formula.Whats the difference and should you shell out extra money for the Ultra version? From what I can gather, all of the Zicam products are essentially zinc salts. Specifically zincum aceticum (ZA) and zincum gluconicum (ZG). The salts are varied in differing amounts, but not necessarily in a consistent way.My confusion is two fold:Active ingredient quantification:First is how they quantify the amount of salts. The crystals have 2X ZA and 1X ZG, but this is a homeopathic medicine and the 1X and 2X refer to dilutions (1X=1/10 and 2X=1/100). You'd think a company selling a product to a consumer in a cold induced haze would use grams or milligrams like every other company. Confusing, yes, but 1X apparently means the product contains 10% of a certain active ingredient where 2X contains just 1%. (So the crystals are 1% ZA and 10% ZG)Active ingredients among different products:The rest of my confusion deals with how the salts are varied between products. There does not seem to be consensus for what zinc salts concentration designates a product as ultra or plus. I also cannot find a trend that would suggest which "level" is likely to contain the most active ingredient for a single delivery method. For instance the original RapidMelts contained 2X ZA and 1X GA, the plus had only 1X GA, and the Ultra return to 2X ZA and 1X GA. Similar strange patterns seem to abound across all product lines where ultra and plus are often no more concentrated (and sometimes less concentrated) than original. If you want the highest amount of the active ingredients you want a product with 1X ZG and 2X ZA (the crystals do fall into this group).I'm not sure if confusing system is just poor product development, or an intentionally ambiguous marketing play directed at getting the consumer to try the latest and greatest Zicam even if the last version didn't work well. Either way its a little off putting for me.WITH ALL THAT SAID:You should buy Zicam if you believe the studies that say it works or if you trust your own anecdotal evidence, but base your specific product decision on the product delivery type or the actual ingredient concentrations and not the Buzz words (ULTRA PLUS etc.).I think Zicam shortens my colds and I bought this product when I started feeling cold symptoms mainly because I don't like the lozenges and chewable Zicam. I found the crystals to be a lot better and easier to take. The taste is actually a pretty acceptable lemon lime. Its not perfect, and it does start to develop an aftertaste after holding the crystals in your mouth for a few minutes. The logical thing to do would be to swallow it before it starts to taste bad, but it is important to hold oral Zicam products in your mouth for a while as the zinc compounds are quickly degraded in stomach acid. I didn't find that to be a problem with the crystals the way I had with the oral spray and rapid melts that not only tasted pretty bad, but gave a very strange and unpleasant texture in my mouth. I also liked that the crystals came in easy to carry single serving tubes that I can drop in a pocket with worrying about a spill or a wrapper coming open.I didn't understand the differences in active ingredients at the time of purchase, but in retrospect that would have positively affected my buying decision as these are among the products with the highest ZA and ZG concentrations).The cold I have seems to be wrapping up about as quickly as when I've used other Zicam products (regular plus and ultra) and probably faster than when I've gone without. The only difference is that the application has been more pleasant.Recap:Zicam is doing a lot of marketing to get your moneyBut the marketing really seems to be just marketing and no product substanceI'd base your purchase on the deliver method or the active ingredient concentrations and not the buzz word on the boxI prefer the crystals over other delivery so I'd buy them againUPDATE: The cold that I had while writing this review the first time ended up lasting just 4 days from start to finish. I'm not a double blind controlled study, but if you're looking for an anecdotal account of success you've got it from me.
