I like these clips a lot. I live in oregon and commute in the rain year round. When its rainy,  slipping off the pedals when charging up a hill or racing to make a light can be a real issue. These toe clips seem to have helped a lot with that.I like them over caged toe clips and clip-less pedals for basically the same reason. My job means that some days I'm in the lab, some days in the field, and some days presenting. Different situations call for different footwear and I'd rather not be locked into a special set of clip-less biking shoes and then have to carry extra shoes in my bag. Caged clips pose a similar problem in that I've found they tend to be rougher on my shoes so I'd have to pack my nice shoes and ride in a designated bike shoe to avoid scuffing them up. With these clips I don't have too much of an issue. They can still scuff up a shoe a bit, but not nearly to the extent of caged pedals.A quick word of caution:You should take a quick look at your pedals before buying. I thought these were so great on my bike that I picked up a pair for my girlfriend's bike without looking at her pedals. Apparently not all pedals are drilled and not all drilled pedals have a level mounting surface (her pedals had inset reflectors that left an uneven mounting surface and made sturdy installation impossible). If you don't have pedals made to accept a toe clip you'll need to pick up a pair of those as well if you want to go this route.Overall: 5 stars for the clip, its design, and construction. I'd buy it again.(2 stars for my apparent smarts in not looking at my pedals before purchasing)Size: L/XL shoe size men's 12/13

So why would 90+ people review a $4-5 dollar item that you would have probably picked up at a gas station without reading any reviews just because it looked interesting? How about... because its awesome!!I'm a front pocket guy (having stuff in my back pockets causes me back pain). My front pockets are usually responsible for keys, wallet, phone, pens, pencils, and anything else I happen to pick up throughout the day. In short they're stuffed, bulky, and difficult to get things out of. So I'm always looking for a way to limit the amount of stuff I have to carry in my pockets.This S-biner works great I've used it for over a year now and have not had any problems with durability or with the wire gates loosening. I generally clip one end to my belt loop (or backpack etc) and the other end holds all of my rings of keys (I've got 3 rings of a few keys each but it could hold several more). Keeping the keys on a separate ring than you use to attach/detach the S-Biner from your pants keeps them from accidentally slipping off and I have not lost any of my keys in the year I've owned the S-Biner.This configuration (keys on just half of it) also allows you to utilize the bottle opener on the key ring. The opener isn't huge and can be a little finicky and having keys in the end you're trying to open a bottle with can make it nearly impossible to use, but it does work and its a nice add on to have without adding any extra size/bulk to a standard S-Biner.The build quality of the product seems to be very good. Initially I was a bit worried that the finish would scratch and flake off exposing more of the metal beneath, but I have not experienced very much of this at all. The color is fading a little and is worn through in a few spots after more than a year, but its doing it in a very natural way and looks like a well handled piece of metal, not just something painted black and scraped up with your keys.If there was one thing that I wish was added to the S-Biner it would be a locking mechanism for at least one side of the ring. While I haven't lost any keys to date, I would feel more secure about the safety of my keys if there were a locking mechanism to secure the key side of the ring.Final Thoughts:Well builtBottle opener is a nice feature although its not what I would use if I had a full size opener on handI haven't had any gate issues in over a year of ownershipWould like to see a locking mechanism on future versionsStill the best S-Biner for keys and with some added functionality which is why I continue to use and recommend it

I am reviewing a pair of these that came with an iPhone 5. They're nice and certainly an upgrade from what used to come with iPhones and iPods, but if I was going to spend money on a new set of earbuds I wouldn't buy these.The Fit (comfort and noise isolation):Certainly improved. The new design is more natural feeling in your ear and because the buds are not perfectly circular they do hug the contours of your ear a bit better and they do stay in somewhat better. They aren't totally secure (at least in my ear) and they provide little in the way of noise isolation. I know these aren't noise canceling and very few ear buds are, but the soft plastic earbuds offered by many manufacturers (Panasonic RPHJE120A In-Ear Headphone, Blue, JVC HAFX1X Headphone Xtreme-Xplosivs, Klipsch Image S4i Premium Noise-Isolating Headset with 3-Button Apple Control) at all price ranges do provide some degree of noise isolation and (again at least for my ears) hold much tighter than these do. I'm not saying these can't fit your ear perfectly, but even under the best circumstances they won't seal out sound.The Sound:Again the sound in these are much superior to those in the original earbuds, but not better than whats on the market. If you're serious about sound you may want to aim at a higher price product from klipsch (Klipsch Image S4i Premium Noise-Isolating Headset with 3-Button Apple Control) Ultimate Ears(Ultimate Ears TripleFi 10 Noise Isolating Earphones) or another high end brand. If you are more or less happy with the sound quality that you've gotten from your apple earbuds in the past then you're going to be happy with these and will even get a little boost in terms of clarity, bass, and decreased distortion. But if you're looking for roughly that level of sound quality you  don't need to spend $30. I'd check out the MEE M6 ear buds if you're looking for a slightly lower price and as good or better sound quality. (MEElectronics M6P-BK Sports Sound-Isolating In Ear Headphones with Microphone/Remote for iPod, iPhone and Smartphones (Black)). If you're looking for more of a bargain than that look at any of the sub $10 sets available on amazon.Call Clarity/mic remote:I admit I don't make a ton of calls. I have played around with making calls and using Siri through the microphone on these and it works well, but earbud remotes and mics aren't anything special anymore. This one doesn't do anything that the one on any set of earbuds with a 3 button mic can't do everything special about it is in the software in the iPhone so this isn't a feature you should pay more for just because its from apple. Additionally there are some really great bluetooth and wired call devices designed for making hands free calls if thats something you do a lot of. I don't know enough to comment on specific devices, but would look to a specialty product and not here if that was your priority.Overall Design: They're a good looking set of earbuds and do "go" with the iPhone and new devices. If thats important to you then by all means stop reading and buy this pair. You know what you're getting and its exactly what you want.Wrap upFine earbudsNothing SpecialAn improvement in sound and fit over old earbudsBut not a big enough improvement to justify the priceIf I was looking for a replacement (i.e. earbuds that I wasn't getting for free with another purchase) I wouldn't use/buy these3/5 stars

This is a nice little case. Its not fancy. Its not made of exotic materials. Its not seamless, but it will protect your phone from scratches and dents and it doesn't add much bulk.I've ordered one of the book/wallet cases, but it won't ship until november so I picked this up to protect my phone between now and then and then to protect my phone when I don't feel like lugging around the full wallet case.Its a nice TPU case. I love these newer materials. I still remember the first silicone cases that used to be almost a little tacky and would pull your pocket inside out when you pulled out your phone. Those are long gone. TPU plastic cases are slick and don't tug on fabric at all. The black gloss TPU isn't perfect. Its slick looking and looks great especially when its clean, but it does collect fingerprints like no other. It also has a slight seam where the edge connects to the front lip and back panel. Its not very noticeable, but it is there and if you're a perfectionist it might bug you.The fit of the case is very good. The phone does not have room to shift around and the ports are all fully accessible. Some reviewers apparently received cases with just a single oval outlining the bottom microphones, headphone jack, and power jack. I did not have this issue and the case I received has 3 outlined cutouts in the bottom as in the picture.The volume control buttons (up and down) are covered by the side band and are, while outlined, are more or less flush with the case. I was afraid that this might make them a little more difficult to access, but they still seem to be relatively easy to press. The mute button has its own cutout and is very easy to press. Some reviewers have commented on the camera cutout being "wrong" because it exposes a small amount of the aluminum back. I don't see this as a defect and suspect it was done to provide more room for the camera and flash which might prevent flash reflection off the glossy case.Overall I think its a great little case. It won't end up being my every day case, but thats only because I wanted some functionality that a "normal" case won't provide. If all I wanted was a normal case I would certainly be able to overlook the very slight seams and finger prints given the price of this case.TL:DRNice case, slick look (when clean)Fit is greatDoesn't add much bulkPorts are accessibleSmall seam around the edgesDoes collect fingerprintsGreat value caseI can confidently recommend it

This isn't a small switch. Its probably about as long as a dollar bill is wide (the short way), but its sturdy, made of quality materials, and is relatively easy to install.I picked up an old lamp at goodwill that came with a switch up near the bulb. With a shade on it was difficult to get to the switch so I added this product on the cord to make switching the light on and off easy. As I mentioned before its rather large, but I rather like that. It makes it easy to locate when fumbling in the dark, easier to install (imagine trying to fit a highish gauge lamp cord into a tiny click wheel switch), and generally more sturdy (which is good because mine sits near the floor and has been stepped on once or twice).To install you UNPLUG YOUR POWER CORD and cut one of the two wires in it. Then you make a second cut to remove a small segment of this wire and strip the last 1/2 inch on each side of the cut wire. Remove the screws that hold the switch together and lay the intact wire through the switch. The cut wire is then wrapped around two metal mounting posts, and the switch is put back together. It takes about 4 minutes if you have a screw driver and a wire stripper.Overall:A sturdy switch for replacing an old switch or adding a switch to most home appliancesRather large, but not unattractively so (IMHO)Should handle most household gauge wiresEasy to install with a screwdriver and wire stripperAnd most importantly an easy product for me to recommend

Bar tending can be fun and if you set out bar tending tools at a cocktail party you'll get people trying their hand who've never mixed a true drink in their lives. It can give you some insight into which tools are well designed to do a job and which ones were designed to look good on your bar.Well designed products are easy to use even for people that don't really know what they're doing because they've been designed in a way that makes them more difficult to use wrong than right.I've seen a lot of strainers that come with long handles and look great sitting in a crock with your handled jigger and special stirring spoons, but watching people use them makes you realize how poorly designed they are. The long handle means people hold the strainer far from the glass. Not only does that make it a two handed job, but the long lever arm on the strainer makes it less stable and makes them more likely to slip it off and spill their drink.A good strainer should be difficult to accidentally have slip off your drink when the spring is engaged inside the rim of the shaker glass. But the long handled strainers provide less of a hint about which side should face the glass because you can hold them just as easily with the spring out and the spring in.The Oxo strainer doesn't have a handle (well at least not more than a nub) and the finger rest shows the user where they should be putting pressure to hold the strainer to the glass. By directing the user to face the spring into the glass and place pressure in the middle of the strainer to hold it to the glass, the Oxo strainer becomes much more difficult to use wrong (trying to hold it on by the handle nub would be incredibly cumbersome and turning it backwards would hide the finger indentation) than it is to use right. In my opinion thats just good design.Beyond the design the strainer seems to be made from quality materials. The metal on the strainer's base is closer to the thickness of a bleacher seat or old tanker desk than it is to a tin can (laugh but I've held some flimsy strainers). The spring is stiff so it holds tight to your glass and holds up to being removed for cleaning. The finger pad is heat resistant and seems to hold up fine in the dishwasher.Overall its a great little strainer.Its easy to useIts made from materials that will lastand when someone eventually nabs it from a party as a souvenir I'll be back to buy another

I like this mount a lot. Its been installed in my car for over 4 years and the glue is still holding up despite the temperature swings from freezing winters to hot summer days parked in the sun. I bought it because I wasn't satisfied with the suction mount that would fail occasionally causing the garmin to fall off the dash. This seemed dangerous for both the driver and the garmin. The mount will fit all standard garmins (street pilot, nuvi, etc) and I've used it with a few different models over the years. They all mount securly to the ball mount although some of them did tend to sag over time (this was due to the female mount on the garmin loosening not a failure of this product).Two things I've found is that you should really follow instructions to get the most out of this product. If you are having mounting issues it could be because of a coating on your dash (any plastic cleaning/conditioning product) so you'll need to clean the dash before mounting. I would recommend washing with a drop of dawn soap, rinsing with water, and then rinsing again with rubbing alcohol. The soap will cut oils, the water picks up anything thats water soluble, and the alcohol will pick up alcohol soluble solvents and dry more quickly and fully. When you apply the mount I would put the glue pad down and stick on the mount base and then leave it for a day or two. Giving the glue pad a chance to cure a bit seems to provide a more secure mount. Then go ahead and put on your garmin.Once installed, be sure to unlock the use the button when you rotate the mount. If you force it the plastic can crack. I forgot to mention this to a passenger who was going to enter an address for me. The plastic rim that holds the mounting pole in cracked  and the garmin was no longer secure. It was easy enough to fix with a bit of super glue, but its part of the reason I gave 4 stars and not 5. Yes it was my fault, but I think the locking mechanism should have been designed a little more robustly or should be slightly more obvious so your passengers are more likely to use it correctly.Overall:Sturdy mount (more sturdy if you install it properly)Potentially safer than the suction mount for both the driver and the garminInstall it correctly and use it correctly and it will last you a long time

About 3 years ago I was having back, knee, ankle, and foot pain so I went to see a podiatrist. He convinced me that the insoles that came with my shoes weren't providing enough support. In his opinion the best thing I could do was get a pair of custom insoles made. At the time I had insurance that would cover it so I did. They were hard plastic and molded to my feet. They fit well and did fix my pain problems. I switched them out every time I switched shoes for over 2 years. I was tired of that. I wanted insoles to put in each pair of shoes I owned so I bought a few pairs of these.I was pretty scared that the pain was going to come back. I couldn't imagine that a $10 pair of insoles would ward off pain the way my $300 (before insurance) pair would, but I have been pleasantly surprised. I've been using these for about 6 months and haven't had any of my former pain return.These don't provide the support of a molded prescription insole. In fact they aren't even as thick as some of the other off the shelf insoles I've tried, but they're better than the thin foam insoles that come in my shoes (mostly Adidas) and apparently they're enough for me. These do provide some (somewhat malleable) arch support and the heal cup does work to absorb shock when I'm on my feet all day.The recommendation I can make here is two fold. First these insoles are far better than what comes in your standard sneakers and they can provide pain relief. Second, if you've been sold on high end insoles but never tried (or haven't tried in several years) the off the shelf insoles, do yourself a favor and find out whether you need to be spending that money. You may find that off the shelf insoles are all you need.Final thoughts:These are reasonable off the shelf insoles for a very reasonable priceThey aren't prescription insolesThey aren't the $70 off the shelf insolesBut they're a quality product that are going to be perfect for a lot of people

I see all the negative reviews and I have to wonder if we're reviewing the same thing.  I bought mine for $20 at Bath and Body because I didn't see it on Amazon until after I'd purchased it there, but it looks the same.  The UPC on mine is 752356794712.  It is called the "AquaRug Carpet for Your Shower!"  Size 29.5 x 17.25.  I'll try to add a picture of the label/box so you can see that it's the same thing.My husband is 100% disabled due to Agent Orange, Vietnam.  He is very unstable (Parkinson's and end-stage heart failure).  I have tried a ton of  bath mats and they all slip and/or get very gross.  I bought this one IN SPITE of it saying, "As seen on TV."  I think the TV things are usually junk.I was concerned because, as others have pointed out, the suction cups don't work all that well.  BUT--at least on my 60-year-old cast iron/porcelain tub, the mat doesn't slip at all.  In addition,we have (adult) girls with hair that clogs the drain, but this goes right over the top of the drain and traps the hair. I was afraid that the hair would get in the little holes, but it doesn't.  I was really afraid that dirt would get in and it would be nasty.  It isn't.Here is our daily routine:After the last shower, I take an old toothbrush and run it over the mat.  That picks up all the stray hairs from the females in the family (my husband is bald).  I do this to the front and back.  I then hang up the mat on our bar (the bar that my husband uses to steady himself). It takes maybe 20 seconds at the most (I actually tried to time it by counting!). It dries out very well in time for the next showers 24 hours later.Several times a month, I throw it in my front loader with some bleach, if I remember.  Otherwise, it just goes in the regular wash and stays clean.For us, it's been fantastic.  I was so afraid that something might happen to it that I bought a second one to have "just in case."  It's the only mat I've felt is safe for my husband.  I don't know if it would slip on fiberglass, but on our cast-iron tub it is fantastic.

This subject fascinates me--what happens when identical twins are adopted and raised separately (usually without their adoptive parents' knowledge or consent).  I had expected a fairy-tale-type book where someone else writes a sweet story about the two girls.  Wrong.  This is written first-hand by each twin.  Unlike some reviewers, I wasn't put off by the writing itself.  I thought it was good, and from the heart.The book starts before the women know of each other's existences, and then we are with them as they learn some disturbing facts about their history. The readers also learn unconscionable truths about what went on in times past in the name of "research."  Many of us know about the Tuskeegee Study involving adults, but were not aware that even newborns were subjected to that type of unbelievably unethical activity.The book is written, as I said, in the first person.  One twin will write a few paragraphs or pages, and the next one will.  For me, I would have preferred to have separate fonts or italics so I could more easily differentiate which twin was speaking.  I LOVED the pictures, and wish there had been more of them.  I constantly referred back and forth to the photos so I could really get a sense of who was speaking/writing.If you enjoy non-fiction written in a very personal way, this book may be for you. The book is an easy read (that's a good thing--it kept my interest).  At the end of the story I almost felt as if I knew the women and I would love to meet them in person.  I have a son who is adopted and who has been diagnosed with bipolar disease and schizophrenia. He is doing very well, but we really wish we could know more about his birthmother without having to pay a fortune to find information.  When we adopted him as an 8-week-old we were only told that his birthmother had some "learning disabilities" or something equally benign.  Decades later, we would love to know what happened to her.If the subject matter seems interesting to you I really think you'll enjoy it.

My husband, a Vietnam vet with Agent Orange Parkinson's and heart disease, has end-stage heart failure and must be monitored daily.  His blood pressure is extremely low (ranges from around 72/50 to 90/60).  I also have low blood pressure, but don't need to check mine.  When I got this today I decided to try it on me first.  Following the instructions exactly (as well as the suggestions by some reviewers), I lined it up correctly on my wrist.  I took numerous readings throughout the day and my systolic BP consistently was around 30 points above average.More importantly, my *husband's* readings were also 30 points higher than they really were.  We verified this and were shocked by the inaccuracies.  It is crucial to know my husband's BP, and if it's showing a higher number like 110/65, we are lulled into a false sense of security.Perhaps this type of unit doesn't work for people with low blood pressure, but I wish I'd known that.  We were very disappointed, to say the least, and are returning it.

This is a book about growing up in Duluth, Minnesota, yet it encompasses so much more.  Michael Fedo manages to appeal to those of us who didn't grow up there.  He offers thought-provoking vignettes of his interesting Midwestern Italian-Baptist-Swedish background (completely foreign to this reviewer who was born and raised in Southern California, and is Hispanic, raised Catholic).  Fedo is able to bring out the commonalities to which many of us who are from his era can relate. In addition, Mr. Fedo points out the racial and socio-economic imperfections of the time.If I were still teaching sociology at the college level, I would consider assigning this as a textbook.  Each chapter could easily be used as a point of discussion.  Oh--I should mention that it's great fun to read!

Delightful book.  This is the third one I've read from Mike Fedo, and I've not been disappointed.  You don't have to have grown up in Duluth to appreciate it.  People who like homespun, thoughtful vignettes of life in the middle 20th century should enjoy this book.PS--If you are Italian, Midwestern, Baptist, or Swedish, or any combination of those, you'll probably relate to it even more (I'm none of the above and loved it!).

I am 5'8" and don't enjoy bending over to push my husband's wheelchair.  I contacted the Invacare company which made my husband's wheelchair to see if they made extensions for his chair (they don't).  I saw these and decided to take a chance. I was warned by Invacare not to trust anything that just clamped on because it could slip.  I went to the actual Wright Stuff website and looked at the directions online so I could get an idea of how these worked.They arrived sooner than I expected, which was very nice.  The directions were not hard to follow.  The actual welding looks a bit messy (the handle to the clamp), but it's very sturdy.  I installed the handles and was very pleased with the strength of them.  You'll need a Phillips head screwdriver and some pliers to hold the bottom nut as you tighten the screws.I've only had the extensions a week, but my back feels the difference.  I will probably have to tighten the screws periodically, but the extensions seem very good.  The actual hard plastic handles (very solid plastic) are better than what came with the wheelchair. The rest of the extension is made with extremely strong steel.  I like that the handles are easily cleaned, unlike the porous spongy-type material on the wheelchair's own handles (I'm a bit of a germaphobe, and the spongy-type handle material doesn't really get clean).People have stopped me and asked how I got such tall handles.  Too bad I don't have any business cards for the company!Hope all of this makes sense. :)

I love these--but I'm not using it for kids!  My husband is 100% disabled due to Parkinson's Disease, major heart disease, and early dementia (all caused by Agent Orange/Vietnam, according to the government).  I have him do puzzles every day and it works so well.  I pick the puzzles very carefully based on quality, physical ease of use, and difficulty.As a former paid educator, I can tell you that these particular double-sided-type puzzles would also work well for kids in independent learning stations in the classroom or at home.  I bought four different sets of them and have liked all of them.  Don't necessarily go by grade level or age recommendations.  Go by ability. It's better (in my opinion) to buy something which might be a little too easy at first for a special needs student than to cause frustration.I'll be using this review for other puzzles I've purchased, so don't think you're seeing double if you read almost the same words.  I have bought many, many fantastic puzzles for my husband on Amazon (and some at local stores).  We started out with 35 piece Ravensburger puzzles and are now at 48 piece non-Ravensburger ones.  Educational Insights and Ravensburger are the best quality.  Unfortunately, the only 48 piece puzzles I've found are at the Dollar Stores ("Cardinal Industries"), and the quality is not the same as Educational Insights or Ravensburger.  Our next move are the 60 piece Ravensburger puzzles--onward and upward!

My dog developed digestion issues and this particular product is the only one he can consistently tolerate.  I have found it online for better prices, so shop around to save on shipping costs.  It's also available from vets, but usually at a higher price.  It comes in a canned form, but that is more of a hassle for me.  Both product forms are good, but the dry one tends to be easier to handle on a daily basis.The quality of the dog food has been great.  This particular formula has worked well with my dog's problems and has really been worth the money.  IF you buy from your vet's office, go to the Hill website and sign up for coupons.  You'll get a few which you can usually use at the doctor's office.  After you stop getting coupons, then you can consider ordering the product online if the cost is too high at the vet.

Being a Downton Abbey fan, and having spent time in my youth in England, I anticipated that this would be a fun book.  I was not disappointed.  If you want something deep and profound, this probably isn't it.  If you want something fun--yet with its fair share of insightful observations, you'll probably enjoy this.  Having been in England six times from 1963-1980, and having grown up with a British mum and grandmother, I related to many of the things she said.This is a very easy and entertaining book to read.  It reminds me of Margaret Powell Books--the "lite" version (if you haven't read Margaret Powell, check her out.  She was the basis for "Upstairs, Downstairs" and ultimately "Downton Abbey" by osmosis.  Try to read several of her books, if possible).  Mollie Moran's book added to the knowledge I gained from Powell's books and was the type of book which could be put down and then picked up later without losing a train of thought."Minding the Manor" gives us a brief look at ramifications from WWI (Mollie's father), along with the expectation of servitude for 14-year-olds. We watch Mollie grow and develop into a beautiful young lady.  The book glosses quickly over the rest of her life, but that's okay.  It wasn't meant to be about Mollie as a wife and mother. It's Mollie as she rises from scullery maid to cook.I'm a docent at an American mansion which was built at the turn of the century.  I use all of these types of books to help in my presentations.  Even though they are set in England, they give a glimpse into the mindset of the wealthy and their servants at that time (though in "my" mansion, the family did not believe in drawing such extensive cultural lines!). If you read "Call the Midwife" as well, you'll really get a picture of England in transition.  Mollie died quite recently in the spring of 2014 at the active age of 97, still cooking and enjoying life.  What a fantastic woman.Find this book at the library (or buy your own copy) and enjoy!

I really like it, but it's unusual.  I mean, it goes on one color and changes to another.  I like both colors so I don't mind the change.  It also goes on shiny, but then 'stains' the lips and the shine kind of leaves. For me, it lasts a long time, but doesn't last as the shiny color I put on.  Despite that, I actually bought three of the same ones (one in my purse and one at home, and one for my 19-year-old daughter also loves it.I bought mine at Ulta (expensive!) because the sales clerk said she really loved it.  An Amazon reviewer mentioned that the smell was kind of 'off' and I agree.  It's not the normal lipstick smell I'm used to, but maybe they don't put additional fragrance in it--I don't know.For me, I love it and it's all I use.  BUT, I gave it four stars because others may not be pleased that it changes colors.  I have taken two pictures (before and after) of my lips when I first put it on and a few hours later.  I hope I can upload them.I can't, but I'll keep trying.

As I've mentioned on all my other reviews - I have ordered multiple decals from Yadda Yadda Design for my office and home.  The decals go on super easily, have highly detailed instructions and tester decals, and are great conversation pieces.  Plus, Yadda Yadda has fantastic customer service.  Highly recommend!

I have ordered five different wall decals from this company (including the girl frisking soldier).  They go on easily and are very high quality, and the company has fantastic customer service.  highly recommend!

I love body pillows, but don't get this pillow if you have a queen-size (or smaller) bed that you share with another person.  This is a high-quality pillow - almost TOO high quality.  It is the size of an adult and doesn't squish down at all when you hug it.  I returned it because it was just too big.

Great ring for someone who can pick out a wedding ring in thirty seconds and doesn't want to spend more than $20 (*cough* like my husband).  I worked in fine jewelry sales for years and as far as I can tell, this is genuine Tungsten.  Why spend more?

I have ordered five different full-size wall decals from this company (including these fancy rats).  I am extremely impressed with the quality of the decals, the detail of the instructions, and the company's customer service.  Highly recommend!

SHORT VERSIONPros: Incredibly moving, crazy connection with the characters, can't-put-it-down-before-2AM kind of bookCons: Too short, ending a little abrupt (but fits with the overall tone of the book).LONG VERSION:I can't stand most "Christian literature" (i.e., literature written by a self-professed Christian).  It's fine when you want to waste your time on something saccharine-sweet and easily digestible (kind of like throwing on an episode of How I Met Your Mother), but when it comes to the real world and changing your life or worldview, it's basically useless.A friend recommended that I read The Other Side of Silence and I ignored him for a solid four months for this very reason.  I work in the prison system, and find it hard to swallow books that have no idea how the gritty underbelly (i.e. poverty, addiction, crime) of the real world work.I finally broke down and bought the book and devoured it within a day.  This is a book that sticks with you and makes you think about things LONG after you put it down.  It's the type of book that needs to be read several times.  Like other people have mentioned, the plot runs something along the lines of Crash or Babel, where everyone is interconnected.  It follows people who are desperate in some way, and hear nothing but silence from God - until something comes from the other side of that silence.Make no mistake: this book is not preachy.  The way that the author describes various situations makes me wonder if she's an alcoholic, illegal immigrant, a rich doctor, a seven-year-old child, a yuppie marketing executive, and recently found out she's gay all at the same time, because that's how well she describes what is happening in the minds of all of those characters.  To that end, the author does not pull punches.  She - and her characters - live in the *real world*, and experience God in the *real world*.My only qualm with the book is that it felt too short and ended rather abruptly.  I understand the artistic reasons for ending where it did, and I have no idea what I would have liked to have seen instead (there's a reason I'm not a writer).  This was just my personal opinion and didn't take away from the book in any way.I've already given away one copy, and the friend to whom I gave that book is now buying copies for HER friends.  I just finished it, and I can't wait to read it again.  It's that good.Highly recommend.

Pros: Bass, bass, bass.  GOOD bass.  Not scratchy bass.  GOOD bass.  Decent mids and highs.  Seemingly well-made.Cons: Not as clear as, say, the ATH-M50 cans.  Microphone useless for Galaxy Note 2.Overall: Wow.------I.  Love.  Music.  I listen mostly to hip-hop and rap, but also enjoy rock, classical, pop, folk, jazz, metal, etc.  I listen to music for about 8-10 hours per day.  I know nothing about frequencies, mixing, or how the sound actually gets to my ears - but I know what sounds good and feels good.I've been searching for the perfect pair of headphones for close to five years.  I can't do over- or on-ear because headbands hurt my head after a few hours, and I can't do earbuds unless they have compatible Comply tips.  I've used Klipsch Image S4i headphones for a few years, but finally got fed up with the poor build quality and the fact that they fall apart within a few months of heavy use.After researching for months and ordering/buying/trying/returning several pairs (including the ATH-M50s, Bose OE2s, and another set of Klipsh'), I tried the V-Pulse based on review from Cnet, Head-Fi, and other random dudes on the internet.  I wasn't expecting to get better sound than my S4s - I would have settled for similar sound if I could just get better quality cables.I am completely blown away by these headphones.  I stayed up an hour later than normal listening to music the night I got them (and nothing gets in the way of me and my sleep!).  The last time I heard bass like this - deep, powerful, shake-your-bones, not scratchy or rumbly bass - was at a Nas and Lauryn hill show.  I'm telling you, you have to hear it to believe it - I have NO idea how the people at Velodyne manage to make this incredible sound come out of earbuds.  Bose speaker systems sound like the Sony Walkman stock headphones of the 1990s compared to what I'm hearing from these.There is negligible sacrifice in the mids and highs for this sound.  I don't notice a difference in the mids and highs between these and the Klipsch S4s (or any other earbuds), but they're definitely less clear than the ATH-M50 cans.  I'm not sure that it's even fair to compare clarity in earbuds and cans, though - especially cans made for mixing.I've been primarily listening to rap to get the most out of these beauties, but I have taken bouts with classical, podcasts, folk, pop, etc., to test out the sound.  It all sounds wonderful.They come with 8 extra sets of tips, a clip for your shirt, and a nice hard case. I have no idea how long the cord is, but it hasn't caused me any troubles.Bottom line: these are so amazing that I'm thinking of getting a second pair just in case (on my public defender I-can-barely-afford-food salary!).

This isn't a case that's going to protect your Galaxy from some sort of natural disaster or alien invasion (heh...get it...galaxy...alien...whatever.).  If you're looking for something that will really protect your phone, go for OtterBox.This is a great basic case, though.  This particular color is a beautiful Tiffany blue and it snapped right on and comes off easily.I will note that one reviewer said that her case fell off when she dropped her phone.  She took off a few stars for that, thinking that it reflected the case quality.  However, my engineer brother and boyfriend both say that this is what a snap-on case is supposed to do.  If it can't absorb the shock in the case itself (i.e., if it's not an OtterBox), then it is engineered to come off the phone easily.  That way the shock is absorbed by the case coming off the phone.  I will also note that I failed high school math and science so I have no idea if that's actually true, but I dropped my iphone with a snap-on case onto concrete countless times and never had a problem - so clearly something is working!

Good: Sound qualityBad: DurabilityTip: Get the Comply memory foam tips!Longer version for those who don't mind reading...I'm not exactly an audiophile and I don't understand a bit of science behind music or what the frequencies are.  However, I listen to music about 8-10 hours per day so I know what sounds good and what doesn't - and what's comfortable and what's not.These have excellent sound - especially for the price.  I bought my first pair when they were in the $100 range, and even at that price range they were a steal.  The lows are low, the highs are high, and the mids don't get lost.  The included eartips were uncomfortable, but I hate ALL tips with all headphones, so I always replace them with Comply tips - extremely comfortable memory foam.What's the problem, then? The build quality.  I had two pairs break on me, and it's inconvenient to send them into Klipsch.  The warranty is good - two years - but you're without headphones for the several weeks that it takes to ship them and get them back.  When I got back one of my pairs, it was still broken.  The cables fray, the sound cuts out of one ear or the other, and the mic buttons stop working.I did use mine a lot, but I almost always kept them in the case.  The cables are simply very thin and unimpressive.I switched to Velodyne V-Pulse after months of researching new headphones, and don't regret it a bit (though the price increase hurts).

Maybe I have freakishly small ears, but I have the hardest time finding tips that actually fit and sound good.  I have Klipsch S4-i headphones, and the smallest tips worked well for me but were kind of uncomfortable.  When I lost one, I happened upon the Comply website and decided to try them out.  I got the smallest size in a 3-pack for somewhere in the arena of $15.Sound quality: five stars.  I'm seriously impressed.  The noise isolation is great, the basses are low and the trebles are high.Comfort: five stars.  I love deep sound, so I shove 'em in my ears like earplugs.  They only start to ache after at least six hours of continuous listening.Physical quality: three stars.  I've had them about a month, and the tips are starting to rip and lose their form.  I will say that I don't treat them gently - I twist and pinch the foam to get it deeply in my ear like an earplug.Bottom line: For about $5/month (probably less if you don't mangle the tips like I do), you can greatly improve upon the original sound and comfort of your earbuds.  I highly recommend them.
I would prefer a nice soft cotton, but for the price this is a nice sweater. Smaller fit than expected, but it stretches enough.
I expected this to be a skimpy cut but it actually is a generous cut. Next time I will buy my true size.
Very convenient to store and use when the water rises around the back door.
Dogs love these and they are easy for my 20 pound dog to hold as he chews. No odor or mess.
Nice looking boots, stiff leather but softening with Lexol and wear. The lacing improves the fit. I added an arch support.
A good read. This book is more of the same... I think if you buy one of Pollan's books then you probably know what you need to know after you've read one of them.
Fun, fast paced action comedy. Better than any other action comedy we have seen this year. Funnier, not as gross as most of the guy flicks in this genre -- does that make this a chick flick?

After 2 weeks I am not sure this makes any difference. One dog lost hers the first week, so I am putting another on her because she is the needy barker in the family and we want her to feel calmer. The other less needy dog has been eating less...not what we wanted. But the scent is delightful.
Easily assembled. This holds my big TV and DVD player below. Love the swivel.
A good guide to eating food that actually nourishes with minimal planet damage.
Innovative, beautiful music.Love the combo of cello and piano.
This is the best eye drop for irritated eyes. No dryness, no redness, just refreshed vision.

I bought these in a brown size 8 (I wear a 7.5 shoe but go up with boots so I can wear winter socks). They fit very well, just a bit tight in one toe that is always a little problem for me. I love the look, expensive and yet practical. Good arch support, good soft-enough soles for long walks. Going to buy another pair in different color.
Very lightweight, expect it could break easily but so far it is doing the job as I plant bulbs.
Excellent quality, would buy again.
Well made, do not fit my particular faucet.
Excellent quality. I use these on bushes, and my roses.
These wood toothbrushes look nice, so I leave them out for company. But they are not that great to hold and angle for effective brushing.
Very nice work gloves. I use them for gardening, dealing with stickery plants.
Worked fine to power my Vizio TV, although it came with just the cord, no accessories.
Great narrow spade. I use it for weeding. Stick the spade straight into the earth to detach the weed root, then lift the weed with my hand to dump it into the garbage. Does a fast, effective job.
Mandy's voice is superb. She renders these songs as they were meant to be sung. I wish she had more albums.
Great work gloves. I use them for trimming roses.
Very lightweight, so I hope it does support as advertised. One of my dogs likes it, the other does not. So I think I will not buy a second as I originally expected to do.
Fine for the price. I added an arch orthotic and can wear these several hours. They are a good look with jeans.
Lightweight, good for a night of club dancing. I expected this to be cut very small, but it actually is cut like US sizes, so I need not have bought up so many sizes. An XL really is an XL!

I returned these shoes because the tops of the boot shaft, especially near the zipper, really scratched my legs badly. There was zero protection, unlike any other boot I've bought. The discomfort and distraction made them unwearable for me. Too bad, because the design was exactly what I wanted.
Got our most of the stains. Worth a try when grocery store sprays don't work.
Terrific eye drops, esp. for post-LASIK and other eye surgeries. And just plain old age dryness.
I hired an electrician to replace an existing light. This would not work at all. He said it's a dud, return it. The seller never responded.

Love this tiny thing. I am an adult user, so did not apply the stickers. The other Waterpik I have takes up too much space and the badly designed storage lid constantly falls off. I only use one flossing tip in a small mouth, and can only tolerate medium power. So with our very limited counter space this is ideal - even though lime green would not be my first or second choice for the color! The expensive adult Waterpik now is stored in a cupboard.
Easy to assemble, good size for a big man. But it lacks the strong seat cushioning we prefer and the tilt feature is not great.
Not as clever as I remembered. But nice nostalgic.
Well made.
Well made, good on chair legs that move across carpeting or other flooring.
Good, protective, easy to see through. Tight fit protects against sparks while weed burning.
Good quality and value. We use in doorways and cracks against crawling insects.
Powerful loppers for good sized branches. Easy to use and well made.
Burns weeds quickly but you still have to remove the weeds a few days later when they are truly dead. And maintenance is essential. Using this every two weeks to avoid toxic sprayig.

So far this recharges my phone efficiently, even in its case -- Not as quickly as my Samsung fast wall charger, but good enough. It is easy to situate the phone on the base so that the tiny little light changes from red to blue, indicating a charge in process. I am concerned about how hot the phone gets so I try to remove the phone from this device as soon as fully charged. (BTW, the instructions read as if translated with a Chinese-to-English program, not edited...but still, fairly easy to understand.)
Large gloves are well made, well priced, great for garden tasks.
This is well made, but it is hard to blow out a light amount of diatomaceous earth -- often spurts out bigger bursts than needed.
We use this with our Red Dragon weed burner. Very protective, and adjusts easily to fit a small woman or a big man. Pockets are small, but better than nothing.

Easy to assemble, but the design could use improvement. The belt doesn't hold the propane canister very securely, and the wheels have a tough time on rougher terrain.  Also, it would be great if the dolly could also hold a fire extinguisher, since propane tanks and fire do go together,

These take a chunk out of our grocery budget, but...Our dogs love these better than any other kind of bully stick or rawhide chew we have tried.  They are not very smelly, thank goodness. Best of all, our smaller mutt is able to hold these spirals upright and chew on them easily, which was impossible with the bigger straight bully sticks.  Our big dog consumes one in under 30 minutes, but the 25 lb. dog makes his last for a day, going back to it every couple of hours.
Hardy big gloves. We use these with our Red Dragon weed burner.

This fits my Galaxy S6 very snugly, I just replaced an equally nice leather case with this case because this version allows me to talk with the cover closed (see cutout at top), and this case is slightly smaller, allowing it to fit in my car console's stand-up slot. I also like the red color. Unfortunately, the magnet in this clasp is surprisingly weak, so I am careful to keep just my license, one credit card, and a $20 bill in the wallet. I also wish the license holder had a clear cover on it like my previous case, because then I could keep the license in it sometimes instead of having to always pull it out.
Strong hardy rake, well priced.
I am online looking to buy something compact for travel, but much more effective. This does not get the food bits out of my teeth like the big machine does because the flow is not strong enough.
So far, this works well.
Very nice, heavy duty dog bowls. Mine came in a blue color rather than red, which still looks great.

I bought this wallet case i brown for another phone, now am buying for my new Galaxy S6. It is excellent quality -- the iPhone case my husband bought cost over 2x as much and is very similar. This has a clever design -- the clear display for the driver's license has a hole in the center so you can easily slide out the card when needed. No more struggle or chipped nail polish. I only wish they offered red or blue.

I bought this lamp in white from another source, and love it. Now I am buying the black for my husband. I consider these lamps to be kinda ugly compared to the classic stainless steel desk lamps these are replacing. But the lighting level variety, low heat emission, constantly visible thermometer/calendar/ clock, as well as the rotating flexibility, won me over. This is the best work light I have ever had after decades of buying desk lamps.
Great cables, especially good for traveling -- I tend to leave behind the black cables in rental cars but this color stands out so I notice it and remember to take it with me.

I got the medium for my size 8 feet and the sleeves are a bit tighter than expected, but not painfully so. I think the compression helps my arches and ankles, but I learned to wear only in the day. At night, the compression feels increasingly uncomfortable. (Not so with elbow compression sleeves, which make my arms feel better in the am when I've worn them all night.)
Good value, and little waste with these smaller size containers. The glue works well to keep a nail together with a light application.

The menthol is cooling but there is nothing exceptional about this pain cream when used on my hands and feet. I have arthritis in 4 fingers, and two toes, and none of them felt much better after rubbing in this cream. Worse, I accidentally rubbed my eyebrow and the cream slid into my eye and stung like crazy. Be sure to wash off very well before touching other sensitive spots.

This works great. It recharges quickly! But it is heavier than the Lenovo brand that came with my laptop, and every ounce counts when on travel. So this stays plugged in at home and the original travels with me.
Good value for everyday shoes. Replaceable insole allows me to use my own orthotic.
Beautiful and strong shoes for trail hiking. Like the replaceable insole because I use a stronger arch support orthotic.

A somewhat tough read that covers the evolution of rhetoric from Aristotle to the present. Olmsted explains how rhetoric develops topics around which arguments are made and built, these topics growing and evolving over time as the world changes.  She touches upon the usual triumvirate of rhetoric – pathos, ethos, and logos – and how each is applied differently and to varying effect by various authors and historical figures.  She explains the differences between Cicero and Machiavelli, for example, in dealing with rhetorical issues.  It is at times difficult to keep track of who said what, but it is fascinating how a seemingly academic and even somewhat esoteric topic can guide think and have an historical impact (Machiavelli’s The Prince in shaping reaction and policy as city-states developed in Europe).  Olmsted also turns to literature and covers how Milton and Austen used rhetorical means and strategies to achieve their ends, one to grapple with the reality of multiple theological world views after the reformation, the other to explore the challenges facing women in British society as they attempted to assert their individuality in a world changed by industry.  Olmsted wraps up nicely with discussion of the role rhetoric played in bringing reconciliation to post-apartheid South Africa, and how rhetoric can drive legal analysis.  This latter part is particularly fascinating, as Olmsted describes how statutory ambiguity allows for development of legal topics over time.

A good book that covers the various ways that creativity via insights can come into being.  The authors provide many examples to show how insight moments can happen, including a lot of material on specific brain states that support their claims.  The most valuable chapter is the last one, where they list and summarize the various techniques and conditions needed to stimulate insight moments, like separating from your problem by distracting yourself with a walk, for example. It would have been better if the authors had included bullet point summaries at the end of each chapter as way to reinforce each lesson learned, rather than having to regroup with all of the useful information at the end because the important "how to" tips were lost in each chapter's text.

This was a very challenging and difficult book to read as Neiman writes mostly for other philosophers and academics.  Her main point is that the major ground that used to be the focus of philosophy was the problem of evil.  She explanis how this was present in the philosophical works of earlier philosophers.  This all was changed, however, by the earthquake in Lisbon, which caused Enlightenment Europe to recoil in horror.  The intellectual and philosophical response to the earthquake was to bifurcate evil into moral and natural evil.  This, in turn, had a major impact on philosophy as the latter was put on the fringes of philosophical discussions.  Neiman delved deeply into the various interpretations about life that this new perspective caused; the role of God in all this, especially.  Neiman covers extensively the place of Auschwitz and the holocaust as a touch point of the meaning and causes of evil in the modern. There is a lot to be mined here, with much of the material extrapolated from Hannah Arendt's work. Unfortunately, the lay reader will have a hard time wading through the text and absorbing all the lessons given the occasional untranslated French, for example, or reference that assume a deep knowledge of philosophy or literature.

The way we measure time and space today is significantly different from not that long ago.  According to this book, man used to see time as circular and did not break it down into segments.  And even these non-regimented views of time varied from place to place.  It was not until the introduction of innovations like the clock that man began to look at time as something that could be divided and ultimately potentially conquered. People like David Allen, author of Getting Things Done, are direct beneficiaries of this change in mindset.  Space was also not conceived in the past the way it is today.  Changes were reflected by the introduction of perspective into painting, which used parallel lines joining in the horizon, with checkered floors to aid the eye, to create perspective.  These are two of the “measures of reality” that Professor Crosby covers; others include bookkeeping and music.  One fascinating bit of trivia: the “Do Re Mi” scale comes from the first syllables of words from a Gregorian chant (sorry Julie Andrews).  The book is scholarly but generally accessible.  Crosby writes with some attitude and humors, which makes a subject that could at times be tedious, more enjoyable.

In an age when no one has reasonable debates, talks past each other and demonizes the opposition, a book like this can be an important corrective.  Professor Gutting uses case studies to teach the various tools of the philosophical trade that can informed reasoned argument.  One of the most important of these tools, and the one most needed in these times, is the Principle of Charity, which requires that you "render in neutral language the main elements of your opponent's position".  This is important not just to understand it objectively but to also help you rationally fashion your own counterarguments.  This would be very helpful today in the issue of same-sex marriage, for example, where one side deems the other homophobic for simply objecting and the other side deems the other as destroyers of the values of Western civilization.  Regardless of which side you are on, you need to fully understand the arguments of the opposition.  Another example is the idea of convictions, that is fundamental beliefs from which a person begins that do not necessarily require specific reasons, although they can be rational, similar to axioms in mathematics.  Gutting's case studies include religious agnosticism, the limits of science, and education in a capitalist economy.  For each case study he brings to bear another principle, and teaches how it would be applied for that specific topic.  I do not agree with all his conclusions, but, although it is clear where Gutting stands, the point of the book is not for Gutting to make a case for his positions, but to make a case for reasoned argument.

I was at first put off a little bit by this Idiot's Guide as the writing began in a very condescending tone.  There was even an inaccurate statement claiming that philosophy led to the end of human sacrifice.  After this rough start, however, the booked picked up, raising the level of discussion while keeping the material accessible.  The topics covered the usual ground for philosophy introductions - the pre-Socratics, Plato, Descartes, etc.  What was interesting and refreshing for me was the inclusion of philosophers not often included in these overviews, specifically in this case Margaret Cavendish and the post structuralists like Derrida and Lacan and the post modernists like Lyotard.  This book has piqued my interests in these philosopher's works as well as others.  I highly recommend this book for laypeople who want to get a relatively quick and easy overview of the philosophical landscape, just beware the initial speed bump.

A terrific novel based on the life of Roger Casement.  Vargas Llosa shows his virtuosity as a chronicler of the human condition via fiction.  The story is about Roger Casement, the Irish Brit turned Irish nationalist by his experiences of colonialism in the Belgian Congo and the Peruvian Amazon.  Vargas Llosa entrances the reader with this descriptions of human emotions and living environments.  One can feel the heat of the Amazon, or the claustrophobia of Casement's prison, or the refreshment on the skin of the cool waters wher Casement swam for recreatoin. One can also experieince the depths of emotion and passions, as Casement confronts the cruelties inflicted on the natives by Europeans or by native elites in the Congo or the Amazon, or as he struggles with decisions over when and how to organize an insurrection in Ireland, or, most poignantly, his struggles over his sexuality, and his actual or imagined exploits.  I recently read a blurb on how reading fiction helps in learning how to interact socially under various circumstances.  I think this book is a perfect example of not just that, but also of how the mind struggles and wins, and sometimes loses, in its daily battles with the challenges of reality, be they personal harm inflicted by nature or others, or by the constant struggle to simply stay afloat, above the sadness and even depression that is sometimes just below ground.  The story itself about Casement's evolution from English knight to traitor is fascinating.  Vargas Llosa masterfully depicts the various players in the drama, from the fauna and flora of the various environments, to the personas that crossed Casement's paths - his mother, his fellow revolutionaries, the various culprits supporting and heroes fighting the injustices Casement witnessed, the priest and Casement's jailer, among many.  This is a novel that will endure in the memory of  its readers.

Some philosophers have prescribed an ideal for individuals olive by to achieve a number if things, be they happiness, contentment, etc.  John Kekes claims in his work that ideals can never be achieved and attempting to do so never removes the conflict in values that causes someone to reach for an ideal as a solution.  He has a chapter for each ideal theory, introduced by an excerpt against the ideal, followed by a brief introduction to the ideal, then a story of a person faced with a situation of conflicting values attempting to apply the ideal, concluding with Keke's refutation of the ideal.  For example, their is a chapter on Narrative Unity as an ideal for behaving and structuring one's life.  Keke's presents his protagonist and goes on to refute most if not all of the claims of living by this ideal.  He does so in a very systematic and easy to understand manner, taking each main claim about or for the ideal, and dissecting it and exposing its flaws.  Occasionally his illustrations seem forced, like the protagonist for the Absolutist Morality, who came of as a bit of a caricature. For the most part, however, Keke's does a good job of presenting fairly the ideal in question, before tearing it down.  Keke's prescription is the Practical Approach, which acknowledges the conflicts in values but allows for different responses depending on needs and circumstances. On some level, he seems to be advocating situational ethics, but I think he is calling for more than that.  What struck me how often the everyday examples resonated with my own everyday living and conflicts, and how even when some seem to be addressed satisfactorily, their is always a lingering feeling that a better approach, mindset or attitude would have provided a better result.

These kitchen curtains are elegant and stylish.  They allow enough sunlight in while providing sufficient privacy. The material is of high quality and gives the kitchen an elegant look without being ostentatious.
Very tasty sauce.  Thick but not overdone. Sweet but not too sweet.  Have tried it on a few food items, including some you may think the sauce is not for, and have been very satisfied.

This book discusses the major political insights and practices from the Greek and Roman era, how they evolved and how they impact us today.  Democracy, for example, in Greek society is not like democracy today.  Back then its practice was restricted to male citizens of the polis, with perhaps others who had special status.  Some even saw democracy as a bad thing, possibly resulting in mob rule, or at least rule by the ruffians.  Plato's republic provided an answer to this by anointing philosophers king, or at least by making philosophers out of kings.  This tension between the ruler and the ruled continues to this day, as our American representative democracy can appear to have steered far from the ideal of representation based on principle.  Author Lane covers a total of eight concepts including democracy, justice, constitution, virtue, citizenship, cosmopolitanism, republic and sovereignty.  It's fascinating how the philosophical ground rules established more than 1800 years are still valid, as we deal with in our own presidential electoral process with issues like citizenship (immigration and so-called anchor babies); cosmopolitanism, with the shrinking of the world by communications and travel technology; sovereignty, with border control and submission to international bodies.  The ancient Greeks and Romans began this conversation and it is still going on.

Another terrific engagement by the co-authors of Freakonomics.  The book is a compilation of their most interesting blog posts.  I read these not only for the  entertainment value but also to remind myself of the economist's viewpoint on matters, which can often be enlightening (and a good corrective for what passes as reasoning in the media and elsewhere).  For example, Dubner and Levitt explain why high gas prices do not mean the end of civilization as we know, but instead will result in less use of gas and more use of gas substitutes, with prices and purchases correcting themselves over time.  Economics is about incentives, and a number of the posts focus on that, like incentives to decrease gun violence for example.  There are some very interesting posts that seem to have nothing to do with economics, like the one about names that match occupations for example, or the posts about the Pittsburgh Steelers, which were a bit annoying (yeah, Dubner, you love them but we don't care).  The other posts that also bothered me somewhat were the one's about gang members and the "escort".  i understand that the authors are trying to make economic points, but sometimes these posts can appear to glorify the underlying criminal activity and immorality.  Nevertheless, their books are a good way to exercise the economist's mindset and remind oneself how to apply it everyday situations.

This is one of the best philosophy books that I have read.  Although focusing on political philosophy, it covers the usual cast of characters of any introductory book on philosophy – Plato, Aristotle, Augustine, for example.  But, because of its focus on political philosophy, the book also covers others usually neglected from philosophy overviews – the ancient Greek playwrights, Luther and Burke.  Each chapter is lucidly written, covering the major ways in which the philosopher contributed to thinking about politics – Plato’s discussion of justice; Augustine’s views of two cities, the temporal and the eternal; Marx’s interpretation of history as the expression of class struggle.  The book also includes a chapter on scientists like bacon and Newton, and how their scientific discoveries impacted political viewpoints, leading primarily away from an authoritarian and communal viewpoint to a scientific viewpoint based on experiment and individual freedom.  A real treat was the chapter on Wollstonecraft, and her contribution to political philosophy.  Although I started out thinking that there would be a lot of dry material to plod through in a book like this, the co-authors proved that the material could be presented in a lively and engaging manner.  They had me looking forward to reading each successive chapter.

This is one of my favorite books because it provides a very clear road map for effecting change. The brothers Heath break down successful change into three components: 1) Direct the Rider; 2) Motivate the Elephant; and 3) Shape the Path.  Directing the rider refers to using reason and facts to identify where others have succeeded (the so-called bright spots), give specific behaviors, for example.  Motivating the Elephant refers to pushing the emotional buttons to motivate your target.  They give a great example of a manager piling up the different kinds of gloves purchased by a company to make a point.  The book gave me a strong motivator to stop drinking whole milk when they said one glass of it is equal to six strips of bacon.  Shaping the Path mean working on the environment or setting things up in such a way that success is more likely.  One example is teaching people to have a bowl of soup when trying to lose weight as this makes someone feel full faster.  What I am really looking forward to is combining the Switch methodology with “nudging”, or using behavioral economics and psychological principles of influence to get things done.  I think there is also a tie-in to the idea of “simple rules”.  A book by that name describes how simple rules can effect powerful change and actions.  These three approached could make for significant impact in any environment.

Author Mudd makes a very convincing case for conducting analysis from “right-to-left”, or, in other words, not beginning with the data but beginning with the right questions and the decision needs of decision makers.  As an analyst for the CIA working on critical issues – post 9/11 terrorism, for one – he has a lot of credibility.  He uses his vast experience to create and explain his system, which he learned through a lot of trial and error.  The best take away from the book is the idea of thinking through clearly what the right questions are and what your bosses will need to make the best decisions.  Mudd emphasizes that the decision will not be up to you, but that you need to take into consideration the right variable for the decision maker.  He notes that to do so, you need to focus on the right variables, which he calls those which others would be agnostic about, meaning, given the same situation, almost every analyst would agree that those variables should be included.  One other major price of good advice is the idea that one should set benchmarks for one’s decision variable so that one can reassess whether the variables are still valid,  Too often analysts stick to the same variables and don’t jettison them or add other better ones.  The one criticism that I have of the book is that in some ways it is limited to the type of analysis done by CIA analysts, who may need to take into consideration motives and intentions, and differentiate between those and capabilities.  A current example would be the Iran nuclear deal:  what are the Iranians intentions vs. what are their capabilities?  Analyzing the former is rife with speculation and guess; analyzing the latter is more concrete as it relies more on facts.  I don’t think that most of us in either the business world or government need to include this component in our analyses.  In any case, the book does provide a valuable different way to perform analysis, one that takes the ultimate decision making goal into account, and build reality checks (and even humility) into the process.

This book covers philosophy from a topical standpoint, addressing and exploring the usual suspects –knowledge, God, science and ethics.  The book is an introduction to philosophy but is written in a very dry and sometimes inaccessible manner.  To encourage philosophy newbies to imbibe further, books like this need more vivid and memorable examples; this one lacks them.  Also, although I understand that this is an introductory text, there are times when more can and should be said to enlighten and encourage the reader.  For example, the explanation of Hume’s view on induction stops at a point where it could leave the reader feeling inadequate to the task of understanding Hume’s thought. Thus, it may turn a budding philosopher away from the discipline.  Overall, the book does a good enough job, but there are other introductions to philosophy that make the subject matter more interesting and more accessible.

When I started reading this book I was a little frustrated because it seemed to focus on dramatic born-again type experiences as miracles.  For those of us who are Catholics, these types of experience are foreign.  Also, to me, focusing on this type of experience tends to downgrade the day-to-day grind and mundane nature of everyday struggles.  Sure, some of these conversions can be called miraculous, but let’s not forget that even in these cases there is a return to the everyday struggle of existence.  That aside, this book has an introductory chapter that makes a convincing case for life itself being a miracle, basically expressed in the question “What are the odds?” Specifically, Metaxas relates how physicists have calculated the probability of the universe existing as it does - it is exceedingly small. He describes how if even one factor, say the distance between the earth and the moon, were to change by the smallest amount, there would be no life on earth.  He also explains how scientists have determined that the nature of the universe was set in place within one millionth of a second after the big bang.  For all that to happen within such a tiny time frame seems to strongly suggest involvement of intelligence.  The remainder of the book is stories of miracles that Metaxas shares about friends and acquaintances, some of them more or less dramatic.  I am sorry to say that one of them includes a story that involves Benny Hinn, who to me is a spiritual charlatan.  The crux of the story seems real, but that Hinn is somehow involved leaves a bad taste.  Finally, Metaxas includes a heartwarming story involving Alice von Hildebrand, a renowned Catholic philosopher, and her late husband, Dietrich von Hildebrand.  I note that Hildebrand is Catholic because up until that point, the book had a slight anti-Catholic taint to it, what with all the focus on born again experience and an anti-Catholic quote from one Metaxas’ subjects.  At least in this case, redemption was achieved.

A hysterical collection of lengthy German words for things like the feeling one gets in a stopped train that it's moving when the adjacent train is moving, or the pleasure derived from symmetry.  One has to wonder why the German culture has this predilection (perhaps there is a German word for that).  Whatever the cause, these words provide the rest of the world a cause for enjoyment and a purpose for reflecting on the common things shared by various cultures around the world.

What does someone need to do to become a philosopher?  Gary Cox explains that first and foremost, one has to have a skeptical mind and take nothing for granted.  He illustrates this point by detailing the various philosophers most famous for expressing this trait, Descartes in particular.  A philosopher needs to think for him or herself and not accept any received knowledge without sufficient scrutiny.  This attitude, by the way, serves well in many endeavors.  Cox covers broadly the main areas of philosophy – metaphysics, epistemology and ethics – and gives the reader a good sense of what the philosophical profession entails. One minor disappointment was Cox not mentioning that originally philosophy was a way of life; i.e. Stoics lived by stoic principles; Epicurians lived by Epicurian principles.  This book is geared more to philosophy as a career and even has some career advice.  Cox does note that anyone can be a philosopher by philosophizing, although I think the danger here is that, if applied too loosely, folks who do not apply real rigor to their thinking will consider themselves lofty philosophers.  Cox takes the classic question “If a tree falls in the forest and there is no there to hear it, does it make a sound”, and runs with it to cover a lot of philosophical ground that includes landscapes of epistemology.  This is an easy and fun read for someone who is interested in a quick glance at the philosophical endeavor.

William Ury is the co-author of perhaps the most well-known book about negotiation, Getting to Yes, which he co-authored with the late Roger Fisher.  In this book, Ury shares his revelation that before you can successfully get to yes with others, you have to get to yes with yourself first. What he means by this is that we are often our own biggest obstacle to achieving negotiation success.  Why? Sometimes because we are not honest with ourselves with what we want, or we want the wrong things. For example, in a negotiation we may be seeking revenge or to not lose face, rather than looking for a win-win solution. We may want to achieve certain conditions, like freedom or recognition, but focus instead on the material expressions of this, like a severance payment or percentage of ownership.  Once we recognize what we really want, we then open ourselves to creative solutions. Ury gives great examples of these instances from the many negotiations where he was a participant or an advisor.Ury’s advice is packaged as a six step process: 1) put yourself in your shoes; 2) Develop your inner Best Alternative to a Negotiated Agreement; 3) Reframe your picture; 4) Stay in the zone; 5) Respect them even if; and, 6) Give and receive.  For each of these steps Ury provides a detailed explanation of what it means and vivid examples of where he has personally applied it or seen others apply it.  Number 2 for example is about willing to take ownership of your situation without blaming anyone, including yourself or others.  By doing so, you can focus on current reality and move toward solutions.What I did not know about Ury was how intimately involved he has been in major international crisis, like Hugo Chavez government and its negotiations with rebels.  Other negotiation books I have read are written by people who negotiate business deals, for example.  Ury’s negotiation experience is at an entirely different level.

This book provides a superb technique to identify and reduce stress.  The premise is that stress results not from events but how you react to those events.  This is not new wisdom as the ancient Stoics, and others, professed the same.  What is new here is the very detailed and specific technique that author Bernstein provides.  As someone who experienced traumatic events as a young person – the deaths of his father, step-sister and brother – he is speaking from sorrowful knowledge.Bernstein’s technique is a seven step process that begins with first acknowledging the counterfactual believe that is causing stress – e.g. he should not have been rude to me – and establishing why, seemingly paradoxically at first but ultimately correctly, the person “should have” been rude.  Bernstein explains why that is the case.  That something “should” have happened acknowledges that it did and allows you to move to action and resolution.  Bernstein shows how feelings and actions are tied to how we first react stressfully, and later, after we acknowledge reality, how we feel and react after the analysis using ActiveInsight (Bernstein’s brand name for his technique).Bernstein applies the technique to a range of areas, for purposes of illustration and to teach the technique.  The areas covered include death, anger, weight loss and success, to name a few.  The technique works.  I used it recently when stuck in traffic.  I explained to fellow passengers why there should be traffic – it’s the 4th of July weekend, etc., etc.The name of the book can be misleading and I can imagine people who live with stress thinking that it’s bunk.  Perhaps a retitling to the Myths of Stress may clarify.  I highly recommend this book for anyone who wants to reduce their stress levels around a number of issues.

David Graeber may be best known for coming up with the slogan, "We are the 99 percent". In this book he deals with the issue of rules and bureaucracy.  His these is that rules are not value neutral and objective, but rather are purposely promulgated to benefit the extraction of profit by the powers that be.  In the United States that would be the government and private financial institutions.  An example would be rules related to banking regulation which although ostensibly in place to ensure the proper functioning of the banking system, are in fact in place to ensure that financial institutions have legal backing for whatever their policies need. I think that Graeber is right to a point.  Given that we live in a complex society, there is no question that some sorts of rules are necessary to ensure at least efficiency, if not necessarily fairness.  As a personal example, take a popular local restaurant in my neighborhood.  The take-out area was chaotic and sometimes led to confrontations (this is the Bronx) as no one really knew who was next.  The simple implementation of a numbered ticket system, supported by the implicit rule of lower numbers go first when called out, ended all that.
