This may seem a mundane and irrelevant example but it testifies to the fact that there is no getting around some rules.Graeber points out that one of the major forces available to the government is its power to use violence to ensure the following of rules.  And it is the threat of such violence, not the actual use, which carries the day.  I could not agree with him more.  The current area where this is played out today is in police-community relations and the use of force.  To my mind, police officers have a great power behind simply with the threat of the use of force.  This alone cuts resistance down significantly as most people in such a situation would not want to escalate because of the threat.  I also agree that there is overreach in this in many areas.  For example, why are security guards needed in public libraries?He includes an essay where he argues that those of us who grew up in the 60’s and early 70’s have a sense of disappointment at not seeing the technologies promised in sci-fi  movies – jetpacks, teleportation, hover boards, for example. He claims that this is a result of a conscious decision to place research resources into the military, medicine and communications.  I think this is a bit of a stretch.Books like this are always fruitful to read as they give us the chance to look at our environment and circumstances from a radically different perspective, hopefully for the better.

The author makes the argument that exercise is more than just a physical act but can also be a great mental act.  Young draws from the lives of various people, other philosophers and his own experience to make the case.  Exercise strengthens our character by forcing us to be disciplined and to sacrifice.  It helps one to rise above the daily grind and the difficulties of daily existence, to levels of reveries and, at times, even transcendence.  Exercise removes the Cartesian mind-body split and reunites the individual into a whole and unity.  Young does note that exercise can create bad mindsets, like those of bodybuilders who are narcissistic. He claims, however, that body sculpting can also be a legitimate pursuit of beauty and physical harmony, as supported by the ancient Greeks.  The book essentially elevates exercise above mere physical exertion or to a lofty pursuit of personal wholeness.  For couch potatoes inclined to a more intellectual side, this book may be a good motivator to start exercising.

This is a great book that helps the reader figure out how and when to establish "simple rules" to help in decision making and taking action.  The co-authors describe the rule types, like boundary rules, for example, that tell you ahead of time what to include or exclude.  There are also timing rules, that tell when to stop or start something.  Simple rules tend to be more effective and efficient than complicated rules or logarithms. The authors provide as an example a Noble Prize winning economist who eschews his own complicated logarithim for personal investments and insteas uses a simple rule to invest.  Simple rules are effective because they remove the complexity of analysis and decision making, which can wear the mind out, and allow the individual to take decisive action because, to some extent, the decision has already been made.  An example of this is Michael Pollan's rule for eating: "Eat food.  Not too much. Mostly plants."  The authors also provide helpful guidance on how to create and refine simple rules.  My only criticism is that the authors mislabel instinctual animal behavior as simple rules.  They give examples of bees, birds and locusts for example, and how they achieve certain goals - locating a place for a beehive, flying in formation - and calls these behaviors rule following.  Creation of simple rules implies consciousness and rational choices, which are obviously not involved in these instances.  Perhaps there are not enough examples of simple rules created by humans to fill the pages of this book.  The other issue I had was a with the authors labeling creative people as eccentric when they used Tina Fey as an example.  Perhaps that was Fey's experience but that eccentricity and creativity go hand in hand is a myth that was laid to rest a long time go.  It's surprising to see this error stated as fact here.  They should have known better. Notwithstanding these issues, the book is a great guide for creating simple rules to help organizations and individuals achieve concrete goals.

This is one of the best philosophy overview books out there and I've read a good number of them.  The only qualification I would give is that the book is written for an intermediate level rather than an introductory one.  If you have read other introductory books, this one will take you to the next  level of understanding.  Shand has an uncanny ability to go over the same material in such a way that it presents itself differently but reinforces the particular thought of each philosopher.  As you are reading you get the feeling that the same point is being repeated, but it's okay because it's form a slightly different perspective that is providing more insight into what you just learned.  This approach has resulted in my finally getting a good grasp on Hume's view on induction as well as a better understanding of other philosopher's ideas, including Kant, Nietzsche and Heidegger, which is saying a lot.

Lenoir dissects happiness by revealing to the reader the many avenues which can lead to it.  He puts together a menu of options that can help one achieve happiness, from Stoic teachings to Montaigne's philosophy.  Ultimately, happiness is something that one can achieve by taking responsibility for how one responds to events and by seeing life as something that inherently has ups and downs.  There is material here even from Schopenhauer whom one would think has nothing to say about happiness.  There is also some contemporary material about neuroscience, happiness set points and positive psychology.  Lenoir covers all the bases and provides readers with a variety of approaches to obtain happiness.

Mele takes the most prominent arguments against free will and debunks them one by one, on both logical and empirical grounds.  Sometimes the explanations about why the neuroscience is misinterpreted are hard to follow, but it's worthwhile taking the time to understand.  At times I felt as if it was almost silly to read the book because the arguments against free will seem so lame. Perhaps that's why they are dispatched with in such a short work, a good and quick read to understand the arguments against free will and why they ultimately fail.

Father Morris provides the reader with a practical guide on how to use the serenity prayer.  The prayer is built on three things: acceptance, courage and wisdom.  The first is about letting go of things that cannot be changed - the past, other people, etc. The second is about having the courage to change the things you can.  The emphasis here is on action.  Finally, the wisdom to know the difference, as stated in the prayer.  Father Morris has chapters on how each of these components of the prayer can be applied and realized, and often gives personal examples,  The book is not tied solely to these three precepts, though, as Father Morris expands and extrapolates into other areas of Christian life and morals.  For example, he writes about mercy as an essential component of the Christian and writes about gratitude, living life one day at a time and trusting in God for "our daily bread..  Sometimes when I read books like this I find myself drifting and inattentive, probably because I have heard the same messages so many times and in so many different ways that it does not come off as new or insightful.  Ironically, as I was having this thought while reading, I came upon a passage that said that God really cares about each of us.  At that moment i thought about how much I care about my own children and the message hit home in a profound away that I never experienced before, and I could really feel God's love for me.  This book is then more than just about the words in the serenity prayer but about the Christian life as a whole and, for me, it became a deep personal experience.

This book is a collection of Gary Becker's articles written for the magazine Business Weekly, many co-authored with his wife, a historian. Becker was a Nobel Prize winning economists who believed strongly in the power of free markets and rational choice.  I very much looked forward to reading his insights on how economics affects basic human choices, particularly since behavioral economics has attempted to bury the idea of homo economicus. There are a lot of good articles on how rational choice impacts social policy.  For example, there are good discussions on how special interests interfere with rational economic choices and how they can help to stifle economic growth.  There are also interesting articles on labor economics, international trade, welfare and crime.  Unfortunately, no effort was made to cull out article that were redundant, and there were a lot of those.  Also, none of the articles were dated, so there is not sense of exactly when an article was written and in what context.  The articles can therefor jump from one administration to another, and then back, causing some historical vertigo.  I was also surprised to find some naivete on Becker's part in his policy recommendations, such as how the implementation of school vouchers would work out.  A better book would have been one that first explained the economic principles involved and then followed with examples from the various articles, preferably in chronological order.  Nevertheless, the book is still a powerful advocate of free markets and rational choice, notwithstanding any valid correctives from the behavioral economists.

Adam Smith is best known as the intellectual father of capitalism and as the author of the Wealth of Nations.  Not too many people are aware of his broader philosophical side as reflected specifically in his book The Theory of Moral Sentiments.  Economist Russ Roberts writes about how he finally picked up the book and read carefully and how much it impacted his life.  He shares Smith's philosophical wisdom and insights with the reader and produces a guide to better living through better thinking and ethical behavior.  Roberts notes how Smith observed that the culture and its mores are established over time by social approval and disapproval.  As a result we want to be "loved"; in Smith's terminology this means respected for our  character and noble actions, which make us "lovely".  The sum of all these good actions are what compose a good life.  And we do good and avoid bad not so much because we fear consequences, temporal or eternal, but because we feel that an impartial spectator is watching us, and so we take this spectator's  sentiments into account.  Roberts notes also that Smith was not materialistic.  Instead, he advocated becoming wise and virtuous to be happy and have a good life.  Material wealth is not intrinsically wrong, but it is not necessary for either wisdom or virtue.  The book is filled with these kinds of insights, as well as good examples as well and practical applications to live a better life.

Author Lynch advocates the traits of scientific reasoning as those that should set the gold standard for public discourse in order to maintain a democratic society.  Lynch explains that to give reasons for reason can be begging the question, as it is using reason to justify.  So he explains that there is another basis for accepting scientific reason and takes the reader step by step through his logic, Frankly, a lot of the reasoning was hard for me to understand, but what I get is that science's way of arriving at conclusions - intersubjective, adaptable, repeatable and transparent, is the best way to engage in public discourse and keep the engine of democracy moving.  This would be in stark contrast to the talking past each other, as well as the relativism that opposing sides ascribe to each others' views - whether they be reason or faith based.  There is a lot to chew on in this book, not all of it easily grasped.  But the main goal is clear that as a society we need to agree on method of discussion that gives fair time to both sides without devolving to shouting matches, name calling and demonization.

This book describes the various myths around creativity and how to counter them. Burkus give us 10 myths, for example the Eureka Myth where an idea appears to pop out of nowhere, as when Archimedes figured out in the tub how to solve the problem of determining whether the kings crown was made of pure gold or not.  (Personally, I often jump out of the tub naked on various occassions and run in the streets yelling "Eureka".  Fortunately there is always a clean towel waiting for me at the precinct.) The fact is that good ideas take time to develop; they percolate in the brain and take form over time. When the idea hits, it can feel as if it came out of nowhere.  There is also the Originality Myth, that ideas also come forth ex nihilo, unconnected to anything prior.  Again, this is a myth since most new ideas build on past ideas and are always a combination of two or more existing things.  The problem with these and other myths is that they can create excuses for not trying to come up with good ideas (hey, I'm just a regular schmo with no creativity genes (the Breed Myth) or can lead to counterproductive or ineffective practices (the Brainstorming Myth), in turn depriving the world of a better mouse trap (oops, that's another myth). (By the way, Nature invented the best mouse trap - it's called a Cat.)I did have some issues with some of his points:1) There is no gene for creativity to objectively identify who is creative.  However, Burkus points out that creative people have more white matter than grey matter in their brain.  Is this not then a way to objectively identify creative people (and does it matter)?2) He gives as an example of creativity the Netflix price and crowdsourcing idea to get an improved algorithm for making movie recommendations.  Two issues: a) Netflix ended up not using the algorithm, although they did learn from it; b) the algorithm would have led to non-creative outcomes for Netflix customers who would continue to view the same types of movies.3) As a public servant, I was completely unimpressed by his examples of private sector people working in the public sector to provide an outsider perspective.  The results of their efforts were insignificant and their roles seemed not much different from typical consultants.4) Burkus had an internal contradiction in his writing.  In an earlier chapters he criticizes the bifurcation of jobs into creative and non-creative work, essentially stating that the false dichotomy deprives organizations of the creativity found in all individuals.  Later on, when criticizing Taylorism's approach to incentives, he notes that "creative work if different"; i,e. for white collar analytical jobs that are not defined by repetitive tasks, you can't apply the same kinds of incentives as you would to non-creative work.  So what happened to the prior alert against the false distinction between who is and is not creative?Despite these flaws, Burkus is largely on target with his identification of the myths and their antidotes.  Throughout, Burkus also presents good examples of both the myth and the right approach in practice.

I was unaware until reading this book that Rousseau and Hume had actually met.  Rousseau was on the run after publishing a work that derided miracles and Hume offered to give him refuge.  At first, the relationship was one of mutual admiration, but that deteriorated eventually mostly, as I percive it, due to Rousseau's sensitivity.  Today, Rousseau might be labeled as paranoid based on all the imaginary offenses that he thought were ocurring.  The story is told in a way that keeps the reader engaged.  The writing duo of Zaretsky and Scott are highly gifted; one wonders how they worked together to pull this off.  There are so many illustrious characters involved, beyond the two main protagonists - Boswell, Johnson, Erasmus Darwin, Robert Garrick, Voltaire, Diderot - it's a veritable who's who of Enlightenment personalities.  The reader gets a mini-course on Rousseau's and Hume's philosophies in the context of their relationship, their times and the conflagration between the two.  To be honest, at times it felt as if I was reading nothing more than gossip, a sort of highbrow version of the Housewives of New Jersey.  In the end, however, there is the intellectual satisfaction of reading the masterful writing and tasting of the profound thinking of both Rousseau and Hume.

As an overview of Kant's work I found this book to be quite challenging.  That is not necessarily a reflections of Guyer's skill at writing but more of the inherent difficulty of the subject matter.  As everyone knows, Kant's philosophy is hard to understand.  Guyer takes the reader through each of Kant's major works and goes into quite a lot of detailed explanations about what Kant meant, where he was inconsistent, and how his explanations were satisfactory or not.  There are other introductions that are far easier to grasp, but they only take the Kant neophyte as far as the wading pool; this one takes the reader into the deep end of the pool.  As such, the reading is challenging, and it is somewhat consoling to read phrases like "what Kant meant" because it reassures the reader that the difficulty lies in the material and no some shortcoming in the reader (have I mentioned enough times how difficult Kant is to understand?)  This book will require numerous dips before enough is sufficiently grasped; nevertheless there is quite a thrill when Guyer elucidates a Kantian point through example or clarification, although I am still struggling with fully understanding the connection between reason, freedom, free will, etc. My favorite quote, given the current interest in "nudges" and behavioral economics: Paternalism is "the greatest despotism thinkable".

What is law?  What makes law legitimate or something that should be obeyed?  Where do laws come from?  These are some of the questions that this short tome attempts to answer.  For the most part, author Wacks does a good job of making the material accessible, particularly in the early chapters on natural law, legal positivism and the thought of Ronald Dworkin.  However, as he gets into the later chapter, Wacks assumes too much knowledge and presents topics without sufficient explanation.  For example, some of the views on law involve economic or sociological concepts.  These are presented as if the reader already had basic knowledge of concepts and terms in these areas.  Those who do not will get lost, as I did on some occasions.  This may be the fault of the necessarily limited content in this series, but the author perhaps then should have only mentioned some of these areas rather than attempt to get into them briefly but at too high a level.  I would only recommend this book for the first few chapters.

This book is filled with terrific writing advice, not just for writing under pressure, but under any circumstances.  Kaye explains how writers in pressure circumstances end up with an unbalanced effort because they fail to plan both the amount of space to dedicate to each piece of writing as well as the amount of time.  As a result, someone may spend excessive time on the introduction and then find themselves with a conclusion that misses the mark.  Thinking ahead in this way gives the writer perspective on how much time and space to allocate.  One of my favorite bits of advice is Kaye's recommendation to spit out as many "because" ideas to bolster your point.  Doing so will give you enough material that you can then cull from, instead of being left with too little to say.  Also, he encourages the writer to give space to the other side of the issue, which helps both in crafting your own issue but also lets the reader know that your opinions are well considered.  One unique perspective that Kaye offers is the idea that the end of every writing effort should be an assessment of what was learned from the process so as to improve one's future efforts.  Kaye  also offers an insightful analysis of the writing that occurs in organizations, which tends to lean toward loyalty and not rocking the boat, thereby pushing creative and challenging thinking aside.  In this sense Kaye's book is also a call for honesty, integrity and even courage in the face of organizational expectations.  I wonder what he thinks about the stifling and falsely authoritative appearance created by the ubiquity of Power Point.

A collection of hysterical cartoons by the cartoonist who drew on of my all time favorites - "How about never, is never good for you?" Kaplan had me chuckling and bursting out loud in laughter, to the consternation of some of my fellow subway riders. A few of the cartoons were duds, but the vast majority reflect Kaplan's clever and ironic humor, many of which hit close to home, particularly in personal and business relations.

This book teaches a method to analyze arguments so as to determine whether the arguments makes sense and their reasons lead to conclusions.  Fisher uses what I would call a layperson's approach.  That is, he does not use the methods of traditional logic, especially those of formal logic, but instead introduces what he calls the Assertibility Question;i.e. What argument or evidence would justify me in asserting the conclusion?  (What would I have to know or believe in accepting the conclusion?)  You get to this point after identifying the inference and reason indicators, figuring out how they relate to each other (are the reasons independent or dependent), are their preliminary conclusions which then becomes reasons for the final conclusion?  Through this effort, one should be able to arrive with some confidence at the assertibility of a claim.  The book is written for students, so for someone who is not assigned classwork going through some of the examples is tedious, particularly as Fisher first introduces the text being analyzed in full, then with notations, and sometimes excerpts again to review the analysis.  Part of the reason that Fisher does this is because he wants to motivate the reader to believe that he or she can get far in their analysis and not really on experts or on the need to be an expert in the subject matter itself.  This, I think, is a noble ambition.The book has a supplementary chapter on formal logic, which I skimmed, and a chapter containing readings for independent work.  Some of these are fascinating in and of themselves.

I have always felt that too much time is spent filling out project management spreadsheets at the cost of actually doing the work.  Doing so gives some people a sense of control, even thought that may not be the case.  A book like this is a breath of fresh air because it gets people to ficus on the essentials of project management (filling out spreadsheets is not one of them).  The one-pager is a genuine improvement as it contains all the information that a project manager needs to know, at an appropriate level, where a project is, what still needs to be done, and where a project may need help. I do feel, however, that the format could probably be improved by someone with a better eye for design, as at times, even this streamlined tool can contain too much information.  From my experience top management only needs to (and wants to) see the bare essentials.  I also agree with the authors that a tool like this also focuses meetings and helps to order priorities.  The book is probably about 50 or more pages longer than it needs to be.  There is a lot of filler, especially in the form of endorsements about the product, and some repetition as the authors explain the tool for so-called "agile" project management.  There are also a couple of instances where the explanations are not clear, as for example what the purpose is of "blank squares" in the OPPM. Nevertheless, the OPPM is a significant improvement over multiple page MS Project pages with numerous dependencies.

A fantastic study of all the issues and dilemmas that arose from Descartes' philosophy, particularly the notion that what we fundamentally know is that we think and therefore exist.  Chappell's work takes off from this launching point to explore questions like, if all we know is ourselves )the inescapable self), how can we know that others exits, why should we care about them (i.e. why should there be altruism), is there an objective morality that is possible?  Chappell covers these dilemmas with fair coverage of the major sides in each debate, giving full air time to sides with which he disagrees.  He uses analogies masterfully, helping the reader understand key concepts and nuances to arguments,  Chappell concludes the work with his conciliatory version of how the apparent contradictions in the dilemmas can be resolves.  His writing is also clear and often enough even humorous.  If you want to cover much of the ground that has been explored since Descartes' seminal works, this book takes you on a satisfying and enlightening journey.

Overall this is a book worth reading for both the knowledge and the humor.  It was, however, at times rough going and I felt as if I was experiencing Jacob's challenge of reading through the encyclopedia but on an obviously much smaller scale.  I think it was just too much material, as there is chapter for each letter of the alphabet and, though there are enough fascinating bits of knowledge scattered throughout with the occasional laugh-out-loud Jacobian moments, they seemed for a long stretch to come too infrequently. The book soon became the one I read for a few minutes just before bed, or for a few minutes in the bathroom; in other words, it took a real long time to finish the book.  I managed to read the last 100 pages over a three-day weekend and I don't know if it was because the book got more interesting and funnier, or because I was basically stuck at home with nothing else to do (or maybe I kept going to bed and using the bathroom a lot).In any event, as I noted, there is a lot of fascinating information scattered throughout the book.  Stuck in my mind forever will be the fact that cilantro and coriander are the same thing (what about culantro?) and that Alaska is both the Western-most and Eastern-most state.  As happened to Jacobs, I will probably also forget most of the other information.  Jacobs is a humorist and he has plenty of very funny and laugh-out-loud funny comments and observations.  However, as I suggested above, during the first two-thirds of the book these seemed to come few and far between.  Also, he drops the f-bomb too often for my taste (and it is unnecessary).Here is my petty complaint about the book: as a backdrop to his effort to read the encyclopedia, Jacobs keeps us up-to-date on he and his wife's effort to have a baby.  Unfortunately, he kept using the phrase, "We are trying to get pregnant."  I have news for him: until he has an artificial womb inserted in him, and a willing accomplish to impregnate him, only his wife will succeed.  The other background story is his constant comparison to his father, an accomplished attorney who has written more than 20 law books and is a prankster.  This was okay although at times I was wondering if he could have spared us some of his public therapy sessions.  I forgive this because his father is a fellow graduate of Bronx Science.

First, I hope some of you caught my unbelievably clever pun using the title from the management classic "Good to Great" by Jim Collins. Anyway, the grater is very lightweight, simple to use and easy to store.  Just put the cheese against the grating component, turn the handle and voila, nice, airy pieces of grated cheese.  The only downside is that the gadget is just a tad difficult to clean, as cheese remnants cling to the interior of the grater.  Your cleaning to grating rating will probably be too high, if that sort of metric matters to you.

As I read this book I had the persistent feeling that it could have been vastly improved if the author had taken his own advice.  Pinker has a chapter on the curse of knowledge and how not taking that into account results in inaccessible writing.  He then proceeds in succeeding chapters to use grammatical terms that I am sure many readers either don't know or have forgotten: the genitive, what is that?  These terms are scattered throughout and, ironically, slowed down my reading and my understanding.  I also had a hard time understanding his concept of a tree (versus the traditional sentence diagrams).  I understood it intuitively: writing has to hang together; the further words, phrases or thoughts that should be together are set apart, the more lack of understanding.  I get this conceptually but it is really hard to follow using the "tree" diagrams he provides. In a chapter that includes caution against the use of double negatives, Pinker's uses the phrase, "making the negation unambiguous".  How about "making the negation clear"?  These criticisms are somewhat ironic since Pinker does the same to the work of other authors. (There is a hysterical account of grammar experts criticizing each other's texts on punctuation mistakes, each successive author capturing mistakes by the preceding author).Although I started with criticism, the book is actually good, motivating and helpful.  One piece of advice that I have already used to good effect, for example, is to put the old first and the new last.  I also understand better now how the passive voice can be helpful in certain circumstances. For those of us who want to improve our writing and ensure that our communications are effective, this book provides the necessary instruction.Here is something petty: of all the examples of text that Pinker could have provided from literature, he chose two examples from his wife's writing, not Hemingway or Sontag or Talese.  No, two examples were attributed to Rebecca Newberger Goldstein, philosopher/novelist and recipient of a McCarthur genius award.  I have read some of Goldstein's books and she is both a good philosopher and a good writer, but to select her writing and exclude so many from the pantheon of the immortals is pathetic.  Someone did not want to sleep on the couch.  One other thing:  Pinker uses his atheist (a/k/a humanist) buddy Richard Dawkins as another example of wonderful writing.  One humorous note: Dawkins endorses Pinker on the dust jacket.  Isn't there something unethical about that?

Although this book offers provides a positive and even inspirational message about the benefits of continuous improvements, the techniques that it describes are just one of many possible approaches to continuous improvement.  One technique I was not familiar with is the "six-legged spider" chart, which is used for individuals to reflect on their performance, identify specific areas of improvement, identify problem areas, and identify new improvements and insights.  However, this specific tool is just one of many that could be used to this end.  The author also uses the traditional fish bone diagram to get staff to identify root causes.  The innovation here may be in requiring staff to then prioritize the areas of improvement focus.  Ahlstrom also provided a useful mnemonic to help use the fish bone.  One of the best parts of the book is the focus on cultural change, specifically the participation of staff at all levels to foster inclusion and ownership.  This is vital as improvement programs that are not authentically supported will be perceived as senior management manipulation.  In my opinion, establishing a change and innovation culture, where communication is open and staff can point out problems and offer improvement suggestions without fear of reprisal and with some confidence that recommendations will be seriously heard, is more important than the improvement process used.One of the things that was a bit confusing was that the writer of the foreword said that the book was written as a novel, but the text itself reads like actual events.  It leaves the reader wondering if what happened are actual events dramatized or if the events are completely fictional.In sum, this book provides one path of many that can be used to achieve continues improvement.  It's worth reading to identify which specific tools and approach might be best for your particular effort.

One of the classic challenges that Catholics have is both understanding and appreciating the Mass.  For whatever reasons - poor catechesis, personal shortcomings, etc - too many Catholic do not understand and appreciate that the Mass is the sacramental recreation of Christ's sascrifice at Calvary; instead, many Catholics see the Mass as just another service or an obligation foisted on them by the Church.  What happens at Mass, as  Scott Hahn, has explained, happens eternally in heaven, as the Book of Revelation includes the Mass itself. At the Mass, bread and wine are consecrated to become the actual body and blood of Christ, in fulfillment of Christ's commandment to eat his body and drink his blood to have eternal life.  It's hard to understand, given what the Mass is, why so many Catholics complain that they "do not get anyhting" out of the Mass, or that it is boring.  How can being at the foot of the cross be boring?  How can receiving Our Savior in the form of bread and wine not give you all you can possibly get in this life?Father McGloin's book is an attempt to address the above malady in an informal and down-to-earth manner.  His audience is Catholics with these attitudes and misunderstandings.  He educates the reader by taking each segment of the Mass - the opening prayer, etc - and explaining its role in the Mass.  Father McGloin speaks to the common man with mundane examples and analogies to reach the reader.  There are no profound theological expositions, only streetwise remarks.  He alludes often to the typical distractions that Mass attendees face, such as thinking about the afternoon ballgame, judging the quality of the homily, rushing out of Mass, etc.  This is particularly important because it shows that Fr. McGloin knows what he is talking about.  For each of these maladies, Fr. McGloin provides both understanding of its occurrence and ways to counter them.  For any reader, it would be a comfort to know that it is not just you that suffers from these distractions and thoughts.  On one or two occasions, becuase Father is attempting to reach is audience where they are, he stoops a bit too low and gets too close to expressing his corrective examples in tones that can sound offensive.  Other than that, it would be helpful if the book were republished and marketed to today's Catholics, as the problems and misunderstandings described in the book continue to exist forty years after the publication of this book.

I do not understand why other reviewers are so positive about this book.  It is a collection of kumbaya-type essays about what a wonderful world this would be if only we could all be more creative.  There is constant reference to the imminent demise of existence, mostly driven by the abuse of the environment.  It's as if a bunch of hippies with PhD's got together and smoked one too many joints. Contributors include a former TV sitcom writer who believes that television watching can be a creative act and that tv episodes can be used effectively for psychotherapy (and dubs this teletherapy).  I have a nominee for the first client.  There is a lot of passing reference to everyday creativity, with the occasional praise of things like making recipes and arranging schedules, but nothing as to how this can practically come about.  There is a lot more substantive discussion about so-called eminent creativity or the geniuses in the field, but with a lot of very loose thinking about how this comes about.  The terms chaos theory and fractals are bandied about as if they obviously apply to the creative process. I was sad to see the renowned psychologist Mihaly Csikszentmihalyi attach his name to this "publish-or-die" endeavor, but he did warn the prospective reader quite diplomatically about the content.  To give you a sense of the type of writing that you can beat yourself with, the phrase "ontogony recapitulates phylogeny" is included.  I gave up on about page 250 of this 310 or so page book, when I decided that I could not take it any longer.

This book is written for young adults and covers "contemporary" philosophy from Bentham and Mill to Sartre and Camus.  The author begins with Bentham and explains how the industrial revolution began turning philosophical interests away from metaphysics and epistemology to more mundane concerns such as the happiness of individuals, which was the concern of the utilitarians' philosophical enterprise. After the utilitarians the author covers Kierkegaard and Nietzsche, specifically their intense focus on the individual; the Pragmatists James and Dewey, describing their similarities and differences; Process Philosophy, covering Bergson and Whitehead; Analytic Philosophy; Phenomenology (Husserl and Heidegger); and, finally Existentialism, including the thought of Sarte, de Beauvoir and Camus.  For each philosopher author Price provides a brief biographical sketch as well as some description of the contemporary culture or pressing social issues.  She does an excellent job of covering the main topics.  (This is not her fault, but I have yet to find a writer who can explain Heidegger.)  I am not so sure that the reading level is at times appropriate for the intended audience, perhaps only for more gifted high school upper classmen.  In any event, this is a very good introduction to the most influential philosophies and philosophers of the modern period,

This book, being a philosophical discourse on happiness, does not give a definitive answer as to what happiness is or how one can achieve.  Haybron covers the different approaches to identifying and measuring happiness, including well-being and life satisfaction.  These tools, however, are  limited, not only by the slippery subject of happiness but also by respondents' apparent tendency to rate their happiness level high whenever they are asked, as if providing a lower rating would be embarrassing or shaming.  Hayborn lists three major factors that he believes can construct a happy life: Endorsement (feeling happy and other "classic" emotions; Engagement (vitality and flow); and, Attunement (peace of mind, confidence, expansiveness).  For the most part, I think these categories work and Hayborn explores how they can be attained.  The one item that seems to have been covered ad nauseum is the effect of money on happiness - it is good up to a certain point ($70,000 in the US) and then goes flat.  The hedonic treadmill is also discussed, where individuals seem to return to a set point of happiness after a change in circumstances, new experiences or material possessions.  Meaning is also explored, and how while other things may appear counter to a happy outlook, a meaningful job, for example, could overall result in someone having a happy life (or having the subjective perspective that your job is meaningful).  The bottom line, I think, is that happiness is something that we experience in spurts and intermittently, simply because that's how life is, but we can always step back and see that, in the big picture, our lives are not all that bad or that they could be far worse or that there is something to be learned from tough times, and so we can rate our overall well being highly.  This book does a great job of covering all the different angles from which happiness can be studied in a short volume.

This is a terrific achievement in making philosophy accessible to the layperson.  Adamson writes in plain language and takes the reader playfully throughout this first of many promised volumes.  He interjects humor occasionally to add to the pleasure of the ride.  Because, as promised, this is philosophy "without the gaps", Adamson covers philosophers and topics that would otherwise be passed over or discussed only superficially.  For example, Adamson includes discussions of Anaximander, Anaximenes and Parmenides when covering the pre-Socratics.  Each chapter gives enough information to get significantly familiar with the philosophers and their teachings without overwhelming the reader. Nuances and controversies are sometimes introduced but not expounded on because of the limitations of this kind of effort, but enough is provided to encourage further study.  The "without the gaps" approach is also reflected in Adamson's coverage of Plato.  Usually Plato in a philosophical overview is limited to some of his major thesis, like his theory of Forms and his theory of justice, with discussion of the Republic and the Symposium.  Here, Adamson instead provides one chapter for each of Plato's major works (two for the Republic ).  Again, Adamson does this in such a way as to not intimidate the reader, carefully connecting the works together where appropriate.  I cannot say enough about this book.  If Adamson can maintain the same quality and controlled depth throughout the rest of his anticipated series, he will have done a great service to the task of making philosophy accessible to the general public.

The point of this book is that we often don't solve problems because we approach them the wrong way.  We tend to get overwhelmed by them because we try to take them on head on, on their own terms.  This sounds somewhat vague.  Also, how to not take problems on their own term seems impractical.  Niven provides a few examples: When the mechanical shark that Steven Spielberg was using for the movie Jaws did not work properly, instead of spending time and money on fixing it, he mostly kept it out of the movie.  The physical absence but mental presence of the shark is what created the terror in Jaws and made it the greatest revenue maker.  The book concludes with an example of a train company in Japan that could not figure out how to solve a problem of water in a tunnel that they had to dig through a  mountain.  A person who was not an engineer tasted the water - it was great - and the train company created a successful bottled water subsidiary.  There are other examples like these, as well as advise on how to have the right mindset, that suggest the reader look at problems from a different angle.  One may be surprised at how solutions come, or in what other direction one is taken.One issues:  I think Niven takes too many liberties in re-interpreting one of the classic human behavior experiments, specifically the Milgram experiment where participants continued to give increasing levels of shock to another person.  Niven reinterprets this behavior as "obedience to a problem" instead of "obedience to authority".  He does not really support this; it just fits the theme of his book.

This book is a superb guide that teaches the reader how to prepare successful presentations.  Practicing what it preaches, Roam uses his steps throughout the book, showing the reader how to create presentations using the six ways that people visualize situations.  He convinces the reader that a story needs to be told and uses his PUMA, or Presentation's Underlying Message Architecture, approach to show how to tell one.  Roam is an advocate for using pictures instead of words, a case which he made strongly in one of his previous books, as this is how people think and remember most of the time.  To achieve this goal in a presentation he advocates showing - using pictures, graphics or drawings - and telling - speaking off the presentation slide.  i totally agree with him as i have difficulty following my own presentations when they abound in text.  He also repeats here the six ways of presenting information  -who/what, where, when, how much, how and why - and the visuals that correspond to each.  This work is inspiring and I will definitely use the techniques for my next presentation.

An excellent and comprehensive survey of how happiness has been viewed throughout the history of Western civilization.  Beginning with the Greeks submission to fate at the hands of the Gods, where happiness was something that was not up to individuals, all the way up to the present day's obsession with achieving a guaranteed happiness, Darrin McMahon show the reader how perceptions of happiness have changed over time, usually as a response to historical, cultural or societal realities.  For example, the Stoic approach to happiness developed in response to the reality of a declining Roman empire where individuals were at the mercy of tyrants, natural disasters or invading forces.  During Christendom, people sought happiness in the after-life, as their daily routing could guarantee only the barest of subsistence living.  The Enlightenment changed the focus, as men of learning and science sought to wrest the fate of the common man from religious authority and place it back with the individual.  The industrial revolution, which opened the possibility of material luxury, also opened the door for seeking happiness in material accumulations and entertainment.  It was interesting to see how Alexis de Toqueville saw back in the 19th century he malady that exists today of Americans continually seeking happiness and never quite finding it.  This massive work is filled with so much more that enlightens the mind about happiness;e.g the Freudian, Nietzschean and Marxist views and influencec for example.  This book orients the reader to hold a reasonable view about the possibility of happiness and its place throughout history.

Hegel is a tough read no matter who writes about him.  In this short work Raymond Plant attempts to capture the essence of Hegel's philosophy of religion.  He does a fairly good job in tying together the different strands to form a coherent picture of Hegel's thought, which is always a challenge.  What I got from the book is that Hegel is trying to somehow reunite man and the rest of the world, including God, so that man is not somehow alienated from them.  This will be accomplished when man achieves Absolute Knowledge, or the innate understanding of the inter-relatedness of all reality.  Hegel's philosophy is meant to transcend theology, at the same time elevating the latter to a universal level so that the particulars of religion are not restricted to a specific time or people.  In many respects, Hegel's thought on the matter is a re-interpretation or re-casting of the meaning of the Holy Trinity.  Again, a lot of what is included requires careful reading and will also require rereading to being to grasp Hegel's thinking.

Bruce Nussbaum makes the case the creativity is the key skill that will drive economic growth.  The question is: how does creativity come about.  Nussbaum identified five factors that need to be present so that creativity can take place and innovation can occur: 1) knowledge mining - a depth of enough knowledge in a specific discipline or across discipline to have the raw materials to make new connections; 2) framing - the ability to see a position from different perspectives, rethink it and imagine new future scenarios; 3) playing - the act of arriving at solutions not through problem solving but through imagining, engaging in competition and playing around in an open manner with tactile things or concepts; 4) making - the physical act of taking an idea and turning it into reality; and 5) pivoting - the process of taking something from an initial idea to a creation that is purchased.  Nussbaum goes into detail on how each of these competencies is expressed, some with their own subcompetencies.  For example, he claims that pivoting includes charisma, which can be the passion expressed by the creator.For the most part, I found the book motivational and inspiring, as I found myself thinking of new ideas as I read, ways of implementing them, and jotting down the good number of resources provided by the author.  Oddly, I found some of his examples unconvincing although they did not necessarily take away from the main claim (Horatio Sanz as an example of creative success?  He was possibly the worst cast member of SNL ever.)  Like other books on creativity, this one also struggled with the core question of how exactly it's achieved.  From the vast reading that i have done on this subject, I am not sure that this one has found the magic formula. I still think the closest, most accurate attempt is Gary Klein's Seeing What Others Don't, which is more of a hindsight review that a how-to.The book also includes an incisive criticism of the financial economy that is driven by shareholder gains and short-term profits, and how this has hurt the masses to the benefit of the few,  This discussion is one of the clearest ones I have found on the source and consequences of this economic shell game.

This book claims to have finally definitively identified with DNA testing and other scientific techniques who Jack the Ripper was.  The author is Russell Edwards, a British entrepreneur who developed, like many others, a fascination with the case. The missing link which he uses to identify Jack the Ripper is a shawl that was allegedly recovered at the scene of Catherine Eddowes' murder.  Through an almost unbelievable number of coincidences and lucky turns of events, Edwards follows a winding trail that includes getting DNA from one of Eddowes' descendants; with the help of his scientist sidekick finding the Ripper's DNA on the shawl, and then matching the two up and - voila! - Jack the Ripper was Aaron Kosminski, one of the original suspects who ended up dying in an insane asylum.  The book covers the usual ground for this case: the crimes and their victims; the culture and history of the time; police procedures and such.  Edwards also discusses at some length some of the other plausible suspects and explains why each would be unlikely to be the actual candidate.The theory hangs on the accuracy and validity of the DNA testing, all of which seems tenuous given the age of the material involved.  As a non-scientist, I found the detailed explanations of the DNA evidence hard to follow but seemed to make sense at a high-level.  I leave that for scientific minds to sort out.  What to me seems to lack explanation is the meaning of the shawl.  Edwards makes the case that it did not belong to the victim but rather to the Ripper.  He supposedly was using the shawl, which included what was known as a "Michaelmas" pattern, to signal the dates of his murders, as they coincided with various dates for Michaelmas, the Christian feast in some Orthodox churches that honor St. Michael.  According to Edwards, the crimes occurred on these dates of observance.  This somewhat complex messaging system, however, does not mesh with the character decryption that was derived for Kosminski, who apparently was a schizophrenic who was becoming progressively more mentally ill.  It seems a stretch to think that someone losing their mental faculties could create a complex scenario using a shawl to send a cryptic message.  Perhaps that's why the story is not elaborated on further by Edwards.  In actuality, that tale does not matter so long as the DNA work is accurate and valid.

Hegel is one of the toughest philosophers to understand.  He wrapped difficult and innovative concepts in sometimes incomprehensible prose.  As a layperson, I feel good reading in this book that other philosophers found him obtuse.  In this shirt book, Peter Singer, more famous for his book on animal rights, captures the essence of Hegel's thought and packages it in a way that the lay reader can grasp.  He begins his coverage of Hegel's philosophy with Hegel's belief that "the history of the world is the progress of the consciousness of freedom.'' Singer explains that for Hegel, freedom was not "negative"; i.e. the ability to do whatever you wanted; rather true freedom was the individual's ability to act from reason uninfluenced by culture, habit or any other external forces.  Over time, history has been progressing toward this Hegelian ideal, with the mind coming to understand itself evermore as the creator of reality.  Singer also discusses how Hegel came to influence other major thinkers, including Feuerbach and Marx, the latter taking Hegel's concepts and constituting them to develop his philosophy of history that would germinate into his ideal of communism.  Singer also points out that Hegel's work was often in direct response to Kant's philosophy, particularly to the idea that there is an unknowable world, made so by the fact that the mind's instruments of knowledge cannot capture it.  For those readers interested in an introduction to Hegel that will not intimidate them, this is an excellent work.

This is a clear and easy-to-read guide to prepare both simple and complex arguments.  Weston follows and models his own advice by writing clearly and in plain language, and making his case for logical thinking using logical thinking itself.  Weston compiles 45 "rules" from the basic and fundamental, like "identify premises and conclusions" to the more pragmatic advice like "use the web with care."  The book includes explanations deductive, like modus ponens and modus tollens and gives simple, easy-to-understand examples, as well as arguments by analogy and other techniques.  He also covers the logical fallacies and provides a good set of further readings.  This is the type of book that should be on every undergraduate's bookshelf.

Goldstein is a philosopher and a novelist (and good at both).  In this work she combines both talents to give us a sense of how Plato would today deal with many of the philosophical issues he raised more than 2,000 years ago, in a weird way making himself a footnote to his own work, as supposedly all philosophy since him is.  Goldstein begins with Plato making a stop at Googleplex on a book tour.  He sits to chat with his handler and a Google nerd and they discuss philosophical topics like the difference between information and knowledge, the role of experts in determining what is good, and other similar topics.  This is a very clever and effective way to cover the topics that Plato discussed in his original works, mostly through the voice of Socrates.  That chapter is followed by one where Goldstein reverts to a more traditional format where she discusses Plato's views.  This format is actually a welcome respite from the fictional set ups because they can be a bit long and lead the reader to start thinking more about Goldstein's skills as a fiction writer rather than the topic at hand.  Plato is also placed at the 92nd Street Y (a very New York City-centric chapter),  at a call in talk show and at an MRI facility.  At the Y the topic is mostly child-rearing, at the call in show it's mostly influence and values, and at the MRI facility the mind-body problem.  Again, Goldstein uses her deft novelist skills and her profound philosophical knowledge to create a work that is entertaining, educational and provocative.  Even the footnotes, which are quite lengthy at times, are engaging.
The dock is sturdy and stylish and serves well it's basic purpose of holding your ipod steady.

The author makes a good case that having low confidence and low self-esteem is can actually be beneficial.  Why?  For two reasons: first, those whose confidence is higher than their competence are perceived negativeness by others.  Secondly, thinking that you are better than you actually are prevents you from making improvements.  Combined, these two effects of overconfidence are a recipe for failure.  In contrast, someone with low confidence will seek ways to improve their competence, thereby improving their competence and, as a by-product, also raising their confidence to match their competence.  The author shows how overconfidence can be a problem in business, personal relationships and health. He also very clearly exposes the lie that has been bandied about by the self-help industry that someone with confidence can accomplish whatever they want.  The opposite seems to be the case.For the most part, his claims and evidence are convincing.  I do have some problems, however, with pieces of the presentation.  First, the author suggests that reputation is a better gauge of where someone stands than character because character is internal and therefore subject to numerous self-biases and reputation is external and more validly objective.  This may be so; however, his recommendation to then be very conscious of what others think about you can be very unsettling to people who suffer from social anxiety.  if anything, they are working to decrease the amount of thought they give to what others think about them.  I get the authors point, but it seems to fly in the face of what other therapies, particularly cognitive behavioral therapy, recommend for people with social anxiety.  Also, in the social relations section, he actually encourages people to lie on their first date about their interests and accomplishment because the date will not remember the specifics but will instead remember broad generalities about the person and thereby leave with a better impression.  It seems to me to begin a relationship of any sort with deliberate lying is to start off on a very wrong foot.  My final rebuke is that it is sometimes hard to follow the train of thought because the author also encourages faking confidence in certain situations.  This advice seems inconsistent with the main claim that overconfidence is bad.

This is a somewhat odd mini-introduction to Locke's epistemology.  About half the 58 page book are direct quotes from Locke's works and the other half commentary by the author.  One would have liked to see a better division that provided less of Locke and more of Ayers, as these introductory types of books are more valuable when the author provides more insight and direction into the philosopher's work and whets the reader's appetite by providing some key quotes.  Locke's material in this body of his work, as opposed to his work on political philosophy, is much more difficult, which is another reason why Ayers should have spent more time clarifying.  My concern is that a book like this might do more to turn off potential Locke readers than to excite them to read more of Locke.

Tasty (great chocolate taste), easy to make, not grainy like some gluten-free baked goods products, creates a cookie that's a little airier than normal (but that's fine), overall great product. everyone enjoyed them.

This book covers all the different ways in which humans do things unwittingly, sometimes to their own detriment.  There are 17 chapters, each covering one of these "maladies".  For example, there is the "post hoc", or the fallacy that we attribute cause to something because it precedes something else.  At best, this is faulty reasoning; at worst, it is superstition, like wearing your old, dirty underwear at every final because after you wore it the first time you aced the test. (Personally, I wear old, dirty underwear just because I like it).  There is the No True Scotsman fallacy, where when someone from your group does something that puts your group in a bad light, unless you can somehow write them off as not really part of your group.  This happens a lot with Yankee fans who use the term "True Yankee".  In their world, A-Rod is not a "True Yankee" so therefore his arrogance and steroid use cannot be ascribed to Yankees (never mind the fact that he is under contract to them and wears their uniform).  One of the more interesting phenomenon that I read was the Backfire Effect, where trying to convince someone with facts and figures only makes them feel stronger about their original positions and does not change their mind.  You see this all the time on the internet when people debate over abortion, gay rights or who the best rock-and-rill drummer was (it was not Ringo Starr, by the way).  Each of these ways in which people either work against themselves or does so unknowingly is fascinating.  Being aware that these modes of thinking exist is the first step towards guarding against them or even reversing them.

Matthew Stewart, philosopher turned management consultant and reverted back to philosopher, writes a convincing book that the core of America's founding fathers were not Christians but rather atheistic "deists".  Stewart traces Jefferson, Franklin and others' beliefs to Epicureanism which was revived by Lucretius and others, particularly Locke and Spinoza.  The core belief of deists centers around what Stewart calls the "guiding principle" of philosophy, or that every phenomenon requires an explanation and that nothing is based on faith.  For deists God is Nature, or how nature expresses itself in experience, particularly through each living thing's efforts to survive and grow.  The goal of each individual is to achieve understanding via reason.  Deist piety thus is centered on an appreciation of these relationships and interactions between reason, nature and man - together they are held in high esteem and give the (false) impression that deists have the same piety as devout Christians.Stewart covers a lot of ground, including how the deist outlook sought not just liberty from political tyranny but also from what they  perceived to be mental tyranny at the hands of existing churches.  It was their belief that man was better off without religion and instead replacing that with an improvement of the understanding, which would ultimately show that a deist mindset would result in moral living.  Stewart offers numerous quotes from the founding fathers that clearly show that they were not Christian believers but were rightly considered heretics by their contemporaries.  In Stewart's account, men like Ethan Allen and Thomas Young jump to the fore, as they were key in pushing the deist agenda.  Stewart also traces the history of the movement from Epicurus to the present day, ending with secular humanism and covering a lot of ground discussing Locke and Spinoza.My criticism of Stewart is that he is clearly on the side of the founding deists and on the side of today's secularists.  What at first read like sarcasm to emphasize the revolutionary deists point of view is actually Stewart's own voice.  He seems to hold religion and believers in as much disdain as did the deists.  That's ok if the point the book were to express his opinion, but the book is sold as a philosophical history of specific founding father's views, not as Matthew Stewart's beliefs.  Perhaps he wants to replace Christopher Hitchens as the fourth horseman of the atheist apocalypse.  Besides, I do not agree with his thesis that secularism is best.  There is no easy answer. History has shown that humanity is capable of horrendous atrocities under theocracies and under atheistic governments.  To suggest that the latter is benevolent is a case of rank ignorance.What the book definitely accomplishes is that it pulls the rug out from under the feet of current Christians who claim that the founding fathers were devout believers.  The fact is that some were and some were not.  However, they did work together to achieve what, until now, has been the most successful form of government.

This book aims to introduce the reader to some of the basic questions of philosophy: how do we know what we know?  what makes something right or wrong? is there life after death?  why do the Mets suck? (The last one is not actually covered, but as a Mets fan I think it should be).  Thomas Nagle engages the reader by asking some of the sub-questions around these fundamental questions: why should someone care if something they do is wrong if they can get away with it?  If there is life after death, what is it like?  how are causes involved in free will?  Why does every superstar free agent the Mets signs end up stinking?  (Again, that last one was not actually covered but should have been).  Although Nagel says he leaves the questions open and does not provide final answers, on some questions he lets us know very clearly what his positions are: he does not believe in an after life, for example.  Nevertheless, his questioning, prodding and provoking approach achieves its goal: it stimulates the reader to consider the questions in more depth and possibly to reassess his or her view (without ever once naming a specific philosopher).  At a very short 100 or so pages, this book is a great starting point for budding philosophers.

This book is a great resource filled with powerful yet easy to apply and inexpensive techniques.  The authorial trio collaborated on another popular book.  One of the authors is Robert Cialdini, the writer of Influence, the seminal work in this field.  There are over 50 short chapters, each explaining an inexpensive but powerful influence technique.  The authors open each chapter with a question or scenario, and then explain how a particular technique can be used to great leverage.  For example,  although it common wisdom to not be the first to make an offer during a negotiation, the authors demonstrate that doing so puts you at an advantage because you create an anchor from which the other party must begin.  You can set this anchor to your advantage.  Another technique is having patients write down their next appointment time themselves; this dramatically drops the no-show rate.For each technique, the authors describe the experiments behind it.  This is actually the one area where I am a bit skeptical, as it appears that a good number of the techniques are based on one or a few studies, with the usual participants being college students subject to the possible WEIRD (Western Educated Industrial Rich Democratic) bias.  However, a good number of the techniques are also based on well-established cognitive science.This is a great book for anyone who wants to get an ethical advantage without a heavy investment.  I wish there were a way to capture all these techniques in some sort of sheet cheat (or app), where you could select your situation (negotiation, sales, etc) and then pick from a menu of techniques.  I know that I will probably forget most of them to my own detriment.

Roger Scruton is slowly but surely becoming one of my favorite "popularizers" of philosophy.  His writing is clear even for the most difficult of topics.  At the same time, he does not talk down to the lay reader; if anything, he elevates the lay reader by inviting him up to the loftier levels of philosophical thinking through his engaging and accessible prose.  In this book, Scruton's aim was to act as a guide to the reader in how to approach philosophical questions by treading on the usual ground covered by introductions to philosophy - God, knowledge, science, morals, etc.  Scruton's goal, however, as not to spoon feed the reader the usual list of beliefs, arguments and counterarguments for each issue, but to prod the reader along by asking more questions than giving answers.  For the most part, I think Scruton is true to this goal.  On occasion he does take strong positions one way or the other, rather than leaving it up to the reader to come to their own conclusions.  This he clearly does in his discussion of sex, where he stands firmly on the side of traditional sexual morality.  Overall, though, he sticks to his plan and allows the reader, through the raising of well known arguments and counterarguments, to chew on the ideas and digest them with the notion of the reader arriving at his or her own conclusions.  I was particularly touched by Scruton's explanation of why we need God and why reduction of man to mere biology emasculates humanity from itself.

An excellent study and presentation by an eminent Stoic scholar.  Professor Sandbach, who passed away in 1991, provides a clear and accessible study of Stoic philosophy.  He covers the cultural milieu as well as specific Stoic teaching on ethics, logic and cosmology.  One has to be amazed at how much Sandbach knew about the Stoics, as with each topic and Stoic he covers, he includes criticisms of other Stoics, inconsistencies within the specific Stoic's teachings as well as multiple interpretations of the Stoic's perspective.  The impression given is that early Stoicism was in no way monolithic and went through its own growing pains as it addressed and responded to both specific day-to-day requirements of a lived philosophy and longer term metaphysical issues.  Sandbach includes the usual Stoic cast - Zeno, Chrysippus, Epictetus and Marcus Aurelius - but also goes beyond and introduces the reader to lesser known Stoic lights, like Posidonius and Hierocles.  Sandbach is not in agreement with some Stoic philosophy and makes sure to let the reader know when that is the case.  This is a short but comprehensive book that provides a valuable and accessible introduction to Stoic philosophy and its protagonists.

This book makes the case that happiness is something you can achieve by becoming more conscious of what actually contributes to it and how.  Specifically, Dolan says that day-to-day happiness is composed of pleasure and purpose - you don't want to just feel good, you also want to feel that you are doing good.  With this mindset, you can tolerate short term burdens if you know that they are being suffered for a purpose.  At the same time, pleasure must be included in the equation as it is necessary to feel happy.  Dolan covers many of the ways that we obstruct our own happiness, usually unintentionally, because we are not aware of how our mind works.  For example, we think we are going to be happy from getting things but that usually wears off quickly; at the same time, we do not give enough credit to the happiness of experiences, so we don't value them as much.  So, we focus on accumulation rather than participation, to our own detriment.  This and other examples are gathered from the burgeoning field of neuro- and behavioral economics (Daniel Kahnenam is Dolan's friend and mentor).  Dolan proposes a three point plan - Decide, Design and Do, for each area where you feel you can achieve more happiness.  For example  if you want to improve your health, you can "Decide" to go the gym; "Design" by committing to do so with a gym buddy; and "Do" by actually going to the gym.  The Design part is the one that I was most looking forward to.  However, I actually found the few recommendations here somewhat weak and mundane.  Also, the recommendations and exactly how to implement them either do not jump out at you or are somewhat unrealistic.  For example, who you hang out with has a great deal to do with your own attitude and happiness.  However, most of those we "hang out: with tends to be determine by our family members, our work colleagues and the neighborhoods we live in.  There is limited room to design who you hang out with by selecting the individuals who make up these groups.  I think a companion dose of Stoic practices would go well with those prescribed by Dolan.  Though you can plan and design your happiness, life is right now rearing back its arm to throw you a curve ball.  Better to also be prepared for that than to hope that life will only throw you a meatball, 65 mile per hour fastballs.

I often enjoy reading books about books because the authors will share experiences and put into words things that I feel but can't express. This is for the most part the case with this book.  However, the author took a chance by commenting on books that she selected somewhat at random from a shelf at the New York Society Library (which, by the way, is the best takeaway for me from this book, since I live in New York and was unaware of this amazing resource).  Because of that, the quality of books she read and reviewed varied greatly.  However, there were some good finds, like A Hero of Our Time by MIkhail Lermontov and books by Rhoda Lerman.  it's always refreshing and humbling to read books about books by authors, Rose having written a number of books herself.  Inevitably these types of books are very personal and subjective experiences, and one sometimes identifies with the perspective shared and sometimes one is jolted by it, but that is to be expected.  For example, one of the books she read was The Phantom of the Opera by Gaston Leroux.  This is the book on which the Broadway musical is based.  I and others have found "Phantom" (and I hate the single name reference) not that big a deal: it has high moments and quite a few stretches of absolute boredom.  You can go to any production and find a few people asleep.  I am now more interested in reading the book or watching the silent movie with Lon Chaney.  I agree with her characterization of detective novels.  They are mostly entertainment and not literature, although they can, depending on the author's focus, be educational as well.  I found her complaints about the way women writers are treated both valid but somewhat overdone.  Can some of them really complain that they are treated as Chick Lit if their subway ads sell them as the author of summer reading?  I am sure the author's arm wasn't twisted.  Some of the books listed I may pursue on my own, like Gil Blas, for example.  What I will definitely do is take a trip to the New York Society Library.

Buy this kit PCCK614L4 ($190 - 215 depending) and the  2 drill Combo kit PCCK604L2  ($110 - 140 depending) INSTEAD of the 6 tool combo, and it actually costs less and you will end up with four batteries (instead of 2) and an extra (3rd) drill which I can tell you if you do a lot of drilling it comes in handy + 2 charging units. The only tool that you won't get is the small reciprocating multi tool but you can buy that for $65 bucks (I personally did not want it but if you did it's still only totals $410 dollars total which is only $10 more than the six toolkit). As a licensed contractor for 20 years, I've purchased quite a few cordless kids over the years and I've always learned to look at their kits and combos and do the math and there's almost always a better way to put together a kit so that you have more than two batteries because as anyone who uses these kids will tell you two batteries is not enough unless you just occasionally use them at home.  For the record these tools are great so far and i got them because the heavy Dewalt 18v's were getting a little cumbersome for my older hands.  These are extremely light by comparison.
Instantly solved my plantar fasciitous.  I stand about 6 hours a day and was using some thick, soft, foam sandles which i figured out finally it was hurting.  these solved.

For the price, this is actually pretty good.  The tools are built and assembled with a reasonable amount of precision.  This is not like one of those impulse buy multi tools at the local auto parts store checkout stand (do NOT buy those, they break the minute u use em on s/g serious).It doesn't stack up to my Leatherman Wave but that cost $100.  Like most people, i wanted a cheap multi tool to toss into my car so i have something i can do "something" with.  ;o)

There IS a better deal For the same tools. If you buy the 4 tool combo kit PCCK614L4 ($215) and the  2 drill Combo kit PCCK604L2  ($129) it actually costs less and you will end up with four batteries (instead of 2) and an extra (3rd) drill which I can tell you if you do a lot of drilling it comes in handy. Plus, 2 charging units. The only tool that you won't get is the small reciprocating multi tool but you can buy that for $65 bucks (I personally did not want it but if you did it's still only totals $410 dollars total which is only $10 more than the six toolkit). I've purchased quite a few cordless kids over the years and I've always learned to look at their kits and combos and do the math and there's almost always a better way to put together a kit so that you have more than two batteries because as anyone who uses these kids will tell you two batteries is not enough unless you just occasionally use them at home.The tools: These are good tools, you only need read all the reviews to see they are so i will spare you more detail.  These are perhaps not quite as good as a Dewalt set (which i have), but are heavier duty than the Black and Decker 20v line.  All 3 lines (Dewalt, Porter Cable and B&D) are all owned by B&D.  The B&D set is cheaper but far as i am concerned, they are toys and you should get these instead if you actually want a tool that can "get it done."  The saw is bigger, drill chuck is a real half inch, etc, etc.  The B&D kit is a good kit for a homeowner who "might" need a tool now and then.

This is USA made, with cane sugar and brown rice syrup.  Just got mine in and tried it.  Taste is excellent, but sadly it goes away within a couple minutes and that's not really surprising when you're talking about real sugar gum so, it's disappointing but, to be expected.  I've been chewing Spry for years and bottom line, it's much better (and no i don't work for Spry, lol).  The actual gum base for Spry is a more natural/typical gum whereas the Tree Hugger is fine, but a bit softer/stickier.  And the taste and sweetness (mostly taste) in spry lasts a lot longer.  Admittedly, that's when comparing the Spry peppermint to Tree Huggers flavors and a mint is always going to maintain it's taste longer than a bubble gum, fruit gum, etc.  I think the Tree Huggers is probably better for kids but, they will go through a lot of it so be prepared to see your kids blasting through 30 balls a day!

OK first let me say I am sure this product works great, but the reason i am giving it one star is that they should let you know in GIANT ALL CAPS that this poison is like crack for cats.  My cat will literally turn over desks to get at this, and maybe that is unavoidable, but that's something they should tell you and frankly I would warn anyone that if they have cats, this is not something they should use unless they are 100% sure their cats can't get at it (and that friends is not easy).  Our office cat is currently being rushed to an animal ER because, despite my clear and urgent warnings against, my brother put some poison behind his desk, and the office cat crawled in there somehow and got to it and lapped it up, luckily i caught her doing it and, like i said, she's enroute to the ER.  So the one star is basically my way of saying "Come on, you must be able to figure out a way to make this so that cats don't love it."  If it was your animal on the way to the ER, i think you'd understand.

I replaced lenses for SpyOptic, Logan, K61, and my frames say "Made in Italy" though i noticed that the ones on line are made in China.  I only bought these glasses 6 months ago, tops so anyway, whatever.  My glasses cost $100, and i don't recall if they are polarized or not.  The China ones with non-polarized lenses are $41 on Amazon.These replacement lenses, which cost about $40, are extremely thin and also are darker than the lenses that came with my Logans.  I cannot possibly imagine that they have the same impact resistance as the lenses they replace, which are almost twice as thick.  Part of the problem is that the sockets on the frame were designed for that fatter lens, so these new, ultra thing lenses "rattle" around inside the socket.
