I used a 4 way test strip for quite a long time, but decided to try out something with a bit more detail. These 7 way strips test a lot more aspects of my hot tub water quality. I currently use a bromine setup, and it measures just as accurate as my other strips.

I used these to replace the bulbs in my knock off scentsy warmers. They last the standard number of hours a typical bulb would (I am already on my second bulb in this pack), but it does the job: keeps the dish hot to melt wax.

This is the best solar LED light I have purchased to date. I have tried others in the past, but have been terribly let down.I installed this into my large shed with a loft. There was enough cable to go from the ceiling, down the side of the shed, and outdoors to an ideal spot for solar exposure. The pull string is long enough to reach down so it can be easily turned on by anyone.The light is very bright and perfect for lighting up the entire shed at night. There is even a red LED that is always on to help you find it in the dark.I have not tested how long it runs for, but it is always fully charged and bright when I need it.
A very cool color temperature (blueish), but fit our Mitsubishi Outlander perfectly.
Fits my Colman Lay-Z-Spa perfectly. It has enough room for a phone, and two cup holders. While not massive in size, it does the job.

Very cool light strip!There is plenty of lead on this, which allows me to plug this above our kitchen cabinets and power it with a hidden outlet. Yes, its expensive. No, they are never long enough, but I will not judge the product on this alone.Why not 5 stars? I am not too impressed with the non-defused RGB LEDs. Seeing the color separation reflecting off things drives me nuts and cheapens the ambiance.Overall, I am a big fan of Hue and we have it supplement our lighting in every room. The lights are programmed to "follow the sun", with a simulated whole house sunrise in the morning, daylight color temps during the day, a simulated sunset, and eventually night time ambiance. It really helps waking up in the morning and being in tune with the time of day. We sometimes don't get a lot of sun in Seattle :)

I purchased this to connect an extension cord to a hot tub 120V plug. I also put a kill-a-watt to monitor power usage. There is plenty of room in the box for other things, and it appears to have sealed up very nicely for our Washington weather. Sometimes the clasps on the sides do fall off after opening, but this is an easy fix. They simply snap right back on.The box features snaps on the back, two clasps on each side, and a sticky sealing gasket on the tops and bottoms of where the plugs are routed.
These test strips have worked out great for me. The color printing on the bottle matches identically with the color indication from the strip.

I bought some Ikea closet lights with halogen bulbs. They got very hot and used a ton of power. Ugh, time for some LEDs.These were perfect replacements for the Grundtal lights. They look the same, exact color. Use a ton less power. And do not get warm.

I almost did not buy this microscope because of the lower resolution camera. But at the price point, it was a great buy, so I went ahead and purchased it.To my surprise, the camera is actually very good quality, even if its only 640x480.The camera shows up as a webcam, so you can plug it into just about any computer. On Mac OSX, I was able to use it in Photobooth (great for video and pictures) as well as FaceTime. My daughter was able to make a FaceTime call showing video from the microscope, which was very impressive.The optics and construction are high quality. I think a lot of users looking for an inexpensive but not cheap feeling microscope will be happy with this.While it has a lot of features, the manual is absolutely useless. It does not tell you how any part of the microscope works. For example, turning to maximum magnification rendered the image so dark, I could not see it. It took me 20 minutes to realize an unlabeled dial on the microscope controlled the light intensity. After that, I could see fine. There is also an iris selection labeled 1-9 (no idea what this does), and a focus knob which is obvious. There is no fine focus, so you will have to be very careful when focusing at high magnifications. It is not impossible though.Some cons of this microscope: easy to hit the max magnification lens on the slide if you are focused in past a certain point, easy to hit the lens on the slide if you are past the focus point, and strange camera flicker under certain lighting conditions (it can be mitigated by changing the light intensity slightly). I do not regret this purchase.
This is a great break out for TRRS connectors on laptop and phones.

This mask makes the costume. It is very authentic looking and little kids were thinking I was the real batman. This was used to supplement the muscle dark knight costume suit that I bought. It came with a not-so-great fabric mask, so if you want to actually look like batman, this rubber mask is a must.One thing you need to consider is that a lot of costumes have a cape + mask combo. You will need to figure out something for our cape.

Purchasing a hard tub is an incredible commitment in time, chemistry, and maintenance (never mind the thousands of dollars to purchase and install). After seeing this Coleman steeply discounted on Black Friday at another retailer, I decided to give this inflatable a try.The Coleman is a branded variant of the Lay-Z Spa, and other than color, it appears to be identical to the other Lay-Z Spa sold. However, it appears that it holds about 50 gallons more water. It plugs into 120V, which makes it extremely easy to plug and play. Just be careful what else you have on the circuit with this tub, as it *will* consume an entire 15A circuit when you take in account safety margins. I have a Kill-a-Watt connected in series so I can monitor its power consumption (more later).The little green ovalish box is the brains of the operation. It contains the heater, a blower (which doubles as both inflator and bubble maker), and a membrane control panel. I have found it difficult to read during the day. The dark LED segments show bright white while the red is dimly lit.Setup:The instructions are not the best. Warnings are randomly scattered all over the place, making it difficult to read. While physically using the inflator works great, the pressure gauge is not even to the right scale needed to properly measure the correct pressure required. The first marking on the gauge is 2 psi and there is no 1 psi marking! Expect it to move a couple of millimeters and not point anything in particular when you reach 1.2 psi. The main air chamber has a very nice locking connector with a high quality one way air valve, so it is not like blowing up a pool inflatable. The sides are very firm once inflation is complete.*Pro Tip* While inflating, its very likely the keypad will auto lock before you are done. Make sure you unlock it again ahead of time, otherwise you'll spend a minute trying to figure out why the heck it won't turn off and overinflate your pool!There is a ground pad that looks like thick bubble wrap. There is still bits of snow on the ground, and it felt warm sitting on top of it. Although the instructions mentioned nothing of this pad, I faced the flat side down and put the pool on top of it. Do this before you put in the water!The hoses connect up nicely and it took me a couple of minutes to finish the connection. Expect it to take an hour or two to fill up the tub with your hose. I'd imagine, the warmer the water, the better. I couldn't find my sink adapter, so I just used whatever bitter cold water came out of the garden hose though.Operation:People complain about how slow 120V systems are to heat up. This is because you are physically restricted by the number of watts you can pull through a typical house plug. The tub has a two stage heater and can pull between 700 and 1200 watts.  It apparently decides to use full wattage if the water is cold enough. It will switch to 2 elements after about a minute from my observation. When heating, it also runs the pump. This means only 1-2F degrees an hour of warming per hour. While they made a good effort to insulate the tub, it still is an inflatable.The bubbles are surprisingly large for just blowing air into a holed ring in the bottom. It looks just like a typical hard tub. Just remember: the amount of power required to create the bubbles takes away from the power needed for full heating capability. My tub is not at temperature yet (57F), but as it stands now, it turns off all heating in order to make bubbles.Sound:The heater + pump does not make much sound. Its a quiet hum, around 50 dB (or what is called a "quiet street" sound level or maybe a refrigerator hum). Obviously bubbles make a lot more noise, and there is a slight vacuum cleaner sound. But I would imagine a lot of other hot tubs have similar noise levels.Chemicals:You need proper chemicals in your spa. Not putting any in because its "just you" or randomly throwing in a tablet into the floater are not good ideas. You can get sick or chemically burned. The manual is completely useless and tells you to "go to a spa store" to learn about some "chemicals". Thanks guys. Just what I need is another salesmen who will try to sell me a hard tub. Searching on the internet is not much help either, as it is full of snake oil additives, unsound science on forums, etc.Make sure you buy a pack of test strips, as blindly adding chemicals can be very dangerous. You will want to know pH, chlorine/bromine level, and alkalinity.For the type of chemicals, there are two routes to go: Bromine or Chlorine.Bromine is a little bit more work but has some purported benefits. It has less odor, can be restored using a shock, etc. People in our hot tub notice little to no odor.Read the directions, but typically one will add Sodium Bromide (granules) to bring the Bromine levels up to an initial value. After that, you will likely use a Bromine tablet in the floater (1"). You will have to apply a "shock" to convert all that Bromine into free Bromine if your granules do not also include a shock.Pick up some pH Up and pH Down. Its cheap. When I initially filled it, my water was around 6.8 (too low). My Alkalinity is slightly low as well, and usually pH Up will boost this incidentally. Your water will be different.You can use the bubbles to mix chemicals as needed.Energy consumption (from Kill-A-Watt):Standby: 5-8 Watts (electronics only)Pump: 27 WattsBubbles: 650 WattsHeater: ~700 Watts with one element, ~1200 Watts both elements (automatic)Bubbles + Heater: Doesn't appear possible** Update - 1 week of usage **In the Seattle winter with 40F days, this hot tub typically takes around 24-30 hours to reach temperature from cold hose water. It burns around 40kWh of electricity to heat this water up, so the initial startup costs can be costly. (40 * $0.10 = $4.00). I also noticed that it takes a lot of energy to maintain 104F (it runs 100% of the time), and you might be looking at $90 in electricity over the month! This is likely an insulation issue.* however * I have discovered that simply lowering the temperature a couple degrees when you are not using it makes a huge difference. Backing off the temperature, to say, 100F, practically quartered the power consumption. I should have some better numbers later, but this is the way to go. It only takes about an hour to go from 100F to 104F in the worst case, so not much is lost.We have used it quite a few times over the week, and it was very enjoyable. The tub is soft and comfortable, much more than a fiberglass or tile tub. I actually prefer it. The surround is still very firm and has not lost inflation.** Update - 6 months later **The inflatable vessel has developed some problems (leaks) and I have now engaged the warranty process. I am waiting for my RMA to be approved. I could not tell you if this is normal for this hot tub or not. I got my first leak on one of the seams. It was a small hole and I easily patched it. But then another developed...then another...in each case I noticed the internal ribbing completely failed. Eventually, a large section failed and it was hard to keep up with batching all of these holes as the hot tub slowly tore itself apart. These holes developed while nobody was using the hot tub. I will keep this updated with the progress on this. If the customer support is sufficient, I am not going to dock any stars on this review.
There are two requirements of a USB to Serial converter:1) Conversion of USB to the unworthy, legacy serial bus2) Hassle free Windows and Mac (Modern OSX) compatibilityIt passed the test.
This was a lot of fun during this summer's Thomas the Train birthday. If you are looking to serve a set of cupcakes, you may want this inexpensive holder.
These cables work and can metalically transport the low bar of 20KHz without any problems. I have not done extensive stress tests on the cabling, but they should tolerate some reasonable abuse.

This adapter adapts my Nikkor lenses to use on my Fuji body (X-T1).It works perfectly, and looks really nice as well. Like the flat black and silver trim.The silver ring in the center is an aperture control, so it works for even Nikon G lenses without an aperture ring, an allows you to manually control the aperture on your Fuji.My copy is a bit tight on the Nikon receiving end, but works very well. And as i've had some that were too loose, it doesnt bother me.The aperture ring has 6-7 clicks, so its better than the Fotiodix version i have with only 3-4.Not much more to say, but that it works well and allows me to use all of my Nikon lenses on a Fuji body.Of course, this is all manual control, no Autofocus or Autoexposure control--just a metal tube that allows you to mount Nikon lenses.At this price, its a great deal, and works wonderfully. It wasnt available for Prime when i got it, and took about 2 weeks to get it.

So far, my favorite card reader.I've been shooting professionally for 25 years, and using card readers since the Nikon D1. Compact Flash cards and readers are becoming scarce, as SD is now more the norm. But pro bodies still have CF cards, including my D4.As my old one was only USB 2, i figured it was time for an upgrade. Tried another USB 3 card reader, and it failed after 2 months (pin bent in the CF card slot), so went in search again.There are varied reviews on this Lexar reader, but upon closer inspection, it seems there are at least 3 models of this reader (that all look the same externally). The one i got is model # LRW400CRBNA, with a 2015 date on the box. This 400 series i think is the latest at the time i am writing this.It is indeed USB 3, with a usb3 cord as well, that inputs into the back of the device. I like that it has an interchangable cord, and comes with one.I can swap other devices using the same cord--such as my Pioneer external BR burner, another great product:http://www.amazon.com/Portable-External-CyberLink-Software-BDR-XD05/dp/B00HSHLZJ8/ref=sr_1_8?ie=UTF8&qid=1434128497&sr=8-8&keywords=pioneer+bluray+writerIt has a great form factor, as the shell can enclose and protect itself. It stays open very well in use. When closed, the buttons on the side pop open the clamshell--this is very sensitive, almost like a mousetrap, and snaps open! Not a big deal, but kind of surprised me how sensitive it was.It can download TWO CARDS at ONCE--my main reason for purchase. So you can put a CF card and SD card and upload them both simultaneously. It is much easier to put in the CF card first, as it is on the bottom.It is VERY FAST at READING both cards. This of course, is dependent on your computer, usb ports, etc. But its the fastest reader i have ever used (other than other formats, such as the Sony XQD).It has a nice padded rubber bottom that grips relatively well and stays in place. Seems trivial, but its nice.As it only has 2 cards formats, it doesnt use a gazillion drive letters on your computer like some of those readers with 10 or more formats. If you only need SD and/or CF, this is the reader for you. I dont have or care for any of those other weird formats. Of course, you can just use a SD card adapter if you need to put in a MicroSD card.The device was recognized immediately on my two computers, with no need to download drivers or install software. WHEW, what a relief--No crappy proprietary software to put on my machines.It just works well. Reads cards from every camera ive put in it so far (Nikon D4, D7000, D300s, Fuji XT1, etc) with no glitches.Couldnt be happier to have something work well, with NO HASSLES.I will update if i ever have a problem, or if the product fails. Thanks for reading, hope this has been of help to you!

As an early adopter of the Piston 2, I was pleasantly surprised by the sound quality and features of the Piston 2, but there were a few things I would have changed: the bass was a bit too bloated, the treble a bit too harsh, and the midrange quite lacking. But I still liked the sound overall, despite the heavy V-shaped signature, because the price was phenomenal for the quality and features, and they were/are still better than many earbuds in the price range.Basically, I find the Piston 3 to be better in almost every way:The BASS is certainly still very strong, in fact I find it to be more impactful in the lower register with a tighter, faster attack. It loses some of the mid-bass hump of the 2’s, albeit a bit less warm as well, but more natural. It still kicks with authority, but is very well-controlled and never boomy, bloaty and muddy.The MIDRANGE is so very much more present that at first it was a bit of a shock. As most of my IEMs have too low of a MR, my EQ settings were pumped up to compensate, so I needed to flatten them out some. With the P3, the MR is very detailed, accurate, and present. Vocals are a pleasure, with articulation that is just amazing in this price range. I find myself hearing things I did not hear with lesser IEMs. They can be very revealing and true to the source though, and with some recordings can be a bit glaring, but I believe fairly neutral.The TREBLE is airy, detailed, and articulate, and never harsh or tinny. I found the Piston 2 to be a bit too sizzly, with a more artificial air. I love strong detailed treble, and it is ever-present in the P3, but with a bit of a roll-off to be non-fatiguing as well. With the treble and MR, the level of articulation and detail is simply amazing. This is even in comparison to much higher-priced IEMs, including my custom-molded UE Triple-Fi 10s. Because of this enhanced detail, bad recordings or poor-quality MP3 and the like are much more of notice, and I hear a bit more sibilance than in other earphones, but it is never out of place. I think the phones are just so much more resolving than anything else in this price range, and you will notice lisps in vocals, poor recordings or mastering, and poor compression in low-res files.The SOUNDSTAGE is amazing for an IEM, one of the best I have heard. There is a very WIDE airy stage, much more like open-air headphones vs. closed. Depth is good, but not nearly as strong as width. I find myself rolling my eyes back and forth, hearing the wideness of the staging and mixing. Because I believe the outside housing to have some sort of porting, sound leakage (outward) is maybe a bit more pronounced, but probably the very reason the soundstage sounds as it does. It shouldn’t be that noticeable to anyone else but in a very quiet environment, or if you are listening to music too loudly. ISOLATION is pretty good, with most outside sounds diminished and muffled. Not as strongly as some deeper-inserted IEMs, but still good.SENSITIVITY is high, so the Pistons are also great for portability--I find a separate headphone amp unnecessary, with plenty of volume straight out of my smartphone (Note 3, using PowerAMP as my music player—with custom EQ settings).While the Piston3 is much more articulate, with a flatter frequency response and less overall warmth, vocals are silky smooth and inviting, the overall sound signature more clinical and ACCURATE, while still retaining a FUN, involving musicality.FIT and COMFORT to my ear is much better than the Piston 2 also. The nozzle is smaller, the outer shell still fits in your pinna and stays in place better. The finish looks very nice, and subtly understated. I was not fond of the shiny gold personally though. Gone is the sharp edge of the metal shell, as the Piston 3 is mostly plastic, but still looks very attractive and just feels more comfortable and smooth in the ear. Of course, fit is very arbitrary, so your mileage may vary. I am using the medium rubber buds that came on the earphones. Tried the others, but the medium was the best fit for me.The braided cloth-like CABLE is the same on the Piston 3, but the top part, above the convergent cord, is of a rubber texture. I think I would prefer the cloth cord the whole length, as the rubber seems more prone to tangling, and more microphonic.The controls are now on the right side of the top cord, which makes it easy to tell the Left/Right configuration, puts the microphone closer to your mouth, and is fairly easy to reach. But I would still rather the mic be in that position and have the controls separate, lower on the cord, as I find it easier to see and manipulate (the current V-Moda headphone cable is perfect in that regard). The controls work very well, just as they do on the P2, with solid clicks for Play/Pause, double-click for track advance (common Android use). The top/bottom buttons control Up/Down Volume. The controls work better than any IEM I’ve had, which is one of the main reasons I loved the Piston 2. Not sure why very high-priced IEMs cannot include these features!They package is nearly the same as on the Piston 2--but alas, there is no chocolate aroma, or any other for that matter. That was a cool and original marketing feature for the Piston 2s, I must say Smile.The Piston 3’s are just leaps above any budget-priced audio product that I have ever found. They are simply phenomenal for the price, unheard of just a few years ago. {For reference, I have training as a recording engineer, listen to music on higher end headphones, including Shure SRH-940’s, V-Moda M-100, XS, and AT M-50’s. I also build my own custom hi-fi speakers from scratch including a 4-way tower monitor with ribbon tweeters and 4th-order crossover networks, with music processed through DACs, rack studio components including 31-band EQ, compressors, etc. and a Hi-end T-amp}. Are the Piston3 as good as some of the high-end systems I listen on? In short, of course not, but the sound quality available in the Piston3 is the best I have ever heard--by far--for a mere $20! I am utterly astounded, and found myself just wanting to listen to music even more after my initial “critique.” And that’s what my main impression is: I just ENJOY listening to the Piston 3, and feel that I got way more for the money I spent than maybe I even should have!!***UPDATE: please also see my review of the Piston 3 YOUTH EDITION, with a photo comparing the two versions***

Tried the others, but the medium was the best fit for me.The braided cloth-like CABLE is the same on the Piston 3, but the top part, above the convergent cord, is of a rubber texture. I think I would prefer the cloth cord the whole length, as the rubber seems more prone to tangling, and more microphonic.The controls are now on the right side of the top cord, which makes it easy to tell the Left/Right configuration, puts the microphone closer to your mouth, and is fairly easy to reach. But I would still rather the mic be in that position and have the controls separate, lower on the cord, as I find it easier to see and manipulate (the current V-Moda headphone cable is perfect in that regard). The controls work very well, just as they do on the P2, with solid clicks for Play/Pause, double-click for track advance (common Android use). The top/bottom buttons control Up/Down Volume. The controls work better than any IEM I’ve had, which is one of the main reasons I loved the Piston 2. Not sure why very high-priced IEMs cannot include these features!They package is nearly the same as on the Piston 2--but alas, there is no chocolate aroma, or any other for that matter. That was a cool and original marketing feature for the Piston 2s, I must say Smile.The Piston 3’s are just leaps above any budget-priced audio product that I have ever found. They are simply phenomenal for the price, unheard of just a few years ago. {For reference, I have training as a recording engineer, listen to music on higher end headphones, including Shure SRH-940’s, V-Moda M-100, XS, and AT M-50’s. I also build my own custom hi-fi speakers from scratch including a 4-way tower monitor with ribbon tweeters and 4th-order crossover networks, with music processed through DACs, rack studio components including 31-band EQ, compressors, etc. and a Hi-end T-amp}. Are the Piston3 as good as some of the high-end systems I listen on? In short, of course not, but the sound quality available in the Piston3 is the best I have ever heard--by far--for a mere $20! I am utterly astounded, and found myself just wanting to listen to music even more after my initial “critique.” And that’s what my main impression is: I just ENJOY listening to the Piston 3, and feel that I got way more for the money I spent than maybe I even should have!!***UPDATE: please also see my review of the Piston 3 YOUTH EDITION, with a photo comparing the two versions***

I ordered the Piston 3 YOUTH EDITION on speculation that it uses the same driver as the regular Piston 3.Below is my review for the original Piston 3, i will comment on the differences between the two versions following:As an early adopter of the Piston 2, I was pleasantly surprised by the sound quality and features of the Piston 2, but there were a few things I would have changed: the bass was a bit too bloated, the treble a bit too harsh, and the midrange quite lacking. But I still liked the sound overall, despite the heavy V-shaped signature, because the price was phenomenal for the quality and features, and they were/are still better than many earbuds in the price range.Basically, I find the Piston 3 to be better in almost every way:The BASS is certainly still very strong, in fact I find it to be more impactful in the lower register with a tighter, faster attack. It loses some of the mid-bass hump of the 2’s, albeit a bit less warm as well, but more natural. It still kicks with authority, but is very well-controlled and never boomy, bloaty and muddy.The MIDRANGE is so very much more present that at first it was a bit of a shock. As most of my IEMs have too low of a MR, my EQ settings were pumped up to compensate, so I needed to flatten them out some. With the P3, the MR is very detailed, accurate, and present. Vocals are a pleasure, with articulation that is just amazing in this price range. I find myself hearing things I did not hear with lesser IEMs. They can be very revealing and true to the source though, and with some recordings can be a bit glaring, but I believe fairly neutral.The TREBLE is airy, detailed, and articulate, and never harsh or tinny. I found the Piston 2 to be a bit too sizzly, with a more artificial air. I love strong detailed treble, and it is ever-present in the P3, but with a bit of a roll-off to be non-fatiguing as well. With the treble and MR, the level of articulation and detail is simply amazing. This is even in comparison to much higher-priced IEMs, including my custom-molded UE Triple-Fi 10s. Because of this enhanced detail, bad recordings or poor-quality MP3 and the like are much more of notice, and I hear a bit more sibilance than in other earphones, but it is never out of place. I think the phones are just so much more resolving than anything else in this price range, and you will notice lisps in vocals, poor recordings or mastering, and poor compression in low-res files.The SOUNDSTAGE is amazing for an IEM, one of the best I have heard. There is a very WIDE airy stage, much more like open-air headphones vs. closed. Depth is good, but not nearly as strong as width. I find myself rolling my eyes back and forth, hearing the wideness of the staging and mixing. Because I believe the outside housing to have some sort of porting, sound leakage (outward) is maybe a bit more pronounced, but probably the very reason the soundstage sounds as it does. It shouldn’t be that noticeable to anyone else but in a very quiet environment, or if you are listening to music too loudly. ISOLATION is pretty good, with most outside sounds diminished and muffled. Not as strongly as some deeper-inserted IEMs, but still good.SENSITIVITY is high, so the Pistons are also great for portability--I find a separate headphone amp unnecessary, with plenty of volume straight out of my smartphone (Note 3, using PowerAMP as my music player—with custom EQ settings).While the Piston3 is much more articulate, with a flatter frequency response and less overall warmth, vocals are silky smooth and inviting, the overall sound signature more clinical and ACCURATE, while still retaining a FUN, involving musicality.FIT and COMFORT to my ear is much better than the Piston 2 also. The nozzle is smaller, the outer shell still fits in your pinna and stays in place better. The finish looks very nice, and subtly understated. I was not fond of the shiny gold personally though. Gone is the sharp edge of the metal shell, as the Piston 3 is mostly plastic, but still looks very attractive and just feels more comfortable and smooth in the ear. Of course, fit is very arbitrary, so your mileage may vary. I am using the medium rubber buds that came on the earphones. Tried the others, but the medium was the best fit for me.The braided cloth-like CABLE is the same on the Piston 3, but the top part, above the convergent cord, is of a rubber texture. I think I would prefer the cloth cord the whole length, as the rubber seems more prone to tangling, and more microphonic.The controls are now on the right side of the top cord, which makes it easy to tell the Left/Right configuration, puts the microphone closer to your mouth, and is fairly easy to reach. But I would still rather the mic be in that position and have the controls separate, lower on the cord, as I find it easier to see and manipulate (the current V-Moda headphone cable is perfect in that regard). The controls work very well, just as they do on the P2, with solid clicks for Play/Pause, double-click for track advance (common Android use). The top/bottom buttons control Up/Down Volume. The controls work better than any IEM I’ve had, which is one of the main reasons I loved the Piston 2. Not sure why very high-priced IEMs cannot include these features!They package is nearly the same as on the Piston 2--but alas, there is no chocolate aroma, or any other for that matter. That was a cool and original marketing feature for the Piston 2s, I must say Smile.The Piston 3’s are just leaps above any budget-priced audio product that I have ever found. They are simply phenomenal for the price, unheard of just a few years ago. {For reference, I have training as a recording engineer, listen to music on higher end headphones, including Shure SRH-940’s, V-Moda M-100, XS, and AT M-50’s. I also build my own custom hi-fi speakers from scratch including a 4-way tower monitor with ribbon tweeters and 4th-order crossover networks, with music processed through DACs, rack studio components including 31-band EQ, compressors, etc. and a Hi-end T-amp}. Are the Piston3 as good as some of the high-end systems I listen on? In short, of course not, but the sound quality available in the Piston3 is the best I have ever heard--by far--for a mere $20! I am utterly astounded, and found myself just wanting to listen to music even more after my initial “critique.” And that’s what my main impression is: I just ENJOY listening to the Piston 3, and feel that I got way more for the money I spent than maybe I even should have!!COMPARISONS BETWEEN original Piston 3 and this YOUTH EDITION:Soundwise, at first i thought the YE to be a bit more bloated in bass, with less definition. But that was straight out of the box, and as my orginal P3 has many more hours of listening on it, i do not want to make a complete statement, and think that with more burn-in the sound should be the same.I have no definitive knowledge of the drivers between the two models, but have read that they share the same driver, and from the sound signature, i believe this is true.The plastic housing of the two models is the same form factor, but the YE removes the metal accent pieces along the outside and along the bridge of the cable attachment. The back of the housing on the YE (the part you see, not in your ear) is a bit smaller and tapered vs the P3. It uses a plastic or rubbery FLAT RIBBON type cord, the entire length of the cable. The control buttons are in the same position, down about 6 inches on the right earpiece. The control piece (which also houses the microphone on both versions) is made entirely of plastic on the YE, is flatter like the cable, and the 3 buttons are larger rectangle boxes that are more separated than the very thin long buttons on the original P3. Actually, i like this control better, as the buttons are a bit easier to feel and distinguish apart. I'd prefer that there was maybe a difference in the middle button (larger or raised above the other two, or indented). And i'd prefer that the mic and control were separated, with the mic in this placement and the control further down the cord in the center, where it could be more easily seen and used.Both cords are almost the same length, with the YE being just a bit shorter (less than an inch). Both seem sturdy enough, and both are straight plugs--i'd prefer a low-profile right-angle plug, but the straight version may be more universal.The ribbon cable on the YE is harder to roll up, takes up more space (if you try to put it in a small case) and unravels. It also seems to hold its packaged form, and doesnt straighten out well. It may be more microphonic as well. I prefer the cloth-like cable on the bottom part of the P3 and the Piston vs.2. I wish it was the entire length of the vs.3 in fact, without the rubber part attached to the earbuds. The cloth fiber cable is way more supple, stays in a straight line when unfolded, and folds very easily and tightly for storage. Its just a much better cable.The YE also deletes the gold-plating on the 4-pin standard 3.5mm plug, and the metal housing of the plug. Basically, the flat rubber cord runs the entire length from plug to earbuds, with no metal parts.As such, the YE seems lighter and gives the impression of a cheaper build, but i am not saying it is of lesser quality or construction.In summary, i like the control buttons better on the YE, the cable better on the original P3 (or P2). The sound on both the P3 and P3 YE is just phenomenal. I believe it to be the best SQ at the moment in a budget earphone.So the YE, at $10 or so, is an even better value than the P3, but i prefer the original P3 overall, and both are an incredible value for such a high quality sound signature!***I have posted a photo showing both the Xiaomi Piston 3 and this Piston 3 Youth Edition, side by side. Notice that the YE has the rubber flat ribbon cable throughout. ***

They are not horrible earbuds. But they are certainly not the greatest either--something that (at the time i am writing this) over 90% of the reviewers would have you believe. If you read their reviews, they were all sent this product for free. This is a trend on Amazon i am finding disheartening. I bought this item based on the absolutely glowing reviews, as many others do, and i think these reviewers are NOT being as honest as someone who PAID for an item.I dont like to pin myself as an audiophile, but i have some knowledge of the quality of audio. I have training as a recording engineer. I build my own hi-fi speakers/monitors from scratch including the crossover networks. I've bought and listened to many headphones and IEMs. I record/mix/edit A/V content for production.This set has a lot going for it. They look good (although the gold is too showy for my personal taste). The cord is one of the best i've used--it doesnt tangle, has a great right-angle plug which i love. It also isn't very microphonic, something that even high-prices IEMs could learn from. The one-button control works well to play/pause/skip tracks. It does NOT have a volume control, which some reviewers (in their haste to write their review for a free product) state that it does.Soundwise, it isn't that bad either--for the price. It does represent a wide frequency range, but it is VERY BLOATED in the mid-bass region. If you deem yourself a "basshead" maybe you will like it. The bass is bloomy, with slow attack, pumped up in the 100hz range without a tight controlled lower bass. The mids are more recessed, but listenable--but not resolving, with a somehow artificial sound. Highs are rolled off, which is non-fatiguing but also not airy and lending to articulation.For my ears in particular (this of course will vary with ANY in ear monitor-style of earphones) they are very uncomfortable, and hurt my ears within minutes of use. The nozzle does not go far enough in my ears before the large-diameter of the bud hits my pinna. The sharp metal edges of the buds dont help any.As stated, i have heard much worse earbuds, and for the price the quality of the product is good. They are very well made and seem like they would hold up to use, the features are good and the sound is good for the price range. But for me they are uncomfortable (the main reason i am sending them back) and just dont sound good enough, or as i thought they would, BASED ON the glowing reviews thus far.I hope my review is of help, as i have tried to be as honest and detailed as possible. Thanks for taking the time to read my observations.If you are loving yours, that's great and i am happy for you. If you got them for free, that;s an even better deal for you.

This tiny little RC boat is actually much better than i even anticipated!It uses a small rectangular brushed motor, has 2.4ghz radio system, and a true micro servo (with regular hobby grade connector plug) for the rudder. The tiny ESC board also houses the receiver, and a tiny wire goes into the antenna on the back of the boat.Running, it is perfectly fine as is. I had no loss of control or communication from the TX. It turns sharply and has an adequate speed.It is also completely water-tight. Not a single drop of water got into my boat. It uses a great hatch that locks in place in the front with a pin, and a simple turn of the lever on the back locks it down tightly. No tape is needed, and it is simple and effective. This is in my opinion how all RC boat hatches should work. The tiny hole where the front pin locks in is even enclosed so there is no chance of a leak there.Of course, i had planned to modify mine from purchase, so i have upgraded mine to a very small brushless motor, ESC, and a Spektrum RX, running with my DX8 TX. I have built a custom cooling coil/jacket for the motor. The simple bar across the stock motor worked, but did not provide very adequate cooling. The motor was extremely hot after one run, not even fully discharging the included lipo pack.I am now using a 2s 500mAh pack for even longer runs, with a cooler motor.The self-righting feature does work. The boat will turn itself over if it flips. If you modify yours as i have to need to make sure the CG is correct and one side had more weight for proper self-righting. I could not get my boat to flip with the stock setup though. :)For this price, this is an excellent tiny RC boat, with great features, and EVERYTHING is included. Even the LIPO battery pack and a USB charger, and everything worked great on the one i received. Thinking of getting another one, just for the kick of being able to modify it again.I do wish that you could pick the color that you want though. I got the yellow one, which looks fine. I have added some stripes and other paint trims to mine.FUN BOAT, that is TRULY A MICRO SIZE!!

You can find much better, for a cheaper price even.Unfortunately, i sized, cut, and mounted my strip to a multi-rotor before testing. If you do buy this product, i'd suggest you test it first, so you can send it back!There are horrendous soldering joints, burnt traces, etc.that should be an indicator of its mediocrity.Once powered, 5 of the LEDs were not working. The mounting adhesion is not good either and the strip will come loose easily. Which, for my case, is good--since i will need to replace it with something much better. Also, the strip seems to need much more power than other similar strips to output a decent light. Not sure what resistors they are using, but the light is dim and uneven. This is tested with both 2S and 3S LIPO packs. Even with a fully-charged 3s pack (confirmed on my voltmeter to be putting out 11.52 volts) the light is dim and uneven across the strip.Seriously, this is a junk LED strip for a rather high price--for the amount of surface-mounted LEDs on the strip (even if ALL of them actually worked)!

Having loved the original Nano Qx,  I certainly wanted this one.  I had actually installed my own tiny smd LEDs in my old nano,  which helps so much in quads for orientation, not just looks.  It's great that these are installed,  and look great and are easy to see,  even outside for much of the time!  However,  there are several reports surfacing that the LEDs are going out.  Mine are still fine,  but I fear this could be a flaw in the design as the entire PCB board is essentially the frame. Any crack in this frame could render a broken trace making things problematic.  Maybe others are just having very hard crashes,  which  I'd just advise to avoid.  ;)Also,  I had some issues programming mine,  and the documentation was not in the manual,  but once sorted out (using DX8), it flies very well.Compared to the original nano,  which I still love,  it is also very stable but I think needs more room to stretch it's legs,  so I am still happier flying the original nano in smaller spaces/indoors.  This one though I think flies better outdoors,  and as it's heavier,  can withstand some wind much better! It can zoom along well.The 3 flight modes work well,  and I love how the model can be flown inverted with no change in controls in the first 2 modes.  Flips are easy and controlled (half flip or full 180 depending on mode), or all-out full control for the 3d pros and heli masters.It's a great flying quad and a good addition to the nano line.  I love that you can generally keep flying if you turn the quad upside down in a crash, and not have to retrieve it!  But, this doesn't work so well in grass however.I love the inverted look,  the white-red colors along with the LEDs make it easy to track. Wouldn't mind another choice for a canopy.Great,  stable mini quad that works great with your own transmitter (bnf version means no radio is included).  Like the USB charger as well,  and it charges up fairly fast,  but I'd still recommend at least a few more batteries.  I'm getting 5-6 minutes of flight time with my stock battery,  with a mix of fast and slow flying,  with full out 3d, Flips,  and heart throttle I'd expect 4-5.It's a fun ride,  and a great step up from original! We'll just have to wait and see on the longevity of the new brushed motors and possible led problems.

Good stuff.I have used this wire for adding LED lighting to RC micro quads and planes using tiny surface-mount LEDs.Its a good quality wire that is light yet strong with good conductivity.It has an outer film that covers the wire that needs to be melted off with your soldering iron before you can get the solder to melt and make connection. Otherwise, the wires look bare, but they can touch with no shorting.Good service from the company with fast shipping. It is made in the USA.

My wife and I have been getting Carefresh Complete for our pet bunny for several years. Within the last year, they have changed the formula, apparently. Now, it contains tiny particles of hay, which are in reality MOSTLY DUST PARTICLES of shredded hay. You can literally see a cloud of dust coming out of the bag when you open it or attempt to pour the contents into a container or your pet's food dish. When this first happened, our bunny hungrily tried to eat his food but became choked on the dust and started coughing and sneezing. I also am affected by the dust. My nose is running as i write this review, after spending about 30 minutes SIFTING the food so that most of the dust particles are taken out.I might add at this point that the product for more than 5 years has not contained this tiny shredded dust particles, and that this in not a one-time thing. The last 5 bags that we have purchased have been consistently bad.After the second bag, I attempted to contact CareFresh customer service. I did not receive ANY response whatsoever. Again, after the fourth bag purchased, I contacted them twice. Through their customer email as well as their online customer response box. To this day, I have not heard a single response from CareFresh.I'd like to add that I have been a responsible pet rabbit owner for many years. I have tried many brands. I would certainly recommend the Oxbow foods, but our Muffin is very picky and really liked the Carefresh after we started using it. For the most part, the food it contains is as it was before, the pellets seem green and fresh, with some bits of treat but not the harmful junk that is in some rabbit foods.We also feed our rabbit fresh quality Timothy Hay, and give him a fresh handful daily. I do not want tiny pieces of shredded hay and mostly DUST particles in his food however. I am attaching a photo of my most recent "sifting" process, as I want to stress that the dust is not the normal packaging, breakage of pellets in transit, etc. This is HUGE amount of DUST that is a large portion of the entire bag of food!Not only is this completely ridiculous as the cost of on bag is generally between $11-15, it is HARMFUL to your pet's health.As I can also attest, Carefresh CARES NOTHING for its customers, as they do not even respond to inquiries.This rabbit food is not fresh, and and there is no care taken for the health of your pet, nor is there any concern for you, the customer.This company should change its name.

As a RC'r for decades,  I've seen a lot of evolution in model aircraft.  This Nano QX is one of my favorites. It's tiny,  so it's very portable.  It can fly indoors  in small spaces,  and quite well outdoors as well.  Of course,  wind can be an issue with any very small and light aircraft,  but the nano does quite well in light wind and can really zoom along with room to stretch it's legs.  It also has good behavior going either slow or fast.  It's the most stable quad I own.  It uses the standard 1 cell micro battery that is cheap and easy to charge.  You can and should have plenty of spares.  ;)It looks really nice too I think,  love the low profile,  canopy,  and colors.  Wish they would offer more choices.  I also wish it had LED lights,  which would help for orientation,  as the quad gets very small,  especially flying outdoors. I've put some in myself, and it helps.It is also reasonably priced I think,  IF you are already a Spectrum radio (TX) owner.  It bound perfectly to my DX8 and has never had a glitch.The quad is so light,  and with the protector guards on the blade ends,  I've never once broken a prop,  knocked one off.  The flexible plastic body is so strong it can take a beating and never breaks.  The canopy however can crack but it's easily replaceable, and besides it comes with two (one green,  one yellow) and with matching pairs of extra props.It truly is a great flying micro quad that's durable and fun to fly!

As an early adopter of the M-80, then the M-100, i honestly didn't think i would ever need another model, but now the XS is my most-used headphone. Here is why:I won't go into great explanations of the sound of the XS, as others have already covered that extensively, but i will make comparisons to the other two models, which I have also written reviews on, and am quite familiar with the sound signature of both.Perfectly Portable.The XS is indeed Extra Small. It utilizes the ingenious click-fold feature which the M-100 debuted, but as the XS is a much smaller on-ear (supra-aural) versus over-ear (circumaural) headphone, it is quite a bit smaller. I know of no other hp that can fold this small and compact. The case, which is another clone of the M-100 exoskeleton case, holds the folded XS well, protects it, and packs in a very small space. These are cans you can truly take with you everywhere.(Perfect) Xceptional Sound.Sure, that's highly debatable. And relative to your experience, and types of music you enjoy. But to my ears the balance of sound in the XS is certainly one of the best-sounding small headphones I have ever heard. When I first wrote a review of the M-80, some did not agree with me but i thought the sound was not as flat as others suggested, even though i liked the M-80 overall. I complained of a too-forward midrange. First of all, i love MR, but it felt slightly artificial to me, with a spike in the range between 1500-3000hz. In some recordings it sounded very good, in others it could be a bit harsh or grating in the higher-mid register. The treble, though very non-fatiguing, lacked sparkle and seemed a bit dull to me. The bass to me was good. My review of the M-100 was much better, although i thought the bass was much over-emphasized as a whole. As i stated, with EQ it can be toned down to sound very good. The bass in the M-100 is still very much more present and impactful in comparison to the xs, but it is not as balanced. (If you're a bass-head, you'd be happiest with the M-100).The bass in the XS is fast, deep, and of a better balance with MR and treble frequencies. It is never bloating, muddy, or slow and thumpy. I think it is better than the M-80 too (deeper with slightly more impact and less decay). The MR is clean, slightly warm, and has no harshness in the upper mids. Vocals are upfront, but not overly pronounced, with very good resolution and intelligibility.Treble is extended with good air and sparkle, without any harshness or sibilance. It helps the clean midrange to further the overall resolution of the recording. While not the absolute most resolving of headphones i have, the XS just has a very good BALANCE of sound that is very good for casual and fun music enjoyment, without being too fatiguing or critical as well. As such, even lower resolution recordings (MP3's on portable devices) sound resolving and listenable. This is what makes the XS so desirable in my opinion...they are tuned for portable use in particular. They are also, like the M-80 and even the larger M-100, sensitive enough to play very well without an amp. I have had great success with the PowerAmp app on my smartphones (currently the Note3, which has a Yamaha op-amp), which allows for great EQing and plenty of pre-amping sound. I have custom EQ settings for each of my headphones and IEMs. I no longer carry around a seperate headphone amp for portable use as I did before to get good enjoyable sound on the go.Better Fit.I complained of the fit on the M-80. As i stated in my review of the M-80, i feel that on-ear headphones are more related to IEMs than full-sized over-ear cans, in that fit is more critical and more highly specific to each person. The XS is much better, at least to me. The elongated band truly fits around the shape of the head more snugly, and closer. There is no longer a huge halo above your head with gaps between your ears. And as the band contacts more area of your head, the weight is distributed more evenly, making the phones feel much lighter and more comfortable. I did still need to slightly bend my band to get a perfect fit.  The strong metal band is still conformable for personal fit--Please search online for the proper way to bend your headband for your perfect fit if you are unaware of this intended feature.Same great Build and features.The XS continues the excellent build quality of all V-Moda headphones. They are impeccably well made, surely among the best. You feel assured they could literally last your lifetime, and V-Moda gives you the warranty to secure that. The M-100 model set the bar for the evolution of features in the line: the foldable hinges, the dual inputs, the separated mic and button placement on the great cord. The XS is  basically a baby brother of the great M-100 in almost all regards. So which is better? I love them both, but the newest model, the XS, is clearly an exceptional PORTABLE headphone: extra small and compact, with great balanced sound, that goes with me everywhere.

I didn't really need this flash. I have 5 SB-800's, a SB-910, and SB-700, in addition to many manual flashes (Vivitar 285 to Yongnuo YN-560 iii).Why did I want it?1) It's tiny and very portable, and has features my very (expensive) high-end flashes have.You really need to see comparison photos to see just how much smaller this flash is from a regular one, so I have posted several photos with this review, in addition to some hopefully helpful shots using the flash.I can easily tuck this flash into a side pocket in my camera bag (Domke's or Lowepro Pro Messenger 160), or put it into a small fanny pack when shooting very light. Before I may have foregone even taking a flash, just in case.Its so small, I'd rather have 2-3 of these instead of my Nikons. I could carry a couple of these in half the space of the larger units. As most of my flash is done off-camera, I generally use the Nikon CLS system or with radio slaves for wireless operation, and I generally shoot with multiple flashes. It would be nice to carry several of these smaller units with half the weight and space in a smaller bag.2) It uses Manual dials for controls, something I still love on my old Vivitar 285's. The dials are highly intuitive, and user-friendly. I still haven't even glanced at the manual for this flash.One push of the power button starts up the flash. The same one-push shuts it off--you do not hold the button to shut down--that is used to control the manual zoom functions.Two click-stop dials control all the other functions. The smaller dial to the left is the main function dial, with selections for Video (a dual LED light on the front comes on), Sf, Sd (slave funtions), M (full manual exposure), A, TTL, and then three positions for the Nikon CLS system (to select either channel A, B, or C).The larger dial to the right serves three funtions. Firstly, when in TTL mode, you can use flash exposure compensation, with clicks in half-stops from -2 to +2 stops. When in the TTL mode, a LED light to the right of the dial confirms you are using the dial for exposure compensation. Secondly, when in M mode, an LED to the left of the dial is lit, showing you that the manual settings are in play. You can set the flash power in clicks from 1/1 to 1/256 power. I like that a lot, as I use manual flash still quite regularly, even with a dedicated TTL flash. Going into menus and pushing a button while rotating dials and such is a pain, and then going back to the basic TTL is another pain. This system could not be easier and more liberating to use.The flash shoe is metal, and uses the pin lock system, which clicks and locks when mounted, a push-button disengages the pin to release the flash. It seems to work perfectly and is very stable on the hotshoe of every camera I've tried so far.Even as tiny as the flash is, it still uses the standard 4AA batteries. There is not much space left for the electronics, I'd think. The door is hinged and has a metal mechanism. It seems too easy to open when picking up or playing with the unit, however it stays shut more tightly when batteries are installed.The flash head can be swiveled 180 degrees in both directions, it can be tilted the full 90 degrees in 4 click-positions in between. It has an outer sliding door that pushes up to reveal a bounce card. The little door has tiny magnets that hold the door in either the closed or open position. When open, you see a color graph for the manual zoom functions: Green for Auto, blue for 24mm, magenta for 50mm, cyan for 80mm, and orange for 105mm. As stated earlier, holding down the power button enables the manual zoom function, one long push for each manual mode. The main power LED changes color which corresponds to the zoom function.There is also a wide-angle diffuser that pulls out from the bottom and folds onto the flash head. It seems to work well mechanically and to provide the widest coverage for wide-angle lenses. A plastic diffuser (Stofen-style) mounts to the head for further soft-bounce use. It works fine, and clicks in place if you put in on the right way.There is no LCD screen with readouts, and I don't miss them. It could possibly be useful in low light, but you can see the settings in your camera viewfinder for the most part.A red LED on the front center, under the nameplate, blinks when in wireless modes. A light sensor is located here as well, which seems to work well. I prefer it be in the center, as many of my Nikon units it is on the side and gets covered up if holding the flash, or just seems to be on the wrong side when off-camera and positioned for the main flash or TX to reach it. The system seems to work every bit as good as my Nikons for off-camera CLS use. I often use the Nikon SU-800 transmitter in this case, and this Nissin works with either another Nikon flash as Commander, or the SU-800.I REALLY WISH THIS FLASH COULD WORK AS THE COMMANDER, but it does NOT.In video mode, the dual LEDs put out a fair amount of light, which is then controlled by the power/compensaton dial from low to full power output. The light seems clean and balanced in the image. No funky blue color shift, its color-balanced well, so I may use this function more than I had even planned--for a little on-camera fill for video or even stills. Its useful for aiding in focusing and seeing the subject in very dim lighting as well.  The LED turns blue to the right when in this video mode. In every other function the dial LEDs are lit in white.Another great feature that I wanted this flash for: true high-speed sync (called HSS in the Nikon system). I have tested exposures shot in broad daylight with a little bit of flash-fill, shot at 1/2000 sec., with great results. Enabling higher shutter speeds to use lenses with wider apertures in bright light is very useful for me.  For a few of the test pictures I have uploaded, these images were made with a Nikon D300s (my D4 works well too) whose top sync speed of 1/250 is expanded in HSS mode. Images were shot with a Tamron 60mm f/2 MACRO lens at very close distances to subject, at f/2.8 at 1/2000 shutter, balancing daylight well and also providing great exposure even at such a close subject range. I am impressed!! Also, there is no buttons or mode to fool with to enable the HSS, it just works when it needs to (provided your camera body is capable and set right). The high speed sync works up to 1/8000 sec! (if your camera supports such use).Additionally, bright or spotty overexposed images have not been found so far using TTL. The flash seems  to balance very well in autoexposure. I'd say every bit as good as my SB-910, if not BETTER.Of course, such a small flash does not put out as much power nor recycle quite as fast. I can live with that in such a tiny portable flash. It works great for fill flash when you know how to balance for ambient light anyway.A few niggles I might mention:when using rechargeable AA's, the two slots close to the back of the flash are tighter, making those two batteries harder to remove. This is not the case with regular alkalines or lithium AA's, only with the slightly fatter rechargeables (I have multiple eneloop and eneloop XX versions). I can easily remove them with a slight tap on the other side of the flash however.I really wish the flash head when tilted was flush with the rest of the flash (like almost all regular flashes are). I guess this is part of the design to keep it so small, but it would be even nicer and more compact to store if the head and body were flush. I  much prefer to store the flash in my camera bag in the tilted position. That said, the design is just the opposite: the storage pouch has the flash head tilted down, and the diffuser is stored under the flash in a cube-shaped pouch. As small as it is, its more like using the space of a small prime in your bag.The bigger compensation dial, although having nice clicks, is a bit too loose for my comfort, making me worry that the dial could be unintentionally moved too easily in use or in storage.I actually like that there is no unlock button to tilt the head or swivel it. Its just another pain to deal with onmy Nikons, as long as the design is good and the indentations provide enough force to hold position well, which they do.ADDITONAL info for users that may use this flash in a manual setting on different camera brands:As I also shoot with the Fujifilm X system (X-T1), I had thought about getting this flash for the Fuji system (which the dedicated version is now available for). I decided to go ahead and get the Nikon version, as I use Nikons for my day-job. The added benefit of the wireless TTL system with the Nikon CLS is very useful to me, that function would not be available (at this time) for the Fuji system. I can happily report (as I had hoped) that the flash functions beautifully on the Fuji X-T1 in manual mode. It fires perfectly, and using the manual dial is very easy to set the right exposure quickly. I can also carry it with a couple of radio slaves for a very small flash system for the X-system. To those wanting this flash for the smaller mirrorless cameras, I can say it would be a great match as well. I cant comment in terms of function for other brands, but it does work well in manual mode for the Fuji X-T1, and the size looks absolutely perfect for this camera. The manual dials of the flash work in concert with such a camera as well.This Nissin i-40 flash is designed in Japan, and manufactured in China. It seems solid despite its tiny size. I would be worried if it was dropped onto a hard surface, but durability is in question with any product. I will report any faults or problems I have with the unit as I use it more.If this flash had the added benefit of a built-in radio RX it would be perfect! I can see a  similarly sized and featuredYongnuo (with built-in radio) to be highly desirable!  ;)

Works simply with a low price.  Have 4 YN560 III flashes,  this controls them wirelessly with the added benefit of full control of power levels on each flash.  Sure,  it's all manual flash (no TTL),  but it's consistent and rock-solid with no missed syncs or miss-fires or variances in output. Once you dial it in,  your set and you can think about getting the shot.  No line of sight worries either (as infrared or slave),  great radio range.  Uses 2 AA batteries,  so you only have to carry extras of  one type. And no extra modules to attach to my flashes and carry separately and keep batteries for those as well!The best part is you can stay behind the camera and never run back and forth to each individual flash to change each settings/power levels. .. fully adjustable from 1/1 to 1/256.You can hold down the left side  Group button to get the additional 3 groups (which then shows groups DEF--6 total groups of flashes to control),  the buttons are fairly easy to use and intuitive as they line up the functions under the LCD screen.A great yet inexpensive system!

Seem to be about the best 1-cell micro batteries I have found thus far.  The 45c amp draw really seems to help with higher drain RC vehicles.  Using them in several micro planes,  helis,  and quads,  as well as a few custom-made aircraft. Like all batteries,  their shelf life is limited,  as well as the number of re-charges,  but they seem to provide the best oomph per use.  Have over 10 of these,  and so far not a bad one,  no bad or failing/loose connectors,  or swelling of cells. Happy flying!

Seems to work about as good as the Fuji oem battery.  Great deal for 2 batteries and an extra charger... which works great for having on hand for travel. Using in Fuji X-T1 body,  with no problems whatsoever.

WORKED! Had a yellow jacket nest inside the masonry wall of my garage,  could not get to them to kill them.  Tried spraying 3 cans of bee insecticides to no avail. Bought a can of this and a duster bulb,  after a few days dusting into the hole they flew in and out of,  and hitting a few of the bees themselves,  all activity ceased.  They are gone,  much to my relief.  Thus stuff is pro - grade,  will keep some on hand for any future invasions!Might also mention that I am allergic to bee stings and really needed to rid my house of the nasty yellow jackets,  so thankful for this product.

I have DOZENS of camera bags and wanted a great sling. I really wanted to like it, but i had to send it back.Love the color (got the slate blue) and look of it, the size is nearly perfect and it does hold gear well without being overly bulky (all great features).You of course need to decide what is most important, as your whole trunk of gear will not fit inside it.A DSLR without a grip will fit easily, even with a moderate lens attached (say Nikon D7100 and kit zoom). You can also fit a couple of other moderate lenses, say a couple of good primes such as a 85mm f/1.4.It would fit my Fuji XT1 even with the attached grip. A pro body such as a D4 is very hard to fit inside.Its also extremely well made, as all ThinkTank products i've owned, and is fairly light too.It will also hold a small tablet in its own pocket, with padded protection. A very nice feature.WHY i sent it back: The sling is designed to go over your RIGHT shoulder only. After 25 years of carrying a camera bag on my left shoulder, i just can't get used to carrying a bag on my right, unfortunately. Sure, this is a personal thing--but i thought it might be useful for some to understand. It would otherwise be a very good photo sling bag. ;(

Really nice cleaning brush. WHY? the best part is that the brushes are angled all around the surface of the front, so it brushes everything at once in all directions, so a surface of the brushhead doesn't scratch or do damage, especially when washing your car and such. Makes washing a car fast and easy, without worry. The brushes are very soft and do not damage the paint either. Really like this brush!

One of my favorite shampoos ever. It has a good smell and makes my hair feel shiny and healthy. It also gets the daily oil out easily but doesn't make it feel too dried out and brittle either. It does make your grey hairs brighter so they look more like blonde highlights. I've been using it for years, but it was getting hard to find locally, so i have been ordering it on Amazon.

For the price, you cant beat it!It looks pretty good (a little bit like my Springfield XD9 subcompact), has decent power, and very good accuracy. Sights are quite good, better than some of the pricier guns, although they are non-adjustable. The CO2 powerlets are easy to put in (and the turnscrew is somewhat hidden so it doesn't give off that its a CO2 BB gun) as is the BB clip. The clip works very well and is made of a heavy solid metal. The gun is mostly plastic and light, but feels OK.The main thing i do not like is the trigger. It has a very long pull and needs a  lot of weight making it somewhat hard to pull. This mostly translates to bad target acquisition, as the long, hard trigger gives you time and pull to get you off-target.Otherwise, for $20 it is a great little plinker though.I'd recommend a bottle of Pellgun oil to lubricate your CO2 cartridge and keep the seal working well.

Not sure what "Pack of 12" in the title and description means, but what I received was ONE tiny TWO OUNCE box containing around 26 very small crackers, slightly bigger than a Cheez-It (1 1/2 inch squared), and most of them broken into pieces.Unfortunately, mine are also stale, so i'd really not try to judge the consistency of the product quality, but they have little taste, even the sea salt is bland and old-tasting. They are also very thin, more like an unleavened bread.Come to think of it, they might do quite well in a church communion service if that is what you are buying them for.They are not really for EATING.If you think paying $4.12 for ONE "fun size" candy bar at your local grocery store, or $2 for one individual stick of gum, is a fair price, you might think you are getting a deal here.Seriously, do not bother. This is blatant false description, and should not be allowed.I'll be reporting it to Amazon and seeing what i can do to get my money back.

To be honest I was not planning to get this lens. But I did need a good all-in-one zoom for my X-T1 as the only lens I have (had) so far is the 56mm f/1.2 (an amazing gem of glass).  Had hoped to get the 16-55mm f/2.8 by the summer/fall of 2014, but when the Fuji roadmap recently changed, and with some more specs announced and sample photos released on this 18-135mm, I decided to give this one a chance as my “light travel” lens.The FOCAL RANGE is quite broad, and certainly useful.  Sure, it could be wider and longer, but it’s still a decent wide-angle (27mm) and a decent telephoto (206mm). I’d personally prefer more degrees at the wide end at the expense of the long though (as the 16-55 will be). A 16-120mm (24-180) with at least a constant f/4 would be more in line with my wishes.Yeah, it is kinda SLOW. And I am known for using and loving fast primes (25 years as a photojournalist), so when I first saw the specs on this, I was not even interested. As I shoot a D4 on my day-job, my X-T1 is more of my personal (fun/art) camera. But it is highly capable for pro work, and for some things, I’d prefer it.The useful max f/stops break down like this (or there-abouts) :18mm 3.520mm 3.623mm 4.028mm 4.235mm 4.355mm 5.070mm 5.385mm 5.3100mm 5.6135mm 5.6What the lens lacks in aperture speed, the vibration reduction system (OIS) makes up for. And the OIS in this lens is really amazing, I really think the most useful I have used. Better than my Nikkor 70-200 f/2.8.For most of my pro work, VR or OIS is honestly not very useful to me. I’m more worried about subject movement vs. my hand-holding ability, which is why I prefer (need) very fast glass. I regularly handhold a 300mm 2.8 and have never used a 70-200 2.8 with a monopod—I just use a higher ISO and shoot wide open. But the ability of this lens to keep an image tack sharp at 4-5 stops slower than normal is amazing. And the system is quiet, unobtrusive, and doesn’t shake around. It is very useful on a compact all-in-one lens such as this, which would (in my use) be more for scenics, still life, nature, portrait snapshots---Travel, vacation. I don’t love variable-aperture lenses for my pro work either, but as a travel zoom, its fine. This lens is also highly useful for basic video work (home movies) with the broad focal range and very effective vibration reduction.The SHARPNESS is actually quite good for this 7.5X focal range. Bit soft in corners wide-open, especially at 18mm (I’d almost wish it was less sharp in corners at the long end vs the wide end) but it is still very useful. In fact, it seems resolving enough at EVERY focal length, which is really pretty impressive. Don’t expect it to match your primes, but I haven’t met any lens that does. There are just too many variables to engineer into making this broad a focal range perfect. I’d certainly say it’s the sharpest all-in-one lens I’ve had though. The multiple ED/Aspherical elements probably help out there.CONTRAST is very good all the way through, which adds to the impression of sharpness. Flare seems well controlled and Starbursts look decent too.Can a slow lens like this even have BOKEH?  Well, that is probably what is impressing me most with this lens. WIth careful study of background/highlights, it CAN!It’s fairly smooth and creamy for the slow aperture openings it has. Guess the aperture openings stay fairly circular throughout the range and help with OOF highlights for a fairly decent bokeh for a slow lens.The minimum focus distance (MFD) is another highlight for me. It makes this lens way more useful as an all-in-one when you are able to get in close on a flower and just about fill the frame. No, its certainly not a 1:1 macro, but its more useful than most primes with generally more-limited MFD. In real-world shooting it seems to be around 10” in front of front element (filter to subject). This 10 inches or so is comparable across the focal range as well, so you can shoot around the same distances from wide angle (27mm) to telephoto (206mm). This is very useful and the close-focusing is helpful for bokeh in macro-ish shots.One of the major selling points is the WATER RESISTANCE, and that was certainly of interest to me. It’s nice to not have to worry about ruining your lens/camera when you get caught in a shower or want to take a hike and still get nice nature shots in any condition (which is sometimes more productive in cloudy light in drizzle).Well, if you are looking for an exact test on the effectiveness of the water-resistance, I am not gonna be the guinea pig just for tests-sake!! Winking smileAs I use the lens more, I will try to add some more observations though. I think the dust-resistance is nearly as important, although not nearly as touted about. Keeping dust particles from blowing around and through the back of the lens onto the fine sensor is very beneficial.But being able to use a one-lens system and not HAVE to change lenses in the field is very important for the effectiveness of the weather-resistance features.I can certainly see this lens as being great for shooting fall scenics and waterfalls in particular (as you generally want a slow shutter and don’t need a fast lens)—the range will be great.It is fairly LIGHT in weight too, making it even better for travel. Although light, the BUILD QUALITY still seems high. The ZOOM ring is very smooth mechanically, and it does not creep around either. I’d prefer a zoom that was totally internal, but probably hard to do with this wide a focal range. My copy seems to be a little tight at just the last few millimeters of zoom, say 128-135mm—but that may loosen with use.The included hood somehow seems a just bit small for the lens girth to me, and the plastic is slightly a lighter shade (grey vs deeper black of lens) which appears a bit mis-matched to me, but not a big deal. Unfortunately, the hood does not have a great “click” stop once in place either, making it a bit loose and prone to falling off.The AUTOFOCUS is internal, so you can easily use SFX filters (esp. polarizers) easily. The AF system is FAST and hits the mark well!  I’d say its better than my 56mm honestly, with less hunting. It is also extremely QUIET and SMOOTH. Very pleased with the focus.In conclusion, This is a very USEFUL lens, even though it is slow. If it were faster with an even broader focal range, it would also be very heavy, very large, with a huge front element (that needed 77mm or larger filters). As such, it suits the small mirrorless bodies (such as the X-T1) perfectly as a take-anywhere but highly-capable camera system.

LOVE this thing! Its worth every penny. Is unobtrusive, uses double-stick tape to put the controller button in a easy-to-reach place. This button also houses the mic, so be aware of placement so its close to your voice. The SOUND is very good for Bluetooth audio. I am using a ground-loop isolator as i have it powered through my phone's wireless charging system too. The top has two buttons for forward/reverse track skipping, the main front button can Play/Pause and take calls. Pushing it down can also redial last number called.It is simple but just works very well. I can now listen to music on my stereo, take calls hands-free. The phone call quality is about the best of any in-car device i've used. Of course, you have road noise, other factors that can vary, but i can hear my caller well, and they can generally hear me good too.

Works very well for me. I am using a Samsung Note 3 inside an Otter Commuter case, and it is a snug perfect fit.The clip seems strong enough and doesnt sag down badly, even better if you use the belt loops too. Good protection and carrying ability. Its big of course, but so it the phone, so it CANT be any smaller.

This is a charming little documentary on one of the best music producers ever. It gives some background on his personal life: his military service, his wife and family, upbringing, and weaves all into a life of music. Includes touching interviews alongside Paul and Ringo. Very well done and insightful.

It is a neat idea, and it should work well, unfortunately mine didn't work at all. No charging, no sticking to surfaces well. Am using a big, heavy phone (Note3 in Otter Commuter case) and i think every situation could be vastly different, but unfortunately the charging system did not even function, and i have 3 other QI-wireless induction chargers that work very well with my phone. So it went back.

This is a great flying heli for the money! I've had about 10 rc helicopters, from the cheapest Blade to 6 channel fixed pitch large rotors. I'm not an expert 3D flyer and have not spent the kind of money for the very large expensive machines to tear up yet. ;)But this is a great-looking helicopter that flies quite well for its very cheap price. Its very stable, will hover without drifting much and was trimmed about perfectly out of the box. It has a button on the transmitter that allows it to fly a bit faster. The included battery seems to give a good 7-10 minutes of flight time and the charger works well enough too. The transmitter radio actually looks decent enough for a toy (wouldn't mind if this was Spektrum-compatible and I could use my DX-8 though!)One cool thing about it is that although it is only 3.5 channels (whatever that means) is that you can ADD the true 4th channel with the addition of one servo, which is actually quite cheap to do, and the board RX already has a position for it, and uses the standard hobby-grade JR connectors too. And the TX is capable of giving input to the 4 channels as well.Of all my helis, i have never ONCE crashed this one. I do have quite a few years of stick-time, but this is a very stable flyer. It could use a good bit more power of course, but for a little fun in your yard, its a winner. As i havent yet crashed it, i cant comment on the reliability or crash-proofness, but it SEEMS VERY STURDY. The frame is quite strong and the blades seem very bendable and able to handle a few strikes. It even comes with extra blades if you need them.I love that it has an ON/OFF switch on the frame, so you can leave the battery plugged in and wires tucked out of the way before you turn it on. It actually looks quite good in the air too with good smooth turning and response.Just don't expect some quick, agile, 3D aerobatic helicopter here! ;)

Nice cheap alternative for the Nikon diffuser. I had temporarily lost my diffuser from my SB-910 and so started the search for a cheap alternative.Actually, i like this one better than the OEM one!
