This model has to have plenty of dyhedral in the wings which is achieved only with proper rigging...this is a must, not an option, for proper flight characteristics and structural reinforcement, and the instructions say little or nothing helpful.With lots of love and extra parts you can make a nice SLOW FLYER, but not out of the box.I now love the plane, but not because of the manufacturers work or help.
Cool looking knife and functions well too.Spring-assist mechanism is smooth and works great. Blade is sharp enough.Makes a great letter-opener!

This works great and its cheap. Using for samsung galaxy note 10.1.The app "Galaxy Media Importer" is a useful tool to import files into the tablet with this adapter. Works great.Works with usb drives and card readers for cf and sd cards straight from my dslr....i'm happy!

Like many others, i read the horrid initial reviews spitting out the viral misinformation about this tablet and although i was interested in it, i almost dismissed it and continued to search for another tablet. I'm glad i didnt after reading actual USER reviews, and forums such as xda developers give much more enlightened information.Although i am still getting my feet wet after just a few days of ownership, i am very happy with my investment.This tablet is the perfect bridge for me between a smart phone and desktop, and in many ways adds functions that even a highend desktop is incapable of, in particular the stylus s-pen input. Personally i wanted to be able to use the device for drawing and photo manipulation, as i am a photographer/graphic artist. Is it perfect? No, but ive been using Photoshop since about vs.1 and seen it grow by bounds. PS Touch is still an infant, but is usable, it can only get much better with updates and new versions.If the prospect of writing drawing and input with a pen is not for you, then by all means maybe you should look for an alternative with a "better" screen. The pen input is the whole point (pun intended) of this device, and even though this is new to tablet tech, it works quite well. I have used a Wacom input tablet for years on my destop, but was always frustrated by the hand on tablet while looking at monitor issues. As an artist being able to draw on the device is so much more intuitive, precise, and FUN...the way it should be. Thats not to say there is not a learning curve with the softwares. But being able to bring a device this size with you anywhere and draw paint etc, without a bevy of actual paint tubes, pencils, other medium, is just amazing. The software is somewhat limited as yet, but is still useable and should only get better as developers and users realize how useful and desirable this can be. I am using Touch as well as Autodesk Sketchbook, Infinite Paint/Design, FrescoPro, among others so far.The battery life is just amazing...this thing can literally go all day long. If you dont use it continuously all day it can last for days without charging.Does it feel cheaply made? Not to me. But im more concerned with what i can use it for instead of the look or color of the shell or the brand logo emblazed on it. Seems quite sturdy and mine doesnt creak in my hands.I got the 16gb version as it was readily available, and i added a 64gb card to the slot, for less than the $50 extra for the 32g model. Thank you so much for adding the card slot, Samsung!The audio quality is very good. The builtin speakers are great for their size, lack bass, but have clean clarity. The actual output is very good though. Ive read that the opamp is made by Wolfson but cant confirm, it is comparable to the SQ of the GalaxyNexus phone though. My preferred music player is PowerAmp (amazing sq and user tweaking).Wifi and Bluetooth work very well. Great signal with good range. No problems connecting to any bt devices so far. Have also used my Epson 645 to print from tablet wirelessly.Email and browser apps work great as does the Multiscreen with limited but useful apps.This review was written using the Note with the on-screen keyboard.I will try to update with more information as i use the Note more. So far i am extremely happy with this tablet!*** UPDATE (10-7-2012):Still loving my Note.Am using several art apps successfully on the tablet, including AutoDesk SketchBook (i'm using the full paid version), Infinite Painter, FrescoPro, and ZenBrush.So far, really like it. The S-pan is pretty precise and i think there are a good many levels of gradation/pressure sensitivity.PS Touch is usable for editing photos on the fly. "NexusMediaImporter" is a great app for dowloading raw files into your Note.You will need this or similar adapter, which works quite well for the cheap price:http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B005YWIRBS/ref=oh_details_o00_s00_i00(Sanoxy Female USB OTG adapter) which allows you to hook up a flash card reader or a USB thumb drive to your tablet. With the app you can see your files and download them into the tablet from the card or drive. I use the app on my smartphone as well (GalaxyNexus) to be able to able and transmit photos out of my DSLR in the field (i'm a photojournalist), and it works quite well.If you have read the comments, you'll see that a 64gb sd card will work great in the Note 10.1, AFTER the latest ICS upgrade to 4.04. Otherwise, you will need to reformat some of the newer cards that come formatted in the exFAT format to FAT32. But if you are just getting your Note, i would suggest waiting until you get the update before using the card so you can just use the exFAT format.My particular card is a Sandisk "MobileUltra" SDXC card with a Class10 rating. It works great in the Note, and i have over 50gb of content on it, including music (MP3) and photo (JPG) files.I have also opened text files, including MS WORD documents, that will successfully open using the included PolarisOffice app on the Note, and are then editable in Polaris ;) which seems to be a very nice included software on the tablet.Also, i just dont understand the reviews, comments on the Note's so-called horrid screen resolution. It seems quite sharp to me. No, it doesnt have the 'HD' resolution of some newer devices, but it is my no means bad. It is punchy with good blacks and looks plenty sharp at the normal viewing distance of a 10" screen. I have also downloaded and am using different fonts, with i think look even sharper to my eyes.The Note10.1 is a nice tablet for the price, and is quite functional to actually DO THINGS with. Until the MS Surface tablets appear and we see how well the new Win8 touch interface works, S-pen is among the very best interfaces for writing and art there is at the moment, and the price is quite reasonable for this technology.***UPDATE 10-19-2012A few more comments with more use:The Polaris app will view, open, edit files including Word, PDF, etc., and is a very useful and well developed app.The sound quality of this device is very good, particularly when using apps such as PowerAmp to tweak the sound.Battery life is EXCELLENT, i can use the Note for generally 2-3 days of use (with at least 2-3 hours a day) before a recharge.Reading works well on the Note as well, including Kindle, Aldiko, Nook, and YouVersion apps. Also using some digital magazine subscriptions.As i almost waited for the release of MS Surface, with the price now being known to be $600 (with the keybord cover), i am happy i didnt. That's for the RT version, not the full Win8 version to be released next year, with a much higher price to be announced.And the Note's touch interface with S-pen is i'm sure still a more advanced input, as well as the limited app availability for WindowsRT at the moment.

Not much to say, but if you own the Fuji X10 you know that it has a somewhat rare filter thread.This filter fits it perfectly, and i have a 46mm UV filter attached to the stepup ring. Not only does it fit, it is almost perfectly flush with the camera's lens.Had originally bought the step-up ring/hood specifically for the X10 that steps up to 52mm filters, but the back has holes in it that let in dust, and light, and it sticks out much more, and blocks more of the image through the optical viewfinder. I already had a B+W infrared filter in a 46mm, so it also fits this ring perfectly. And works well with the camera, as no stray light comes thru the back as it would with the 52mm setup, for infrared photography.The seller was quick with delivery and the product seems well made. Works perfectly for my intended use. Very glad i found this solution to the Fuji X10 filter mount.

I was about to purchase a lower-end model (545), but then found this one on sale for the same price. The only upgrade from the 545 is that the 645 is capable of printing on both sides of the paper, which for some might be quite useful. I like that is has it, but havent used it much yet.The printer connected well with my system (WIN 7) via USB. The usb cable is NOT supplied unfortunately, but i just swapped out an old printer anyway and had the cord hooked up already in place. I ALSO have the wireless wi-fi mode functioning well too, so i can print from the main computer corded, or another old computer in another room, AND my smartphone, which is very nice. Did take a little bit of thought getting the phone configured and you have to download the Epson app. I also have the GoogleCloudPrint app installed. I've even printed photographs from my phone wirelessly and it worked like a charm. Amazing!Overall the printer is fast, produces clean sharp lines for text, and good photo images with accurate color balance. I am a photographer, and have used Epson printers for years for photographs (since the PhotoEX model years ago), and currently use the PhotoR2400, so am not printing too many photographs on the 645, as i got it to replace a 10-year old general printer i had, mostly just for text printing, but the 645 seems to do a decent job with photos nontheless, just not to the level of the high-end photo-specific Epson models.I like the clean (black) look of the printer, the menu/settings buttons, and LCD readout. It also has several card inputs if you dont have them on your computer, you can use the printer to input files from your camera and such. Believe this may only work with the USB cord connected to your computer, not wifi though.The top flatbed scanner works quite well too, and you can use it as a fax machine if you connect a phone line to it.So far, my inks are lasting pretty well. I have purchased another set of inks for when i run out, but so far i havent needed to yet (about 2 months of occasional, mostly text printing). Think the inks are reasonable since they last a while, and the printing is consistant and clean.The printer just works, and well, without hassle. I'm VERY HAPPY with it. Think i made the right decision to go with the Epson make, and this model in particular for my general printing needs.Can't really say anything negative about it so far ;)

This is the first work by a prolific and profitable author.SYNOPSIS: a Canadian  60ish woman is living a comfortable life in her small town as a vampire.  She drinks blood, & sleeps in a coffin all day.  Her friends/neighbors have no doubts about her being a vampire because they witnesses her reverting from a 60ish widow back to a hottie 25 year old.  Her friends get together and attempt various match making schemes to secure a male vampire for their vampire friend.  When the book opens, the heroine doesn't know that there are several male vampires scheduled to meet the lady small town vamp a la the bachelorette.  One of the contestants is not only a 'real' vampire, but he's the bad A with a  capital A enforcer for the secretive Vampire Counsel, and he's in town to find out if he has to execute a rogue vampires for exposing vampires to the straights.  It's a romance, so there's some loving going on, and it's a suspense, so someone's trying to kill the vampires, and it's plain funny.I laughed several places, and not realizing The Reluctant Vampire is  the start of a long series, nodded my head saying to myself, this should become a series that I'd love to read.  It's charm is in the funny moments, and the romances, and even the stumbling awkward phrasing of the author - many times she used the phrase 'the X of her'.  After reading it for the 10th time, I decided it was a colloquialism  and decided it although distracting, added to the charm of the novel.IMO: read it and enjoy - it's fun.

This is the most beautiful work of art light bulb!!!!!  I was so surprised to see they are LED bulbs, which means as long as you don't smash them, they will last for years longer than regular light bulbs.  I have included a picture of a standard 60 watt soft white bulb, and this gorgeous art bulb.  The art or Edison bulb is not for reading, it's for setting a mood, or decorating.  It's interesting and would actually be something cool to give to someone as  a gift.  I love unusual items, and this one fits the bill in so many ways.  It's useful, you can screw it into a normal light bulb socket.  It's pretty - when you see one in person, you'll see why I called it a 'work of art'.  And it's a great way to inexpensively decorate and 'change up' the house without buying a new expensive couch or heck - a grand piano.  I was given a bulb in exchange for a review, and find myself salivating over it and contemplating purchasing more of them for the reasons stated above.  So buy this bulb and skip the grand piano.

I travel and always have a fear of getting ripped off.  I have had a version of this and have always found them perfect for both my peace of mind and as part of my strategy of stashing money and credit  cards in different places so I don't have a nightmare scenario where I'm stranded in a foreign place if I lose my wallet/I'm a normal size American (ok a little on the fluffy/chunky side), and this $ belt stretches perfectly well to fit both my waist and that of  a smaller person.  The waist strap is adjustable and made of elastic, so it's comfortable. It has 2 zippered pockets, one on the outside, for stuffing a few 20s, and a more secure large pocket that can hold a lot of items/cards/cash.  Inside the main compartment, there is a mesh divider, with one side suitable for credit cards, and the other big enough to hold a passport.  The main inside pocket is quite roomy, and one could easily hide much in it.  My strategy is to keep pocket cash in my jeans pocket.  Occasionally, if I need more $, I slip into a restroom stall and remove cash where no one can see the money belt.  It's an effective and sensible way to protect your $.The material it is made of is the kind that whisks away moisture, so even if you're in Tangiers in the boiling sun,  sweat (glow if you're a gal) will not permeate the bag and I think it's also reasonable to believe that the bag is waterproof and will protect your $/etc in a downpour (or dropping off a liner into the ocean).  I was given a sample in exchange for a review.  IMO, it's a bag I would buy.

This is such a beautiful 'hip', retro, old world, coooool, perfect for any hipsters apartment light.  This has to be installed by a professional or someone who goes on youtube and understands how to hook up an electrical light.  It's similar to installing a light/fan and is easy to accomplish.  Just don't miss that first step in the instructions where you shut off the power.  The instructions recommend placing the lights within 3 feet so they can hang separately.  This light is a work of art.  It's not for your regular LED or 60 watt bulbs.  It's made to showcase the delicate and beautiful Edison bulbs that are becoming popular.  It's meant to give off a mood, to create atmosphere, to bring art into your lighting scheme.IMO, it's easy enough to install, and pretty.  I was given a sample for a review.  My teenagers fought over who gets to have it installed in their room.  Since it's not for reading light, we decided to use it in an area as a decoration.  If you're into art and love something different, this lighting fixture is just the thing.

This stuff is a tasty tea.  It's like a cross between a bold green tea and one of those specialty teas that someone gives you for Christmas that are all fruffy.  I didn't  explore the detox features, I just enjoyed it as a tea and try not to think about nature taking its course or stuff like those yogurt commercials seem to be all about these days.  When I see the name "detox tea", I think of Dave Barry describing his colonoscopy preparations  akin to the space shuttle on takeoff.  I didn't see any of these effects with this tea (thank God!), but I enjoyed the tea and the flavor.  (I also read that if you want to 'detox' eat about a pound of sugar free gummy bears, that'll do the trick).Oh!  My cat kept attacking the box, so I had to put them in a zip lock bag, then she went after it more furiously, so I suspect it has some cat nip in it or something that is attractive to cats.  Or my cat is stupid.  I was given a sample for a review.  Bottom Line: it's a nice tea, it may have some other 'benefits', but you'll enjoy the flavor either way.

I have had another one like this for months and it has never failed me.  This one is an 8 GB and will store over 24+ hours of audio.  I set it on my desk and played music all day and all night, and found out the battery lasts around 24 hours.  The battery recharges by plugging it in.  It has an LED light that lights up when it's turned on.  It has an on off switch at the end.  If stealth is your game plan, this beauty can plug into a laptop, looking just like a regular USB flash drive and record everything within the room and some from the next for over one day and it will recharge itself.The audio is crisp and clear and it is a device that easily has thousands of uses.  I was given a sample for a review.  IMO, it's an amazing bit of technology at an amazing price.  A great business tool, just be careful when recording others without their consent, that's usually a no-no.

This is for capturing VHS or other types of video to your computer.  I was given a sample to review, so I hooked it up to and ran the software on my laptop with windows 8, and after loading the two software programs was able to capture video from an old VHS VCR tape player.PROS:It is relatively simple to set up and it has windows movie maker type controls, only with more transitions and you can fuzz out a face if you like.It’s an inexpensive way to capture your old home movies.  Years ago, I bought a DVD recorder for saving my old movies.  This EZCAP will do the  trick and it’s many times cheaper.  If you send out your videos to some company to transfer over to DVD, they will charge you potentially hundreds of $$.There is a quick start guide with the item, but a more detailed and easy to understand manual is included on the disc.  I consulted the manual on the disc several times, and found it to be quite helpful.The box says it only works on XP and Vista, but  I was using Windows 8 and it worked ok.The editing software is easy and even has an “Upload to Youtube” option.You can edit (add names and dates or transitions or even make little movies) and burn them to a CD/DVD or just upload to Youtube.CONS:Remember there are TWO programs on the disc, they don’t automatically install - you have to install both the driver and the program “arc soft showbiz”.My video capture from VHS flickered to black occasionally.  I’m reasonably sure the tape and machine work, but as old as they are - and face it, they weren’t meant to last this many years - it could be a tape error.BOTTOM LINE:If you’re in the market to save your memories to digital, and don’t want to spend hundreds of $, this is a safe bet.

The glasses are surprisingly lightweight and yes they do cut the glare of a computer screen.  They come with a very nice case that has a zipper and will protect them well.  The case has a clip on it so you can attach it to your messenger bag or backpack etc.  The glasses are light enough that they will not bother the wearer.  I have a slightly large head, and they fit fine, so I suspect they fit most people, but the pair I have seems more suited for a female.  I was given a sample in exchange for a review.

Peppermint scent has medicinal uses - it's know to help concentration, boost energy, repel bugs (mosquitos hate it), and reduce cravings for food.  A few drops of this in your diffuser, or in a hanky (Kleenex) in your pocket can change your day. This evokes the memories of Christmas morning and my grandmother.  It is a highly concentrated product that you can drop around your home to relive wonderful times and to make new memories for the next generation.  I was given a sample for a review.  IMO, it's a wonderful product that makes a thoughtful gift.

I did a party this week and needed to 'freshen up' the hall we rented.  This Lemon Oil came in handy.  A few drops here and there in a napkin or frankly on the carpet worked better than gallons of fabreze.  This is a natural scent.  I also put a few drops behind the lemons we had out for the tea and it made the illusion that my lemons (which for some strange reason did not smell at all like anything) were the most bountiful and perfect lemons that ever existed.  This isn't a medicinal smell, it's a garden full of freshness bursting forth to a perfect beautiful day kind of smell.  I was given a sample in exchange for a review.  I love this stuff, and IMO, the essential oils have countless uses for making your life brighter.

I'm a ginger fan.  It can calm any nausea up to and including flu suffers with vomiting.  Often when the kids or hubby is sick, this is all that they can hold in their stomachs.  It's like how aloe will heal a burn, ginger fixes a sour stomach.  This particular tea tastes like a root, we put honey or sugar in it.  If you're not grounding up your own ginger to make tea in a strainer, this is a great way to go with ginger tea.  I was given a sample in exchange for a review.

If you're going to go to all the trouble to "Bake", you may as well use the best and freshest of ingredients.  The Kazu cinnamon is IMO the best on Amazon.  It has the perfect texture when you put the apples and brown suger in the pie crust and becuase it's the best of the best it  makes your mouth water as you scent the apple pie baking in the oven.  If you're doing all the work for a feast or a regular family dinner, put forth your best effort with the best.  I was provided a sample in exchange for a review.

I thought turmeric powder was for turning your foods bright yellow or enhancing curry based dishes.  I was stunned when I researched it on the web to find out it has all kinds of health related benefits.  You can use turmeric for everything from preventing cancer and  slowing Alzheimer's to polishing your teeth.  It has enormous and varied benefits that are claimed and studied extensively.  I use is for turning my Sunday yellow rice and chicken dinner a particularly sweet shade of yellow that is the envy of the church ladies at the potlucks.  (snicker).  This is a high quality product that I was given in exchange for a review.

Ginger is on the 'old wives tales' remedies that truly works.  Ginger can be used for making tea,  homemade ginger ale,  jello, or my favorite is for treating motion sickness and nausea.  We travel by boat a lot and NEVER leave home without ginger pills.  This all natural ground up root is IMO more healthy and powerful than the stuff you get at the pharmacy because it's closer to nature and is apparently processed with the strictness standards.  I have given the ginger tea to my children when they had the flu or other problems and it never fails to calm them and stop the vomiting and nausea that plagues the flu sufferers.I was given a sample in exchange for a review, and IMO it's  a good natural product that  has to better than stuff that's been sitting on a shelf in a store for week/months or years.

This is such a great flavorful chili - I'm hoping it will help me win a chili contest this fall.  I'm tired of losing to the guy that uses deer meat (venison) to make chili.  This year, I'm going all out with the freshest of ingredients and best chili powder I can find on Amazon.  This is colorful, it's tasty, it has the right texture, and if I were a betting person, I'd say to lay odds that I bring home the Chapter 78 trophy !  I was given a sample of this wonderful chili powder in exchange for a review.  IMO, it's the best and freshest, on the market.

I love windows phones.  I've had android and I couldn't wait until they started making windows again.  I bought one with a lot of memory since the memory chips in the android phones do not work as advertised.  This one has 32 gb and so far holds all the pictures, music, and audible books I want and I am no where near the memory limit.WHAT I DON"T LIKE:Mine came speaking French and did not have a qwerty keyboard.  Fortunately, I knew enough French to fiddle with it, then gave up and let my 13 year old figure out how to turn it to English.  Then I finally discovered that if you remove Chinese as the keyboard/language option, it goes back to qwerty keyboardIt has a good memory, but you can't add a sd or micro sd card to it.The maps I downloaded work 20% of the time, and never when I'm lost and need them, usually only on my street when I'm pretty sure I know how to get home.I have trouble downloading any pictures that are sent from android/Iphones.  I usually text them and say - can't see it - it's annoying.  Probably just a setting, but I've had it over a month and I still can't receive pics.I have yet to figure out how to get it to work on data v wifi.  Better consult a 12 year old huh?WHAT I LIKE:The memory - it rocks!I have security cameras from blu iris that I monitor from my cell phone - this has enough memory to see my cameras when the Wi-Fi work.I love LOVE LOVE the way it interacts with Audible - I love listening to audio books and this app for windows on this phone works seamlessly so I can pop between stories with ease.I love that is ok with syncing my 5 or so email accounts for business work, kids, etc so that I can see all of them separated as they should be on my phone.I love windows.  It's how tech should be.

I got these so my pet sitter doesn't have to open or move my bird cages around too much to water my birds.  My one complaint is that since it's a new item, my birds decided to pull them off the cage wall and toss them into the bottom.  I would NOT rely on them as the sole source of water for your pet, but as a supplement or a bathing bowl, or for special food treats, it's a good investment.  They're easy to clean, and the wire is pretty solid, so it's hard to twist - although my macaw and mouloucan gave it a try.

Bought these for a bd party - I used paper clips to hold them together rather than the provided double side tape.  For one reason it can be taken down and reused again - and another is that the double sided tape doesn't really hold them together.  I should deduct a start because several of them only had a hole in one side of the paper where you bring it together and hang it from the ceiling.  I had to punch a hole in the other side while standing on a 8 ft ladder and I did NOT appreciate that.  However, they are cute and festive and friendly and cheap and helped make my party a hit, so I'll give them the coveted 5th star.  Also it comes with little perhaps 12 inch string when tied - but I threw them away and used fishing line and paper clips to attach them to the drop ceiling.  Watch what kind of ceiling you're going to encounter, because a flat or popcorn ceiling can't hold them.

I bought these for a poker tournament at a bd party.  The teens loved them!  I thought the little kids - the 5-9 year old group would like them more for indian poker, but the teens scooped the deck up and played with them the whole night.  They are reasonably well made and  are strong enough to use for another party and to play with another day.

This is such a beautiful subtle scent.  You would think the lavender would be overpowering since it's concentrated, but it's just right.  I put a few drops on a hanky and stuffed it into my purse, it provided a  whiff  of happiness every time I opened my purse.  I put a drop on a piece of paper next to my computer screen and have enjoyed the quiet scent enormously.  The concentrate can be dropped into a diffuser and make your whole room/house smell like lavender - but not the "hey - someone dumped a lavender bush in here & stomped on it" kind of smell, it's a grown up - subtle - "I'm here when you notice me and I'm beautiful" kind of scent.  I was given a sample for a review.  IMO, it's well worth the price and putting a few drops here and there in your life is a small investment in olfactory happiness.

This is a wonderful S & P grinder!  You don't need batteries, it's adjustable from the coarsest to the finest grains, it's easy to fill and makes you look like Martha Stewart as a hostess when you put it on your table, or in your picnic basket, or in your camper.  We put round pepper corns into one end and sea salt in the other.  My husband got a kick out of seeing how adjustable it is according to how you move the lever on the bottom.I was given a sample for a review.  In my opinion, this is a great way to show class, and would also be a good gift.

I can never find oven mitts, or they get wet, so when I saw these, I jumped at the chance to review them for a sample.  They work scary good!  You can pick up anything from your oven and the mitts do not transfer the heat to your hands.  They are a loud and fun color and come with a basting thing for BBQ as a bonus.  I love the fact that I hang them on my cabinet door, and simply grab them when pulling stuff in and out of the oven .Honestly, I was a little scared the first time I used them because they are so revolutionary and lightweight and so completely unlike anything I'd use to protect my hands from burns.  But I'm glad I tried them out.  They are the future, and I for one am enjoying them in the here and now in my kitchen.

The oil smells nice, it's a masculine scent, with just a hint of a sugary candy.  It comes with a tiny little bottle that can fit on your pocket. The little bottle is for keeping the beard well maintained throughout the day.  It's a form of conditioner for beards, and is essential to a well groomed man.  I have a relative with a beard who tried this out for the review.  His beard is closely cropped, not a Duck Dynesty type, but even so, it should be properly treated and softened so his wife will let him near her.  We were given a sample for a review. IMO, it's a must have product if you or your loved one sports a bear.

This is for a dog that is 16 years old, that's 80 in human years for a small dog, and 87 in human years for a medium breed.  (The internet chart doesn't even list large breed dogs that age!)  I've read about this product for years, and had to see it to believe it.  It was poured over wet dog food and was slurped up each and every time.  I don't think dogs care about flavor, (I mean they roll around in dead animals and poo!) but the flavor seems to be more than ok by the dog.The dog is not acting like a puppy, but the Glucosamine has a positive effect on him.  As it gets in his system, he is getting up quicker, and seems eager to do some of the play time that has lately been co-opted by sleep time.  I was given a sample to do a review.  IMO, (in my opinion), the product is a good one that benefits dogs and would be a good way to improve your best friend's over health by making him want to get active again because the pain is reduced/gone.

I've used this phone casing for a week.  It provides tough protection for my Noikia windows phone.  It has a little stand so you can pose the phone either direction.  The buttons do not crowd the phone, so you can press them and they instantly work.  My only complaint is that it does not come in pretty colors.
This hard to find part worked to replace the damaged part.  It fits with no problems, or issues.
They fit the car exactly like they should.  If we experience any problems, I will update the review.  We bought them to replace a missing light.  They look factory original.

My daughter loves her Nintendo, and this case is PERFECT for keeping all the little expensive cartridges in place.  It's strong enough to withstand a 12 year old standing on it (don't ask), has 8 pouches for individual cartridges, a zippered compartment to protect more cartridges. and you can put the Nintendo unit itself inside this case.  It has a separator that pulls out that has a net like pouch to store the cord for the Nintendo unit.  The zipper comes with two pulls, and it has a clip on that can be attached to a belt, or a backpack.  This is designed for a young kid/teen, and it is made with durability in mind.  I would recommend you put your name and phone number inside it, because you know it's going to be left somewhere.I was given a sample in exchange for a review.  IMO, it's a good sturdy item that protects your investment and the case will probably outlast your child's interest in Nintendo games.

The bands are a little small, but they easily stretch out to accommodate an adult size wrist.  We use them in our business to color code the key sets.  Since most people don't wear them on their wrist all day, they are no problem.  They also do not break despite vigorous pulling/yanking/stretching  by impatient employees.  I was given a sample for a review.  IMO, they fit the bill and do their job, so what more can you ask from a key ring?

We all carry our phones everywhere, and our wallets, so this combines the two.  It has plenty of space for $ and cards, and the clear pouch for your drivers license.  The actual case that holds the phone is built into the wallet.  It comes with a clear cover to protect the phone (why doesn't the phone factory put the covers on there?!), and it is super easy to apply.  Mine came with two clear covers.  The stylus is an actual pen with fine point black ink.I was given a sample for a review.  IMO, it's a nice item.  I think the cover is leather, if it's not, it's a good imitation.  I got the blue one.  It's sewn together, not glued.  It has a magnet holding the strap to the body to close it. It has the hole in the case and in the matching wallet, very finely drilled for the camera for the phone.  This is a good way to protect your phone.
The problem with these boards is that the metal holes pop right off! You need to get the shiny version of these (I've only seen them in green). They have a coating to keep the holes in place!

I've been looking around forever for a lightweight multimeter with lead storage as an alternative to the Victor VC921 I've been using, and this is the one!! I do a lot of microcontroller circuit builds and this thing is great. You won't be using it to impress anyone like those big old 1990's looking meters you see in the back of YouTube videos, but it sure blows them away!BTW this is the same as the AIMOmeter M320, which is cheaper.
I have several Aeon outlet controllers and figured I'd give this I try. It works great - no problems!

I havent't been using this long but so far this thing has functioned worlds above the plunger desoldering tools I've attempted to use. I need to desolder extremely small components from PCBs and this makes it cake! The plunger tools always leave solder around the PCB holes making it nearly impossible to suck up enough solder to remove components without mangling or destroying them. To remove through hole components with this I just touch the inside hole of the tip to the pin on the compononent to remove, run it around in circles several times, and the components come off with very little force.

Test your wires to make sure they are labeled properly, as mine were not. Also, I found that for EKG, the sensors worked best on my forearms. Other than that, this works great for the EKG and EMG! Don't bother with the SeedStudio EMG - the gain/sensitivity it terrible.
Don't waste your $$ on this. The analog values returned are useless and barely vary at all. I got the Olimex EKG EMG shield and use that for EMG. It works awesome!

For nearly a month now I was dealing with frustratingly slow USB device detection of USB serial adapters, flash drives, and more. Sometimes it would take Windows up to 30-120 seconds to detect devices that I had just unplugged and plugged back in. I finally broke out Sysinternals Process Monitor. I saw that every time I plugged in a USB device, I would see CSRHCRPServer.exe blow by in the log. I ended up ending task on that process, and guess what, my problems went away!! I uninstalled the CSR Harmony Bluetooth stack and switched over to a Broadcom based USB Bluetooth adapter.Furthermore the Serial profile sucks on this. If your device disconnects, it can take minutes for it to reconnect vs. seconds with the Broadcom adapter!

I tried switching to these from Wellgo pedals recently. I tested them out riding around on pavement for a little while. My shoes felt like they didn't really grip will on these, but I thought I'd put them through a real test. I then took them out on a real mountain biking hill and my foot ended up slipping of one of these pedals and one of the pins putting a nice 2 inch gash down the front of my shin, leaving blood everywhere, and a scar so I can always remember what these pedals did to me. These have two problems. First, the pins should be bar shaped rather than circles. Second, there's not enough surface area where the pins are. Third, it feels like the pedal axle comes up too high, stopping your feet from making enough contact with the pins. They should have run these through a 3d printer first and tested!

I thought there was some sort of problem with my project until I tried Olimex's snap leads and they worked fine. I went back to test conductivity with a multitester and found they were actually labeled incorrectly!

The first season I had these they were great, the next season my bike developed a loud popping/clicking sound when applying pressure to the pedals. After trying to ignore it for a while, I went out and purchased a generic set of pedals to see if it was from the pedals or the bottom bracket. Well, it was both pedals!!

I purchased this elsewhere, but thought I'd add my input here on this. I got this with a Neulog USB module which is required to connect this to a PC. I installed the latest Silicon Labs CP210x drivers for the internal USB to serial adapter in the USB module from Silicon Labs' web site. I installed both Neulog's non-browser application, and their API that you can use with http connections from your own apps. Both work great with the GSR sensor. The resolution is great compared to building your own with a standard Arduino or the like. Not sure what the other person's problem was on here. Maybe they're still using a rotary phone at home and get around in a horse and buggy:)

I didn't but this on here, but thought I'd add my input here on this. I got this with a Neulog GSR sensor. I installed the latest Silicon Labs CP210x driver's for the internal USB to serial adapter in this from Silicon Labs' web site. I installed both Neulog's non-browser application, and their API that you can use with http connections from your own apps. Both work great!
This sounded like a great idea, but it stretches out during the day and I find myself having to adjust it tighter about 5 or 6 times throughout the day.

I got this to add to a barely functioning outdoor spigot. It worked great for a few months, then when the outdoor temps dropped below freezing, I came home to water gushing out of this valve and a miniature lake. As you can see from the photo, there is a design flaw and low quality steel used in this.

I used to by the Crunchies brand blueberries at my local Wegmans for 3.99 for 1.5oz. I recently saw them as being discontinued for 3.49 and went into a panic. I found and settled on some Trader Joe's brand blueberries at my local Trader Joe's for 3.99 for 1.2 oz several days ago as an alternative, but thought I'd see what Amazon had to offer seeing that the flavor was not as good as the Crunchies brand. I decided to try the Honeyville Farms brand here. Although these are about $5 more expensive by weight for 12oz than the Crunchies brand blueberries, they are much more dry and crispier. They also have a very good flavor. Make sure you get a nice air tight sealing container to put them in after the can is opened.

After trying the Columbia, Timberland, and Quicksilver quarter socks, I ended up settling on the Timberland socks. The Columbia socks tend to have some annoying spots around the toes that rub. The Columbia socks are a bit thicker than the Timberlands, but the Timberlands are more comfortable all around. None of the 3 made my feet stink like some other brand socks. The Quicksilver socks were no where near as soft and comfy as the Timberlands or the Columbia socks.

I just needed a large water pitcher since I hate having to constantly fill up the smaller ones since you have to wait what seems like hours for the water to flow through filters. Of course the LED didn't work on mine either when it arrived, but I don't really care since the pitcher is otherwise designed very well.The spout is narrow so that water doesn't go everywhere. If you start pouring water before the water has filtered through from the top, it doesn't leak. Also, the flip open top to refill the pitcher makes it so you don't have to take the entire top off to fill from a faucet like most pitchers.

I can't say enough good things about this camera. I've been working with IP and camera technology for many years, and have tested hundreds of cameras. This thing is spectacular for the price. I did purchased these elsewhere though since I found better pricing, but I had to patiently wait a month for the seller to ship them, and another 2 weeks for them to arrive. I also have only used these with firmware version 5.2.5 and 5.2.8. If you absolutely need pan/tilt, the Foscam FI9831W seems to be the only competition with a name brand manufacturer supporting it in this price range at this time, but still has nowhere near the features and functionality.Highlights:• Image quality is outstanding. It even has pretty fair low light capabilities with the IR LED disabled. (Make sure you enable WDR if need be - it's not enabled by default. Also I tweak up the brightness slightly).• The IR LED is amazing (and can be disabled if you're pointing it out a window)• The features available in the web interface are entirely unsurpassed.• Audio sensitivity is adjustable through the web interface, unlike other manufacturer’s cameras, and can be tweaked to be VERY sensitivity. Note that you need to go in and enable audio on the stream settings if you want to hear audio!• Video motion detection and local SD recording is great (make sure you get a fast SD card). If you're indoors though, and not facing out a window, you should be using the super awesome PIR sensor instead of video motion detection for 99.999% accuracy. If you're doing video motion detection, enable "Dynamic Analysis for Motion" and "rules" under location configuration so that it will draw rectangles around motion detection objects in the live view for fine tuning motion detection. SD card recording automatic overwrite of older recordings is enabled by default. It supports adjustable pre (up to 30s) and post (up to 10m) event recording. It also supports multiple NAS devices.• Endless customization options and settings! (Therefore don’t buy this if you’re an idiot, or if you’re an idiot and don’t have a 10 year old to help you set this up).  For any IP camera, you need to understand port forwarding, bandwidth, IP addressing, and frame rates, so don’t be lazy and do some reading first!!!• For people who are concerned about their privacy and don’t want others viewing your video, you can disable P2P (point to point) capabilities (this is under Platform Access). I don’t know why people are so lazy and sacrifice their privacy and buy those plug & play / point to point cameras!!• Be sure to choose the right lens when buying this. There are several options. I have these with 2.8mm and 4mm lenses that I use for different applications. Buy the 2.8 if you’re viewing close range and want a very wide angle of view such as a vestibule, garage, porch, etc.. Buy the 4mm, or larger, if the camera iss going to be looking down a hallway or down a street.• Wireless works great and supports all the latest security protocols.• PoE works fine.• Supports SSL,DDNS, NTP (make sure you adjust the DST settings since the timing is wrong, and make sure you set the offset to 60 minutes), FTP, SMTP alerts, QoS, SNMP, etc. etc.Drawbacks:• The biggest drawback is that the latest versions of firmware aren’t readily available. I’ve had these cameras for months now and have yet to see version 5.2.5 or 5.2.8 posted on any of Hikvision’s web sites. Hikvision, if you’re listening, please always post the latest versions of firmware on your site!!! You’re only hurting your sales by not posting firmware updates.• I haven’t been able to use talk back through the web interface and Firefox. This may just be a problem with my particular setup. When I try using talk back with Tinycam for Android, I get a bunch of static at first, then it works so-so. I don’t really care about the talk back since I’m not using them as a video intercom.

I got this after reading some research regarding inosine's potential benefits in regards to neuron repair and survival, and more. It seems like 2 capsules is generally safe (actual experience may vary since we're all different), but excessive amounts can increase uric acid too much and trigger kidney stones! (Look in the studies on pubmed regarding inosine and uric acid). I make sure I take this in the morning and have plenty to drink all day.
I tried these, as well as the Timberland and Columbia Quarter Socks. These were OK, but the Timberland and Columbia socks were much more comfy, with the Timberlands being the most comfy.

I have an old Dell 1700 that I've got quite a bit of use out of. It was very straight forward to refill the cartridge for it. My advice would be to wear a painter's mask so that you don't breathe the stuff in, make sure you lay down a bunch of newspaper on the floor, and be sure to clip the top of the nozzle to make it larger. This stuff is super fine and very messy, especially as you're trying to squeeze the bottle to get it all in the cartridge - it sort of poofs up everywhere when you squeeze the bottle. So, if you clip the top of the nozzle there's more of a chance it will just pour into the cartridge rather than you have to squeeze the bottle. I also needed to use a piece of double sided scotch tape to mount the new chip on the cartridge.
This is probably the best camera clamp out there for the price at the moment! I can get a nice good secure grip on many objects with this. Excellent design!

I read a lot of the reviews on this camera and similar cameras before purchasing it. First, I decided on this over the FI9826W which adds 3x optical zoom, since there appears to be no manual focus on that, and where these cameras are going, I don't really need it. Second, I can't believe people don't care about their privacy enough to avoid so called P2P (point to point)/Plug and Play cameras, which actually make use of a third party server to relay video to your portable device when it's outside of your home network - these cameras are for lazy people who don't want to bother reading how to or have someone setup VPN or port forwarding on their home router to access their home network, all at the expense of video from your home open for others to see! I'm happy to have a camera that is not P2P, and if you value your privacy, you should be avoiding P2P/Plug and Play cameras at all cost!!Also, even if you don't get the plug and play cameras, be sure to access your camera using SSL (HTTPS). This camera does support SSL access, you just need to be sure to use it that way and setup the appropriate port forward as necessary (the standard port is 443). Another option would be to use VPN to access your home network/cameras without https (less taxing on the camera CPU). If you don't use HTTPS, all of your video, as well as your username and password when you login are sent unencrypted over the Internet for anyone in between to view. Foscam cameras don't automatically redirect you to SSL. Android and Apple devices natively support PPTP VPN, so buy a router that supports PPTP VPN if yours does not, or install something like dd-wrt on your router if it supports it. Also, note that this camera has an option to enable dynamic DNS provided by the manufacturer so you can use the address shown in the camera's setup to access it.I fail to understand how anyone could have so much trouble setting these Foscam cameras up! I had mine up and running within 15 minutes!  If you don't know anything about computers, you're lazy, are illiterate, don't know how to use Google, don't have a 6 year old accessible to you, then you'll probable have a problem and I wouldn't buy this camera. People that are morons or too lazy to education themselves about what they're purchasing should have a stamp on their forehead and be blacklisted! They just bring up the price for everyone else with ridiculous tech support calls costing companies money and forcing them to outsource tech support to India. Think about how cheap this camera is relevant to what it can do and how much they have to pay tech support people to answer calls from lazy people! The rest of us are paying for their calls in the price of the camera. If you can't understand the concept of IP addressing, port forwarding, and dynamic DNS, and don't have someone around that does (pretty rare in today's world), just don't buy a network camera. End of story. If you choose to buy a P2P/Plug & Play camera, just be aware that your video is not private, and will also suffer from somewhat greater lag time.I did find a better deal elsewhere on a bundle of 2 of these cameras with mounts, power extension cables, and high gain antennas. I had no problems using Internet Explorer or Firefox to configure them, but had no real plans to use a browser to access them, and there's plenty of third party software you can use with this since it supports standard video and audio transport protocols, and you should plan on using third party software from the get go (ie Blue Iris, TinyCam, etc.). Android is the better platform for remote camera viewing in general since Android is an open platform, has more flexible API's, support, and there are better, and cheaper apps out there in general. There are plenty of software options out there for PC, Android, and Apple though. TinyCam is definitely the best for Android, and also supports accessing this camera with SSL. At the price, Foscam can't possibly support every odd-ball system out there, so please understand that. Let Foscam concentrate on delivering us the hardware at a reasonable price that works and that we can all afford!! Third party software is CHEAP (TinyCam has a free version, and a few dollars for the pro version), and as long as you get standards based cameras such as these, there won't be a problem. This camera supports both modern H.264 video streaming with dual streams, as well as MJPEG (continuous jpeg snapshots), and I had no problems using Blue Iris (PC Based) or TinyCam (for Android), or even VLC media player (RTSP/H.264) with the camera. If you are using TinyCam as your viewer with H.264 mode, the video had some artifacts in it for the first several seconds, but only when trying to use the H/W decoder option (a TinyCam/Android problem - so just stick with the default S/W decoder setting). Other than this, using TinyCam works great, including control over the pan/tilt, and IR LEDs, and two way audio.One VERY important note (following 4 paragraphs):When viewing the video over a cellular network, you need to have sufficient bandwidth and signal. I recommend viewing the RTSP sub stream, NOT the main stream, and setting the RTSP stream to a much lower resolution and frame rate than the Main stream so that you will be able to view it without connection errors, pauses, etc. due to delay lack of bandwidth on the cellular network. This will also save a ton on your bandwidth quota!  Also, on small screens, unless you are pinch zooming a lot, you're likely not going to notice a big difference. Never ever use the MJPEG stream over a cellular network - it consumes a ton of bandwidth, and you also don't get audio. The RTSP stream URLs for the Main and Sub streams are, assuming you left the camera on port 88 (replace username, password, and camera_ip_or_hostname with your values):rtsp://username:password@camera_ip_or_hostname:88/videoMainrtsp://username:password @ camera_ip_or_hostname:88/videoSubNote there are a couple different methods to access the MJPEG stream from this camera. I'll leave those for you to Google.When you are viewing the video locally, or over a remote network with high bandwidth available, obviously choose the main stream. If you are using TinyCam, there is a checkbox under Video Settings to choose "2G Low-bandwidth Profile". If you setup your Foscam cameras by specifying the make and model, TinyCam will use the sub stream when you select the "2G Low-bandwidth profile" checkbox.The stream selection and setup process is one thing that is not very well designed in the web interface and is very convoluted, but once you get it, it's understandable. It functions entirely different from most cameras on the market. In the web interface, when you go to the Settings tab, then click Video, then Video Settings, here you will find what are actually presets for the Main and Sub streams - they don't actually change the active stream settings, they are only presets. When you login to the camera, there is a drop down box that gives you the option of what stream to view. If you want to change the preset that the sub stream uses, you must change this from Main stream to Sub stream, then login. Under the Live Video tab (already selected if you just logged in), here you will select the preset that the stream actually uses (both when viewing through the web interface, or third party RTSP/MJPEG viewers). There is no save button, which almost leads someone to believe that this setting is just for the current viewing session in the browser, but it is not, it is actually setting the resolution for the RTSP stream!I also upgraded to the latest firmware after setting my FI9831W's up. Though there were two firmware files required for upgrading and it took several minutes, and a two step procedure, it was extremely easy.If you don't need the pan/tilt functionality, I recommend taking a look at an app called IP Webcam for Android. It will turn any old Android phone into a high res MJPEG surveillance camera. (Remember though that MJPEG compressesion consumes an enormous amount of bandwidth, so it is not generally practical for viewing over cellular networks). You do need a phone with a good low light camera though. Also, take a look at the Hikvision DS-2CD2432F-IW. There are plenty of discussions regarding it on the web if you want to read up on it, and you should be able to grab one for under $130 including shipping at the time I wrote this. Just make certain you specify the 2.8mm wide angle lens when you order it unless you are monitoring something far away from the camera, since if you do not specify, it will ship with the 4mm lens. You may also need an external IR illuminator since the internal LED is of limited range (see online reviews). The Hikvision camera also adds a PIR (passive infrared) sensor for motion detection, which unlike video motion detection that the Foscam cameras are limited by, as well as most others, it is not vulnerable to lighting and other artifacts - it's the same technology used in home and business motion detectors for security systems.Anyhow, I've tested and used nearly 60 different cameras over the last several years, and for the price, this Foscam camera is pretty decent and has a good feature set, hence the 4 star review. In reality, I would give it 3 stars.The cons for me are:¤ There are a couple bugs with the web browser/plugin interface display. The Stream selection drop down box under the Live Video tab is truncated, and the selection boxes for setting the motion detection area under the alarm settings are truncated.¤ I don't like the fact that you can't configure the camera without the plug-in installed and a compatible browser. Without the plug-in installed, it would be nice if you at least had some limited functionality that would just let you set the IP address, SSID, etc. and other settings that wouldn't necessarily require¤In low light without the IR LEDs enabled, the CMOS sensor and DSP starts producing strange artifacts in the video. However, compared to anything else out there in the price range, the FI9831W is still best in its class.¤The internal microphone produces a terrible digital static noise when the camera gets cold, specifically below about 35 degrees Fahrenheit.  It gets to the point that you can't hear anything besides the static noise. You can observe this on your camera by placing the camera in a freezer for a little while, giving it time to cool.  I wanted to place one of these cameras outside in an enclosed area, but learned quickly that wasn't going to be possible if I wanted audio. Even with an external microphone plugged in, there was still noise in colder temperatures. I brought this to Foscam's attention, and they're supposedly investigating the issue, but obviously to correct this issue, it's going to be more than just a firmware fix.¤There should be a gain control in the web interface to set the microphone sensitivity. Even though the microphone sensitivity is worlds better than previous models, I've heard better (and I've heard worse). IP Webcam for Android combined with most phones has amazing microphone sensitivity, for example. You can attach an external high gain microphone, though I haven't tried one out yet on this. If you Google, Foscam microphone fi9831w, the first hit is people complaining about the microphone issues. If you know about electronics, and don't mind voiding your warranty, you may be able to open the case, and put in a lower value resistor as mentioned in the link.¤You can't relocate the position of the on screen Date/Timestamp/Camera Name, or change the size, which is exceptionally massive when viewing the lower resolution streams, and can hide video. All you can do is disable it.¤ If you have problems with the alarm functionality, the camera being slow, or choppy video, you might want to reduce the frame rate to 10-12 fps. 12 fps is still pretty decent unless you're trying to catch cars driving by at 60mph. Other than adjusting the FPS, try reducing the video resolution (running this at 720P will be less taxing on the CPU). Video consumes a ton of CPU, and changing the FPS and res will spare some more CPU for motion detection, alarms, and other functionality.¤The motion detection area setup is buggy. The video motion detection area display hides the options in the browser (both IE and Firefox). I've notified Foscam about this issue. Also, although you can setup multiple detection areas, you can't control the sensitivity of each one individually.¤There is no external alarm input/output. Video motion detection is inherently inaccurate. It would be nice if these had alarm I/O like most other cameras to be able to hook up an external I/R sensor (they are about $10) for 99.9% motion detection accuracy.Some pros are:¤The pan/tilt through the browser and apps works very will, with a good network connection. Expect some lag over cellular networks. I've seen other cameras have all sorts of issues with Pan/Tilt. Mirror/Flip works well if you need to ceiling mount this.¤Very good video quality when there's lots of light, or when the IR LEDs are on (note that it switches to black/white).¤You can set the IR LEDs to manual or automatic. Many cameras out there don't give you the option.¤It has most of the features you can think of - SMTP mail alerts with attachments, upload to FTP server,PLEASE MARK THIS REVIEW HELPFUL , and so OTHERS CAN KNOW ABOUT THE DANGERS OF P2P (and how to select a camera)!

I was apprehensive about getting this with all the bad reviews out there with competing products, however now that the cold weather has really sunk in and put this to the test, I have yet to find a trace of ice in this. I also connected this to my Z-Wave energy management system, and it does very well on electricity usage (obviously it will vary based on environmental temperature).

I've used these about 20 times. Installation was a snap. My last grips were more comfortable and easier on the hands when coming down and landing on something since they were gel filled, but these are 1000% more solid, I don't have to worry about them sliding off, and you can get a good grip on them. I guess I just need to find some gloves now with more gel in them.

I purchased this under a second listing here on Amazon. I've used this for about a week now, and it appears to be working pretty good. My only issue is that if you don't use the transmitter remote for a while, the display backlight will turn off for power saving(fine), and then the LCD display (low energy usage anyway) will completely turn off (not so fine since it will take longer if you want to see what your settings are first). When you press a button on the transmitter after going to sleep like this, the transmitter/remote wakes up and then the display looks like it's transmitting (the antenna icon on on the LCD flashes), but it's actually not. You actually have to wake the transmitter up first by hitting a button, then wait about a second (I tested - you can't just rapidly click the button you want twice) until the antenna icon shows on the LCD, then press a button again. If you forget this double step, or think your remote is already awake, it is often too late to catch your pet in the middle of doing something bad, especially since it'll probably take you at least several seconds to locate the remote, find the buttons you want, adding a critical delay.Since it takes about 4 hours to charge, and the battery lasts about 30 hours after being charged (I'm sure it won't last as long as the battery ages), you should consider purchasing the two receiver version of this (AT-211SW-2). Also, make sure you pay attention to the instructions as there are a few odd things, as well as a couple things I noted here. There is a red and a blue LED on the top. When the collar is active, the blue LED will blink about every 15 seconds. When it's charging the red LED will be lit. When charging is complete, the blue and red LED's will both be lit. After unplugging it, the red LED will be lit. The red LED will even stay lit after disconnecting the collar receiver from the charger. However, this means that it's waiting for a signal from the remote to pair with it. So, after each charge, you must repair the remote with the collar. I believe this is because you can have multiple remotes and collars with this system. This isn't really a big deal. If you aren't going to use the collar receiver immediately after disconnecting it from the charger, you should power it off by holding down the power button for about 5 seconds until it vibrates and beeps to indicate it's powering off. Also, you need to make sure the charger's plug snaps FIRMLY into the collar (it almost feels like you're going to break it). There should just be a spec of metal from the charger plug seen from the side. If you don't have it in all the way, charging will be erratic. The collar receiver takes about 4 hours to charge.Make sure you get a pretty snug fit (but that your pet can still breathe obviously), and once you get the position correct, to put a mark on the notch on the strap you're at with tape. The collar is made of very thick plastic, and is also about an inch wide. It's very long, but it looks like the length could be easily trimmed. You might want to consider purchasing a different collar as I did. Line of sight I can get about 180 ft range. With walls in the way I get about 90-120 ft. Also, the instructions are clearly written by someone who's primary language is definitely not English. Even though you barely need the instructions, except for an explanation of the LEDs and numbers, they should have just paid a high school student like $20 to proof read them first.It could also use a louder buzzer for locating - it's very quiet and could definitely only work outdoors in near pure silence when very close by. It would actually be nice if the volume of the buzzer followed the level set on the transmitter. The version I purchased happened to be the newer version that operates at 900MHz instead of 400MHz. I believe these were updated to 900MHz in February of 2014, so everything shipping now will be the newer version.We'll see how this holds up over time, how long the batteries will hold a charge for, and what the lifespan is on this. I haven't tried to open anything up yet to see if I can find replacement rechargeable batteries somewhere online (I'm sure they're very proprietary and need to be soldered in). It sure beats the competition in having to purchased massive quantities of those flat watch style batteries.

It seems these days there's so much junk out there and products that are shipped that are partially functional and have serious bugs and obvious design flaws. I expected there to be something seriously wrong with this, however, I ended up being surprised at how well it worked. I set this up with a T-Mobile prepaid SIM (the $3/month plan that gives you 30 minutes or texts and is good for 3 months, no data). I sent it a couple of programming commands via text message (all you need to know is how to read to set this up, so unless you're illiterate, or didn't make it past the 3rd grade, you shouldn't have a problem setting this up), and it was up and working. I read the reviews on here, and like a lot of negative reviews on technology products on Amazon, the negative reviews are due to owner confusion, failure to read the products description or directions, or just plain too lazy to use Google to educate themselves.Here’s how I set it up for SMS text message location trackingFirst text message: begin123456Second text message: admin123456 XXXXXXXXXX  (where the X's are your cell phone number - not sure if this is necessary for your primary number, but authorizes this cell phone number to communicate with the tracker)Third text message: monitor123456 (changes what happens when you call into the tracker so that you can listen in vs. having it send you a text message back)Text message to have tracker send you its location with a Google link: G123456# (obviously G stands for Google. I haven't tried hacking it with any other characters.)Note that there are two ways you can use this. The first is just by sending it an SMS text messaging or calling the phone number to have it send you an SMS text message back with a link to its location on Google Maps. The second is by using GPRS, which gives you online tracking via a web site, with location updates sent from the tracker at an interval that you set (default is every 2 minutes) This however also requires that you both have a data plan for the tracker to communicate over the Internet to a server in China (yes I verified the tkstar server is in China), and that you program your carrier’s APN information in the tracker). I did not attempt to use the GPRS option since it was completely unnecessary for me and a waste of $$.Also note that the manual for this left out the Monitor123456 command, which changes the tracker so that when you call into it, you can listen in to audio in the surroundings, instead of having it send you an SMS back with its location. It will still send you an SMS text with its location when you text G123456# to it. I believe the command to disable this and switch it back so that when you call it sends you an SMS message instead is Tracking123456.We'll see how it holds up with time, and how waterproof it is (there is a rubber grommet that goes into the USB/SIM port). I got this for a new cat that really wanted to go outside along with an Aetertek RF collar (since the Aetertek can be used as a close proximity locator/beeper once you get in the vicinity of your pet with GPS). They are both kind of big, but my cat has no problem wearing them both on her collar, and actually purrs when I put them on, probably because she knows she's about to go outside). If you think your cat or dog might have a serious problem with the size, I would try putting a wide dog collar around their neck with something bulky attached to it to see how your pet will react.Hints:You might want to disable the auto sleep option at first when you start to play around with it, or else it will automatically turn off the LED indicators and the GPS chip in 5 minutes, and there may be delays in it sending you its location.You may need to purchase a smaller or different size collar for it.I didn't use the GPRS option. I'm fine with just sending it text messages, and having it text me back with a location link on Google maps.The first time you turn it on make sure it has a nice clear unobstructed 360 degree path to the sky.Pros:The microphone actually works OK, though the sensitivity could be better.Light weight (it is kind of big, but my cat doesn't have any problem wearing it, though I did get a different collar for it).Sleep mode seems to work OK. It powers off the LED’s and GPS chip, but leaves the cellular radio on. With sleep mode off, the battery will drain much quicker since the GPS chip and LED lights will be on all the time, however it will return the location much quicker since it won't have to determine its location every time you wake it up.Improvements could be:1. It needs an on/off switch vs. a stupid momentary button that could get pressed by accident and needs to be pressed all the time, and it also makes this useless for anything else that would require a hard wire implementation down the road.2. It takes quite some time and pretty good signal strength to get a GPS lock at first.3. The Google maps URL cannot be reprogrammed. So, if Google ever decides to change the URL, the links sent by SMS to Google maps won’t work anymore.For the dummies out there:This is GSM. You can’t use a Verizon or Sprint SIM card (or MVNO’s that partner with/use Verizon or Sprint CDMA technology). Verizon and Sprint, use the older North American CDMA technology, unlike T-Mobile and AT&T that use GSM like the rest of the world. You can obviously use any AT&T or T-Mobile partner that uses GSM and lets you use unlocked phones on their network if you don’t want to use AT&T or T-Mobile.If you live in the boonies, make sure you have signal from whatever carrier you choose.Obviously you should have a Smartphone so you can click the link in the text message and have it take you directly to Google maps. If you don’t have a Smartphone, you probably aren’t technologically savvy enough to use this tracker anyhow, but obviously you could use an old school phone and copy the link and/or coordinates into Google on a PC with Internet access and find the location on a map that way.Don’t complain about monthly fees with this product.  LOL @ those morons! First off, there’s no other realistic alternative than using cellular networks to support this product and no way around paying cellular fees since the manufacturer isn’t going to build their own trillion dollar cellular network to support this product.  In fact, be happy that you have the freedom to choose whatever carrier you want to use with this product, and that the manufacturer hasn’t partnered with cellular companies to provide services for a monthly fee like other tracking or car systems that you have to pay $20/month or more for!

I settled on this after being infuriated with those stupid breakaway collars. There's probably more cats that get lost, never brought back to their owners, and end up getting killed because those stupid things fall off. This fits nice and snug, and works great with my TKSTAR GPS tracker!

I had been looking at this sofa for a while, and finally ended up purchasing it since it had the specs that I wanted:1. Short height padded armrests. This is nice for laying your head on or putting your feet up on if you're laying down. I can't stand those stupid high walled side sofas.2. Seat depth not too deep and sofa height not too tall. The vast majority of sofas out there seem to be made for people who are at least 7 feet tall - when you sit on them with normal posture, your feet don't touch the ground or your lower back doesn't touch the back of the sofa, eventually leading to back pain. This sofa has a shorter height, and comes with legs that you can add on if you choose for additional height (they come tucked under the rightmost cushion). Also, the seats aren't super deep on this sofa, and you can adjust the depth somewhat (1-2" on or out) by pushing in the cushions more or pulling them out slightly since they're held in place with Velcro.3. Lumbar support. The rear cushions should have lower back support. The rear cushions on many sofas out there bulge out in the middle, leaving you with no lumbar support in your lower back. Just looking a the picture of this sofa, you can see the extra roll for lower back support.4. Easily replaceable foam in the rear and seat cushions. The seat cushions of this sofa are held in place with Velcro, and unzip in the back (they are not reversible though). There are also zippers on the bottom of the fabric in the rear (although they're sewn in as part of the sofa).5. Not leather or rough fabric. I detest leather. Many people purchase a leather sofa or choose leather in their car just as some sort of status symbol. Unless you plan on spilling all sorts of liquids on your furniture, leather is terrible. It's slippery, gets cold in the winter, sticky in the summer, etc. This sofa is made of pretty comfortable microfiber. It does however get a bit warm when sitting on it.6. Light weight and no recliner. I hate moving heavy sofas around. Not only is it a pain, but they always tend to end up getting ruined in the process. Clearly having a recliner is out of the picture, but you can always just add on an ottoman if you need something to put your legs up on. Non-electric recliners are annoying anyhow since they don't lock in place, and with any little movement in your body they tend to return to their unreclined position.So, this sofa met the above requirements. Unfortunately, starting within a week, the seat cushions started to soften up pretty bad, to the point where you would sit on them and they would go from 6" to about 1"! The middle cushion of the sofa seems to be affected the worst, so perhaps the spring support underneath is also a factor in the softening of this sofa. However, I could tell that cheap low density foam is mostly responsible for this. Higher density foam contains more material, and is therefore more expensive. As a note I'm under 180lbs.I ended up ordering replacement 55 ILD High Quality Lux foam with Dacron wrap from foambymail for about $130. So plan on adding that into your purchase price for this sofa. I measured the foam to be 25" deep, 24" wide, and 5" high. It actually ended up that the foam I ordered was not high enough, so it must've been 6" that I needed. So, I ended up ripping off the Dacron wrap from the original foam, wrapping around the replacement foam that was already wrapped, and the cushions ended up perfect. My sofa is now nice and firm, but still has good support and molds to your rear end nicely.

I got this several weeks ago for a stray cat that would hang around once in a while. I would put food in it for her. It got really cold one night and I found her in there early in the morning shivering!! She died shortly after. 20 watts is not enough to heat anything on a cold night.Furthermore, when it rains, the entire thing gets sopping wet, including the interior and heated pad. Also, when the heated pad gets soaked, it triggers the heating mechanism and draws full power as I verified with a current meter.

I saw a good deal on these so I purchased 2 of these to try. This review is with the latest firmware and Android app as of the date of this review.First, it took me over 4 hours to program them. You enter your WiFi SSID and key in their app, then you hold your phone against the thing's sensor on top while it sends pulses of light for up to and around 20 seconds in order to program it. The power strip blinks back a series of cryptic varying color flashes of which there isn't really much explanation of what they mean, other than if you start seeing green flashing, you're good, and if not, you're not good. I tried programming them with 3 different devices, following some tips I read online (turn any light off in the room, use WPA encryption instead of WPA2, setting the phone brightness to max, trying a different access point, etc.) In the end, my problems turned out to be a combination of things - I needed to use a newer device that the screen was LED backlit, secondly I had to change the CPU governor in my phone to performance mode to be able to flash the screen quick enough (thankfully I'm running a modded Android operating system that lets me do that!), the dark room seemed to help, and finally there appeared to be a bug in the Android App in that once you go through one programming attempt, you have to go all the way back 6 steps, and re-enter your WiFi SSID and password because it loses it. Apparently Quirky didn't test programming the power strip with many devices, or else they would have made the flashes slower and would have designed these issues out of the Android app.After that was all said and done (note that these do in fact work with WPA2 encryption, and 802.11n 2.4GHz), I began testing them. Here are the problems (I sent these to Quirky, and they have not responded yet):1. It does not keep the last state of the relays in onboard flash memory. Therefore, in the event of a power outage and Internet connectivity is not available, the outlets remain off. In fact, after testing disconnecting my Internet, there seemed to be a timeout, and the outlets on both power strips would just turn off! I also tested with the outlets on, then powering off the power strips, disconnecting the Internet connection, powering the power strips back on, waiting a couple of minutes before reconnecting the Internet connection, and guess what? The ports remained off, and they even showed off in the app, whereas previously they were on! The ports would only return to on if there was an Internet connection immediately available upon powering up! After calling into their support number, they confirmed that if there is not Internet connection when they boot up, the outlets stay off! The engineer that thought that through needs to be banned forever from designing any electronic devices and would be much better at cleaning toilets somewhere, although they would probably manage to somehow screw that up too.
