What's weird is that I have the GE ZWave outdoor appliance module, and it does in fact go right back to state it was in when it lost power, regardless of connectivity.As I sit here, I just heard both relays click in the power strips, and lost power both of my devices connected to the 2 switchable ports, after working for about 12 hours (and my Internet connection is just fine). Oh joy, I get to waste more time fruitlessly trying to make these work.2. The Android app is dreadfully painful to use. The GUI needs to be completely redesigned and the person or person(s) responsible for its design banned from programming anything ever again as well! Even the standard Android back button actually closes the app when it should just go to the previous screen, and only the home button should close the app.Finally, the functionality of these is 100% dependent on access to Wink's cloud server. I did a full TCP port scan on these and there are no open TCP ports listening, meaning that even if you purchase a hub that lets you access it locally, it will still have to manage and communicate with these via Wink's cloud server! So if Wink's cloud server is ever down or they go out of business, guess what?I will be returning these shortly.

It's hard to find chargers that work well with two Android devices. Most chargers seem to be designed for one crApple device, and one Android device, with the crApple port not working with many devices.The LED light is ridiculously bright. If I were the owner of LEPOWER I would immediately fire the moron engineer who added this LED like that. If you're planning on sleeping anywhere in the vicinity of this, or want your room dark to watch a movie, you'll need to plan on also purchasing or using some black electrical tape to cover up the top of this.
I was using this one day and the part of the handle that pulls back on the metal pin when you squeeze it just split right off from the handle. Do not buy!

This is a great idea, but definitely needs further refinement. If you move around at all while you're sleeping, it will go off constantly as it doesn't have an accelerometer built into it to thwart false alarms from moving around. If either of the electrodes ever so slightly lose perfect contact with your skin while moving around it will continuously sound, rather than notice a discrepancy in the EMG readings and disable for a period of time. There should be some sort of detection threshold setting for it losing contact where it won't sound for several seconds. Also, it's buggy in that the alarm sound sometimes stays on for up to 5 seconds or more even after you stop clenching, then beeps several times before stopping. The piezo buzzer doesn't get that loud, and is just a single tone that you can easily end up getting used to, as I did. So, after a couple weeks of use, it was pretty much useless.If you can manage to stay perfectly still while sleeping, can deal with the bugs, and are a light sleeper, this may work for you, otherwise save your money until version 2.0 comes out with these issues addresses unless you're desperate. Also, make sure you’re using fresh batteries and you clean the electrodes nightly before use, or you'll end up with even more problems. Also, as the batteries go, you need to crank up the sensitivity setting as well.Also watch out for fake reviews and reviews being voted as not helpful. Never believe a review that has no criticism, especially with a product like this.Update 6/25/2015I ended up building my own super comfortable Bluetooth EMG headband pretty easily. You can use the NeuroSky TGAM1 EEG chip with a Bluetooth module, a headband, TENS electrodes and wires, an accelerometer, an Arduino, and conductive fabric. When you clench your teeth, the RAW EEG data will generate numerous peaks. I just created a program to play sounds when it detects the presence of peaks in the RAW EEG data (actually EMG at this point), in the absence of accelerometer movement, and bam, it works perfectly!

It does everything it's supposed to. If I were to have one complaint, the most that it would be is that it tickles the inside of my nose!
I got this for a pendant to give as a Christmas gift. It looks great and is very solid. Thanks
I purchased this battery from CellularFactory. The hologram wasn't the same as the OEM battery. I contacted Motorola, and they confirmed this.
I purchased this as a gift, but it was well received and the case seemed to be made very well, and fit nicely.

I can't say enough good things about with with DD-WRT. I used this to connect two office buildings together with external antennas, and the receive sensitivity is amazing compared to many other wireless routers I have tried with the same antenna configuration. Without moving the antenna, this blows away every other wireless router I have tried (Linksys, Asus, D-Link).

I purchased the TL-WA5110G to replace an older failing wireless router that I used to connect to a wireless ISP. I also purchased a TP-LINK TL-WR741ND, and installed the latest version of DD-WRT on it. After spending an hour going back and forth between the two testing the performance, I found the WR741ND with DD-WRT performed significantly better by about 20%. With the TL-WA5110G, I would average around 4Mbps, and the WR741ND around 5Mbps consistently. Mind you nothing changed with the antenna configuration. All I did was swap back and forth the LAN cable and external antenna connection between the two when I was comparing. I don't know what would happen if I had the TL-WA5110G at both ends of the link, but contrary to the manufacturers claims, the TL-WA5110G receiver sensitivity is significantly less than that of the TL-WR741ND's.

These cables are terrible! I did better with $2 cables from China. They were loose and didn't fit correctly in any of my phones (Droid 3, 4, and a couple other phones) right out of the package. They would only charge if you hold the cable in at a certain angle. Also the clips that hold the cable in place are very harsh on the slot - they don't fit in smoothly which will cause excessive wear on the slot in your phone.

I've been exclusively using JVC systems over the past 10 years, but after many failures due to poor quality component sourcing, specifically the buttons and knobs internal components failing, I figured I'd give this Kenwood a shot (even though they merged in 2008). What I was nervous about since Kenwood didn't specifically detail how it worked in the manual I found on their web site, was how having multiple phones paired to the system would work. Actually it works decent except for the bugs I'll outline below. You can have two phones simultaneously paired to the system and it will work with any phone that's paired automatically when a call is received. When a call is placed from any phone, it will automatically switch to that phone. When a call is placed from the stereo, the device with priority set is used.I installed this system myself in about 10 minutes since it used the same wiring harness style connector that my JVC had. The audio is phenomenal. It has plenty of options to set things the way you like them.  I ran the rear USB input to the glove compartment where I keep a USB stick in the cable. I wanted to leave the front open for when friends. Everything works decent with my android phones - Bluetooth, USB, Pandora, iHeart, AHA, and the dual USB inputs. I have a problem with iHeart radio though in that custom stations never load - the system stays in a buffering state.While this system's basic functionality is decent, I have found numerous severe problems and annoyances. To begin with, you can set a device priority for Bluetooth hands free and media audio. However, this priority isn't saved upon Bluetooth devices disconnected and reconnecting.  So this means if you have two phones, or you and your significant other both have your phones paired and are in the car at the same time, it could randomly use the wrong phone depending on whose phone opened the Bluetooth connection to the stereo first. Second, I find it annoying when you scroll through songs using USB memory, it displays the folder name as a number which is idiotic. You have to hit the music search button to scroll through folders by name, which first makes you wait several seconds while the display says MUSICSEARCH. At least it isn't like some systems with USB playback that order the files by the order they were written to the USB stick instead of alphabetically. Next, there are a couple really dumb Bluetooth default settings. First is that Bluetooth audio is set to only use the front speakers by default. This even includes Bluetooth media, not just hands free. Second, auto answer is automatically enabled after 8 seconds, forcing you to talk to the person who's calling. You have to make sure you go into the Bluetooth settings to change these settings. However, I have had this system about a month, and it has already randomly lost all of its Bluetooth settings (and phone pairings), so make sure you remember every time it loses its settings to do this. One other problem with the Bluetooth is if you have two phones paired, it doesn't disconnect the Bluetooth audio of the 2nd phone while you're on a call. Instead if you are on a call on Bluetooth, and your second phone or passenger whose phone also happens to be paired with the system gets a call, there will be an annoying repetitive high pitched beep through the system until Bluetooth on the second phone is manually disconnected.  Another problem is the display backlight is very dim so that it can barely be seen at all if you are wearing sunglasses while driving. Another thing is there aren't enough pixels in the display so you can have all the information you need on the display including cell phone battery, cell signal, etc. I do like that there are 3 configurable detailed lines of text though. Finally I wish they would find a better way to use presets, or just bring back the friggin preset buttons to systems.Just a couple note - make sure you go and check for firmware updates on Kenwood's web site for it.  Mine was pretty far behind.  Also make sure you read the directions and follow them precisely. There is a little tiny reset button behind the faceplate that you will need a paperclip or something small to press it with during the procedure. Second, be careful where you mount the Bluetooth microphone or you will sound like crap! The best spot for most cars seems to be up on the roof by the lights facing towards the driver's seat.  So, you will need to be skilled at carefully removing the plastic panels in your car to run the wire cleanly.
This worked great for basic a basic return with stock sales, 1040's, 1099's, donations, etc.  It was easy to setup and make my way through everything.

I wish the shag in this rug was all of a reasonable height and that the "pebblez" shag was flush.  The height of the shag outside of the "pebblez" if very short so that it's uncomfortable to walk on barefoot.

Due to cheap design, you can't use this to charge two smartphones at the same time (ie. iPhone on port 1, Android Smartphone on port 2).  The Smartphone on port 2 will take days to charge, if it ends up charging at all.

If you have 2 smartphones, forget it.  The port closest to the middle of the charger can't be used for charging a second smartphone.  I don't see why the 2 ports should be so different other than the manufacturer was being cheap.  Finally, I have a battery monitor widget on my android phone that I can view the phone's charging rate.  It takes approximately twice the amount of time to charge my phone with this charger than the more popular PowerGen charger that I purchased after this one.

After reading many reviews for different competing products on multilple web sites, I decided to get the medium bag.  I like the expandability of it, I just wish it had the pocket divided up in two so you don't have to worry about metal objects scratching up your phone.  I guess I'll just have to keep my tools ina felt bag.  It seems to be well made, though the zippers seem a tad on the flimsy side, so we'll have to see how they hold up.

I had been looking at this sofa for a while, and finally ended up purchasing it since it had the specs that I wanted:1.  Short height padded armrests.  This is nice for laying your head on or putting your feet up on if you're laying down.  I can't stand those stupid high walled side sofas.2.  Seat depth not too deep and sofa height not too tall.  The vast majority of sofas out there seem to be made for people who are at least 7 feet tall - when you sit on them with normal posture, your feet don't touch the ground or your lower back doesn't touch the back of the sofa, eventually leading to back pain.  This sofa has a shorter height, and comes with legs that you can add on if you choose for additional height (they come tucked under the rightmost cushion).  Also, the seats aren't super deep on this sofa, and you can adjust the depth somewhat (1-2" on or out) by pushing in the cushions more or pulling them out slightly since they're held in place with Velcro.3.  Lumbar support.  The rear cushions should have lower back support.  The rear cushions on many sofas out there bulge out in the middle, leaving you with no lumbar support in your lower back.  Just looking a the picture of this sofa, you can see the extra roll for lower back support.4.  Easily replaceable foam in the rear and seat cushions.  The seat cushions of this sofa are held in place with Velcro, and unzip in the back (they are not reversible though).  There are also zippers on the bottom of the fabric in the rear (although they're sewn in as part of the sofa).5.  Not leather or rough fabric.  I detest leather.  Many people purchase a leather sofa or choose leather in their car just as some sort of status symbol.  Unless you plan on spilling all sorts of liquids on your furniture, leather is terrible.  It's slippery, gets cold in the winter, sticky in the summer, etc.  This sofa is made of pretty comfortable microfiber.  It does however get a bit warm when sitting on it.6.  Light weight and no recliner.  I hate moving heavy sofas around.  Not only is it a pain, but they always tend to end up getting ruined in the process.  Clearly having a recliner is out of the picture, but you can always just add on an ottoman if you need something to put your legs up on.  Non-electric recliners are annoying anyhow since they don't lock in place, and with any little movement in your body they tend to return to their unreclined position.So, this sofa met the above requirements.  Unfortunately, starting within a week, the seat cushions started to soften up pretty bad, to the point where you would sit on them and they would go from 6" to about 1"!  The middle cushion of the sofa seems to be affected the worst, so perhaps the spring support underneath is also a factor in the softening of this sofa.  However, I could tell that cheap low density foam is mostly responsible for this.  Higher density foam contains more material, and is therefore more expensive.  As a note I'm under 180lbs.I ended up ordering replacement 55 ILD High Quality Lux foam with Dacron wrap from foambymail for about $130.  So plan on adding that into your purchase price for this sofa.  I measured the foam to be 25" deep, 24" wide, and 5" high.  It actually ended up that the foam I ordered was not high enough, so it must've been 6" that I needed.  So, I ended up ripping off the Dacron wrap from the original foam, wrapping around the replacement foam that was already wrapped, and the cushions ended up perfect.  My sofa is now nice and firm, but still has good support and molds to your rear end nicely.

OK But Has Drawbacks, Mangles Thin Paper, Pulls in Crooked!!I've had this scanner about 3 weeks now and the consumable status shows I've scanned over 9,000 pages with this scanner.  I thought I would share my experiences and the pros and cons that I've found with this scanner.  For general document archiving, it works ok, probably better than most if not all of the scanners that are currently for sale in its price range and category that I have read about. However it definitely has some caveats.  I wish I had a Brother ADS2000 to compare it to, which seems to be the most competitive scanner at this time.First I'll start by saying I'm using it with Windows.  The software that's included with the scanner, ScanSnap Organizer, makes scanning very smooth and quick so you can scan one set of documents after another with little interaction.  In my decision making, minimal interaction between scanning documents was an absolute requirement for me with the stacks of documents I need to scan.  When I first started looking at scanners, I was considering a Brother 8910DW MFC, but that would have been a nightmare because of the number of steps required to scan.  I didn't want anything where I had to click on multiple dialogs and confirm a million settings between scans.  I was hesitant to purchase this Fujitsu scanner since the interface and software is proprietary and doesn't support TWAIN or WIA.For the most part, the software developers did a pretty decent job with the included software.  First, there is the ScanSnap tray icon application that's responsible for low level interaction with the scanner.  You can access the scan settings by right clicking or double clicking on the tray icon.  These include settings and defaults for resolution, brightness, save directory, file type (pdf or jpg), blank page removal on/off, OCR, compression, etc.  This application is responsible for the major scanning activities, providing a small quick preview of each document as it is scanned, and warning and mitigation of scan errors (ie jams and multi-feeds).  There is also the ScanSnap Organizer software.  Each scanned document shows up in this application as a thumbnail, and there are forward and back buttons to move through the pages on each thumbnail without actually opening the scanned document.  A file folder structure shows up in a pane on the left where you can organize your scans into. If you want to rename the file to something other than the default (which is based on the scan date/time and you can also tweak), then you can rename with a single click.  Unfortunately, there are no PDF editing operations available from within SnapStream Organizer - you have to open the document in a separate PDF editor (Acrobat is included, but I use PDF-XChange since it's quicker) to perform simple common tasks such as deleting, rotating, and inserting pages.One wish for ScanSnap organizer is if you could trigger a scan from directly within the application, both simplex and duplex.  There should also be a way, either with scanning directly with ScanSnap organizer, or the tray icon, to scan using customized settings profiles that you can customize and create with different quality settings for different types of documents.  I would like to have a single point and click way of scanning using a customized scan profile for each.  There are pre-defined profiles that you can select from in the ScanSnap tray icon app, but you only customize one, and once you select another profile, it wipes out all your settings - very stupid design!  I realize Fujitsu is trying to keep things simple with a single button on the scanner, but the intelligence just isn't there yet to allow this to work well.One bug I've found with the ScanSnap Organizer software is if you try to change the case of a character or characters in any of your file or folder names, it won't take affect.  So, you either have to use another application like explorer to rename the file or folder, or change the name to something else and back.  For example, if you have a file or folder called "My scans" and you try to rename it to "My Scans", it will always revert back to "My scans".Also, there are some dumb defaults selected when you first install the Fujitsu software.  Please take these in mind when you install the software if you choose to purchase this.  One of them is that OCR settings by default only performing OCR on the first page.  Perhaps Fujitsu thought that this would be sufficient for finding documents and increase speed, but that should be up to the user to change to since the risk is that if you don't notice this foolish default immediately, you will lose out on being able to search the entirety of the documents you scan .  Second, the carrier sheet default is to scan in a two-sided document as a side by side document, not two separate pages.  Third, the preference "Always link when one of the applications is running" is not selected by default.  It is set to "Link when one of the applications is active".  I kept finding that the ScanSnap Manager dialog box would pop up annoyingly every so often when I would scan, and ask me what application I wanted to scan to, even though I had ScanSnap Organizer open and maximized.  I found that the determination of whether or not ScanSnap Organizer is running/active is flaky.  I've found that if you're scanning in a large document, and you click back to work on ScanSnap Organizer while the document is scanning, you will end up with the ScanSnap manager dialog popping up in your face.  In order for the linkage to work every time into ScanSnap Organizer, the scan status application has to be on top of ScanSnap Organizer, without ScanScap Organizer being active/selected.  Since I pretty much only scan to ScanSnap Organizer, changing the default setting to "Always link when one of the applications is running" solved this problem.  Therefore no matter what state ScanSnap Organizer is in, it will scan into it without asking.  I guess Fujitsu designed it this way in case you decided to have multiple Fujitsu scanner applications running, it would automatically choose the "foreground" application to scan into.  Unfortunately, it's a little buggy.  Also, note that the setting for application detection is not logically placed and hard to find.  You have to right click on the ScanSnap tray icon, then hover over Help, then click "Preferences..."  As a note, I have installed the latest software updates available from Fujitsu's web site.The multifeed detection seems to work good.  Unfortunately, it's not absolutely perfect and you do still have to pay some attention to every sheet that gets sent through the scanner and/or count the number of pages you're scanning.  Out of the 9,000 pages I've scanned, I have caught two separate sets of pages that were multifed without the scanner detecting it.  The blank page removal works so-so.  If you're scanning in a letter that was previously folded, it will pick up the fold marks and flag the page as non-blank.  This mal-behavior is pretty consistent.  Bleedthrough also defeats the blank page detection on 2-sided documents.  This makes it impossible most of the time to leave the scanner on duplex scan mode, or forces you to manually do a simplex scan on single sided documents.  This is especially true for receipts. Blank page detection does however seem to work well with hole punched paper, interestingly enough.The image sensor is CMOS.  CMOS is a newer and cheaper technology than the older CCD type of image sensor; however, it requires a lot of light, as anyone would know who has tried to take a low light picture with a smart phone.  As a consequence, there is quite substantial bleed through when scanning 2-sided documents, most notably with thinner paper.  There is an option to reduce bleed-through in the scan settings, however this results in very faint text since apparently it just lowers the brightness on the scanner illuminator and doesn't really have any sort of intelligence such as comparing the front and back images of the document that was scanned.As far as scan quality goes, it is great for general document scanning.  I usually scan basic documents on the "better" setting (Color/Gray 200 DPI, B&W 400 DPI).  This seems to provide a decent combination of file size and quality.  I have tried scanning a few photos, and it seemed hit or miss.  Although the resolution provided clarity, the colors were fairly off in a few photos.  I would suggest a separate high resolution flatbed scanner if you're looking for something for photo archiving (this is max 600 DPI optical color, decent photo scanners at the moment are 9600 DPI optical resolution).Don't expect the paper exit tray to work very well either.  You need to sit there with your hand at the end of the exit tray to prevent your scanned documents from flying all over the place, especially if you are scanning in anything but new perfectly flat paper.  Fujitsu should have added paper guides to the exit tray, as well as a fold out adjustable paper stopper at the end.  Also, if you place the scanner to your right, you're going to have to reach over the exit tray to hit the scan button.  It's very annoying if you're scanning in a lot of documents, since you have to reach awkwardly over the exit tray to hit the scan button.  I completely gave up on using this fold-out exit tray because of this.  I kept hitting my arm on the end of the exit tray, and I figured it would eventually break off (the exit tray, not my arm), or I would end up breaking it off in frustration.  Finally, if you're scanning in stacks of stapled documents, you're bound to miss a staple somewhere.  There's no handling of this type of issue, so your document just gets pulled in, caught, and mangled, until a paper jam is triggered.Out of the 9,000 scans I've done, this scanner has also mangled about 120 pieces of paper. I see often that these pages have ended up not being pulled in straight.  I have noticed that this mostly seems to occur with thinner paper and notebook paper, or when scanning in a stack of paper, and it's nearing the last page.  It seems that there's not enough pressure on the pages to keep them in place and prevent them from going in crooked when getting pulled into the scanner.  Also, the 2 rollers seem to be able to function somewhat independently, as I see frequently that the left side of the paper (facing the front) often gets pulled in quicker than the right.  Fujitsu should have made the paper guides higher on the sides as well.  Even when guiding the paper in by hand, single remaining sheets and thin papers still get pulled in at an angle quite often.  The scanner sometimes has trouble with mangling thinner/notebook paper as well.  I've also noticed that in general as the pages get pulled into the scanner, they often pull up at the end of the page just enough so that they get pulled in crooked.  Again, this happens more when there are only a few pages being scanned or a few pages left in the scanner.  The deskewing seems to work OK.  If you purposely put in a piece of paper in the scanner so it scans skewed, it will deskew it very well.  The problem is that a lot of the times it pulls in documents at such an angle that portions don't even pass over the scanner element.  I selected the option to deskew based on the documents text, which isn't selected by default.  Without this option selected, the scanner will still attempt to deskew, but it doesn't always do a great job, and since papers do often get sucked in crooked, deskewing is important.  I also have meticulously cleaned the scanner as described in the manual with lint free cloth, but that didn't help with any of these issues.  It's surprising when it does end up mangling smooth pages since other times it seems to scan pages that are wrinkled or even torn on spots without a problem.I haven't used the wi-fi option to scan to an Android/Apple device yet, but the scanner had no problems connecting to my wireless router.  What's nice about this feature is that it doesn't scan your document to a cloud based service where the employees at the cloud service will be perusing through all your scans, it scans it directly to your phone.  So, for those of us who value your privacy and personal information, this is huge!  I do wish there was a Windows app out there that would let you scan to a regular PC with wireless.Finally I have had zero problems with the software installation, disconnects, power save mode, etc. that I read some users were having difficulties with. I am using this with a Western Digital USB 3.0 card.  Overall, I think Fujitsu did a pretty good job with this scanner.  I hope they will take into account some of the caveats in this model in their next mode.If anyone has any experience with the Brother ADS2000 and could share their experience with it compared to mine with the iX500, would you please share?  Just from reading reviews on here, Costco's site, and others, it appears the Brother also has issues pulling in documents crooked.

I was very disappointed after purchasing this to find that this is basically a mattress cover.  It's two sheets sewn together with hardly a spec of cotton in between the layers.  If you're expecting a "pad" with any sort of loft, look elsewhere.

I've had these for a couple of weeks now and have worn them several times.  They were great for a recent multi-stop cross country flight to isolate the jet noise so I could comfortably watch movies.  I also wear them at the gym.  I'm also hoping they'll protect my auditory system from loud flights and the stupid lunk alarm they have at Planet Fitness so I never end up with permanent tinnitus.Look up noise induced tinnitus and read some people's stories (and make a donation to the ATA or similar organization if you feel for these people) - once you get it, it's permanent, you will never be able to relax or sleep through the night again, and your life is over.  Protect your hearing!Don't expect the sound quality to be amazing, but I didn't find it bad or distorted.  The only thing that's weird with these is that they haven't published an NRR rating for them, which I think is actually legally required.  Once thing that's nice about these vs. most of the competing products is that they don't have a super long protruding piece of plastic hanging out of your ear to get in the way, though you can't exactly lay your head on a pillow with them in your ear.  I have noticed that there's not a very good seal where the wire goes into the back of the plug.  I think it should have some type of flexible epoxy in it.  If you pull the wire up/down, you can hear the sounds around you get louder.  We'll also have to see how the wires hold up over time from use and abuse.

Torturous To UseI gave this keyboard several days, but it was torture to use.  If this is going to be your only keyboard you’ll ever use, and you won’t know any better, than you may be OK.  For the rest of, forget it.  I fail to understand how anyone can give this a good review.  All most of us want is a keyboard with a layout and keys EXACTLY like an HP or Dell laptop, and a touchpad to the side or below.  Look at where they arrow keys are on a Dell or HP business laptop – it makes sense, and they’re easy to locate and press without looking.  Look at how the keys on these laptops are concave so your fingers easily press them.  What’s wrong with these compact keyboard manufacturers?  They also can’t think out of the box and keep trying to squeeze all the keys into a perfect rectangle.  Is that really necessary?The first problem with this keyboard is of course the right shift key location and miniature size which always makes you end up accidentally hitting the up arrow.  The next problem is that pressing certain combination of keys is not always recognized.  Next, there’s a difference between the left and right touchpad buttons which makes it difficult to feel when the buttons have registered a click, which has also been an ongoing manufacturing problem reported elsewhere.  Last, there’s not even fold out legs on the bottom, so typing is very uncomfortable.I stuck this back in the box and sent it home.  Unfortunately there really isn’t any competition for this.  Where are the competitors?  Hello?

I purchased this so I would have something to raise my laptop up when sitting on sofas and chairs to make it more comfortable and avoid neck strain. I was afraid it wasn't going to have enough height when I ordered it, but it actually works well.  The angle raises the screen height while tilting your keyboard down to make typing easier.  It's fairly lightweight was well.My HP laptop has fan vents on the lower side thanks to intelligent design.  Some moron laptop designers have stupidly put fan vents on the bottoms, which are easily blocked and cause overheating if you set them on anything besides a hard surface.  This is pretty firm and flat, so I could only see there being a overheating problem with laptops whose fan vents sits very close to the surface that they're sitting on.  It's nice how such a simple thing can help so much.  I do wish though there was actually some meaning behing he "cush" in CushTop though. It is pretty solid.

I recently purchased one of these, but only by accident did I notice there is actually an old version of this still being sold with exactly the same name.  There is a review here that explains the differences between the new and old version.  If you pick up a box, the old version will have a copyright date of 2011 on the bottom.  The new version, which is much improved, has a copyright date of 2012.I've only had this for a short time, but it seems to be working well.  My only gripe with it is that you can't turn down the amount of soap it despenses far enough.  Some soaps are more concentrated and you just don't need a big glob of.  Other than this, I like that your hand needs to be within an inch or two of the sensor to trigger it to prevent accidental soap dispensing.

Look at the dates for the good reviews for this.  They are all old.  This used to be a great product until some idiot decided to try and get their hands on the product and "improve" it to get kudos from upper management, but instead destroyed the product with a change of fragrance from a nice light pretty much unscented smell to some disgustine femine lavender stench that makes me sneeze.  I've since switched to Aveeno unscented shave gel.  Goodbye Edge!  Hope you go out of business!

I've been using Edge Ultra Sensitive shaving gel since it came out.  I figured I would give this a try since it's cheaper, the gel that's in the reservoir in the Schick Hydro 5 blades that I use is pretty nice, and recently Edge Ultra Sensitive was ruined by some moron that deided they should change the formula.  However, to my dismay, this is far from the gel in the reservoir of the Schick Hydro 5 blades.  It's mediocre.  Not only that, the fragrance from this stuff is that horrible generic after shave type stench.  Who came up with that stench and decided all men's cosmetic products need to have this?  I would fire them and blakclist them from any future employment.  Secondly, why do these prodcut designers refuse to think out of the box and either just drop the fragrance alltogether or have something normal like Edge did.
I've had this for about 9 months now for my wireless router which has a single duplexed antenna jack.  What can I say other than it works great!

I've had these for a few months now.  They cut about as good as my Cutco steak knives and no rust has turned up on them even after letting them soak in water many times.  I only wish they had better quality looking handles.
I got this to use with a Seagate external 3TB drive with Windows XP.  It works great with good performance.
I've had this for a couple months now.  There's not much you can say about a network switch except that I've had no problems with it and its performance is great.  I would recommend it to a friend.

I've been using several of these for a couple years now.  I've had no problems charging multiple different device types including non-motorola phones, my car security fob, etc.  I also like the coiled cord.  I only wish there was a way to disable the LED.  It can not be disassembled without destroying it.

I've tried the cheap cables from eBay in China, and they all end up creating a humming noise, not to mention have quality issues.  This cable is flexible and decent quality.  I have both the 12' and 25' version of this cable

If you don't describe yourself as a child or a petit person, this is not the support for you.  I am an average adult male and this would need to be at least 2-4 inches taller to offer any support for my head/neck.  It could also use a ridged center core to stop it from sinking in and giving your neck even less support.  Even with it fastened so tight around my neck that I can barely breathe, it offers near zero support.

I was looking for a neck support that would be taller than the Futuro ones they sell at all the retail chains since the Futuro one could only be good for a child size neck, and offers little support.  This neck support is bascially made up of two plastic strips with some very firm padding on one the top of one strip, and the bottom of the other.  The two strips Velcro together so that in order to adjust the height, you just Velcro the two strips at different positions.My first problem with neck support , is just as a reviewer said about the version of this with the chin support, is that it bites painfully into your neck area, both front and back, as the padding on the edges is very thin and hard.  I imaging I'm going to have to wrap it with cotton badding or something of the sort.My other problem with this is that there are no details on the sizes vs. neck size.  I have a pretty big neck and head, such that most shirts don't fit around my neck, and hats don't fit around my head, so I ordered the XL version.  Unfortunately, it's way too big.Overall, this product is a disappointment and a waste of a design effort.  People need to think through and test products a little better before putting them on the market just to have them fail.

I recently purchased this razor after seeing it in the store and being sick of draining my bank account on blades for my Gillette Fusion Proglide Power.  I'm happy someone finally came along and gave Gillette some competition! I wasn't really expecting a better shave from it, but wow, it's so much better than the Gillette - less cuts and a much smoother, quicker shave!  I have incredibly thick hair too, which an electric can't even touch.  I would always have problems getting under my jaw line with the Gillette, and this thing sailed right through it!  I don't have to go over every area 20-30x as I did with the Gillette.  Thank you Schick!One thing I didn't realize at first as I was shaving near my nose is that the plastic piece at the top of the razor blade flips back so yoy can get the edge of the blade right up close.My wishes for the next version of this would be:1.  The razor is so thick it's hard to grip.  It needs to be designed easier to grip.  The Gillette definitely has an advantage on size and weight.  The Gillette also has stronger vibration.2.  Make the power on button so that it starts off on high vibration, then decreases.  Or, just have some way of setting the vibration permanently since having to hit the button 3x is annoying.This really deserves 4 stars because of these annoyances, but I didn't want to deter anyone from buying it since it gives such a great shave.

I had been looking all over for a good quality laptop riser stand for quite some time after junking a previous one that would fall out of the position I set it at and my laptop was not stable on.  Finally, I got desperate due to neck and back aches, pains, and noises from alternating between either sitting slouched back or looking down at my laptop screen.  I figured I had better fork out the cash for something good now or I'll end up be forking out a lot more in medical expenses down the road!  I was debating on this one or the 3M one, but decided to try this one out due to some bad comments about the 3M one.I definitely made the right decision.  This is a great riser stand.  It is light, yet not flimsy.  It has a super wide range of adjustability so that you have have your laptop almost vertical if you like your screen that high.  It has a nice rubberized base and top (the black parts you see in the picture) to keep your laptop snug without any parts getting in the way so you can remove your laptop quickly out of the stand.  It has a metal screw lock with a plastic knob to lock the stand position in the back.  There are also nice rubberized feet to stop it from sliding around.One thing to note is that packaging and instructions are in Japanese, but all you really need to figure out is how to get the stand locked in place.  I think a 3 year old could figure that out.Highly recommended!

There's nothing in the description that says anything about it, but this has an old style 3 pin fan plug, which is garbage if you have a normal CPU Fan header.  You won't be able to have your motherboard control the speed of this fan based on temperature, and therefore it's ridiculously loud!

I got this phone to use as a prepaid phone for a side business.  What a mistake!  This phone is atrocious!  The touch screen is reflexive and very unresponsive.  Furthermore, it's ridden with bugs, including if the alarm goes off, it will just vibrate forever until the battery is dead!  You can't just start typing a name to find them in your contact list; you have to scroll or use a separate search page, both very time consuming processes.  They keyboard buttons are completely flat and flush with the phone's surface, making them more difficult to press.  Also, the keyboard is backlit, but the navigation keys on the phone's face aren't! The only plus for this phone is the battery life.

I needed to replace my old, busted up crank set on my old Giant mountain bike.  I also needed something I could get a bash guard on, not just for protecting my outer chain ring from getting mangled on logs and rocks, but to protect the side of my leg as I probably lost a liter of blood once when my foot slipped and the side of my chain ring sliced up the side of my leg, landing me in urgent care and leaving with a collection of stitches.It was painful figuring out all the components and tools I would need to install this, the number of teeth on the chain rings, and the length of the crank arms (ended up with 175's).  It wasn't clear that this comes with the Hollowtech bottom bracket at first, but it does.  It appears there are different versions of this available with different tooth counts other than listed here and on the specs on Shimano's web site.  I also purchased this with the Deore front derailleur.  I wanted to keep my outer chain ring and have the benefits of a bash guard as well, so I got this with a Salsa Tooth Fairy triple bash guard.I've ridden on this about 5 times now.  The Hollowtech makes it so much lighter than my crappy stock crank set.  I love having the outer ring since one of the places where I go mountain biking is just a couple miles away so I can ride up there pretty quickly, but I'll probably end up dumping the outer ring and using an FSA toothed bash guard I ordered with this since the Salsa Tooth Fairy slightly interferes with my front derailleur.--Installation Notes--I had a 68mm bottom bracket space, so I used 1 spacer on the left, 2 on the right.  The spacers included with mine were all 2.5mm, though the instructions mentioned 3 different sizes included.--General Tools Used--Wrench set for removal and installation of pedalsLatex gloves to keep the nastiness off of my hands--Tools Used for Removal of Old Crank Set--Park Tool CCP-22Park Tool BBT-22--Tools Used for Installing This Crank Set--1/4" Torque Wrench with 1/4" extension and 1/4" to 3/8" adapter with 5mm 3/8" hex socket.  (All from Harbor Freight).  This is needed to properly tighten down the two 5mm hex screws for the left crank arm to 12-14 N-m.  This is equivalent to about 123 in lbs. Don't screw this up and guess!  The tools are cheap enough.Park Tool BBT9 to tighten down the bottom bracket (preferred over BBT19 since BBT9 has the pieces at both ends that you'll need).  The bottom bracket included with this crank set with this is an outboard type just FYI.Tools Used for Installation of my Bash GuardSunLite Chainring Bolt Spanner5mm Hex Wrench

I'm not into the clipless pedals, and wanted some plastic pedals without sharp spikes as I had enough of the bloody, scarred shins from my foot slipping off those moron designed crappy steel/plastic/combo pedals and getting whacked in the shins with the grip spikes.  I had tried many of the generic type plastic pedals (i.e from Welgo), but they always felt like my foot was getting pushed up in the middle and list there was no grip in the middle of the pedal.  These are much nicer.  They are light weight, have a nice, flat, even feel to the surface, with decent grip.My only issues with these are I wish they had even more grip spikes across the surface, and they came with the black plastic side plug inserted and not the red ones.  It was nice that they came with the black ones though, but it was a huge pain to pull the red ones out, and impossible to get the black ones in.  I resorted to a rubber mallet, but they still didn't go in even.At first I was dissuaded from these as I had read that some people had issues with the grip pegs wearing down, but as far as I could tell that was just for BMX riders who do pedal grinds.
What more can I say about these?  They're plain old medicine cups.  I've had these for a while and have no problems.

I had been taking these for quite some time.  I had also been getting random stomach upset.  I didn't correlate anything until after having severe stomach upset and dizziness after trying a low strength magnesium supplement (80mg). I then realized these have 40mg magnesium oxide, which is actually the cheapest, least absorbed, and most side efffect ridden form of magnesium available.If you're one of those people that has a stomach made of steel, I'm sure these will be great.  Otherwise, it's too bad since without the magnesium these would make a great multi - they are small, easy to swallow, and don't have 100x the RDA of what you need like most other multivitamins that try to ell you on "more is better".  From reading numerous studies, more is not always better.  In fact, it can be harmful.  These meet the RDA for most everything (see Carlson's web site for the nutrition facts) and aren't loaded down with iron which is dangerous for men.

I have worked with many IP cameras, and this one is pretty poor.  I've had this for about two years now, and I would have to say that I would never purchase another camera from Microseven.  First, it has had a chronic problem where it periodically disconnects from the WiFi, requiring a power cycle to get it to work again.  None of my other devices experiencs this.  Secondly, it periodically suddenly stops recording on the SD card.  After rebooting it, it will start recording again.  Imagine having the area you're covering with this camera vandalized, or your property stolen, then expect your camera that you've invested time and money in to have captured the perpetrator, only to find out it failed to record!  Finally, Microseven is far behind in their technology, exemplified by the fact that the WiFi in this and other devices don't even support WPA2 encryption or H.264 streaming!  There are much better options out there - keep looking.
I wanted some decent terminals that would be corrosion resistant.  I hate the pure lead and brass ones that corrode, not to mention that lead is a very poor connector and is a weak metal.

This is a comparison review of the DEI Viper 5704V, the AutoPage CS3-RS915 LCD, and the CodeAlarm ca6551sst. I also have a DEI Viper 5901aka 5702V (the previous version of the 5704), and an AutoPage RS855 LCD.---Background---I have always done and prefer to do all my own installs. Not only is it something that I have the skills for and I enjoy doing, but I don't like other people disrespecting my property. Nobody respects anything that's not theirs, and I like to ensure everything is done to perfection without ruining anything. If you are technical and have patience, these systems are not difficult to install by any means. It's just a matter of knowing a little bit about electricity (12 Volts DC), locating the wires in your car that you need to tap onto, knowing how to carefully remove the panels in your car without breaking anything, and using the proper test tools, connectors, and wire wrap to make a very clean install without even cutting wires or drilling holes.---Preface---After purchasing a third car, needing to upgrade the systems in my current two cars, and researching the current selection of alarms, I decided to try each of the Directed Electronics Viper 5704, the Audiovox CodeAlarm ca6551sst, and the AutoPage CS3-RS915-LCD. They are all in the same class of 2-way paging alarms with remote start, and use spread spectrum technology to communicate between the main unit and the key fob. For those of you that don't know, this technology has been around for a while, and simply means that the communications can occur on multiple frequencies. This is good in case there is interference on one frequency, the transmissions can potentially get through to the receiver on another frequency.Besides having long range 2-way and spread spectrum technology, the other things that are important to me when selecting a security system:*Rechargeable remote - I hated having to keep a stash of AAA batteries around for my previous security systems.*Good manufacturer reputation - I've had good luck with my AutoPage system, and I know that Audiovox has been around for a while. I gave DEI a shot again just based on their name. I have used a lot of their accessories in the past (shock sensors, motion sensor, power door lock actuators, etc.) and have had good luck. DEI is the largest car security system manufacturer out there. DEI was founded by Darrell Issa, who is currently a congressman with a new worth of approximately $ billion. One big problem I have with DEI is that they are very partner focused, and don't warranty their systems if they aren't installed by an authorized DEI dealer. This also means if you lose the (very un-detailed) install/wiring guide that the system comes with, you're not going to just be able to download it from their web site. So, make sure you take photos of it/make copies before you lose or destroy it.  AutoPage and Audiovox both make their install guides available for download on their web sites, and I suggest you review those as well as the user's manual entirely before deciding on a system to purchase since they will give you a lot of information as to the functionality.*Lots of customization options - one important thing for me is to be able to disable the arm and disarm chirps. Since the remotes for 2-way security systems such as these beep/vibrate to confirm that you've successfully armed/disarmed the systems, why would you want your car's siren or horn to chirp as well, unless you're trying to show off? I like to be stealth! The arm/disarm confirmation chirps can be enabled and disabled through the customization programming that's described in the install manual of all of these alarms.*Two car functionality - All these systems support 2 cars, with varying difficulty of switching the remote from one car to the other.*Vibrating remote - Being in a noisy place can easily drown out the high pitched sounds that the key fob makes when your alarm goes off.---The Reviews---I installed the DEI Viper 5901 in my older car several years ago. I purchased the 5901 and a competitive AutoPage alarm that came with a color OLED display at the same time. I decided to send the AutoPage alarm back and keep the 5901 in that car due to it having better range when comparing side by side, and the AutoPage's fob's color OLED display being impossible to see in sunlight. Had I have known the problems I was going to run into with DEI's junk 5901, I would have returned them both and purchased the AutoPage system with the non-color LCD display and with the spread spectrum technology. (Spread spectrum allows for communicating over multiple frequencies to get around interference.)Going back to my DEI Viper 5901, it has a major flaw where once every 2-3 months it will take 100's of tries of hitting the unlock button to disarm the system and unlock the car. I usually will end up having to use my key to get into my car, setting off the alarm along with making everyone around look and/or waking up all the neighbors, and quickly reaching under the dash and pulling the system's wire to the horn/power (whichever I could get to first). Pulling the power and resetting the system will fix the problem temporarily. The Viper 5901 would also frequently have a long delay before actually arming/locking and disarming/unlocking after hitting a button on the fob. Furthermore, sometimes pushing the buttons on the fob would have no effect at all, not even a confirmation beep like the fob would normally emit when pushing a button. I've read some other reviewers complain about this as well. I also have a couple other gripes with it, one being that the car finder will simply lay on the horn solid for several seconds, rather than a series of short beeps (like the CodeAlarm and the AutoPage systems will do). The way the 5901 and now the new 5704 just slams the horn solid for several seconds is a great way of getting people near your car pissed off and getting everyone to stare at you looking for your car. Maybe if you're the type to always pay attention to where you park or live in a small village somewhere and don't ever travel to a shopping mall this won't be a problem for you. Like many people out there though I have a very busy lifestyle with a lot of ADD and distractions, so I need to have a good functioning car finder! Second, even though you would have the system set to not chirp when arming/disarming, if the battery in the fob was low, it would chirp the horn for a long duration after about a 5-10 seconds from disarming the system. This was very frustrating at night when trying to wake everyone up, including the neighbors. The fob beeps when the battery is low anyhow, so why does it need to chirp your horn in addition? Also, if by design you're going to make the system chirp the horn when the battery in your fob is low, why have it chirp when you're going to the car???? It should chirp when you're leaving your car because that's when you're most likely going to go inside somewhere that you can charge it! There's also no option to disable this. Lastly, they decided it would be smart to integrate the shock sensor into the unit on the 5901. Ridiculous! This all just goes to show how little common sense the engineers who designed this thing have.I called DEI to mention these problems, and some cocky kid answered the phone that had no interest in my comments. They did verify that the car finder and fob battery low chirp issues I mentioned above had not been corrected, and I verified this after receiving the new Viper 5704V and testing it.After receiving each system, I first hooked them up on the bench to test. The first test was the power draw when armed and not alarming. This is important if you're going to let your car sit armed for an extended duration, like at an airport parking lot. The Viper and the CodeAlarm each drew ~40ma when armed, and the AutoPage ~24ma. Next was the range test. With the antennas all near each other, the range was almost identical when walking around my city neighborhood. Of course, it was no where near a mile that all the manufacturers claimed - more like 1200 feet down to the end of my street. Sometimes the CodeAlarm would work where the Viper wouldn't, and vice versa. I'm sure the FCC has a transmit power limit that the manufacturers must abide by. Expect around 1000-1500 feet at the most. If you really want to get notified, you can always get a prepaid SIM card and a 12v GSM alarm from eBay so you can get a text message on your cell phone. I will tell you I can park my car half way out in the parking lot of a typical WalMart or grocery store, and be able to communicate with my car half way into the store. Range is very dependant on obstructions.One thing to note is that these systems are not capable of full duplex communications between the system and the fob, meaning that if the system is transmitting to the fob, the system will not receive any button pushes on your fob. This is relevant in a couple scenarios. First, if your car is alarming, expect it to take up to 15 seconds of you standing there pushing the button on your fob for your system to stop alarming. This is because your system will be transmitting to alert your remote that there it is in alarm. The manufactures may have designed in periodic brief pauses in the transmission to allow for a signal from the remote to get through, and if you're lucky to press the button at just the right time, you might get your system to stop alarming sooner. In my tests, I was able to stop the AutoPage from alarming the soonest. This also applies to remote start. After your system starts your car, it will be transmitting to confirm that your car has started. You'll have to wait up to 15 seconds to be able to disarm your alarm and unlock your doors after using remote start. If I'm in a safe area, I'll usually disarm the system before activating remote start.Another thing to note with the fob communications is that for all of these systems it may take up to 10 seconds or so for your fob to be notified of your security system going off. The fobs from all manufacturers work similar to cell phones to conserve the battery life - they only turn the receiver on every so many seconds. So, if your security system happens to be triggered right after your fob went out of listening mode, you may have lost valuable time to nab the perpetrator who broke into or crashed into your car. From my tests, the AutoPage had the slowest frequency of checks and took the longest to be notified of an alarm condition.Each system has a "warn away" function that relies on the dual stage shock sensor they come with. When a lighter touch on your vehicle is detected, the siren/horn chirps quickly. I find that the "warn away" is pretty much useless, and is frequently set off by loud motorcycles driving by. The warn-away feature is complicated by the fact that the shock sensors that these systems come with only have a single adjustment, rather than a separate adjustment for each stage. So, you can't customize your sensitivity for full alarm vs. warn away and you may end up with lots of warn away pages/beeps if you like your shock sensor sensitive. You might be better off either not using the warn-away, or purchasing a separate shock sensor (they are cheap) just for the warn away function to be adjustable. In my case I installed a front and rear shock sensor in my daily driver for better coverage of my car.  In my car that I installed the AutoPage system in, I had to rig the warn-away wire over to the full alarm input to get better sensitivity.  I also had to use a DEI504D shock sensor with the AutoPage system due to the bug mentioned below and the fact that it has better sensitivity than the AutoPage OEM shock sensor.--Pros and Cons of the Systems--First, I'm very jaded against DEI with the bad experience I had with my 5901. Furthermore, the issues I had with the battery low warning chirping your horn/siren when you go to your car, and the car finder have been carried over to the 5704V. The other disaster with the 5901 was that the shock sensor was integrated into the 5901, which limited your installation locations. Thankfully, due to enough complaints, DEI did not carry this dumb idea over to the 5704.  The only thing that was nice about having the integrated shock sensor was that you could adjust the sensitivity from your remote, vs. having to potentially pull apart interior panels to adjust your shock sensor.  If these companies could come up with a standard to be able to adjust the shock sensor sensitivity from the system itself rather than the shock sensor, that would be great!The DEI 5704 has the most fine tuning options of any of the systems, as well as programmable output wires. The vast majority of people will not need to make use of these, and furthermore, you need to purchase a DEI Bitwriter to program many of those options. They could have just put a USB or serial port on the main system, but DEI wants to sell you an additional piece of hardware. Some of the Bitwriter options include remote start run time by the minute, smart start temperature, and siren duration by the seconds. You can also customize the key fob icon for each of the Aux outputs to Trunk, Window, and Sunroof with a Bitwriter. For me, I would rather not have the above problems, not have to buy a Bitwriter, and slightly less customization capabilities.In regards to the key fobs, the fob for the 5704 is the same as the one used with my older 5901. One complaint I had with that was that the rubber cover over the USB charging port only lasted a few months before disintegrating. Of all three of the fobs, none have an extremely noticeable vibration capability. During an alarm, the CodeAlarm and the Viper had the most noticeable vibrator, with the AutoPage being slightly less. I can tell you from the Viper that I've had mixed results with the vibrator alerting me. The problem is that none of the fobs actually vibrate and sound at the same time. Rather they sound, then vibrate briefly, then sound again. The piezzo buzzer on the AutoPage fob, however, is at least twice as loud as the one on both the Viper and the CodeAlarm.  In fact, I find myself having to use the AutoPage's fob while it's in my pocket sine it's so piercingly loud.The Viper 5704 and the AutoPage CS3-RS915LCD both have mini USB connectors on the key fobs. The CodeAlarm has the more modern style, micro USB charging connector. If you're an iPhone user, you're going to have to have multiple chargers in either scenario. If you're an Android user, you'll be happy with the CodeAlarm's fob since it's nice to have one universal charger that will work for your phone and your key fob, not to mention there will certainly be lots of your friends and coworkers that will have a micro-USB charger lying around if needed. The fobs that come with the AutoPage and the CodeAlarm both have painted fronts, and expect them to wear quickly.  The plating on the CodeAlarm and AutoPage's fobs have both disintegrated pretty well over several months.  I wish they would just leave the paint off and leave them rubberized black plastic. The silver paint on my Viper fob is half gone exposing an ugly greenish plastic underneath. Finally, I found with all the fobs, that it's very easy to accidentally hit one of the super large lock/unlock buttons when they're moving around in your pocket. One thing with the AutoPage, if you hit the lock button while the system is already armed, it triggers the car finder and will beep your horn - annoying. With the CodeAlarm, you have to hit a side button to trigger the car finder, which is difficult to do by accident. If you manage to hold down the unlock button, that ends up being a trunk release, if you have that functionality in your vehicle.The fob for the AutoPage is almost identical to the CodeAlarm (they both must be using the same manufacturer for the remotes), but the navigation is completely different. Getting to 2-car mode with the CodeAlarm is much easier - just press the F button, then lock and unlock together. With the AutoPage, you have to go through the menu, which can be tricky (though it's at least a menu vs. having to memorize some random key sequences). For the Viper, you have to hold down the F button as well to change to car 2.  I like how you can also customize the color on the Viper's and the AutoPage's fob's backlights. As far as battery life goes, you should get at the very minimum around 5 weeks or more per charge on any of the fobs depending on usage.From experience with the key fobs, the plastic LCD display covers get scratched and blurred very quickly from being in your pocket, bag, etc with other keys and items. At the same time you get one of these systems, get some good quality screen protectors with STRONG adhesive so they don't peel up. When you get the systems, they come with a cheap plastic sticky protector on the fob's display.  Peel that off and keep it to use as a template to cut screen protectors.  Put it on top of a screen protector, and trace around it with a fine tip marker (I use the fine tip Sharpies). Cut out inside the line you drew. It's not going to be perfect, but it's better than eventually having a blurry and scratched display. Oh, and make sure you clean the grease, etc. off your fob's display with rubbing alcohol before applying the screen protector.For the remote start functionality, they all behave pretty similarly, though I've only tested the CodeAlarm in practice. The only two difference I see are that first, you have more one more option with the AutoPage to avoid accidental starts. With all of them, you can at the very least set them so you need to hit the start button twice within a few seconds. Second, with both the AutoPage and Viper, you can have temperature controlled starts, with the AutoPage able to be set at 0 degrees F, and 15 degrees F, and Viper only 0 degrees, but the Viper customizable to 10 degree F increments if you also have a Bitwriter. The Viper can also start your car at a high temperature for cooling, where the AutoPage only has a low temperature. The viper might be helpful for you if you happened to need to leave a pet in the car in a hot climate. For me, I would never use temperature controller start, and I would carefully consider whether or not you would use it before making a decision based on this.So far, I've had no major issues with the remote start functionality of the ca6551sst. I tested it in combination with an iDatalink transponder bypass, as well as a DEI PKALL, but it took many, many tries to get the PKALL programmed, so I didn't trust it. With both bypasses I had to increase the crank time since they're slow to send the code, but the ca6551sst let me easily adjust that. And that leads me to one more difference in the remote start - the Viper and the AutoPage have several more options for crank time than the CodeAlarm, but again that hasn't posed an issue for me with the CodeAlarm.As far as the alarm functionality goes, the CodeAlarm has an enormous win over the Viper and AutoPage, and that is that if you use the horn for your alarm, when your alarm is triggered it will optionally (by default) hold on your horn with random brief pauses! This definitely is an attention getter - wow! Personally, I don't hook up the included sirens, I only use the horn since I don't like to drill a hole through the car's firewall to run a wire for the siren. Sometimes you can find an unused wire in your car to use for the siren, or just be able to slip a wire through an existing hole through the firewall.As with my Viper, when disarming the CodeAlarm I've found that once or twice a week it will take 1-2 button pushes to disarm the security system, where each time I'm standing within a few feet of the vehicle. Fortunately it hasn't been the 100's of times it would take  with the Viper.One other issue I have with the CodeAlarm is that there is a "ground while armed" wire on the CodeAlarm that I use for a secondary warning LED that I mounted on the dash of my vehicle. Unfortunately, it's also on during remote start even when the system is disarmed. Because of this, it stays on until I put my key in the ignition, turn it to on, and press the brake to release the system's control over the starter. This means I'm going to have to get a relay that will cut off ground to the LED during remote start. The Viper on the other hand has 4 programmable outputs that you can set either to validity, link to arm, link to disarm, link to arm/disarm, or remote start only. They're all controllable from the fob. It's nice that they have these built in, but you'll need a Bitwriter to program and fob icon and the latch time away from the default of 30 seconds if you're planning on using them for window rollup and/or sunroof closure. The AutoPage has 3 programmable outputs, and you can program the timer from 1 second to 2 minutes without any sort of add-on. For the CodeAlarm you'll need an external timer relay.The AutoPage is the only one of the three that doesn't have warning LEDs on the antenna, and comes with an external LED. This is important to me since the antenna can draw attention to the antenna's location. If someone is smart enough, they could break into your car and if they rip off the antenna quick enough, you would never get a page. On the other hand though, not having LEDs integrated into the antenna could be a drawback for the install since then you have to find a place to mount your LED, and potentially have to drill a hole somewhere. For me, I purchased a small black plastic project box, drill a hole in it, mounted the LED in, and mounted the box in the car using double sided 3m sticky mounting squares found at Walmart.One other note is that the CodeAlarm has no car temperature check functionality, whereas both the Viper and CodeAlarm do. Also, as alluded to above, both the AutoPage and the Viper have extra programmable outputs if you want them to close your windows, sunroof, etc. The CodeAlarm only has one programmable output, though on the Viper and AutoPage, those outputs have various limited functionality. I suggest downloading the manuals for more info.In regards to support, I did contact DEI three times - twice by phone, and once by email. I definitely have to give them credit as they answered me each time in a timely fashion by phone and email. I tried calling AutoPage, and was not able to get through on their consumer phone support number.  I also tried emailing AutoPage, and I never received a reply. I did not try contacting CodeAlarm's support.In summary, I think any of these can be winners depending on your requirements, likes, and dislikes. The AutoPage has everything the CodeAlarm has and then some, except for the random horn honk feature when alarming. The big thing that I really like about the CodeAlarm is definitely the random horn honks - that would really get people's attention in a parking lot full of cars where most people have learned to tune out car alarm honking. However, the AutoPage does have a slightly better fob with a more powerful vibrator and much louder sound which is really important to me. I also like how the AutoPage will let you change the fob's background color whereas the CodeAlarm will not, not that this should be a deciding factor. I would only go with the Viper if for some reason I didn't mind purchasing a Bitwriter, needed an extreme customization option, or the high temp auto start capability.Personally, my favorite is the CodeAlarm. I like the random horn honk feature, the micro USB charging port for the FOB, the fact that you can use a jeweler's screwdriver to release the wires that you don't need form the harness rather than cutting them (in case you move it to another car or decide to use a feature someday), and that it's virtually bug free except as noted with taking 1-2 extra unlock pushes on the FOB once in a while.Lastly, it should be mentioned that all three have the ability to link to optional cellular based add-ons that you pay subscription fees for so you can get alarm notifications, start your car, unlock your doors, etc. from a smart phone. AutoPage calls their's C3. DEI/Viper calls theirs SmartStart (not good reviews here on Amazon), and CodeAlarm (Audiovox) calls their add-on 220Carlink. The DEI/Viper and the AutoPage both have GPS tracking available. The subscription fees vary, so do some homework.---Major Bug with AutoPage System Received---Finally, I must mention that the AutoPage CS3-RS915 LCD systems apparently have a manufacturing bug at this time. I purchased two from different resellers, and they both had this bug. The majority of the time, triggering the warn-away stage on the shock sensor will subsequently trip the 2nd stage/full alarm for the majority of the time. Other times it behaves normally for a while until the unit is power cycled. Or, if the unit is power cycled, it will start misbehaving again. Sometimes when the 1st stage is tripped, the LED's for both stages go into a frenzy for a minute or so, though the alarm never gets triggered. When I remove the blue wire from the shock sensor harness (the 2nd stage trigger), the 2nd stage doesn't get triggered. When I have the system set in shock sensor test mode, it behaves fine. It also works fine when paired with a DEI 504d shock sensor. So, the problem appears to be a combination of the main unit and the shock sensor. This problem could go unnoticed since unless you are paying close attention, the only symptom one would see, depending on how and what you were doing when you set your shock sensor's sensitivity, is that occasionally it will either take much less of a shock to set the system off (if you set the shock sensor sensitivity when it was behaving normal), or it will take a much harder hit to set the system off (if you set the shock sensor when it was acting up). Personally, I hate the warn away feature since it's an annoyance, and I always pull the warn away wire out of the shock sensor's harness (the green wire in this case), so it's not a big deal. It's still a bug though that makes me doubt AutoPage's quality control.  I actually ended up using a DEI 504d shock sensor (relatively cheap) with one of these, and RMA's the other.If anyone else out there reads this review that has one of these system, please test your shock sensor out over a few days time and leave a comment here letting us know if you're experiencing the same issue. You will see this issue as it will be impossible to just trigger the warn-away feature of the shock sensor. With a light hit, the green LED will light first, followed by another blink of the green LED, then the red LED.

This is a comparison review of the DEI Viper 5704V, the AutoPage CS3-RS915 LCD, and the CodeAlarm ca6551sst. I also have a DEI Viper 5901aka 5702V (the previous version of the 5704), and an AutoPage RS855 LCD.---Background---I have always done and prefer to do all my own installs. Not only is it something that I have the skills for and I enjoy doing, but I don't like other people disrespecting my property. Nobody respects anything that's not theirs, and I like to ensure everything is done to perfection without ruining anything. If you are technical and have patience, these systems are not difficult to install by any means. It's just a matter of knowing a little bit about electricity (12 Volts DC), locating the wires in your car that you need to tap onto, knowing how to carefully remove the panels in your car without breaking anything, and using the proper test tools, connectors, and wire wrap to make a very clean install without even cutting wires or drilling holes.---Preface---After purchasing a third car, needing to upgrade the systems in my current two cars, and researching the current selection of alarms, I decided to try each of the Directed Electronics Viper 5704, the Audiovox CodeAlarm ca6551sst, and the AutoPage CS3-RS915-LCD. They are all in the same class of 2-way paging alarms with remote start, and use spread spectrum technology to communicate between the main unit and the key fob. For those of you that don't know, this technology has been around for a while, and simply means that the communications can occur on multiple frequencies. This is good in case there is interference on one frequency, the transmissions can potentially get through to the receiver on another frequency.Besides having long range 2-way and spread spectrum technology, the other things that are important to me when selecting a security system:*Rechargeable remote - I hated having to keep a stash of AAA batteries around for my previous security systems.*Good manufacturer reputation - I've had good luck with my AutoPage system, and I know that Audiovox has been around for a while. I gave DEI a shot again just based on their name. I have used a lot of their accessories in the past (shock sensors, motion sensor, power door lock actuators, etc.) and have had good luck. DEI is the largest car security system manufacturer out there. DEI was founded by Darrell Issa, who is currently a congressman with a new worth of approximately $½ billion. One big problem I have with DEI is that they are very partner focused, and don't warranty their systems if they aren't installed by an authorized DEI dealer. This also means if you lose the (very un-detailed) install/wiring guide that the system comes with, you're not going to just be able to download it from their web site. So, make sure you take photos of it/make copies before you lose or destroy it.  AutoPage and Audiovox both make their install guides available for download on their web sites, and I suggest you review those as well as the user's manual entirely before deciding on a system to purchase since they will give you a lot of information as to the functionality.*Lots of customization options - one important thing for me is to be able to disable the arm and disarm chirps. Since the remotes for 2-way security systems such as these beep/vibrate to confirm that you've successfully armed/disarmed the systems, why would you want your car's siren or horn to chirp as well, unless you're trying to show off? I like to be stealth! The arm/disarm confirmation chirps can be enabled and disabled through the customization programming that's described in the install manual of all of these alarms.*Two car functionality - All these systems support 2 cars, with varying difficulty of switching the remote from one car to the other.*Vibrating remote - Being in a noisy place can easily drown out the high pitched sounds that the key fob makes when your alarm goes off.---The Reviews---I installed the DEI Viper 5901 in my older car several years ago. I purchased the 5901 and a competitive AutoPage alarm that came with a color OLED display at the same time. I decided to send the AutoPage alarm back and keep the 5901 in that car due to it having better range when comparing side by side, and the AutoPage's fob's color OLED display being impossible to see in sunlight. Had I have known the problems I was going to run into with DEI's junk 5901, I would have returned them both and purchased the AutoPage system with the non-color LCD display and with the spread spectrum technology. (Spread spectrum allows for communicating over multiple frequencies to get around interference.)Going back to my DEI Viper 5901, it has a major flaw where once every 2-3 months it will take 100's of tries of hitting the unlock button to disarm the system and unlock the car. I usually will end up having to use my key to get into my car, setting off the alarm along with making everyone around look and/or waking up all the neighbors, and quickly reaching under the dash and pulling the system's wire to the horn/power (whichever I could get to first). Pulling the power and resetting the system will fix the problem temporarily. The Viper 5901 would also frequently have a long delay before actually arming/locking and disarming/unlocking after hitting a button on the fob. Furthermore, sometimes pushing the buttons on the fob would have no effect at all, not even a confirmation beep like the fob would normally emit when pushing a button.
