After charging up the unit, and following the instructions for "pairing" or syncing the band with a bluetooth device, the unit failed to link. I tried this on two different Android devices that were supposed to be compatible, according to the minimum requirements, but the device never was able to function as it was supposed to.The Pivotal Tracker is really a nice looking unit, but because it failed to link with my devices, it basically was useless. That's too bad, because it would have been a really great alternative to the other expensive fitness bands out there. Perhaps in version 3.0, the dev team will be able to make this device more compatible with a larger variety of Android devices. As it stands now, if you buy one of these, you're just taking a shot in the dark in whether it will work for you or not.

I've tried other bicycle saddles that were padded with gel, foam, and other substances to make the ride more comfortable, but although they promised a better experience, they never seemed to fulfill expectations. The Vader Road/Offroad MTB bike saddle was, I must admit, selected because of it's fantastic looks, and the very reasonable pricing.This bike saddle is the first skinny seat that I have tried, and honestly, I didn't know how it would feel, nor did I think it would be really that comfortable. But the majority of reviews here were positive so I took a chance and ordered one.First off, the styling of this seat is outstanding as the red and black accents, with the white background are very eye-catching and high-tech. The design matches perfectly with the look of my bicycle's red frame, white highlights, and black graphics.OK, so how does it fit/feel? After about a month of riding on this seat, I'd have to say that it is comfortable, when compared to the others I have tried. This was surprising to me as it is a narrow road bike type of seat, and I didn't think that there would be enough padding to produce a good ride. But the design of the seat helps to distribute the weight nicely, and I can ride on the Vader without being raw or sore.It took a few weeks of tweaking the seat's angle, fore and aft position, and height, but after I dialed this in, the seat performs fine. The reason why it doesn't rank a perfect 5-stars is because while it is comfortable, I can still feel a bit of pressure, and this may become an issue during longer rides--but time will tell. But as an overall replacement seat, I would have to say that the Vader is an excellent value for anyone who wants a better ride.The Vader certainly is more comfortable than even the $40 saddles I have purchased, and that's saying something about getting your money's worth. I think Luke would approve of this seat for his Skycycle.

A physical therapist suggested buying this hand rail for our mother in law. I was skeptical about whether this would provide any assistance to her in getting in and out of bed, but upon the recommendation, we purchased it. The instructions for assembling the device weren't as clear as they could have been, and added to the confusion, the photos did not match up with the actual pieces that were shipped. Apparently the product was changed and the appearance of the parts didn't match the images.After fumbling around for 20-minutes in trying to figure out how to put the thing together, I just went with what I thought the instructions were trying to say and was able to put it together. Minus one star for the less than adequate instructions.As far as how the rail works, we were all surprised at how it gave our mother in law the extra leverage she needed to easily get her in and out of bed. It works well, and is a bit expensive, but it gives her that needed support.

I have an old Aquaclear 20 that served me well for many years, but the filtering ability of the unit started to go downhill, and the water never was as clear as I wanted it to be. Fine particles seemed to be beyond its ability to filter out. Hence I was on a search for a better filter.The Fluval series can be considered an upgrade to the workhorse Aquaclear series. I purchased the Fluval 20 as a replacement for my old filter. Setting it up was easy and straight forward, however after firing it up, water seemed to be leaking from it. Luckily I stayed around to see how it was operating, or many gallons of water would have ended up on the floor. After closer inspection, I found a substantial crack on the side of the filter, which was the culprit. I immediately sent in for a replacement by Amazon, and to its credit, the new unit arrived in a day. Another testimonial to the excellent customer service provided by Amazon.The second installation went as easy as the first, but with more caution on my part this time. The new unit had no cracks or defects and has been running efficiently for several days now. The water had a haze, due to very small particulates that couldn't be filtered with the old Aquaclear 20, but after 3 days, the water is crystal clear.I like the way this filter is compartmentalized for each filter medium, which means I can just pull out the carbon section, filter section, bio-stars, or bio-screen without disturbing the other three. The Aquaclear 20 had to have all three filter sections pulled out at once to exchange one of the media, and this left a horrible backup of debris being pumped back into the tank. Not a good thing and very unsightly.There seems to be conflicting reports as whether these filters are quiet or noisy. I happen to be in the camp that says it is quiet. When starting up the filter, whether for the first time or when stopping it for feeding or maintenance, the noisiness does happen, but this seems to be the result of air being stuck in the filter. The impeller churns the air trapped in the system and this produces the noise. All that needs to be done is to make sure that the filter is completely filled with water (you can trickle some into the top of the filter as it's starting up) and this allows the air to be purged. You might have to quickly plug and unplug the filter several times to expel the trapped air. I also added a dab of Vaseline, as suggested by others. on the impeller shaft to help keep things lubricated.Maintenance for this filter is a breeze, and the fact that you can rinse out the polyfoam filter (not in tap water, but treated water that has the chlorine neutralized so as not to kill off the beneficial bacterial) will save on costs. As a side note, my old Aquaclear 20 motor seems to be a direct twin of the Fluval 20 one, so I'll keep the old motor/impeller assembly as a back up for the Fluval.The Fluval C2 is working exceptionally well, and the fish, (and the fish hobbyist, me) are having a great time. One star is deleted from this otherwise high rating due to an apparent lack of quality control or substandard packaging of the filter, as the first one I received was defective with a 3-inch crack down the side. Interestingly enough, another review described the same exact crack location and leak as I had on my filter. I wonder if the defective one was somehow recycled and resold? I guess I'll never know.If you're looking for a very good filter that will keep your aquarium water looking crystal clear, assuming that all your other water parameters are decent such as pH, nitrate levels, ammonia levels, and nitrite levels, the Fluval C2 should work well for you.

Really liked the innovative design, but when all is said and done, the sound may be loud on this unit, but the sound quality still needs more work. But if you're just interested in volume, this may be a good choice--just don't expect a good tonal range from such a small speaker.
Not much to say except that this unit is just the right size for bring your liquid sups to the gym. The bottle is sturdy and easy to use.
Worked great right out of the packaging. Very reliable and serves our DSLR needs well. Good solid, dependable memory.
Works well, but it is far overpriced for what it does.

We've used all types of air purifiers and filters over the years, from the trendy ion types to regular HEPA filter units. These did a somewhat mediocre job at cleaning and filtering the air, but the Honeywell 20250 outperforms them all with visible results.We set up the unit in a corner of our living room, which is adjacent to the home office. There is no separating wall, but only a couch, so the space this air purifier does double duty and covers both spaces. After only a day of running the Honeywell, our family members stopped sneezing. The visual results were just as impressive. Light that comes into the main hallway through a window in the front door is longer is visible. By this I mean that the sunbeams, which are nothing more than light being bounced off of stray dust, were completely gone. The air was fresh and clean.Family members have commented that the house smells cleaner and fresher and is void of the usual house odors that were lingering in the air. Everybody is very happy with this purchase.The only downsides to this filter, and this has been mentioned by others, is that this powerful filter produces a high amount of sound. I wouldn't call it noise as much as a very noticeable fan exhaust sound. Think of it as a mighty rush of wind that is confined to a small area. On low setting, it is fine, but as you go higher, the wind noise can be loud enough to make television watching impractical.What many people have done is to set the fan power to either medium or high when no one is at home, and then turn down the fan to the lowest setting when everyone is at home, or just turn it off completely when viewing television or listening to music.The other negative is that after a month of using this air filter virtually 24/7, is that our electricity bill has jumped up about $20. Our only conclusion is that the Honeywell uses quite a bit of energy. If you are an especially energy conscious person, this may be a deal killer.The Honeywell 50250 is a powerful unit that will clean, scrub, and filter the air in your house or apartment. Not only will your environment be better, you'll see less dust too.

There's nothing wrong with Muscle Pharm Combat powder. This product works great and is of high quality. However the flavor of Orange Creamsicle just didn't work for me. After several days of trying it out, I finally just gave up because I couldn't get it down due to the very nasty chemical flavor and bad aftertaste.This particular protein powder is also very sweet; another reason why I didn't like this particular product. This is no reflection on Muscle Pharm, it's just that the flavor that didn't agree with me. It may work for you though. I think I'll go back to my standard Chocolate Milk Combat Powder.

Bicycle enthusiasts come in all shapes, sizes, and income levels, but Bicycling Magazine seems to think that the only ones out there are people who have gobs of discretionary income and can purchase bikes that cost $5,000 and upwards. Most of the content in this magazine is very limited and narrow in scope because it reaches only into expensive aspects of bicycling. What about all of us "regular" bicycle fans who spend a grand or less on a bike?The editorial staff believes everyone out there is a millionaire, hence all the articles on expensive bikes and gear. One recent article centered on extravagant, very expensive services related to customized bike fitting, while another issue listed the top road bikes--virtually all of them $6,000 and much more.Unfortunately, this magazine has become an elitist publication singing the praises of over-the-top equipment and has failed to reach into the hearts and minds of your average bicycling citizen that likes to ride to and from work, for exercise, and for fun and is looking for good articles related to good moderately priced bikes and accessories. For some reason Bicycling Magazine has some sort of phobia against any product that has an affordable price. 10 times out of 10 they will recommend a $350 bike jacket and not mention similar products that cost just $70, for instance. In this magazine, price (high price) is king.Bicycling Magazine has taken a wrong turn somewhere and has lost its way. Many of us love bicycling, but the editorial staff has decided to exclude a major number of us, and has instead, turned this into a publication that is aimed at the snobbish and elitists.I suppose the proper quote for this sort of behavior comes from Marie Antoinette when her poor citizens where just getting by while she lived in luxury..."Let them eat cake!" Easy to say when the people didn't even have bread. Bicycling Magazine is the Marie Antoinette of bicycle magazines and has lost touch with the general public.

My original review of HR Block Deluxe was rated by me with 2-stars. However the main reason for this low review was the program's inability to import TurboTax data. This occurred with computers running Windows XP. However, the latest updates have now fixed this problem and not only do the TurboTax data files transfer effortlessly, HR Block's program works as well as TurboTax.As it is with other former TurboTax users, I switched to HR Block to give it a trial run. My first impressions are that it is an easy program to use, and the interface and presentation is slight different than TurboTax, it basically does the same job by taking your through a series of interview questions. The overall program seems more streamlined and data entry goes faster after you get used to the system.And of course, HR Block as all the missing forms that were formerly left out of TT Deluxe. After doing a side-by-side comparison of the two programs, and after the initial jitters as to whether or not I would like HR Block's product, my personal conclusion is that I like HR Block and can safely say that I'll be a customer next year too, if HR Block doesn't self-destruct like Intuit did this year.As to why I gave this program 4-stars instead of 5, this basically has to do with the slowness of HR Block addressing or even admitting that there was a problem with the importing of TurboTax data. The HR Block forums finally did address the issue and notified its customers that a fix was on the way, but it took way too long to quell the concerns of customers who recently switched to its software.Customer service reps didn't have a clue to what was happening with this bug, and most of the time didn't even realize there was a problem. All they basically said was, "Gee, we're sorry. But call tech support for help." This didn't do any good as these guys just said to reinstall the software, which didn't work of course.But in-spite of all the bumps in the road, HR Block Deluxe came through and proved itself to be a worthy opponent to Intuit's product. As far as the refund numbers from TurboTax and HR Block, the difference was a matter of a few dollars, with HR Block erring on the side of caution.

Not a bad addition if you need more space for your crowded electrical plugs. The separated top and bottom outlets helps to keep the congestion down, but the other four are closely spaced and sometimes don't allow bigger plugs to be inserted next to each other. Not a bad product but could be redesigned a bit better.Finally went on to purchase a competitor's product (Belkin Pivot Wall Mount Surge Protector with 6 Outlets) that works much better.

Actually bought this as a gift for a family member after several of her cards became demagnetized. I thought this case would be a good safeguard against RFID and general protection for her credit cards and ID.She loved the design of the flowers on the case (she's likes to garden) and the case works very well. Other cases similar to this were either overpriced or very boring to look at. But Plixio has so many designs that anyone can get one that will suit their tastes.

For the price you just can't beat these close-up filters. No, they won't be as good as a dedicated macro lens, but then again, you won't have to spend hundreds of dollars more for macro performance that is quite good.For occasional closeup shots, these filters do the trick. They're compact and can be easily carried around in your camera bag, and with the 1X, 2X, 4X and 10X magnifications, you should be covered for any sort of closeup work.

I used to buy the KAL brand of pure stevia, but it cannot be considered pure any longer as the product now contains maltodextrin, the highest glycemic index for any sugar or sweetener. Not a very good product for those trying to avoid sugar.The Now Foods Organic Stevia was my fallback plan and as of now, I am very pleased with the product's purity, taste, and price. The bottle is bigger than the KAL brand and also lacks the handy scoop found in KAL products, but this is a minor setback and I just used an old scoop from my previous KAL stevia.You do need to use more to get the equivalent sweetness of the KAL product, but since there is more of the product in the bottle, I suppose it all evens out in the long run. I actually prefer the taste of the Now Foods stevia as it tastes very similar to sugar and doesn't have a bad aftertaste. It does linger after you use it, but it's sweet, and not bitter like other brands.As long as Now Foods keeps its price competitive to the KAL brand, I will be a repeat customer.

For the price these sturdy little plastic cases are ideal for storing your charged batteries. Because they are translucent, it's a snap to see what brand of batteries are inside. These will fit AA and AAA batteries nicely.You get nine of these and that's more than sufficient for my needs. The only drawback is that the delivery to your doorstep may take a little longer since these are shipped from overseas. But considering that the shipping is free, waiting a few more days isn't that big of a deal.

Purchased this case because the one we bought from RooCases started to come apart and break under very light usage. We thought about buying another one but the price took a sharp turn upward for no apparent reason and we ditched this idea.Saw the ULAK on Amazon and we liked the styling and the price. Ordered one up and so far, the case is working fine. The 360 rotating platform is really nice and it's a lot easier to use than the "origami" case from RooCase. Fits the Kindle HD 7 (2012) model perfectly.There were also problems with the RooCase and magnetic latch...it caused the Kindle HD 7 to malfunction and would turn it off without notice. Not so with the ULAC 360.

Successful businesses always under-promise and over-deliver. However, judging from Intuit's unintuitive actions, they have actually OVER promised and UNDER delivered. A fantastic recipe for failure and anger from formerly loyal customers.It would have been a better idea to just up the price a bit rather than disabling features and passing it on as though it was the same product from previous years. Sure, you can say just read the label, but there was a certain amount of trust that was built up over the years between Intuit and its users...TurboTax Deluxe has always worked the same way, except for this year, that is..Forms C, D and E are no longer available and you must now upgrade to either Premier or Home and Business versions, depending on your needs.Basically, it's no longer a matter of paying more for the functionality that used to be TurboTax Deluxe, it is now a matter of confusing the issue by selling a product under the same name, same price, but with major features disabled. This is neither smart business nor good PR, as can be seen by the many negative comments written here.But it goes further than just people being mad about this "bait and switch" tactic, what this means is Intuit has burned its bridges and have presented themselves as untrustworthy. What other changes are coming down the road that will affect customers adversely?Let's put this simply: If Intuit staff were used to going to a favorite restaurant and were used to ordering their favorite entrees year after year, and suddenly found that the dishes they ordered all had less food, and was missing important ingredients and food components, how long do you think it would be before they left and never came back? And on top of this, the owner of the restaurant says, "But you can get the same ingredients, food components, and quality if you only pay two times more for our new improved dishes!"Buh bye.I am sure Intuit felt that it had a good reason for doing what it did, but it wasn't a good decision as far as I'm concerned. I have been a long time user of TurboTax, but this recent debacle has left me feeling cold and disappointed with a company that I have trusted for years. A quick fix may be in the works to get a free upgrade to a version that works, but the irreparable damage done to this company's reputation has not only angered its users, but has started a wave of bad feelings and distrust that will take years to repair. Remember, one dissatisfied customer tells 10 people, and those 10 people tell more people. Intuit, you cannot afford this kind of bad publicity.Someone dropped the ball on this, and whoever it is, needs to step back and return the full functionality of TurboTax Deluxe for next year's version, or risk losing even more customers. Intuit needs to also whip (or fire) the programmers or lead programer that cannot find a way to make cross-platform versions for TurboTax work smoothly. It's not rocket science guys.At this stage of the game, H&R Block's Premium or Deluxe version may be the way to go for disgruntled TurboTax users such as myself. I was tempted to take the free upgrade offer by calling TurboTax, but thought differently about taking this course of action because of the dirty tactics by Intuit. I may get the freebie this year, but what about next year when I have to pay full price or get more features deleted?I will drop TurboTax this year and will be switching to HR Block Deluxe, which covers all the schedules formerly in TurboTax Deluxe, to see if it works; I have already ordered it. It's worth the risk in order to move away from TurboTax and Intuit's customer angering policies. They have to make a profit, and this is understandable. What isn't understandable is the sneaky and underhanded way they did this. They have lost my trust and it will be hard for them to win it back, if ever again, as I'm sure other former TurboTax users will agree.I will provide an update on HR Block Deluxe here after I receive it. Look for the in-depth review on HR Block Deluxe in the coming weeks.UPDATE ON HR BLOCK DELUXE: 1/12/2014-----------------------------------------I just installed HR BLOCK DELUXE in lieu of my usual TurboTax Deluxe product. HR BLOCK states that this version is compatible for Windows all the way to XP with SP3. After installation, which was very easy, I was presented with the option to import last year's TurboTax income tax data. It was able to search and find this file automatically, but after I hit the "import" button, I received an error message that stated:"HRBLOCK has encountered a problem and needs to close. We are sorry for the inconvenience."Apparently, after doing a search on the Internet, this seems to be a bug in the software when running on XP machines. HR BLOCK has not given an official fix date for this, nor an official statement, although some users said they were promised a fix from the 1/9/2014 update release. However, this did not solve the problem. The next update is scheduled for 1/22/2-14 from HR BLOCK, but no word as to whether or not this will fix the import bug.As I am typing this update, I have been online waiting for a chat representative to explain and offer some sort of fix date for this bug. I am number 10 on the waiting list, and it has been almost an hour and I am still waiting. (I am doing other computer related work while waiting). I also tried calling HR BLOCK's customer service number and was put on hold for over 15 minutes, when I decided to hang up.So far, this experience with HR BLOCK has not been stellar. I do NOT want to return to TurboTax Deluxe, but if HR BLOCK drops the ball on this, it will have lost my confidence, as well as many other former TurboTax users regarding the inability to import TurboTax data as promised. If you are running Windows XP, you may want to hold off buying HR BLOCK DELUXE until a fix for the import function is available, and hopefully, this will be soon.UPDATE 1/12/2014 CHAT Session with HR BLOCK REP----------------------------------------------------Here's a transcription of the chat session I just had after waiting one hour and 20 minutes to chat with an HR Block rep. The results aren't very inspiring for customer support there. The rep's name has been replaced to protect the guilty, other info has been changed to protect the innocent. The dialogue is funny and tragic. Read the part about "TT."-----------------------HR REP.: Hello ----, welcome to H&R Block Tax Product Support! Please allow me a few moments to review the information you have submitted to us.ME: Hi, I hope you can help me.I cannot import my 2013 TT data into 2014 HR Block Deluxe as advertised by the product description. I get an error message that states the program has run into a problem and must shut down.I have just switched from TT Deluxe to HR Block's version this year due to the Intuit downgrade fiasco eliminating Schedules C,D, E and other forms. But unfortunately, this hasn't been a very good start with the HR Block product.Is there a fix for this from HR Block, and how long will it be till the update fix is available, if at all? If it takes too much time or the fix isn't available, I will have to go back to TurboTax for full functionality, something that I really would hate to do.ME: ...I a running Windows XP Service Pack 3HR REP.: I'm sorry but when you say TT, can you explain what you are referring to?ME: TurboTax DeluxeHR REP.: Thank you, let me just verify some information from you. Can I please get your e-mail address, phone number, and zip code please?ME: Sure, my email address is: -----------------------ME: Home phone is: ---------------HR REP.: Where did you purchase the software?ME: Amazon.comHR REP.: Do you need help with the steps to download it?ME: no. I have already installed it. As I mentioned, it does not import last year's Turbotax info as stated in the description for HR BLOCK Deluxe. I would like to know when a fix for this bug will be available.HR REP.: I'm sorry this will be technical support, and this is product support. I am not sure when the bug is available. I would either return the CD back to Amazon or get in touch with Tech Support.ME: How do I do this?ME: And since this is product support, can you look up an answer for me?HR REP.: I would call the 1-800 number tomorrow morning, the number is on the H&R Block website.ME: Wow. This isn't looking too good for us former Turbo Tax users. Thanks anyway for your time. I waited over an hour for this, lol.HR REP.: Is there anything else I can assist you with today?ME: No. That's it. Have a good evening. Take care.HR REP.: I would like to let you know that you may receive a short Customer Satisfaction Survey by e-mail in the next day or two. If you could take a moment to provide me with some feedback on my performance today, I would really appreciate it.HR REP.: Thank you for contacting H&R Block Tax Product Support, ------. We look forward to supporting you in the future!ME: Not too sure about that, though. Thanks anyway.Thank you for using H&R Block Technical Support. Your satisfaction is important to us. You'll soon receive a short survey via e-mail. Please share your thoughts about your service experience. Your chat has now ended. Please close this window.Your session has ended. You may now close this window.UPDATE 3/23/2015:-------------------------------------In the early part of February, HR Block released a fix for the Windows XP bug that wouldn't allow the importing of last year's Turbo Tax Deluxe tax data. The fix worked perfectly and I was able to complete my taxes with HR Block Deluxe. The session went smoothly, the e-filing of both my federal and state tax forms went without a hitch. As of now, I am an HR Block convert and have dropped Turbo Tax Deluxe as my go-to tax preparation software.Intuit's incessant agenda of taking advantage of its customers, its highly confusing product line, and the constant juggling of its prices for its products has left me with a large confidence hole in ever doing business again with Intuit and its Turbo Tax products.

We had an abundance of thick branches and shrubbery in our back yard, and considered hiring a professional gardener to take care of this for us. But as most people know, cutting or pruning a tree can cost you an arm and a leg when it comes to hiring professional help, so we decided to take things into our own hands, literally, by purchasing the GreenWorks G-Max 40V pole saw. We had considered purchasing one from one of the store brands at a home improvement center (rhymes with bowls...) but the unit looked heavy and was more expensive than the GreenWorks.We were struggling to make the decision between a battery operated one and one that plugged into an electrical outlet with an extension cord. After using the GreenWorks battery powered model, we feel that this is the only way to go. But if you do select a battery operated pole saw, be sure that it is at least a 40V unit, as the lesser units may not give you enough power or run time.This was our first experience with this type of equipment, and to tell you the truth, we were a bit apprehensive about using such a powerful tool. We read the instructions thoroughly, and assembled the thing in less than  5-minutes. After checking that all the fittings were secure, we went out to the backyard to attack the dead branches and trees. To our surprise, the GreenWorks saw was very easy to use and provided more than enough power to cut three to four diameter branches with ease. We'll be tackling the 6-inch dead tree trunk later this week.When we assembled the pole saw, we attached all the segments ( three of them) together and it was very long and a bit unbalanced because of all the top weight on the pole saw end. But the battery at the other end helps to even out the weight a little.What we didn't know, after reading further in the manual, is that you can shorten the overall length dramatically by just attaching two of the segments instead of all three. The manual writers could have saved everyone some trouble if they had pointed this fact out in the beginning of the instructions before they tell you to assemble the entire thing with the three sections.After about 35 minutes of pruning, cutting, and trimming, the battery power only went down by 25 percent--pretty amazing. The 40v battery also provided more than enough power to drive the pole saw to allow it to cut through the thick branches. The chain stretches a bit when using it for the first time, but adjusting the tension on the chain was extremely easy to do. This was one of our concerns about operating a pole saw, but the process was problem free and any future adjustments should be just as smooth. Adding chain oil to the reservoir was also easy. The little translucent window on the side of the saw lets you know when to add more oil. After the first session of use, we used about 25% of the total amount.One tip that I was made aware of is to have the saw running before you start cutting, and not to start it while it is resting on a branch or tree trunk. Doing the latter can jerk the saw out of your hands as the teeth of the saw pull away from you due to the friction between the teeth and the wood. The saw is powerful, so always maintain a good grip, and wear eye protection when using it.In thirty-five minutes of use, the GreenWorks pole saw literally paid for itself many times over by us not having to hire a professional gardener. It's convenient to use, and we no longer have to depend on someone else to address our more serious backyard/garden needs. We're pretty happy with this pole saw and would recommend it to those with similar needs like ours.

This stereo system was very substandard and didn't operate properly out of the box. One speaker was inoperable, the tuner was weak, and the quality of the unit was a bit cheap.Sony, back in the day, was known for quality products, but this portable stereo is a mistake and probably shouldn't have ever been produced as it just gives Sony a bad name for making inferior products.

Lots of standard hymns in this album, but the production aspects are a little disappointing. This is basically a live recorded sing-along-session with lots of people. There are much better ones outside of this one. Might be a good deal for you if you buy it used.
Did not create enough suction to pull on anything. The vacuum cup is very shallow and this seems to be the design problem with this product. Avoid and move on.

This case was the perfect solution for protecting a family member's previous generation Kindle Fire. The fit is perfect, the case looks very sharp, and it seemed to do a good job of protecting the device...right up till when it developed a crack at the back of the case for no apparent reason.The case wasn't abused and occasionally received the standard bumps and jostles that every case is expected to encounter. But after less than a year's use, a small crack about 4-inches developed.The case is good, but it can't seem to hold up under normal wear. Since the return time has past, we are stuck with it. Too bad, it could have been a contender.If you're looking for a good case, you may want to be careful about this one and make sure you don't bump it too hard as it seems a bit sensitive to these jars.

Needed to upgrade my mountain bike and the first order of business was to replace the plastic pedals. I considered  buying a more colorful set by Fyxation or Odyssey, which are good products, but I was able to score a real deal on the Wellgos at an auction site for only a few dollars more, so the decision was a no-brainer.First off, I'm an urban mountain biker, if there is such a term, lol. I primarily ride on the streets, which are filled with cracks, bumps, potholes, and uneven pavement. The bike does a good job of handling this terrain, and for my purposes, the Wellgos do a great job of keeping my feet planted on the studs.The pedals seem very well made, and I was surprised that they were heavier than I expected. Not a big deal since I don't count ounces on my bike. The paint finish (I bought the silver ones), which I was most concerned about, is holding up well, with no flaking or chipping. If you ride hard, the paint will probably go bye-bye, but for "regular" biking, the finish does great.These pedals feel and perform solidly. The bearings are sealed and don't make a sound when pedaling. When you try to spin the pedals by hand, you can feel a bit of resistance from the grease the ball bearings are packed in, which is a good thing.These pedals came with reflectors, which saved me about 8 bucks by not having to buy them separately. There were no replacement studs in the deal, but after tightening them all down before my first ride with them, they shouldn't fall out.Pretty happy with these pedals. They look great and seem to be of good quality. If it weren't for the great deal I got for these, I would have probably opted for the plastic pedals--but I'm glad I didn't.

I wanted a basic, good bike rack at a reasonable price. The Allen Sports Deluxe 2-Bike Rack seemed to fit the bill. The main gripe I have with this device is that the video demo was somewhat untruthful in its presentation. The supporting struts that attach to the frame are not as easy to attach as it shows in the video. It took quite a lot of force to get the pins lined up with the ports.The strap system was also confusing. The written instructions advice you to wrap and tie the straps a certain way, which doesn't really work. It took a while before I figured out that the standard pull and stretch way was the best way to do this.The rack is sturdy, and for the price it's a pretty good deal.This is advertised as a two-bike rack, but the space separating the mounting areas for bikes is extremely small, and putting two bikes together will be a challenge. It should also be noted that the maximum weight this rack can carry is only 70 pounds. This may be a problem for two department store bikes as these can easily exceed this limit.

Pretty nice lamps. They're smaller than the humongous fluorescent lanterns I used to have, but they produce more light and use less batteries than the old ones did. And they're much lighter as well and can be kept anywhere without taking too much space.The only thing I'm concerned with is the constant flashing LED that helps you to locate the device when the lights are out. This is a nice feature, but I wonder if this slowly depletes the power in my batteries. Too bad it doesn't have an option to turn this light off.Overall, a good lantern at a pretty reasonable price. Brand name alternatives cost much more, but this one performs just as good.

Purchased this phone for an elderly relative who wanted a cell phone that was easy to use and could be relied upon to call her family in the event of an emergency.For a technical person, the phone is easy to set up with emergency phone numbers, etc. But for an elderly person, this may not be so easy as there are many menus and submenus to navigate around in order to set it up. Once this hurdle is jumped, the phone is easy to use.If this phone is for a senior, it may be a good idea to set up the device first before handing it over to them, just to make things easier. This phone is unlocked so you can add your own SIM card from an existing wireless phone or set up a pre-paid phone service.The phone is easy to use as all you have to do is to press the "A" or "B" buttons to alert those already entered into the emergency number slots.Sometimes reception isn't as good as it can be, but overall, it does a nice job for a simple and easy to use phone for seniors or anyone who just wants a basic mobile phone.

After more than two-weeks of trying this saddle out, and really wanting to like it, the final results are in and my butt says it didn't work at all for comfort, although the advertising states that the saddle would give "unparalleled comfort for cycling." This didn't happen for me, unfortunately.The saddle is very well made, and it did provide some very strong ventilation in the nether parts of my anatomy, but after adjusting the fore and aft position of the seat, the angle, and just about everything else I could think of, the rides on this saddle ended up producing soreness at best and pain at the end of the ride at worst.I don't doubt that others have good experiences with this seat, but for me, it didn't meet the stated effects or the comfortable ride the manufacturer promised. But although the price was more expensive than other seats, and should have provided better performance in comfort, it was less comfortable than saddles costing half as much.In the long run, YMMV.

Well, what can I tell you? My first review of this item was three stars due to the "fact" that it seemed no more comfortable than my stock seat. I tried adjusting the saddle every which way but loose, but the final result was a sore bottom and a ride that couldn't be tolerated for more than 40 minutes before my derriere screamed "Stop!"This prompted a quick change to another more expensive saddle that promised more comfort and 40% less pressure points. The seat height was also extended a bit to improve my biking position. After two weeks, this alternative saddle was sheer agony no matter the tilt or fore and aft positioning.I switched back to the Planet Bike A.R.S. saddle, and the results were much better. It's almost a year since I purchased this bike seat and it has been an improvement over the original seat that came with my bike. But after a year's worth of riding on it, the comfort it provides is just average. An improvement, no doubt, but not as comfy after a year as I would expect.As with all bicycle saddles, YMMV and one seat that is comfortable for some will be uncomfortable for others. My search continues for a truly comfortable bike seat.

Well, simply put,this little tool may save you hundreds of dollars in teeth cleaning bills if your pet doesn't mind you poking around in its mouth.Fortunately, our dog didn't mind, and on the first use, there were gobs of tartar, (gross, I know) that was scraped off. We're pretty  conscientious about brushing his teeth, and was surprised at how much gunk we were able to remove.This tool will save us some trips to the vet, and also keep him from going under anesthesia when he went in for teeth cleaning, which we really didn't like.The only downside is that the price suddenly jumped upward because it was becoming a popular item. The third party seller was already making pretty good money, but I suppose it decided to take advantage of the situation by bumping up the price by a couple of dollars. Felt like giving one less star for them being greedy, lol.

Not exactly for beginners although the author has made a strong attempt to reach this crowd. The first quarter of the book is dedicated to general information about bicycles, how they work, and different styles of bikes. If you like background info, Todd Downs does a pretty decent job of it.The rest of the book is broken down into the various sections and functions of the bike and goes into more detail on how to service specific items, how to troubleshoot, and some advice on bike maintenance.Overall, it's an OK book, but it's a toss up on whether it will be an effective reference book for you or not. While the mechanically gifted will get the most out of this book, for beginners the book falls short on levels of being a bit too complex, being too wordy when more graphics or photos would be more appropriate, and sometimes leaving out details that may be obvious to seasoned bike repair artists, but can be missed quite easily by new comers.Glad I purchased it used and not new. I'll keep it around as a reference, but it won't be my go to book for bike repair.

I only gave this product a 3-star review previously, but I have to admit, the reason why it didn't work as well as I expected it to was because of user error. The D-Cells I used to power the unit were fresh, or so I thought. It turns out that they were not, and were almost depleted because they were sitting in a lantern which eventually drained them.When the battery finally wore out, I replaced it with a new battery, and it instantly worked like a charm. I was able to drain a gallon jug of water into my aquarium in a matter of seconds. I now use it for water changes and it does a great job. I don't drain the water out of my tank with it, as the gravel could get sucked into the drive blades, but replacing the water back works a lot better and stresses out the fish less than pouring the water from the gallon containers.This suction device works better than some units I've seen that cost three times as much at the local pet stores.

I've been using Tetra fish food for a long time, but the flakes would cloud my tank water even after very light feedings. I saw the Aqueon product at a local pet store and decided to buy a small sampler.The fish loves this food, and the best part, even after a heavy feeding, the water remains clear and not cloudy. Of course, if you go overboard like this all the time, your water WILL get cloudy. But under normal feeding circumstances, this food is just great.

Works just like the OEM part, and maybe a bit better. Installation was quick and easy, and the price for this replacement air filter was great.Although my old air filter looked clean, when compared to the new filter, the old one was off color and full of little bits of dirt. As soon as I replaced it, the car seems to be running a lot better, and even a slight increase in mileage.If you've got a first generation Prius, this filter will fit exactly.

The problem with six-outlet electrical plugs is that you rarely can use all six. Somehow, the electrical engineering wizards who design these things place the outlets way too close to each other, which basically defeats the purpose of using any appliances or electronics devices that have odd shaped adapters.In the case of the Belkin Pivot Wall Surge Protector, the design is spot on with six outlets; each outlet can be independently swiveled. Other swivel outlets only let you swivel a bank of three at a time, which basically presents the same problem as a standard flat six-plug wall mount--you can't fit all your devices because the plugs are too close together.This Belkin provided enough space to use every one of the outlets for my electronic gadgets. The most offending shaped one wasn't even an AC adapter, but a very large, round nightlight that hogged up two spaces. But with the Belkin Pivot, I just simply swiveled the outlet 90 degrees, and voila, problem solved.This product gets one star less not because it doesn't perform well, but it is quite expensive when compared to the other six-plug non-movable  outlets.But on the flip side, it does give you total access to all six plugs, plus it offers some safety advantages by not having some of your AC adapters precariously hanging on by a tread because they don't exactly fit.There's a screw that you can attach to the wall plate to keep the Belkin Pivot nice and secure, which is also a nice touch.

For an entry-level tablet, it's an OK selection, but those who want more freedom in configuration should look elsewhere.The tablet performs well for surfing, playing games, and reading books. Wi-Fi connection is always solid, and the heavily modified Android operating system is locked in to the Amazon universe. You won't be able to access any apps from the million or so that are available on the Google Play Store.Out of the box you won't be able to play flash video content either. This means you won't be able to view videos on websites, YouTube content, and other video related stuff. Big omission. You can get around this but it takes a bit of searching the web and finding the answers to do this. If you like reading ePUB books from your library, forget about this too. Again, there is a way around this, but it isn't entirely apparent.After about a year and a half, the Kindle Fire would suddenly shut off for no reason at all. It could never go past 47% without turning itself off. Called tech support at Amazon and all they did was read a pre-printed statement to me about resetting the device, which I already did. The long and short of it was that I solved the problem after searching, again, the Internet for a fix. However, the tablet still turns itself off occasionally due to this glitch.I'm pretty disappointed with the product and the usually great customer service by Amazon. The rep told me, "I have no record of this sort of problem." Really. Just read your own forum here and see the hundreds of individuals having this problem.This tablet had great potential but due to the wonky operating system, the amount of work you need to whip it into shape, and the faulty product, I think 2-stars is being pretty generous.This tablet was for a family member, and were it not for all this fussing with it, the thing would not work at all, sad to say.No more Amazon tablets for me, my friends, or my family. I cannot recommend this product.

This is a very nice scale to look at. It has nice, large numerals, and the glass designed is liked by everyone in the family. However, it has a serious design flaw. I keeps the reading of your last measured weight in its memory for at least a minute. What this means is that if you weigh yourself carrying something heavy, the scale will still read out its last measurement.I was wondering why the manufacturer suggested this in the instructions:"We generally recommend that you weigh yourself no more than once a week when you're dieting."Really? This seemed crazy to me. Now I know why. People will complain, and have complained, about this scales inaccuracy, which is probably due to this memory problem.We've adapted to this defect, and repeated weighings means waiting about a minute and sometimes less, between sessions.We checked this scale against another brand that was more expensive, and without the memory defect, and after about 20 minutes of testing, this scale works fine and gives accurate readings within its limitations.This scale would have easily received a 5-star rating if not for the memory defect. What is totally ironic about all of this is that this scale is approved by Weight Watchers. Selling a defective product under its brand name, I'm sure, is a great advertisement for the company's image. (Sarcasm intended)

There are lots of models of meat thermometers out there, and this can make your head spin because of all the selections. But I picked this model out of the crowd because I liked the looks of it. I know--not very scientific, but I figured, since Norpro made a lot of kitchen gadgets and accessories, it might be worth a try.The Norpro meat thermometer has a very long sensor that measures 8-inches and is great for keeping your hands away from a hot pan, stove, or bbq grill.The digital display is great and is large and easy to read. I especially like the seven preset modes on it--all you have to do is to select the type of meat you are cooking and the gauge automatically screens up the proper target temperature and the real-time temperature. The reading comes up extremely fast--about two or three seconds. The Norpro also has a "user" mode that just reads the temperature without any presets.I tested the accuracy of this unit in a cup full of ice and it read 32 degrees--right on the mark.As an added bonus, the device gives off an audible "beep" when the meat reaches the proper degrees. For beef there is a setting that allows you to select the option of medium rare, medium, or well done.This meat thermometer, when compared to others, has a great deal of features not found on devices costing much more.As to the review that claims that this device melts--there is no way that this can happen under normal circumstances. My guess is that the reviewer accidentally melted the device by leaving it in the oven while cooking, or left it over the bbq grill and forget to take it out. ALL devices will melt if you do this.I like the Norpro and am glad I took a chance on it.

I read the glowing reviews here and also viewed America's Test Kitchen test of this pan and decided to purchase one from Amazon, in spite of some of the reviews saying that the pan was defective and bulged in the middle when heated.As soon as I received the T-Fal fry pan, I carefully seasoned it according to the instructions and attempted my first cooking experience with it by making an omelet. Things worked out very well and the egg slide right off without any problems at all.The next test was to make some fried chicken. This is where the quality control of this pan went south. As soon as the pan registered it was hot enough to cook in, the added oil in the pan quickly went off to the outside perimeter of the pan and pooled at the edges. This pan becomes convex when heated. Not a good thing.I believe that there must be an on going problem with these pans and T-Fal has yet to admit it. I sent an email to customer support and all they said was to return it to them to get the pan evaluated. Of course I would have to pay shipping. No thanks T-Fal, you've just lost a customer for your fry pans.Due to the poor customer support and defective workmanship of this pan, I cannot recommended it even though it received high marks from television review shows. They must have received a different batch then those sold to the general public, as these pans are definitely warped.Too bad, this pan could have been a contender.
Very disappointing anti virus program. Very slow scanning of device and is a heavy drain on the battery. Uninstalled from device.

I was torn between the Ozeri BP2M and the nearest competitor, the Omron 7. I was dazzled by Ozeri's multi-colored readout, so I ordered it. As it turned out, it was one of the worst BP units I have ever used.First, it never was able to take a complete reading without an error message or failing to inflate. The instruction were very clear, and I followed them exactly. Usually after five of six tries, I would finally get one reading. This is unacceptable, and one of my family members commented that the Ozeri was probably raising my blood pressure because of its ineffectiveness.I couldn't agree more.The colored LED display is really nice and cool, but if the machine can't even take a reading on the first try, it fails in its purpose. The Ozeri doesn't have an audible or visual signal to tell you when your arm is in the proper position for a reading, so you have to do the best you can from the illustration in the manual (your arm should approximately be at heart level). A table or flat surface is needed use Ozeri, and even so, the unit still failed again and again.I have returned this unit to Amazon, and its great return policy has saved the day again. I realize that this may have been a bad unit, but even so, the inconvenience of not having a position alert, and the necessity of having to have a table to place your arm on is a lot of hassle.I have opted for the Omron 7, and this unit is a wonder. It did everything well the first time I used it, and it is very easy to use and has a position alert, which is invaluable.It's too bad Ozeri failed, I would have liked keep it. But considering the circumstances, I have returned it.

I know a lot of the reviews on here and on the Internet have basically trashed this game with phasers on kill, but in spite of all the bugs, I enjoyed playing this game. Basically, Star Trek was rushed through to store shelves without enough time to fix all the bugs, some of which, are unintentionally funny:* Spock runs in circles in front of open fire during some battles. (AI bugs)* Screen status displays get stuck and don't go away when playing. (Interface bugs)* You can see inside Kirk's or Spock's head when the camera angle is high and they are against walls. (clipping bugs)* Spock or Kirk can get stuck in corners or objects trying to follow you. (Collision detection bugs)* The Gorn like to run at you in the open while you blow their heads off. (AI bugs)* In a later part of the game, if you don't have the right equipment with you, you'll never finish the level. (Level design bug)There are many more bugs, but this kind of shows you how embarrassing this game must be for the QA testing teams, and the producers of this game. If I were part of this project I would be hesitant to have my name on the credits or have the game listed on my resume.OK, with this out of the way, I still enjoyed this game because the plot continues the storyline after the first movie and is entirely unique. The dialogue between Kirk and Spock are great, Bones, Scotty and Sulu have some great lines too. Uhura, not so much. Kirk and Spock give some very funny lines--too bad the real movies didn't have more of this.I suppose this is more of an interactive movie more than anything else. I know the AI is a little dumb, but it isn't any more different in the movies where the bad guys always lose, right?This is also sort of a puzzle game too. You get your mission objectives, and you really have to think things out to complete them. For those who don't like to figure things out, it won't be a game they like. But if you like games like Tomb Raider or the Fallout series, Star Trek is sort of like these, but more simple.Graphics are a bit embarrassing too. If this game were made 10 years ago, it would have been considered cutting edge, but by today's standards, they look a little dated. They're not awful, by any means, but we've all been spoiled by Gears of War and BioShock graphics.Although this game was rushed, I could still enjoy it for the Star Trek experience it gives. The plot is very good, the music is great, the script is good, and it feels like you're inside a real Star Trek movie.The game is not perfect, but I liked it anyway. This could have been a better game, but with only about a year to get it out, it's amazing that anything works at all in this game. It feels like a very late "alpha build,", or an almost completed game with lots of bugs still in it.

If you've read some of the reviews about this product, you probably came away a bit confused. I know I was. There were reviews that said it was cheap and didn't work to other comments that said it was a great product. So which ones were true, I thought. Only one way to find out; I purchased one. Here is what I found out.This review is for the 20-inch LED hood and are specific to this hood size.Bright lights--------------As far as adequate lighting, there is more than enough to fill up a 10-gallon tank. I don't know why others have complained about the lack of lighting. I found it quite bright when compared to my old incandescent lights, and the slight falloff of brightness in the corners is just nitpicking, in my opinion. It is barely perceptible.Plants like it---------------As far as being good for plants, the LED lamps are doing a fine job providing enough lighting for them to grow. None of them have died, and if anything, appear to be as healthy or better than with incandescent lighting.Cheap or not?-------------Some reviews said the hood was cheaply made. On this point,this all depends on what you consider cheap. The hood itself is well made, but it isn't of the thickest plastic that I usually expect in aquarium hoods. The fit was just right, but the hood did not fit flush on top of the fish tank. I did a little adjustment with the clips that attached the light to the hood and it straightened out nicely.Filter panels--------------The opening on the back of the hood, for hang on the back filters, measures about 6 and 7/8s inches. There was enough room for my filter plus a little space left over to place my aquarium heater next to it. For filters that are wider, you will need to cut or saw the plastic to make the openings wider for your use.If you've got an air stone at the back of the aquarium like I do, you'll see a significant amount of water splash onto the back of the hood. This didn't look too good for the light switch so all I did was to cut a piece of filter foam to cover the exposed hood area area. Problem solved. You can also cut a piece of stiff clear plastic from a package to do this as well.If you've got a water filter that splashes water upon its reentry into the aquarium, a similar solution will also fix this.LED protection---------------There is a little plastic shield that covers the LED light, and I found that this completely shields the LED lights from any water that splashes onto this area. The light was securely snapped into place, and when the hood is opened, it does not fall out as others have indicated. But it will fall out if the hood is opened at a 90-degree angle.The hood can be propped up with a small spoon or fork if you need to clean or vacuum the tank, and it's really no big deal to lift the hood to feed your fish. It only takes a micro-calorie to do this. There is a little slide out door that you can remove to leave a little opening to feed your fish, but I have left it on to make the hood look more uniform.Clean and healthy design-------------------------The main reason why I purchased this hood was because of two reasons. I suspected that my old incandescent hood was slowly leeching bad metals into the water because the metal parts were rusting from the moisture, and the excessive algae growing underneath the hood was really unsightly. The LED hood is free of metal parts, and it is healthier for my tropical fish. I also like the low profile design of the hood. It makes the tank look sleeker.Easy assembly; read the directions-----------------------------------Setting up the hood on my fish tank took about a half an hour because I wanted to make sure I understood the directions on how to attach the hood clips at the back of the tank. You actually have to angle the clips down at a 45-degree angle and then lift up so the other side of the clip can attach underneath the aquarium frame. There are two sizes of clips so make sure you use the right ones.Once this is done, you have to apply pressure to the joints of the hood, on top of the clips, in order for the two to snap together. No a whole lot of force is needed, but you do have to angle your push so that it is directed exactly downward on the clips. The instructions saved me a lot of hassle, so you may want to read them carefully.One thing that should be noted is that the opening at the back of the hood, for a HOB (hang of back) filter is about 6.5 inches wide. If you place an aquarium heater in this space alongside the filter, you'll just have enough room for both. But if you have a larger HOB filter, you'll need to cut away some of the plastic to accommodate a wider filter. I used a Dremel-like tool to cut away the extra plastic and a Fluval C2 filter now fits nicely in this area. It's too bad the manufacture didn't allow for snap-off sections to make the filter opening larger.LED Performance----------------Switching over to LED from incandescent was a bit of a shock as the light spectrum of LEDs is definitely on the bluer side as opposed to incandescent bulbs which are more yellow. This lighting really makes everything pop in the fish tank, but since it is a bit weak on the red spectrum, reds and yellows don't come out as much. The blue moonlight feature is an extra bonus and I've watched my fish during the night under this lighting. They seem to like it, although I haven't left it on all night yet.After about a week of getting used to the LED lights, I prefer these over my old lights. Family members are envious of how the tank looks in comparison with their regular light bulb setups. They've noticed that the tank now looks very sharp and "professional," whatever that means, lol.You may not like the bluish-green tint of these lights, so take this into consideration if you are thinking about buying this unit.Conclusion-----------This hood is a great bargain, and only time will tell if it is long lasting as well. But for what I paid for it, which is essentially the same price I would have had to pay for a similar incandescent set up with those horrific rusting metal parts, I would say that this LED hood is well worth it for the health of my fish and the overall look of the tank. Plus it uses less energy and puts out virtually no heat--a plus when the weather gets hot.This hood isn't perfect, but for what it does, it definitely is a good aquarium hood. This hood works for me, but YMMV. Just understand that this is a bargain hood, and don't expect $100 features from it. If you've got that down, you should be OK with it.

It's not very often that a sequel to a game turns out better than the original, but this is exactly what The Bigs 2 has done. The game play is still fun, and there are many more features and things to do in the game.The Be a Legend mode starts you off as a rookie, and you progress in your star rankings by going against the greatest players in baseball--past and present, fulfilling sports challenges, and of course, winning ball games.The narration by Damon Bruce is as hilarious, if not more so, than the previous Bigs game and the way he goes, "I don't THINK SO..." gets me every time.You get to go to Japan and play against some of the best teams over there, and the crowd noise makes you feel that you're really there. Want a taste of baseball in Mexico? You'll go down there too, but watch out for that Toro pitcher. You'll know when you see him.The Bigs 2 is probably my all time favorite sports game right now, behind The Bigs.Pitching and hitting mechanics seem to be a bit more tuned in, but maybe that's just me getting used to hitting the ball better.If there was one gripe, it's really a small one. The Turbo bar is now white, and it's not the clearest thing that you can see. A green color would have made more sense.Too bad there isn't a Bigs 3 in development because 2K Sports has the best baseball arcade game in the industry, imho.

This is a good basic mini-stereo system for playing your CDs, for listening to FM radio, and listening to your collection of music from your iPhone or iPod. The compactness of the unit fits very comfortably on a table, shelf, or window sill.I know there are more expensive versions of this styled unit from Panasonic, but a family member just wanted something under $50 to listen to her favorite CDs in the kitchen. Previous to this, we were just using an old Sony clock radio, so this new unit is definitely a step above in sound quality.You won't get pulse pounding deep bass or detailed highs, but overall,for general listening the unit produces pretty good sound and even though it is only rated at 10 watts, it easily fills a room with music.The iPod feature is great and the connector will fit any iPhone or iPod with the old 30-pin connector. I have an iPod iTouch and hooking this up to the Panasonic took only a few seconds. Very easy set up. The iTouch was charging in the dock and this means you can play music all day long without running down the battery. Very nice feature.The radio portion of the Panasonic is OK. Not stellar but it will get the job done. There is no manual tuning nob so you'll have to scan through the stations to lock them in. It's automatically done, so no big deal.For more picky ears, you can probably go to more expensive units, but if you're just looking for a good, inexpensive music player that doesn't sound like a cheap boom box, the Panasonic may be what you are looking for.

You may have noticed the wide range of review ratings on this product from 5-stars to just 1-star. This had me a bit worried before I purchased this unit, but since Amazon backed up their products with its excellent return policy, I took a chance on it.First off, for those who haven't "programmed" a universal remote before, the steps and instructions can be a bit scary or involved. You must read carefully regarding the sequence of buttons you must push in order to get this to work with your devices. There are basically three ways to do this and if one doesn't work, you have two other fallback plans.For me, I choose to just input the different codes available for my TV, DVD, VCR, and Xbox 360. The WR7 lists several codes for each device and you input each one until one turns off your device. In some cases, multiple codes work but only one will give you full functionality.For my outdated Realistic VCR from Radio Shack, none of the codes worked, so I did the "automatic" scan method where you just tell the WRC WR7 to go through a list of pre-programmed codes. Once your device recognized one, it will turn off. As it turns out, the code it used was for a Panasonic VCR, which means the Radio Shack unit was made by Panasonic.In addition, I used the "learning mode" to program the WR7 to take over all of my Roku LT's functions. But according to various websites, because the WR7 only works with IR remotes, later models of the Roku cannot be programmed into the remote. It also should be pointed out that the directions for the learning mode of the WR7 may be in error. After programming, in some cases you will need to hit the component button again before "saving your work."Basically, I can understand the frustration some users of the WR7 have experienced because there is a somewhat steep learning curve if they haven't programmed a remote before. Also, after reading many of the 1-star reviews, it seems that a good deal of them have to do with user error, impatience, or just unrealistic expectations.I was able to program the WR7 between breaks watching streaming videos with my Amazon Prime account. Total time actually spent on programming was about 30 minutes--most of which had to do with re-reading instructions and making mistakes and figuring out what I did wrong.I like the layout of the buttons and the back light is pretty bright; the color is red, but it would have been nice if it was a shade of blue or just plain white.A good thing about this remote is that all your commands and programming is stored on a memory chip. If your batteries die, according to the manufacturer, you can come back months later to insert new batteries and the programming will still be in the remote. In real world terms, this means if you run out of batteries or use rechargeables, you have more than enough time to replace the batteries in the unit without losing all your hard earned programming.This remote is quite deep in features, and I may never get to the point where I used all of them, but it's good to know that they're there in case I need them. I did use one of the more "advanced" functions by mapping all of my devices to the TV volume controls. Now, no matter if I use the DVD, Roku, or VCR, the volume controls are linked to the TV functions.However, it should be pointed out that programming macros or steps for customized features doesn't always work. I found out that while doing a macro for turning on various components, it was all but impossible because the remote has no way if knowing where the last input setting was on the TV. Some TVs have dedicated buttons for video 1, video 2, etc., but if your TV needs to screen through button presses, you're out of luck with the WR7.It takes some work to program this thing and YMMV as to how quick, easy, and successful you are in getting the expected results. Some devices may not work with this remote, but using the learning mode or scan function takes care of most of these worries. There are probably instances where this remote will not work on some electronics; but for 20 bucks, it seems to handle most situations very well. It should be pointed out that even the most expensive universal remotes have programming issues.Overall this device doesn't get a perfect 5-star because the steps in programming may turn off some people and it isn't as easy as the company leads on. But if you've programmed universal remotes before, don't mind spending a bit of time learning how to program this unit, or are OK with carefully following instructions, for about $20, this remote is really worth it.

UPDATE: After about a year or so of use, this unit has proven to be unacceptable because of quality issues. The spring-loaded plates that keep the napkins in place often move out of place, the flanges that keep the napkins from popping out are too small and short to retain the napkins, the "stainless-steel" finish stains easily with fingerprints. I am bringing the original rating down from 4-stars to 1-stars and will be looking for another brand.If you can, avoid this model. This unit is going to the Goodwill shop.

From the reviews it seems that some folks are getting the shiny Mylar material while others are receiving the standard gray (polytaffeta shade) that most people are used to. I received the latter and am pretty happy with the purchase.I have a 2001 Prius with a gigantic windshield and virtually every sunshade that I have tried is too small to cover it completely although these manufacturers claim that their products fit. The Magic Shade Super Jumbo sunshades are huge and are able to fit nicely, without any gaps. One shade almost covers the entire surface area of the windshield and the other one completes the coverage. I can use these vertically or horizontally.Good product and it works great.

I really enjoy reviewing products, but I dislike reviewing things that I don't really like. It seems like a service to people to let them know about great things that they might have overlooked. Less so to warn them that they might not want to buy something.But, here goes.People have been trying to put "message centers" on the front of the refrigerator for many years. I guess it just seems like an obvious thing, that should work, but it never really does. Sadly, this is another example.First, this is supposed to magnetically stick to your refrigerator. They show it that way in several pictures. Interestingly, every picture shows it stuck to the front of a stainless steel refrigerator. Which, if it is actually stainless steel, and not a cheaper metal that looks like stainless, is impossible because stainless steel is a non-magnetic surface. So, it won't stick on my fridge without double-sided tape, which isn't going to happen.The looks. It is a good size. Not too small, not excessively large, and has a convenient "handle" on the top, which I guess means you could hang it from a hook, though the look might be kind of sloppy, depending on what you are going for in your kitchen. The overall thing reminds me of a transistor radio from the 70s. Or maybe a gray Speak N Spell. The overall impression is that of a child's toy, not a $200 piece of equipment. I guess you could call that retro, but in my opinion it is pretty unattractive.The setup routine was fairly easy, though it felt a little "beta" in that there were obvious places to help me where it didn't. Like, it told me it can't connect to 5GHz networks, which was very useful (I usually find that out when something tries to connect and fails), but it also didn't scan for any networks other than the one my iPad was connected to which, you guessed it, is a 5 GHz network. So, I had to manually enter the network name. Not too hard, because I'm the one that set up the network, but I can't remember any other piece of equipment where I've had to manually enter the name instead of selecting it from the available choices. Such an obvious thing, but missing. But, don't get me wrong - setup was not very hard, and I had mine up and running in minutes. It just seems like there are some areas for improvement.The sound is okay. It seems to have two small speakers on the front grill (that I could see with a flashlight). It connects to wifi and plays internet radio stations, which is good. It will also connect to Spotify, if you happen to use that.The little display is e-ink, like a Kindle, so it doesn't use power after it is drawn - a good choice for this application. It is pretty small, though, so you aren't going to be putting much on it other than "I miss you!" or "have a good day!" Both of which you could also do by scribbling on a pink Post-it Note. And that would actually stick to the stainless steel fridge. Or the inside of their lunchbox. You get the idea. One of the main functions of this device can be easily replaced by a notepad, which is quicker and easier to use, though you won't be leaving any notes remotely.The "make calls through the app" thing. Why would I need this? I can already do it with Skype, or the free app that my cable company gives me, or any of a number of different ways. Or, I could just dial their number and make a phone call. This seems like something that people may have wanted ten years ago (maybe), but today?So, the main thing this does that is useful is play Internet music. But, check out the price. You could buy an Echo for less, do the same thing, all by using voice control, and from many more services than Spotify.I buy stuff like this just for fun - I consider it entertainment money. I have at least five media streamers, just because I find it interesting to play around with them and to make comparisons. I bet I have ten bluetooth speakers. But this thing? Like Tom Hanks said in Big, "What's fun about that?"Not enough.I'd give this one a pass.Sean Logue, 2015

There are two stands that look somewhat like this one. The other is by Bello, and instead of an S-curve in the wood, it is more of a curve from top to bottom, and then along the front edge.Amazon sells both, and you may be conflicted as to which one is better, as I was.Well, I bought both of them. I sometimes do that with less expensive items so that I can review them, but this isn't in that category. The reason is that I needed two TV stands, one for my den downstairs, and the other for my bonus room, and as happy as I was with the first one I bought for the den, I really didn't want the exact same thing upstairs.I won't spend a lot of time talking about the Bello version because this is a review for the Lumisource. If I were going to buy only one, I would go with the Bello. However, they are both very good.This was fairly easy to put together, if you follow a few simple guidelines, none of which are in the single sheet pictogram that comes with it. The instructions for this are, on a scale of 1-10, a 2. There are a few picture, with lines and letters, but it basically is horrible. The feet on the back piece aren't even in the picture, so there is a 50/50 chance you will install it upside-down, then realize at the end when you have extra feet, and have to disassemble it. So, instructions? Horrible.The glass pieces are fairly thin, and have a matte-finish side along with a smooth, polished side. Put the polished side up. They do have steel supports under each one, because they need them.The wooden S-Curve sides are preassembled, with chrome bars. I liked that these were pre-assembed, but I noticed that they had fasteners underneath that fit the included allen wrench. Two of them on mine were loose, so I recommend tightening them before placing things on the shelves. The finish on the wood is cherry. On the box, they call it wenge-wood, which may refer to the grain pattern, but understand that the actual color is traditional cherry wood.I recommend scraping each screw against a piece of bar soap for lubrication. And, for each one, keep in mind that your main goal is to not cross-thread it (put it in straight). Instead of doing one side, like the instructions say, do each shelf, starting from the bottom, on both sides. Do not fully tighten the screws - leave them wiggly. When you finish all three shelves, do not tighten the screws (like I did).After the shelves are in, put the back wooden piece in place. The two screw holes on the top should be facing the floor, because those two holes are where feet will be screwed into later.If you did what I said, and left everything wiggly, you will be able to get the back piece on. If not, loosen up the screws and try again. The metal supports are not precision-made, and they flex, so if the screws are loose, and you put each one in straight, at the end you will be able to tighten them all up and the metal supports will bend to accommodate.At the end, tighten everything up, but try not to be a gorilla about it, especially in the spots where screws go into wood.At the end, put the glass pieces into place. Largest one on the bottom, medium one in the middle, and smallest one on top (glossy side up).It is a good looking piece. It isn't as well-designed as the Bello, and the instructions are pretty horrible. The end result, though, is a good one.Recommended, but check out the Bello version before clicking Buy it Now.Sean Logue, 2015

It is really difficult to review this kind of item, because without a double-blind clinical study, it is hard to say whether it works. And, if it does appear to work, it could be because of eating different foods, experiencing different amounts of stress, drinking more or less fluids that day - lots of hard to control for factors.So, I'll just say this. Probiotics like this one appear to be helping me. The most effective ones seem to be the ones that have multiple strains, a large number of colonies, and are contained in a pill that is coated so that it can make it through the stomach (where it won't help) to the intestine (where it will).
