By the time a standard gelatin capsule goes all the way through the stomach, many of the colonies will be destroyed by the acid.This one ticks off all the boxes, which makes it a good choice to try. Because everyone is different, however, you should take it daily for at least a week, preferably two, and then monitor whether it seems to help. If it doesn't, try a different brand with different strains and design of the pill. These things are not inexpensive, so only buy one bottle, and the smallest one they have, so that you can evaluate it before buying more.Hopefully this one will work for you!Sean Logue, 2015

This would be a terrific gift to show up with when attending a dinner party, or picking someone up for a date. It is small, so it isn't over the top, but large enough so that it doesn't look like you grabbed it while standing in line at the supermarket.The box is very elegantly designed, and has a little booklet on the outside that has pictures and full descriptions of each piece. It looks and feels expensive, which is another reason it would be great as a gift.Finally, the chocolates themselves are a nice little assortment of high-end, Swiss-made chocolates. Nothing odd in this bunch, so chances are that whoever gets it will enjoy all of them.I'm actually thinking of keeping a few of these on hand for the upcoming holidays. Every so often, it is nice to have a gift available at the last minute, and because of the great box, you won't need to wrap it.Recommended.Sean Logue, 2015

This is a great pendant!The blue is bright and clear, and the white sapphires along the edge look great, without distracting from the primary stone.Sapphires are extremely hard, and won't scratch, so the stones will retain that clarity over time. The hardness also means they are somewhat brittle, and they can chip on the edges. That's why having the white stones around the entire edge is a good thing - they help protect the primary stone from accidental chips.It is true that these are manufactured stones, which means they were grown in a lab using very expensive equipment that recreates the heat and pressure-filled environment that creates natural stones. The end result is a real sapphire, free of flaws and impurities. Truthfully, the manufactured ones are in some ways better than natural stones because of their clarity.If it sounds like I really like this, I do. It isn't overly gaudy, but will definitely attract attention and positive comments. Even the box it comes in, while simple, is nice and elegant. It would make a great gift, for others or even for yourself.Recommended.Sean Logue, 2015

This is a very attractive, reasonably priced pendant.The Celtic knot design is interesting, and adds to the antique look.The rhodium plating over the silver makes the silver less bright, and will prevent tarnishing. That is great, because it means that when you pull it out to wear with an outfit without being surprised by tarnish and having to pick something else.I like the size too. It is a bit on the small side, but if it were larger it would look less like jewelry and more like some sort of medallion.Recommended.Sean Logue, 2015

These are very elegant earrings. Not too large to be gaudy, not so small that they can't be seen.The white and yellow gold combination is excellent, sophisticated, and looks great. The posts and backs are gold, which is especially good news for people who have sensitivities to nickel, and other metals.The only real downside I can see is that they came in the cheapest box known to humankind. I mean, this thing was made of very cheap paper with a rectangle of foam thrown in. And, then, in case that wasn't unappealing enough, the earrings themselves were in little ziplock bags inside the box. I mean, it is good that they didn't get lost, but if I were giving these as a gift, I would definitely seek out a better box and move them into it.On the other hand, the actual item looks really good, works very well, and is a great value. So, buy your own box, but still get these. And, heck, if they are for you? Skip the box altogether. Nobody really needs that anymore after they are on. :-)Recommended.Sean Logue, 2015

This is a fantastic, all-purpose wireless keyboard. Backlit, laser-cut keys, integrated touch-pad, and attractive enough to prop up against the side of the sofa for when it is needed.The key feel is very good, and the keys themselves are full-size. The two together mean that it is has a nice feel when typing.The rechargeable battery is supposed to last a very long time before needing to be plugged in, and I haven't seen anything to contradict this claim. If it did run out, you could plug it in while using it, so that wouldn't be a very big deal regardless.The aluminum accents on the top and bottom edges look nice, and probably contribute to the solid feel and general lack of flex.Overall, it works well, looks great, and is a far better alternative to moving a cursor around choosing letters with a remote.Recommended.Sean Logue, 2015

Turtle Beach recently released a new line of gaming headsets. There is this red one, a green one at a higher price point that adds wireless, and a high-end one that has Dolby Headphone features for sound effects. Pretty cool, because all of these headphones are good, and you can choose the one that is right for you based on your needs and how much you want to pay.This one has excellent sound quality, with crisp, clear vocals. The microphone is bendable, so you can position it in the best place for you. It works very well.The headset itself is lightweight, and very comfortable, even when worn for hours.There are plenty of audio controls, so you can adjust the sound level or mute right from the headset.There is one real drawback, however. The wired cord that connects these to the computer audio jack is way too short. You will probably need an audio extension cable for them. Also, because many computers (like my iMac) shut off the external sound when headphones are plugged in, you can't leave them plugged into your computer all the time or you won't be able to hear anything when not wearing them. This is very annoying, but isn't a fault of the headphones.Overall, though, these are a great value if you can live without wireless. Turtle Beach really knows what they are doing when it comes to audio.Recommended.Sean Logue, 2015

Years ago, when I was considering which single-serve coffee machine to buy, I asked my friends which one to get. The Kuerig, of course, was the most popular (here in America), but the small coffee pods seemed to make the coffee a little less robust than I was looking for. The Tassimo had a contract with Starbucks, and had the option to use double-sized pods for the stronger brews. One of my friends in Sweden strongly recommended something called a Nespresso, which I had never heard of. I did some research, and discovered that over in Europe, Nespresso is the dominant brand. There are even Nespresso coffee bars, where you can go buy a cup while on the go. It uses little aluminum pods that are small, but the espresso-based drinks it made were also small, so the coffee was very good.Back then, I chose to go with the Tassimo, and I enjoyed it for years afterward, even after they lost their Starbucks license and the pods it used started disappearing from the local supermarkets, their shelf space assimilated by the far more popular, and saleable, Keurig pods.Things change, and now it is time to finally give the odd machine my Swedish friend swears by a shot (pun intended - sorry!).This machine is all about espresso-based drinks. Lattes, macchiatos, ristrettos, lungos, and straight espressos are all available by popping in a pod and pressing the appropriate button. All of these fancy-sounding drinks are basically just different sizes of espresso, with or without foamed milk. My guess is you will quickly settle on one favorite (with or without milk), so it gets less confusing, very quickly. The hardest part of this is remembering what the tiny graphics on the buttons mean. I know why companies do this. It is because graphics don't have to be translated, which means they can sell the same unit in multiple countries without changes for the local language. For me, however, all of the graphics basically look like coffee cups to me, and I have a tough time with it. I'm getting used to it, but good luck if you expect a guest who isn't familiar with the machine to be able to pull it off.The pods are aluminum, color-coded, and very attractive. Color-coding them to the type of coffee was a brilliant move. If you know what color your favorite is in, you can quickly pick it out, even if they are all mixed up in a bowl. The writing on the foil top of each pod that identifies the coffee, however, is nearly impossible to read. It looks nice, but I had to hold them under the light and look at them from different angles to see it. They look nice, but some contrast would really help here.So, how is the coffee? Fantastic. The crema, the rich foam that floats on the top of a well-made cup, is thicker than any other single-cup maker I've seen. I suspect the reason for this is the high pressure this machine uses to extract the coffee. That is probably also why the pods are aluminum instead of plastic - so they can hold up under the pressure and not deform.The pods are available only from Nespresso, through the mail. Yes, there are a very small handful of "boutiques" that sell them, but we are talking five of them in the entire United States, which hardly counts as a retail "presence." They don't require a monthly subscription, and sell several mixed packages. When you sign up, there is a good deal on a one-time purchase of a welcome pack that contains all of them for around $200. It seems expensive, but this is a heck of a lot of coffee, and worth considering.The unit is small, compact, and seems very well thought out. I enjoy using it, even in the bleary-eyed mornings when I'm trying to get my kid onto the bus on time. I think it is something about those colored pods. They just make me happy.Recommended.Sean Logue, 2015

I hooked this up to my TV in about twenty, very leisurely minutes.  The only thing I needed the manual for was when it came time to program the unit to respond to the TV remote (necessary for such things as responding to the Mute button).  Even that wasn't hard, but I did have to read the tiny text a few times to "get it."It comes with everything you need, including an optical cable and two sets of white speaker wire for the satellite units.  The subwoofer is wireless, so it just needs an electrical outlet.  However, the subwoofer is very easily localized, which is geek-speak for it needs to be fairly close to the TV in the front of the room.  My first try was putting it behind me and I could hear dialogue clearly coming from behind my chair.  Now it is up front and it isn't a problem.The sound quality is much better than the built-in sound on the TV, and is very transparent to use once hooked up.  It seems to just work, muting when I press Mute, turning on with the TV, and turning off when appropriate.  It isn't going to replace a receiver with a dedicated speaker system, but it won't have wires strung all over the room, either.Overall, a nice addition to a modern TV (with optical out).Recommended.Sean P. Logue, 2013

My eight-year old daughter and I used this over the weekend as a fun project together.  Instead of using a recipe, we just made carrot juice and then put some apple juice on top.  This worked very well and tasted great!Pros:Very quiet, just a grinding (chewing) soundSeems to get the juice out - the pulp was very dryFairly fast.  It made short work of the carrots, and the apples were even easier.Compact.  Doesn't take up too much counter space.Attractive. Mine is the silver one, and it looks like the finish on a car. I bet the red one is even nicer looking!Cons:Tiny little chute for adding fruits and veggies meant that everything had to be cut up very small in advance.  Even some of the carrots were a little fat to fit in the hole.Seemed to get stuck fairly often, but was easy to unstick with the reverse button.Must be disassembled for cleaning, which isn't very hard, but also isn't very fun.Overall a nice way to get into juicing.  Just keep a sharp knife and cutting board nearby.Recommended.Sean P. Logue, 2013

I love these Griot kits.  They take a few of their products, and package them together for a single purpose.  In this case, it is their interior cleaner, leather cleaner, and some microfiber cloths.My car has an off-white (actually ecru) leather interior.  I also have an eight year old daughter who rides in it and tends to get footprints in seemly impossible places.  Consequently, the passenger seats really needed a through cleaning.Using only the items in the kit, I first sprayed the seats down with the interior cleaner.  The large sprayer head made this easy.  Perhaps a little too easy - the seats were a bit wet!  I then wiped them down with one of the cloths.  Most of the dirt came off at that point, but there were some nooks and crannies that needed some rubbing.  I also cleaned the interior door handles with the cloth, which was now wet enough that I didn't need to spray.  The oil and grease came right off.Then I used the leather spray.  While the interior spray really didn't smell like anything, the leather spray is scented to smell like fine leather.  This was great, because after wiping down the seats my whole car smelled great!  The spray dried to a nice matte finish after wiping with a fresh cloth from the kit.This kit really works, and is easy and quick to use. So easy, in fact, that it would make a great gift to anyone with a car that has a leather interior.  Particularly if it is ecru.Highly recommended.Sean P. Logue, 2013

This is easy to hook up because it plugs into the HDMI cables in between your TV and video source (like a cable box).  One extra HDMI cable, which it doesn't come with, and a spare power outlet is all you need.The keyboard remote is very slick.  It activates automatically when it is turned over, so you won't accidentally press any keys while using the "remote" side of it.  They keys are all back-lit too, which is great in the dark.It does get a bit hot during normal usage, so you won't want to put anything on top of it.Minus one star because I've found that after the novelty of searching for shows wore off, it doesn't really offer a lot of utility over the much cheaper Apple TV or Roku devices, and using those is simpler.Sean P. Logue, 2012
This shampoo cleans well, and smells great.The bottle is large, and the amount needed is small, so it will last a long time.I'm enjoying mine!Recommended.Sean P. Logue, 2012

This is great suntan lotion. It smells really good, and goes on like an expensive, non-greasy hand cream.The only downside is that the bottle is pretty small, which means this is pretty expensive per ounce.  You may want to use this just for faces and cover larger areas with a cheaper kind.  At SPF 30, it would work well for that.Expensive, but recommended.Sean P. Logue, 2012

This stylus is very standard, light-weight hollow aluminum with a black rubber tip.They are listed as being for the Kindle Fire, but will work on any pad with a capacitance touch screen such as the iPad (which is what I tested them with).The big advantage is that it is inexpensive, and comes in a pack of three.  That way if you tend to lose them, you'll have backups.You could easily spend this much money on a single stylus, so I highly recommend getting these instead.Recommended!Sean P. Logue, 2012

This is a nice collection of a charge cable, car charger, and outlet charger.  All of them are rated at 2.1 amps, which means they are suitable for the high power draw of the iPad.They are well packaged, and have a nice glossy black finish.  It would make a good gift.The outlet charger has flip-out prongs and a rounded shape, which makes it good for travel. I do wish it had two USB ports on it instead of one, but I guess they couldn't do that given the higher power in the single USB it provides.  I tend to travel with my iPhone and iPad, so it would have been helpful for me to be able to charge them both at the same time.Nice solution to a charging problem.Recommended.Sean P. Logue, 2012

This unit, which is about the size and shape of a small remote control, processes music to increase the apparent sound stage and separation of musical instruments.  It does work.  I found it works better on already heavily processed pop music than on other types, which is fun in a car because you'll have music seemingly coming from all over.  It works very much like the older SRS systems that now tend to be built into TV audio systems.  It would be nice if this were built into the actual player as well.The disadvantages are pretty obvious.  First, it is a separate unit with cabling that has to be connected between your portable player and your car stereo.  It isn't hard, but it is messy.  The second is the cost of the unit, which is at least twice what it should be, if not more.The price is just too high for what it does.Not recommended unless you can get it for a good deal.Sean P. Logue, 2012

Small, well-designed, fast (USB 3.0) drive.  The small blue light indicating use works well.  My Windows 7 system recognized it and installed the drivers for it without a fuss.The one disadvantage, and the reason I docked it a star, is that the enclosure is made of a relatively flimsy plastic.  Aluminum would have been better, both for ruggedness and heat dissipation. However, I didn't notice it getting more than warm in my testing, so this may not be a big issue.Recommended.Sean P. Logue, 2012

The box I received was left by UPS on the porch in 100 degree heat. Plus who knows how long it was in the hot truck. The carton says to store in a cool, dry place....so I was a bit concerned about consuming these. I stuck them in the fridge overnight.The twist off cap was a little hard to remove. I don't prefer drinking from a pouch so I squeezed it into a glass. It's very thick and very hard to drink from a glass. The color looks natural though.The flavor was a bit off-putting. I think it's the whey in it that I was detecting. But the banana comes through and is the lingering flavor from it. My 5 year old thought it was pretty good but had to use a spoon to get any from the cup.It's really a large portion for a kid, but not enough for an adult. (This is if using it as the only component of a meal.) They would make a good snack though.There is a lot of sugar in it, which concerns me, but in sure most of that has to be from the fruits. The nutritional content is decent though. Calcium, fiber and protein are in a good balance and the vitamins are at a good DRV as well. 100% of vitamin c is great, as is the amount of potassium.Be careful though if you're looking for yogurt with active cultures. The squeeze pouch says the product was pasteurized after culturing. I'm sure that heat is not good for the cultures.These are good for the intended purpose though. They don't require chilling, although they taste better that way, so they're good for keeping in a desk drawer or carrying with you on a trip.

This is a thick plastic binder with accordian sides which allow it to expand a bit. The bottom itself does not expand but the sides do. The colors are vibrant. The dividers are all clear with tabs on the top to allow a label to be put into them (like page or binder divider pages). The closure is what looks like a pony tail holder style elastic band. It's very loose when the binder isn't too full and stretches a bit when it is.I think files like this have lots of uses. I'm using it for our yearly tax deduction receipts. I have another that I use for our yearly medical expenses and bills. Files like this make it easy to keep everything in one place.The reason I don't allow more stars is that it does feel flimsy and the bottom doesn't expand which will create a file that topples or bulges in the middle instead of fully expanding to hold more stuff.

I got this for my husband, who shaves every morning before his shower. He used it for about 5 days before I asked him about the product. This is his opinion about the product: the razor works well, it didn't pull hard on longer hairs, it was a smooth surfaced head on the razor that allowed him to control the razor better over the curves of his neck and jaw. He liked that there is a pop-up trimmer on the back of the razor for getting a clean line along his goatee as well as trimming hairs along the back of his neck and sideburns. Although he did say it was a bit awkward to hold the razor at the right angle to use the trimmer.I grabbed it one day to get hairs around my knee and ankle that I always either miss or cut myself trying to get. I noticed that the hairs were still a little stubbly but I was able to get my knees shaved without bleeding, so that's a win for me. I like that there is a protective cover for the foils that will keep it from getting banged up in the drawer.

My 5 year old has been having trouble learning certain letters and numbers (why are 5, S, and 8 so hard anyway?) so this is a great way to help him learn to control his hand in the proper way for forming the ones which trouble him. The unit was pretty hard to get out of the packaging. You have to locate the locks which are hidden under folded cardboard. Kind of a pain and in no way frustration free packaging. (There are actually instructions in the booklet about how to get the unit out of the package but you can't get to the instructions until you get the unit out. Ha!)The volume does not get too loud, which I like. There are so many different ways to play. When you turn it on it will prompt you to enter your name using the letter buttons on the right. The instructions suggest that you "activate" the screen before you play by using the stamps to cover the screen in "writing" then clean it off by swiping. We didn't see that instruction before we started playing and it worked just fine. It did work better after doing it as it said. It did look like there were lines on the screen that didn't wipe away when we did it though.There are 6 main activity settings for learning to write and draw. The Guess the Picture one is virtually impossible to figure out. You're supposed to just draw until the picture comes up and match it to the letter button. My kid got frustrated really quickly with that one. But he spent hours working on the stencils, the how to draw, musical drawing and the letter practice.I did notice that the musical drawing didn't really keep playing the music unless you're drawing. There were many times we were drawing though and the music would stop anyway. All in all, I've seen that he has been more willing to practice working on letters on this than he was on paper.

I have naturally curly hair, just past my shoulders. I also have bangs that I blow dry and straighten daily. I also live in a fairly humid area. I'm always looking for something new and better to help my hair not frizz up and to protect my hair from heat daily. This seems to be doing the trick really well. I've used it three days in a row and my hair is softer and shinier each day. I have been able to dry the curly part of my hair without frizz and its still very well defined and soft.My only concern is that the product is shipped without any sort of hard plastic cover. The dispensing nozzle turns to lock but I still had quite a bit of spillage. The smell tends to linger in the hair as well. Its not an unpleasant smell but it does come across pretty strongly.

This book has 50 short daily readings. The author is candid and funny. She's easy to relate to and doesn't shy away from using stories from her own life. Each reading is easy to finish in a few minutes each day. They are typically stories with a lesson attached. Then there are several Bible verses which relate to the story. This will make a great personal devotion guide as well as a great gift book.

This is an awesome notebook. The heavy plastic cover is impossible to tear (we tried) and will hold up to lots of use. The addition of the cover over the spiral is awesome. I don't know why this wasn't done years ago (if it was, my apologies, I've never seen it). This will keep the notebook from snagging the inside of my purse as I carry it. The cover on the spiral is a canvas material and the blue colored patch on it is great for marking it. There is also a grey elastic pen loop on the outside.Inside, the paper is just paper. It's nothing new or special. There is a divider with one large tab and pockets on front and back. The packaging says the pocket is expandable, but I wouldn't advise putting too much in them because the notebook would get too bulky. The divider can be moved do any spot in the notebook via a set of tabs. They took patience to remove and place because although they are a fairly flexible plastic they are rigid enough to hold their shape and stay in place.I intend for this to be my new grocery notebook. I'll use the pocket to hold coupons. It's small enough to fit inside my purse but large enough to handle my list every week.

This is not your ordinary notebook. The heavy plastic cover is impossible to tear (we tried) and will hold up to lots of use during the school year. The addition of the cover over the spiral is awesome. I don't know why this wasn't done years ago (if it was, my apologies, I've never seen it). This will keep the notebook from getting snagged inside a backpack, locker or desk. It is a canvas material and the blue colored patch on it is great for marking it. There is also a grey elastic pen loop on the outside.Inside, the paper is just paper. It's nothing new or special. There are are three dividers with tabs (red, blue and green) and pockets on front and back. The packaging says the pockets are expandable, but I wouldn't advise putting too much in them because the notebook would get too bulky. The dividers can be moved do any spot in the notebook via a set of tabs. They took patience to remove and place because although they are a fairly flexible plastic they are rigid enough to hold their shape and stay in place.If this was wide rule paper my son would be using this for school this year. As it's college, it's mine and will be used for household organization.

My boys have been fighting over who gets to wear this! It fits both my 5 year old (wears size 6/S) and my 8 year old (wears size 8/M) very comfortably. The mesh back allows them to wear it without getting too hot. The front, with all the pockets, allows them to carry all kinds of things! Looking at the picture, the top right (top left when wearing) has a place for a pen to hook onto the vest. It's an open bottom so pencils without a hook to hold them fall right through. Next to that is a very small pocket which holds a small notebook really well. The other three pockets have a flap which close with velcro. Handy indeed. I'm not sure what all the elastic orange loops would be for. I like that there's some bright color to help it be more noticeable when outdoors.My only issue with it is that the zipper is quite difficult to get to line up and zip correctly. My 5 year old has to have help with it every time.

This is a really good book. One of the things that most people feel is important in life is to leave a legacy, to be remembered. This book gives advice on how to do that. It discusses using our faith as a focus in your story and how living that faith makes an impact on those who will know you.There are several "checkpoints" as well as things for you to think about as you"gear up" for your journey. Just like you wouldn't undertake a major vacation or trip without preparation, you can't expect to live an authentic life without preparing yourself and your heart. Each chapter ends with tasks for exploring ahead or thinking about what you want your life to look life next.

The showerhead looks fine and works like you'd expected.  There are two spray settings.  You turn the clear plastic rim about a quarter of a turn to switch between them.  I'd describe the options as "wide spray" and "narrow sandblast".  The latter is fine if you're cleaning the tub, but I don't really use it."Delta Faucet U3001-PK Universal Showering Components Wall Mount" and "Delta Faucet U3401-PK Universal Showering Components Adjustable Shower Arm Mount" fit, depending on what you're using for the hose.  The mounts actually hold the end of the hose, not the thick handle itself.The lights are not very bright, but it's bright enough for fun, I guess.  There are a bunch of different LEDs in the plastic rim, and they are not synchronized.  They sometimes start off all the same color, but they quickly start doing their own thing.I have a small water leak that I plan to seal by unscrewing it, adding some teflon plumbers tape like "EZ-FLO 50011 Teflon Pipe Thread Tape", and then screwing it all back together.  When I do that, I'll also insert "KES Solid Brass Shower Head Shut Off Valve with Long Blue Swith, Chrome" into the line, because this shower has a hotel-style control that lets you pick the temperature, but not control the water volume.  Turning the shut-off valve partway off will let help save water.

I had an opportunity to compare this watercolor book to a "licensed cartoon character" one from the drug store, and wow!  I had never realized that there was such a difference.  These Fisher-Price watercolors are much nicer.  The colors are brighter, there is more paint on the page, the paper is thicker and brighter, and the printing is clearer.  The perforations are easier to tear.  In fact, everything about these is better.It seemed like the red "paint" is a little slow to dissolve here (especially compared to the blue), but it works out fine in the end, especially for little kids, who aren't painting within the lines anyway.

It's a cheap toothbrush.  If you need a cheap toothbrush, then get these.The head is large, which is okay, I guess.  I suspect that some people will really like that, and others will really dislike it, and that most people will be like me and not care a lot.The handle is too skinny for me.  It's thicker than a pencil, but not by much.  There's also something about the grip, or the way that it goes from slightly thicker to thin again that seems to land in exactly the wrong spot for my fingers.  Perhaps it's just my arthritic fingers, but I just can't use this with any kind of comfort.  The rest of these are going in the "in case you forgot something" cabinet for guests.

These used to be so easy to find, and now it's almost impossible.The seller says that the sizes work like this:Size 1 = 22 to 24 lbs.Size 2 = 25 to 28 lbs.Size 3 = 29 to 32 lbs.Size 4 = 33 to 37 lbs.I don't know what that means for the size 5 and 6, but I'd guess that you add four or five pounds.  By that age, you can usually trust the little girls to keep their dresses down.  (On the other hand, that doesn't mean that they won't get caught up in a game and accidentally show off London and France.)I know one family that treated this style as fancy underwear, but back when these were common, most girls wore them over their regular knit panties.

Simple and classic.  This is the perfect size for putting a little milk or half-and-half on the table when you have a few friends over for coffee or tea.  It's big enough to hold half a cup, but it's small enough that it feels okay to put just a little in, if only one or two people are likely to use it.
It works.  However, it's both too thick (MacBook Air won't close all the way) and too thin (very easy to snap the sliding part in half).  It still basically works for me, even though it's broken.

I sent this to a birthday party for a 10-year-old boy.  Apparently, of all the odd-shaped Lego pieces I sent him, the trap doors were his favorite.Each piece is pretty cheap, and shipping doesn't amount to much.  I suggest looking at the options and buying an assortment, like I did—just don't forget to include some trap doors!

Five stars for Masha; three stars for the seller's description.As far as I can tell, there's no English sound on this DVD.  There are English titles for the episodes, but that's it.  On the other hand, you don't really need to speak any Russian to figure out what's going on.  Masha is as much fun and as appealing as VeggieTales used to be.

This is sturdier than what I could find in the dime stores, and much sturdier than what I saw in the dollar stores.I have two wishes:  that there were two shovels instead of a rake and a shovel, and that the sieve fit into the bucket a little better.  It looks like it's just the right size, but it doesn't sit flat for some reason.

I like this cake pan.  I've had no trouble with cakes sticking yet.Wilton 10-inch cake circles fit this cake pan very well, with just a thin rim of the cardboard showing (so you have something to hold onto!).

This is a nice semi-sweet chocolate with a moderate level of cocoa mass.  It's smooth but not too waxy, and melts nicely on the tongue.  It's a brighter taste than you'll get with chocolate chips from the grocery store, with no burnt flavors lurking in the background, and of course it doesn't have the stabilizers that make it possible for a melted chocolate chip to remain chip-shaped.Compared to similar chocolates, Barry Callebaut's semisweet is more fruity (Peter's Burgundy is more like a red wine than like fresh fruit), Guittard's  has more vanilla flavor, and Valrhona is drier and less distinctive.

I bought a lot of these for my husband a couple of years ago.  Every now and again, I pull out the sewing machine to stitch the latest pile of rejects back together.The fabric is nice enough (lightweight satin), and the elastic is entirely covered (good for people with latex allergy), but the stitching is the cheapest quality of workmanship I've seen in a commercially produced product.  Because of the nature of the fabric, the vertical seams get the most damage -- the satin just shreds right along the stitching.  So if you're handy with a needle and not too picky about clothing, they're fine.  You're getting what you're paying for.  If you're not interested in everyday use, they'll likely hold up for "special occasion" status for a long while.But if you're the kind of person who pitches perfectly functional clothes because they're not absolutely perfect, then you should look for boxers that have double-stitched/reinforced seams.  You'll have to pay quite a bit more, but they'll last longer.

This is the first, and will be the only, Agatha Raisin book that I have read.  The others are going back today.  The writing itself is fairly good -- better than, say, the first book of the "Gourmet Girl" series, which was recently inflicted on my consciousness, although not nearly as good as, say, Dorothy Sayers' classic works, like Busman's Holiday.  The plot in this book is a bit thin and fantastical, but acceptable.  I have read, and will continue to read, more books by this author; I'm just really turned off by this character.Agatha Raisin is a 50-something divorced woman that is irritatingly "sensitive", which is to say that she obsessively overanalyzes whether each and every male character's action indicates sexual attraction to her.  If men were to swoon at her feet, or to say romantic things to her, then this would prove that she's desirable and that therefore life is worth living.  However, most of the men around her live their normal lives, which doesn't involve much swooning or delivering romantic  gifts or expounding on her 'deceptively youthful beauty' (why is "young" a compliment in our culture?) every few pages, so she tends to think that she's doomed to a life of romantic failure, and -- quite unfortunately -- she hasn't got a Plan B:  either she's an outstanding romantic success, or she's a failure.  She has almost zero self-confidence, few enough moral standards, and is really disgustingly vain.  She tries to buy her way out of emotional disarray with cosmetics, hair styling, exercise classes, cigarettes, and expensive vacations.  I found the nicotine addiction to be intrusive, but the scene in which she can't pay attention to *anything else* because she has discovered a short hair on her upper lip, and "he" might be revolted by this tiny and temporary physical imperfection, was the end of any lingering sympathy for her.In this book, Ms Raisin runs away from the problems engendered by her "hopeless romanticism" -- twice -- to get advice from a conveniently placed stranger, a Latino "wise woman".  This character irritates me for being essentially a classic, and classically racist, "magical negro" character, with the only material difference being that she exists to make Ms Raisin look pathetically sensitive and in need of gentle guidance or loving support (character development), instead of simply a deus ex machina to advance the plot.Ms Raisin is also stupid, which is to say that she lets her vanity lead her into amazing foolishness, resulting in a supposedly exciting (read:  predictably life-threatening), but unrealistic, conclusion.  (A realistic conclusion would have involved a search warrant, a couple of police officers, and a debriefing over coffee after the action.)This book really seems to be a romance novel, with enough detecting thrown in that you don't have to face the stigma of buying a plain old romance novel.  Perhaps it appeals to women that are as vain, shallow, insecure, stupid, and/or wholly dependent on men to prop up their flagging self-images as the title character.  If Ms Raisin's life and values seemed realistic to the reader, then perhaps such a reader would find the character more sympathetic.  Perhaps (being average in most of these respects) I'm simply too young and too successful to appreciate a character that is convinced that she's a worthless old failure.  I don't recommend giving this book to anyone as a gift unless you want to say, "I think you're an aging, oversensitive failure, so perhaps you'd like reading about this other aging, oversensitive failure."Also, like old cult horror movies, I suspect that the series also appeals to people that can laugh at Ms Raisin's endless "sensibilities", instead of being disgusted by her apparently total lack of "sense", and who can therefore treat it as a bit of candy for the brain.  Unfortunately, I'm in the "disgusted by it" camp, and wish I hadn't read it.

I just don't relate to any of the reviews.  Did any of you read the same book that I did?  Specifically, did any of you read it any more recently than, say, when Dr Martin Luther King was assassinated?Practically every character is introduced with derogatory racial statements.  The author has painfully outdated attitudes against every single non-English person in the book.  I learned a new slur for southern Europeans while reading the second chapter (page 19, and throughout the book).  All Spanish sailors are sweepingly condemned as talkative, lazy, and incompetent.Of course, Europeans fare better than non-Europeans.  The people in Central America are all swarthy, dirty, and ragged.  Their loyalty and convictions are constantly suspect.  Nearly every person in the villain's service is disparaged as multiracial.  Not described -- disparaged.  The most fearsome and least sympathetic characters, such as the major domo, are those multiracial characters with some African blood.Speaking of Africans, Lady Barbara Wellesley announces within minutes of setting foot on the deck that she will have to lock up her black maid because otherwise the maid will unashamedly have sex with every possible man on the ship:  '"It is not on my account, Captain, that I need a key.  It is Hebe here whom I have to lock in unless she is directly under my eye.  She can no more keep from the men than a moth from the candle."  The little negress grinned widely at this speech, showing no resentment and a good deal of pride.' (page 110 -111).  Lady Barbara then explains that her method of keeping her maid in line is simply to beat her into submission -- just the kind of sweet lady you want for a story's love interest, right?I've read the entire Aubrey/Maturin series repeatedly.  Jack Aubrey would have had nothing but contempt for Hornblower.  He's a scrub with absolutely zero respect for the men under him.  The lower deck consists solely of men that can't do anything except wring their hands unless an officer tells them what to do.  (Yes, these would be the same men that are supposedly at risk for self-organizing a mutiny in the first pages of the book.)  He flogs twice a week.  He lies to and deliberately manipulates his junior officers.  He deliberately tortures them with unfelt displays of serene chat about playing cards when they would rather be preparing for battle because he thinks it might improve their opinion of his god-like infallibility.His first lieutenant is best characterized as the son who wants his father's approval -- and will never get it, because his father is a stuffed shirt.  Hornblower's hang up about talking to his staff results in withholding critical information.  The men under him are supposed to mindlessly obey his orders like automata, and nevermind that a little bit of fair warning would have saved at least one life.There are certain stupidities in the storyline, like the author's decision that Hornblower would be the sole person aboard that speaks any Spanish.  Nevermind that this is unbelievably unlikely in a collection of nearly 400 sailors that had spent so many years at war in and around the Mediterranean, and that lifelong sailors picked up a few words here and there of all sorts of languages.  The average sailor's speech might not amount to much more than "Woman" or "Beer", but speaking none at all is 'poetic license' at best.In the initial capture of the Natividad, the timing on the action is completely wrong.  The ship drops sails, closes a significant distance, fires a broadside, and lashes its yardarms to the Natividad -- in the length of time that it takes Hornblower to run from one end of his smallish frigate to the other; nevermind that in the very first pages of the book, just getting up the masts and setting (all) the sails takes 24 minutes, firing three broadsides in five minutes was considered a quite good rate back then, it takes a couple of minutes to lash spars together (especially when your opponent is trying to kill you at the time), more than a few seconds to get dozens of men up and down the masts so that you can do any of these things, and a fifty-yard dash (Hornblower was actually running less than that distance) is usually measured in mere seconds--as in, less than ten of them.  But somehow, the author thinks that Hornblower's running from the quarterdeck to the bow takes just as long as all of the above, which is absurd.There are things in this book that are well done -- they do exist, and for that, see all the other reviews -- but overall I cannot recommend it, and I hope that future readers will go into it with more awareness of its contents than I did.

There's no picture here on Amazon right now, but after a long discussion with Mr Google, I've determined that this is a "pancake turner"-type spatula, not a "mixing bowl"-type spatula.  It has a metal handle, and the business end is coated in clear-ish silicone.

After a long websearch (no thanks to Amazon for the embarrassingly incomplete description they're using at this moment), I determined that this contains:* Three kinds of salt:  salt, "Gourmet Salt" (whatever that is), and celery salt* Garlic powder* Black pepper* Cayenne pepperI approve of the garlic powder and the peppers.  But who needs that much salt, especially the celery salt?  This is like a lifetime supply of celery salt (in one container, and Amazon sends you FOUR of these in one box).  I think they should dump the celery salt in favor of garlic salt, lemon pepper, or Italian herbs.

I discovered Dreamfields when Trader Joe's discontinued their not-quite-as-good low-carb product about two years ago.  I like Dreamfields, and it's the closest "low carb" pasta to plain "high carb" pasta that I've ever encountered.  The picky eaters in my life have never turned up their noses at this.It's a bit pricier than the alternatives, but Amazon's current price is 12 cents less per (now 17% smaller!) box compared to my local grocery store, so I've just placed my first order here.Two things that might interest a person that hasn't ever tried it:* This is not a "low calorie" pasta.  The calorie count is almost identical to regular pasta.  If you're trying to lose weight, then you need to control your portion size, not just your carbohydrate intake.  However, I find that controlling the portion size is somehow easier with this pasta.* It seems to want a bit more water for boiling than regular pasta.  If you've perfected the art of boiling your pasta in the smallest possible pan, then this probably isn't going to work as well.  It seems to froth up and make a mess if I don't give it a more reasonable amount of water.

This is not what I expected.  Instead of an annual collection, this is a "treasury" of their favorite strips involving a specific character, Pierce.  Most of them are duplicated in older collections.  If you're fond of Pierce, then you might like this, but I was hoping for the next year's worth of regular strips.

I was so looking forward to the next regular installment of this comic strip (which the local newspaper unaccountably doesn't carry).  I was so disappointed to discover that despite looking for all the world like a regular, almost-square collection of last year's strips, it's actually a "treasury" of all the strips they've ever done about school.  Perhaps it might make a good gift for a teacher, but I think I'll be figuring out Amazon's return policy for the first time ever.

As a cookbook:This cookbook was originally produced around 1990 as a marketing/advertising opportunity.  I believe that you sent in proof of purchase from two Hershey's products and about $4 for shipping and handling to get it.  Because of this focus on promoting their products, the recipes don't call for "chocolate chips"; they specify "Hershey's brand semi-sweet chocolate morsels" or whatever the marketing-speak is for their particular brand's version of some normal ingredient.  My favorite is the one that specifies that you have to use mini chocolate chips -- even though you're going to melt them.  The book included a couple of coupons in the back for getting more copies of the cookbook as well as buying some of the ingredients.These are family-friendly, average-skill recipes.  There are a wide variety of desserts:  cakes, pies, cookies, candies, cheesecakes, and sauces, including some reduced-calorie desserts (but nothing using sugar substitutes like Equal or Splenda).  There are no exotic ingredients:  everything you need will be available at any grocery store.  Only a couple contain any alcoholic flavorings.  Any typical teenager could easily master all of the cooking techniques in the book.  It's a hardcover book but spiral-bound, which I think is the ideal arrangement for a cookbook, because it stands up nicely on the shelf with the other cookbooks, but lays perfectly flat when you're using it.  The cover wipes clean with a damp cloth, which is also a nice touch.As a book:Sometimes this cookbook lives on my kitchen shelf with the other cookbooks, and sometimes it's in the living room with the kids' books.  This cookbook and one very similar to it, on Eagle brand's sweetened condensed milk, have been very popular with younger kids as a book.  There's a photo for each recipe, and they love flipping through the cookbooks and talking about the pictures as much as they love looking at Dr Seuss books.  The kids look at the pictures of a given dessert and talk about what they think the ingredients are (It's pink, so could that be strawberry?  cherry?  raspberry?) and sometimes how they think it might taste or how it's made.  It's kind of a "coffee table book" for the preschool crowd -- something to look at in a quiet moment, or to use as a conversation starter.Some readers may be surprised to hear that talking about these recipes has never resulted in demands for sweets, but this has been my experience.  I have "read" this book dozens of times with at least five different preschool girls, and while we have talked about "maybe someday we'll make that and find out" or even made some of the treats, I have never encountered a demand for sweets as a result, or had a child claim to be hungry as a result.  Our track record is zero temper tantrums -- zero anything even close to "I WANT THIS NOW" demands.  That may be due to the kids' deep and abiding conviction that being rude to me has never, and will never, achieve their goals, but I think it actually has more to do with our interest in seeing what's on the next page.  Kids are interested in food, and there's a lot to discover in this little book if you're willing to sit down and look at each page in turn and ask a kid-sized question like, "Do you think this one is crunchy or creamy?" or "Does that look frozen to you?  Do you think it's supposed to be cold?"  Unless looking at pictures of desserts makes you desperate for something sweet, then I recommend it as a non-cookbook "just plain book" for the kids' bookshelf.

I got this to make a lazy Susan for my workshop.  I made my lazy Susan with a 24 inch diameter top and base and mounted three  bench grinders on it for my metal working area.  Now I can rotate from my grinding wheels through my polishing wheels  for knife and tool making.This bearing is quiet and smooth.  Also strong enough to handle much more weight than I am putting on it.  Does exactly what I wanted it to domat a very good price.Highly recommended for making your own lazy Susan.

This system worked great!  I just wired the transmitter to my existing wired doorbell and plugged the doorbell receiver into amwall outlet in our bedroom where it was difficukt to hear the main door bell.My existing doorbell didn't have enough room to out the transmitter inside,mso I just laid the transmitter on top.  Barely noticible.This worked somwell that I bought a second receiver to use downstairs in my art studio.When the wired doorbell rings, the Safety Technologies doorbell receivers sound a couple seconds later.  Very nice.

I had previously gotten the doorbell extender system by Safety Technilogies that has the transmitter and one wireless doorbell receiver.  It worked so well, that I ordered this second doorbell receiver to use downstairs in my art studio.  Nomwiring required to add this doorbell receiver.  Just plug it into a power outlet.This is just a single doorbell receiver.  You need the transmitter to go with it which is part of the Doorbell Extender System.

I like this little toaster oven!When I review a product, I review it based on how well it does what it is intended to do and its quality for the price.  Is it something I would buY again at this price?This toaster oven wins on all fronts.  It has simple analog controls which should last a long time.  I don't think of computerized controls when I think of a toaster oven.  The heating elements are quartz which also should hold up nicely.  There is an element on top and on on the bottom with a heat spreader over each of them for more even heating.  They also heat up pretty fast although I haven't done any timing measurements.The rack has a drip pan that slides onto the bottom for broiling although I am just leaving it in place all the time.  It could also be used as a baking tray.  The top element is only used for broiling and toasting and both are used for baking.The oven is 8 inches deep and 10 inches wide with about 3 1/2 inches over the rack when it is in the lower position.  The center over the oven bows out one inch to the back so that a 9 inch pizza will fit.  A TV dinner will ift nicely or several baked potatoes,or a casserole, or a small pan of biscuits.  About four slices of toast will fit as well.  Perfect if you are looking for a small toaster oven.  The thermostat is marked up to 450 degrees F but it will go higher if it is turned all the way up.I actually will not be doing much cooking in it.  I got it for my workshop and plan to use it for jobs like heat treating rocks for flint-knapping, or for tempering homemade steel knives and other tools after heat treating them.  I can temper to a hardness above 60 Rockwell.  I also make Kydex holsters and it will be perfect for heat molding them.  Not having to use the kitchen oven for these jobs will keep me out of trouble!!Seems to be a good toaster oven for anyone wanting a compact, lightweight unit!

My cable that came with my iPad is starting to fray next to the lightening connector, so I have been needing a new cable.  This Belkin cable is great!The first thing I noticed is that the cable is thicker than the One that came with the iPad,mso it should hold up MUCH better than my old cable.  Since this cable is 10 feet long,mthe wire gauge is probably larger, but the big difference seems to be the thickness of the insulation.  The insulation feels like it is tougher than the insulation on the original iPad cable which is softer when I press it with my fingernail.The 10 foot length is going to be very handy too.  I can use my iPad while it is charging more easily since I don't have to be so cloase to a power outlet.  For data transfer, I am not tied so closely to the computer.  If I don't need the full length, I just coil up the middle section of the cable.  The reason my old cable is fraying is because I use my iPad a lot while it is charging and tend to put more strain on it since it is so short.All in all,mI am very pleased with this cable!

This is presented as a lady's watch, but seems awfully big for most women.  I was going to give this to my wife, but it is too big for her.  However, it is a good size for me so I plan to wear it as my dress watch for church or going out.  I am 6'4" and 250 pounds and the watch face is the size that I normally wear.  There is nothing in the design that makes this watch look feminine, so it will work great as a man's watch.The gold plated finish on the watch and band looks great!  As delivered, there is a plastic film covering the face and band for protection, so Invicta has paid attention to the details.  A very attractive watch!As can be seen in the photos, the watch has three sub-dials and three control buttons like the Invicta chronographs, but there is no chronograph function.  Instead the three dials are for day of the week, date, and 24hour indicator.  They are rather small and hard to read, so their usefulness is somewhat limited for my old eyes!  They do make a nice decorative touch though.  The dial hands, though, are very easy to read, so it is very well suited to its primary function.A very beautiful watch at a good price!  Not just for the ladies, though!  Men shouldmdefinitely consider this watch.  I will definitely be wearing it!

I really like this little recorder for voice recording!  I used to use one of the similar sized recorders that recorded on the little magnetic tape cassettes and found it hard to keep up with the cassettes plus the voice quality was not all that good.  This recorder is completely different.  Good voice quality and plenty of storage time.There are lots of available setting options that could get confusing.  There is a simplified mode that would be helpful to avoid all these options.There are tow microphones to give you true stereo sound and noise reduction.  Recording a lecture or sermon and then playing it back using headphones sounds like you are back in the room!  Very nice audio!  Recording live music isn't as good.  The high and low frequencies seem to be clipped so it is best for voice recording.It accepts up to a 32 gig SD card for more storage capacity than you will ever need!  There are folders for different categories of recordings, but I could only find five preset folders.  It would be nice to have a way to add more folders.  This might be possible but I couldn't find it.The User Manual is not very good.  It gices the minimum amount of information needed, so most of the features and ways to use it have to be discovered by trial and error.  Fortunately, using it as a basic voice recorder is fairly straightforward.  At least it isn't one of those manuals that assumes nobody can read and that only uses pictures.I dropped off one star for the absence of user instructions.  Otherwise,it is a pretty good voice recorder!

I have never used artificial tanners before, so have no way to compare this product to others.  I have tanned in the sun in the past and have used tanning beds. This product gives a pretty good tan.  I have had a skin cancern taken of my nose so I now avoid the sun as much as possible which means this is about my only choice for getting a tan.Applying it with the tanning mitt (separate purchase) was pretty easy. I just had to make sure I had good coverage.  Doesn't take much and I went over each area two or three times to make sure I didn't miss any spots.  My wife applied it to my back.  The color in the gel goes away pretty quickly so you can't use that to judge how well you have applied it.  I just had to concentrate and be careful.I lift it on two hours and got a reasonable tan.  Not too dark and not too light.  Seemed to be a fairly natural color.Seems a bit expensive to me.  Of course, not as expensive as having a skin cancer removed.  I normally wear a t-shirt and shorts so I will probably use it in the future on just those sking areas that are exposed. I rarely swim any more, so don't really need it for that.All in all a good experience.  Just a bot on the expensive side.

Anyone interested in our nation's beginnings and the man who was essential to its successful start will thoroughly enjoy this book.  It reads like a well written history book which I greatly appreciated.  I was concerned that it might be more aponna historical novel, with doses of imaginatively "filling in the blank".  The author's sources are all carefully documented and are put together in a very enjoyable way.  The book not only presents an interesting story, it would make an excellent reference itself for further research.Martha and George were a good match for each other.  Martha's strength and charm were a perfect complement to George's talents and were perfect during and after the Revolutionary War.  One fact that the book points out is that Martha gave George a great deal of his stability and confidence.  She visited him frequently in the fueld during the war and he always cheered up when she was around.  Thus was not only a oerfect political partnership, it was also evident that they deeply loved each other.This book give a fascinating insight into George and Martha and their influence on the beginnings of our nation.

Like many customers, I have been trying to figure out how to lower my Comcast Xfinity costs.  They just keep in going up!I had already replaced my rented cable modem, using it with a separate wireless router.  So that saved $10 a month, but I kept feeling I coukd do better.  Then Amazon offered this combination modem/wireless router.  It does what I hoped it would do.  Simplified my setup and improved my performance.When I installed my previous cable modem, it was a pain trying to get it done through Comcast.  This one self installed easily using their online instructions.  Whatever provider you use, I would suggest going to their web site to search for cable modem installation instructions.  All I had to do was to plug the AC1750 into power and the czble connector.  I then used an ethernet cable to connect a laptop computer to the modem/router, opened a browser and went to the setup page on Comcast's website.  It installed easily.Connecting my other devices to the router was also easy.  I just followed the ac1750 instructions.For performance, Imwant to do more testing at different times of the day, but so far it looks like I have speeded up my overall performance.  One problem I have with testing is that most of my neighbors akso use Comcast, and when they all jump on and start streaming, overall performance goes down because there isnonly one pipeline into the neighborhood.  So, I need to separate the Comcast speed from the modem/router speed.My signal strength is about the same through the house as my old setup.All things considered, I am pleased with this combo device.  Getting rid on one device plus not having to pay Comcast rest is well worth it!

Update:  well, i was wrong.  We've been trying to use this feeder and have given up.  Both sections of this feeder are leaking and i can't figure out what to do to stop it.  I reduced my rating from five stars to two stars.  It could be used where the leaks don't matter but we can't use it.This is a very creating feeder design.  Very attractive.The feeder sections come apart easily for cleaning and filling.  The two sections are totally separate and can be snapped apart to make two feeders or left together for a double feeder.  Refilling the two sections is easy and the two clear containers just unscrew for cleaning and filling.The white flowers with a yellow bee guard in the center are very attractive.  The perch is the stem of the flower.  Ours arrived with one of the perches broken off, but the hummingbirds just hover at that station, so it isn't hurting anything.Make your own nectar.  It's much less expensive.  On cup sugar to four cups of water, bold for two minutes, cool and refrigerate.  The hummingbirds LOVE cold nectar.Refill every two to three days, and keep the feeder scrupulously clean to attract and keep your hummingbirds.We get about 200 hummingbirds a day at our feeders in late August and September, so we expect all eight feeding stations to be well used!  During that season, we hand as many feeders as we can.  This one will be right outside our window so we can watch the hummingbirds fight over it!

Very good hummingbird feeder.  A hanging hook is included.  Easy to fill.  Large 30 ounce capacity.The bottom tray comes apart easily for thorough cleaning which is VERY important for attracting and keeping hummingbirds coming to the feeder.  The bee guards work pretty well, but you will still get a few bees.  I don't think it's possible to completely stop them from trying to get the the nectar.The only negative I see is that the built in ant guard isn't deep enough to work well.  Water will evaporate pretty fast, so we will use a separate ant guard.  An ant guard is a necessary addition to a hummingbird feeder.When you use this, make your own nectar.  The red stuff sold in the stores and online is expensive and many people have concerns about the red dye in it possibly harming the hummingbirds.  Easy to make.  One part sugar to four parts water.  Boil the mix for 2 minutes and let it thoroughly cool.  Keep it in the refrigerator.  In addition to it keeping longer without spoiling and a side benefit is that the hummingbirds LOVE cold nectar!  Change the nectar in the feeder every 2 or 3 days and keep the feeder very clean.In late August and September is the hummingbird migration to Central and South America.  During that season, we will have over 200 hummingbirds a day at our feeders.  So we put out as many feeders as we can and go through LOTS of sugar.  We have friends who come to our yard just to watch the hummingbird swarms.  This is our go-to feeder design.

I agee with the other very good reviews on this hammer.  It is quite a good mid-range hammer. The magnet for starting nails is a nice feature, and the fiberglass handle is tough and lightweight.  Of course, if it is abused, any handle wil eventually break.The weight of the hammer is mostly in the head which gives you a nice, powerful blow.  Because the weight is in the head, it feels decidedly "head-heavy" which can be considered either good or bad.  A prolonged session of hammering will tire your wrist out faster than a more balanced hammer will.  On the other hand, it drives a bit faster, and if you use it enough, it will strengthen your wrist.  Not necessarily a bad thing, but at my age (almost 69), it feels a bit heavy for me.  Many carpenters and framers prefer a head-heavy hammer, and a lot of them use a 20 ounce hammer with no problem.  So, just keep this point in mind.I've never used a magnetic nail set and was a bit skeptical that I could position the nail accurately enough.  However, with a bit of practice, I could position the nail and then get it started pretty accurately.  If you have to hold your board in position with your other hand, this allows for one handed hammering.  As someone else mentioned, you can also use the magnet to pick up nails, so that can be handy.  I'll probably continue to position the nail with my left hand and drive it with my right most of the time.The fiberglass handle plus the rubber coating does seem to reduce shock and vibrations as opposed to a wood handled hammer.  The rubber coating also provides a secure grip, especially when you start sweating!  Also prevents blisters, or at least reduces them.All in all, a very good mid-range hammer.  Many pros will like it!  The only hammer brand that I consider to be better is the Estwing line, but they are also more expensive.  A 16 ounce Estwing claw hammer is about 50% more expensive, but is more rugged and better balanced for me.  However, I'll probably use the TEKTON for hard nailing and the Estwing for the rest.

As soon as I received this, I took it to try shop to try it out.  Works great!  It make a very portable vacuum for small jobs in the shop or for tasks like vacuuming out the car.  The suction is about the same as an upright home vacuum cleaner, so it seems strong enough.The head had a couple of tabbed clips on each side for snapping it onto a 5 gallon bucket.  A very nice feature of these clips is that they have notches for the bucket handle.  I just snapped the head onto the bucket and pulled the handle up and it snapped into place.  Since the entire assembly is so lightweight, it is very easy to carry around the house.As is usually the case with shop vacuums, it has a vacuum port and an outlet port that the hose can plug into for blowing sawdust and sauce off of a work surface.  Also has a wet and a dry vacuuming capability.  The filter bag is removed for wet vacuuming and it has a float valve that blocks of the vacuum port if the bucket fills with liquid.  This protects the motor.No wheels, but they are not needed since the assembly is so light.  One other reviewer didn't like the 6 foot cord, preferring a longer one, but I like the length as it is.  If I need a longer cord, I have plenty of extension cords.The only complaint I have about it is that there are no attachments.  At this selling price listed, I would like to see some attachments.  However, I did find that since the hose is the same diameter as on an old upright vacuum (1 1/4 inch OD), the attachments from the upright will fit.  An attachment I would really like to have, though, is a long extension tube so that I can reach the floor while I am carrying the vacuum around.  I'll have to find something that will work for that.  Maybe some thin wall pvc.My planned use for this as as a dedicated vacuum for my band saws.  I plan to mount it under the base of my bandsaws and will set it up to come on whenever I start my bandsaws.  Should be perfect for that.

This seems to be a well made smoker cover, but is a bit tight on my Weber Smokey Mountain smoker.  So far, it seems to provide good protection but I would prefer something that is easier to get on and off.I like the vents in it to help keep condensation from building up.  I don't use the elastic bands over the legs because I don't think it will blow off.The only remaining question is how log will it last in the Georgia sun.  My other covers have only lasted about two or three years and then the sun begins to crack the material.  This material looks similar, so I suspect it will be the same.  However, for the price, I can afford to buy one every two or three years!Overall, a good cover.

This cookbook is written specifically for Weber Smoky Mountain smoker owners, but it also has excellent recipes for use in other smokers.  So anyone with a decent smoker can benefit from having it.What is unique about this book is that it gives specific instructions for using the WSM as a smoker, an oven, a grill, at high temperatures and at low temperatures.  It describes the Minoin method for making a long lasting smoking fire.  I have used this method for a 14 hour smoke without having to add any more charcoal and the WSM held a very steady temperature.  The WSM and this cookbook are the perfect combination for outstanding smoke cooking!The book starts out with recipes for making competition worthy BBQ and then goes on to include a wonderful variety of recipes for side dishes, and even desserts.I am a dedicated Weber user with A WSM, a Genesis gas grill, and a Weber Kettle grill.  This cookbook is now one of my favorites!I have also used quite a few other smokers and grills including the Big Green Egg and have made my own custom smokers and modified others.  This cookbook could be used with all of them with good results as long as you have a good working knowledge of how to use your particular cooker.  This cookbook gives instructions specific to the WSM, but they can easily be adapted to any of the others.

I bought two pairs of these glasses.  One is the smoke color with mirrored lenses and the other is the amber color.  Both are great!  Exactly what I needed.The Amber glasses were bought to help with night driving.  My eyes have always been light sensitive and over the last couple of years, the headlights from oncoming cars made it impossible for me to drive at night.  The lights were painful, especially those new bright blue/white headlights!  The Amber glasses cut out most of the blue wavelengths and make driving into headlights tolerable!  Those blue/white extra brights are cut down even more tan regular light because a high proportion of the wavelengths of those lights are apparently in the bluish region.The smoke glasses are for daytime use and work great.  Driving in the bright sun is no longer painful!These glasses are wrap around so you can pick up motion to the sides and they also block off light from overhead.  They look stylish...not St all like the old, clunky, fit over glasses look.  Very attractive!The lenses have no distortion that I can detect and are very comfortable to wear for extended periods.

When I saw that this has no MSG I had to give it a try!  MSG give me a roaring headache, frequently before the end of the meal!As other reviewers have noted, it isn't quite as good as homemade, but awfully close!  And it saves a lot of time.  Here are a couple of ways to use it that are delicious!Chicken and rice or any other *** and rice dish.  We use mostly white rice mixing the appropriate amount of water and rice and cooked chicken (usually a rotisserie chicken from the grocery store), taking it to a boil, add the correct amount of Chicken Base, stir it quickly and cover and simmer for about 25 minutes.Flour gravy (roux, chicken gravy, white gravy, sauge gravy, etc). Any gravy that calls for oil, flour and water.  You just brown the flour in the oil (fat, drippings, grease, etc) and then add the appropriate amount of chicken stock made from this base.For soups,me like to mix at least two meats.  Our preference is ham and turkey and you can add a roasted chicken flavor by using this base in the soup water and just add your meats and veggies.As I say, nothing beats making a stock from scratch, but this is a close second.One other point...this base is pretty salty if you use too much.  If you try to increase the chicken flavor by adding more, it will likely end up being too salty.  Better to add cooked chicken and stick to the recommended amount!

Trees and shrubs need fertilizing too!  Most of us don't take the time or don't think about it though.  We pamper our flowers and vegetables as well as our lawns, but tend to neglect the trees and shrubs.These fertilizer spikes are very easy to use and since they are made by Miracle Grow, we have confidence that they will work.  Now is when we are getting everything ready for the growing season, so these arrived at a good time!  We are in Georgia, so here in mid-March, Spring has Sprung!There are 12 spikes in the package and only one is needed for trees and shrubs with up to a 4 foot diameter drip line.  There are two plastic caps in the package to put on the spikes for driving them into the ground.  It's good to have the extra one for hard spots in the ground, although we have had a good deal of rain lately, so one was all we needed since the ground is soft right now.  We just drove them in about two feet from the trunks and seated them about two inches below the ground surface.Easy to use and we are confident they will help our trees and shrubs to do their best this growing season!

I think this is going to become my favorite cookbook!  It actually gives you far more than the title promises!And, these recipes and instructions are written for the Big Green Egg and other ceramic cookers, BUT they can be adapted to any smoker or grill that has reasonably good temperature control.The title is "Smoke It Like a Pro", but it has instructions for using the cooker for smoking, grilling, baking, roasting,,and even frying.  There are recipes here for all kinds of meats and fish, and also for vegetables, breads, and desserts.  What's more,mother author has used these recipes in competitions and has won many of them!  He is also a Certified Judge, so he knows what the judges are looking for.A couple of recipes from this book than I plan to try soon include one for making my own pastrami from scratch, another for creme brulee that the author got a perfect score for in competition, and his Championshiip Coffee-Encrusted Lamb Chops!Of course, he also include some fantastic recipes for the traditional smoked fare like baby back ribs, brisket, and Boston butt.Anyone who likes to cook over charcoal will thoroughly enjoy this book!

The initial bitter taste that others have mentioned is too much for me.  It does go away pretty quickly, especially when I eat something afterward, but I can't handle it!  Sorry.I love garlic, especially baked or pickled, and usually don't mind the garlic taste or smell.  I also am an "adventurous" eater and will try just about anything and enjoy almost everything.occasionally, though I run into something I can't handle.  Limburger cheese is one that I can't even get close to even though I like other cheeses like a strong bleu cheese.  To me, the Allivictus Garlic is to regular garlic like Limburger cheese is to strong bleu cheese!I'm grateful that the taste went away pretty quickly!The recommended dosage is 3 or 4 sprays, 5 or 6 times a day.  I couldn't do that!  In addition, taking it that often means that the small bottle won't last long.  One reviewer said about a week, but since I can't use it, I can't verify that.It's a great idea, and quite a few reviewers like it and gave it positive reviews.  It's just not for me!  Maybe you will do better with it than I did!

This little device works so well, I have now bought two of them for different locations.  This is now my go-to range extender!The first one I bought was for my art association (Paulding Fine Arts Association in Dallas, Georgia). Our gallery and studios is in a 100 year old courthouse building and we were unable to get a decent wifi signal over the entire area.  I had installed a very good wireless router, but still didn't have a strong enough signal, so I decided to try a range extender.  This one was a perfect solution!Because the courthouse was built a century before the Internet and wi-fi, there was no way to install a wired repeater.  I neded something that received the wifi signal and simply rebroadcast it.Installation was very intuitive using the built in touch screen.  There is even a built in stylus for typing in passwords! I simply plugged in power, and selected the range extender option and made my selections as they came up.  It was as easy as logging into a new wireless network on an iPad.The re-broadcast network name is simply the original network name with "- Almond" added to it.  Of course, you can change the network name and either use the same or a different "password".This installation was so successful, I decide to out one in my home to boost the wifi signal there.  I had first tried installing a Linksys router with an external antenna array thinking that better antennas would give me more range.  Didn't boost the signal as much as I needed, so I got one of these Almond devices.  Installation this time took about a minute!Needless to say, I am very pleased with these devices, and will recommend it with no reservations.  I have only used it as a range extender, but it also can be used as a wireless router.  I'll try one as a router next!

I struggled with deciding how to rate this product.  I finally decided to rate it based on overall quality and on how well it does what it claims to do.Essentially, it is a combined extension handle and battery pack  for the GoPro.  The only drawback I can see is a GoPro problem, not a fault of this extension pole.  This drawback is the fact that the GoPro camera has no way to plug in a charger without compromising its weather resistance.  Polar Pro makes it VERY clear in their description that this is the case.  GoPro has an open back for thieir case that alllows a charger to be plugged in, which is exactly what Polar Pro recommends.The handle is very high quality and rugged.  Well built and has seals for protection from light rain or snow.  Five stars for handle qualiity and ruggedness.The battery has a capacity equivalent to 4.5 GoPro batteries, so if the battery in the GoPro is fully charged, total capacity is 5.5 times the normal battery life.  It is easy to turn the battery pack on and off and the charging port for the battery pack is convenient and has a sealed cover.  Ther are also three blue LEDs that indicate how much charge is left.  For powering the GoPro, there are two full sized USB ports just below the camera mount and the Power Pro comes with two USB cables, one short and one longer.  This allows the battery pack to recharge any two devices that charge from a USB port.  So, for design, packaging, control and use of the battery pack, I give five stars.The camera mount is designed for the GoPro, but there are numerous mounting accessories available that will work with it, so it will work with any mounts or devices that are GoPro compatible.  I can think of numerous attachments that would be useful and that would extend the usefulness of this handle/battery pack, so most likely they are available.So, I see no reason to lower my rating for problems that center around the GoPro system and are not part of this products design.A good, well mde and designed product that delivers on exactly what it promises.

I have several camping hammocks and also several that I bought in Mexico and South America.  One of these in a Hennesey Hammock which was rather expensive.In my opinion, the Eagle's Nest Outfitters hammock system is the best out there for strength, durability, and comfort.  What I like the most is that I was able to buy the components of a camping shelter system one at a time.  I now have a single nest, a double nest, a rain tarp, a mosquito net and hanging straps.
