Everything I need!This review is on the double nest.  The reason I got it is because the extra width enables me to lie on a diagonal so that I am lying flat.  Very comfortable!This system is an excellent compromise between weight and load capacity.  I am 6' 4" and weigh 250#, so the ultralight stuff is not strong enough for me.

What a fun book!  I thoroughly enjoyed this book and the idea behind it and recommend it highly for anyone who enjoys travel.When I was in high school, I read John Steinbeck's book "Travels with Charlie".  This was an account of Steinbeck's travels around the United States in a pickup camper with his dog, Charlie.  I loved that book, and wide Open World is the same sort of story and just as enjoyable.Wide Open World is the true story of the adventures of a family that travels literally around the world on the adventure of a lifetime.  Most of us would love to do the same if it weren't for the time and expense required.  The idea that the Marshall's had that made the trip possible is "volunteerism".  They still had to take the time off, but were able to eliminate most of the cost of food and hotels by finding several organizations that exchanged room and board for their help with the organizations, or at least provided them very inexpensively.  The Marshall's still had to cover their airfare, but they saved a fortune in hotel and restaurant expenses.  And had some marvelous adventures at the same time.Of course, all of their adventures weren't good. Monkey bites, a wildlife "sanctuary" the turned out to not be as advertised were a couple of less than stellar experiences, but that comes with world travel.The worst thing that happened to them was that the tenant who rented their house while they were gone ended up trashing it.  Based on personal experience, I would recommend that anyone considering a trip like this should  use a property management company to rent their house.  It's worth it!Not only does the idea of this sort of travel appeal to me, the idea of "volunteerism" also is very appealing.  As more and more of us retire so that our living expenses are covered, there are many organizations that could use volunteer help. For those who want to travel, there are mission trips that need volunteers, and there are cultural exchange programs that offer great opportunities.In short, this book fed my love of travel and my interest in providing volunteer help with some great stories along the way.  The Marshall's travelled with their teenage children, but as more and more of us retire while we are still vigorous, this would be an interesting way to travel.

To my taste, this espresso coffee is quite bitter.  I like an intense, strong coffee flavor, but don't like the burnt flavor of Starbuck's espresso or the bitter taste of the Aldecoa Intense.  To be very clear, though, I like my espresso neat with no sugar or cream or other flavorings.  I think that the bitterness of this coffee like the Starbuck's burnt taster would probably go well in a latte or cappuccino where the sweetness and crime would balance out the bitterness.The other thing I don't like is that in each box, all 10 capsules are sealed together in one aluminum coated bag.  So, once it is opened, the coffee will start losing flavor, although I think that the fact that each capsule is plastic will at least slow that down some.  We'll see.The coffee produced a fairly nice crema, although I don't think it was quite as thick a layer as the Nespresso brand.  Not enough difference to be important, though.  It is still enough to be desirable.The cost of 63 cents per capsule makes it a little less that the Nespresso capsules, but not by much.  I just looked on the Nespresso web site and most of their flavors are 70 cents.  All but one of the Intenso blends are 70 cents and only one is 75 cents.  These would be the ones that are in the same intensity range as the Aldecoa.  I only saw one special blend that was 80 cents.To me, the flavors of the Nespresso blends are more complex and satisfying and well worth an additional 7 cents per cup.  I have tried most of the Nespresso blends and prefer all of them to the Aldecoa.In the interest of full disclosure, I have been a fan of Nespresso since before it was possible to buy their machines in the USA.  I use to get it whenever I traveled to Europe on business.  I have also visited the Nestle offices in Switzerland and have also visited several of their coffee bean suppliers in Central and South America where I sold them laboratory equipment that Nestle required them to use for their quality assurance testing.  So I know first hand how demanding they are with their suppliers.  Interestingly, the coffee suppliers provide coffee to many different bends and each brand has their own roasting and other processing requirements.  Nestle's were among the most rigorous.Even so, I would have been pleased to find another coffee brand that I could use in my Nespresso Essenza machine, but this one is not quite to my taste.

I like this tea a lot.  Good blend of black tea and spices.  I notice that some reviewers prefer to add spice to their taste, but I like this as is.  I tend to drink tea with no sugar or cream, and that is how I like this one.It is a loose tea rather than tea bags.  The tea leaves are cut more coarsely that the tea in bags which I like.  I lost my tea ball somewhere, so until I get around to buying another, I am just using a square of paper towel with the corners twisted and tied.  Works fine.Good tea!

This book has a useful premise that could be explained in far fewer words.  It feel like the author was struggling to expand this into book length.  One statements he makes over and over, but doesn't substantiate is that "cheap experiments are worth more than ideas".  To me, without having an idea, your have nothing to experiment with!In summary, what the author seems to be saying is that any business idea should be validated via a small scale, inexpensive experiment.  An example he gives is the Amazon.com recommendations based on purchases.  One of the software engineers put together the code and they ran a limited test to see how it would be received.  The point is, they didn't just roll it out to everyone, they did a small "experiment" first.This would seem to be an obvious concept, but many managers seem to come up with an business idea that sounds good and then just implement it fully and hope it works.  So, Schrage has a valid point.... Do an inexpensive test before doing a full scale implementation.The useful portions of the book are the examples he gives of small scale experiments that companies ran to test out an "idea".  If you are not sure how to frame an experiment, these chapters are helpful.So, the premise of the book is a good one and the examples of some typical experiments are helpful.  Instead of a book, this information could be presented in an extended article.  The difficulty is that wading through so many words to pick out a few good points will cause most readers to give up on the book.

Very impressive sound quality!  I am actually using this system to replace a set of Bose speakers in a component home entertainment system, and the sound is more clear and natural than the sound I was getting with the Bose system.  I also replaced the receiver/amplifier that I had since the Klipsch has its own built in amplifier.  So, I simplified my setup and got better sound.I am using this with a Vizio 47 inch flat screen TV, and since it has several selectable sources, I can run my other components through the TV instead of the receiver/amplifier I had in my setup.  I am using the optical audio output form the TV and have not tried the RCA analog inputs to the speakers.The sound is well balanced across the frequency range, but since the subwoofer has a volume control, the low end can be adjusted to your preference.  I see no need for a treble or bass adjustment.Setup was dead simple.  Plug in power to the soundbar and the subwoofer and connect the optical fiber cable between the TV and the soundbar.  None of the rats nest of audio cables that I had with my old Bose setup!  I now have a simpler, cleaner, better sounding sound system.This is my first experience with Klipsch and I am very impressed!  I never expected to prefer the Klipsch system over my Bose system.Update:  Just tried to connect via Bluetooth from my iPad.  Worked great!  I found instructions in the Manual or doing this. (actually pictograph instructions... no one seems to actually use words any more!)  I know that the system used Bluetooth between the sound bar and the sub woofer, but did not know that you could connect to the entire system via Bluetooth.So, there are three ways to connect... via optical cable, via RCA analog, and via Bluetooth.Note to Amazon:  The description on this product's page just calls it a "Soundbar"  Doesn't mention the Sub-woofer.  Some customers might be confused by this and not consider this product.

This humidifier is very quiet and compact.  It is easy to fill and as the description says, it takes about a day to run out of water.There is a control knob to set how fast it generates the water vapor.  We keep it set at about 60% or 70%.  We haven't measured the capacity, but it appears to be a little under one gallon.  As the description says, it is ideal for a small room.  Or, if you have a sore throat or allergies, you can set it to direct the vapor to your face.It is very quiet and we have not had any problems with noise or defective fans.  Seems to be working quiet well.This is the first filter less humidifier we have had.  Our others are larger and have a filter element in them and are a bit of a hassle to keep clean.  In addition to providing humidity, we use the older ones to generate white noise to help us sleep.  This is because the older ones are quite noisy, which is an advantage for us.Quiet, clean, and easy to use!

These are really good!The cucumber bread and butter style pickles are crispy/crunchy with a good mix of sweet and sour with just a bit of spicy hot.  Just enough to let you know it's there!  Delicious!  I just had a peanut butter and crispy pickle sandwich and it was great.  For a fan of bread and butter style pickles, these are great.  Nice and crispy!The jalapeño pickles have the same perfect mix of sweet and sour, but are only sliced jalapeño peppers, so they have a great hot spicyness.  Hotter than the cucumber pickles and delicious!My favorite is the crispy jalapeños, but then I am a certified chili-head!  Not unbearably hot, just enough to give a kick!Both are super!

This is a book that everyone in  the USA and Europe needs to read and understand.  Our media provides very little information on the extreme persecution of Christians thAt is going on in many parts of the world! and this persecution seems to be on the increase.  Christians in the USA in particular think that we are being "persecuted", but what we are seeing her is merely disrespect and discrimination.  Real persecution is going on around the world at an alarming rate.Rupert Shortt's definition of Christianity is quite broad and includes all faiths that identify themselves as "Christian"..  So Catholocism, the Eastwrn Orthodox Church, and the various Protestants are all included.  Essentially, anyone who has the faith and courage to stand up an be counted as Christian.While much of the persecution of Christians is initiated by Muslims, Shortt points out that there are other sources, including governmental persecution.  According to Shortt, more Christians are currently living under threat the. Any other religion.The book is organized with separate chapters on each country that he is examining.  Included countries are Egypt, Iraq, Iran, Pakistan,Turkey, Nigeria, Indonesia, India, Burma, China, Vietnam and North Korea, The Holy Land, and a chapter on the six countries Cuba, Venezuela, Belarus, Sri Lanka, Laos,, and Sudan.The reason this book is so important, is that, as the author points out, "...freedom of belief is the canary in the coal mine for freedom in general."  As the disrespect and discrimination toward Christians in the West increases, everyone will experience a corresponding decline in general freedom.

I am an artist and woodworker who is recently retired.  This means that I have time to paint more, but also means that I have to come up with a lot more frames.  The price of custom frams is outrageous and even buying ready made frames gets expensive.So... I have been looking for ideas on making my own frame moulding and using it to frame my paintings.  This book is exactly what I needed!It has information on making all types of frames for all types of paintings and photographs.  Making mats, cutting glass, cutting and assembling the frames using either pre-made moldings, or your own home-made mouldings.  On the pre-made mouldings, it even has suggestions for construction moulding profiles that can be used, so you don't need to buy expensive picture fram mouldings.  It even has instruction on finishing techniques.Most of this information is available in other books.  What I was have a hard time finding was a book with ideas for making your own moulding shapes using various router bits.  This books has LOTS of profiles for you to make.Some of the reviews say that the information in the book is "dated".  I totally disagree.  Also, the black and white photos have been criticized, but I see no loss of information due to the lack of color.  The only dated information is that a radial arm saw is shown, and these have been replaced by chop saws.  Also the photo of a chop saw in the book is of an old design.  Other than that, I see nothing that i would  classify as "dated".In my opinion, the chapter on making your own mouldings is worth the price of the book.

"The Road to Recovery" is a call for debate among economists and policy makers into the current state of the world economy and the causes of the problems we are seeing.  The author, Andrew Smithers, presents a very thoughtful and detailed analysis, backed up by extensive data, into the economy and it's problems.  The data is presented in the form of numerous charts (126 charts) with many of them in color.  The reader who is so inclined can, with some effort, verify the author's conclusions based on data and not simply conjecture.The author points out that while the causes of the current sluggishness of the world economy may be simply stared, correcting them will be quite difficult due to the fact that "the political understanding is generally lacking".  There must be a "willingness to debate the issues  and consider the evidence" in order to implement effective solutions.One concern that I have is that too much attention will be focused on the author's assertion that the current "bonus culture" of executive compensation as the primary cause of our economic problems and as a result, not enough attention will be placed on the deficiencies of current economic theory and fiscal policy, which are equally in need of fundamental change.  The problems are deeply pervasive, and solutions will require fundamental economic changes.  In addition, there are different causes in different economies that will have to be taken into consideration.Regarding the "bonus culture", the author's contention is that because bonuses now can far exceed salaries, corporate executives are now making decisions designed to maximize their bonuses, leading to a focus on short term results.  This is resulting in decisions that are negatively impacting the overall economy.  This assertion is impressively supported by data.Other important conclusions presented include the current excessive corporate and governmental debt levels, poor economic theory, the lack of recognition that current problems are structural rather than cyclical, and the general lack of political understanding to properly address the issues.The author states that he fears that unless effective change is implemented, we will either continue to have sluggish growth, or we will suffer another, deeper economic crisis.  My experience is that the more fundamental the required change is, the stronger the motivation to change has to be.  Perhaps the needed changes will come without a major crisis, but I am doubtful.For the reader who needs to gain an overview of the book before digging into its contents more deeply, I would suggest first reading chapter 2 - Why the Recovery Has been So Weak, chapter 5 - Cyclical,or Structural: The Key Issue for Policy, chapter 14 - Tackling the Bonus Culture, chapter 15- The Need for Change in Economic Theory and the Resistance to It, and chapter 16 - Summary and Conclusion.While this book is not for the "casual" reader, it is quite accessible, and deserves a very wide audience.  The information and conclusions are very important, but at the same time, they will upset the "status quo" so that there will be resistance to making the required change.  A wide audience pressing for change will hopefully keep the message of this book from being ignored.

Two flavors I love are sardines in olive oil and anything spicy hot!  These sardines combine the two very nicely.  I do not like most of the other flavors, such as mustard, etc.  sardines in olive oil are the best to me.My preference is to eat sardines with saltine crackers., so that is how I tested these.The tin has a pull tab opening and the King Oscar tab worked perfectly.  I have had the abs on some of the cheap brands to break off.  These work as they are supposed to.When I opened the tin, there were four of five slices of jalapeño on top of the sardines.  The heat from the sardines had infused through the oil.  The peppers are softened through the packing process and there is no vinegar taste leading me to believe that the peppers are placed fresh.I am not a good one to judge heat valves for others since I am pretty much a "pepper head".  To me, the heat level is just below medium, which would be about right for most  people who like spicy hot.  A little hotter than the typical salsa in a Mexican restaurant.Since capsaicin dissolves in oil, the olive oil seems to serve as a carrier of the heat as well as a soother of the heat.  This means that the heat is not too long lasting.  So, if it is a bit too hot for you, it won't last long.I will definitely be buying these if I can find them!  I love this combination!

I'm very pleased with this ring binder.  It would be better if it were cloth covered, but for a vinyl covered notebook, it has some great features. There are four overlapping pockets on the front and back cover.  I'm not sure this this is more useful than just one on each cover, but maybe...The covers also have pockets on the outside and spine, which can be used for a title sheet to know what the subject of the notebook is.  Haven't tried it yet, but ink from copiers or printers will probably stick to the inside of the pockets.  At lease it does on all the other vinyl notebooks I have used.  However this is a fairly minor issue.The best feature on this notebook is the rings.  They are "D" rings so you can fill it and open it without the sheets separating.  They stay nice and neatly stacked.  The rings are also mounted on the back cover instead of the spine.  This also helps when you open the notebook.  This is the best ring arrangement, in my opinion.The rings are also listed as "never gap", so they are not supposed to gap partially open over time.  Can't tell yet how well this works, but on receipt, they are all closed perfectly.The nicest feature is the single lever for opening and closing the rings.  It is located at the bottom and works very smoothly.  Very convenient to open and close.  Very nice when combined with the D rings.  With standard notebook rings, I usually end up opening and closing the notebook using the middle ring, so the sing lever is very convenient.The cover claims that the notebook will last ten times longer.  Ordinary notebooks hold up pretty well, so it will take a long time to evaluate this claim!All in all a very nice notebook.  I am in a Dixieland band (clarinet and tenor sax) and will be keeping my music in this notebook, so it will see a lot of use.

I am very impressed with the book!  I have a number of book on archery and how to improve your performance, but this is the best I've read.  My other book are accurate and correct in what they teach, but this one is much more comprehensive.I am a "primitive" bow maker and archer, making my own straight-limbed, longbows from either boards or bow staves split from trees.  I have not made any recurves yet, but will try them soon!  One word of warning to other "primitive" archers is that the authors are prejudiced toward "modern" bows and materials, and do not think very highly of traditional wooden bows and arrows, which I VERY strongly prefer!  That should not dissuade the primitive archer at all, though, because if the instruction in this book is followed carefully, it will most definitely improve your performance!The sub-title of the book is "Steps to Success" and that describes the approach of the book very well.  It covers the details of archery in a very step by step manner from selecting your equipment to setting it up properly, and how to shoot with proper form.Details on shooting straight limb, re-curve, and compound bow is covered equally well, even though the emphasis is on target shooting, which is most often done with re-curve bows.  No matter what type of bow you select, this book will help tremendously to improve our shooting.  There is a chapter that discusses the differences between target shooting and hunting very well, so every type of archery is well covered.  Of course, if you are hunting, it doesn't cover how to find your quarry, just how to hit it when you DO find it!The method I would recommend for studying this book is to go through Chapters 1(fitting equipment), 3 (Shooting with good form), 5 (aiming and sighting), and 6 (Anchoring and releasing) first to make sure you have fitted your equipment well, and that you you are shooting with proper form and technique.  It would be good to have an experienced archer check you out early on and then periodically during your progression to make sure you are not developing bad habits.  Once you have proper form and technique down, then use the instruction in chapter 4 and 7 to refine your technique.  Also, you will need to periodically review all the material, because as you progress, you will learn things that you missed before.  (Oh, THAT'S what that meant!!)This book is what the beginning to intermediate archer needs to become quite proficient, although having an experienced archer check you periodically is also going to be important.  To go beyond this book, you will need a good coach!The only negative to me is the authors' prejudice toward "primitive" bows and arrows.  A good, straight-limbed, wooden longbow can outshoot most recurves and even many compound bows.  The only advantage to the compounds is that a higher draw weight can be handled with less arm strength and the fact that it is easier to mass produce bows using the modern materials.  Primitive archery is experiencing a massive revival worldwide and it would be great if the authors could be exposed to some of the advances that are taking place.  In spite of that, this is still an excellent teaching manual!

I am convinced that one one has the capability of understanding a child like that child's mother.  This book drives that home and shows that often a Mother's instincts are more valuable than the opinions of "experts".In addition to being a very engaging story, there are lessons to be learned here for any Mother.  It is not likely that many mothers will have a child who is a ganius or autistic, but the lessons of this book will still apply.  There is nothing like a Mother's love!The key point to be learned from this book, in addition to the value of a Mother's love, is the instinctive insight that Kristine had to focus on her child's strengths and main interests.  Our education system today is geared around forcing every child into the same mold.  The problem is that this tends to focus on building up perceived weaknesses and also has the tendency to play down any exceptional qualities.  The genius of Kristine's insight was to focus on Jacob's strengths and interests and to work on developing those.This hit home with me because for most of my life and career, I followed the advice of the self help books and worked on strengthening those areas that someone else had decided were weaknesses.  How many job reviews have you had that identified some weakness or the other and encouraged you to strengthen it?  Finally, I found a book that helped me identify my strongest areas and interests and that encouraged me to focus on developing them more than on my weaknesses.  It made all the difference when I started working within my strengths and on those things that I was most interested in.The lesson in this book for all parents is to find those areas that your children are strongest in and help them to develop those areas.  If your child is most interested in mechanical things, don't try to force him to become a doctor.  He will be mush more successful and happy if he is working within his strengths.Wonderful book and a marvelous story!

I had always understood that the Old Testament pointed to the New Testament and to Jesus and that there are many prophecies in the Old Testament regarding Jesus and His life.  This book brought that home to me in a very fresh and meaningful way.There are many books written on the life of Jesus that take different approaches.  There may even be other books that take the approach followed by this book, but this is the first I have read.What this book does is to look not only at the life of Jesus in His earthly incarnation, but also to look at Him and His existence throughout eternity and through the entire Bible.  The theology of scripture and the life of the historical Jesus are merged in a way that is very helpful.  This book is not just a biography or a book on the theology of the Bible, it is a Theography.This book helped me to a grander and more sweeping view of who Jesus is.  My view of Jesus has been too small in the past!

This is a very good book for those of us with older parents.  I found it to be accurate and it gave me some critical information that I needed as my parents became less and less able to take care of themselves.  They have both passed on now so I guess that next I will be using it for my wife and I to help ease the difficulty that our children have taking care of us.This book seems to cover all of the landmines and pitfalls that you will run into as your or your loved ones age.  And there are MANY!!  It seems that everything is getting more and more complicated and at times, it seems that everyone it out to take as much of your assets as they can.What I did, was to use this book to educate myself on what needed to be done and then I found a good ElderCare attorney to help me implement all the documents I needed and to help with the government applications then I needed to fill out on my parents.  I needed this book to help me evaluate the advice that my attorney was giving me.  This book and my attorney were both indispensable to me and helped me to avoid some expensive mistakes!Be sure to read through the table of contents available to the Amazon page.  This will give you a good idea of what this book covers.  One of the most valuable features on Amazon!With this book and my attorney, I was able to keep both of my parents secure and well cared for during their last days.  I will always be grateful for the time I had with them and for the fact that their last days were as comfortable as possible.

In a busy world, it is not always easy to find that one minute to dedicate to ourselves. This is why I am happy to find quick, crisp and to the point books such as this one about how to revert the focus form a hectic life to myself. Focused on self-improvement and proposing a simple approach, not at all time consuming, I find the meditation invitation available in this book appealing. It's an easy to try method that I believe can bring benefits only by the simple fact that it dedicates one whole minute to the individual. An interesting approach in exploring one's potential.

Furry and funny adventure, Manx is a great furry hero. A funny read beginning to end, with well placed jokes and well developed adventurous story line. Reading Manx's adventures felt like watching a great animation movies - everything was so alive and energetic that I couldn't read this book without feeling my energy level going up, like I was a character in a computer game and I was watching my energy bar refilling. A very tasty read, an adventure set that made me smile and join Manx in his adventurous ride.

It is not hard at all to become a fan of Gregory Wolk's work, mainly due to the originality and quality of each of his writings. "The New Dark Ages" did not disappoint me either, even more it exceeded my expectations when it comes to dystopian novels. The power of will, the courage and true feelings for loved ones are beautifully portrayed in Danielle's quest to save her father in a futuristic world where electricity becomes a luxury. A heroine of the future. Danielle is a pure expression of dedication and ambition, making this novel more a character novel than a dystopian one. A truly enjoyable reading, unique and in total sync with the author's writing style.

I find those authors that play with words to be very talented, because it is not an easy job to play with words and build a nice story at the same time - as this is not poetry. Pat Hatt does a a great job in putting words into action and creating a nice and funny story for both children and adults. Handy Dalmatian's story is funny and accompanied by the great graphics within the book, turns out to be a funny read for me and my boys.

I am a big fan of international cuisine and I also enjoy trying out new things when it comes to cooking, Portuguese cuisine was an area I have never explored in the kitchen and I thought starting off with some tasty deserts would be the perfect start. I have found within this book a collection of tasty and quick recipes, easy to cook and delicious to eat. A recipe collection for anyone who enjoys new experiences when cooking.

Health issues strike in different ways, some are more aggressive than others, and gout attacks are definitely painful. The author of this book takes his own experience and converts it into advice for others suffering from gout attacks - it is not intended to be a medical book, as the author often mentions within it, he is not a doctor, but he manages to put together an useful set of advice that can help prevent or manage the pain that comes with gout attacks.

Last autumn, my husband and I visited Belgium, and there we had the chance to visit a family business that was represented by a century old brewery. The whole experience was very interesting and got by husband keen on finding more about what it takes to brew beer. This is why we have found this book to be very interesting and providing a really complete overview on what is needed to brew beer and it even goes beyond this, covering what it takes to make ethanol fuel. An interesting and easy to read guide, really holding up to its title - a distillers bible, containing all the need to know practical advice.

It is not often that I have the chance to read a modern interpretation of a dialogue between mythological characters. So I jumped into reading this book with no specific expectations but I can honestly say that I found the mix of modern and mythology to be very well reflected into this dialogue, that kept me engaged and intrigued throughout the reading. Interesting and captivating read, out of the box approach.

Vampire stories sometimes seem to become redundant but this is not the case of the Necropath Series. And to be honest, on top of that it is my first time reading a liaison novella, in between installments. Goth is definitely a remarkable character, a pure vampire or necros - a fascinating personality around whom the storyline develops. Of course this is not the only detail that makes this series outstanding, the multitude of interconnected storylines, the wonderfully developed characters - everything within this novel gives vampire stories a better name. A must read, in my opinion and an interesting approach when it comes to writing style - confirmed by this liaison novella.

An enriching collection of writings that provides a holistic overview of the current state of national security, this book provides perspective and insights on political and strategical challenges of our times to any of its readers. Leveraging the crisp and structured approach of essays, the author manages to portray exactly the potential threats that United States face in nowadays economical and political landscape. A great and insightful reading.

Twisting legends and creating an unique plot, re-writing a fictional story of humanity - "Plague of Angels" is a novel for the open minded, those people who can draw the line between belief and imagination and who can enjoy a well built story on things that most of the people have as basic moral values. A very interesting twist in the perception of God and his Angels, a world recreated within the pages of this first installment of the series, thought provoking and highly imaginative. A novel that kept me engaged and that used the good and evil battle to a different level of fictional representation, making an unique book that I have enjoyed reading.

Taking the work of world renowned philosophers and sharing concepts and thoughts about their philosophy proved to be a very interesting and engaging reading. "An eye for an I" takes ten philosophies and does exactly what philosophy is expected to do : makes the readers think about life and who we are. Addressing a wide range of readers, the book does a great job at being thought provoking and engaging, with every line provoking a new thought. A read that makes you think about the power within us and the value we bring to the world.

There is nothing like a quick and enjoyable romance to light a rainy day. Ashely's and Tanner's story is engaging, exciting and intense - so it has all the right ingredients for a good and catchy romance. And the fact that the story is not that long makes is so good for reading during a nasty rainy and cold day, because it gave me the chance to walk through their love in one shot, and that actually helped maintaining the intensity of the story.

I am not sure why, but love and war mix wonderfully together and create passionate stories. Mixing the hope that comes with love with the darkness and sufferance that the World War II brought to the world - Mary D. Brooks manages to create a wonderful work of fiction. Her attention to details, the descriptive passages of the book, plus the way she develops Zoe and Eva, the two main characters of this book turned "In the Blood of The Greeks" into a realistic and passionate work of fiction, that can not pass by unnoticed. Lesbianism during mid 20th century was definitely a taboo those days, but love finds its way through blood and sufferance and transforms this story into one about courage and emotion.

I really like to understand things around me - and that applies as well to religious belief. Educated as a Christian, I have developed my own beliefs through time - and there is nothing I see preventing me from understanding those around me that choose a different path. This is what made me download and read this book - and I found it to be very accessible for those unfamiliarized with Buddhism as a concept, exactly as its title promised. Providing an overview o key Buddhist concepts, explaining the history and existent subdivisions of Buddhism, the book really helps in gaining an understanding of the values and beliefs of this lifestyle. A very interesting and understandable overview.

"Scorn of Angels" mixes mythology with fiction in a complex and very well written series. Filled with deeper meaning and mythological details, the story reveals a forgotten past, the everlasting battle between good and evil, between Heaven and Hell in a wonderfully developed plot - but is taking everything and every detail to another level - one were humor and sexuality also find their place. Given this, the series might not be for those very religious people, but I definitely found it to be intriguing and interesting  This is the second installment in the series, following "Plague of Angels", and continues the imaginative and creative storyline, mixed with complex character development, making out of the novel an interesting and complex reading.

I believe sci-fi si that particular type of fiction that touches every layer of imagination - mostly when it is well written. What made me interested in this particular novel was the fact that it is not the ordinary sci-fi novel - although common themes such as post-apocalyptic worlds and spaceships are as well encountered here. What makes this story particularly interesting is that it takes the most raw human emotion and places it into this imaginary post-apocalyptic Earth - by developing an intense and passionate love story between Steven, a starship commander and Ashlyn, a genetically engineered woman. On top of the out of space adventures, fast paced succession of facts and happenings, their passionate and intense relationship brings this new layer of romance and eroticism into this kind of literature - making it unique within the sci-fi books I have read.

Self-development is something that should come as natural, but of course everyone needs a reminder and boost every now and then. I have discovered this book accidentally and I have really enjoyed reading something unique and original about progress and self-development. A great and inspiring book that made me think about success and growing my life and career from a different perspective. On top of the original ideas explored with a good writing style this book is also engaging and really serves its purpose as motivational book. A very good read.

Food highly influences the quality of life - from health to appearance and mood. This is why I have a genuine interest in what we eat and how can we build a healthy diet. A guide such as this one provides very good advice on healthy foods and also shares perspective on the way the influence our moods. An interesting perspective for looking at what we eat, and very helpful in developing a simple eating routine to maintain health and energy.

A set of advice addressed to people that really need it. I've once met a single mother who was struggling with the situation described within this book and I must say I really admire her courage and her power to smile. Having a child with problems is not easy at all, and beyond the pain felt for him or her, there is the pain of not being able to help the most important human being in a mother's life. This book gets right to the point, being crisp and focused on encouraging parents to find happiness again, exactly as the title says it.

I recently saw this product in my local grocery store in a small bag.  What you get here is an attractive tin, suitable for giving as a gift or for a keepsake / storage.The tin contains both milk and dark chocolate squares filled with caramel.  There are about 70 pieces in the tin which is 2.5 pounds.The chocolate isn't similar to regular Hershey's milk chocolate bars.  It is more similar to Hershey's Pot of Gold if you've had those.The caramel isn't a flowing kind of caramel but a chewy and thick kind.They are very delicious - the chocolate is a perfect match for the dense caramel filling.I was fortunate to be home when these were delivered.  Being chocolate, there is a risk of melting in warmer states.I think this would make a wonderful gift.  I think I am going to order a couple more of these for the Holidays and gift-giving.

I'm somewhat brand loyal when it comes to paper towels so I tend to be picky about trying new brands.The rolls are 247.9 square feet and each sheet is  11 x 10.4.  Comparing to Brawny Big Roll, they have 280.5 square feet and the sheet size is 11 x 10.4.  The Plenty rolls have 52 two-ply sheets and the Brawny has 46 two ply sheets.As for look and feel, the Plenty feel strong and soft though not cloth-like.They are absorbant and don't quickly break apart into little pieces like some brands.One thing I like about Plenty is they use tree-saving technology which uses less trees to make more great quality paper.You get 4 six packs of Plenty paper towels which is a good quantity.  We use a lot of paper towels and probably go through 8 big rolls in 2 weeks.On the downside, these are full sheets, not "pick a size".  I like the 11 x 6 sheets because I seldom need a full sheet unless I am cleaning a mess.  But for drying hands and small tasks, a small sized sheet works best for me and saves towels.I consider this a convenient way to purchase towels and this pack will last a while depending on the size and voracity of your family.I would recommend them when put up against the big brands.  They are strong and powerful enough for cleaning tasks and they get the job done.

The premise behind this product is pretty simple.  You spritz the surface of the toilet water 3-5 times which creates a barrier on the water's surface.A moderate yet fresh scent is emitted.  In my case, I had the original scent which is lemongrass-citrus scent.Does it work?  Surprisingly it does.  The odors stay trapped beneath the protective barrier and the bathroom has a moderate scent which lingers for several minutes.I guess if there was something to complain about it would be that the angle needed to spray sometimes chokes up the sprayer and makes it hard to spray.Not much else can be said about this product.  I keep a bottle in my guest bathroom to prevent embarrassment.I would recommend this product.

The Dreamworks Eye Found It! Game is a large, six-foot game board.  The game board features characters from your favorite DreamWorks films.  Think Donkey from Shrek, the Penguins of Madagascar, Po from Kung Fu Panda, etc.  The board is divided into eight lands which are themed after each DreamWorks film character.You get 1 Six-Foot Game Board in three sections, 6 Movers, 6 Mover Bases,1 Spinner, 12 Shrek Ear Markers, 30 Search Cards, 1 Sand Timer, Instructions.This game is for kids 4+ and accommodates 1-6 players.  Game play does not drone on forever like some games.  Perhaps half an hour or a little more.Players scan the universes of Shrek, How to Train Your Dragon, Madagascar, Kung Fu Panda and more to find favorite characters and hidden items on the board. The game builds upon the success of the Wonder Forge Eye Found It! Game line.One of the things that occurred to me is a savvy kid can find things ahead of time and memorize their locations.  Even so, consider it a good memory exercise and appreciate the ability to spend time with family.I think this is a fun and non-competitive game for family game night or even solo-play.  I would recommend adding it to your collection of games.Update:  There are some major annoyances with the game.  The sand timer runs down too fast and doesn't give ample time to locate all of the items indicated by the card.  There are not enough markers if you have 6 players.  You also need a ton of real estate to set up this game board and with six players it is elbow to elbow.None of us who have played it really like the objective.  You basically have a low chance of spinning a card or landing on a search space.  If you end up landing on the movie snacks then all of them could be depleted quickly, effectively ending the game. We would also prefer more competition.  This is more collaborative play.Unless you have a kid's eyesight, locating the items from the card require sharp eyes.  My parents had trouble playing for this reason and got frustrated when the timer ran out.I think this could be a fun game if the objectives made more sense.  We actually collaborated on coming up with our own set of rules to make it more fun.  Put it this way:  when we have family game night, the consensus is that we very rarely play this game.

There is a lot of advertising now for eliminating WiFi dead zones.  My cable company offers this feature for a monthly fee in which several repeaters are placed in low-signal areas of your home.If you are asking "what is a repeater?" then I will offer an explanation.  A repeater boosts an existing WiFi signal and can extend wireless networking to hard-to-reach spots or low coverage in your home or office.  You might use something like this for notebooks, tablets, smartphones, game consoles and smart TVs.I put this one in my garage.  That's because I have a WiFi enabled treadmill which tracks my workouts and it was barely getting a signal.  With this installed I get a full signal where I only got a 20% signal before.I use mine with a Belkin router as the base wireless router.  This repeater hs a small footprint at 7.5 x 3.2 x 5.4 inches.I was able to get this set up in 15 minutes or so.  I connected mine to a PC via an Ethernet cable and accessed the web-based configuration menu directly.  You could also set this up by pressing the button or wirelessly from a tablet or smartphone.  Like my other Belkin extender, you get a SSID similar to your primary one with _rpt at the end and this is editable.  This model offers a 300 Megabit per second transfer speed.One of the benefits I see is this tolerates my router going offline really well and seamlessly reconnects when the router is back online.I don't find this item aesthetically pleasing.  However, you can adjust its external MIMO antennas for the best signal and tuck it away behind something.  The Smart LED signal indicator helps you find the best location for optimum Wi-Fi.  It is green for an excellent signal and red for a weak signal.This product also features a media bridge mode and access point.  An access point might be useful if you are in a hotel, for example.  You can create a personal Wi-Fi hotspot, allowing the internet connection to be accessed from laptops, phones or other Wi-Fi devices and have only one internet fee.  As a media bridge, it can be connected to any Ethernet-compatible device — such as a smart TV, multimedia player, game console or PC — to give it Wi-Fi capability.There is also a nice feature called roaming assist.  In a nutshell, as you move around the house your device will attach to the strongest signal instead of being tied to one (possibly the weaker) signal.I am pleased with the size of this device as well as its performance.  I would recommend it to helo eliminate dead zones around the house.

This is a really substantial mat at more than 8 pounds and 53 x 41 inches.  It is 10mm thick or about half an inch thick.It arrived rolled, wrapped in plastic and inside an outer box.  You will need to unroll it and give it a chance to flatten.  I had to put some books on the corners to achieve this.  It also has a plastic type smell when first opened.The mat is double sided - side one is a city scene and side two is a zoo scene.The zoo scene is appealing but upon closer inspection the two sides of the zoo have the same critters.  The city scene is similar - lots of reused graphics.The graphics in general are colorful but probably beyond what a baby can understand, making this suitable for toddlers.  It would be good for playing with toy cars or action figures during imaginative play.I am not sure this would be good to lug around.  I just leave mine in place.In summary, this is a pricey mat and is thick and comfy.  Be sure to check the dimensions to see if they are right for your needs and the size of your play area.

My initial reaction when I opened the box was "this is Cuisinart?".Upon unboxing and examining the ladel, I was surprised at how uncharacteristically low quality this was for a Cuisinart product.The area where the handle meets the cup looks like it had stretch marks - rough annealing lines or stree marks in the metal.  There are even some rust colored splotches which wiped off with a good scrubbing.  It is supposed to be stainless steel (100%) so I guess these are factory marks.The handle is sort of thin and doesn't exude the feel of quality.  The edges are not polished and smooth.If this wasn't embossed with Cuisinart I would have thought it came from the bargain bin.As for functionality, this is where Cuisinart saves itself.  The cup is the right size (4 oz.)for pizza sauce for soreading sauce on a pizza crust.  The product picture shows a grill but I use mine inside when making pizza on my pizza stone.  The bottom of the cup is flat which is another feature that aides in dispensing sauce.  The length is good and it has a curved end for hanging.  A hole would have been OK too.I am reducing by two stars due to the rough area where the ladel meets the cup and the relatively thin/sharp and non-ergonomic design of the handle.I wouldn't call this a must-have item but it is handy to have when you are making pizzas.

I got this for my grandson as a birthday gift.He is a big Thomas fan and has even been to a Thomas theme park.In summary, this is a wooden railway train track set.  It includes Thomas the train engine and a cargo car.The train tracks are interlocking pieces of wood.  The engine and car lock together magnetically and they are also wooden.  Thre are 18 pieces of track included in this set.This set has a lot of fun features.  Rolling down the hill engages a xylophone effect where some chimes are struck to the melody of the Thomas theme song.  As Thomas continues down the tracks, he rounds the bend and passes through the overpass right past the water mill, just like in the Thomas & Friends opening credits.  Spinning the water mill loads the train with cargo.  The hill itself is 'painted' with a Thomas scene.It is worthy to note that this set fits on Thomas & Friends Wooden Railway Play Table.  In terms of coordinating items there is a Dino Fossil discovery 2-pack of train cars that would interlock with this.  You can also get Samson and some extra ascending track and risers.Adult assembly is required but no tools are needed to complete the assembly.This set is built to last.  It utilizes imaginative play and is not powered.  I would highly recommend it for your Thomas fan.

I am not shy about trying supplements, even if they don't sound too appetizing.  My wife raised her eyebrow as I told her I was trying SoTru's fermented mushroom powder mixed into a glass of water.I was expecting an earthy and musty flavor but was surprised to get a sweet citrus type of flavor.  It mixed in with water quite well and was palatable.  I am happy that it is very low calorie.One of the things I noticed was that only approximately half of the plastic jar this comes in had product.  I believe the size of the container is a bit large for the net weight of the supplement.  However, the jar has a pleasing brown color with earthy colored lettering.  The color scheme immediately makes you think "forest" and for me was a selling point.So let's discuss the contents.  I current take a daily vitamin complex which contains Cordyceps, Agaricus blazei, Maitake and Shiitake in a Cordyvant Polysaccharide Complex.  I am aware of the immunity boosting power of these mushrooms/fungi.  The blend in this supplement has Cordyceps, Reishi, Agaricus blazei, Shiitake, Maitake and Turkey Tails all fermented on organic oats.  There is also some Acerola Cherry Extract for vitamin C, green tea leaf and ginger root.One scoop also contains 5025mg of Organic Gum Acacia.  The acacia gum alone has demuculent and bacteria inhibiting properties.  Cordyceps has along list of posible benefits and you can Google that information for more.  It basically works by stimulating the immune system.  Reishi has similar benefits. From WebMD, Araricus "contains chemicals that might improve the body's use of insulin and decrease insulin resistance in people with type 2 diabetes. Some developing research also suggests it might be able to strengthen the immune system, fight tumor development, and work as an antioxidant."  Shiitake has chemicals that could lower cholesterol as well as other benefits.  Maitake stimulates the immune system and is a cancer fighter.  (Note: many of these mushroom components have cancer / tumor fighting elements) Turkey Tails was a new one for me but I did some armchair research and found it is called Coriolus and a host of other names.  It is primarily an immune system stimulant that contains polysaccharide peptide (PSP) and polysaccharide-K (PSK, krestin).With all the potential benefits, I see this as a very valuable supplement in terms of immunity boosting and prevention.In today's environment we need all the assistance we can get.After drinking this several times, I didn't notice anything in particular.  The work it is doing is likely at the cellular level and not easily measurable.  I am happy to add this to my daily supplement regimen and I would recommend it.

Kinitic spinners are perennial favorites in Florida gardens.This large spinner features colorful hibiscus flowers being courted by ruby-throated hummingbirds.The wheels are stainless-steel and spin in opposing directions when properly assembled.The box contained the spinning blades, pre-assembled.  There was a lower post in a separate box and a stake assembly.  Assembly was very easy, taking less than 5 minutes.  The only gotcha is to remove the thumb screw completely before inserting the lower post, then tighten.Once assembled, there is some post assembly work.  You must bend the blades at a 30 degree angle.  This is harder to explain than it is to do.If the left and right wheels are bent in the same direction then the wheel will spin in the same direction.  So you bend them counter to each other.Make no mistake - this is a substantial spinner.  Be sure to plant it in firm soil.  I had a chance to see this thing weather a recent thunderstorm.  It was spinning really fast but kept it's posture and looked nice.  Hopefully it won't be attractive to lightning.The spinner comes with a 2-year warranty.  I doubt you will need it though - this thing is solidly built.I would recommend it to spruce up any garden setting.UPDATE 10/25/15:  I might need that warranty after all.  Mine fell apart.  Both spinners disconnected and were found on the ground after several weeks of light use, no storms or gusts.  It was in an isolated garden section but I cannot rule out wildlife as a suspect since we have lots of possums and raccoons in the vicinity.  Regardless, it fell apart and I would have to purchase hardware to fix it myself or spend a fortune on shipping to send it in for warranty repair.  Minus two stars for this.

A couple of things appealed to me about this item looking at its product page.It doesn't require the practice and training of a traditional drone.  That's a big plus for me.It also has auto take off, auto hover and auto landing.  No more hard landings or botched takeoff attempts!The first thing I thought when I got this was "I thought it would be larger."  I had seen the video and even read the specs but was still surprised by how small this thing was.The controller uses a 2.4 GHz frequency and has a range of roughly 250 feet.  It takes 4-AAA batteries.There are flip buttons and auto stunt buttons.  The drone features proximity sensors to prevent crashes and provide a soft landing.Crashes are still inevitable but this model seems to resist damage.I tried mine in my office, after hours.  It could be flown outdoors but the minuscule size might make it susceptible to wind.Battery life of drone itself is poor.  The sensors worked pretty good but there are some things in a relatively mundane office environment that trip it up.Overall it is very fun to play with but would require a good investment of time to master.

I got this surge protector because of its cable protection feature.  I have some AV equipment on my bedroom TV and this was an ideal strip for protecting those devices plus the incoming cable feed.You get 1000 joules of protection and EMI/RFI noise filtration.  There are six outlets and none of them are spaced for transformer blocks.  The outlets have sliding safety/dust covers.The plug is a right angle flat plug so you can fit this into an outlet behind furniture.  There is an on/off switch which turns on/off all outlets.As with most surge supressors, this one doesn't last forever.  That has more to do with the particular technology used to avert the surges.  I replace all my strips every 3 years just to be sure they are still protecting my equipment.In the end, I feel better knowing my electronic stuff is plugged into one of these strips.  Having recently lost a cable modem from a coax-based surge, I very much recommend coax protection.  This strip is no-frills.  It is inexpensive and not aesthetically pleasing.  But it is better then plugging something straight into the wall outlet.

Ellen Byron has put together a whodunit set in Cajun Country.  Having been to New Orleans and surrounding areas, I felt the portrayal of the Pelican, Louisiana setting was accurate and well constructed though quick to stereotype.Told from the point of view of a historic plantation B&B owner, the mystery unravels slowly and keeps you guessing until the last set of chapters.  In between the mystery there is a shallow romance with strategically placed characters interwoven with the plot.  The characters had some depth but as a reader I never felt particularly emotional about any of them.This book ended up being a Cajun murder mystery, moving at the speed of the bayou  I never felt compelled to turn pages but I was interested enough to want to know how it ended.Overall, this was a satisfying read without twists and just suspenseful enough to keep you reading.  Some of the subplots tried to take over the story and I could feel the writer trying to tame them.  But overall I thought it was a good read.  By the way, there are some good recipes at the end of the book which you'll probably want to try after reading about all the delicious food and pastries.

This review is for the Woods 041708 8-Outlet Electronics Energy-Saving Surge Protector.Surge protectors are an absolute necessity in areas prone to thunderstorms and pretty much anywhere else.The idea is to balance affordability with features and protection.  The Woods surge supressor has some good features which make it worthy of consideration.I live in Central Florida and we recently had a lightning strike about 8 feet from our kitchen on a palm tree.  The nearby cable company wiring block was fried, even though it was not directly hit.  (By the way: nearly nothing electronic survives a direct lightning hit and no surge supressor can handle 5 billion joules.)  One of my surge supressors in the house was taken out, thankfully sparing the attached electronic equipment.  You never know what surges, spikes and electrical noise might be doing to your sensitive items.  Why take a chance?This supressor is rated for 4200 Joules so it provides basic to intermediate levels of surge protection.  It has 8 grounded outlets and 2 of them are offset to accept transformers.  LEDs indicate ground and protection status.  There is a resettable 15A circuit breaker.  The plug is flat so you can plug this in behind furniture without losing the ability to push the furniture flush with the wall.  Another feature is that it filters EMI/RFI noise.One of the big features of this supressor is that it automatically turns off up to 3 devices, eliminating phantom power loss.  Consider this scenario:  You plug your TV into the Master Outlet.  When the TV is turned off, this device will detect that and shut off power to the peripheral devices (DVD player, speaker system, etc.) provided they are plugged into the controlled outlets.  The non-controlled outlets remain on all the time.  Both are clearly marked to prevent confusion.The outlets have rotating dust covers when not in use.  If I have a situation in which things don't fit, I use those little extension cables such as ASIN B003I7FEHQ.There are other models which have either phone or coax protection.  You should always protect coax since a surge can travel over coax just as easily as it can over electrical wiring.Overall this is a good general purpose surge protector in cases where you would need the controlled outlet feature.  If you don't then just get a normal strip that protects against surges.

This is a three-story interactive toy house featuring the Miss Norah MagicPoint character.  Norah is interoperable with other Go! Go! Smart Friends doll accessories and toddler playsets.  There is also a puppy character included.This house is really feature packed.  I will try to summarize.First there is an elevator that goes up and down by pressing the yellow button on the character.  This is part of the MagicPoint feature.  This set has 7 MagicPoint locations which interact with the character(s).  There is also an interactive MagicChat location that lets two friends chat and sing with each other.  So you basically place Miss Norah on a MagicPoint location to experience her personality, lights and more.The front of the house has 6 windows, a treed area with swing and an entrance with a slide.In terms of learning, this set teaches letters, cause & effect and motor skills.  There is also an element of imaginative play which most toys share.  It's kind of like a modern doll house.You will need 2 AAA batteries to replace the "demo" batteries that are included.  Ideally you will need other "Smart Friends" to interact with Norah.I think this is a good doll house type of toy and turns out to be a lot of fun.  The MagicPoint locations are the life of the toy and really aide the imaginative play aspect.

Simply put, the VTech Kidizoom Smartwatch DX is a fun smart watch for kids.At a high level, the watch features 3 fun activities, 5 games, 3 action challenges and a pedometer + motion sensor.The watch features a camera and video capability.The 256MB memory stores about 1600 photos at the camera's resolution.The video clips are limited to 60 seconds each and are 320x240 or 160x120 pixel @ 15fps.The photo resolution is 640x480 which makes this a 0.3MP camera.There are creative photo effects, frames and filters that can be applied to photos.This watch is packed with features.There are four learning games:  Jumping Egg, Tic-Tac-Toe, Super Snowboard and Finger Dance.There are four action games:  Sound Shaker, Crazy Dance, Racing Run and Funky Jump.Additional games can be downloaded from the Learning Lodge, a dowloadable app for PC or Mac.Kids can share videos and photos via social media using #smartwatchdx.There is also an alarm, timer and stopwatch, plus a calendar feature and a calculator.The watch face can be customized with either digital or analog display themes.The watch arrives in an attractive acrylic case.  The bottom portion of the box contains a micro-USB cable for uploading photos / videos and an instruction booklet.  Appropriate ages would be 4-9 years old.The battery is a lithium ion battery which has a duration dependant on frequency of usage: 1 day for heavy usage, 2-3 days for typical usage and 2 weeks for low usage. The watch is "splashproof" meaning it is not waterproof but would resist casual moisture.I found transferring files from watch to computer to be a bit dated and cumbersome.You plug in the watch via the micro USB.  A drive appears called VTech 1557. You navigate to the DCIM folder and locate the files which are drag and dropped to a location on your computer.  I would have expected a driver capable of automatically importing files upon connection to a PC/Mac.One thing that should also be noted - there is no language setting on this watch.  It is English only.  I was considering recommending this to a Spanish speaking family I know but it does not support Spanish.With all the features and downloadable games, I think this would make a wonderful gift for a 6 year old.  Kids these days are practically raised on electronics.  This would be a starter for an introduction to a smart watch possessing greater capabilities at a later age.

Whether you are camping in the back yard or elsewhere, a solidly constructed and comfortable sleeping bag is a necessity.This sleeping bag is touted as a Women's sleeping bag, rectangular design.  Dimensions are 80" x 34".  It fits up to a 6' human.  The packed size is 10" x 18" and the carry weight is 4 pounds, 14 ounces.  The shell/liner is made of Polyester Taffeta.  (Synthetic insulation)This bag is rated for 20F though I don't live or camp in a state where temps would typically reach that low.  My wife recently tried it in a backyard setting in the mountains of NC where it got to the mid-40's at night.  The bag felt comfortably warm in that setting.What makes a sleeping bag a women's specific model? Women often have colder extremities than men.  Women's bags are sometimes cut to be a bit wider in the hips and narrower in the shoulder though I can't see any difference with this bag.  It's rectangular.  I do not know if there is any extra insulation at the feet.  The men's version of this bag has the same carry weight and temperature rating.  Surely this company didn't just call it a women's bag because of the color?At any rate, the bag is functional and comfortable.  Two bags can be zipped together and it comes with a stuff sack for compacting.  I would recommend this for male or female use.

This food features cubes of poultry and bits of swelled rice in a gravy.The can has a pull ring for convenience.I have used Nutro brand dry food products for my dog and the outside stray cat who is trying to adopt us.One thing I can say about this food is my large dog loves it.  He loved the tender bites and the gravy.The cat also smelled this food and started eating it...so it is liked by both feline and canine which says a lot about the flavor.One of the problems with large dog breeds is joint issues.  This food features glucosamine and chondroitin for healthy joints.  It also has a balanced protein to fat ratio plus omega-6's and zinc.  Oddly, this product contains gluten which a lot of high end pet food manufacturers shy away from these days.I think the verdict is in.  My dog loves this stuff and I like the ingredient list, for the most part.  I would order it again.

I own and have owned several Epson printers.  I also interact with Epson printers at work.The models I have owned or utilized are as follows:Epson XP-520 (home)Epson XP-800 (work)Epson WorkForce WF-2540 (work)Epson Artisan-800 (home)Epson WP-4020 (home)Epson XP-630 (recently replaced the WP-4020 and XP-520)I am going to reuse a bit of review material from my other Epson reviews because this information is still relevant.My first all-in-one from Epson was the Artisan-800 - a fabulous machine until it started consuming a whole ink cartridge every week with only a few printed pages. I also had big issues with the WiFi on this machine, eventually switching to wired Ethernet. Next was the WF-2540 - a wireless all-in-one copier, scanner, fax machine and color printer. This served as my mail printer at work for a period of time until it simply quit printing. The WF-2540 started the same ink consumption cycle as the Artisan - I would replace a cartridge, print a few pages and watch the ink levels reduce by half. Then it stopped printing and finally got to the point where it would constantly tell me my cartridges need replacing (and wouldn't let me print). I have also used an Epson WP-4020 in my home office which I use for more voluminous printing chores. It hasn't had a single issue except the occasional duplexer jam and the inks last a long time.  I eventually gave this one to my daughter for frequent printing of homework based stuff and it is still going strong.One of point of irritation for Epson's. When they run out of ink (ANY color), you can't print. Period. And when the printer *thinks* it has run out of ink (even if a fresh cartridge is installed)...you're done.  Having extra ink cartridges on stand by is a must for Epson owners.You might be wondering if I am doing something wrong to have these ink issues. I always use genuine Epson cartridges when replacing inks. Per the instruction manual, I periodically clean the print head using the built in function for this. I also periodically use the "clean Nozzle" function per the manual to keep the printer maintained. I also apply firmware updates when prompted and use the latest driver set. My printer is kept in a dust-free area and is not crowded where it would overheat. I also use high quality paper.With all of that history stated, let's move on.  These days I am using an Epson XP-520 at home and it does use ink quickly but has not had a single issue.  I opt to use the high capacity cartridges with it which are genuine Epson parts.Amazon has now offered me the XP-830 in exchange for an honest review.Installation of the XP-830 was easy and took 45-50 minutes from unbox to print.  I followed the included quick start guide. The printer itself prompted me at each step on what to do after it was powered on. The printer found my WiFi router and more or less configured itself. All I had to do was enter my passkey. The driver worked well, connecting to the Internet to get its own updates.I would like to note this model also includes Ethernet for a wired connection.The XP-830 has a 5-ink technology.  The colors are Black, Cyan, Magenta, Yellow and Photo Black.  The Black is used for everyday text printing and the Proto Black is used when printing photos.  Step up to the XP-860 if you need six-color printing.The XP-830 processes large print jobs very quickly and prints at ISO 14 for black and ISO 11 in color.  One thing I like about the XP-830 is the automatic 2-sided printing which my XP-520 lacked.I don't normally use these but there is a card slot and USB port for printing directly without the need to go through a computer.  I usually like to process my photos and text prior to printing so these features don't get used as much.Let's discuss paper handling.  I use a lot of Avery labels to print things and this printer handles them all well.  There is a DVD tray for printing CD/DVD labels and a photo tray for standard photo paper sizes.  The trays are all adjustable and the printer accommodates many sizes, just not mega sized stuff like tabloid.I tried printing a borderless photo on premium paper and the result was very good, exceeding that of my XP-520.  The ink can smudge when wet so it has to dry a bit.  I find that a drop of water on a normal printed color document can cause inks to run as well.I already have an Epson Connect and Google Cloud Print account set up and I was able to add this printer to Epson Connect quite easily.Doing this allows me to print from my iPhone and Android device, an HP Slate and my Dell laptop via wireless.  I printed from all my devices with no issues.  I even printed some docs from my work PC to my home printer via cloud print.As I have stated before, inkjet output in terms of text documents just isn't as crisp looking as laser.Copying does feature a 30-page ADF with auto two-sided printing, copying, scanning, faxing.  This is a big deal for me as I really use the two-sided copy and fax feature a lot.  So you can basically fax or email up to 30 2-sided pages without having to fuss with turning over paper.The software accompanying the printer includes a scanner driver which works well to capture scanned content to a PC running Windows 10.I scanned both a text document and a photo and the results were excellent.  The scan to cloud or email feature is useful if you are sharing something with friends or family.The LCD is a larger than the XP-630; 4.3" versus 2.7". Navigation is better thought out on the XP-830 versus the XP-630.My experience with ink failures on earlier models seems to have been rectified on these later generation models.The XP-830 does a good job of keeping the user informed about remaining ink levels.  Do opt for the extended capacity cartridges when you go to replace these starter cartridges.With the addition of a duplexing ADF and fax plus slightly faster print speeds and a better LCD, I would definitely think that the XP-830 is a better value than the XP-630 if you are comparison shopping.  You won't be disappointed with this printer - it is feature packed and well designed.I would recommend this brand having worked with Epson products for several years.

I also interact with Epson printers at work.The models I have owned or utilized are as follows:Epson XP-520 (home)Epson XP-800 (work)Epson WorkForce WF-2540 (work)Epson Artisan-800 (home)Epson WP-4020 (home)I am going to reuse a bit of review material from my other Epson reviews because this information is still relevant.My first all-in-one from Epson was the Artisan-800 - a fabulous machine until it started consuming a whole ink cartridge every week with only a few printed pages. All I had to do was enter my passkey. The driver worked well, connecting to the Internet to get its own updates.The XP-630 has a 5-ink technology.  The colors are Black, Cyan, Magenta, Yellow and Photo Black.  The Black is used for everyday text printing and the Proto Black is used when printing photos.The XP-630 processes large print jobs very quickly and prints at ISO 13 for black and ISO 10 in color.  One thing I like about the XP-630 is the automatic 2-sided printing which my XP-520 lacked.I don't normally use these but there is a card slot and USB port for printing directly without the need to go through a computer.  I usually like to process my photos and text prior to printing so these features don't get used as much.Let's discuss paper handling.  I use a lot of Avery labels to print things and this printer handles them all well.  There is a DVD tray for printing CD/DVD labels and a photo tray for standard photo paper sizes. I find that a drop of water on a normal printed color document can cause inks to run as well.I already have an Epson Connect and Google Cloud Print account set up and I was able to add this printer to Epson Connect quite easily.Doing this allows me to print from my iPhone and Android device, an HP Slate and my Dell laptop via wireless.  I printed from all my devices with no issues.  I even printed some docs from my work PC to my home printer via cloud print.As I have stated before, inkjet output in terms of text documents just isn't as crisp looking as laser.Copying doesn't feature an ADF.  You lift a cover and put in your item to be copied. Copying is pretty quick and can be used in situations where you need a quick copy and don't mind wasting the ink on it.The software accompanying the printer includes a scanner driver which works well to capture scanned content to a PC running Windows 10.I scanned both a text document and a photo and the results were excellent.  The scan to cloud feature is useful if you are sharing something with friends or family.The LCD is a little larger than my XP-520.  I find this useful.  The menu system is streamlined to get you to the settings or ink levels or whatever you are trying to set.My experience with ink failures on earlier models seems to have been rectified on these later generation models.The XP-630 does a good job of keeping the user informed about remaining ink levels.  Do opt for the extended capacity cartridges when you go to replace these starter cartridges.One of the things that persists with Epson models is the annoying clunking sounds they make at random when idling.  Not sure why they do this - maybe they are keeping the inks primed or something.Overall I consider this a gradual evolution of the Expression Premium line of printers by Epson.Definite pros are ease of installation, good color prints and paper handling.Some cons are ink consumption and cost and occasional responsiveness issues.I would recommend this brand having worked with Epson products for several years.

I have a lot of LED powered candles around the house during the holidays (and otherwise) and my family and I go through lots of AA batteries which have become ubiquitous in kid's toys and automatic scent dispensers, weather stations, etc.Being a 48-pack and offered as part of Vine in exchange for a review, I decided to give it a shot.First, and to get it out of the way, the recycling program requires you to enter into a points system.  I simply won't do that and I fully expect the spent batteries to end up in a landfill.  I'm just being honest.I see a US flag on the packaging but these are made in China.  I find that somewhat deceptive.I actually did do a drain down test on these compared to Energizer and Duracell, equivalent alkaline consumer grade batteries.These finished last with the copper top lasting longest.  It was not a scientific test but used the same exact item which was left in the on position while a countdown was conducted.  Even if no one else is convinced, I am.These don't have a mAh rating but I think they are probably better suited in low drain applications such as remotes, led candles, etc.  I put two in a pen flashlight and they worked pretty well.I like the price and the convenience of having a ton of them standing by in case of a need.I still prefer name brands to these.

It seems like every day a new hair care product comes out featuring some new kind of botanical or oil.This one introduces babassu and marula oil, two I had not heard of prior to this review.Babassu oil comes from the seeds of the babassu palm.  Think S.America / Amazon area.It is used in similar contexts as coconut oil.Marula oil is extracted from the kernels of the Marula tree.  Think Africa / Madagascar.Together, these oils plus elastin protein restore dull hair and add luminosity.I think the fragrance smells typical of most Nexxus products - a very "salon" type of scent, if that makes sense.It is definitely an aggressive scent but I think it is pleasant.My wife smelled it and thought it smelled "like conditioner".As for results, we both tried it.  My hair is dry and hers tends to be dry / drizzy.  We both noticed an improvement in how our hair felt and reacted to styling after using this a couple of times.  Hair was also noticeably more healthy and shiny looking, sort of like Ojon or other high end brands.I have been a long time user of Nexxus products and this one is my favorite of the lineup.I would recommend it.

This is a set of bathroom essentials including a small rug, a shower curtain and shower hooks.Starting with the hooks, they are 12 button style hooks in a coordinating blue color.The rug is a foam rug, thick and plush but small in overall size.  It has a standard rubberized backing which tends to slough off when dried repeatedly.  It does hold its shape when on the floor and does not curl up on the sides.The curtain is a basic polyester curtain.  You'll need a vinyl liner, available almost anywhere.The best thing about this set is the coordinated colors.  It is not a set that is going to last a long time so consider this a part of a rotation of different themes for your bathroom.  We use ours in the upstairs (kids) bathroom.I would call this a very basic starter set, appropriate for a kid's bathroom where it will be changed out frequently or an apartment bathroom for those on a shoestring budget.
