I used it 6 days a week and did the full treatment (with the original trainer and the ele attachment) nearly every day (there were probably 3 days out of the entire 2.5 weeks where I didn't have time for the Ele attachment). When I returned, no one noticed anything different.I had one coworker who told me I look good, well-rested. But there are so many variables there, being away from the family and work for 2.5 weeks could have been the reason for looking well-rested, I cannot attribute that to the NuFace.I, personally, did notice that my lips plump slightly when using the ele attachment. I noticed it particularly when doing half of my face (which is actually what they recommend). But it was no greater than the plumping I get from my favorite lip gloss.Overall, I personally wouldn't spend the money on this. However, if you go to the spa regularly to get these kinds of treatments that just make a hint of a difference, then it will pay for itself over time.

Let me first caveat this review with I’m a huge George Forman Grill fanboy. We’ve used many electric grills, to include several in the George Foreman line for years, and have been very pleased with the results. Being a family that’s fairly health-conscious and on-the-go a lot, the grills fit perfectly in our lifestyle.And that’s probably the biggest reason that I was so excited about this griddle. I had visions of massive feasts on the weekends and even getting up earlier during the week to cook lavish breakfasts for the six of us, before we all go off to work and school. I was sure it would be perfect!Well after a couple of weeks, I see it’s a little less than perfect.For one, after less than ten uses, I can already see marks on the surface where the heating element is. It’s basically stained the top side of the griddle. It’s not a show stopper, but it’s a little unsightly for a device that has been used for less than two weeks. Couple that with the fact that I never turned it past 4 on the heating element, I don’t see why it shows wear that fast, unless that’s just expected.The cooking is more or less even – but not perfect. I find that I have had to learn the sweet spot on where to cook the eggs and pancakes, as the surface temperature seems to be significantly different, and changes depending on how many inches you move the food.  I did notice that a simple pancake recipe seemed a little more challenging (sticking to the griddle, turning too dark too fast, etc.. ) but over time I was again able to find the sweet spot.I’m not thrilled with the way it cooks the turkey bacon that we usually throw on, as it seems uneven in cooking compared to when we cooked everything on the cast iron griddle.Now the good parts: I tried cooking some Mexican chorizo and it cooked the sausage perfectly right on the top part (this is where I learned that splatter was a tiny issue with really greasy food). It does clean up super-easy, although we are still looking for where to store this thing when we’re not using it. The little removable trays are perfect and dishwasher safe. I do like that the power cord easily unplugs either for an emergency or for cleaning/storage.  I also appreciated how easy it was to run a paper towel over the surface, while I was cooking, to make room for other food. That’s probably one of the nicer parts about cooking a larger breakfast was the fewer dishes used and the easy clean up while you go.So this wasn’t perfect, and I dare say that I was a bit disappointed by my expectations, but once you get the hang of it, and learn from the flaws, it cooks eggs and pancakes pretty well. I haven’t used it for the fajita function yet (although I’d kind of love to try that soon) and so I can see possibilities.

I always find reviews of supplements are so difficult to quantify. With supplement usage in general, I’m not sure how much is in my head, and how much of the effects are attributable to actual success of the product.To start off with – I like the taste of the watermelon. It went down like a regular Gatorade (not the G2) and there wasn’t a hideous after-taste. This made daily servings something I actually looked forward to. I only had experience with Blue Raspberry from this manufacturer, so I was happy that this was tasty.One of the major selling points for me was the claim (not FDA Verified of course) that it can help with muscle recovery/soreness. For the last several months I’ve really be ramping up my running routine (up to ten miles at a time – 4-5 times a week) and since I’m doing that on hills – I’ve had some mad-soreness in my calves that’s been lingering.So after less than a week of taking this regularly, the persistent soreness in my calves faded away. The caveat is I have NO way of proving that this actually helped, or if after several weeks of ramping up my workout my muscles had finally gotten comfortable. But it’s a positive nonetheless.On the other hand – about a week ago I jumped back into the gym with a killer upper body routine – I am still sore 6 days later and after drinking this every day at least once a day; however, since correlation does not causation, I can’t tell for sure if this isn’t having any effect, or if the soreness would have been worse. For that matter I can’t be sure that I didn’t strain something trying to do too many reps in the gym, but what is clear is that despite my previous success with my calves, this didn’t have the same magic effect on my biceps and forearms.  Mind you – I don’t think it hurt, but I can’t tell for sure that it helped.I will add that I personally can’t drink this before a workout. It’s really thirst-quenching after a workout, and I’ll usually mix it up with ice, have a full shaker, and then pour more water on top of the ice to retain the flavor. But trying to take it before a run (as is subtly suggest on the product’s webpage) is a non-starter. Assuming a similar reaction, I have not had this before a gym workout.And finally – And it’s hard to put this correctly for a G-rated review, but to me – there’s a side effect that I haven’t seen listed in any product description… but after taking this product for a couple of weeks, I’ve had an increase in blood flow in certain areas of my body. Again – it’s impossible to say that this particularly supplement caused that… but to me (assuming it’s not all in my head) there has definitely been more blood flow to areas of my body where that’s a good thing.For those reasons – I am probably hooked, and this will be a mainstay in my supplement program. Overall I really appreciate the effects that I’m seeing.Lastly – my parting words are make sure to read the fine print before you order… I did not see this when I placed the order, and it would not have affected my decision, but it would have been nice to have this in larger letters: “Do not use this product if you are pregnant, nursing, or are currently taking nitrates for chest pain or if you are taking medication used to treat erectile dysfunction such as PDE-5 inhibitors… Discontinue use 2 weeks prior to surgery.” That almost sounds ominous.

We through a package of these in a care package for our college kid and she gladly shared them with large groups of friends.All I can say, besides "They're gummy bears! They're delicious" is there were no reports from her or her friends about how eating a lot of these having caused any unusual trips to the bathroom (unlike other large bags of gummy bears featured on Amazon). So that's something I guess.

Maybe it's the type of scratches to our furniture, or the type of furniture that's in our house, but this wasn't a perfect solution for us.I will say that it made the unsightly water stains/warping of our brand new furniture a bit better, but it's still noticeable when looking at it (angle or head on) and while it does help, it's not a permanent fix.So it is worth a few bucks to try it out - but it's not exactly a professional solution.

Everybody loves Pringles - and in my house these are popular with both the kids and their lunches and the adults with an indulgent 100 calorie treat once in a while. The boys love them in their lunches and don't complain with either flavor.The only complaint, and this is probably more Amazon than Pringles, is that they arrive crushed. We have them on a monthly delivery, and every time it seems they are packed with larger items and end up getting to us a little crushed. They are packaged well, but not good enough when packed with either the Complete Calvin and Hobbes collection, or a plastic tub full of cascade dishwasher pods. They end up getting to us in pieces. Again, the kids don't complain, but I'm not sure if Pringles could do something different about that or not.

Our 9-year-old is a bit of a picky eater and pretty much stopped eating sandwiches at lunch.I got this on a hunch that bringing creativity to his lunch would get his attention - and it worked. He was actually excited about this when it came int he mail, and when we started sending him to camp with Tetris-sized pieces - he came back with less leftover sandwich.For us (possibly the bread we use) there's a bit of waste with the crust, but that' not a show-stopper.I did notice that it's not a perfect cut. Unless you are meticulous about it - the pieces don't get cut perfectly the first time (at least not with straight Nutella sandwiches). With the sandwich pieces still connected, this felt more like a dollar-store item, but that's not the price point I paid. That's our only disappointment.,

I only bought one box because several other reviews on Amazon showed that these favorites were delivered and tasted stale.I did not have this problem with this box. I don't recall how far out the expiration date was, but they were tasty and went a lot faster than they should have!

I am a military guy with pretty short hair, so when I found a gel that worked for me - I've stuck with it.Normally I use Herbal Essences Set Me Up Gel, Maximum Hold, 6 oz because it's proven to hold up pretty well.I tried this dove Styling gel because it was available, and I have been pleasantly surprised at how it compares to my usual brand of hair gel. The most noticeable difference from this and the gel I normally use is that this is very light and washes off my hands a lot easier than my normal stuff. The gel itself holds about the same, and can be easily managed when brushed or blow-dried. It's not particularly amazing at actually holding my hair, but it's still very comparable.The fact that it washes off my hands right away is a very positive point and one that will probably be good enough to make me switch brands. All and all - it's been great.

For many years in the military I have always carried a Gerber multi-tool (in a sheath – not like this with the clip on the device itself), and I really didn’t think that I was going to be very open to change. The way a Gerber opens is significantly different, and based on muscle memory alone, I did not have high hopes for this particular device.To my surprise, I have really grown to like this little guy.Being self-contained, it’s much easier to remove from my belt loop, but I have been more prone to slipping this in my front pocket rather than leaving it exposed. The change in habit with the way I open it took a little bit to get used to, but it’s been growing on me for the last week. I can now easily remove and flip open the pliers with one hand, but closing it back is still a two-handed operation.Once I spent the appropriate amount of time wearing it in, the parts started to move more easily. It comes well-greased (still a little bit of grease obvious when I opened it up) and so after a few days it really felt a lot more natural to use. It doesn’t take long before the press of the  button gets easier and the pliers pop right open. I still don’t think it’s a fluid as the motion of opening pliers on a Gerber multi-tool, but I can certainly see where I can get used to this too.The Swiss-Army tools that come are all standard and effective. The can opener and bottle opener came in handy very shortly after I got it. I really like the ruler (both in inches and centimeters) as an extra. That might be standard now, but it’s a nice touch. The awl is quite sharp although I’m not sure when that will come in handy, but the main blade is also pretty sharp (at least for now) and that will come in handy as I tend to use these multi tools a much for cutting open packages and boxes as much as anything else.The biggest selling point is the Lifetime Warranty. That’s where I get sold. I like tools like this to last for a long time, and if they will stand behind it (presumably) to replace it if it is defective years from now – then that tells me a lot. Ur firstSo overall there are no issues. My only caveat would be that if you are switching from using another brand, there’s a few habits that need to change. But I like the thinner form factor and the continued ability to use the pliers with one hand.

I played this with our 21 year old, 12 year old and 10 year old. It's a lot of fun and easily tailored to the group you are playing with. Our 21 year old thought it would be great to play with her friends at college, but we had a great time playing together too. Because you are coming up with the answers, you can play to your audience.Cons: The box. You need somewhere to keep the contents and this box is a bit worthless. ANY other board game box would be better than this. If it were just a card game, the box it comes in would be fine, but you at least have to keep the apples to write on somewhere in addition to the cards.If you are playing with family members or people you know really well, you will know the handwriting right away and it takes away the anonymity. We actually all started writing with our non dominant hands, which actually worked for us, but added time for answers.Overall, we really enjoyed it and it has become a really fun game for us to play together in our summer rental.

Our 9-year-old has been reading Captain Underpants since he could read, and so when this was available, we jumped on it.No surprise, he loved it. He read the entire thing in the morning, then picked it up to re-read it in the afternoon. I’m sure he’s gone through it a couple of times since then.In our house we always feel it’s better to read something rather than nothing, so while the jokes and themes aren’t exactly deep reading, we feel that if he really enjoys it – then it’s a success.The 10-year-old also read it but his response was a bit more mundane. When asked how he liked it – he only responded. “It was pretty good”. He doesn’t elaborate much.So the one that LOVES the Captain Underpants books says it’s fantastic. So that’s good enough for us!

From the minute the UPS guy delivered it, the 10-year-old immediately began to put this together. With absolutely no help from anyone else, he was able to pretty much instantly put together the configurations just by looking at the box. When his 9-year-old brother came home, they spent hours coming up with different possibilities.If there was a down-side to this set, it was that the set did not come with any action figures. The product really promotes the “Create a WWE Superstar” collection, but we found that using the WWE Battle Pack was more economical (half the price), and just as satisfying for the kids.After the 10-year-old had pretty much moved on from constant playing with the toy, the 9-year-old (I’m convinced that he’s a future engineer) really enjoyed taking it apart and putting it back together. The use of the wrestlers of course was an added bonus, but he really enjoyed making the shapes on the boxes and event trying his own designs. So that’s the aspect that I liked the most. It really brought out his creativity in putting the set together and then breaking it apart and trying again. There really wasn’t any frustration expressed by either kid, except when trying to take some of the pieces apart (they can be pretty tight for 9-year-old hands). Worth noting: The 1-year-old had little-to-no interest in this product.So aside from some pieces being a little tight, and the fact that they don’t throw in any courtesy action figures, this is actually a lot of fun. Even though they get more enjoyment out of making the different rings than they do from actually using it to stage wrestling matches!I should probably caveat that where we are stationed, we actually watch a LOT more Mexican wrestling than WWE (We attend Lucha Libre matches regularly) and so my kids gravitated towards the WWE packs with the masked Luchador. That’s worth a compliment to the WWE marketing folks.

So we're not avid snorkelers - but this is by far the best set that we've tried.Mind you we don't normally spend a lot of cash on this sort of item, so our expectations are low, but this set worked really well for us.The kids tried it first (9 and 10 year old boys) and they had no issues with sizing. So then Dad (with a significantly larger head) was easily able to adjust and use it right away with no issues. It was refreshing how easy it was to make adjustments and go (unlike much cheaper alternatives).After a few hours of total use, we all like it a lot. Dad had to learn to keep his head down, but the feature that stops water from being inhaled accidentally is nice. None of us ever had any problems with fogging and that was a big plus. Occasionally both the boys and Dad would have issues with a little bit of water seeping in, but it was very minor, and not enough to be any irritation.I will say that we have not yet had the chance to try out in a salt water environment, so this is all from the fresh water perspective. We had wide field's of vision, and no real complaints all. My only problem is now I am pretty sure I need to order more sets for everyone!

I used these to hang Christmas tree lights across a long metal I-beam. The only issue that I had with them is that surface had to be REALLY clean for them to stick, and since it was a metal beam, it didn’t get cleaned very often.So as I was about to knock one star off, I realized that they specifically included extra sticky parts so that if you do end up not being able to use some of the devices, you can just reattach and start over. So that’s a plus.Aside from having to be pretty darn clean, they worked perfectly. I have the lights dangling directly from being attached and it’s working fine. None of them fell off after-the-fact, and the kind-of humid environment seems to have no impact. ‘As long as you can stick this on a flat, clean, non-porous surface, they should be perfect for your needs.

When I ordered this I assumed that it was over-hyped. When I opened the shipping package and it revealed  a box with a magnetic front lid, I was sure that this was hype.But I was pleasantly surprised that when I pulled the cord out of the fancy box, it felt really solid. I immediately thought that these types of cords would be perfect for the 9-year-old who tends to be REALLY hard on ipad charging cables. I kind of regret not getting more now that I have it.They are longer than stock cords, and they feel so much tougher. I really think that this will keep us from regularly replacing the cords that we have.The color is a fine (a nice touch) but the cable not only feels more solid in your hands, but it really feels like it can put up with a lot of wear and tear.I was pleasantly surprised at the apparent durability.

I wasn't trying to do anything earth-shattering with this adapter. I was trying to upgrade the on-board wifi of a simple PC build to connect with my 802.11ac router. I expected some increase, but was reasonable about what to expect.The end result was disappointing. It barely connected to the router at all, and the speeds using the n channel with the on-board wifi card were better than with this adapter. We're talking one room (albeit two walls) over. I wasn't going for across the entire house.In the same room as the router, the speeds were fine and I could stream HD video even, but I guess I just expected more. If I have to be in the same room to be able to stream HD video, it doesn't seem to do the job. This is the first adapter that I've used on the ac protocol... so this might be par for the course... and if so, then the course is disappointing.

This was exactly what I was looking for.I was trying to get away from caffeine drinks in the morning as I’ve really been watching my calories lately. I dropped cokes months ago – and recently stopped drinking Red Bulls. I’ve been using this to slowly transition off of Starbuck’s on weekdays, and I’ve seen positive results.I only take one pill in the a.m., and try not to consume any caffeine after that. So far my body has agreed with this. No jitters and overall a fairly rejuvenated morning/afternoon.A small bonus is the 8% recommended daily allowance of calcium. I have been watching all food intake for months and I don’t see any added weight-loss bonus as a result (nor was I really expecting any). But I am definitely just as alert in the morning than before. No side effects.

genre: scifi romancesetting: post zombie apocolypse Earthformat: part 3 of 5 serial; must read in orderThis book picks up where part 2 left off: with Max and Jack responding to a major attack. Like the previous two parts, this is an action packed story that takes place over a short time (about one day) and includes fascinating worldbuilding. The story focuses on Max and Emma, plus a few new people from the cyborg base and nearby human outpost under attack.Good characterization, consistent plot, highly recommended. Very few typos.

genre: fantasy, erotica, romancesetting: alternate modern dayformat: stand aloneThis book stars Ann, a young lady fresh out of college. The main plot joins her with her three attractive men to do good deeds. There is a weak romantic/erotic subplot (menage) between him & him & him & her, thus the title and cover art.The best aspect of the book was the portrayal of Ann at work with a nasty boss (female). Ann manages to be assertive without getting nasty or aggressive, and I thought that those passages were a wonderful role model for us all. The second best aspect of the book was the creative magic system and curse terms. Those bought this book the 2nd star, where otherwise I would have rated this book 1 star.Now, for the negatives. Expect anti-military plot elements, no emotions (which makes it really hard to buy into the romance), explicit erotica (which somehow is still boring), over-the-top goody two shoes good deeds (nice but again pretty boring to read about), an amazingly bad  portrayal of soldiers (the author has obviously spent no time with any enlisted man or officer), and a lackluster romance (it reads like a business arrangement or friendship). The dialog is excellent between Ann and her boss, but bad between Ann and her three guys. There is no padding, but the book does have quite a few pages of links to the author's other novellas.

genre: paranormal romance, eroticasetting: Earth, alien worldformat: standalone, short storyThis book is worth reading for the prologue alone, which describes the leading lady. What follows is a sweet romance, well written. Nicely developed characters & good dialog. No padding (book spans all pages); no trigger warnings.

genre paranormal romance, eroticasetting modern dayformat standaloneThis tired rewrite starts strong and peters out half way through. Though it has a good opening, the conflict is resolved about 1/3 of the way through and the rest is tedious padding--mostly sex. No climax, and her psychic ability only appears in the opening sequence.Only recommended if the price drops to $3.

The colors are muted, more so that I expect from Cactus Bay and rather bland. The pattern is all over front & back. Sparkles limited to middle front area. Looks more fun in the picture than in person.

genre: scifi romance, menage eroticasetting: future, Earth & alternate planetformat: stand alone novelIn what can best be described as an arranged marriage, a vapid young lady from Earth marries two brainless politicians from another planet. The strength of the book probably lies with describing one man's amazingly posh house and what it is like for her to suddenly live in the lap of luxury. The personalities and situations of the three main characters are interesting and showcase the author's potential.All three main characters are TSTL. The villain is stereotypical and obvious; metaphorically speaking, he twirls his mustache and chuckles evilly, while the leading thee look around oblivious. This is really obnoxious, and my biggest complaint with the book. Expect a meandering, unfocused plot. The entire presentation was somewhat juvenile, which seems more likely to appeal to the sort of young reader who probably isn't interested in a menage romance / erotica.

genre: paranormal fantasy, contemporary, romantic subplotsetting: alternate earthformat: sequel (not standalone)The plot summary and free sample read like a stand alone romance between him & her. The rest of the book, alas, draws upon a huge number of characters from prior books. The supposed main couple rarely get alone time. They instead spend most of the book waiting while couples and characters and events from prior books play out continuations of prior book plotlines (yawn).Unless you read and loved all prior books, do not bother with this book.

genre scifi, romancesetting future spaceshipformat standalone novellaThis entirely forgetable scifi romance stars an egotistcal pirate, his rather one dimensional sweetheart, and an argumentative space captain. It makes a better scifi than romance, and has some but minimal erotica. Forgettable but an okay read.

genre: scifi, romancesetting: alternate modern day, other worldformat: unclear, can be read as standaloneAliens have conquored the Earth and part of their terms is the surrender of a few 21 yr old women each year to be slaves. This story follows one such woman as she suffers the heartbreak of selection, and learns what it really means to love.I thought the ending was perfect. This book can be read as a standalone novel, but is fertile ground for a sequel. We will have to see what the author plans.Strengths are emotional development, characterization, plot, climax, and internal consistency. I particularly liked our hero, and did not mind that he is a late arival in the plot. I am seldom so wowed by a romance novel.No triggers / warnings; some erotica.

genre: paranormal romancesetting: alternate modern dayformat: sequel, only of interest if prior books have been readThis is a sweet sequel that centers on recovering from painful past family issues and differences between a marriage and a werewolf's mating tradition.It is a feel good book with two basic issues. 1st, this sequel is totally of no interest unless you have read most of the author's prior books. I think those are better than this one, in any case. 2nd, there is no reread potential.This is well worth a Kindle Unlimited download, but not innovative enough to justify ought-right purchase in my opinion.

Genre: scifi, romance, eroticaSetting: spaceship, alien planetFormat: serial (currently unfinished) but can be read as a standalone novelA young lady is kidnapped by aliens and put into a cell with another alien. The story focuses on their time together in that cell & eventual escape. This is a unique romance in that they don't have a language in common and come from very different cultures.This is a serial, however it nonetheless contains a stand-alone plot with a climax & resolution & everything, and so can be read as a standalone novel.

Genre: romance, scifi, eroticaSetting: future, space ships & foreign planetsFormat: stand alone novelThis scifi / romance stars an adventurous lady who, at the opening of the book, is stealing a spaceship from a group of bandits as part of her escape from them. On board, she finds a man they have mind wiped and enslaved. The bandits pursue, which triggers a series of interesting adventures as the couple flee from place to place. Meanwhile, he grows from a brainwashed and obedient servant into the sort of guy you would want as a husband and lover.What I loved about this book is the strong plot and personal growth. Many authors have one theme and are seemingly too uncreative to do anything but repeat the same events over & over & over. That is not the case here. The setting changes, but also what is happening truly changes, as do the two characters and their relationship. The book includes some events that would be terribly embarrassing in real life, but instead serve as light hearted erotica.My only complaint is that the author has not yet written anything else. Bummer.

This PNR stars about a dozen different strangers in an overly complicated arrangement of werewolf packs & marraiges & siblings & friends. It is as exhausting as trying to folow the conversations at a stranger's family reunion, and about as unrewarding. More of a drama than a romance and focused on too many people, I cannot recomend it.

This PNR could have been excellent.Instead, the leading lady is beyond TSTL. Here is her thought process every time a dangerous group of thugs wants to hurt her:  I'm safe here under guard, I hate being guarded, I must assert my independence by sneaking away from my guards and wandering around in dark alleys by myself.Her behavior qualifies in my opinion as criminally negligent, endangering her babies' lives. Three times! She lies to her allies and is not capable of learning from past mistakes. Her mind boggling stupidity results in her babies being born very prematurely, likely causing damage on top of her irresponsible choice to drink caffeine and alcohol during pregnancy. I could be wrong about the alcohol, but it sure seemed that she served everyone, herself included. She shows the total lack of judgement and selfishness of a maladjusted three year old, or maybe an out if control / rebellious teen in desperate need of therapy. If it were just her life on the line, I could look past this, but not when she is pregnant and risking her babies at such an incredibly vulnerable time. That is just plain wrong.If you can ignore her appalling behavior (and I can't), the writing quality is good and the universe is interesting. The leading man is interesting, complex, hot, and brave enough to admit when he is wrong.

This is intended to be a cutsie PNR about a modern woman, BBW, and her prince charming. Alas, she is the sort of gal with unrealistic expectations who expects her guy to read her mind, be perfect, and appologise when thay argue regardless of who is wrong. Ugh! I hated her.

Genre: fantasySetting: magical alternate earth of the past, think Tolkien or EddingsFormat: standaloneIt is a pleasure to review a rare book that can actually rate 5-stars. We open to a teenager (half human, half orc) who struggles with poor treatment as a serf. A series of unlikely events throw him into a fun series of fantasy adventures. Along the way, he makes a few unlikely friends, and though I am often skeptical of such "fantasy group" plots, this one really works very well. Each character is well developed and quite interesting in their own right--and not always present, to my relief. Good pacing, good writing, creative events, and altogether worth the purchase price.

Genre: scifi romanceSetting: outer spaceFormat: standaloneThe book summary on plot is accurate. A lady pilot on the loosing side of a battle is pulled into treacherous orbit around a black hole, along with an enemy ship.The writing & plot quality were average for a Kindle Unlimited offering, which is to say 2 stars. This novella offers nothing special, but it was an okay light read.

Genre: paranormal romanceSetting: alternate modern dayFormat: standaloneThe plot, setting and characterization were poor, and the writing quality not good enough to make up for that lack. Book summary is accurate.

After reading this book (or trying to), I just don't understand the plethora of 5-star reviews. Sorry, but this just is not a terribly good book. The best I can say for it is read this only if you have Kindle Unlimited for the month and can justify that $10 with other books.

Genre: fantasy, paranormal romanceSetting: alternate modern dayFormat: standaloneThis is part of a set of loosely related books in the same universe, each in the same small town. Each stars a man from a group of hot shape changing men who have recently moved to that town. The standard opening applies: the guy meets the perfect woman for him (instant love) and pursues her.This book starts strong, with the leading lady having a crush on John (one of the guys), but she hasn't met him yet. She has an interesting history of jumping into relationships with hot guys that turn out to be lousy choices, and her inner dialog is really fun. Alas, that fun mood is only in the first chapter or so; I guess it was too much effort to write. After that, the plot devolves into her "I am not worthy" depressing ramblings and his lackluster pursuit. The villain is a Kelpie who definitely steals the show, being far more interesting than either H or h.I thought the 1st and 3rd books in this universe both much better than this one.

Genre: fantasy (some romance & erotica)Setting: alternate historyFormat: standaloneThis book is first & foremost a fantasy adventure. Each of the three main characters has an interesting set of abilities, and the world is well developed with many fantasy elements and interesting tidbits. The pacing is slow, and the romance really more of a subplot than the main event. Expect a very light hearted fantasy story with a light side of ménage romance.Personally, I found the pacing to be too slow. I stopped reading out of disinterest, as I prefer a faster paced book. However, I think this book would be enjoyable for someone who enjoys that slower pace.

Genre: fantasy, romance, eroticaSetting: alternate modern dayFormat: standaloneThis book contains two novellas. Neither one is terribly outstanding, and both will be better reading experiences if you don't expect 4- or 5-star books. These novellas lack the innovation and charm of Dohner's earlier writing, with her daring plots that pushed the reader's comfort zone. As happens with most authors, the technical aspects of writing have improved with time, while the plots have devolved into low-risk standard plots. These two novellas are good enough to provide an enjoyable read, if you don't expect too much. Think "Harlequin" in a paranormal romance.The first novella is a sweet romance that brings together a widow and widower, both grieving for their losses. The strength of this story is for that interpersonal drama of healing past wounds, and a bit of interesting dynamic of how the New Species "date." This was the better idea, but too sad for me.The second novella is a "second chance at love" story. It has an interesting premise. The leading lady was effectively raised as per a New Species, and is just released. Her behavior and past is fascinating. Alas, her romance is pretty dull stuff. It would have made a better book if either her romance was eliminated entirely or she ended up with a different guy. Warning: contains rape and a slew of post sexual assault issues. Not the happiest of stories, though it improves in mood as the plot winds to a slow and lackluster close.

Genre: scifi, romanceSetting: future, space stations & spaceships & alien worldFormat: 6th piece of a 6 part serialThis book brings to a close a 6 part serial. The ending was nice in that it brought all of the plot lines together into a satisfactory conclusion, and gives us our first really "happy" encounter between him & her. Taken as a whole, I would recommend this series for reading on Kindle Unlimited, and give the 6 parts combined an overall rating of 4 stars.

The plot of this book is exactly as the title foretells. It is an erotic encounter between two strangers: casual sex without any expectation of seeing each other. The scifi setting was fascinating, as was the cyborg technology and role in society. That was definitely the best characteristic of the short story, and my enjoyment of this short story was entirely for the scifi aspects. The erotic encounter itself was not as well done, very lackluster. It seemed very abrupt with no apparent attraction beforehand---an obligatory sex scene.

Though I adored the early books in this series, I found the later books so disappointing that I stopped reading entirely. Many prior books were boring multi-view monsters that included scads of alternate views to be "charming" looks into prior characters' lives---but I just found a waste of time & money. (Hint to authors: it isn't charming.) Or, worse, the alternate views described a totally irrelevant alternate plot that in no way connected to the main characters, and thus an actual insult to my spending good money on the book. So when this book started into the multiple view hopping, I got quite nervous.To my immense surprise (and pleasure), the multiple viewpoints in this book actually work together to form an interesting plot that otherwise could not be done. Most conflicts from prior books stemmed from problems that have been resolved in this universe, and instead of dragging things out unnecessarily, the author took a creative and interesting new direction. My only complaints are that this book is unlikely to have good re-read potential; and the leading lady was a bit too prone to melodramatic whining---but that is an issue with most of Singh's leading ladies.

genre: romance, scifi, eroticasetting: spaceshipsformat: standalone novelA female engineer (J--) is assigned to control & manage a dangerously hostile cyborg (R--). Managing a cyborg is her life dream, so J-- is willing to do whatever it takes to make their relationship work. After years of abuse by humans, R-- is reluctantly impressed with J-- ... and wildly attracted.This book contains a wealth of elements that really impressed me. J-- was submissive without being vapid and brainless; she was likable in her own right, with skills and a situation that encouraged sympathy; and her enjoyment in a dominant man was totally believable. (Contrast this with 90% of Amazon D/s romance, where I have to wonder why the lady doesn't seek help from the police!) The plot contains male prejudice without grating; a sexual assault element that worked for me both as an intrinsic plot element and a sincere presentation of surviving assault (very rare!); revenge without sinking into evil; plenty of action and excitement; and well written erotica. The book got me to both laugh out loud and cry, both of which are very rare for an avid reader like myself.The writing was very good, the dialog interesting, and the characters' situation changed often enough to keep the book interesting. The beginning is perhaps a bit slow, but the pacing picks up about half way through. Good cost for the book length, at least with the current $3 asking price.Highly recommended.

genre: dramasetting: contemporaryI don't get the plethora of 4 & 5 star reviews. This book is to a romantic comedy as "Moby Dick" is to action. Not the movie, I mean, but book, which I was obliged to read in highschool. Both are the painfully slow paced books, filled with detailed descriptions, and not much else going for them.

I hate to say it, but the earlier 1- & 3-star reviews are right. This PNR scifi is realy bad. I don't recommend for YA simply because there are a lot of better books out there. Starts with a lot of nasty & nonsensical insults and does not improve.

genre: sci-fi, romance, eroticasetting: outer space, alien planetThis novella is enjoyable due to the interesting characters and creative universe. The leading lady is a cyborg warrior. This is a premise that I usually don't like, yet the author does such a fabulous job writing, that I highly recommend the story to people who may not normally be attracted by that plot premise. She is newly assigned to guard an alien, and the book focuses on their developing relationship.There is erotica toward the end (fairly explicit). The mood is up-beat, hopeful and happy. Though a short read, this novella is great fun and left me wanting to read other books from the author. Good tight plot; well expressed moods & dialog; nice visuals.

genre: romance, sci-fisetting: alternate earthformat: stand alone novelThe premise is absurd yet ignorable. Earth is so over polluted as to be dying, yet still overpopulated. Color has inexplicably been destroyed yet somehow candles abound. Rather than being an excuse for the "marry an alien" plot (which would be fine), the author uses this as a stump to preach a lot of "humans are evil" hatred and "we deserve to die" vile nastiness, plus a side of "save the trees" for good measure. Throw in some plot inconsistencies to enable more anti human rants, and half the book is done.The romance itself is lackluster. That plot had strong potential and could have been good. Alas, it was overwhelmed by the political rants and hate speech. My advice to the author: concentrate on sci-fi / romance and keep your political opinions to yourself.

genre: dark eroticasetting: paranormal modern dayThe plot is forced sexual slavery with BDSM: the dark fantasy of a man dominating a woman completely against her wishes. No romance.The author warning is critical. This book starts with a werewolf raping a woman to get her pregnant, and the plot is their later relationship--or rather, his continued actions in that vein, since he decides to enslave her. The writing is skilled, more so than most Kindle Unlimited books.My first complaint is not that beginning, but instead aptly described by the woman about half way through: "You have given me no reason to respect you." And he never does. I had hoped for some personal growth on his part, or at least some consideration for her, but instead it is basically a woman falling in love with her kidnapper / en-slaver, a man who has money yet no redeeming values.  Do not expect personal growth on his part. My second complaint is that she very quickly loves him for abusing her, with no justification or convincing reasons. Being beaten into submission I could understand, that part was obvious, but affection and love? Such over-the-top claims require overwhelming proof, which is not provided. In my opinion, for such a dark erotic fantasy to work, the woman must get something out of the relationship. In this one, as described herein, she gets nothing.Overall: interesting idea, poorly implemented

Genre: paranormal romanceSetting: contemporaryFormat: stand alone novel, short storyThis author excels at setting and characterization. Like the rest of her "BBWitches & Scorching" series, this story is mostly characterization and setting, so I suggest you skip the plot summary (which gives too much away) and just start reading.Since the author asks for "feedback to improve writing," my advice is to work on plot development. The setting and premise of this novella could easily have been built into a fascinating full length novel, with building tension and surprise events...but isn't. The alternative would be to focus on your strengths, and continue to put out paranormal romance novellas. Hey, I'd enjoy reading them, and you'd learn what works and what doesn't. Regardless, the short plotline doesn't impact this book at in particular. It excels at what is promised: a quick, fun read through a paranormal romance.

Genre: drama, paranormal romance, some eroticaSetting: contemporaryFormat: standalone novel, originally released as a 3-part serialThis book is labeled paranormal romance, but is first and foremost a drama. Personally, I loathe drama, because I find it to be massively depressing. This book is no exception. I only recommend it to people who love dramas; think "Chicken soup for the soul". I recommend this book only if you like both drama and romance.Plot: a 21 yr old shapechanger is torn between her dream of being a model, two hot beaus, and picking up after her selfish mom. The paranormal elements were interesting and creative. The book could have easily have been a contemporary drama romance with no menage; most of the plotting & effort went into her introspective coming of age story. Author has potential, but this book is too sad for me.

Genre: romance, scifi, some eroticaSetting: near future Earth, alien planetFormat: stand alone novelThe premise is Armageddon: humans are dying out from disease. An alien race offers Earth a solution: interbreed with us to give your children immunity. The alien prince (future king) chooses a human lady to be his bride, to encourage integration of humans into their society.The author gets my high respect for entirely avoiding political rants. The personalities were interesting and well developed. I liked very much that the leading lady's personality was different from the popular "aggressive heroine" trend: she adapted and compromised to her new situation.  The alien society was fascinating, and that was much of the fun in reading. I didn't always like the leading man, but most of the story is told from her point-of-view, so it is to be expected that we (the reader) naturally take her side on fights. Writing, characterization, setting & plot are improved from West's prior works.

Genre: fantasy, maybe murder mysterySetting: modern with paranormalsBook type: serial ending in a cliffhangerA garden witch breaks up with her boyfriend and he, in a not well thought out move to impress her, turns himself into a wolf and gets stuck. She is trying to get him back to human.The author has an interesting setting but overuses the "I am overworked and tired" ploy. No notable romance, just some drooling over a hot guy. Major mixed signals (or inconsistent character) from the werewolf she turns to for help, but interesting characters otherwise. Interesting universe but slow pace typical of a mystery. The cliffhanger tries to make up for that, but I thought it more annoying than anything. Plot is not as interesting as the universe, which is most of the fun.

Genre: scifi, romance, eroticaSetting: future EarthFormat: Serial divided in 5 mini booksHaving undergone a sweet romance (alas never presented) an angst filled alien dumps his sweetheart. The series of shorts follow their angst, moping, self pitty, and generally inept eventual romance.This book has a slew of problems, starting with the author hiding the reason for their breakup so long that it is impossible to feel pity for our hero. Their govt is pathetically inept, the action plot is resolved by waving a magic wand, and the couple's problems are all caused by lack of communication so extreme as to be less believable than scaly aliens being sexy.The series starts weak, never imprives, and ends poorly. Only recommended as KU. Read one of the author's other series instead.

I got this for the cyborg story, and reading this one first would be a wise choice. Part 1 the cyborg story is great (5-star) and the ending is good enough to satisfy. Both are available on Kindle Unlimited.Cyborg part 1 (4 star)The premise is typical: evil scientists create cyborts, this leads to problems, they try to kill all the cyborgs, and the cyborgs escape to live elsewhere. (Why do the scientists always have to be the bad guys?) What the author does with this premise is unique and fun: a brilliant young doctor (pediatrician) is kidnapped by cyborgs to work for them, and the job is not at all what she expects. The creative & fun parts are personalities: for all their knowledge, the cyborgs are emotionally imature, not having had to deal with emotion & personal choice during their prior enslavement. She ends up falling in love with three guys, and has a few cybernetic surprises and erotic encounters.I wouldn't call this quite a romantic comedy, but it was close. The plot had surprises so unexpected that it kept me engrosed.Genre: scifi, romance, eroticaElements: menage, cyborgsAssessment: read once & forget, very enjoyableVenus part 1 (1 star)This story story is so incredibly bad, that I would never have even given the cyborg story a try if I'd read it first. Wow! After a brief intro, we suffer through endless didactic lectures, preachy sermons about the author's favorite beliefs: human caused global warming is destroying the earth, humans are stupid/violent/liers, the US is worse than other countries, our military is inept, humans are all evil, and any random alien race is ethically superior, la la la. After 17 years of no global warming whatsoever the "scientific evidence" is even weaker than the lame plot: another race invades our solar system, and somehow we are the bad guys for wanting to check out who they are and what their intentions are.Genre: scifi, romance, probably erotica but I didn't get that farElements: menage, alien raceAssessment: avoid at all costs, very insultingI found that book so offensive that I didn't even open the others.

Setting: future, multiple plannetsGenre: romance, erotica, scifi/fantasyHe is leader of one planet / race; she is basically heir to another. The plot is a convoluted romantic seduction that ought to have been erotic, but is ruined by the total lack of communication on both their parts. The entire issue could have been worked out over a pot of tea if either party had been willing to talk. Instead, each had a convoluted scheme to manipulate the other party, establish dominance, and basically get their own way. I couldn't enjoy the romance or erotica due to all of the back room double dealing. It all came across as nasty and backstabbing instead of romantic--especially our hero.Basically, this is a great idea with a few bad elements. Good writing. Good length for the cost. Best read with poor expectations.

Genre: romance, eroticaSetting: modern, paranormalSpecial element: menage, unusual ideas for the shape changing dragonsThis romance stars a lonely young lady who meets two shapechanging dragons. These guys need to marry one lady. They have been burned before in romance, so while one of the guys is enthused the other is reluctant. I found this interplay charming. No tension between the guys.Overall, this was a good but not excellent book, worth reading as kindle unlimited. I don't understand the plethora of 5-star reviews, but I can recommend the download.

Genre: fantasy.Setting: mostly modern day--in the sense that "The Island of Doctor Moroe" or "Terminator" are modern day.Special element: Humor.I found this while looking for a romance novel. There is a romantic sub plot, sort of, but don't buy this book looking for a romance. The real plot is a tongue in cheek plot following a mad scientist's capture of a young lady and her boyfriend. The mad scientist is conducting experiments with robotics, AI, and piecing together creatures from multiple parts (e.g., a shark man). There is violence, but almost cartoon in that it is neither dark nor graphic nor serious, despite being, well, fatal.The writing quality was good quality, as was the editing. The satire did not appeal to me, but I cannot blame the book or author. Books are personal, and this one just wasn't my thing.  If you are looking for satire or fantasy, you will probably enjoy this book more than I did.

This contemporary romance stars a lady who just had the worst of weeks, and abandons her life to start anew. Her car breaking down lands her in a storybook ideal date with 3 guys. They have a dog, a perfect county fair, a white picket fence house, rediculously hot bodies, and perfect families--except for one perfectly tragic background, to add melodrama. She is the perfect damsel in distres: rich, beautiful, and easily distracted from her melodramatic woes.My big problem was the juvenile implementation, with rambling emotional musings and over the top revenge on the cheating ex. Read like it was aimed at teen readers. As a mature reader, this style really turned me off.Includes copious man on man eroticism, and some men on woman eroticism. Good editing. Okay dialog.Not an awful book, but the elements did not work for me.

This is a PNR urban romance, but the PNR part seems to be just tossing random animal names around.He and she are coworkers. She wants to date him. He moons after her, wanting to date her but adamantly avoiding her. This basic scene repeats about 50 times in the 1st half of the book. Yawn. For a supposed romance novel, the romance is really minimal and appears exteremely late in this slow paced & repetitous book.The backdrop plots are a murder investigation that goes nowhere (do not expect mystery or clues) and him getting framed, which is pretty easy since his whole police force is totally inept. So is he: I am glad he is not investigating murders in my town! The signature scene in the plot summary is a too little too late arival, well after we the reader are bored to tears waiting without hope for something to happen. Even then, with him stuck in her house, the romance is a no show for several long chapters.Not erotic, light humor, decent editing, supposed to be a romance but I just found it too be a boring drama.

My cats prefer the "Kittenator" attachment, however their appreciation is so high that actually getting the mouse away from the cat is difficult.This one (Kiticatterfly) moves in an interesting way, and my cats like the appearance and movement of the toy being pulled. They seem to like the chasing as much as the catching, and are more willing to let go. By trading off play time with brushing, my long haired cat lets me brush the matted fur off his tummy, which is otherwise impossible. At 1 year, he is too wiggly and doesn't like being brushed. This toy is the perfect reward; much better than food.

This is a sequel to "Omega," and the books must be read in order. The genre is scifi/fantasy in an urban setting, with an emphasis on dark fantasy. The grammar, editing, and Kindle formatting are excellent."Beta" suffers all of the typical flaws of the middle book of a trilogy. It does not seem to have its own plot, with theme & elements building to a climax. I had the feeling I could skip straight from "Omega" to "Alpha" without problem."Beta" is composed of individual scenes: interesting vignettes in an interesting but highly depressing universe. Where "Omega" at least gave us false hope for societal improvement, "Beta" is mired in a depressing now. Neither the establishment nor the revolutionists are trying to make life better, and D-- succumbs deeper and deeper into brainwashed obedience to an evil dictator. The book exposes more of their larger society, which just serves to expose the evil and corruption hidden behind a pleasant facade. D-- has no friends, no allies, dubious morals, and a drug addiction. There are no good role models in this book, and frankly that got really depressing too.(To be fair, I found the opposing alpha, R--'s, facade of perfection to be equally disturbing. A good person would not heap rewards on her chosen few while leaving the rest of her race to a cruel fate. She reminded me of a politician: hypnotizing with golden promises while she is talking, but the reality is revealed by her actions.)The writing and world building are almost good enough to make up for these flaws. I finished the book wanting to know what happens next, but hesitant to buy any more of the author's books in case they are all this depressing. If you enjoy dark fantasy, then you will probably enjoy this sequel.

So, the idea of this erotic MFM menage contemporary romance is good. First date of secretly in love people. The implementation alas had two major flaws. 1st, the erotic scenes were all from a man's POV, which does not interest me. 2nd, the entire plot fell apart with the morning after---major ccrash and burn in an explosion of junk plot.Great editing; good writing; decent emotional development.

The other reviewers do a good plot summary, so I will start with the elephant in the room.This book is chocked full with nasty insults aimed at you, the reader. The author is the sort of self rightious liberal who thinks slander against conservatives and other political foes is acceptable behavior. Included are blatant accusations equating pro life, editing a child's TV habits, and running a company to rape, torture, and murder. Being Christian is equated with being a terorist, and the villain is named after a famous CEO. The author repeats his name about every other page to be sure you get the dirty insult.The author waits until after the free sample to start start spouting potty mouthed insults at 50% of the US population, so the free sample is misleading.Buyer beware.If the political opinions and steady stream of insults were deleted, the romance plot itself would have been about 3-star. The plot was a basic "woman & bodyguard" scenario. The conflict between him & her resolved too quickly, resulting in diminished tension.

This is the 4th book in a series. Their ratings in order are about 5, 4, 3, & 2. Start with #1, as it is by far the best of these super soldier romances.I enjoyed greatly having the loose ends tied up nicely (well except for the lame horror movie villain final laugh). However, the main couple is pretty bland. Best read with low expectations.
Nice socks. Good height & fit. Material feels nice. Height is what you would expect from the picture.

I bought this for my daughter, to help her get around her large university campus. It quickly developed two major problems. First, the folding / closing mechanism gets stuck in the open position. So far, brute force allows the unit to be closed, but it is clear this mechanism will fail completely sometime soon. Second, the back wheel's rubber covering is falling off. This is after less than a month of use.

This probably is 3 to 4 stars if you want a M/M erotic romance...which I really don't.The setting is a fantasy future in outer space that feels more fairytale than sci fi. The two lead men are childhood friends who have been enslaved and left caged together while waiting sale. The plot is surprised by love; one of the guys thought himself stictly hetero. Decent erotica and romance if this is your thing. Me? I would not have bought if I knew this was the main plot.About 66% of the way through the book, a woman who had been adamant that she wanted to avoid all romantic and erotic encounters with them is between one page and the next committed as their third. No romance, no building plot. Her plot line is post rape recovery---and a lot of boring whining before her subplot begins. Neither particularly appealed to me.Another subplot is an adventure, creative but amateur writing and not strong enough to stand on its own.Another subplot is erotic encounters of an evil slaver, female, from her point of view. These were really not my thing: forced sex with her male slave.Best read for the M/M erotic romance.

She sneaks into a man's bedroom hoping to seduce him into a relationship, and gets his brother instead. The brother has a crush on her, and doesn't resist the seduction. The morning after leaves her embarrassed and fleeing. Fun premise, but the plot from there goes no where in particular: pretty bland, with no real conflict or erotica.This contemporary romance / erotica is best read as Kindle Unlimited.

This paranormal romance is set in modern day. This is the 2nd in a serial. The prior one wasn't great but showed some promise. This book's plot is totally incoherent and nonsensical. It reads like the author had 20 different plot ideas and just threw them together willy nilly, with no coordination or planning. The leading man is totally unlikable and his personality seems to change at random. The author's strength continues to be portraying the leading lady's anger and hurt from being teased. This (and the lack of an understandable plot) totally ruins any chance of eroticism or romance. The action / adventure is also a bust.

This paranormal romance is set in modern day. The author's strength is portraying the leading lady's anger and hurt from being teased. She is 20, he is her 20 year old step brother, not seen in 5 years. Meeting again, he is a complete slime, to the point that I am surprised Mom and Dad don't call the police and have him evicted from the wedding. The plot goes from there it a minor adventure and totally inexplicable sex encounter between him & her.The plot makes no sense, but in a serial there is the chance that the next book will explain what in this book is a jumbled mess. Unfortunately, book #2 is nearly incoherent, so enjoy this book (or don't) based on what you see: a short story with no good ending.

The plot of this paranormal romance is so complicated that I have no hope of summarizing. The other reviewers do not seem to really try, instead summarizing only one subplot: a menage second chance romance that turned sour for reasons that do not make sense and are never explained to anyones satisfaction. Then everyone seems to just shrug and ignore the whole prior arguement in a fit of inexplicable personality changes.This book starts strong with interesting characters and building romance. Then the author goes nuts adding rediculously complicated plotlines, one after the other, hoping against hope that one or another will inspire you to read the sequel. Meanwhile the romance plotline (the only decent plot) is resolved for no reason between one page and the next. Huh? There is no building tension, no climax, just confusing new "but wait, also this" complications, dumb personality changes, inconsistent worldbuilding, and obligatory erotica. Showing the worst of what a serial can be but shouldn't, this novella's cliffhanger is the least of its problems.Best read with low expectations and Kindle Unlimited. This author shows some promise in worldbuilding, an inability to proofread, and the same 17 second attention span as my cat.

At the current $3 for 20 pages, this short story is terribly over priced. Still, I had already paid for Kindle Unlimited for a month and gave it a try.The plot summary is accurate enough. A single lady notices a space ship crash in her yard, rescues a hurt alien, and has sex with him that day. His description was pretty much a turn off for me. The whole thing is supposed to be erotic, but I didn't find it so. The ending is basically a cliffhanger with no indication of a follow-on story to come.There was a "surprise ending" but I thought it kind of lame. I found the alien's approach to accomplishing his mission to be highly unlikely to succeed in modern USA.

This is a modern paranormal romance, centered on witches & warlocks for once instead of the so popular werewolves or vampires. The plot was basically "forced seduction" with menage. The leading lady is bullied into a menage with two guys by the witch's council. The two guys also put pressure on her.I found the writing to be lackluster and uninteresting. Personally, I think the "forced seduction" plot only works if there is strong conflict within the lady, a mixture of unwilling & eager & enjoyment of being forced. In this book, I did not get that feeling of tension. My stronger emotional response was "no I don't" followed by "whatever".Best if rented under Kindle Unlimited. That way, it doesn't matter if you agree with the 5-star review or my 2-star review; you won't feel cheated.

This is an interesting variant of the evil scientist plot. She is a soldier in training to be a super soldier with high tech implants. He is a captured vamoire whose blood is the last ingredient needed. But the scientists did not count on the odd effects of his blood.Ending peters out into nothing instead of a climax. No explanation of why she works willing for an evil company. Lots of erotica, but frankly the early action is better. Lame ending left me unsatisfied.

This futhre romance has an interesting premise. Two hot guys are ageless due to nanobots, illegal experiments that left them with a tortured past. They were in an unhappy mairrage with a lady long ago, seemingly the guys at fault. Much later, she is cloned and starts to remember this prior, unhappy life. The guys find her by chance, and want a second chance at love. She is not so enthused.Besides the angst, my biggest problem is that they treat her as a continuation of their late wife insted of her own person. She complains of this and they never change. Also they are beyond dominant and into pushy.Erotic menage, silly male dominant society at the end.

I liked the Cinderella story premise in this contemporary romance. The sex club idea worked surprisingly well.The big problem is that the leading lady does not own up to her own mistakes & failings. When an argument occurs between him & her, she demands that he accept all blame and beg piteously for forgiveness. Meanwhile she refuses to admit to her own share of the blame, of which there was plenty; do not buy her "I am perfect" self delusion. All sub-characters enable and support this very bad behavior. Terrible role model, and he would be better off without her. I've met women like her and none are happily married.That incident aside, this book contains a lot if men bashing prose. Wow, that gets old.If men bashing is not a trigger for you (as it obviously is for me), then add 2-stars to my rating. Best read as kindle unlimited, if you can justify the monthly fee with a few other books.*** SPOILER ***Here's the incident. A friend of the rich boss runs a sex club. Everyone is anonymous, wears masks, takes a pseudonym, and communicates by texting. Couples meet to flirt & have sex. Delilah goes there and ends up having sex with her boss, Nick. Neither of them recognize each other, and they have a 2-month affair that way (texting, anonymous sex). Nick recognizes Delilah at some point and breaks off the affair, uncertain what to do. Despite this, he tries to protect her feelings--by stopping the affair, by not telling her who is who, etc.The friend then breaks his company policy and spills the beans for no apparent reason---with the lame claim that it was all "obvious" and he "thought they knew". Yeah, right. Friend saw the books of who is who every day and that's the only reason that makes sense as to why he knew. The author made it very, very clear that both of their identities were extremely well hidden, Delilah's in particular, so this is very stupid. Friend also gets upset when Nick is mad at him. Um, duh? Why would anyone trust this company again? Worse, Nick is expected to apologize to this friend!!!Basically, this is my first pet peeve. Friend acts poorly and everyone gives him a pass. Grrr.The bigger problem is Delilah's reaction. The rules she agreed to (enthusiastically) was sex with a stranger. If her boss had continued the affair, I could see her being mad. He did the right thing. People go there for the thrill of an anonymous sex partner, not to learn who it was.But no, Delilah is not mature enough to take such responsibility for her own actions. She is the sort of woman who demands her man apologizes profusely for every argument and never admits fault. This is the behavior that I could not stand, and it ruined the entire book for me. She was 100% willing to do have anonymous sex, so she is to blame for her partner being someone she knew. Instead of being honest and saying that she is upset to have had sex with her boss, or that she is upset Nick did not tell her when he figured out who she was, Delilah claims a lame, "I'm upset because you continued to be a good friend to me at work." Seriously!To rub salt into the wound (so to speak), everyone in the book joins into the "let's bash Nick" brigade: Nick's friend, Delilah's girlfriend, etc. So the message is basically sexist (anti-men). Other sexist incidents occur, but none so blatant.*** End of Spoiler ***

Like another 1-star reviewer said, I cannot recommend this book to anyone. The leading lady is systematically abused by her boyfriend and raped with his help. She stays with her rapist willingly, when she could easily leave in a totally normal US city, before any paranormal stuff starts. Bad role modeling, non romantic. Not erotic.

I enjoy reading novellas from new authors, including people who have never written a book before. That said, many such stories are not worth reading and I am sorry to say that I think this book falls into that category. The writing quality shows promise yet needs work.The setting is the future, an after apocalypse Earth with walled cities, werewolves, and shape changing dragons. The world is interesting enough to be worth the read. The leaders of various city-states make plenty of stupid or nonsensical decisions, but I suggest you ignore these and enjoy the world.The plot is a straight romance, where the leading lady is being wooed by two men. This is not a menage. Neither is this erotica. The lady jumps into sex quickly and with no reservations; and by personality she comes across as being kind hearted but with little judgement or wisdom. The reviewer who said "juvenile and silly" describes her personality perfectly.Faux violence (poorly described; take a few martial arts courses if you want to write better prose). Various sex scenes, but I didn't find them erotic. Stand alone novel. Overpriced for the quality, but not for the length. Best read as a Kindle Unlimited download.

This is an erotic short story staring werewolves and group sex. She is an innocent but willing participant in a surprisingly repetitive sex magic ritual involving a whole bunch of male werewolves. I found the writing a bit boring, the erotica unconvincing, and the romance even less convincing. I could only recommend this if you have already justified your Kindle Unlimited $10 for the month with other books.

I respect the author for trying to write an erotic story around centaurs. Since I already had Kindle Unlimited for a month, I thought it would be worth reading. I ended up skimming. The price is too high and length too short for you to consider this unless you've already justified Kindle Unlimited's $10/month already.The setting is fantasy. She is married off to an older man for political reasons. Centaurs at the wedding feast kidnap her for erotic purposes. My conclusion was that no one else has tried this as the basis for a romance or erotica for the good reason that it isn't an erotic or romantic premise. The "how would that work" question was IMO boring, but I won't spoil the only real surprise in this book.

This paranormal romance is massively overpriced at $9. If you are considering justify paying $10 for Kindle Unlimited based on this book, I would value it at $2 to $3.He is a vampire, imprisoned by evil scientists. She is also imprisoned by the evil scientists, and he is over-the-top attracted to her. Her super powers are fascinating, and the main value of the book is finding out about them. Other than that, the book is massively repetitive, and just not creative enough to maintain interest. His first escape attempt is TSTL, making no sense given his vast experience and the severity of the situation. I get her emotional influence on him, but this is still too lame for words. No one that dumb and with that little tactical sense would live to be 1000 years.Excellent editing. Interesting universe. Repetitive plot. Lots of filler. Good romance.  My main disappointment was too much failed potential.

This is a fantasy / alternate modern day paranormal. The leading lady is very angry, and that is the emotion best conveyed by the book. She is an orphan raised to be sold off to a shape changer as a wife / concubine / breeder. The plot is supposed to be a romance, but her constant anger was a total turnoff for me. If in today's world, she would wear goth and run away from home to spite her parents.The fantasy world is creative. The editing is decent. This is a serial in the sense of containing a partial story without a fully developed plot.

At $4 for 90 pages, this collection of related short stories is terribly overpriced. The setting is contemporary. A single woman has a series of erotic encounters with two handsome guys. There is a plot, sort of, but like many Jackie Chan movies, the plot is cobbled together to make the erotic scenes fit---which is to say, a very low quality plot. The only erotic scene that I thought worth the read was the first one. Most of the book just isn't that well written.Best use: if you have Kindle Unlimited for the month already and want some erotic menage.

This bundle contains a series of unrelated short stories. Each is set in modern day, staring a young lady who has casual sex with two or more strangers (all men). The intent is that all of the settings are naughty yet exciting fantasies. The first one (in the free intro) has a lot of very negative emotions and actions throughout, and ends in a particularly icky way. Two of the stories were pretty good--one where a lady hired a company to enact her fantasy, and another where a lady's car broke down, resulting in an erotic evening.All of these are erotic vignettes with explicit sex. There is no romance or expectation of commitment. No M/M action; the F is always the focus of events. Some swearing.

These are 6 novellas, all with about the same story. Each stars a immortal werewolf warrior living in modern day and fighting evil werewolves. Each meets his mate amidst romance, action, and erotica. HEA, no cliffhangers, good editing, happy mood. Best read separately in time due to similarities. Minimal reread potential.

This contemporary romance stars a commitment scared man and a workaholic woman. Both are filled with angst and insecure. There are some good atraction scenes at the begining, but these lead to nothing and the whole story disolves into angst.The plot quality steadily degrades as the book progresses.Excelent editing; standalone plot.

This scifi romance stars a totalitarian man who must have his woman's constant obedience, even in her thoughts. She is seemingly only aroused by pain.She claims to want to make her own decisions. His response is always passive aggression and then punishing her if she does anything except cower in their bedroom--and she is okay with this. His punishment is BDSM then sex (repetitive, I thought), and apparently his mystic powers leave her brainwashed into standing up for herself less and less. She is always the one to compromise--or more fairly put, yield, such as to accept his chauvinistic society's rules. This is supposedly his desire to protect yet always came across to me as a bully's power play and subjugation of women.Unless you really like BDSM, I would skip this novel. The 1st book in series is hugely better.

This is the sort of serial where each book is interesting but does not have a stand alone plot and ends in a cliffhanger. This is a future paranormal, and this piece is all world building with no erotica, no sex, and barest hints of romance to come. The setting is creative and interesting. The length is a bit short for $0.99 as this 70 page book ends at 85%. The writing quality and editing are good.Plot of this piece is spunky lady fights back in a seemingly hopeless situation, with a surprisingly upbeat mood for all the occasionally nasty setting element. Some preaching about killing animals for meat is immoral. Mild "we are destroying the world" preaching also.

While the basic PNR plot was fine, the prose itself was so bland that I could not get into the story. I did not feel the emotions, see the visuals, or enjoy the setting. The whole experience felt like watching a movie on an overseas flight on those tiny TVs supplied by some of the big airplanes on the seat in front of you (video on demand). The loud nose of the airplane drowns out the music and makes it difficult to hear what people say; the screen is tiny and low quality so the picture looks faded and grainy; and the constant interruptions to the video stream make it difficult to keep paying attention regardless of the movie's original quality. That is how this book felt to me. It could have been good, but the implementation was too lackluster to capture my attention.

This regency romance emphasizes angst and condemning companies as evil. I cannot recommend it unless you want a hefty dose of drama with your romance, and you could see yourself connecting with a guy over the sexy activity of setting up a union.

The first story is about 1/3 of the book and a sweet & sexy romantic menage of an ex con (woman) and three hot guys at a remote ranch. It is likely worth the purchase price of (currently) $1.The others are casual sex with stranger stories and just not my thing. They all take place at a club where people have sexual menage encounters with strangers based on names drawn from a hat. Some people rig the draw, but this intimate encounter is still between strangers. I did not think these were as well written as the first story, but that could be my lack of interest talking.

I bought some of these while on a business trip in Switzerland, and they are delicious. Yes, they are worth the high price: very smooth chocolate, mild tasting, no corn syrup. Swiss chocolate has a very low melting temperature, so I would get expedited shipping in summer; they are very likely to melt if shipped in warm weather.

I bought some of these while on a business trip in Switzerland, and they are delicious. Yes, they are worth the high price: very smooth chocolate, mild tasting, no corn syrup. Swiss chocolate has a very low melting temperature, so I would get expedited shipping in summer; the "melted" review was probably a summer purchase.

This is the 4th in a series, and pointless to read unless you have read the prior three. The first book is free.This PNR picks up where the prior left off, just after the couple's mating, and contains a nice mix of romance, action, erotica and world building. There are quite a few open plot lines floating around (e.g., his son, the ocean sick, suspicious Councilman, his crazy ex, her old life, how his blood has changed her). This book focuses on the son while showing interesting progress on the others. Regardless being in a series, this book had enough of a plot/climax of its own to be satisfying. The ending is fabulous, and left me eager to read the fifth book. I vastly prefer such a promise of fun future events to cliffhangers.I thought this better than the last book. I appreciated the new setting changes and unexpected developments after their mating. I think a plot summary would be a disservice, because the plot surprises are the fun part of this series. Weaknesses are minimal personal growth and unclear physical descriptions--how exactly is he configured down there?This book has some BDSM elements, described from a fresh perspective. The creative "why and how" elements are refreshing to read since most BDSM books are boringly similar. Even if you aren't into BDSM, I encourage you to try the series.

This is not a stand alone book, and the main plot line is not a romance. The free sample on Amazon matches the book summary; and that would have been a fun book. Unfortunately, this is not that book.This is a multi-view book that hops between many viewpoints. Most of these viewpoints assume that the reader has read a string of prior books and remembers them well. Since I had only read one of the author's prior novels (her first in this universe), none of the alternate viewpoints made sense and it certainly wasn't fun to read. There doesn't seem to be much romance here, being mainly focused on some sort of continuing adventure involving mainly characters from prior novels. The three characters mentioned in the book summary are seldom present.If you have read all prior books, this might be fun to read as the 4- and 5-star reviewers claim. Otherwise, buyer beware.
