This book reads like the author cobbled together disparate scenes in a rush to print and profit. The spunky chick from the free intro disappears almost immediately, replaced with a compliant pushover. Her panic over being teleported vanishes into thin air along with her gun. The plot is lame and nonsensical. Several times, the main characters are guilt tripped into doing something risky and stupid and illogical just to keep the plot moving. There is no tension between the him & her & him, so the romance and erotic elements fall flat. Most of the scenes read like lame re-writes of the prior four books. Finally, this book is way overpriced at $3 for an approximately 100 page novella.If you are a first time reader, I recommend you give the first book in this series a try.As an added complaint, the lead lady is supposed to be a handgun instructor. Her unsafe behavior with a handgun was highly offensive. My father was a hunter, so I met many hunters and gun safety instructors in my youth. All of them would be appalled at her behavior and loud spoken in their disapproval. I cannot imagine any shooting range in the US letting her teach. She plays out like a straw man (i.e., a fictional gun owner who behaves poorly to make gun owners look bad).

For genre, this is a modern day paranormal romance scifi. An ordinary young lady is kidnapped by aliens from today's Earth and sold into slavery. The book starts with her on a mining planet, horridly mistreated yet still resisting. The miners are to fight for their overlord's entertainment, and the winner gets her to do with as he wants (to her horror). The plot as it progresses from there is a mixture of scifi, adventure, romance, erotica, action, and introspection. I know that sounds like a lot of plot elements to mix together, but it all works. I found the plot to be well crafted and filled with wonderful surprises, so I won't go into much detail there. Let me just say that the book does not all take place on the mining slave planet. The setting changes often enough to be wonderfully entertaining.This story is a wonderful surprise in that it breaks from the typical romance plots. The strongest element of this book was the settings, and in particular the different cultures. The plot centers largely around culture conflicts, some of which are bold elements where one culture thinks the other culture's approach to sexual relations and courtship are downright wrong. All parties involved need to think through their morals and compromise to make their relationships work. I greatly enjoyed that the characters did this, instead of just throwing hissy fits like so many lazy writers. Now this sounds like a lot of thinking, but there is enough action and erotica to keep the pace lively.Here are a few warnings, though these may be elements you will enjoy to read about. Some interactions in the book can be interpreted as rape, so sexual assault survivors may want to avoid this book. I typically avoid such books like the plague, but I liked this book better for including this plot element, treating it in a very different and unique way, and not having the leading lady spend the whole rest of the book obsessing in depressed ruminations over the issue. The consequence is making you, the reader, have to think about morals and culture, which is a major theme. Another issue is that the book contains menage. This was very tastefully done, so that I do not think readers should avoid the book based on that.The book length is long; the price for length is currently very reasonable ($5 for 600+ pages); the writing quality is excellent; and the basic story elements are all done well (theme, characterization, plot, climax, resolution, etc.).I am greatly looking forward to the next book, "Thunder Claw."

Crest Pro-Health HD Two-Step Toothpaste System is a two-step tooth-cleaning process that requires minimal time to complete. The steps are simple: brush with the fluoride toothpaste for one minute, spit (but do not rinse), then brush with the hydrogen peroxide gel for an additional minute. The expectation is that you will use the system morning and night, totaling four minutes a day of oral care (not including flossing and all the other stuff you might or might not do).I can honestly say that my teeth have never felt cleaner than when I used this system with my Spinbrush classic. My teeth literally felt like perfectly buffed pearls in my mouth. I can only imagine how well the system works with one of the more high-tech brushes (sonic) applying the pastes.My complaint is in regard to the whitening claim. I literally saw no change in how white my teeth were even after weeks of use. This may be because I have used Crest Whitestrips within the past two years, or it may just be that whatever has caused the discoloration of my teeth isn't affected by hydrogen peroxide. Whatever the case, I can't recommend this whitening toothpaste for its whitening properties - though it still does an impressive job of cleaning teeth.

_Fly Casual_ is a 96-page full color sourcebook for the Star Wars Edge of the Empire (EotE) roleplaying game (RPG) that focuses on the Smuggler career path. It contains three new player races (Falleen, Gotal, and Quarren), three new Smuggler specializations (Charmer, Gambler, and Gunslinger), two new signature abilities (Narrow Escape and Unmatched Fortune), new equipment, new vehicles, and a few additional rule expansions. The sourcebook is completely compatible with Fantasy Flight's other Star Wars RPGs Age of Rebellion and Force and Destiny.There was a lot of expectation for this book among players. While smugglers are some of the most interesting characters in the Star Wars movies and books, their treatment in EotE is generally considered less than stellar. Sadly, this book does not enhance the game very much for current smuggler characters. There are very few new rules or pieces of equipment in it that I will be referencing with any regularity. In fact, the recently released _Lords of Nal Hutta_ sourcebook actually provides better support for smugglers, as well as more useful equipment and information. Still, there are some interesting parts to the Fly Casual sourcebook, and its usefulness can not be completely discounted.New Races/Species. The racial choices are one of the highlights of this book, and definitely a reason to consider purchasing it. The Falleen (green-skinned pheromone-releasing aliens) and the Quarren (squid-faced rivals of the Mon Calamari) are both exciting choices with rich lore, and even Gotal (horn-headed energy-sensing beings) prove to be of note. Any of these races would make excellent choices for player characters, and are worth a look.Signature Abilities. The "super powers" of the career path fit well with the smugglers, and are not horribly overpowered. "Unmatched Fortune" gives players the ability to change a dice roll, and "Narrow Escape" lets them flee from combat. Of the two abilities, Narrow Escape does feel the weakest, and will have a tendency to be overruled by the GM.Ship Modifications. As one would expect, there are a decent number of vehicle modifications in this book (9 mods in all). Some, like the Rapid Cargo Evacuation Chute, are pretty specific to smugglers; others, like the astrogation droid brain, are useful for any career or situation.Additional rules and information includes:The Charmer, Gambler, and Gunslinger specializations. Sadly, none of these specializations have much to do with being a smuggler. The Charmer takes the unique (at least in EotE) strain-healing mechanic of the Politico and adds some debuffs in. The Gambler can alter dice rolls and change results. The Gunslinger is more of a Bounty Hunter or Hired Gun - basically, an old-West-style trick shooter/quickdraw artist (think Jango Fett). None of these have anything but a superficial connection to moving cargo (what a smuggler does), and would have been better in the sourcebooks of other career paths.New Vehicles and Ships. Vehicles include the TAGGECO Cargohopper speeder, Starhawk Speeder Bike, Sunrunner ZX Landspeeder, XG-1 Star Wing assault gunboat, Imperial Customs Frigate, VT-49 Decimator, CEC WUD-500 Star Yacht, Starlight Light Freighter, YKL-37R Nova Courier, GX1 Short Hauler, BAUDO-Class Star Yacht, Mobquet Medium Transport, Gozanti-Class Armed Transport, Corellispace Gymsnor-3 Light Freighter, Gymsnor-4, HWK-1000 Light Freighter, YT-2000 Light Freighter, Interdictor Heavy Cruiser, and Golan 1 Space Defense Platform.Rating: 3 out of 5 stars. Excellent races for the EotE game, but not enough focus on useful additions for the smuggler career path.

The Star Wars: Imperial Assault Dice Pack contains 11 dice for use in Fantasy Flight's Imperial Assault miniature game. These dice are not the standard 1-6 most games are played with, but have special symbols and numbers on them that make them useable in Imperial Assault and derived games only. You get two black defense dice, two red melee/damage dice, two blue long range dice, two green midrange dice, two yellow short range dice, and a single white dodge/defense die. They had a suggested retail price of $11.95 on release in late February/early March 2015.There isn't a whole lot to say about these dice. They are identical to the ones that come in the Imperial Assault box set (unless your set had one of those rare misprinted defense dice with circles instead of triangles on it, which would explain why you want new ones). If you want another set to let the players use during a campaign game (only using one set for both sides during said campaign can be a bit annoying), they are currently your only option unless you intend to purchase another boxed set. If you are attempting to get into Imperial Assault "on the cheap" and only purchasing the dice pack and specific miniature expansions... well, it is marginally possible, but you'll still need the cards for a command deck (primarily found in the boxed set) and a partner that can provide the tiles/map to play on. To put it bluntly: that path is not recommended.The dice themselves all have six sides, and are pretty much only good for use in the Imperial Assault game (or throwing at people when you get angry at them, but that can put someone's eye out and get you banned from your local place of play). They can be stacked one on top of the other when you get bored, but 8-sided and 20-sided dice are far more challenging (and, thus, more interesting) to do that with.Rating: 5 out of 5 stars if you play the Imperial Assault miniature game; 0 out of 5 for anyone else.

Pathfinder Battles: Iconic Heroes Set 1 is a box containing six miniatures and six cards for use in both the Pathfinder roleplaying game (the miniatures) and the Pathfinder Adventure Card Game (miniatures and cards). The plastic miniatures come fully painted, and include Valeros the Fighter, Seelah the Paladin, Seoni the Sorcerer, Sajan the Monk, Lini the Druid, and Droogami the Snow Leopard (animal companion). The cards are PACG boons for each character represented in the box (though the Snow Leopard's card is actually an Ally card owned by Lini, giving her two cards). The set is produced by WizKids in conjunction with Paizo, and had a suggested retail price of $29.99 on release in late February/early March of 2015.These items serve multiple roles depending on what game you play. For those that enjoy fantasy roleplaying games or miniature combat, they make very nice looking play pieces. While most people don't actually play the "iconic" characters in the Pathfinder game (there are some exceptions), the miniatures still make very nice representations that players can use, and are certainly worthwhile pieces for any Game Master to own.The greater use for the set, however, is within the Pathfinder Adventure Card Game (PACG). First, the miniatures can take the place of the hero cards within the play area, marking the location of each person in the game. Second, the set provides an additional boon card for each represented character, changing the game experience slightly. None of the cards have shown to be "game breaking" so far, but are a decent perks.Potential buyers will most likely compare these miniatures to the Dungeons and Dragons "Icons of the Realms" starter set released by Wizards of the Coast in July of 2014 at a SRP of $19.99. Both products contain six plastic miniatures representing some of the best known heroes of their respective game universes (Drizzt Do'urden being the big one of the D&D set). Head to head, the D&D miniatures come off at a significantly lower price, but much less detailed in terms of painting and sculpting. That $10 price difference goes to giving the Pathfinder minis things like the whites of eyes and intricate runes on sashes - details someone hand-painting the miniatures might add with a little effort, but certainly a noticeable and significant difference straight out of the box.That's not to say that the Pathfinder miniatures are perfect. There are some inconsistencies in painting (my Lini has an add green paint cast to her face), and there are reports of occasional bent weapons. My friendly local gaming store (FLGS) Art of War in Cincinnati got in four of these initially - of those, two boxes had slight issues due to insufficient packaging (Seelah had come free and was bouncing around inside one box, and Droogami was off its base in another [easy fix with a little glue]). Hopefully, Paizo and Wizkids will secure the miniatures a little better in the next release.Rating: 4.5 out of 5 stars (rounded up to 5). This is a great addition for the Pathfinder Adventure Card Game, as well as a set of nice looking miniatures for general roleplaying game use.Note: This is the first release in a series of Iconic Heroes boxed sets. Set 2 is expected to contain Amiri the Barbarian, Ezren the Wizard, Kyra the Cleric, Merisiel the Rogue, Harsk the Ranger, and Biter the Badger. Set 3 is expected to contain Alahazra the Oracle, Damiel the Alchemist, Imrijka the Inquisitor, Alain the Cavalier, Balazar the Summoner, and Padrig the Eidolon.

_Nursing Student and Career Reference_ by BarCharts is a 300 page full-color book containing information used in the nursing profession. Chapters include Medical Math, Pharmacology, Nursing Assessment, Getting a Job in the Field, and a number of others - all concisely written and full of profession-specific information.This book fills an odd niche area between full NCLEX study guide, textbook, and CliffsNotes reference that both students and professionals will find useful. One example of this would be laboratory blood panel results (p277-279) - the standard results are listed with their ranges and what the abnormals might indicate, but the reader is not overwhelmed with ever single lab result or all possible outcomes. Basically, the book provides the core information someone would need to refresh themselves or get a better understanding of the subject matter, but is not in-depth enough to provide mastery of the subject.Rating: 4 out of 5 stars. You'll still need your textbook and NCLEX study guide, but this reference can make finding and understanding information and certain aspects of the profession much easier.

_Mort(e)_ is science fiction novel written by Robert Repino. It is the tale of a cat, a dog, rapid evolution, and an exploration into what really separates animals from humanity. Comparisons include _Animal Farm_ meets _The Matrix_, but, in all reality, I found _Mort(e)_ to be a significantly unique piece of fiction that is much more complex than an "X meets Y" categorization implies.Contrary to what the fantastical nature of this book might suggest, people thinking about reading _Mort(e)_ should understand that it contains some extremely serious moments. Life, death, love, hate, religion, and the human condition are all touched on within its pages, and that is some heady stuff. At the same time, it is a book about a cat with a gun, so there is definitely some humor and absurdity in it as well. All of this combines together to make a VERY different and, in my opinion, very interesting book that is worth reading. If you like your fiction more on the plausible side and less on the allegorical, however, this is probably a book you should avoid.Rating: 4 out of 5 stars. If you're looking for a book that is different and might make you think, pick this one up today!

The OREI Diamond Enhanced Bass Bluetooth Wireless Speaker is a portable, relatively small (4.7 x 2.8 x 2.2 inches) speaker. It is designed to pair easily with other devices either through the wireless Bluetooth connection or via a more traditional 3.5mm audio cable. While it has numerous other features, one of the most significant is the built-in Lithium-Ion battery (rechargeable via the micro-USB port) which is listed as lasting between 8 and 10 hours per full charge. A 3.5mm male/male audio cable and a micro-USB to USB charging cable were including with my speaker.This is one of the best self-contained portable audio speakers I have ever used. The sound it produces is very clear, and does not "lag behind" my smart devices (example: lips properly syncing with sound on a YouTube video being shown on a phone). The audio is definitely loud enough to be heard for general use, though don't expect it to be loud enough to fill a large room for a party (it is, however, perfect for a dorm room or private office). I have not yet used it through a "full charge" (I charge it nightly), but I have used it for multiple hours straight with no battery issues.Rating: 5 out of 5 stars. Excellent self-contained portable speaker for the money!

The Singer 90S Special Edition with accessories is a modernized version of the traditional sewing machine. It contains such things as computer controls, a (very simple) LCD screen, and a modern lightweight body. It also contains built-in storage and accessory compartments.Coming off of my much older sewing machine, the 90S was a big change. First and foremost, I'm used to a heavier machine that contains a lot more metal (especially in the base) - this one, though, is much lighter (and appears to be made of plastic). While the light weight is generally a good thing for most people, it also makes the machine feel much flimsier. I haven't had any problems with it yet, but my guess is that I'll need to be more careful with this one than the previous, especially when moving it for storage when not in use. We'll see how things go.Other than that, I haven't had too many surprises with the 90S. There are A LOT of new features, but since I generally only sew to hem clothing or make simple costumes (and the occasional pillow), they're wasted on me. It gets the job done for my needs, though it has the potential to do more if I ever intend to press my skills.

I purchased these Utilitech bulbs from a local supplier for my mom when I was at her house in the spring. I had been using GE Reveal CFL Bulbs at my own place, but could not find 100 watt equivalents in that brand (she likes a lot of light). By the time Christmas rolled around, all of the Utilitech bulbs had burned out. Literally. The plastic bases on all of them have browning near the vent/glass sections that looked almost like scorching - this happened no matter where they were located in the house. On the other hand, the single OttLite 100w replacement CFL bulb I got my mom for her crafting area (a place she spends HOURS a day working) was still functioning. This time around, I found the 26w GE Reveal bulb at the store - I'll never use Utilitech again.Rating: 0 stars.. or it would be if Amazon allowed it. I guess I will have to give it 1 star since that is the lowest possible rating.

_Clash of Eagles_ is an alternate history novel written by Alan Smale. It follows the adventures of Praetor Gaius Marcellinus, leader of the massive 33rd Legion, as he explores North America in 1218 A.D. in search of gold for the ever-expanding Roman Empire. It is easily compared to the book/film _Dances with Wolves_, with the obvious difference being the replacement of the Union Army protagonist with a Roman soldier.It starts out slowly. Very slowly. You'd think the experiences of a Roman army visiting North America for the first time would grab the reader, but it is just a bunch of one-dimensional and stereotypical characters stomping around the woods with all that entails. There is some fighting, some things happen, and the situation eventually changes (how's that for a no-spoiler summary? :) ).Here is where the book takes off. The culture clash and technological expansion we see in the second part of the book is very interesting, and where Smale really shines. He's done a lot of research on the subject matter, and uses his imagination to figure out what suddenly adding these elements to a new civilization might do. There are also some small-scale battles that Smale is able to make very exciting, as well as a decent amount of character reflection and development.Then, at the very end of the book, we're back to a boring massive battle and a regression of the characters into one-dimensional beings again. Hooks are left for sequels, so expect at least another book if this one does well.There are a few other problems I have with the book, and they all involve technology. The first is the advanced level of technology the author gives to the Cahokians (primary Native American tribe in the book). Without giving away any spoilers, I just couldn't accept the advances in relation to what was developed in the real world, and had to constantly remind myself that this novel was more of a "fantasy" creation than one of realistic fiction. The second problem involves how the author seems to use whim instead of logic to haphazardly change whether technology will have a significant impact on a situation. In one instance, advanced armor and weapons allow a nearly complete slaughter of enemy forces; a few pages later, they make no difference at all. Such a lack of consistency makes all of the other events also seem implausible.Rating: 3 out of 5 Stars. If you can get through the boring beginning AND accept fantasy-levels of technology in an alternate history novel, there is definitely something worth reading in _Clash of Eagles_.

For years, many masters of the "striking arts" (boxing, Taekwondo, Kempo, etc..) have proclaimed that blows to key areas of the head are far more efficient at knocking an opponent out than others. From boxers talking about the knockout button below the ear and behind the mandible to MMA fighters speaking of the efficiency of flying knees to the temple, such techniques abound. The problem has always been practicing these strikes properly so that they can be used with success - allowing someone to be repeatedly struck in the head so another can learn the correct location and technique simply isn't practical to the partner. Using the lifelike "BOB"-style foam body opponent bags works to an extent, but those are often too bulky and heavy to practice anything other than the basic strikes against a stationary opponent.The Quest Training Allstrike training head is an attempt to fix that problem. It is basically a striking pad shaped like a human head that the trainer sticks his hand inside of (there's a handle inside to help him/her hold it). The student can then practice striking a lifelike head that is moving in a similar way as a normal human head (depending on the skills of the trainer). Believe it or not, this is A LOT different than just striking traditional pads or the stationary BOB, and those using it should see improvement in the pinpoint accuracy of their head strikes relatively quickly with regular (and proper) use.Be warned, though, that the Quest Training Allstrike isn't the answer to all of your training woes with such strikes, and does take some getting used to. Initially, we were holding the head too close to our own bodies during practice - and getting hit by it when the striker popped it too hard or at an unexpected angle. The trainer still has to hold the head out and away from his/her body like a normal striking pad (meaning it is harder to simulate an actual fighter throwing counterstrikes), but can simulate it moving like a real head would in a fight. But it really does help those training with it to improve their head strike accuracy, and should be considered for any gym, dojo, or martial academy that uses such strikes.Rating: 4 out of 5 stars. Definitely a worthwhile investment for those training others to use head strikes.

The OXO Good Grips 16-Ounce Healthy Portions Analog Scale is a portable cooking/meal measuring tool used to weigh out meals and ingredients. Probably most associated with those on very strict portion control diets, these types of scales are also useful for those that tend to be out-and-about when cooking/brewing or that are just looking for a decent kitchen scale that is easily stored. The OXO has a really nice design that screws together for easy transport or unscrews and flips to form a bowl-top for easier measuring.Overall, I am very pleased with my OXO scale, and especially like the compact design. If you are carrying the scale around with you (say, in a bag), though, it tends to be a little noisy - unless you keep the original packing materials. The little cardboard disk that slips into it will stop almost all noise when walking around, and should not be thrown away. In fact, keeping the entire box works well, as there is not a lot of excess space in the original packaging.Keep in mind that this is not an analytical balance, nor is it a digital device - it is a very simple item that works extremely well for what it is. No batteries required, and easily zeroed with a simple turn.Rating: 4 out of 5 Stars. A very nice portable scale!

This free diving mask and snorkel set from U.S. Divers / Aqua Lung America (imported from China according to the packaging) has a significant portion made from silicone, and sports a number of premium features not seen on base models. These include the mask's button-press buckles for easier fitting and pivot/filter top for keeping water out of the snorkel.I wish I would have had my set sooner (I think it would have been perfect for my visit to Dauphin Island), but I was able to put it through some trials. My only significant complaint is that it tended to fog up more than my previous mask, but a little adjustment cleared most of this up in the field. Other than that, I have no complaints about the product, and found it to be a joy to use. Though it has a higher price point than many sets, it is of excellent quality (and also large enough to fit my rather big head, while still being able to adjust down to my girlfriend's size). It is also below the price point of what I would consider the "Prosumer" level, meaning it is an great buy for those either just getting into the hobby or just wanting a quality set for vacation, but not looking to break the bank on something they'll be using only once or twice a year.Note: This mask is currently being listed as a "Silicone Free Diving Mask" - it should, in fact, be listed as a Free Diving Mask MADE OF SILICONE (though some parts are made of glass and/or plastics). That's a selling point - it doesn't stink of rubber and/or latex like older masks (perfect for those allergic to such things), and should (in theory) last a little longer.

Let me preface my review by stating that I have read through a large number of supposed "game programming" books over the past few years, and every single one of them has fallen short. Most of the time, they are just "fluff" books with no real content (no code, no real physics, no explanation of the math) looking to make a quick buck from those interested in making computer games. Sadly, that means my useable knowledge of the subject matter has come from the internet, coworkers (that do most of the actual coding), and using general professional programming books (a great reference, but often a bit broad)._Game Engine Architecture_, Second Edition, is the first REAL book I've seen on the subject. This is not some poorly written, quickly printed piece of junk - it is a full-blown resource for understanding how games are made. Rightly, it focuses on the game engine (the software that creates the game experience), and provides the code examples, explanations, and mathematics so that you can learn HOW to do it yourself (or, more accurately, be part of a team that does it). For many, the information inside will be over their heads initially (do you know how to program in C++? Do you know how to use Visual Studio?), but that just means readers know WHAT TO LEARN in order to make their own games. It is the best book on the subject I have ever seen, and I look forward to putting more of it into practice.Rating: 5 out of 5 stars. THE BOOK to pick up if you want to learn how to program a game.

The George Foreman GRP360R Grill continues the line of clamshell-shaped kitchen appliances made famous by the former world champion boxer back in 1994. This model has a number of useful features, including removable grill plates (that can be cleaned in the dishwasher), a pre-heat light (so you don't start your cooking at the wrong temperature), and (of course) the drip pan that collects the unwanted fat (a familiar feature on these grills). The line's concept is that the fat drips out of the food, slides down the grill's panels, and into the collection pan - making the food cooked in it healthier.To me, the leaner meat concept of the grill is just a nice side-benefit - what I like about it is how easy and quickly it can prepare food. Let me give you an actual example of exactly HOW EASY it is to use: I can put two FROZEN tilapia fillets into it, and IN UNDER FIVE MINUTES the fish is done (generally four-and-a-half minutes for me). Toss on some blackening powder or other seasoning, and you've got yourself an extremely healthy main course. If you've got some fresh salmon or thick-cut tuna steaks, it will work on those, too. Fast. And you can use it on chicken, hamburger, steak, veggie patties, and more!The grill itself is not quite perfect, though. The EXTREMELY short cord can be VERY frustrating, especially for those with only a few outlets in their kitchens. And the device has no off switch, so you have to yank it from the wall every time you want it to cool down. But, with as useful as I'm finding it, the benefits definitely outweigh the drawbacks.Rating: 4 out of 5 stars. An excellent appliance that helps make fast, healthy meals.

_Social eCommerce_ covers the exact subject of the title - how to use electronic and internet resources such as social media to improve your business. It is paperback, roughly 276 pages, and filled with a bunch of new business buzzwords that people not reading these sorts of books have never heard before (but that business people seem to love).I definitely have mixed feelings about this book. It seems written for business professionals that have little idea what social media (or the internet) is. If that's you, buy this book. :) If you're a little bit more social media/tech savvy, there is still a lot of information you might find useful. Each chapter (and they include such titles as "Marketing Strategy: Physical Goods," "Event Promotion," and "Book Promotion") has a number of headings that contain tips and techniques for being successful in that area. This information is not all-encompassing, but usually includes links to websites that have more details. That makes this book a great starting place (especially if you just want a broad understanding of the subject), but not an in-depth resource - you'll need a more focused book/webpage on that specific area if you want to completely understand it. But, at ~276 pages, Social eCommerce does a solid job of providing basics.Rating: 4 out of 5 stars. A respectable starting place for learning about Social eCommerce.

This Farberware New Traditions Nonstick 8-1/2-inch Skillet rises to the high level of quality I have come to expect from Faberware cookware over the years. With a durable (and insulated) handle, stylish red enamel outer coloring, slick nonstick coating, and just general high quality construction, it has all of the qualities I desire from a skillet. I find it more than adequate to use when cooking for myself or when preparing certain side dish items, but the listed 8.5" size can be a bit misleading - the modern-styled "bell-shaped profile" means there is less bottom to cook on, but that just seems to be the style these days. It doesn't seem to negatively impact my cooking, and it can even make it easier when using the spatula in certain instances.This New Traditions product also has a number of features I don't ever see myself using, but should probable list anyway. For instance, it is listed as being oven-safe up to 350 degrees Fahrenheit (good for reheating and certain cooking tricks, but nothing I'd ever use). It supposedly has a limited lifetime warranty (but how often does anyone actually use that?). It probably also works really well when used to fight zombies, but that's another aspect I will (probably) never use. Bottom line: it is a quality skillet of sufficient size when cooking for one (and making certain side dishes/browning things/etc..).Rating: 4 out of 5 Stars. This is fast becoming one of my favorite skillets.

_The Peripheral_ is a subgenre-destroying novel by speculative fiction author William Gibson. It is also extremely hard to describe, other than to say that I consider it the pinnacle of Gibson's work thus far. Take the speculation and edge of of his novel Neuromancer, add the style and flow of the Bridge Trilogy, give it the relevance and polish of his more recent works like Zero History, mix them all together with some lightning and you get _The Peripheral_. It has elements of action, cyberpunk, biopunk, spy fiction, far future SciFi, and more merged into it. Parts are difficult to read (similar to Gibson's earlier works), others flow almost too smoothly; together, it creates an experience beyond the simple reading of a story.Rating: 5 out of 5 stars. It is the next science fiction novel you should read.

The EA6350 Linksys AC1200+ Dual Band Smart Wi-Fi Gigabit Router with USB 3.0 is a mouthful to say, but also has a large number of features and apps that will make it attractive to many people. It is listed as being Windows 7, Windows 8, and Mac compatible, though I can only vouch for the W7 aspect of that (what I use at home).My issues with the router started right out of the box. The box clearly states that the router has an easy 3-step setup. Only, if you look at that third instruction carefully, you'll notice it is to connect to your router network and FOLLOW MORE INSTRUCTIONS. That's a bit of a cheat if you ask me.Then there's the actual size of the device. It is a little bit larger than my previous one, and it is designed so it can not stand vertically. I am sure there is a technical reason why it has to lay like a wide, flat rock, but it also takes up more space (I just tucked my previous router on the side of my printer and it covered the entire house). Keep this in mind when you are looking at different models.Rating: 3 out of 5 stars. It certainly isn't a bad router, but it may not be right for everyone (especially if you're used to a thinner one).

Continuing right after the events of _Children of Fire_ (CoF), Drew Karpyshyn's _The Scorched Earth_ (SE) follows the travels of Keegan, Scythe, Vaalar, and their companions through a sword and sorcery fantasy adventure. Though not entirely necessary, readers should pick up _Children of Fire_ first, as SE doesn't do much explaining of past events - after a brief prologue dealing with The Big Bad Villain, the book takes up with little backstory/retelling of previous happenings.The easiest way to determine if you will like this novel is to ask yourself, "Did I like the first book?" _Scorched Earth_ is really just more of the same - it has similar pacing, similar events, and the same characters with most (but not all) acting the same way. Once more, nothing really happens in the first third of the book (certainly not enough to justify the thousands of words it took to get us there); then there is an event, a bunch more nothing, and finally a relatively fast-paced and exciting ending. The villains remain typical caricatures with laughable plans, but there are a few great scenes with some of the heroes to make it worth suffering through. In the end, not a lot is accomplished, some heroes and villains are dead, and the protagonists are poised to jump right into the next novel.Rating: 3 Out of 5 Stars. The Scorched Earth is a fun read, but significantly less memorable than the first book.

_Far Horizons_ is a Star Wars Edge of the Empire (EotE) roleplaying game sourcebook that focuses on the Colonist career path. It contains rules for three new races (Arcona, Chevin, and Gran [though the Gran were already introduced in the Age of Rebellion core book]), three new career specializations (Entrepreneur, Marshal, and Performer), two new signature abilities (high level career abilities for colonists), new vehicles, new equipment, and more. In total, it is 95 beautiful color pages of material for the EotE game.While I have greatly enjoyed ALL of the other expansion books for EotE so far, I found Far Horizons to be a disappointment. The reason for this is simple: it really doesn't focus on Colonists. What it does is try to introduce space police as player characters into the EotE game, and that's not really what I wanted from THE COLONIST SOURCEBOOK. The vast majority of the material is centered around this concept, so players of the already established Colonist career specializations (Doctors, Politicos, and Scholars) are out of luck. If you think it is a terrible shame that the Hired Gun sourcebook actually contains more new medical equipment than the one for Doctors does, you'll also be disappointed.Ignoring the idea that the sourcebook should contain more information for established Colonists, it still leaves a lot to be desired. The Entrepreneur career specialization, for instance, is basically just filling the same role that the already established Trader does (just with a different talent mechanism). The Performer is okay, but it won't fit into everyone's game (talents like Biggest Fan, which is exactly what it sounds like, are a perfect example of this). The Marshal, which the author focuses the majority of the sourcebook on, is basically a combat-modded version of the Colonist that is immune to Deception at high levels (their Unrelenting Skeptic talent is unbalanced and needs to be modded right out of the gate, especially when compared to Scoundrel talents dealing with Deception). A little bit of text is actually given over to the equipment Colonists would use (Atmospheric Processors and Vaporators, for instance), but most of it is just for flavor - besides price, there isn't actually a lot of game data supplied with these items (especially compared to all of the new police equipment; but, hey, everyone was looking forward to stats for a riot shield, right?).The one thing I really did enjoy about this book was the section on establishing a Base of Operations (pages 81-85). Though it only covers about five pages, this gives new rules for buying and upgrading a base for your characters. A base gives bonuses such as a bonus career skill, but takes money and/or obligation to establish and enhance it. This section could have been thirty pages longer in my eyes - in terms of rules, it really adds an element to the game. Hopefully, we'll see this concept expanded in future sourcebooks (maybe even Age of Rebellion, where having rules for specific types of Rebel bases would make a lot of sense).Rating: 3 out of 5 stars. If you're looking to bring space police into your EotE game, this sourcebook is for you; players of established Colonists, however, will be disappointed.

Tattle Tea Earl Grey is a stylishly packaged loose leaf tea. It has nice hint of flavors to it, and is definitely an upgrade from the standard (and horribly bland) Earl Grey most people drink. The flavors are certainly not overpowering, but might not be quite enough for everyone. Still, it makes a very respectable beverage of class and distinction most will enjoy.A note for those new to "loose leaf" tea: unless you want the leaves just floating in your drink (some people enjoy that style), you'll want to pick up an infuser / strainer. Amazon has them for sale relatively inexpensively and in dozens (if not hundreds) of styles.

Prior to using the KOBI Electric K2L3 LED Bulb, I'd been using CFL and hybrid-CFL bulbs in my home. The problem with CFL, however, is that they take a while to warm up before they glow with their full brightness. That's not an issue above the dinner table or next to the TV, but when it comes to those lights that are constantly being turned on and off (say, on the stairs), it can cause problems. This LED light, however, does the job perfectly, and I'll be putting similar ones in the utility room and the basement.In terms of performance, this light instantly brightens like a star. It provides brilliant illumination throughout the area, and it has very good coverage (especially for an LED bulb, which tends to produce shadows "behind" the light). It still creates a few shadows around it, but it does better than the other LED bulbs I've seen. Also, unlike most traditional LED bulbs, it can be dimmed if your lamp/outlet has that option built in. I highly recommend it.Rating: 5 out of 5 stars. Brilliant light that will work with a dimmer!

Legendary Encounters is a deck building game that uses cards and a game mat to create exciting playable scenarios for 1 to 5 participants. While the heart of the game uses two relatively simple mechanics (basically money cards to buy things and damage cards to kill things), Encounters is also complex - there are numerous special rules to pick up, and some options allow players to actually battle each-other. It is a standalone game, meaning everything you need to play comes in the box.While the Legendary game system has previously been known for using characters from Marvel Comics (those such as Iron Man, Captain America, and Spider-Man), this Legendary set goes in a completely different direction by exploring the universe of the Alien movies. Yes, you can still cross-over cards from the other sets into Encounters (Wolverine & Ripley vs. the Alien Queen can actually happen), but most people will find the real fun is playing out the various scenarios - scenarios that recreate the movies and can be extremely difficult. This game is MUCH HARDER than previous Legendary games, and optional rules allow players to even fight each-other (either as a sort of traitor or when they are turned into aliens by a facehugger). These aspects make Encounters an exciting but at times a very dark game - one that will take even veteran Legendary players a number of tries to become skilled at.Rating: 5 out of 5 Stars. If you like deck building games and the Alien movies, this standalone game is for you - it truly captures the feel of its source material well.Note: as always, I recommend putting the game's cards into standard card sleeves. These will help the materials last through multiple play sessions, drink spills, and being touched by pizza sauce-coated fingers.

75034 Death Star Troopers is a 100 piece LEGO Star Wars set released in early spring 2014 with a LEGO Store suggested price of $12.99. Following the instructions, four minifigures (two Emperor's Royal Guards and two Imperial Gunners) and a turbolaser cannon can be built. Hand-held weapons for each figure are also included.With these minifigures previously being difficult to find, it is hard to imagine a better Imperial army-building set unless a four stormtrooper box was put on the market. Still, with two of each of these iconic figures, you'll be able to fill out your rows of Imperial soldiers easily and at a relatively affordable price. The turbolaser also makes a nice background piece, and can be re-assembled into various other things (as many as you can imagine) or just added to the larger brick pile as desired.The other interesting feature of this set is new blaster pistol. Two are provided for the Imperial Gunners to brandish when not at their stations. They are very love-em or hate-em for most fans - those looking for movie-similar pieces hate them (the guns are very bulky and don't look like Star Wars blasters); those that like "action" bricks love them (they are simple levers that can shoot small bricks EXTREMELY far). Like any good LEGO part, these blasters can be further customized, with pieces from other LEGO sets turning them into grappling guns, rocket launchers, and other things.Rating: 5 out of 5 Stars. This is an excellent Imperial Army-building set with interesting new blasters to make things even more interesting.

One of the co-owners at my friendly local game store (Art of War in Cincinnati) introduced me to Upper Deck's Marvel Legendary game, and I enjoyed it. When he added in the various hero expansions (Dark City and others), it was great. When he switched it up and we started playing Legendary Villains, I was completely hooked.At its heart, Villains is a relatively standard deck building game (all the cards you need to play are provided) with streamlined rules and fast play. You have your money cards and your attack cards, and you'll work each turn to defeat the city's heroes (the various X-teams, Avengers, and more) by both attacking them and buying new abilities to make yourself stronger (cards that are shuffled into your hand). Take too long, and the schemes of your head honcho hero opponent may come to fruiting and defeat you; don't plan far enough ahead, and you won't have the strength you need later in the game.Villains works as both a stand-alone game and as an expansion to the original Legendary. As a stand-alone, you get all of the rules and mats to play an exciting game in which the villains try to defeat the grand efforts of the heroes of the Marvel universe. It plays in a similar manner as the original Legendary (relatively easy to learn), though some new card mechanics and rules add needed challenge. When used as an expansion, it opens that game up in new ways, and adds epic comic book team-ups to an already exciting experience (Professor X and Magneto teaming up is probably one of the best examples).The game is designed for 1 to 5 players, but take note: adding more players generally makes things harder, and a full 5 player game can be very difficult to win. The Villains game in general is also a bit harder than the original, which I find to be a positive (there were complaints that the first was too easy).Rating: 5 out of 5 Stars. Fast play, exciting team-ups, and hours of fun both for fans of the Marvel universe and general board game enthusiasts.P.S.: I highly recommend buying and using card sleeves (plastic covers for the individual cards). This will significantly increase the life of your game, especially when Cheeto-eating friends put their greasy fingers on them.

The new Dungeons and Dragons Player's Handbook is a unique form of game that transports players into a fantasy world of stout Dwarves, noble Elves, and everything in-between. It does this by using the power of the players' imaginations, along with some oddly-shaped dice (sold separately) and this rulebook. Older players will understand that it is a redesign of the legendary tabletop roleplaying game (RPG) that was originally published in 1974. Sometimes called D&D Next, 5th Edition, or just 5E, it is a significant revision of the game that plays different than any other version. Still, enough of the core mechanics remain that it can be easily learned, and none of the rules are so odd as to make the game unrecognizable.The main focus of the revision seems to have been streamlining and focusing the game so it both plays faster and requires less rule referencing. This tends to polarize players - those that want to customize every aspect of their character (rule-focused) will be disappointed by the changes; those that are more interested in the adventure (story-focused) will probably enjoy this. Mechanics like "advantage/disadvantage" (rolling two twenty-sided dice and taking either the best or worst depending on the ad- or dis-) replace a lot of the number crunching bonuses; early character customization is more about making broad choices (Race, Class, and Background) rather than many smaller choices (example: skills/proficiencies are primarily determined by Class and Background, and you don't choose how to spend skill points every level like you did in other editions). It is definitely a change in concept, and one that makes the game easier for new players to pick up and understand.A gaming aspect that makes a strong comeback in this edition is that of "Theater of the Mind" - that is, not using miniatures and grid maps, but having combat and other events take place through words and descriptions (in a storytelling atmosphere). 5E supports both aspects with its rules very well, so those that enjoy their figurines shouldn't be put off, either.If this seems like a lot of changes, it is. There are, in fact, too many changes to cover in a casual product review. Additional ones include: Toril (Forgotten Realms) is now the default campaign setting; every class has been altered from previous editions; classes transition into "archetypes" that are specialized versions at about third level.Other info: Player races include Dwarf, Elf, Halfling, Human, Dragonborn, Gnome, Half-Elf, Half-Orc, and Tiefling (along with multiple subraces). Classes include Barbarian, Bard, Cleric, Druid, Fighter, Monk, Paladin, Ranger, Rogue, Sorcerer, Warlock, and Wizard. The book itself is full color.Note: if you are unsure whether this game is right for you, Wizards of the Coast is currently providing a PDF version of what it consider the core rules for free on its website. This document has all of the information needed to create characters, advance in level, experience combat, and play the game, but only contains a limited number of races, classes, and backgrounds to choose from. Feel free to visit their website and try the free basic rules to see if you'll like the game before significantly investing in this book.Rating: 5 Out of 5 Stars. 5E can't be everything to everyone, but it is an incredible re-envisioning that manages to separate itself from all of the other editions by creating a unique play experience that can still be recognized as the venerable game it is based on. Highly recommended for all tabletop RPGers to try!

Star Wars Age of Rebellion: Onslaught at Arda I is the first hardback adventure book/module released for the Age of Rebellion game. Though it can be run with players at any XP level, it is designed for newer characters. The book itself provides a few suggestions for integrating this adventure with the one found in the back of the Age of Rebellion core rulebook if that has not already been played (basically, just changing a few names). It should take multiple gaming sessions to run through this adventure completely.Overall, I found the Onslaught at Arda I adventure to be a very respectable, both gameplay-wise and in maintaining the feel of the Star Wars movies. Rebel characters of varied careers/specializations will all find they have something different and important to do in various parts of the adventure; as well, the different parts have varied objective focuses to keep things interesting (one is starship piloting, another is combat, another is investigation, etc..). My biggest complaint is that there's not a lot of flexibility to things - the characters will be heading "down the rails" and can really only succeed or fail at each task (there's no jumping around or significantly altering the course of events).As to the "New Rules for Handling Mass Combat" the back of the book touts, they cover 2 pages (30-31). I didn't find them to be particularly significant, though they do make Leadership a lot more useful (it acts to upgrade dice).On a side note, this adventure can be easily modified to run in an Edge of the Empire campaign. Perhaps the EotE characters are mercs hired to help the Rebellion / smugglers delivering needed supplies / etc; only a few "speeches" and a little creative reasoning are needed to make it work.Rating: 4 Out of 5 Stars. If you are looking for a decent Age of Rebellion adventure, Onslaught at Arda I definitely has the feel of the movies to it - just don't buy it only for the new rules, however.

Age of Rebellion is a pen-and-paper roleplaying game (RPG) based in the Star Wars universe.  Its rough focus is the time and events of the original Star Wars trilogy, and it primarily deals with the Rebel side of things. It is also the second core rulebook in Fantasy Flight's Star Wars roleplaying game series, and is compatible with the earlier core rulebook Edge of the Empire (a game focused on the scoundrels and outcasts of the galaxy, but in a similar time period). In order to properly play either of these games, you will need a set of specialized dice that have symbols on them instead of numbers (listed as either "Edge of the Empire Dice" or "Age of Rebellion Dice" and sold separately; there's also an app to simulate them). The dice themselves tend to be the most intimidating part of the game, but most players get used to them after a few sessions of use.But on to the game itself! If you enjoy RPGs and Star Wars, Age of Rebellion (AoR) has a lot to offer! The book itself is filled with some of the best FULL COLOR artwork of any product to date, and really helps to get the feel of the setting into the minds of the players. The gameplay flows well (after the shock of the dice is overcome), and allows for a large selection of humans, aliens, and droids to be chosen as player-characters (PCs).  AoR tends more towards storytelling, and even has dice mechanics that allow players to briefly take control of events and sculpt the outcome. Those prospective players that lean more towards hard rules and number crunching might prefer the previously published D20 Star Wars game by Wizards of the Coast, which was a fine but very different experience.While the contents of the 460+ page book are too large to cover in detail, the book contains everything needed to play except for the dice. Examples include rules for character creation, rule for advancement, career (class) section, equipment section, ship section, Force section (probably a bit lacking for those that really want to play a Jedi, but there will be another Core Book for that in the future),  adversary section (sci-fi bestiary), Galaxy and Rebellion information section, and a short introductory adventure.Note to Edge of the Empire (EotE) players: this book can also serve as an expansion to the EotE game. It contains multiple new races, many new ships (Rebel and Empire-focused), and some new career options (though some are repeats and others do not balance well with those in EotE [example: medic vs. doctor]). It does not, however, significantly expand The Force or greatly increase the amount of available equipment. As well, it repeats A LOT OF INFORMATION FROM THE EotE CORE BOOK. I enjoy AoR greatly, but it may not be the best expansion for EotE players on a budget.Note - PC races covered in the book: Bothans, Droids, Duros, Gran, Humans, Ithorians, Mon Calamari, and Sullustans.Rating: 5 out of 5 stars. An excellent pen-and-paper roleplaying game for fans of the original Star Wars trilogy! Also a respectable (but sometimes repetitious) expansion for Edge of the Empire.

The Mead Trapper Keeper (I call it the modern version, though maybe 2012 version would be more appropriate) is a three ring binder with sewn cloth exterior and metal snap closure. It doesn't have a lot of other frills, though it does have a piece of clear plastic on the front (that you can slide your own cover image into if desired) and comes with 5 plastic dividers. And that's it. If you're looking for a decently durable binder with a closure, this may be one for you - but there is not a whole lot to it for the price.The strength of the Trapper Keeper system is in the additional products you can buy for it, such as the Trapper Keeper Plastic Folder or the Trapper Keeper 2-Pocket Portfolio. In the end, though, there is not a lot that separates the Trapper Keeper system from many of the other binder and organizers on the market, except perhaps nostalgia (just remember that this model isn't the same as the one from the 80's, which used Velcro and had a different design).Rating: 3 Stars. This is a respectable binder that closes.

The Five Star 2" Zipper Binder Plus Multi-Access File is a mouthful to say, but is also the standard by which I judge all other binders and organizers. It is one of the best choices for people that want to carry their papers and writing supplies with them WITHOUT using a backpack, or that are looking for an extremely high level of protection for their materials. Here are the highlights:- Zipper-Closed Compartments. The two main sections of the binder zipper close, insuring that your papers stay protected and locked inside. The organizer section zips COMPLETELY closed; the three ring binder section zips almost completely closed except for a small (roughly half-inch radius) section on one end. Papers can not escape once the zippers are secured.- Internal Compartments. There is an additional small compartment in the binder section for writing utensils (pens, pencils, and whatnot); there's also an additional zippered pocket for whatever longer items you want to store in it. Finally, a second accordion-style paper organizing section is also in the binder area (it is closed with Velcro, and is in addition to the zippered one on the outside of the binder).- Durability. The binder is made with cloth to help resist the wear-and-tear of the world. The zippers are of a heavy make and also strong.Certainly, this product isn't for every situation (a simple three ring D-ring binder might work better and cheaper if you're already carrying a backpack everywhere), but it is a top choice if you are looking to take papers and writing utensils with you in one neat, easy to carry item.Rating: 5 Stars. This is a great binder and organizer for multiple situations.

So, yeah, three-ring binders aren't always sexy.. but what you put in them can be! When using a D-ring binder, whatever interesting tidbits you put in yours will tend to suffer less wear-and-tear than those stored in the more common O-ring binders - and that means the precious pages will last longer without needing to be taped or reinforced as often. Nothing but the heaviest reinforcements will stop the top page of any binder from suffering damage, but those further in will thank you for sparing them additional suffering if you go with the D-ring (or they would if they could talk). Add in the clear cover that allow you to slide your own pages in to display just how naughty or nice the interior material is (very handy if you are using multiple binders and want to distinguish between the one you use for chemistry notes and the one you use as your private journal), and you have an obvious winner in terms of product. Finally, the binder's cover also folds completely under, making it easier to hold/set down on a small desk when copying notes into. Flexible, protecting, and open to displaying whatever you want it to on its cover... now that is a great product!

The Dungeons and Dragons (5E) Starter Set provides players with everything they need to begin their adventures with fantasy roleplaying games (RPGs). The box set contains a six-piece dice set, rulebook, adventure book, blank character sheet template, and detailed character sheets for each class - in short, all the stuff besides players (and maybe a few pencils/pieces of paper) you'll need to run the game. It does this at a very reasonable price ($19.99 suggested U.S. retail), making this box set an excellent value for those looking for an "entry point" into the exciting world of tabletop RPGs!Starter Set Rulebook in more detail: the rules themselves have been "streamlined" from those presented in the 5th Edition (5E) system to make them easier to grasp for new players. While the basic mechanics remain the same, more complex details like proficiencies and racial bonuses have been simplified or skipped. In fact, character creation has been completely removed - players just select their characters from the previously generated (pre-gens) ones provided and start. Those experienced with RPGs should not panic about this, as Wizards of the Coast (WotC or Wizards for short) is currently providing expanded rules with that information FOR FREE on their website. Once players are ready, transitioning to the full rules set is both easy and exciting.Lost Mine of Phandelver Adventure Book in more detail: this is the gem of the box set. Primarily used by the Dungeon Master (DM), it contains the base story that the person running the game will present to the players. Set in the famous Forgotten Realms setting (now the default D&D world), there is enough adventure to get the group from level 1 to level 5; in other words, enough material for multiple days of play in most cases. But the information contained in Appendix B (MONSTERS), can last even longer. Providing stats for many of the traditional fantasy monsters players would find interesting to encounter (the list includes ogres, orcs, skeletons, goblins, bugbears, and even a young dragon - pretty much everything but kobolds), DMs can use this to help design their own adventures without having to buy additional products.Conclusion: those new to RPGs will definitely get the most out of this box, and are the target market for the product. More experienced gamers, however, may notice a number of flaws with it. For instance, the books are printed on relatively light paper with less-than-sturdy covers (especially compared to many of the previous boxed sets). As well, the dice set is BEAUTIFUL (a marbled blue set), but lacks a percentile d10 (not necessary, but desired by many gamers). Finally, there is a definite lack of that feeling of epic adventure that many previous D&D products contained. Why? Probably because there's no introduction story (a piece of fiction that sets the mood when you first start to read the rules) or single-player adventure (included in previous edition box sets). While I know space was a concern, including text to fire up the imagination for a game that primarily takes place in the mind would have been a good idea in my opinion.Rating: 3 Out of 5 Stars. With its low price and streamlined rules, this box set is an excellent entry point for those new to roleplaying games. More experienced gamers, however, would probably get more out of downloading the expanded rules WotC provides for free on its website or buying the Player's Handbook.

The Star Wars Edge of the Empire Game Master's Kit is a fine addition to any GM's toy box, but is a bit mislabeled - what you are purchasing is actually a heavy cardboard GM's Screen and a 30 page magazine-style booklet. The booklet itself is 25 pages of adventure and 5 pages of information on how to better run a Nemesis. The adventure was an interesting but not truly dazzling work involving Hutts and droids; the Nemesis section I've so far found useless. The GM screen is extremely sturdy, and displays basic tables from the core rulebook on the four different partition sections. That pretty much sums up the product.So, for a recommended retail price of $19.99 + tax, you get a sturdy GM screen, a short adventure, and a few pages of explanations for GMs only. To me, this wasn't worth the price - I'd rather buy a cheaper partition (maybe from an office supply story; maybe just use a GM screen from a different game) and spend the rest of my money on another Edge of The Empire product (perhaps a full adventure book like _The Jewel of Yavin_; something with adventure hooks and source material like _Suns of Fortune_; or maybe one of the career "splatbooks" like _Dangerous Covenants_).Rating: 3 out of 5 Stars. The GM screen is extremely sturdy, but it and the included adventure are probably not worth the recommended retail price.

I purchased the _Sisun USB 3.0 3.5-Inch SATA aluminum hard drive enclosure with cooling fan_ (USB 3.0 to SATA - Model WLX-393U3) and use it with both my Western Digital Black 2 TB SATA III 7200 RPM 64 MB Cache Hard Drive and the WD Green 2 TB Desktop 3.5 Inch SATA III 64 MB Cache Hard Drive (I switch them into the enclosure as needed). What I can honestly say is that the enclosure WORKS when it comes to connecting the hard drives to my computer via USB 3.0 (and previous USB versions, since they are backwards compatible). That is the most important aspect of the product, so it earns a base 3 stars from me for that reason alone (you'd be surprised at how many electronic items DO NOT work properly).The enclosure just doesn't do much beyond that, however, and is not well made. The enclosure does not secure the hard drive inside itself with any sort of cradle or rack - you just plug the drive in and screw down the lid. If the enclosure fit the drive snugly, it wouldn't be a problem - but, because there is a lot of space inside, the drive rattles when the enclosure is moved and seems susceptible to damage. The cooling fan is also significantly louder than those on the other enclosures I own, but does not produce any additional air flow.Note: I did not use any sort of install disk - I just plugged my hard drive into the enclosure and then slotted the device into the USB port of my Windows 7 internet-connected PC. The drive itself had to be formatted before it could be recognized, but that is not the responsibility of the enclosure - that's something that can be done through the Computer/Disk Manager software.Rating: 3 out of 5 stars. The enclosure works, but is cheaply made. It is almost more of a hard drive docking station than an enclosure, since enclosures generally provide more protection (and a snugger fit) to the hard drive inside of them.

This review comes in after just over three months of play from the official release date. At this point, many of the common release bugs others have complained about have been fixed. As well, some of the larger issues (such as the guild bank item and gold duping bug) have been found and dealt with. While there are still some gold farming spammers and bots roaming the land, their numbers have been significantly decreased. In short, the Elder Scrolls Online (ESO) world is now playable by all standards.The basic game mechanics are excellent. Significantly different from the stand-alone Elder Scrolls computer games, I actually find ESO's combat system more enjoyable than Skyrim's (previous ES game), especially when it comes to casting combat magic. By leveling and gaining shards, characters can learn a large selection of skills in the game - but are focused into a specific role by only having a limited number of associated abilities available at any given time. Abilities can be switched during non-combat situations (so a character filling a damage role could switch to one of a healer), but they are locked in during a fight.I've also found the quests to be very enjoyable. Though there are some of the traditional Fed/Ex and rat-killing quests, most others are more involved and are associated with one storyline or another. The over-arcing world quest (the same for each character) and the guild quests are well thought out and feel truly epic. The problem is, they also tend to feel like they're designed for a single player experience (because they are in the case of the world quest and the guild quests); most of the time, other players get in the way of enjoyment of these quests rather than enhancing the experience. As an MMO (Massive Multiple Online Game), this SHOULD NOT BE THE CASE.Which brings us to ESO's biggest problem: it really isn't designed as an MMO. The group finder is difficult to use and is less effective than a zone-chat call of "LOOKING FOR GROUP." The presence of other players in dungeons detracts from the experience, especially when they are camping certain spawns. PvP is not particularly enjoyable, and is far behind that of other games. The game doesn't have a lot of "sandbox" features that would allow it to be played over-and-over again differently - as previously mentioned, all characters play the same main world quest, and upon its completion you're expected to submit to be randomly assigned another starting faction that you play in what amounts to hard mode. To put it simply: after you play through ESO's main storyline once, things get boring.Rating: 3 out of 5 stars overall. If you enjoy quest-based CRPGs and have already played Skyrim, you'd probably enjoy buying this game and playing it for a few months (keeping in mind ESO has a monthly subscription fee at this time). If you're looking for a really good MMO that is fun to play in a group, though, look somewhere else.

If you're looking for an interesting book that hits many of the interesting points in the history of modern medicine, _Kill or Cure_ may be for you. A moderately hefty tome (400 pages in hardback), _Kill or Cure_ touches on everything from prehistoric medicine to modern robotic surgery. It is in no way completely comprehensive, but it is certainly an excellent start for those wanting to learn more about the subject matter.The book's biggest draw is the large number of photographs and illustrations it contains; these both allow readers to better understand the material and help lift the sometimes monotonous subject matter. They do an excellent job of this, but could stand to be somewhat larger on some occasions (the tattooed caveman remains on page 19, for instance, take up less than a fourth of a page and are difficult to clearly see).Rating: 4 out of 5 stars. An excellent primer for learning about the history of medicine.

I've had difficulty finding larger gloves that fit properly and don't rip. These gloves did the trick. They fit much better than the vinyl gloves I had been wearing, and don't rip nearly as often when putting them on. Also, they come unpowdered, so there's no significant hand drying or getting fingerprints everywhere when you take them off. They've got a bit of a price tag on them, but I think they're worth it for the above-mentioned features.

This wet/dry contractor vac works great; I have no complaints about it. Great design, excellent power for the style - it does what it is supposed to do. I can't say it any more clearly than that.What I can do is comment on some of the negative reviews I've read of this model and its lack of wheels. Most of these have come from Vine reviewers that received a free vac in order to review it (I know this because I am also a Vine reviewer and received one for free). Such reviews are like receiving a free sled and then complaining because it doesn't have wheels like a wagon. THIS MODEL ISN'T SUPPOSED TO HAVE WHEELS. If you want one with wheels, go buy a model THAT HAS THEM - they're out there. This specific tool doesn't have wheels, and there are many areas/functions where the wheels would be counterproductive. Know what you are doing, and get the right tool for the right job.

If you want a stylish set of headphones for gaming, buy these. This glowing red headset has a sexy style that screams awesome to anyone seeing it. My Siberia V2 even gets comments from people that come over and see them resting next to my computer - **** YEAH!!!BUT.. I question their sturdiness over the long haul. Others have complained about them breaking easily, and they do not feel particularly sturdy when being worn. Don't get me wrong, they fit my head well, but a lot of that is accomplished by what looks like two tiny little cords. The mic works, but.. man, I'm afraid it is going to break every time I adjust it. If you buy these, you can't constantly knock them around (and probably shouldn't take them anywhere) - be careful with these bad boys!

The GE100 Blood Glucose Monitoring System is a nice starter kit for those either just getting started with blood sugar checks or those needing a (semi-) complete kit. It comes with meter, test strips, control solution, lancets, lancing device, a really nice (and short) quickstart guide, manual, and case. What it doesn't come with are alcohol wipes, bandages, or cotton balls (items I was told to use back when I learned how to do a check, but that may have gone out of favor - or maybe not).Overall, my experience with the monitor has been pretty positive. The display is very large and easy to read; the strips don't need a lot of blood for an accurate reading. My problem comes from the lancets (the thing that prick your finger) - I have very minor arthritis in my hands, and I find it EXTREMELY difficult to get the caps off the lancets without bending the needles. This may not be a drawback for everyone, but people with moderate arthritis should be aware of the issue (they may have to get a different lancing device). Otherwise, I have no complaints about the system, and have used it well.Rating: 4 out of 5 stars. The monitor has worked well for me, but the lancing device might be difficult for people with hand issues to use.

This is the English translation of Limit, originally written in German by author Frank Schatzing. I am a fan of both fiction (especially Sci-Fi) and German authors (example: Markus Heitz's translated Dwarves series), and was looking forward to reading this book when I first heard about it. So, when this massive 950+ page tome arrived in the mail, I was elated. After reading 200 pages, though, my enthusiasm had declined significantly; by the time I was half-way through, I was wondering what I had gotten myself into.But let's start at the beginning. The prologue, which details the happenings of one very unlucky astronaut, is incredible. Highly descriptive, it contains action, character development, interesting sci-fi, and (*GASP*) an actual story arc where things happen at a reasonable pace. If the entire book had been like this prologue, I would have been extremely happy!But it wasn't. So I'm not.Limit is a book of uneven pacing with painfully long stretches of nothing important happening. It also needed a better editor. There are chapters that are flooded with newly introduced cookie-cutter characters that will overload the short-term memory of readers. Other chapters are devoted to painfully long dialogues that are supposed to inform readers of world happenings, but just drag on over superficial points. The worst part is, hundreds of pages pass with almost no advancement of the main storyline. It speeds up towards the end of the book, but you have to read a lot of pages before then - and most people just don't have the time and patience for that.Rating: 2 out of 5 stars. I liked the Sci-Fi concepts introduced, but the book just moves too slowly for me.

Adobe Premiere Elements is one of the best selling consumer video editing software packages on the market. That title was well earned with earlier releases, but - in my opinion - one that the software failed to live up to in more recent versions due to bugs and other glitches. Using PE 12, I can honestly say most of those bugs seem to be gone for the Windows version, and all I am seeing is a great program I enjoy using.So, what makes PE 12 so enjoyable to use? Simplicity and power. While the current version is not quite as user friendly as some of the earlier ones, most users will find it much easier to figure out than, say, Sony Vegas Movie Studio (my other favorite Windows video editing program). Adding special effects is easily done, and the various modes allow more experienced users to skip over guided creation when they are ready to do so. As well, PE 12 has seamlessly integrated DVD creation that will let you make professional-quality menus from templates with ease (add Photoshop Elements for the ability to completely customize these templates).Please note that prospective buyers should consider the Premiere/Photoshop Elements software bundle that is also available. The bundle tends to provide significant savings over the combined cost of the two programs, and Photoshop Elements can be very useful when producing videos (creating DVD menu templates, making still images for the videos, etc..).Rating: 4.5 Out of 5 Stars (rounded to 5). Powerful and easy to use video editing software. I can highly recommend the Windows version.

The Boston Acoustics MC100 is an impressive speaker system that merges modern connectivity with excellent sound. Designed to be small enough to fit on a shelf or the corner of a desk, it never the less has enough volume to clearly and completely carry music through a noisy room (say, during a party). It has the typical "modern style" look of being black with blue lighting accents, and also comes with a small remote for volume control (the volume buttons are also duplicated on the top of the device). Connection is done easily through one of three methods: traditional Bluetooth, NFC, or direct cable connection via an auxiliary port.I primarily use mine with my laptop, and have yet to have any issues. Initially connecting the device wirelessly took seconds, and it has played through hundreds of songs and videos now without a glitch. All I get is clear sound!An interesting note about the system: did you know it has ports? It has both an auxiliary-in port and a headphone port. Don't discount either of these - the "Aux-In" allows you to connect older or non-BT devices easily with a cord (like when you want to listen to your old iPod Shuffle mix); the headphone port not only allows you to connect headphones (if, say, you're in the office and want to be courteous to others), but also allows you to pass a signal through to other devices. You probably won't ever need to pass a signal through, but I have done it once.Rating: 5 Out of 5 Stars. I have no complaints with this speaker system, and am very happy with it!

The Defender 22502 Digital Wireless Video Monitor System falls into a niche somewhere above traditional baby monitors but below most home security monitoring systems. It is actually somewhat difficult to completely gauge the device's features and limits because so little documentation is provided (mine came with a single sheet of paper that amounted to a quickstart guide; the promised manual that was supposed to be online had yet to be released when I checked). Still, I was able to figure out most of the menu options, and have used the device successfully.The system does have many good points. The camera works well, and is easily controlled by the monitoring unit. It produces a respectable color picture in normal light, and a decent black-and-white image in low light. The monitor has excellent range when the antenna is extended, and "video" can be recorded to the MicroSD card with a simple press of a button (.SNX file). There are also many other features, including a digital zoom, photo mode, and an intercom feature (though the sound produced is not particularly clear).The bad points, though, are also numerous. My biggest complaint is the lack of documentation - it literally doesn't even show you where to put the SD card. That documentation could also have answered some of my concerns like how exactly does "ClearVu Technology" make the signal secure (can anyone with a monitor see the image? How about anyone with a Defender monitor?). But there are other issues as well.
