This book is all about a very easy weight loss program. It consists of only two rules.Greatly reduce, or eliminate, your consumption of refined sugar. Greatly increase your consumption of fiber. That's all. The author strongly believes that most "diets" are much too complicated. He subscribes to the MISS principle (Make It Short and Simple).When digested, refined sugar, is stored in the body as body fat. Among the potential, and reported, side effects are: it may lead to childhood and adult obesity; it may increase your risk of stroke, heart attack and vascular disease; it may lead to Type 2 diabetes in children and adults; obesity will increase the risk of cancer, and it may double the risk of developing dementia or Alzheimer's Disease.Sugar substitutes, like saccharin and aspartame, are much less unhealthy than is refined sugar. A popular weight loss idea is to do a colon cleanse. Getting rid of that waste material will drop your weight by several pounds. Don't do it. The colon is supposed to have waste material in it. A cleaned-out colon can lead to very bad things physically.The human body is over 60 percent water, so drinking several glasses a day is a very good thing. Fast food restaurants are increasingly adding healthy items to their menus. Another side effect of excess refined sugar is that it causes the body to produce more insulin, which leads to the production of more cholesterol. The book also includes a list of low-sugar and high-fiber foods, and those foods that are to be totally avoided.Just two rules: how much easier can it get? This book is short, very easy to read, and it has a lot to say. This is very highly recommended.

Everyone has heard of Big Data; huge amounts of information, usually involving computers or the Internet. Is there a cultural or historical equivalent of Big Data?Yes, and it comes from Google's intention to digitize all the world's books (or, at least, a significant portion of them). The authors created an algorithm that would search all those books for certain words. On a chart, it will show, for instance, how many times, per million words, the name "Abraham Lincoln" was used, or "World War II." It can also be used to compare the historical use of pairs of words, like Satan/Santa, evolution/DNA, men/women, war/peace, tea/coffee or old school/new school. It can be found at books.google.com/ngrams ("Possibly the greatest time-waster in the history of the Internet." - Mother Jones magazine). Google needed convincing that this was a good idea, that it would not open them up to millions of copyright infringement lawsuits.Using this algorithm, it is possible to look at things like historical attempts at censorship. It can range from Nazi attempts to remove Jewish artists like Marc Chagall from the German cultural landscape, to the 1950's Hollywood Blacklist. A person can also look at how long a certain word or phrase stays in the cultural memory. For instance, "Korean war" has a huge jump in usage in the 1960's, then an equally huge drop in usage soon after, down to its present level of almost nothing.The book also looks at the evolution of the English language. If we have pairs of words like drive/drove, what happened to thrive/throve? Also, what happened to words like burnt, learnt and dwelt? It all has to do with irregular verbs, which change over time.This is a fascinating book, but it will take some effort on the part of the reader. It's very well done, and it gives the reader the chance to do their own historical research.

Based on Fortune Magazine's "40 Under 40" column, this book gives short profiles of some of the biggest names in American business, and how they got there.Of course, the people that one would expect to see in any such book are here, including Marissa Mayer, Elon Musk, Tony Hsieh, and Larry Page and Sergey Brin. Also included are the CEO's of Rent The Runway, TOMS Shoes and Change.org, senior executives from Heineken and ArcelorMittal (one of the biggest steel producers in the world), and Lebron James.It is very acceptable to want to take on Goliath (the dominant company in your field). It is just as acceptable to concentrate on doing one thing really well. These days, it seems to be fashionable to jump from one company to another during your career, never spending more than a couple of years in one place. There is absolutely nothing wrong with spending your career at one company.Some people are serial entrepreneurs. They thrive on getting a company established, or taking it public. Once that happens, they go one to the next one; they are less interested in actually running the company. What do you do after making a large, public blunder? Do you stay at the same company, withdraw from the public eye, and work to rebuild your image? Do you move to another company, and work to rebuild your image? Find something that you are passionate about, something that gets you up in the morning. It may be possible to find, or create, your dream job in that area, no matter how un-high tech it may be.If they can do it, why can't you? This is a very inspiring group of portraits of today's business leaders. Each portrait is only a few pages long, so they are also easy to read. This is well worth reading for anyone in business, whether large, small or start-up.

Like it or not, the streaming of movies and music is becoming an increasingly large portion of all internet traffic. This book gives the details.Why shouldn't a person be able to pay a few dollars to stream a movie at home, when going to the theater or buying the DVD costs a lot more? At the theater, does the projectionist load a film canister on a 35mm projector and turn it on? Increasingly, the answer is no. The majority of theaters have gone to all-digital systems. The movie is downloaded from the distributor, along with an electronic code. That code can be good for just one showing, on one specific day. If the right code is not available, or if it does not work properly, then there is no showing.Fewer and fewer movies are being shot on actual film, because fewer and fewer theaters have film projectors. Unless there is an art house cinema nearby, any watching of older, or less well known, films, on actual film, is pretty much impossible. When is the last time that an older or obscure film was available at the local multi-theater megaplex? If whoever has a film copy of that older, obscure film, does not think it is lucrative enough to put it on DVD, there is little that can be done about it. Soon, the only way to watch films of any kind, will be through on-line streaming. Depending on your point of view, this is either that natural progression of technology, or it's the end of the world.What Netflix is doing to the movie business, Apple is doing to the music business, and Amazon is doing to book publishing. Amazon is now selling more Kindle copies of books than paper copies. Facebook is little more than a way to suck up people's personal information, and sell it to advertisers (Google Glass, plus new facial recognition technology, will make that much easier). Facebook has created over 80 million fake accounts. The hope is that the author, for instance, will see their account already set up, and decide to use it. For that reason, the author says that he will never post on Facebook.This is a very interesting book. For some, it may be common knowledge, but I learned a lot from it. It's non-technical, and very easy to read. It's also very much worth checking out.

This present-day murder mystery is about a small town being menaced by a serial killer, soon after putting another serial killer in jail.Detective Max Larkin of the Rockton Police Department has just returned to work after taking a mandated psychological leave. Larkin and Jesse, his partner, are investigating a double homicide. After a third murder, suspicion falls on Liam, the hot-headed estranged husband of one of the victims. The circumstantial evidence is pretty strong, but it's not enough to force a confession. Larkin, whose instincts about a person's guilt or innocence are usually very good, is convinced that Liam is innocent. Jesse is just as convinced of his guilt.After Liam goes to jail, there is another dead body. Suspicion points in a totally different direction, toward someone a lot closer to Max and Jesse. After that possibility is no longer a possibility, another person is found dead. Can Max and Jesse stop the killer before Max becomes the next victim?This one is really good. It feels realistic, and it has lots of twists and turns. The reader will be kept guessing until the last few pages. It is very much worth reading.

Why are some people able to permanently give up drugs or alcohol, and start to turn their lives around, and some people just can't do it? Are those people destined to be alcoholics or junkies forever?You, the addict, have to want to change; today, and tomorrow, and the next day. There will be setbacks and relapses. Are you going to give up because you fell "off the wagon" once, or are you going to re-focus your efforts to never let it happen again? Don't be afraid to ask for help. If your friends and family see you making an honest effort to change, they might be willing to meet you halfway.There are many things that you, the addict, need to stop doing, now. First and foremost, stay away from your drinking or drugs buddies. Stop being so self-centered. Denying that you have a problem, when everyone around thinks otherwise, helps no one. Drop the "My way or the highway" attitude. Stop lying to others. You are responsible for your actions, and no one else. The world is not out to get you.Anger, depression and anxiety are normal human feelings. The way a person deals with those feelings is what, figuratively, separates the men from the boys (or the women from the girls). Once you are clean, what do you want to do with your life? Come up with some life goals. Learn to follow directions, and honestly share your feelings. Last but not least, learn to recognize the situations that could lead you back to using drugs or alcohol.This is general book, intended to start a person on the road to sobriety, and not so much a detailed, everything-you-need-to-know book. The chapters are short, and it is very easy to read. It is highly recommended for everyone, including addicts and those whose family member is an addict.

"High cholesterol and saturated fat are the major causes of heart disease." That statement has been a medical article of faith for many years. According to the authors of this book, it is also very wrong.There are several different types of "good" and "bad" cholesterol (some "good" cholesterol is bad for the body, and some "bad" cholesterol is good for the body), so a single number for good and bad cholesterol each is rather worthless. People with really low cholesterol numbers can easily get heart disease, and those with really high cholesterol numbers can live their entire lives without one bit of heart disease. Why do some native cultures, who practically live on saturated fat, have little or no heart disease?The real cause of heart disease is chronic inflammation, which comes from damage caused by free radicals (the book explains everything). Sugar is much more harmful to your heart than fat. It contributes to inflammation in the walls of your arteries. It increases the amount of insulin in your blood, which increases cholesterol and raises your blood pressure. It also raises your level of triglycerides, which is a much better indicator of heart disease than cholesterol.What is the problem with statin drugs, the usual treatment for heart disease? Their benefits have been extremely exaggerated. The brain depends on cholesterol to function normally. A common (but under-reported) side effect of statin drugs is sexual dysfunction. Most doctors dismiss complaints of side effects from statin drugs, and don't report them to the FDA. The only people who should take statin drugs are middle-age men with documented coronary artery disease.The book mentions tests that are much better indicators than cholesterol of heart problems. Ask your doctor to order them. Get rid of sugar, soda, processed carbohydrates and trans fats from your diet. Eat more vegetables, berries, nuts, beans and dark chocolate. If you can add only one supplement to your diet, make it Coenzyme Q10.This book easily reaches the level of Must read, especially for anyone on a statin drug. It is an eye-opener that will give the reader plenty to discuss with their doctor at their next appointment.

Most science fiction stories are about tall, square-jawed adventurers exploring the galaxy and singlehandedly vanquishing the alien foe. What about the people who perform the unexciting "blue collar" jobs that make the voyages possible?A being, of indeterminate gender, maintains a ship's waste treatment system. A female asteroid miner has a unique companion. It is an alien-constructed being, made from human sperm. It looks exactly like a human, but, on the inside, there is no mind or personality. Imagine an episode of the TV show "The Deadliest Catch" moved to the asteroid belt.On Titan, a human miner is caught in the conveyor belt that carries the pieces of rock out of the mine, and deposits them in a giant pile, in open vacuum. A trio of women spens their days walking on top of a domed city, patching up holes and cracks in the dome. Another story takes place on an Earth that has run out of energy. The only working motor vehicles are those that people build themselves. There is also a news story about the hazards involved in being part of the crew building a space station in orbit.This is a strong, well done group of stories about a not-well-known part of society. There is a good variety of stories, from lesser-known authors, that are well worth reading

June is your average resident of the planet Pren. It's a beautiful place, with colorful trees and flowers, and birds who tweet Mozart. According to June, it's also really boring. Out of frustration, she fashions something called a pencil out of a piece of coal, and sits down with lots of paper, to write stories of a whole new world. The place is called Earth.June learns that she is a Writer, with the ability to Write an entire world into existence. One Earth, June meets a young artist named Jackson. He has a hard time believing her story; he has an even harder time believing that he has related "abilities" of his own. As a Writer, the intention is that June create a Writer for Earth, someone who, out of frustration and boredom, will Write a whole new world into being.Meantime, Vivien is the Master Writer. Her son, Victor, is a manipulative little you-know-what who thinks that he "deserves" to be the next Master Writer. He also desperately wants to be reWritten (reborn). It is used only in cases of extreme emergency. In her Will, Vivien makes June the next Master Writer, and practically begs her to never, ever reWrite Victor. She is afraid that it will magnify his negative qualities (of which he has many). When told that the answer is No, Victor does not take it well. He spends weeks and weeks plotting the "perfect" way to force June to reWrite him. Does it work? Does Earth get unWritten out of existence (always a possibility)?This one is surprisingly good. The author does a fine job from start to finish. She is only 16 years old (!), but writes like someone older. Young people will love this book; it's well worth reading for adults, too.

American business is supposed to be a tough, ultra-competitive arena where only the strong survive, and nice guys get trampled, right? According to this book, that is not totally true.This book looks at three different kinds of people. Takers claim as much value for themselves as possible. If, for instance, they are the CEO, they are the sort of person who has a full page picture of themselves in the company's annual report, where most other CEO's will have a much smaller picture in their annual report. Takers are very deferential to superiors, and very mean and inconsiderate to subordinates. They use words like I, me and mine, as if they single-handedly caused their company to have a profitable year.Matchers aim to trade value evenly, as if they want to keep their spiritual inbox and outbox equal. Givers contribute to others without expecting anything in return.The giving could involve something like arranging a business introduction, or mentoring a younger employee. There is a fine line between being a giver and a doormat; a giver must also make sure that their business duties are not being ignored. In the short term, takers may do better than givers, but, in the long term, a giver's networking, collaboration and leadership skills will come to the forefront. A giver uses words like we, us and ours.How can a person increase their giving capacity? Take a test to see just how much of a giver you really are. Start a reciprocity ring at work. A group of employees meet weekly to make requests of each other. The intention is that everyone do what they can to fulfill those requests. It may seem a bit silly, but someone in your circle may know someone who knows someone who can fulfill your request. Publicly recognize givers at work. If you would rather give on your own, start a Personal Generosity Experiment.This is a very thought-provoking book, which shows that nice people can finish first. The average CEO, or division head, could do a lot worse than read this book, and start to implement its recommendations.

This is part 2 of a series about a group of average humans who are actually offspring of the gods of antiquity. It is not just Greek gods, but also Norse, Japanese and Aztec gods, who are alive and well, and mating with present-day humans.In this book, the group of six has been given three different tasks, forcing them to split up. Jane and Ryan head into the Nevada desert, looking for a drug factory that is creating a very powerful and very addictive drug. It happens to look and taste exactly like regular tap water.After several days of hiking, they find the drug factory (by being taken prisoner). Among the other prisoners are several women who are used in all sorts of unspeakable ways, and members of a US Army unit who were ambushed while on a training exercise. They are guarded by a number of dark elves, and members of the Army unit who were induced to go over to the "dark side." It is run by Andre Wittenburg, the local crime boss, who knows exactly what Jane and Ryan really are.To call conditions "brutal" is a huge understatement. Jane and Ryan free the other prisoners, and destroy the camp. They have to fight a mythical creature or two along the way. After a few days to recover, the six are back together and off to their next challenge. The tears of Freya (Norse goddess and Jane's mother) were encased in amber a millennia ago. It is very important that they not fall into the wrong hands. The group heads to a very restricted part of the Atlantic Ocean, just off the Florida Keys. It's the sort of place that no sane ship's captain would ever visit. There they meet another couple of mythical creatures (who really are not so mythical).Most times, literary sequels are not as good as the previous book. That is not true in this case. If anything, this book is better than Volume 1, because the reader gets more of the back story. This is very much worth reading.

Digital technology and the Internet have changed American business from top to bottom (what else is new?). What can you, or your company, do to survive in this new landscape? This book gives some answers.If your company doesn't already have a social media presence, forget about hiring some college kids to create one, while the rest of the company continues with its 20th century mentality. The entire company has to embrace social media, starting with the CEO. Most companies assume that they know who their customers are. Do some research, and find out for sure.There are ways to measure, for instance, who visits your website, what pages they click on, and how long they stay. If your company is not already up to its eyeballs in analyzing such data, you are missing out on a lot of potentially useful information.When you are talking to your customers, ask them how they stay connected. It's not a case of web or mobile or tablets being most important, but whatever screen the customer is using now. How can you make your customer's lives easier?This book also looks at how individuals can thrive in this new landscape. It is very rare for a person to, for instance, grow up wanting to get into marketing, and then spend their entire career in marketing. It's even more unlikely for it to happen at one company. You career path is going to resemble a squiggly line. Embrace the squiggle.As much as possible, get rid of cubicles and internal walls at your company. Encourage collaboration between different parts of your company. Such collaboration may create the new must have "killer app." The office itself is becoming less of a requirement, as it is now possible for a person's "office" to be anywhere they can use their laptop, tablet or smart phone.Many books have been written about the new digital world. This one belongs high on the list. It is easy to read, and is full of information for employers and employees.

This book is about a world totally changed by genetic engineering.GeneTech is, by far, the biggest company in the world. Human youth treatments, that make people look younger than they really are, are common. The world of agriculture harvesting has been turned upside down by XenoMats. Imagine genetically-created, dwarf size, green gorillas with tentacles instead of arms that are bred to pick produce in the fields. Commercial buildings are no longer built with steel and concrete. They are made of genetically created material based on the bones of this animal or the shell of that animal.Amade Bertrand is a New York Times reporter who has gotten a tip about strange happenings at GeneTech. She wonders why there has never, ever been a negative story about GeneTech in the press. It is because Whitfield Gray, GeneTech's head of PR, has been given, by GeneTech, a genetically-enhanced ability to bend anyone to his will, to make anyone do anything he wants. Is the fact that Amade is falling in love with him real or coerced?For years, the Church of Traditional Biblical Values has been very vocal in its opposition to genetic engineering in general. A very secret plan is hatched to get a dose of the influence drug, and inject it in the Leader of the Church. His influence will turn America back on the path toward God. It is led by Colonel Ron Savage, who goes up against general Sutherland, GeneTech's Head of Security. The two are ex-military, and have a long and unpleasant history together. A full-blown military assaultis unleashed against a complex of buildings that are full of the latest in high-tech and genetically engineered safeguards.The author does a very good job at making the characters not all bad or all good. There is no well-defined "good guy" or "bad guy." This story takes place only a few decades from now, it's very plausible, and more than a little spooky. The reader will not go wrong with this book; it's a first-rate piece of storytelling.

Last of a trilogy, this book is about a new age on Earth with the coming of the Mayan Sixth World. This time, something is really going to happen.Several years previously, Amy Magee, archaeologist and expert on Mayan hieroglyphics, discovered some real Mayan pyramids that were buried. . . in central California. It seems that the Spanish wiped out only some of the Mayan race several hundred years ago; they did not wipe out the entire race.Today, Mayan workmen are busy unearthing the new Mayan city of Ixabal, getting ready for the coronation of the new King. Amy has a major part in the ceremony, as the Bringer of the Sixth World. Everything has been kept very quiet, so that the public does not know what is happening. The exception is a nosy newspaper reporter, who has been asking questions.A major complication happens when Will, a major figure in what is to come, gets conked on the head during a cavern cave-in, and loses a large chunk of his recent memory. That includes the memory of just what he is supposed to say and do in a couple of weeks. Candis, Will's sister, knows and accepts her part in the coming ceremony (think "human sacrifice"). Leo, her boyfriend, most assuredly does not agree. He comes up with a bold plan for the both of them to flee to someplace where they will never be found. Rumors of a huge treasure attract the attention of several international bad guys. Meantime, Amy races to interpret an ancient Mayan book which may have a very different interpretation of the start of the Sixth World.As with most trilogies, reading the first two books first is a good idea. It's also a good idea because this book, and the whole trilogy, is that good. It's interesting and plausible and it will certainly keep the reader interested.

This near future science fiction story is about a young man who suddenly finds himself in a very dangerous situation.Steve Kowalski is a teenaged crew member on the "Phoenix," an interplanetary space ship that is the flagship of the International Space Alliance. He is spending a few days leave in Miami, helping to design a new star drive. Next thing he knows, Steve finds himself in a tiny jail cell in a very special place called Juno Colony. It's on the far side of the Moon, and does not recognize ISA authority. The "special" part is that not only do women rule the colony, but men have no rights at all; they are lower than slaves. There are some men who, emotionally, want to be treated like that; Steve is not one of them.Learning of Steve's plight, the rest of the crew is not going to just leave him there. A bold and daring plan is conceived, which involves several crew members visiting Juno dressed and acting like dominatrices (plural of "dominatrix") and their slaves. Steve was forced to sign papers making him the property of an arrogant, manipulative little you-know-what named Gianna, who is not going to give him up very easily. The male members are forced to enter the colony's gladiatorial games. Officially, the contests are not to the death, but if a contestant dies in the ring; oh, well. As an added complication, the losing male slave automatically becomes the property of the winner's Mistress. To make things look as legitimate as possible, the male members of the rescue mission signed the same ownership papers. Is Steve saved from a lifetime of slavery? Do all the members of the rescue mission make it out in one piece?This one is surprisingly good. There is one mild bit of S&M, and no actual sex. What it does have is heart, emotion and good writing. Yes, it's worth reading.

Here is a novel of intrigue set mostly on the Moon.The operation of a processing plant to mine Helium-3 from the Moon was supposed to be totally automated. That didn't work, so it was not long before a casino was built for the Lunar residents and tourists. It is run by the Cherokee Nation of North Carolina. Annie Taylor is there to investigate the disappearance of a large amount of money.A solar storm forces her to take shelter with Clint Baker and his family. They found a large cavern, sealed it up. pumped in air and brought seeds and animal embryos from Earth. They now have their own Texas cattle ranch (groups from other countries take over other caverns). Annie finds herself falling in love with Clint and the ranch. She heads back to Earth upon learning that Maddie, her sister, has been murdered.Annie knows of a few people in the Cherokee community who are high on the list of suspects, the sort for whom the term "human scum" is too generous. They have fled to the Moon, where Earth law cannot touch them. Before her return to the Moon, Annie is contacted by a Bahraini prince, whom the UN has appointed as Governor of the Moon. He offers Annie the position of Lieutenant Governor. The UN decided a long time ago, that there was to be no land ownership on the Moon. If a person or corporation wants to sign a lease, go right ahead, but there will be no landlords charging exorbitant amounts of money for industrial or living space. It also means that Annie will spend the rest of her life on the Moon.After several continuous months on the Moon, the human body can no longer tolerate Earth's gravity. Does Annie bring her sister's murderer to justice? Does she re-kindle her romance with Clint?On the positive side, this book has some interesting ideas about Man's expansion into the Solar System (money will be a major factor). On the negative side, this book really needs a trip, or another trip, to a proofreader or copyeditor. Despite that, it's a good story of science fiction that emphasizes the science, and, yes, it's worth reading.

This book shows how to look at your life through astrology. It also explores how famous people recognized their abilities and how those abilities were used.The first thing a person must do is to have their natal chart created. It's much more specific than the average newspaper horoscope, in that it looks at the position of the planets at the exact date, time and place of your birth. It will help identify major obstacles in your life. The position of Saturn at the time of birth means a lot. The other planets of the solar system correspond to areas of your personality (any angles or connections between them can be very good, or very bad).The author spends much of the book with astrological biographies of famous people, ranging from Elizabeth I to Albert Einstein to Lady Gaga. Read about their childhood challenges, and perhaps they will sound very familiar. After each negative part of their personality, the author lists ways that the reader can overcome such obstacles.Here are some examples. If your Sun opposes Neptune, maybe one or both of your parents demeaned you when you were younger (like Angelina Jolie). Find someone you can trust who can help you decide if your goals make sense. If your Mercury is square with Uranus (like Lady Gaga), you have a know-it-all attitude with a short attention span. Ask yourself why are you rebelling; is it just to challenge authority? If your Sun opposes Jupiter, you tend to promise more than you can deliver (like Nostradamus). You need to learn your limitations and develop some self-control. If your Mercury opposes Pluto, you tend to obsess about everything (like Pablo Picasso). Think before you speak, especially when you feel emotional.This is a very interesting book, and will help people, both astrology believers and skeptics, make their way through life. I admit to being an astrology skeptic, but I am always ready to change my mind. This is very much worth reading.

Grilled bacon.  Sounds great, right?  Pretty good, but let's go through some practicals1) The basic design is practical.  The grease traps on each side collect the grease and prevent it from dripping onto the flame and causing flare-ups.  They are large enough that even with a lot of bacon on the rack, they do the job.  So, you can grill the bacon for your bacon cheeseburger right alongside your burgers.2) Will you notice the taste?  On a bacon cheeseburger, not much.  The bacon is already smoked in all likelihood, so if you put it on grilled burgers, it isn't that much smokier.  It does give you very nicely crispy bacon, though, and eaten alone, you can taste the additional smoke, as long as you use charcoal rather than gas, and if you are using gas, why are you bothering anyway?3) The size of the rack is a practical constraint.  Folded out, it is basically 10-inch-by-10-inch square, which takes up a lot of space on my circular webber grill.  Keep in mind also that you don't want to cook the bacon at the same temperature at the burger, which means putting the brickettes on one side, and the bacon rack on the other.  If you want to grill the burgers, some onions, and maybe a few other veggies along with the bacon, pretty much everything but the bacon winds up being directly over the brickettes.  If you have a larger grill, this won't matter to you, but take some measurements because a 10"x10" will take up a lot of space and force the brickettes to be arranged very specifically.4) Clean-up is fine.  Once you collapse the rack, the two pontoons of grease drain easily, it goes in the dishwasher, and collapses to store easily.Over-all, I wish I could lock the rack into a position that isn't fully folded out to take less space on the grill, but if you are willing to set aside 10"x10" for the rack, go for it.

For those familiar with THIS Gilmore's discography, Unified Presence may come across as a wonderful surprise.  He was one of the M-BASE Collective/Strata Institute guys back in the heyday of the group/movement.  Like his compatriots, he played a frenetic style built around convoluted rhythms.  Anyone expecting that here will be in for a shock.  Gilmore's playing on this beautiful album is grounded enough that even your non-jazz friends will be able to enjoy it.  Christian McBride and Jeff Tain Watts are just about the most rock-solid rhythm section in jazz today, equally capable of challenging bop-based material and the funkier side of the genre.  While original, the compositions here sound like they could be standards, threading the needle between Monk and Silver, with the unexpected twists of the former and the driving power of the latter.  Honestly, I kept having to check the liner notes to see if either were credited, but no, this is just a well-led group staying true to the spirit of long-gone masters while playing with a modern warmth that avoids the ostentatiously challenging elements that are intended to scare away the rubes.  It may sound like an insult that even the rubes will like this one (I admit to my own snobbery), but Gilmore and crowd will get your jazz-hating philistine friends to stop whining about how jazz is a naked emperor.  And you can still be a snobbish jerk about the "ur" vs. "re" thing.  Those looking for a dose of Gilmore going nuts on the fretboard in a more M-BASE style should check out Numerology, his live album.  Here, he throws in some elegant acoustic work, plenty of clean-toned electric work, and plenty of Christian McBride: bassist extraordinaire.

This is a pretty good little set-up.  I got it to pair with a Macbook Pro currently running 10.10.3 Yosemite.  I have the computer on a standing set-up, which puts the keyboard and trackpad at the wrong height, and using wired keyboards or mice takes up precious few USB ports.  Despite the Microsoft brand, both items pair quite easily with a Mac, and the music control keys work just fine with iTunes.  I have two minor complaints.  One is visible, but you might not notice it.  To keep the keyboard compact, the arrow keys are integrated into the rest of the keyboard rather than given their own separate section, which means you might have to look down to find them rather than going by feel.  A minor nuisance, but worth pointing out.  The second, you wouldn't be able to guess. I prefer to set the computer not to be awoken by bluetooth devices-- I have cats.  However, if you do that, then every time the computer wakes up, you have to re-pair the mouse with the computer.  Strangely, that isn't true for the keyboard.  I have no idea why.  The result, though, is that the computer must be set to be woken up by bluetooth devices, i.e., by meddling cats.  Other than that, as advertised.

Damon Fowler is one of the most interesting blues guitarists around today, combining the loping rhythms of swamp blues, a bit of rock snarl, and a hint of country twang.  On this 2000 album, though, he was still working out his sound and just starting to peak his head out from the shadow of SRV and the rest of the modern blues-rock pantheon.  This is some solid southern blues, but a bit more rock-oriented than what he has played since, and with Southern Hospitality.  That means a few more rip-snortin' riffs to show off his skill, and a bit less space for everything to breathe.  To me, that space is essential to the greatness of what he now plays, but for those curious to see just how ferocious he could be before he mellowed out, this is a good one.  As my comments above indicate, the sound is more SRV than Tab Benoit, but that suits some people's tastes anyway.  The band is solid, but again, the bass and drum fills keep the sound busier than his recent albums.  If that's what you like, then great, but if you are already a Damon Fowler fan, be warned that his earlier work wasn't as spare-sounding.  Fans of Damon's slide work should also be warned that this album is heavier on fret-work than slide, and the date should be a tip-off that the "sacred steel" influence won't be very obvious.  I keep writing as though the album is a disappointment, but really that is just comparing it to Damon's more recent albums after his sound matured.  This is still a good, solid southern blues album, and if you just want to hear some fancy fretwork, Damon delivers the goods here.Further listening:  Josh Garrett, Colin Lake

The bluegrass/Celtic/classical crossover thing has been done.  A lot.  It can get boring, but this is a pretty exciting album.  The unique trio arrangement combined with the vitality of the players gives the album its power.  Jordan Tice has been quietly pushing flatpicking forward with more classical influences for a few years now, including in other trios including the brilliant Corbett/Chrisman/Tice album.  He isn't a flashy player, he just tries to play the unexpected note.  He succeeds.  Like Charles Sawtelle if he had been influenced by the Edgar Meyer side of the genre, Tice doesn't disappoint, even in the mellower moments.  Paul Kowert should be a familiar name, having been attached to geniuses from multiple generations, ranging from Mike Marshall to Sarah Jarosz and Chris Thile.  Like Tice, he favors unique phrasing over flash, so don't expect Edgar Meyer-type flash.  But that complements Tice well.  The new one for me was Brittany Haas on fiddle, and she's the fiery one.  That lends the critical balance to the more restrained playing of TIce and Kowert.  The music itself will sound right at home to fans of newgrass in the post-Strength In Numbers era.  Fans of Berline/Crary/Hickman, Douglas/Barenberg/Meyer, Ickes/Leftwich/Pomeroy or Phillips/Grier/Flinner should appreciate this one.  The guitar/fiddle/bass combination gives a complete range of pitch and tonalities, while TIce's odd sensibilities keep you guessing about what comes next.Further listening: Grant Gordy, Jake Schepps, Jayme Stone.

Tracks:FuntimeLife In the CountryWhere They Do Not Know My NameLittle Bitty TownDelilah / Love Songs SuckKeep My Skillet Good And GreasyThings I Done WrongOoh La LaDirt On The AngelEverything FadesGet It While You CanDanny Barnes has spent several years now playing around with electronic sounds and mixing them with real instruments.  Personally, I like real instruments, and this live album is just Danny, sans tricks.  He is a masterful banjo player, and his reputation for that has strangely overshadowed his acoustic guitar picking skills.  His nasal voice is... an acquired taste, but this unadorned album is basically a showcase for Danny's fiery picking.  While Bad Livers gained its reputation for mixing bluegrass, jug band sounds and punk aesthetics, this is pretty much a folk album.  An aggressive one, but a folk album nonetheless.  Fans of Danny and his previous band should already have versions of the tracks here, but not like this.  Without Mark Rubin or anyone else around, Danny has nowhere to hide, so he just plays his guts out.  Leave the electronics for those who can appreciate them.  This one's for instrumental snobs who want to hear Danny just pick.

Jim Hurst, despite being one of the most fascinating guitarists on the bluegrass seen, has a pretty sparse output, and this is his first true solo album.  This is Jim, stripped down to the essential sounds of his easy-going voice and always-innovative picking.  His previous solo albums have had accompanists, and his two duet albums with bassist Missy Raines were, obviously, collaborative efforts.  In my opinion, he is the type of musician who is at his best when there aren't any distractions.  That isn't to knock his rhythm playing, which is rock-solid, but his guitar work is so unique that it works best when it isn't competing with anyone for attention, which was what made his work with Raines so great.  Here, Jim has nowhere to hide, which is what brings out the best in him.  Let's talk, then, about why his playing shines so much here.  Innovation is always hard, and doubly so in bluegrass, which has traditionalism built into its DNA.  Jim breaks the rules in so many ways.  For starters, most bluegrass guitarists take their cues from the adaptation of fiddle tunes, like Doc and Clarence before them.  Jim, though, understands that one of the things that made Doc Watson so incredible was that he was as interested in fingerpicking as flatpicking.  Even with a plectrum, Jim draws on the influence of folk-based fingerpickers, giving his musical phrasing a sound that cannot be confused with any other flatpicker.  He also understands that you don't need each note to be articulated with its own picking motion.  Jim has found ways to incorporate the occasional slur into his flatpicking so that he can add his own rhythmic accompaniment while giving him the freedom to play more elaborate breaks.  And somehow he does all of this with the warmest tone of any bluegrass guitarist, which goes well with his voice.  That's pretty much what there is here.  Jim pulls out every trick in his extensive book, but the casual sound makes you feel like you are sitting right next to him listening to him mess around for fun.  Much of the album isn't bluegrass, but bluegrass fans are sure to appreciate it anyway.  This one might even be as good as Synergy (the second duet album with Raines).

14 years.  That's how long it has been since the first Word album introduced me to Robert Randolph.  That's a long wait, but this is quite a follow-up.  It is a marvelous blend of the blues-rock-gospel energy of their original album with the funkier and jazzier styles that one might hope they incorporate.  Randolph himself has matured greatly as an artist, no longer falling back on safely repetitive riffs and bringing more funk to his sound than his original "sacred steel" style of playing.  When one thinks of truly great slide guitarists (presuming one includes pedal steel), Robert Randolph has earned to have his name among the very best.  However, Randolph's maturity is not the only improvement.  The sound is more eclectic, partially because the rest of the musicians are no longer so intimidated by Randolph the phenom that they just stand back.  I'm not a fan of Medeski, Martin & Wood, and even when they became every proto-hipster's favorite jazz band in the 90's, I didn't get it.  But here, with a bunch of blues oriented musicians keeping him grounded, Medeski brings just the right amount of jazz without any of his more self-indulgent tendencies.  The North Mississippi Allstars are a bigger force here too, with guitarist Luther Dickinson trading licks with Randolph more confidently than 14 years ago.  Ironically, I'm not an obsessive fan of NMA either.  Together with Medeski and Randolph, though, the magic happens, and this album is magical.  It rocks harder than the first, it brings the funk, and there are even some nods to country, perhaps in honor of more traditional uses of Randolph's pedal steel.  I could do without the vocals, even if they bring in Ruthie Foster, but there isn't a bad musical choice here.  It is simply that there is a market for instrumental gospel for those who want to enjoy the music without being preached at.  It is mostly instrumental anyway.  Masterful instrumentals, to be clear.  A fine follow-up.  Hopefully it won't take another 14 years for the next.

Queen Esther is an odd one.  I learned of her through Hoosegow, her blues collaboration with experimental guitarist Elliott Sharp.  While Hoosegow was a stripped down affair filled with unusual twists and turns courtesy of Sharp's weirdness, Talkin Fishbowl Blues will sound more familiar to most listeners.  It is mostly R&B-flavored blues, with neither Sharp's attempts to challenge the listener nor Esther's jazzy flourishes.  Esther's voice is powerful without being overbearing, and the band is not particularly showy.  Occasionally, Esther draws from her other influences, including gospel and even some country, but mostly Esther and the band sound like what every bar blues band wishes it could be.  The Tammy Wynette cover at the end of the album will undoubtedly alienate some listeners who are either averse to country or the sentiment (anyone remember 1992?), but it is actually a fine way to cap an album by demonstrating more range than the band had shown up to the last track.

"Scruj MacDuhk" is basically a rough draft of "The Duhks," led by banjo player Leonard Podolak.  Without a vocalist like Jessee Havey on board, though, the sound is much more firmly rooted in Celtic and Cape Breton styles, without the bluesy elements that Havey brought to the table.  Not as eclectic as the Duhks, but as proficient and energetic.  Vocals mix English and French (these are Canadians), with the latter sounding like the precursor to Cajun music that it essentially is.  With a few rhythmic changes and more accordion, one could imagine the band moving south and fitting in.  As is, though, the sound is basically the Celtic-Cape Breton fusion that one would expect-- the new world version of Solas when Karan Casey was with them.  Later, Podolak would collaborate on the TurtleDuhks with a few fellow Canadian musicians, and return to this sound.  The album stands as an interesting testament, though, to the roots of the Duhks.

This is a basic, functional home security system that really requires that you are only attempting to monitor a few areas.  A large house with multiple doors and easily accessible windows just requires more.  Still, the basic motion sensor seems pretty effective with causal testing, setting a schedule for the lights is relatively simple, and there are no obvious holes to me, but I'm a casual consumer rather than a security expert.  I will admit, though, that the cameras make me nervous.  Do you really want internet-enabled cameras monitoring your home?  Remember a couple of years ago when someone found a way to hack into people's built-in computer cameras to turn them on remotely and watch through them without the light even going on?  My preference with this system is to use the motion sensors and light control system without the fancier stuff that I don't really trust.  If you do, that's up to you.

Let's be blunt about the iPhone 6 +.  The thing is huge.  If you use one, you are already sacrificing convenience.  For me, the extra battery life is worth it, but your mileage may vary.  Do you really want to make it bigger?  This case is a heavy duty protective case, but the result of using it is that the device is now not only too large to use comfortably one-handed, but too thick to put in your blazer pocket.  If you are biking, though, the tradeoff for protective casing is probably worth it.  Similarly, if you work in an environment with heavy activity, the protective case is probably worth it.  I didn't want to drop my iPhone just to test a case, but if I weren't an office-dweller, I would be much more comfortable with this than with the slimmer holster case I have.  However, the slimmer holster case allows me to use either the belt clip, or put the device in my inside blazer pocket.  With the Drop Tech case, that second option just isn't an option.  So should you get it?  If you care about extra protection for your device more than minimizing the inconvenience of the already huge size, then yes.  Similarly, if you want some rubberized flaps that keep dirt and grime out of the ports, this will do the job.  If you don't need a lot of extra shock absorption and aren't taking the phone through environments with a lot of extra particulate matter, go with something slimmer.  There are plenty of options.

This desk has a couple of nice features, but before buying it, keep in mind a couple of points that you might not have considered.  First, the USB ports.  Nice, right?  Remember, though, that we are in the process of transitioning to the next version of USB, and that will require dongles to mix the old and new USB systems.  Is now really the time to buy furniture based on the built-in USB ports?  Maybe not.  Second, consider something that may be more aesthetic.  The curve in the base puts your chair in the center of the desk.  Fine, but where does the printer go?  That depends on the size of your computer, and the size of your printer.  If you have one of those tiny things like my old lexmark inkjet, it can go on that top shelf and stay out of the way.  However, I have a larger Brother printer/copier/scanner unit that just doesn't have a convenient location here.  On the other hand, were it not for the curve in the base, you could put your computer and seat on one side, and have room on the other for the printer.  It just doesn't work, though, with your computer in the center.  Whether or not this matters to you depends on the size of your printer.  Small printer = decent design for you.  Large printer = look elsewhere.

Leftover Salmon is back.  WIth Drew Emmitt off on his own (or playing with Bill Nershi from String Cheese Incident) and Vince Herman leading the outstanding roots-country-rock group Great American Taxi, Leftover Salmon was basically on hiatus for a while.  They came back with Aquatic Hitchhiker in 2012, which was a fine entry into their catalog, although they played it a bit safe (by the standards of a group who describe their style as "polyethnic Cajun slamgrass," anyway), and the album was just a comfortable demonstration of their old style.  On High Country, they are back in top form, with a few guests and Little Feat's Bill Payne on keys.  It is hard to say which element brought them back into peak form, but even though the basics of their style remain the same, the playing just has more excitement to it than Aquatic Hitchhiker did.  There are more hints of what Herman was doing with Great American Taxi, more patience on the slower numbers reminiscent of one of my favorites from Bridges To Bert-- Nothing But Time, and Andy Thorn has more fully integrated himself into the thankless task of replacing the irreplaceable Mark Vann on banjo.  In fact, one of the highlights is a straight-up traditional bluegrass number called Thornpipe, in reference to Andy and the traditional "hornpipe" pieces.  The band even dips into Little Feat's catalog with Bill on board, and not surprisingly, the transition to LoS's sound works just fine.  One can forgive them for the slightly juvenile final track, Finish Your Beer, which is about exactly what you think.  I don't know what to read into the transition from the  hints of pot in their earlier albums (they are from Colorado...) to a song about beer here.  It probably means nothing.  The song is fun, in a sophomoric kind of way.  The rest of the album, though, is Leftover Salmon, back on top.  Welcome back.

JJ Grey can do no wrong, and he has honed a style of southern, funky blues to perfection.  His secret?  Hold nothing back.  Ever.  JJ sings and plays his heart out.  It took me a while to understand that this was his real trick.  The first two albums, credited merely to "Mofro," had a very different sound from what he started to play on Country Ghetto while playing as "JJ Grey and Mofro," with more emphasis on lo-fi acoustic sounds early on.  Even when he moved to the "JJ Grey and Mofro" monicker, he kept a lot of open space in his music, which I thought was the key.  Since then, his arrangements have gotten bigger and fuller.  And it's still great.  He doesn't even need Anthony Trube to play flashy guitar solos all over the place.  The horn arrangements have gotten more confident, and everything just keeps that propulsive groove going at full power throughout another inspiring album.  The music is inspiring.  It is cathartic.  It makes you feel like you know everything about JJ.  And that's before even talking about the lyrics.  Usually, I'm not big on lyrics, but JJ is worth listening to.  And who else can write such an inspiring song about lusting after his wife?  Just great.  Put on Ol' Glory, and don't do anything else.  Just listen and be up-lifted.Of course, Derek Trucks puts in another appearance, which is always welcome.  I'd like these two to play together more often, but with the Tedeschi Trucks Band reaching similar levels of perfection, Derek's wife is already the majestic singer needed to compliment his slide guitar.  Different, of course, but equally powerful.  JJ, though, just has the best gritty voice around.  I love this stuff.  JJ can do no wrong, and he manages that by holding nothing back.

There just isn't enough of Clarence White's bluegrass picking.  Even with the Kentucky Colonels, he was an ensemble player.  That is to his credit, but I'd rather listen to Clarence than Roland.  On the surface, then, this looks like an ideal album.  In a stripped down setting, you get more Clarence, proportionately.  Unfortunately, the album is quite short (around half an hour), and the sound quality is far from ideal, including plenty of pops and cracks from the source tape.  And it still isn't just half and hour straight of Clarence taking lead breaks.  This is good music, and both Roger and Billy Ray are fine players.  At the end of the day, though, even for the value of Clarence's playing, I'll take Appalachian Swing over this one, and both Clarence's "Flatpicking" album, and the compilation of solo recordings offer a broader array of what Clarence could do with a plectrum.  This trio album is a good addition to the Clarence White acoustic catalog, which is sparse enough that we'll take what we can get.  Appalachian Swing is still pretty hard to top, though.

Twenty years of Geoff Achison.  Strange.  Some musicians take a while to develop.  Some come right out of the gate fully formed.  I recently tracked down Geoff's long-out-of-print first album, Big Machine, which was released twenty years before this concert, hence the title.  It is fascinating to see how fully formed Geoff's concept was, and yet how finely he has honed his approach since then.  Geoff is truly devoted to his craft, and his fluid, slippery guitar technique just gets more precise every year.  Still, nobody sounds like him, not even Hamilton Loomis, and nobody blends scorching blues, funk and R&B like him.  He doesn't disappoint.  So, how do we assess this concert?  First, the material, which is the only real stumbling block for me.  It makes some sense for an anniversary concert to focus on favorites, but the material on Geoff's electric concert albums is getting somewhat redundant.  Tell Me Something I Don't Know, Crazy Horse, and others are great pieces, but not only do I have other versions of them, I have other similar live versions on his other live albums.  A bit more diversity in song selection would be nice.  Also, for an anniversary concert, why not showcase some of Geoff's spectacularly percussive acoustic work?  Nothing here disappoints, but I'd rather have a live album of rarer selections and a broader overview of what he can do.  Second, Geoff's voice.  He always has that slightly histrionic warble, but it is pretty subdued here.  No complaints.  Finally, Geoff's propensity to have backing musicians play rinky-dink keyboards.  The keys sound pretty decent here.  All-in-all, then, I would rate this at 5 stars if I didn't already have similar live versions of most of these tracks anyway.  That said, it isn't entirely redundant.  It took a while after his time in Georgia, but it sounds like he is finally incorporating some Allman-type sounds, which is ironic since Whipping Post has long been in his repertoire, although his versions are totally unique.Note that this set comes with a DVD, but it won't play on a region 1 player.  Just be warned about that.

Geoff Achison is just amazing.  His guitar style is so fluid and elegant that you can tell within two notes when you hear him playing.  His acoustic work is always astounding.  His electric work can be more hit-and-miss.  While there is some acoustic work here, the album is predominantly electric, and it is the best of Geoff's electric studio-based work.  He strikes the perfect balance between tight arrangements with a strong band and his funk/R&B-laced blues guitar playing, and unlike many of his live electric albums, the keyboards here don't sound like those rinky-dink Casio things from the '80s.  I have commented in reviews of his live albums how that can detract from the genius of his own instrumental work, but everything here just sounds good.  What is fascinating about the sound, though, is that while it reflects Geoff's time in Atlanta hanging around various Allman-affiliated musicians like Randall Bramblett, there isn't much influence of that.  Instead, I hear more shades of '70s Jeff Beck in the slightly reggae-tinged, jazzy fusion sound that pops up all over the place on this album.  At this point, I have pretty much come around to Geoff's voice.  It will never be my favorite, and I still find it somewhat affected with the over-emphasized warble, but I just associate it so much with his guitar work now that they are part of a total package.  And there's the bottom line-- Geoff sounds like no one else.  What else can a musician aspire to?  I still can't figure out how he gets those guitar sounds, and even Hamilton Loomis can't come close (Hamilton being the most similar I have heard.  Keep it up, Geoff

This budget all-in-one does the job.  I'll keep things brief.Printing:  Fast and clean.  'Nuff said.Scanning:  The only problem I have is that when I connect wirelessly, pressing a button on the machine itself to scan doesn't seem to send the file to my computer.  I can open Brother's application on my computer, press the scan button on the computer, and have it work, but that means I cannot put the machine at more than arm's length from my computer and do any significant scanning because I have to walk back and forth.  That diminishes the value of a wireless connection.  I have followed all of the instructions, and I just can't seem to get that working.  I am not exactly a computer expert, but I'm generally at least marginally competent.  I am probably doing something wrong, but even if that's true, it shouldn't be as difficult as it is.Faxing:  Is this still a thing?  I don't think I've sent a fax since the 90's.  The alternative was FTP.  Anyone remember that pain-in-the-rear system?Set-up:  Slightly more complicated than I would like, but not a major ordeal.  It's a breeze if you just want to use a USB connection.Over-all:  A good, solid machine.  The only real issue I have is that the wifi issues are a bit harder than they need to be.

Billy Cardine is at it again.  One of the best dobro players around continues his quest to show that there are players whose names aren't "Jerry Douglas."  This project shows just a few hints of bluegrass, and along with a guest appearance from Biscuit Burners bandmate Mary Lucey on vocals, Cardine works primarily in a dobro/bass/percussion trio to explore a very Indian-influenced world-jazz-fusion type sound.  The Indian sound isn't new for Cardine-- he has been weaving those sounds into the Biscuit Burners and his solo works for a while, but this album tries to embrace the Indian sound throughout, augmented by a few more western traditions.  This kind of thing has been done before for slide guitarists, but not generally with a dobro.  Ry Cooder, of course, recorded with VM Bhatt, Bob Brozman recorded with Debashish Bhattacharya, and recently Jeff Lang has been playing with tabla player Bobby Singh after years of incorporating Indian sounds into his playing.  Cardine, though, favors the dobro, whereas Cooder prefers bottleneck, Brozman liked resonators, and Lang uses primarily a Weissenborn when playing with Singh.  Also, all three come from a blues background, and even with the bluegrass kept to a minimum, the subtle hints show that Cardine is coming at this from a separate field entirely.  His accompanists are good, and one could easily mistake the bassist for Michael Manring.  Whether that is a good thing or a bad thing for you depends pretty much on your opinion of Windham Hill.  The vaguely new age/fusion type vibe is definitely here, though.  Make no mistake, though-- you won't hear this while getting aromatherapy.  The music is interesting, and it will be nice to hear where Cardine goes with it.  The album doesn't hold up quite as well as Lang's "Djan Djan" project for me, though, simply because it doesn't surprise as much.  When I read about Djan Djan, that didn't quite prepare me for everything in it.  The Billy Sea pretty much sounds like what I expect, and I sort of expect Cardine to throw some weird ideas out that I wouldn't have seen coming from his previous work.  Cardine usually surprises me more than this.  Again, "Global Americana" is a good album, and worth listening if you want to hear the dobro in an unconventional context, and for someone other than Cardine, I might give this four stars.  Billy, though, has set a higher standard for himself.  The next one will probably be weirder, and therefore better.By the way, keep an eye out for Maru Tarang-- Jeff Lang's current project with Bobby Singh.  Also, track down an old album by Crowsong called "Dark Comes Light," in addition to the stuff mentioned above.And should I mention that Jerry Douglas recorded an album with VM Bhatt?  No?  OK.  Sorry.

Second time's a charm.  The duo of Andreas Kapsalis and Goran Ivanovic put out their first album in 2009.  It was quite good.  But this one is genius.  It just took some time to put their collective talents to their best use together.  I have been a fan of Goran for years now.  His albums with Fareed Haque were masterpieces blending Haque's unique jazz leanings with Goran's Macedonian roots.  Fans of Vlatko Stefanovski & Miroslav Tadic's albums together should check them out.  Kapsalis, though, is more of a slap-n-tap type, following in the tradition of Michael Hedges and Preston Reed.  I didn't learn about him until he hooked up with Ivanovic.  Together, their first album had moments of greatness, but the percussive approach of Kapsalis and Ivanovic's Macedonian sound are not as obviously compatible as Ivanovic and Haque's styles.  On Blackmail, though, everything comes together perfectly.  Kapsalis' percussive approach provides the propulsive energy while Ivanovic's mastery of Macedonian folk with hints of classical and jazz provide the unique flavor.  Guitar duos risk either redundancy when the players' styles are too similar, or awkwardness when they can't find the right middle ground.  Blackmail shows what happens when two completely different guitarists  figure out exactly the right balance.  Imagine Miroslav Tadic and Michael Hedges trying to jam.  It could go very wrong.  Or it could go very right.  This album sounds like the latter.

This album is credited to Bad Livers, but it should be noted that (with the exception of an older live track) it is just the duo of Danny Barnes and Mark Rubin, sans fiddle.  Danny sticks to the banjo, and Mark sticks to the bass.  You might think, then, that they play a bit more traditionally than the Bad Livers' normal bluegrass/jug band/punk weirdness.  Perhaps, but when they start out with a Sun Ra cover and throw in nods to Monk, you know you are still listening to Danny Barnes.  The stripped down sound appeals to me, and the background noises add to the easy-going, casual nature of the recording.  Basically, you are listening to Danny and Mark play around and have fun.  The album lacks the visionary brilliance of Delusions of Banjer, but it also isn't as challenging, meaning that it may be a good way for more traditional roots-music fans to ease their way into Bad Livers and the musical world of Danny Barnes.  The voice is as nasal as ever, and that could remain a turnoff, but Danny's hard-driving banjo work and relentless need for fun make this about as accessible as any Bad Livers album is likely to be.  Come on, give it a try.  Let Danny take you on a journey through Appalachia by way of his own disturbed mind.

Beppe Gambetta could easily be written off as a novelty from the short version of his bio--  he is an Italian musician drawn to bluegrass-based flatpicking because he developed an early obsession with Doc Watson.  Any such illusions should be dispelled by this fine compilation of live tracks just by looking at the roster of musicians anxious to share the stage at the Teatro Della Corte with Beppe.  He is joined here by a rotating cast of musicians from both sides of the Atlantic, including Darrell Scott, Mike Marshall, Bruce Molsky, Dan Crary, Patty Larkin, Jim Hurst, Tony McManus, and others.  If that guest list doesn't have you anxious to hear the album, you probably don't listen to modern acoustic music.  They are distinguished not only by their stature in the acoustic music world, but by the diversity of styles that they play.  And they are the ones lined up to play with Beppe, who shows his wide-ranging musical palette here with styles ranging from American folk and bluegrass to Brazilian to jazz to European traditions, and even some Balkan hints on a track with Bruce Molsky.  Beppe is a musical omnivore who just happens to play mostly with a plectrum.  There may not be another flatpicker out there with such range.  That wouldn't matter if he didn't play his heart out every time.  Fortunately, he does.  Beppe puts on a great show.  It would be nice to have a compilation of live tracks from his fantastic solo shows, but he is such a fun accompanist that this album is easily recommended to any Beppe fan, or anyone else curious about the Italian flatpicking phenom.  Would this list of guests play with a slouch?  No way.

I had low expectations for this device, but my expectations were surpassed.  Let's take this step by step.1)  Sound quality.  It's a tiny, bluetooth speaker.  How good can it be?  Better than what I had in college, and that thing took up a lot more space.  I would put the sound quality at least on par with those boom boxes we all used to have and probably a bit better, which, for the size, strikes me as reasonable.  I can take this thing around the house, take it outside while grilling, take it for picnics, etc., and we're happy.  The key to that assessment, of course, is that the speaker is fine when the music isn't the center of attention.  It's good accompaniment.  Like those old boom boxes, but much smaller.2)  Set-up and operation.  Easy, as bluetooth devices should be.  The only thing worth noting is that I kind of like being able to pause the music with a button on the speaker so that I don't have to pull out the iPad or whatever is streaming the music.  This is the only surprising feature, and I like it.  Convenience is a good thing.3)  Battery life.  This one had me worried.  I get about 9 hours on a full charge, which is good enough for most purposes.  The device works on a rechargeable battery, which has its benefits and drawbacks.  The benefit is obvious, but rechargeable batteries don't work for as long, and have a limited number of charges.  Once the internal battery goes (probably around three years, depending on how much you use it), you will basically just have to keep it plugged in by running the USB charge cable through whatever old block you have sitting around from an i-whatever that died years ago.  At that point, it just won't be as portable.Over-all assessment: better than I expected, and pretty darn good.  Perfect to give to a kid going off to college since it packs easily, gives portability, and to be frank, they just don't care that much about the audiophile experience anyway.

What is there to say?  It is a USB-lightning cable to connect iPhones/iPads to your computer or a power block.  It works, it's cheaper than what Apple will charge you (barring the occasional pricing glitch), and the construction has no warning signs.  The only thing to keep in mind is that this is just the cable, with no AC adaptor.  That you will have to buy separately.  I'm happy to have this to keep in my office-- when a device has a battery warning, I can charge it through my computer.  'Nuff said.

Just when I think I have a handle on Elliott Sharp's blues-based "Terraplane" projects, he releases "4am Always."  What do you listen to at 4 AM when you can't sleep and the air is thick with menace?  You need something spooky, with the darkness of Skip James and the funkiness of Maggot Brain-era Funkadelic.  If you are in New Orleans, you listen to Dr. John's first album, "Gris Gris," from his Night Tripper days.  Apparently Elliott Sharp has decided that the world needs New York's answer to Gris Gris, because it just wouldn't sound right in Greenwich Village.  So he put together this perfectly titled gem, which is vaguely rooted in blues, but mostly just spooky music, filled with odd textures, rhythms that feel like they could fall apart at any moment, and instead of the loping rhythms of New Orleans, we get New York's tension and the feeling that an explosion is just one slip away.This doesn't really sound like Sharp's last few Terraplane albums.  Those recent albums have been rooted in both blues and the jazz stylings of Mingus, Rahsaan Roland Kirk, and Sun Ra, with the free-wheeling energy implied by those associations.  This is a darker album, stripped of the horn section led by Curtis Fowlkes that graced more recent Terraplane albums, stripped of Mingus's son's vocals, and sadly stripped of Hubert Sumlin's guest spots (RIP, Hubert).  With a configuration that is basically a trio (augmented sometimes by Tracie Morris's chant-like vocals), Sharp overdubs different string instruments in a few places, but leaves a lot of open space, with plenty of subtle menace rushing in to fill the space.  As always, Sharp's guitar cuts deeply without ever calling attention to itself through needless flash, and the oddness of Sharp's background in avant-garde jazz creeps in just enough to keep everything off balance.  This is a masterpiece of dark, blues-based weirdness, and it is the perfect soundtrack to those late night moments of unease in places like New York.

I suppose I am not the real target demographic for this speaker set.  It is pretty clearly aimed at those who want a modest, budget enhancement for gaming, whereas I am a music fan.  The speaker set basically exists for the primary purpose of having a small, unobtrusive subwoofer.  However, the main speakers are not exactly audiophile equipment, so what you really get with this set is the ability to crank up the bass a bit so that there is a modest rumble with those explosions in games.  For music, the sound is only a modest improvement on the built-in speakers on my iMac desktop.  Frankly, I have no desire to crank up the bass while listening to Miles Davis, so without good treble, these speakers are not for me.  The other limiting factor to keep in mind is that the cables are rather short, meaning you won't have many options for speaker placement.  They are just long enough to keep the subwoofer at your feet underneath the desk with the main speakers to either side of your monitor.  For music, speaker placement matters far more, so you need to have longer cables.Is this for you?  That depends.  If you want a good listening experience for music, sorry, but you'll have to shell out more money.  If you just want a cheap set with a subwoofer for those games, then I suppose these might do, but don't expect miracles.

Alas, The Bridge is no more.  This album, which predates their self-titled not-really-debut, is an interesting rough draft of the band, with some live tracks and some relatively informal studio tracks.  The basic elements of the band that released "Blind Man's Hill" (an all-time classic, in my opinion), are here, including Little Feat-style rock, some country, some bluegrass, some funk, and yes, some beatboxing.  Two things merit discussion.  First, the sound here just isn't as tight.  Several of the tracks are extended jams, making it sound like the band was trying to cash in on the tail end of the jam band resurgence brought on by the HORDE festival in the 1990's.  Here's the thing, though.  If you are a virtuoso on the level of, say, Derek Trucks, you can play a 10-minute guitar solo that is thoroughly exciting for every second of it.  Not many guitarists can pull that off.  Cris Jacobs is a fine guitarist, in the David Hidalgo tradition (Steve Berlin would later have a hand in The Bridge's sound, so Los Lobos is a pretty good reference point anyway).  Hidalgo's perfectly structured, elegant, concise solos are vital to the sound of Los Lobos, and Jacobs learned that trick too, helping to make Blind Man's Hill such an amazing album.  On the extended live tracks here, though, the band gets a bit self-indulgent.  The elements are all here, but they just didn't quite have that Little Feat-level of tightness yet.  Had I been in the audience, I'm sure I would have loved it, but without that live energy, the extended solos here come across as just a tad self-indulgent.  Don't get me wrong-- this is good music.  It's just not GREAT music, which Blind Man's Hill is.Then there's the beatboxing and hip hop stuff.  OK, I'll admit that I'm just not a hip hop fan.  The beatboxing on their later albums comes across as perhaps a bit too cute, but it doesn't detract.  Here, though, there is more of it, and more direct reference to hip hop beyond the beatboxing.  Their clear fondness for funk makes it seem at least somewhat sincere, and the beatboxing might just be a nostalgic childhood reference, particularly when it references the theme from Beverly Hills Cop.  But it doesn't sit right.  The word, "appropriation," has an ugly history, and I wouldn't go so far as to accuse the band of it, but some of the hip hop references seem aimed more at the frat boy audience than real hip hop music snobs.  I'm neither, though.  On their subsequent releases, The Bridge toned down the hip hop and beatboxing stuff, recognizing that it could easily come across as gimmicky, but like I said, this is kind of a rough draft for the band.I don't want my criticisms here to take away from the fact that Cross Street Market is an enjoyable album that fans of the now-sadly-defunct band will enjoy.  It just isn't as good as what was to come.

As far as I'm concerned at this point, Elliott Sharp's avant-garde jazz career might as well not exist.  I never liked that style anyway.  Sharp, as the leader of the "Terraplane" band, is simply one of the leading blues guitarists around, and this album is as seamless a blend of blues, jazz and funk as can be found anywhere.  This particular album from Terraplane turns the jazz influence up higher than many others, but fortunately for those of us who don't like avant-garde jazz, Sharp dips more into Mingus territory, which is appropriate given the bassist's son's presence in the band.  Perhaps more than Mingus, though, I think of Rahsaan Roland Kirk when I listen to this album, and what would have happened if Rahsaan had recorded with Hendrix, or maybe Buddy Guy.  Nowhere is that combination evoked more clearly than on "USA Out Of NYC," during which I cannot help but think about "Blacknuss" due to the structure, the feel and the chanting.  The piece's title is an elegant middle finger to those who implicitly, and sometimes explicitly, denigrate New York and its residents as not being real Americans as a cheap political attack.  Some might be offended by Sharp's sentiment, even some who express similar regional loyalties to regions other than NYC, but let's be honest.  The people who make snide comments about New York not being a part of "real America" are more likely to buy Lee Greenwood albums than Elliott Sharp albums.  Really, then, the piece just serves as an opportunity to blend Rahsaan-style, funk-infused jazz with blistering blues guitar that somehow manages to be virtuosic without ever calling attention to flashy technique.  And that pretty much sums up Sharp's approach on this album.  Take the best from hard-edged funk, jazz and urban blues, stick it in a blender, and have a lot of fun.  Maybe Sharp wouldn't be able to make this kind of music if he weren't steeped in some of the more experimental kinds of jazz, and if so, I appreciate what he has taken from that, but at the end of the day for me, Sharp is just an awe-inspiring blues musician.My references to Mingus and Kirk suggest other blues/jazz hybrids like Heritage Blues Orchestra, and this is probably the Sharp album closest to that approach, but where Heritage draws more from rural Southern styles of blues, Sharp is a New York musician through-and-through (hence that song...).  Technically, he wasn't born there, but he may as well have been, and the gritty urban sound makes Secret Life a wholly different animal from Heritage Blues Orchestra.  Nevertheless, fans may appreciate both.  I do.

When most blues fans think of the people pushing the genre forward most effectively, names like Otis Taylor come to mind.  A strong case can be made on the basis of albums like this that avant-garde jazz guitarist Elliott Sharp belongs in that category.  This album was recorded under the auspices of Sharp's "Terraplane" project, which is the name he gives to the band with which he plays blues-based material.  The first Terraplane album was an interesting but not particularly innovative Hendrix-plays-the-blues type of album.  By the time this album rolled around, though, Terraplane had evolved into something truly unique.  While everything here is clearly derived from the blues, half of the time I have no idea what I am listening to.  I just know I love it.  There is Mingus-style jazz, with none other than the bassist's son on vocals, some pretty hard funk, some experimental noise, all tied together by a few basic blues patterns and a disregard bordering on out-right contempt for any form of traditionalism.  It is aggressive, exciting and dangerous music, as unpredictable as anything you are likely to hear in modern blues-based music.The more time I spend listening to Sharp's Terraplane project, the more I find myself thinking about Gary Lucas-- another current obsession of mine.  Whereas Lucas' weirdness has a distinctly punk-ish feeling, owing to his background with Captain Beefheart, Sharp traces his routes back more to people like Ornette Coleman.  What is interesting to me about this is that I'm not really a fan of Beefheart, I never really got into Coleman, and I don't like either punk or avant-garde jazz.  Yet, phenomenal guitarists like Lucas and Sharp can use their backgrounds in genres I don't like to make some truly creative blues.  Basically, I wouldn't have expected to like Forgery as much as I do, but the wild improvisations, just barely rooted in blues, have so much vitality that I can't help but love it.  I still don't like Sharp's more high-profile avant-garde recordings, but albums like this make a strong case that he is a leading light in the future of blues.  Or "blues."
