Or whatever the heck we want to call this Frankenstein's monster of an album.

With the holidays coming up it really would make a nice gift.I purchased this product at a discount in exchange for sharing my honest and unbiased review. Opinion is entirely my own.

This is a very nice set of Washi Tape. It comes with 5 high-quality rolls, which are all lovely. I love the bright colors and fun prints. I will be using these to seal my holiday card envelopes this year, and I think that they will look great!I am happy with this set of tape and would definitely recommend it.I purchased this product at a discount in exchange for sharing my honest and unbiased review. Opinion is entirely my own.

3:59 MinsThe Pure Clean Automatic Vacuum Cleaner works well to vacuum up dust and crumbs from the our  tile and laminate floors. It has a large garbage collection tray which is great because it takes a while to fill up. I love that it is thin enough to fit under my tables and sofa, so it can reach areas my regular vacuum cleaner cannot.The only thing that I do not like about the Pure Clean is that I found that it gets stuck on my area rug. It would be fine if it just didn't go up on it, but it does go up on it, and then gets stuck. So, whenever I use my Pure Clean I have to keep an eye out for when it gets stuck on the rug so I can take it off. This gets annoying, and removing the area rug when I use this is not an option (a table is on top of it!). Therefore, I have been only able to use the Pure Clean in my kitchen. It works beautifully in my kitchen, and I will be using it daily in the kitchen.I would definitely recommend the Pure Clean Automatic Vacuum Cleaner. It is inexpensive and works well. However if you have area rugs like me, buy with caution. This device is definitely best to use in areas without any carpet or rugs.I purchased this product at a discount in exchange for sharing my honest and unbiased review. Opinion is entirely my own.

This Aromatherapy Essential Oil Diffuser by Naska is great not only for diffusing yoru favorite essential oils, but also as a humidifier, air purifier, ionizer and as a great decoration. It features 16 colors of LED lights, an adjustable mist, timer settings, and turns off automatically when water level is low. It has a 10 hour run time, which is not too shabby.I like to use my Aromatherapy Essential Oil Diffuser to diffuse oil in my bathroom. Some peppermint oil in the morning when I am getting ready for my day helps me to wake up and get going. It is such nice start to the day. In the evenings I like to unwind with some lavender oil and a nice hot bath or shower. Very relaxing. I mix it up and use other oils at times, but those 2 are my absolute favorites.I am very happy with the Naska Aromatherapy Essential Oil Diffuser and I would absolutely recommend it. It is lovely and easy to use, and would even make a nice holiday gift.I received this product for free in exchange for sharing my honest and unbiased review. Opinion is entirely my own.

In all honesty, when I ordered this set I was a little concerned that these spatulas might be flimsy because they were made from silicone. Luckily, once I received the set I realized that I was 100% wrong. These spatulas are strong and sturdy - they have a steel core and are coated in food grade BPA-free silicone which is heat resistant up to 450 degree.The spatulas come in a set of four, with 2 being larger and 2 smaller. They are comfortable to hold, work well, and are easy to clean (dishwasher-friendly!). I am very pleased with this set and I would recommend it without hesitation.I received this product for free in exchange for sharing my honest and unbiased review. Opinion is entirely my own.

This Emoji Pillow is so fun and unique - I love it! I got the heart eyed emoji, but now I totally want to collect them all. They pillows are soft and plush, and comfortable to use to on the couch watching TV or in bed to prop my head up a little bit extra to read a book. The pillow would look nice on a chair as a throw pillow or on your bed.I think that this pillow would make a great holiday gift for a tween, teen, or adult who loves to text message. Heck I am in my 30s and I love it!I received this product for free in exchange for sharing my honest and unbiased review. Opinion is entirely my own.

This set of LED Gloves are vrey bright, colorful, and fun. The gloves are white with a beige band around the wrist, similar to gardening gloves. When the gloves arrive pull out the little tab to active them, and then turn them on. Keep pressing the ON button to cycle though the different effects, which there are many of.  I really like these LED Gloves and would definitely recommend them.I received this product for free in exchange for sharing my honest and unbiased review. Opinion is entirely my own.

I love these gloves! They are so unique and perfect for Halloween. They will be great for a skeleton costume. The gloves are plain white gloves with a beige band around the wrist. They remind me of gardening gloves. Once they arrive be sure to pull out the little tab to active them, and then go ahead and turn them on. You can keep pressing the button to cycle though the different effects. Very cool! The LED lights are bright and can be seen well even in a lit room. There would be killer at a black light party or something like that too.I really like these LED flashing gloves and would recommend them without hesitation.I received this product for free in exchange for sharing my honest and unbiased review. Opinion is entirely my own.

I LOVE my new shower caddy! I have been wanting to find a solution to having bottles of shampoo, conditioner and body wash sitting on the edge of the tub, and this is the perfect solution. It has plenty of room to keep everything neat and tidy. Two shelves for all my bottles and then 3 hooks which are great for razors, my shower comb, and to hang my shower poof off of. It looks great, and is well made too. It is made out of stainless steel so it will not rust like a cheaply made shower caddy would. I love my new shower caddy and am happy to have it in our shower. We would definitely recommend this shower caddy to anyone and everyone!I received this product for free in exchange for sharing my honest and unbiased review. Opinion is entirely my own.

This high-efficiency LED light has been very useful as a book and work light in my bed room. I can easily clamp the light onto my nightstand or headboard and aim the light right at my bed. The light has 3 levels of adjustable brightness, which are nice to have. I like how bright it can get, and I would recommend this light without hesitation.I received this product for free in exchange for sharing my honest and unbiased review. Opinion is entirely my own.

This Costume Princess Hat from OliaDesign is a great hat for a Halloween costume, school play, or  an home costume chest. It is a sturdy black hat with a decorative red band around it and a yellow feather plume.The hat is made one size fits all but is designed for adults, not children.  Although a teen would fit in the hat well also, just not younger children as the hat would be too large.While to me it doesn't' look like what I would think of as a "princess hat" it is a nice hat indeed. I think this hat would be great for a wide variety of costumes, although not so much a princess costume.Overall I am pleased with this hat and would recommend it, as long as you check out the images and understand this is not a typical "princess" hat.I received this product for free in exchange for sharing my honest and unbiased review. Opinion is entirely my own.

If you are looking for a hook to hang your garden hose on, this Spigot Hook Hose Holder from OliaDesign is perfect for the job. The hook is made of steel and it very strong and sturdy. You can just place the hanger over the spigot and then loop the hose around the bottom. I love how neat and tidy the hose is when wrapped around this hook, and I would definitely recommend it.I received this product for free in exchange for sharing my honest and unbiased review. Opinion is entirely my own.

This set of Venetian Costume Party Masks are beautiful. They are gold with colored feathers and feature LED lights in the feathers which shine brightly. The masks come in a set of 6, each with different colored feathers.  The makes come in only one size, but it should fit almost any teen or adult. The masks are secured in the back with a ribbon tie. I would absolutely recommend these masks for your next masquerade or costume party!I received this product for free in exchange for sharing my honest and unbiased review. Opinion is entirely my own.

This Electric Shaver from Creation Springs is awesome. I got it for my husband, and watched him shave with it for the first time. We love that it can be used wet or dry, and the large shaving area it gets with it's 3 heads. A larger shaving area means quicker shaving, which is a plus. There is a contour trimmer built in that can be popped up and used for sideburns or other contouring. After shaving the heads can be rinsed off in the water (since this baby is waterproof) and then opened up and emptied out. I like how all the hair is trapped in the heads rather than falling all over my bathroom sink and floor.We are very happy with this Electric Shaver, and would recommend it without hesitation. It would make a great holiday gift or birthday gift for a man or young man as well.I purchased this product at a discount in exchange for sharing my honest and unbiased review. Opinion is entirely my own.

These hair removal strips from BodyHonee are great. They are made from an all-natural formula so I know that they are safe to use on my sensitive skin. I love that they come in strips, makes waxing so easy-peasy! I run the strip together in my hands for a minute or two to warm it up, then just peel and stick on my skin. I run it down really well then pull up quickly in the direction opposite of the growth. It helps to hold my skin tight while pulling it off.TIP: make sure skin is completely dry before using - otherwise it will not work well!I love these strips, and would definitely recommend them.I received this product for free in exchange for sharing my honest and unbiased review. Opinion is entirely my own.

This is a pretty bell that will look great on the tree, especially with the room lights off and the twinkle lights reflecting in the silver. There's nice detail in the ringer (in the shape of a Christmas tree), too. It's sized nicely for the average tree (not too small), so I can see it becoming one of my favorite ornaments over the years. It would also make a great hostess gift at a Christmas party.My only quibble is that it seems a little lightweight, but that will at least keep it from weighing down the branches of the tree.

This is a cost-effective way to get some basic Spanish skills under your belt. I've previously used Pimsleur's Italian and Portuguese CDs and prefer their style - but the cost is so high it's hard to justify. The lessons are pretty basic, but they're good for an absolute beginner (like me). One reason I prefer Pimsleur is that I picked up some of the grammar as I went, which I'm not doing as easily with these lessons. I find that understanding grammar helps me form my own sentences and have conversations in a new language (I got around Italy for 2 weeks with the Pimsleur courses), so I'll probably pick up some books to supplement this course. But overall, I'd recommend this for basic, "getting-started" language training.

I haven't used this type of hair wrap before, so I wasn't sure what to expect. I hoped for faster-drying hair and a fast-drying towel. The promise of fewer split ends, etc. from less blow drying time was nice, too. That said, I'm going back to my usual towel unless I'm traveling.This wrap is very thin. The fabric is soft (as you'd expect from microfiber), and while it may hold "up to seven times its weight in moisture," that's not a lot of moisture given the starting weight. I tried wrapping this several different ways over several days (I'm glad another reviewer posted instructions), and never noticed that it did more than my usual towel. It even seemed less effective if I didn't wrap it "just so."So while this might be a nice addition at the gym or in hotels with paper-thin towels, I don't see this as being of much use at home. I'll keep it for travel, the beach, and the pool - but only if a regular towel isn't handy.

What a handy little dish! It's definitely attractive enough to go use on the table, and feels nice in the hand. The shape is good for passing from person to person, too. But being able to pop the lid on and store the contents without dirtying another dish is really the best feature. My one quibble is that the lid takes a little finessing to fit perfectly, and I worry that it won't hold up over time. Make sure to check the dimensions, too, since this is definitely a *small* dish.

Otterbox cases are my go-to for protecting my phone, so I had high expectations of this one. Another reviewer put it well when s/he described this as "Otterbox lite" - it's definitely a lightweight case with about half the usual Otterbox protection. It does fit well, and all the ports are easy to access. The inserts are a (kind of) cool idea, but they're definitely gimmicky. For this price, I'd expect the case to come with 2 or 3 inserts, at least, especially considering they seem pretty cheap and flimsy.If you're going for a decorative case, this one has some decent options. The price is just too high for what it is, though. Improve either the protection or the inserts, and this might be worth the price.

What I liked:1. Gorgeous photos. This cookbook is as much eye candy as it is inspiration. If you're a cook who likes to browse a cookbook by the pictures to find your dinner ideas, this one does not disappoint. Most recipes include full-page photos of the finished dish.2. Recipe layout. I appreciate having the ingredients in bold on the left, with the instructions spelled out in easy-to-read, short paragraphs alongside. Especially nice is that none of the recipes require a page flip, which is particularly helpful considering the long ingredients lists a lot of them have. Flipping back and forth for amounts and process could get tedious mid-recipe.3. Seasonal menus. Using seasonally-fresh ingredients really puts the emphasis on flavor, and Cogswell makes it easy to pick and choose by what you've found at the market.4. Complete dinners. Menu ideas for each season give you the entree and sides in one recipe set, so it's simple to make a complete meal without mixing and matching or tagging multiple pages. That said, you can do that, too - she makes the point that her menus are just guidelines.5. Non-traditional recipes. Peaches and cream salad for summer, lobster and celery root bisque for winter, or roasted monkfish with farro risotto for fall, are all examples.What I didn't like so much:1. Organization. This is my biggest challenge with this cookbook. While Cogswell explains that she's divided the recipes into menus (2 for each season), the menu organization doesn't make sense to me since they're not "complete meals." Rather, they're a collection of (I assume) related recipes that could be combined to make a meal. For example, Menu 2 for summer includes two appetizers, three entrees, and a dessert. Menu 1 includes 2 appetizers, a salad, 3 entrees, and a dessert. Why are these on separate menus? Cogswell points out that we can pick and choose from each menu, so why not group "summer appetizers," "summer entrees," and "summer desserts" together?2. Dinner only. There are no recipes I'd cook for meals other than dinner, so look elsewhere for New England breakfast/lunch/brunch/party ideas.3. Techniques are only sort of explained. The recipes assume a certain level of kitchen knowledge (how to tell if pistachios are toasted, for example, or what "stiff peaks" are in beating egg whites. I wouldn't gift this cookbook to a beginner. (But a regional, restaurant-inspired cookbook like this one is rarely for beginners, is it?)4. Not simple. None of these recipes are "quick" or "easy" meals for a busy weeknight. I'm never going to pull this cookbook out at the last minute or when I need something foolproof. This cookbook is a weekend companion for experimentation for me (still working my way up to pumpkin pana cotta with cinnamon whipped cream and honeycomb candy, for example).As a gift for experienced cooks, this cookbook would be excellent. As inspiration to experiment with interesting ingredients and flavors, this would be, again, a winner. As a practical, everyday cookbook - keep looking.

I've been using these bands with Cathe Friedich's DVDs, the ones that feature moves like firewalkers. I use the black band (highest tension) and really feel the burn nicely. They're easy on/off, which is good because they're not made to be left on without the band attachment, and I don't want my heart rate to slow down while I change equipment between exercises. They could definitely chafe, but I haven't worn them more than a few minutes at a time yet. Once I finish this round of Cathe workouts I'll be adding the SKLZ exercises to the mix, which should give these an even harder workout (I hope). I'll update this review if my opinion changes then.

I was pleasantly surprised by this pendant. For the price, it's much prettier than the pictures show, nicely sized, and very versatile. The chain is kind of thin and a little cheap-looking, but not so much to distract from the pendant. I'm not sure I'd gift this (I doubt the finish will last long), but it would be a nice complement to any number of outfits.

I've previously used other scents of this spray when I lived in an apartment. It was great for that, especially when we had overnight guests. My husband took this bottle to work, where four men share a small, single bathroom in a very small space. They've used Lysol and an ozone product in the past, but those haven't really done away with the bathroom smells. Lighting a match works pretty well, but doesn't always do the job.According to his report, this does a very good job not of masking the smells (like Lysol does), but actually preventing them. He gave it 3.5 stars, though, since he said the fragrance is "very strong" (even with just 2 pumps instead of the recommended 3-5), and "overwhelming" in an enclosed space. But given the choice between bathroom smells and this fragrance, the guys apparently choose this. I suspect they'll be ordering another bottle with a different fragrance when this one runs out (I liked the Deja Poo fragrance when I used it before).

This feeder is a lot more attractive than the average feeder from the hardware store. The tinted glass gives it a little extra visual interest (and may help attract hummingbirds if you're not using the red coloring in the nectar). I agree with another reviewer that perches would be a nice addition. I also suspect the wire holder may not have a long lifespan, since it's pretty flimsy. But our hummingbirds seem to like this feeder as much as the regular, red plastic kind, so my quibbles are just that - quibbles.

This is a roomy sleeping bag (5'4", average build) with a cinch string around the head and velcro closure to keep it zipped once you're inside. The zipper operates smoothly from both sides, and the polyester was comfortable even directly against the skin. It does pack fairly large, so a compression sack would be a good idea. I haven't tried the women's version of this bag, but didn't find that I really needed anything different than this bag offered (ergonomically).I haven't had a chance to test this on colder nights (it's mid-summer in SoCal), but will update this review if I notice any drawbacks once the temperature drops.

We recently installed this range in a kitchen island during a renovation. The installation specs and instructions were spot-on, making the electrical, gas plumbing, carpentry, and counter fabricator's jobs less complicated. (The range does have a small overhang on the sides to prevent food from falling between the range and counters, so make sure to take that into account in your design.)Functionally, I'm (mostly) thrilled with my new range. Burners light quickly without the large flare some gas burners exhibit, and the gas burns evenly. The ovens heat quickly, and I don't notice the kitchen overheating like it used to with my 2-year-old oven in my last house. The oven doors open smoothly, without the hard tug some doors require, and they stay open until you're ready to close them. This latter seems like a small thing until you have a door that constantly wants to close on you while you're sliding a heavy pan onto the racks.I've deducted one star because the oven temperature seems to consistently be low. Not only do cookies and biscuits take 3-7 minutes longer than usual, my thermometer shows the temperature is several degrees off. I haven't yet looked into anyway to address this (just finishing the renovations), but I expect a range this expensive to work as advertised on installation.Side note:I expect to use the top oven 90% of the time, but am thrilled to have the bottom oven when I need something bigger or a second dish. For those who are debating whether the double oven is worth it - I'd say for me, it definitely is. I'm very happy I went ahead with this instead of a single oven, even with the greater expense.

We installed several of these doorknobs during a recent renovation, along with the interior locking and exterior deadbolts in the same design. All installed very easily and operate flawlessly. The finish matches our other satin nickel fixtures, and none of the knobs showed any finish flaws. We were also very happy to see that these knobs were a lot cheaper here than in the big box store.

We had this hood installed on 9-foot ceilings at a height of about 31" over a GE Profile gas range (1 inch higher than the instructions recommend).1. Appearance. The vent cover came dented in one place, but it was covered by another piece so I didn't trouble to contact the company. Although the vent was hung straight, the cover installed slightly skewed, so it took considerable adjustment to get things looking straight.2. Installation. The installers mentioned that this was one of the better vent hoods they've installed, and said they were impressed by the inner workings. They compared it to high-end Thermidor hoods they installed, and said the only difference they noticed were some cosmetic differences.3. Functions. I love having the controls on front and back, and the buttons on both sides are very responsive. The four lights are very much on the cool side, glowing blue when on (I'd guess they're around 1500K color temperature, maybe even cooler. I'd definitely prefer warmer lights.)4. Ease of use. Nothing complicated about this range, including removing and cleaning the baffles. I'm very impressed with how easy they are to clean, in fact, unlike other hoods I've seen.5. Performance. This vent does draw smoke and grease pretty well, even at 31". That said, I can tell NO difference between levels 1 and 4, either in performance or noise. It works as well as I'd expected an island hood to work, given the height and air currents.6. Noise. It's supposed to be 1.5 Sones at level 1, going up to 6 Sones at level 4, but there's absolutely no discernable difference. Instead, it's a constant loud hum no matter what level it's on. I'd love to leave it on level 1 to finish venting during dinner, but it's too loud in our open floor plan. I'd compare it to a very loud garbage disposal (in loudness, not type of noise), whereas I'd expected the hum of a loud refrigerator level 1. We're VERY disappointed by this aspect.Overall, it's a decent hood for the price, with a much higher CFM and stainless baffles, unlike comparably-priced hoods. But the noise, lack of performance variation from level 1-4, and quirky installation deduct 2 stars.

These knobs are heavy, and feel great in the hand. The package of 25 were uniformly made and polished, and all came with appropriate hardware for my drawers. I compared these to cheaper, similar-looking knobs and found them to be much more "finished" looking, with cleaner lines and smooth brushed look. They also blend with my stainless appliances and satin nickel faucets. I combined them with the Tudor 5-inch drawer pulls by the same company, and they match very well. Great purchase, and highly recommended.

When I first tried these lids, I was ready to give them a glowing, five-star review. Placing them on a bowl resulted in a nearly-instant, tight seal, and they're endlessly reusable (and dishwasher safe). I could see my days of wrestling with plastic wrap coming to a close.Now after using them for a while, I'm much less impressed. Sure, they seal to perfectly round bowls smaller than their own diameter (makes sense). That said, if I put a dish in the fridge at night, half the time the seal's gone by morning. At first I thought it was just warm dishes causing this, but I tried it with cold dishes, too. In both cases, condensation collects on the underside and the seal vanishes. The three sizes are also too small for many of my bowls, so their overall use is pretty limited.Another disappointment is that these don't seal even a little bit on bowls with any kind of pouring lip, even when the lip is also fully covered and seamless with the lid. Again, this makes sense, but that means half my bowls can't be used with these lids. This isn't a design flaw, but something to consider if you like to use lipped bowls, like I do.

Edit: I also received dish towels in the same pattern, but the reviews appear to mixed up with the apron reviews. I'd give the dish towels only 2 stars, since they're pretty but not functional. Instead of drying dishes, they just kind of smear the water around. So even more than the apron, they're more decorative than functional.Original review:Cute, nicely-made apron! The color (mustard) was just as it appears in the description. Fabric is heavy and stitching seems fairly secure. There were  a few loose threads, but the seams appear tight.What I liked:1. Well made, as mentioned above.2. Functional pockets! It's really handy to have pockets in the apron, and I wish more aprons had such deep, wide pockets.3. Decorative. This apron is attractive enough to stay on display when not in use.4. Good coverage. Unlike some aprons, this one covers enough of my shirt front to actually do its job of protecting my clothes.5. Adjustable. I'm 5'4", so most aprons hang much too low in front to be useful. I like that this one's neck length is adjustable, so I can shorten it as needed.Why it's only 3 stars:While the adjustable neck is great, it's also the biggest design flaw. The neck and waist ties are one continuous piece of fabric, so tightening the waist ties tightens the neck. This results in pulling on your neck as another reviewer noted, and there's no waistline at all. What's even more annoying to me is that when you go to hang the apron after use, your only option is to hang it by the neck loop. So the neck loop loosens and the apron droops on the hook, then you have to readjust everything every time you put it on.A relatively quick fix would be to sew the neck ties in place once it's adjusted to your preference. Sadly, this also negates one of the benefits of this apron. It might work for some people, though.Note that the fabric is only printed on one side, so you'll want to adjust the folds if you don't want the white backside showing when you display it. Note, too, that I haven't washed this yet, so I'll update my review if it washes poorly.

I took a chance ordering this rug, disregarding "you get what you pay for." Knowing that monitors can vary in how they show color, I took care to view this rug on three different devices. On all three, the dark brown appears... dark brown. The tan appears... tan. Likewise the other colors. When it arrived, I actually wondered if I'd been sent the right rug. The dark brown was a medium mud color, and the tan was a yellow beige (VERY yellow). The blues and greens were completely washed out, all leaning toward the very yellow end of the spectrum. What looks like a "cool" brown rug with distinct tan, blue, and green was actually a yellowy-beige wash of blah.If the wrong colors hadn't decided me, the cheap quality would have. This is the thinnest rug I've seen of this type, even including rugs hanging at Home Depot. It's more of a mat than a rug, on par with the indoor/outdoor woven jute rugs for thickness (but not as dense). I toyed with the idea of living with it for a day to be sure, but the third time walking through the room I couldn't take it. Back it went.

I have a smallish obsession with perfectly sharpened pencils, and my old sharpener started eating the pencil leads (I assume the blades were getting dull). This sharpener wasn't the cheapest by far, but it's worth the price. My pencils come out exactly right every time, and the three different settings are great for getting the point I want. The cable and adapter mean I don't have to keep AA batteries on hand, although it's nice to use this without cables, too.

Both our picky cats love these treats. I appreciate that they're 100% salmon and made without additives. The treats in the bag I received wasn't too crumbly or dusty, but maybe I got lucky.Unlike other reviewers, I haven't had an issue with the cats' receptivity to the new design. This could be because I spent the last year switching to a Wysong rotation diet, which changes the cats' food every few days. I've noticed they're a lot less picky since I did that, as if they're more receptive to different flavors. If your cat is used to the same things every day and you used the old treats, these new treats might not work anymore. But if you've never tried them, they're definitely worth a try.

I use these tubs to decant my face products into from larger jars when traveling, and they're about perfect. Easy to open, but don't pop open in my plastic baggie; sturdy, but surprisingly flexible plastic; and they hold far more than I expected. I can get at least a week of face cream in one container, and likely two weeks (I usually just check a bag if I'm traveling that long, though, so don't use these). Highly recommended.

I was thrilled to find this blush on Amazon, since I can't find it where I now live. The powder is fine and light, with very good pigmentation. It goes on evenly and lasts about as long as any powder blush usually does. I find the color (fair skin, blue undertones, copper hair) mimics the perfect flush for me. I'll keep buying this as long as they make it, and probably stock up if it gets discontinued.

I really wanted to like this book. This is a genre I usually enjoy, the world seemed intriguing, and it was nice to have a strong female lead for what is basically the standard commoner-saves-the-world plotline. Given the summary, I wasn't expecting anything epic or especially complex, but rather a fast-paced adventure with strong characters and interesting plot twists. In the end, I was disappointed.-- Plot -- The plot, while pretty straightforward, actually managed to get confusing - not because of interesting twists, but because the storytelling was choppy, disconnected, and uneven. I kept wondering where the editor had gotten to when this book was coming along, since it seemed like entire paragraphs were misplaced or pointless. And the flow from beginning to end didn't follow a logical story arc, but that's because of the...-- Narrative -- Far worse, the author repeatedly tells us about significant developments rather than showing them to us, making for a very, very dull narrative. The storytelling, itself, has some great moments, particularly at the beginning. Sadly, whole chapters of the story are replaced by italicized plot summaries (written a lot like a Star Wars movie intro) that gloss over character development, world-building, and even actual action. ** minor spoiler** For example, chapter 2 is prefaced by a quick synopsis of several years of the main character's life, telling us that she changed her attitude twice, learned a lot, and discovered that she was "brighter than some of the other Chosen." We're then introduced to a main character who has very little in common with that of chapter 1, and I was left wondering why chapter 1 existed. **end spoiler** This happens again and again - geography gets explained, history laid out, action sequences sketched with the most cursory attention. The effect is to make the book incredibly episodic, like a season of Xena, Warrior Princess (without far less character development). Which brings us to...-- Characters -- A weak plot can be saved by great characters. But even the eponymous character was one-dimensional and, frankly, boring. I frequently forgot who was who simply because they all talk and act the same, until the author reminds us why we're supposed to like or hate that character. But rather than subtly reminding us by something the character actually does or says, the author simply... tells us the person is good or bad. Making it worse, some character interactions make no sense. **spoiler** Irona's son, for example, is alternately pleasant or a hellion, but Irona responds exactly the same. Maybe this is supposed to reflect maternal feelings, but if someone saves my life and then says he's going off to rape some prisoners, I'm going to feel at least a teensy bit conflicted and might actually follow up on that later. Irona just goes back to moping about how she doesn't understand her son. And what's with the rape scene? Irona shows virtually no reaction other than a few lines of "gee, how terrible that was," and never once does the story speculate on why it happened. Your lover has probably been possessed, definitely rapes you, and likely falls off a cliff. Maybe you want to look into that, just a smidge? How about when he starts leaving you messages from the grave? No? Just going to act like none of it happened? Huh, okay. **end spoiler**-- World building -- This world has some great potential. Looking past the Disney names (Maleficence, Craver, and Caprice are among the named gods, who each act exactly as named. A backwater town is named Brackish. Yes, I am serious.), the evil magic kingdom and its mysterious inhabitants could really pack a narrative punch. The king of kings and his elaborate family sound intriguing. Even the inner workings of the hero's kingdom could offer excitement. But instead of giving us depth, the author barely explains any of it. This would be fine for fringe elements, but at least color in the main plot points. **spoiler** For example, the "fixes" that play such a key role are completely vague, but not in a deliberately shadowy way. They're simply unexplained, and we're supposed to know that they're something no one is supposed to have, but everyone does. Even Podakan's "journey to evilness" remains unexplained. Was he created from an evil seed? Was he a normal kid that heard voices? Did he only become evil when killed by the bad guy? We'll never know. **end spoiler**I could go on about the rushed, 24-page climax and denouement, or the terrible love scenes*, or the constant, bizarre "leering," or how emotionlessly deeply emotional scenes are told (**spoiler** not just the rape, but Jamarko's betrayal of 680, or Vly's death **end spoiler**), or a whole bunch of issues. When I finished the book, though, I realized it's utterly forgettable. I don't regret reading it, so two stars for that. But I can't recommend it, and I won't look at a sequel.*Actual text: "She wanted to drag him off to bed right away, but she mustn't" and "[She was surprised that] a lover could be diffident, attentive, and obedient in public, but insistent, tyrannical, and irresistible in bed" and "Fatigue forgotten, she was going to rush Vly straight home to bed, *rip* off his tunic, and *ravish* him." [original emphasis in italics]

Like other Avery products in this line, these plastic pockets are great for making sections of my home binders really pop. They're generously sized, so the tabs poke out far enough to be seen even past slightly-oversized documents. The pockets hold around 10 sheets of paper easily, and the plastic seems durable enough not to rip with normal use. (I'll update this review if this changes)My biggest issue with these pockets is that the plastic is so flimsy. They have about the same bend as a piece of paper, so they don't hold papers very securely. They're also too flimsy to make flipping around the binder easy, like the old-style paper pockets did. I also find that the holes usually get stuck as I'm turning sections, so I have to constantly adjust them.Note that the product description refers to a "Unique tab design keeps inserts from falling out." This does NOT refer to the pocket design, which has no features to keep your papers in place. Instead, it's talking about the little tab on the side, where you insert your labels. I'm not sure what the "unique design" is since they look like every other tab I've seen, but my labels have stayed in just fine if I use appropriately-sized labels.

I'm using these bookmarks in a couple of binders for a home renovation, and they've turned out to be pretty helpful. They're easy to spot inside the binder, given both the bright colors and the ample length (they poke out above the binder's edge, in fact). For just marking a spot in the binder, they're great.I wasn't familiar with "snap-in" inserts, so for anyone else who may be fuzzy on this - it simply means the binder holes are slit to allow the bookmark to be moved without opening the clips. This isn't really a feature I find terribly helpful, since I don't find opening the binder clips to be that big a deal when I need to move something. (Over-stuffed binders could make opening the clips a nuisance, so others might really like this feature.) BUT if you turn to the section you want by grabbing the top of the bookmark, you're likely to pull the bookmark at least partially out of the holes. I find this annoying, and spend more time re-inserting the bookmarks than I'd spend opening/closing the binder clips. But they're also too flimsy to use them for turning back and forth between sections, so...If you're only using these as decorative placeholders, they're pretty useful. If you want to use them to flip among sections, look elsewhere.

The light I received doesn't match the specs in the listing. According to the box, this lamp is 20" tall and comes with a 50w bulb - which is what I received. What I liked: the dimming function works very well, and the head also adjusts easily for directional task lighting. The finish is a very matte nickel, with noticeably less sheen than, say, my satin nickel switchplates or doorknobs from a big box store. The shiny finish pictured in the listing isn't even close. I actually prefer the matte finish of this lamp, and find it doesn't show any fingerprints.What I didn't like so much:I agree with another reviewer that the action on this lamp can stutter, and probably won't stand up to daily use. I also found that the base isn't quite heavy enough to keep the lamp from lifting off the desk when I'm raising the arm. This can be mitigated by unscrewing the adjustment knob almost all the way, but it's still not terribly stable.My biggest issue with this lamp is that the swing arm wobbles side-to-side no matter how I adjust or tighten the base pin. I'd prefer a more stable, durable lamp for daily use.

I use this device for backup storage of many, many photos for my business, plus some movies/music (not much of that). For these really basic purposes, it works great. Had everything I needed out of the box and was easy to set up. The speed to backup all the photos was slow, but honestly about what I expected. I haven't tried it as a media server, but will update this review if I have any trouble with it.

Digital planners only do so much for me, so I'm always looking for a great paper planner. This one came at just the right time, when I decided to start a new project mid-year, and wanted a dedicated planner for it.If you like this size planner (which I really do), this is a solid choice. Each week has a two-page spread with plenty of room for daily notes, plus one additional space for general notes for the week. The month pages also span two pages, and include major and minor holidays in bright orange print (so that stand out well when you're scanning the month). The month pages also have space for additional notes, plus little calendars of the previous and next months. I love this last feature, especially, so I don't have to flip around as much when planning multi-week schedules.The back has several lined pages for notes, plus a list of holidays by date for four years (!), including what day of the week each holiday will fall on. There's also one page for a one-year at-a-glance event calendar, and a surprisingly handy map of US time zones and area codes (although I'll probably still just use the internet for that stuff).The cover is thick enough to provide support without being too rigid, and it looks great. My only quibbles are that the pages don't turn as easily as I'd like, and I have to futz with the cover to re-close it after it's been opened front-to-back. I think the wire binding is a little too small for it to work perfectly. Also the plastic sleeve for loose paper is nice, but too small to hold a lot, and papers are likely to slide right out if not secured with a paperclip.But all in all, this is a great planner that I'm likely to use a lot.

This dryer has all the features I've been looking for in a travel dryer: folding handle, retractable cord, cool shot button, variable heat & air, dual voltage, and concentrator attachment. I'm indifferent to the "ionic conditioning" gimmick, since I've never found it makes a difference in any dryer I've used. This dryer is also relatively lightweight, which helps with carry-on weight. So overall, it's a decent travel companion.There are few reasons it's only a travel dryer for me, though, and will never replace my everyday dryer:1. It only dries my collar bone-length hair decently if it's on high heat and high air. Anything lower, and not only does it take a while, but my hair just goes flat. So essentially, I only ever use one setting even though it has more.2. The concentrator doesn't concentrate enough. I'm accustomed to a much tighter shot of air from these attachments. This one does focus the air a little, but not as much as I like.3. Even on the high settings, my hair never looks quite a good as with my Croc dryer. I tried alternating them in case humidity or something else was impacting this, but my Conair days are consistently less satisfying.Because it's still better than other travel dryers I've used (especially at this price), I'm likely to use this dryer for short trips, when I'm only taking a carry-on. If I'm checking a bag, or my hair really matters to me for a certain trip (like a wedding), I'll probably lug the heavy, big Croc out. Still searching for the perfect compromise!

Edit: After a couple months of occasional use, I'm disappointed to say that this sheet isn't working as great as it originally did. My cookies are sticking pretty badly, although they're not scorching. Maybe the dishwasher is the culprit, but it does claim to be dishwasher-safe. If you decide to use this cookie sheet, consider handwashing only. One star deducted.Original review:This is one of those times that I'm happy to be wrong. Since I'm used to heavier, insulated sheets from the likes of Calphalon, I honestly had low expectations when I saw how lightweight and almost flimsy this sheet seems. I've since made three batches of cookies without any parchment or butter, and the results have been uniformly great. What I expected: scorched cookie bottoms, sticking cookies, uneven cooking, tough to clean. Instead, my cookies have been evenly browned with zero scorching, and clean up is actually as simple as wiping with a soapy sponge.I don't know yet how durable this pan will prove to be, but so far so good. I'll update my review if I find the finish wearing off, or if performance changes. But I'm surprised to say I recommend this cookie sheet.

These types of produce keepers are a great idea solution you don't eat all your produce before it goes bad. Like other reviewers, I have something similar built into my refrigerator drawers, so this keeper is a nice addition for extra produce on the shelves. It's nicely sized for a pint of strawberries (I received the small size). The build is typical, solid OXO quality, exactly what I would expect from this brand. Assembly is ridiculously easy.  Although nothing in the packaging tells me it's dishwasher-safe, I ran it through my dishwasher with no problems (sanitized it, even).I was disappointed in the packaging, since all it says is basically a repeat of the marketing language. More helpful would have been an explanation of what produce needs high vs. low humidity, produce care tips, or something else educational. There's also no explanation of the slider under the lid, and I'm hoping a reader can explain to me what that's all about (it doesn't have any apparent function, just... sliding...). Note, too, that the "optimal humidity level" option is just "open" or "closed." From the description, it sounded to me like there were, say, three or four settings for different types of produce. Nope, just two. So if your fridge drawer has more settings, you might find it more useful for long-term produce storage.Of course, this keeper means you have one more filter to buy and remember to replace, and one more piece of kitchenware to keep clean. You can sign up for OXO's reminder service or just set a reminder on your calendar - but you still have to remember/buy regularly for this to work. If this isn't a problem for you, and your fridge drawers aren't enough, you might find this a perfect solution.

This is a good, if small, feeder that entertains us as much as our cats. The suction is very good right out of the box, and assembly is easy. The instructions could be better, but one honestly doesn't need the instructions to figure out how this feeder works. As long as you handle it as intended, refilling should be easy and shouldn't over-stress the rather flimsy plastic. The size is necessarily small, so be prepared to refill often if you have a lot of hungry birds, like we do.

I've been using the Schick Hydro Silk razor for a while, since that gives me the best shave I've found so far. So I'll compare this razor to that one, to give a sense for how it stacks up.1. Size. The Remington is overall bigger than the Schick, both in size and heft. Anyone who likes a heavier razor or feels that the Schick is flimsy might like the Remington better. That said, the larger Remington head means it doesn't maneuver as nicely in tight corners. Winner: Schick, but only by a little.2. Hold. The Remington sits nicely in the hand, with good balance and shape. The Schick also has nice balance, and only suffers in a side-by-side comparison. But this razor is very comfortable to use, with good grippiness when wet. Winner: Remington.3. Accessories. Both come with shower holders, but the Remington's holder is huge by comparison. It also requires you to "click" the razor in and out of place, so a less-than-perfect suction will make the holder pop off the wall when you're removing the razor. The Schick's holder has a tiny footprint and relies only on gravity to hold the razor. I've never had it come off the wall in the year+ that I've used it. Winner: Schick. (that said, you can probably use your Schick holder with your Remington razor. Just sayin'.)4. Price. These razors appear to be priced about the same, until you get to refill blades. The Schick refills are almost twice as expensive (based on Amazon prime pricing at the time of this review). Winner: Remington by a mile.5. Shaving action. Both have great pivoting heads that maneuver easily over knees and ankles. Neither gave me any cuts or nicks. Both gave me perfect, smooth shaves. BUT when I got out of the shower, I found that the Remington had given me razor burn up and down both legs. I haven't had that happen anytime in memory, and I chalk it up to the plastic head and lack of "moisture strip", although it could be that the six blades actually shave a little too close. In fairness, I don't use shaving cream, so those that do may not have any problems with razor burn. But the Schick never gives me the slightest irritation, even when I only shave with soap and/or water. Winner: SchickSo between these two razors, the choice seems to depend on whether a person uses shaving cream and/or minds the higher price of the Schick refills. But I can probably buy a whole lot of shaving cream for the price difference, so it may be worth a trial to get the same performance.

This is another great Holmes air purifier, working much as the floor versions do. I really like that the "select your filter" feature that these air purifiers have, so I can decide whether I'm more worried about allergens, odors, or general dust. Like the floor models, this unit is only noisy on the highest level, so it's easy to leave on all the time.That said, be sure to read the dimensions carefully. This purifier is "desktop" only in that it sits horizontally instead of vertically. I'd need a pretty big desk/nightstand/bookshelf to hold this without crowding everything else. The box and packaging actually don't say anything about this as a "desktop" purifier, so that's in the online description only. The footprint and height make this a not-at-all discreet desktop companion, and the shape means you can't stack anything on top, either. This unit seems like it would fit best on top of a bookshelf , where you don't mind giving up the space.

Unlike the other reviewers, I haven't had any luck with this weed killer. At first, I was very happy with the spray trigger action and how easy this was to apply. I've found that Roundup triggers seem to get stuck or have weak spraying action, so this was a nice surprise. But the nice surprises ended there.I sprayed liberally on the weeds during a warm, sunny day, with no rain expected for the next week. Within 24 hours, I noticed the weeds had browned a little, but a week later they all look lush and healthy again. I expect two-three treatments within a few days would be needed to be effective (unlike Roundup, which kills everything first try). Not only does reapplication take more time, it also makes this weed killer much more expensive over time. I'll update this review if I'm able to kill the weeds with 2-3 applications closely spaced.So if you're concerned with killing your grass along with the weeds, and you don't mind extra applications, this may be just the thing. If you're only concerned with killing the weeds first go-round, you might want to keep looking.

We live in a 1923 house with plaster walls, which we've discovered spell the end of wifi signal indoors. Although our router and modem are centrally located and our house is only 1,900 sq. ft., we had no signal at either end of the house. I'd tried another brand of extender with no improvement, so I had low hopes for this one. But this range extender actually solved the problem completely.As others have noted, setup isn't completely seamless. My first attempt failed, but all I had to do was reboot my router & modem once, then everything worked exactly as promised. We now have four bars at the furthest point from the router.I was unhappy briefly when we lost power once and I couldn't get the extender to work again. I couldn't find anything in the documentation to help, but the fix was simple. I just used a paperclip in the "reset" button on the side of the extender and ran through setup again. I'd hate to have to do this every time we lose power, but at least I didn't have to reboot the router & modem this time around.I haven't used the audio capabilities, so can't speak to how well that's implemented. But as an extender, I'd recommend this highly.

Since bone meal is bone meal, this product is really rated based on the packaging and ease-of-use. I was a little skeptical about how easy the bag would be to use, but it turned out that the built-in "handle" made spreading the bone meal really easy. Having the screw-on cap also meant I could use only what I needed and store the container without worrying about spilling or moisture. The only mild caveat I had with this product was that the hole for dispensing was a little small. The bone meal sometimes clumped a little when pouring, but this was easily solved by shaking the bag a little. Overall, I really liked the spreadability and ease-of-use. I'd definitely get this again.

This is a decent spot cleaner that's not too heavy, but the performance and build were disappointing. I had a SpotBot for many years and really liked it, but gave it up when I moved cross country. I'll compare this machine to that one, since that's the spot cleaner I'm most familiar with.What I liked:1. The internal heater to maintain water temperature was a nice idea. (That said, I'm not really sure it made any difference in cleaning.)2. The size is fairly compact, which makes this easy to store. It's a little smaller than the Spotbot, but not by a lot3. The handle is rubberized and comfortable for carrying.4. The hose is plenty long enough for cleaning a fair sized area without moving the unit. I believe it's longer than the hose on the Spotbot, although it also seems narrower in diameter and less flexible.5. The attachments, cord, and hose store neatly on the unit.What I didn't like as much:1. This unit seems heavy for true portability (over 8.5 pounds by my scale), and of course is heavier when filled. I'd definitely place it on the ground, which might make it awkward for cleaning stairs. The Spotbot had the same problem.2. The suction is mediocre. I used clean water to test out how much would get picked up. I then cleaned by spraying an area and then going over the same area two or three times more without spraying. Two cups of water went into the machine, but only 0.75 were in the dirty water container when I finished. So I left 1.25 cups of water on my carpet, or somewhere inside the machine.3. The hose construction makes suction worse. The bristles make the brush attachments (two of them, the only ones in the package) sit on the carpet so that the nozzle doesn't actually come in contact with the surface. If you tilt the nozzle forward to improve suction, the sprayer sprays all over. So it's not really feasible to spray and suction on the same pass (unlike the Spotbot).4. The sprayer sprays beyond the edges of the nozzle. Even with the bristles squarely on the surface, lots of water comes out either side. Again, this makes one-pass spraying/sucking impossible, but it also means you're using more solution than you need to. It might be more efficient to spray the area once, scrub with the brush all over, and then finally suction two or three times.5. The build quality is less impressive than the Spotbot. The handle on the brushes seem too long for comfort, and the sprayer button feels really flimsy. My water tanks wobble quite a bit, and the rubber tank covers take a lot of fidgeting to close. I suspect there are lots of leak points in this machine that the Spotbot didn't have - and the added product instruction page confirmed this. It includes several "tips" on how to keep the unit from leaking.Overall, I'd buy the Spotbot again, but I wouldn't recommend this spot cleaner.

This is good, basic pasta in a very useful shape, and having extra protein and fiber added mean less guilt about eating such a starchy food. It cooks up at about the same rate as regular pasta, and seems interchangeable with all my regular pastas as far as quality and "toothiness." That said, this pasta definitely has more of a starchy flavor, making dishes seem a little drier and bland. (This really surprised me, since I expected *less* starchiness.) The difference is made up for by adding a little more water and seasoning than usual, so it's not a deal-breaker. If you're looking for an excuse to eat pasta again, you could definitely do worse.

I've been using this morning and night under La Mer creme and Algenist Genius cream, respectively. Like other similar products I've used, I put a little in my palms and pressed the treatment onto my skin after cleansing, then let it soak in before applying moisturizer. Previously, I've used La Mer and Algenist serums, serums/toners from various other brands like Fresh and Jurlique, a couple of facial oils, and plain old mineral water under my moisturizer to help with product penetration and moisture. I've never noticed any "brightening," "smoothing," or other benefits from any of the serums or oils, despite their claims. This one is no different.What I liked:1. There's very little fragrance, and what little there is fades very quickly.2. My moisturizer goes on nicely after I apply this treatment. Not any better than anything else I've used, but it's fine for that3. It didn't cause my skin to break out. I tend to be sensitive to new products, but this one didn't bother me at all4. The product absorbs quickly and completely. There's no tackiness or feeling of "product" once it soaks in.What I didn't like:1. The bottle came unsealed in an unsealed box. This is cut-rate packaging for a VERY expensive product, and of course it does nothing to protect product integrity.2. Neither the box nor the bottle had any instructions of any kind, and there was no insert with instructions. If you're at all bewildered by what to do with this product or what's in it (what's "pitera essence" anyway?), you'll have to look online (or talk to a rep at the store and hope they know)3. While it didn't cause break-outs or oily shine, it also did... nothing else. This treatment gives every appearance of being nothing more than water, for all the effect it had. When I went online to figure out what it was *supposed* to be doing, I had to laugh. Based on the marketing hype, I'd expect some sort of facial miracle from this treatment. Based on experience with other brands, I'd expect at least a little smoothing/brightening. But what I got was no different from spritzing my face with mineral water.Maybe this product does something if used for months, but I'm not willing to pony up the price tag to find out. I'll happily pay for a product that works (like La Mer), but I can't recommend this one.

I use my pizza stone for everything, including cooking sweet potatoes (delicious!), and that means lots of stuck-on mess. It never occurred to me to purchase a just-for-the-pizza-stone cleaner, but it seems like a great idea. However, I was disappointed by this.First off, the scraper part is pretty unpleasant to use. It feels like metal-on-metal and sounds equally awful. My husband commented that was as bad sounding as fingernails on chalkboard. When I do clean my stone, which sadly is not often enough, I use a dough cutter, and I pulled it out and compared the two. The dough cutter, though it has a similar edge, must be smoother, and it cuts through burnt on remains more cleanly and without the awful feeling. This scraper is also pretty small, so it's more work, and I can't get as much leverage with it being on the end of the long brush. So, on that score, this tool was a fail for me.The brush does a pretty good job, but it leaves a lot of residue behind that one needs to clean up with something else. I use a small (and cheap) mini-broom and a paper towel for that job.So, this works fine, but I wouldn't recommend it.

I'm an artist who also does crafts and loves to fool around with different mediums and materials. When I want to cut shapes, usually for handmade envelopes, personalized gift cards, and the like, I use a scissor, an x-acto blade, a self-healing mat, a rotary cutter or a paper cutter. I make little books and recently I've been making tiny drawings with glass cabochons over them. Those were driving me a bit crazy because cutting out perfect little circles is not easy, even with all the cutting tools I own.In the midst of my frustration, I was offered this machine as a member of the Vine Program. I figured I'd pass but then thought better of it. It was the solution to my circle-cutting problems! Ideas of what else I'd do with the machine danced through my head, and I was excited.Setting it up was pretty difficult. Maybe I'm a dolt, but since I have no experience with a machine such as this and have never seen one in person, I wasn't really sure what was what. The instruction booklet is not very good. It is for many different models, the pictures often do not correspond to this one, and for some procedures one has to jump from section to section way to much for ease of understanding. Since I'm not especially technically inclined, I have found referring to the instruction manual very frustrating every time I've had a problem with the machine, not just with the set-up.Nonetheless, I did get the machine up and running. The first time I did a test, it did not cut. The second time, after adjusting the blade, it cut into the mat quite far. It took a lot of fiddling to get it right. Not the biggest deal, but my mat is already quite beat up, and I really wonder why it can't be made out of a self-healing material. But, I do not know if any of the competitors use that, so it's neither here nor there, I suppose. Still, I can see that the mat will need to be replaced often.I was thrilled to play with the pre-set patterns that are in the generally easy-to-use touchpad. For making collages and decorations, this machine is a blast. I pulled out all sorts of papers and had some easy fun for a few days.It's when I wanted to get down to business that things got wonky. Perhaps I wanted to do stuff that was too advanced too quickly. I succeeded in cutting out all my little circles, but when I tried to set up a page of shapes that were all lined up properly on a 12 x 12 page for a display that was behind the cut-outs, I had this experience: I tried cutting the same page of shapes 16 separate times and only two of those times the "margin" was the same! That's a real problem. I don't know if this is my particular machine, but that's what happened. So, after wasting a lot of high quality paper on that experiment (which I should have photographed before throwing away, for it's hard to explain), I just gave up. I was really stressed and frustrated and that's one reason I forgot to take photos. For those with low technical problem frustration thresholds, be advised!The next day I scanned some totally clean line drawing templates for fancy hand made envelopes. The scanning function is even wonkier! It picks up the slightest things like minute differences in the paper, dust, and who knows what. I spent hours trying to figure out how to set the machine to scan a perfectly good image that scanned clean in my regular scanner. The manual just frustrated me even more, as the instructions for scanning are definitely not appropriate for this model (unless I'm really missing something). Finally, even though the scanner missed one object completely, I got two out of the three scanned images on the mat perfectly well, saved them, and cut them out.The cutting is beautiful. That I'm delighted with.I've found the machine highly frustrating because I see its potential and there's so much one can do, but I find it's not as precise as I imagine it should be and it's got a steep learning curve. I wish that the touchscreen would show the measurements of the mat at 400% and not doing so seems an oversight. I wish the instructions were better. The instructions on YouTube that I've seen are excellent.I didn't try the rhinestone kit because I have no interest or knowledge of this kind of thing. It seems superfluous as an "extra" for this machine; the $50 online activation card would have been a better extra and really should have been included in a package of this price.I have a Chromebook, so I wasn't able to hook it up to the machine, but I can see that using this with a computer would open up a lot of possibilities.I am concerned about the lack of availability of the extras and even essentials one needs for this unit. I am very interested in printing stickers and while I know one can do it oneself (I tried), the sticker kit sounds like a better idea for a beginner. Only the pricey starter package was available last week. This one thing made me wonder if a machine like Cricut might be better for most people, but as I have no experience with it, I can't say for sure.Lastly, even with my limited experience, I think this machine is probably best if you're cutting out discreet shapes that don't need to align to things perfectly. It does a great job of cutting. I think it would be wise for an potential consumer to do a lot of research into which is the best machine for their money and desired use. I am not sure my review is that helpful except for saying that and propose that this is not the machine for a rank beginner such as myself. Two women in a knitting group I belong to rave about their Cricut machines and for a beginner, it's probably great to have a friend to guide them. Just something to think about. I rather wanted to give it three stars, but I "like it" more than think it's just "okay".Addendum: I'm not amending my review, but adding this: Today I spent the entire day fooling around with the pre-set designs. I cut out all sorts of designs and glued them to envelopes I'd made using my own templates. The results were so professional that my husband said I might have trouble convincing people they were handmade. I'm really pretty smitten with this machine, frustrations and all, but that may be that I'm smitten with what machines like this can do. Anyway, I'm enjoying using it very much. It's a creativity enhancing machine, even if it's not perfect! Added a photo of a pile o' stuff I cut out. I'm having a blast!

This charging dock is, simply, "just okay." I like the way it looks, though be aware the white in the photo is really a light gray. The difference in the color from the photo was a bit of a shock! However, I was happy to get this because I use my little iPod (yes, an iPod) to listen to music while I'm working and it generally is at the edge of my large desk, just waiting for me to knock it off and crack the glass yet again (sigh). Putting it in the dock while it's hooked up to my Bluetooth speakers is a good way to avoid any more accidents, and looks a lot better, too.However, I was disappointed by the fact that the plug is raised so far up. It sure looked like it would be a nice secure fit for a an iPhone or iPod, but it seems to be designed to accommodate a design with a case on it, yet others complain that it needs modifications for use with their models and/or cases. So, this design isn't ideal for most folks. The high plug  keeps any device from being seated at the bottom of the dock. The device is not steady at all and tapping hard enough for it to register makes the device move backwards quite a bit, enough to be worrisome for the connection.  If all you're using this for is charging your device on a nightstand and perhaps only punching in your code in the morning when the alarm goes off, no big deal. But if you want to do more with your device while it's plugged in, it's not the best choice.Still, perfectly functional and modern looking.

I've heard so many good things about this series of brushes and am totally disappointed. The first time I used this brush, with watercolors, I noticed that it felt dry. I needed to load it with more water and/or paint  than I normally do to get the paint to flow smoothly. Still, it seemed like a nice little brush with a good tip. Three nights later, it's not holding its point. It's splitting into two separate parts unless it's dripping wet and laying down a wash as big as something over a size 10 brush. This is a size 2! I'm going to put it in my collection for students to fool around with.I've got some two-bucks brushes that held up longer than this one and two painting sessions doing very small work is not a high bar.  A complete waste of my money. I'm glad I didn't buy more than one.

Absolutely beautiful gouache. Some of the colors are so smooth, I feel like I'm painting with butter. They are definitely more like opaque watercolors (which is what they technically are) and adding a tad of white helps opacity and consistency. The white included in this set is stellar. The price here on Amazon for this set is a bargain. I can't recommend buying it, especially at this price, highly enough

Simply stellar book. Great instruction. Beautiful graphics Even though it's not a large book, it's easy to read. I wish all calligraphy books had spiral bindings so they'd lay perfectly flat! This is not a book for beginners, though I wouldn't steer you away from it because it's filled with such good instruction from basics of materials to some really advanced stuff (like the truly esoteric preparation of real vellum) and it's inspiring. I wish the book were larger, but I don't want to give it four stars.

Ever pick up a book that you think you'll love and just can't get into it? Well, that happened to me. I don't have a burning interest in cheese, but I like reading non-fiction about subjects like food. I very much enjoyed all of Michael Pollan's books, for instance. I've read a whole book about olive oil, and one about mushroom foraging.As a member of Amazon Vine, when I was offered this book, I was excited. I live in part of New England where there are many artisan cheese makers. I thought it would be great fun knowing more about the ubiquitous cheddar cheese.Like a blind date that doesn't go right and you can't put your finger on it, I just didn't like the author's writing. I kept trying to read it, really, I did, but every time I put the book down, I found it hard to pick it up again. I tried reading different chapters. Nope.Unfortunately, as a Vine member, I can't pass on reviewing. If I wasn't a Vine member, I would absolutely not review this book, as I don't like to review books which I think are simply not to my taste (like gorgonzola). The author's sense of humor doesn't tickle my funny bone and there's no particular reason for it.So, even though I really found it a slog to read, I give it three stars. I see others enjoyed it a lot, especially someone who's really into cheese. Cheese freaks will probably enjoy it, especially cheddarheads.

I originally gave these a poor two-star review, but after washing them twice and using them quite a bit, I've trashed that review (instead of trashing the dishcloths). I didn't like them at first because they were stiff, even with one washing, and seemed to repel water slightly. The very tight weave combined with the ink of the printed design seemed to make them particularly water non-absorbent.I think the color and design are extremely pretty - a combo of modern color and old design that I love - so I kept them hanging up in my kitchen. When I stopped thinking they were dish towels and trying to use them that way, I started using them to dry dishes, cups, and silverware. For that? They are fantastic. That tight weave? Leaves no lint. Perfect!So, don't use these for wiping off your counter top or cleaning. Save these pretty towels for drying and they'll serve you well.

This is not going to be a technical review because I haven't the qualifications for that. Here's my impressions:Set-up: Unless you already understand how to set up a printer, you may well be baffled by the set-up instructions. Luckily for me, I've set up six new printers in the last year and know the drill. First off, I didn't use the CD with driver that came with it as I had no need. After unboxing and installing the ink cartridges, wi-fi set up was easily done from the touch screen on the printer. I installed the Epson printing app on my iPod and registered with that. Then, on my Chromebook, I set up Epson services, the ability to scan to the Cloud (my Google Drive), and was up and running in less than a half an hour.Then, the great part: Fantastic printing!! First, I simply copied some calligraphy I'd done on cheap "regular" printing paper that I buy at the dollar store. The page printed damp, but I was astonished at the color accuracy. I set it down on a table and when I came back and it was dry I was even more astonished as how much it looked like the original hand-lettered calligraphy, ink subtlety and all. Then and there I swore to stop buying cheap paper!I printed out a photograph of some other artwork I'd done only low quality photo paper. It, too, was stunning.I was going to put off writing a review until I'd gotten some better paper, but I can't give this any more than five stars, so why bother? Even with low quality paper, this printer produces stunning prints.This is something of a specialty printer. The Epson XP-950 has a document feeder, fax, and uses the same six colors of vibrant Claria ink. This all-in-one doesn't fax nor does it have a document feeder, but it does print large format prints. For me, that's much more useful than the "business" features of the XP-950, but one does have to ask if the price is worth it or if you need the features of the other printer. I'd prefer the large format as I've never (ever!) used a document feeder in my life. I use a printer for scanning and printing artwork and flyers. This isn't true pro quality printing, though it sure comes close and I'm really thrilled with it. Also, the ease of printing from all the devices in my household (Apple, Android, Chromebooks, and Linux) is fantastic!!

It was love at first write! I started using a fountain pen a few weeks ago and discovered I had not one piece of paper or any notebooks that were smooth to write on. I love grid paper but read that the popular Rhodia pads' grids are thick. After reading some reviews, I passed on all the usual suspects of pads and got this one. I am delighted that I did!! I tested a page with a number of pens including two that write really wet and none have any bleed or show through. One can write on both sides of the paper and it's a real delight. I didn't realize that the back was blank - what a bonus! Plus, you get cute but subtle Japanese cartoons of how to use the pad on the inside of the cover. Oh, the back is really solid. LOVE it! Enough exclamation points for ya? Ten stars!!! I'll never buy another pad of paper. Too bad it's ten times the cost of the same size pad at my local store. Who cares? It's a small luxury that goes a long, long way. Update: Still love the paper, but I hadn't used a flex nib on it yet. It seems to lay down thicker than on other paper and with a wet flow, using Pelikan Edelstein ink, there is some bleed through, though not enough to get on the next page. Still a great paper. There's no feathering, even with the seemingly thicker line.

I'm not going to be too technical because I don't know much about that. There are some excellent technical reviews here and you can read them.Here's my thing: I'm an artist who uses a printer now and again. I really don't need a document feeder (never used one), two-sided printing (never used that, either) or any number of things. I want a printer to be easy-to-use and to print well enough. For really good printing, I send stuff to a professional.I have used Epson printers for well over a decade and went from liking them (not loving them 'cause the ink is so expensive) to hating them. Back in the summer, I bought three different Epson printers, each one successively more expensive, and not one of them worked out of the box. For that, I went and bought a Canon printer. I like it a lot.So, when I was offered this printer as a member of the Vine program, I was hesitant. Truth be told, I needed a second printer for my studio, and I didn't want to be saddled with a non-working printer, even if it was free. Now that is a truly bad pre-review, isn't it?Well, surprise surprise. This one works. I set it up pretty quickly - about a half an hour - but mind you, I'd spent a few weeks setting up similar Epsons during the summer. It works well, easy to set up from a Windows machine. Easy-to-use touchscreen on the unit which makes me happy 'cause I mainly use that as I'm doing lots of copies. Very nice job. I love the six colors of ink.I have yet to try it with my iPhone or Chromebook and if it's problematic I will come back and adjust this review; unfortunately, us Viners have deadlines and this review is due. My apologies.

I've used this product four times, twice in the morning and twice at night. I must be allergic to something in it. During the day, my eyes were red. When I woke up in the morning, my eyes were not only red, but my under-eye puffiness was more pronounced. If it weren't for the fact that I'm a Vine member and must do a review, I wouldn't. This is obviously my problem and not the product's per se, though it is rare that I have such strong allergic reactions. Some of my morning eye puffiness is due to allergies and this product either adds or accentuates that, so perhaps this may be a problem for other allergy sufferers.

I love the sound of this speaker. It has great bass, as expected, It doesn't sound boosted, though I have to admit I did not listen to any pop or dance music. I wanted to try this speaker because I have an art studio that is almost thirty feet long and I've been using an old set of powered AR speakers. There's nary a speaker that I find to be as good. But, I was tired of using up desk space having a device or computer hooked up to the speakers just to have ambient music in the studio. Someone suggested I get bluetooth speakers just as I was offered these (as part of the Vine program).They are perfect for my space. It's a "loud room" and it needs a speaker such as this. I can play it very loud (complaints) or softly. It sounds good at both volumes. What was a surprise to me is that podcasts and classical music sounds good. I didn't expect that. I listened to some modern music and discovered I wasn't hearing it clearly before!I'm sorry this isn't a technical review - that I can't offer you. What I can say is that this speaker holds up to a high standard - that AR pair I've had since the 1980's. As far as being portable - well, I wouldn't want to walk anywhere far with it. The "handle" is really just an indent that is barely big enough for my fingers to fit into. It is neither comfortable nor secure feeling and the speaker is pretty heavy. It's portable insofar as it's light enough and sturdy enough to toss into the back seat of a car and bring somewhere.It's a good looking speaker. It's rather big for indoors, but it's got big sound. I find the buttons on the top of the speaker redundant and unnecessary and did not find them useful. My iphone's controls worked perfectly. Set-up was a breeze.

I've never used a Swiffer duster so I can't compare it to them. Upon receiving this product, I immediately used it as the room I was standing in was sorely in need of dusting. I have a cat and I work with textiles, so dusting is something I need to do frequently. But, I don't, so there was a LOT of dust.I found "fluffing" the Swiffer to be a bit difficult, but even though I don't think it's was fluffed all that much, it worked quite well. Within five minutes, the thing was completely covered with dust bunnies, dust, and cat hair.Worked great!
