One of the front zippers clasps came off on my first try at unzipping so not happy about that. I used some pliars to put it closed tighter so hopefully it doesn't pop off again. I don't often buy purses so when i finally decided on one I had hoped it would have no issues.

Let me begin by saying I have read a few books by this author and they just keep getting better. In this short but sweet story we have Declan a young boy who is best friends with a girl his neighbor Alyssa.All through elementary school and primary school, these two are inseparable. Then when they hit about 15 or so years old things start to change between them. They share their first real kiss and from there they are on again off again as boyfriend / girlfriend. Declan’s father keeps putting in his sons ear that if he is serious about his racing future he needs to leave Alyssa alone because one day she will make him choose. However, Declan does not believe that considering Alyssa was his best friend before anything else and she knows how he feels about racing. But in time Declan sees a change in Alyssa and it’s not a good change and she has now given him an ultimatum her or the racing.What will Declan do? Will this be the end of their friendship and relationship? I was gifted a copy of this book for my honest review.

So happy to see Kat and Lucas get a book!Kat gets a call from her mother whom she hasn't heard from in awhile and it’s to warn her she is in danger. Kat is very happy living with Luke and his pack / brothers and nothing her mother says will change that. Or will it?They do not have a good relationship. Her mother knows they killed a witch. The witch deserved her death for trying to kill Kat's best friend.Kat now has some new powers from killing the witch. She does not want them and has no clue what they are.And on top of that little shock from her mother she is given yet another big shock.And Des and his mate a long with Kat and Lucas are all in for a big shock which just blows their minds.And just what is going on between Marcus and Brianna? hmmmmWe get our hot sexy vamps, even hotter shifters, Strong witches , fae and a few other paranormal characters. I enjoyed this book very much.I was gifted a copy of this book for my honest review.

Ethan wasn't born a werewolf no oh no he was made one by a human crazy doctor. Ethan owes a huge thanks to Paz and her mate Adam. Caro is sister to the Alpha Lazlos mate and he has dreamed of her for many months now. But Ethan feels more like a freak than anything considering he was not a true werewolf.Caro is the packs healer and of course, that puts her up close and personal with most.She was not an adults doctor however but never mind that she took great care of thosewho needed it.Ethan asks her out and she refuses him. But he refuses to give in and until she gives in they are going to be just friends.When an ex of Caro's comes stalking around Ethan makes the decision its time to take his mate.I enjoyed this book. Ethan is an alpha male although he has not been a shifter very long. He is loving and loyal. Everything Caro deserves and more.I was gifted a copy of this book for my honest review.

Thomas has craved and loved Nissa for many years and now she is back in his life needing his protection. They have a few things that stand in front of them being truly happy. The fae do not want any treaty with shifters or anyone else. Centuries ago, there was a very blood war but now there are many who are marrying outside their race.Can Thomas protect himself from Nissa? And can he protect her from her enemies?Very hot and steamy with Alpha Male and Alpha Female. This one was my favorite of this series so far!  Loved it!I was gifted a copy of this book for my honest review.

In this story we have Adam Tucker who is the enforcer for the council. The council is unsure how to handle the mixed breed who is family to the Lazos family via a mating. Can Adam keep business in mind or will he now be trapped also by finding his mate?Paz is sister to Carly. She was found at the last sting operation that Stephan was on. There is just a few problems now to deal with and one of them is knowing she has a mate also.Adam never thought he would find his mate and now that he has what will he do?Paz is unlike any woman he has ever met. And they are also dealing with finding the rogue wolf who is the reason Paz, Marisol and many others were taken and abused and others killed.Can Adam keep Paz safe?Can Paz accept Adam?Sexy, but short book and tons of action.I was gifted a copy of this book for my honest review.

Stephan is one of the Lazos' brothers and works for the DEA. While at a party as an undercover agent, what does he find? None other than his mate. And if that hasn't thrown him well knowing she is a she wolf and that she is some how messed up with the bad guy has.Marisol knows Stephan is her mate but right now she has one thing on her mind and she is not going to allow her feelings to get in the way.And now do they not only have to learn about each other but the Council is sending their enforcer regarding another issue that springs up in the story.This is a short shifter story. Tons of hotness and a whole lot of action. Enjoyed this book in this really good series and can't wait to find out what happens in the next book.I was gifted a copy of this book for my honest review.

Carly lost her family at a young age her grandmother raised her. She decides to make the move to Miami to be closer to her grandmother.She gets a fantastic job and has fallen hard for her boss Nick.Nick knows he has found his mate but there is one problem. How does he explain it to Carly?Someone is after Carly but who? Moreover, can Nick save her? Can Carly accept Nick for what he is?Very good shifter book, Hot Alphas, strong females and suspense.I was gifted a copy of this book for my honest review.

I go through many earbuds for one reason or another so when I was asked if I would like to try and review this product I jumped at the chance.They are lightweight although I have had lighter. They are very easy to pair. The sound quality however is not the best I have heard and the battery life is not that great but overall for the price they are decent.I was gifted a pair of these earbuds for my honest review.

Katherine has been stalked and haunted by someone since age 16 when all in her life changed. She lost her mother to a tragic event. Cole is a detective and has been asked by a good friend to help Katherine. Sparks flutter between Cole and Katherine and at first, he thought she was just talking crazy but then realizes she is very serious and the stalker is very real.Now at age 25 Katherine’s nightmare is still there still following her.Can Cole save her?Who will save Katherine's heart from Cole?This was a very good book indeed. If you like oh so hot romance mingled with a touch of suspense then this is the book for you. And the culprit when they are finally revealed you will say Oh wow I didn’t see that coming.I was gifted a copy of this book for my honest review.

Rose is born in a time where supers are free to walk the earth but more than that, they are free to destroy it all as well. Rose's mother is a witch and her father a werewolf and someone is out to destroy all witches. Rose’s mother knows they are coming and she hurries off to the hiding place although her mother does not stay with her.Rose is soon taken to a friend of her father’s home his name is Seth and he is a witch. He trains Rose, and comes to love Rose although he knows she is not his mate.Rose is a powerful Assassin and is hired by the council to take out those who are killing and doing other horrible things. She does not kill however until she knows it’s a warranted need.The new head of the council is a powerful demon and after taking on the job Rose finds she can not follow through with it.Cassius the vampire she is sent to kill does not seem to be as he is portrayed.Can Seth, Cassius and Roses father keep her safe?What will the head of the council do to her?Well grab you a copy of this book that is filled with paranormal beings and get reading. I do believe I have a new favorite book by this author.I was gifted a copy of this book for my honest review.

New to me AuthorOscar is a big time baseball player and gay. He has had many lovers due to never being in a place to have more. He knew Brian was leaving but he wasn't prepared for the little speech he gave him before walking out the door. Oscar meets Danny and all bets of not wanting something more is off. Danny is not a baseball fan so he has no idea who Oscar is.  Danny never has experienced his feelings about being with a man and that thought now though after having met Oscar is becoming a need he wants to explore.After a chance meeting with Oscar things go downhill for Danny. Will Oscar finally throw caution to the wind?I enjoyed this book although it seemed a little rushed in some areas. The romance comes on slowly, which is a nice thing. It could also use a little more proof reading but overall was a nice read.I was gifted a copy of this book for my honest review.

Book 6 and I loved it as much as I have the others. Cam and Chastity are off to rescue an orphaned mixed breed shifter baby an Alpha has said he will drown. Well things do not go as planned because the Alpha is one mean person. They do get the infant back to their pack and begin life as a family. Of course, soon their family will become much bigger but I am not telling you why. Buy the book and read. Mac also has a surprise of his own and he is not dealing with things very well at first but after a talk with Grant and then with Cam he has made a decision. I love this series and each book gets better and better. This one had some hiccups but nothing massive. I would recommend it and if you have not read this series I’d suggest beginning with Book 1.I was gifted this book for my honest review. And that is what I give you.

I was excited to review this product. Many years ago I took COQ10 to help relieve a bleeding ulcer so I know the benefits although many years ago many had never heard of it. These were easy to take and I have been taking them for a bit over a week and already I have more energy and just feel so much better. This is a book bundle that has a little something for everyone in the romance department. I have written reviews for a few although all are really good and the writing styles are fantastic. You can't go wrong with this bundle.My Review - Out Of The Box, Regifted – Jennifer Theriot - 5 StarsFrom the very first word this book grabbed and kept me wanting to read more. I just loved Olivia and Ash and all the grown up kids between them.Olivia is a older woman in her 50’s who goes through something horrible after 30 years of marriage and Ash is the man there to save her from herself. He also is the man who teaches her about Intimacy , Passion and how a woman should be treasured.The book takes you on ONE hell of a rollercoaster ride though I went from Laughing, to Seething Angry , to Crying.I whole heartedly recommend this book to anyone who loves a uplifting and romance involved book.All I can say is WOW !!!My Review - Scary Modsters – Diane Rinella - 5 StarsRosalyn is head over heals for dead rocker Peter Lane and her Ouija board is trying to tell her something. While out with her girlfriends she meets Niles’s and although they aren't totally compatible he is a nice enough guy but she wants Peter. Rosalyn and Nile's figure out that Peter Lane was murdered and take it among themselves to figure it out.Can Niles finally win Rosalyn's heart? Can they help the now dead Peter Lane?Rosalyn is way into the old music and Niles well he needs to get onboard or get lost. This book was well written although the jumping back and forth from each character got me a little lost.My Review - Cheating To Survive – Christine ArdigoThis story evolves around three women who work at the same place and are friends. Each are married with families but missing something in their marriages. We venture with each one on how they handle things and find happiness finally in their lives. I really enjoyed this story.My Review - Chain of Title - Robyn RozeIn this story we have a cheating husband who loses the one thing he can no longer have. We also have tons of deception, a world never known about , and a past so strong it almost crumbles what is left of a family. We also get a woman with a strength and protectiveness that devours any in her way and a Man who will destroy anyone who tries to take what is now his. We have a new beginning and others will find their ending. Very good story !!!

This is Griff's story. He like others of Storm MC carries a deep secret and it rears it's ugly head on a certain day of the year. Madison is having a huge Christmas party and Griff knows he is expected to show up but he just can't do it. One day while sitting having a drink he meets a woman. This woman it turns out lives across from his Aunt. Griff is taken with Sophia and just has to see her. Storm is tryiing to find out who the member is against the club. Once they find out they let the Sydney chapter president King know. The guys are trying to get everything back to some normalcy after Marcus was removed. Scott has a lot to deal with but he knows deep down they will get through it.I really enjoyed this book since Griff had become a favorite of mine from previous books in the series. I recommend you start with book 1 in this series but I do recommend if you love Romance with a little darkness and Oh so hot Alpha Males grab your copies and get reading.I was gifted a copy of this book for my honest review.

Anita and Larry whom she is training are off to raise some really old zombies but when they get there the issue is there is bones galore and not full bodies. Can Anita pull it off? While there she is called in by the local police because of a vampire attack or what is thought to be a vampire attack.In this book we get fae, really old powerful master vampires, witch spells of old. This is a new to me author and I have found I really enjoy these security, rock star books so I grabbed this one. Abby is the singer in a band that is all ran by her over bearing mother. They do not have a good relationship at all and that only gets worse. Sean is in the band and he is Abby’s boyfriend. The problem is Abby has always allowed everyone to walk all over her and finally that is going to come to an end or will it? Danny is Abby’s bodyguard and he has his work cutout for him. Abby is being stalked, she has issues going on with her now ex-boyfriend and her mother. Abby feels something for Danny but she is so torn with everything going on in her life and does not even trust herself how can she put trust in someone again?What will Abby do when her mother throws another wrench in her already confused life?Can Danny let go of his past to embrace what he wants with Abby?I enjoyed this book. The characters are strong although at first Abby is not so brave. Danny is all alpha male. Sonnet is a tracker of paranormal beings for Fang Squad Inc. She has never really killed anyone but her time was a coming.Her partner Emely did all the killings and she loves it. So much has happened since book 3 which left us wondering so many things especially the where abouts of the twins. This is book 2 in this wonderful series. Mia still is battling her many demons and has decided to move on from Ethan. Easier said then done. Fantastic third book in this series. We get Vinny in this one. If you have read the previous books you will know that Vinny is the twin brother to Gabe. New to me author.We have Andy a young mother who is struggling all alone with her very young daughter Harper. One morning while running late to work anything that could go wrong does. Liv has endured pure hell being away from Roen and has even begun to see a therapist.Her sister has been hospitalized for an unknown reason but Liv is not stupid she knows who / what is behind it. I am an avid paranormal lover and when I seen there was a merman book I just had to have it. Harley Awakening by  Claudy ConnLet me say WOW first and foremost. I love Claudy's style and her books but this one was over the top HOT and Action never ending.Harley is the product of a white witch and a vampire dad. They all live happily within their clan. I highly recommend this book. And I truly hope I see more in this series.

New to me Author,In this story we have Abby who is a strong, independent woman who has carried on through life even after some abuse done by an ex-boyfriend. As noir novels go, this one is definitely in the upper ranks, though not quite a perfect performance.  I have not read Ted Lewis's other novels, though I know Get Carter from the movie adaptation.  If this is a good sample of his work--and I suspect it is--then I am sure i would enjoy the others and will seek them out.  Most of this novel works like a well-oiled noir machine, smoothly purring its way through the layers of suspicion, paranoia, mayhem and murder that characterize the genre at its best.  The central character and narrator manages to ingratiate himself with the reader, even though he is quickly established as a ruthless and insatiably greedy criminal who happens to be in a "business" that is peculiarly repellent and far from admirable--that is, he is a producer, maker, distributor and merchant of violent sadomasochistic pornographic films of the most extreme kind.One of the fascinations of such characters at the center of stories of crime as a business, especially when he or she is the first person narrator of the story, is the apparent calm and ease with which the "boss" exercises power, even life and death power, over the people around him.  The suave and low-key approach to delegating criminal exchanges, disciplinary or revenge killings (which, because of the expertise of the perpetrators, can be exercised sometimes with no remaining evidence or with sufficient misleading evidence that the investigators are directed elsewhere and the narrator and his cronies suffer no consequences), while maintaining a luxurious public lifestyle, tends to glamorize the narrator even as one finds him despicable.  If necessary, well-placed agents inside the police hierarchy can be counted on, thanks to substantial bribes that are mere pocket change for the criminal, to misdirect the investigation or conveniently misplace crucial evidence.  On the surface, all is orderly and controlled.The lurking dangers to such a criminal power are, primarily, two:  first, the ambitious assistant or agent who figures out the patterns of behavior and the structure of the criminal enterprise in such as way as to make it possible for the assistant to invade and even take over the criminal territory, and second, the "hero's" mix of paranoia and obsession with exercising what he believes to be his unlimited powers of comprehension and control, prompting him to begin to believe in the reality of imagined threats, while forgetting that there is always at least someone out there who may be smarter and more ruthless even than he is.It won't do to reveal any details of the plot of this novel--it starts spinning rapidly, and except for several brief stumbles where it seems to go offtrack or into needless repetition, is continued with the kinds of surprises and shocks that are the main reason for reading such a work.  If we want to philosophize about the apparent similarities between the criminal enterprise and the standard day to day operations of late Western capitalism--well, even that has been anticipated, at least as early as John Gay's The Beggar's Opera.  This kind of crime story is about power and influence and the will to impose one's wishes wherever one needs to.  Lewis offers a fast and satisfying noir experience.

Potential readers need to know what this book is not.  It is not a biography of Ted Hughes, the great twentieth-century poet, though it does qualify as a charming memoir of the life of his elder brother, Gerald, who expresses love and pride throughout and does offer a number of brief anecdotes and character sketches of Ted's life.  Neither, thankfully, is this book a source of more sensational or shocking details about Ted's life with Sylvia Plath (and other women).  Gerald supplies a respectful and somewhat affectionate account of Ted and Sylvia's early married life and the tragedy of her death, but he does this mostly through information from letters and relatively brief encounters with the couple while they lived in England.  All this said, the book is readable, enjoyable, and it does offer insights (perhaps fanciful) into Ted Hughes's poetic genius.  Most of the book, however, is devoted more to Gerald's life and experiences—especially a fascinating account of his activities as a RAF plane mechanic, stationed mostly in North Africa, during World War II.In portraying his own and Ted's childhood experiences, Gerald comes closest to providing insights into the character of Ted Hughes.  He describes the almost idyllic environment of Mytholmroyd, a mostly rural area though supported by industrial works, where he and Ted were able to fish, ride bicycles, camp out in places not too remote from home, and generally live the lives of "boys" as they were experienced during the 1930s.  A move to a larger town, Mexborough, and a change of profession for their father, forced some changes in their lives, but both seem to have found ways to occupy themselves and remain upbeat and cheerful, even during the darker days of the Depression.  Gerald regularly provides details about Ted's early experiences with poetry and with music (tracing his early and lasting love of the music of Beethoven, for example), and constantly reminds us of the passion for hunting and fishing that he and Ted shared and that Ted continued to pursue through much of his adult life.  (This latter is well described in Boyanowsky's memoir, Wild Gods, Silver Ghosts: Ted Hughes in the Wild.)Gerald emigrated to Australia after his stint in the RAF during the war, and so much of his adult life was spent (including his marriage and fatherhood) half a world away from Ted.  That would include most of the fateful time that Ted was married to Sylvia Plath.  Gerald is careful to indicate the secondhand nature of much of his description of their relationship, though he and his wife did spend some time in England during one of the more positive periods of the Hughes/Plath marriage.  But he avoids engaging with any of the controversy (though he mentions its negative effect on Ted's emotional life).  In other words, this book will give nothing to those who still hope to dig for more than is known about that sad period.Gerald has been an avid painter and drawer since his early years, and that also is a subject of his writing here.  Indeed, Gerald comes through this narrative as a generous, loving, and engaging man who truly wants to produce a tribute to his beloved younger brother, and he succeeds in that. The prose narrative is written in a genial conversational style that creates the sense of sitting comfortably over a drink with a talkative friend who has had an interesting life. It is not a great memoir, but it is certainly of interest to anyone who cares for Ted Hughes, and it can be recommended.

I am afraid there is more interest in trying to figure out what prompted David Park to arrange this trio of narratives as he has and then call it a 'novel," which it could only be if there were some perceptible interconnections among the three narratives, some cross references or recurring imagery that prompted the reader to think about the ways in which the several stories (of quite different lives) might comment on or illuminate each other, achieving some kind of unity that would justify the term "novel," than there is to be gained from reading it.  Yes, many works of fiction exist that include disparate narratives intertwined and played off against each other (famously, David Mitchell has made a career of constructing such complicated intertextualities), and when they work, they are marvelous.  Fans of Charles Dickens can cite examples in his work, as well, and we could look further back.  But I have looked in vain for a reason to accept the term "novel" in relation to this book, and so I would have to say that we have three narratives of women's lives, of unequal length and quite different mood, and I guess I must consider the three individually.,The first long short story (not really a novella) is based on what little is known of the life of Catherine Blake, the wife, companion, supporter, and collaborator with the great English poet, William Blake.  Park has decided on a kind of interior monologue as his narrative mode, and we first encounter Catherine as she is adjusting to life after the death of the man whose presence and personality had dominated her during her whole adult life.  She thinks about William, about her difficulty in understanding his visions and the full significance of his art (some of which deeply unsettles her by its violence and sexual explicitness, but she refuses to be offended by it because it is his and she has confidence that he has known best what it meant and could never intend anything obscene or evil), and she remembers, not in chronological sequence, experiences and events (some of them known to be apocryphal stories debunked by later scholarship--as, for example, the story of Catherine and William sitting in their garden, both nude, reading aloud from Paradise Lost--a story she tells and indicates that she could not refrain from blushing when a friend came unexpectedly to call on them) from their lives together.  Here is where the work begins to fall apart.  The reader gets what is expected--the familiar stories, whether true or fabulous, of those events, combined with accounts of what is known--that William taught her to read, to work in watercolor, to help him to illuminate his works, to help with the printing.  It is known that they did not have children and she (in this story) expresses some regret about that.  The stories of William's outrage at injustice and cruelty are repeated, as well as the famous arrest and trial for treason when he is falsely accused by a drunken soldier of damning the King..  But where is the insight, the illumination, the addition to what we could know from reading a thorough encyclopedia article?  We learn of Catherine's steadfast love, as she expresses it, and her faith in William's wisdom and genius, and her determination to stay with him and to wait until she can join him in eternity.  Much of this is narrated in rather flat prose which includes, as an ominous warning, frequent descents into cliched imagery that is not sourced from William and not fairly loaded onto Catherine.  So the story, in my view, adds nothing to our understanding or thinking about Catherine that is not readily available elsewhere.The second novella, also about a wife deeply devoted to her husband and especially to preserving his great poetry, is based closely on the life of Nadezhda Mandelstam, widow of Osip, who was exiled to a work camp for writing and reciting a satirical poem about Joseph Stalin.  As it happens, Nadezhda Mandelstam, herself, has provided incomparable testimony and memoir about this same life in her masterpiece, Hope Against Hope and its companion volume, Hope Abandoned.  I could enumerate the many ways in which Parks narrative merely recapitulates the most famous and familiar stories from her great works, and I could point out the obvious--while it was an ambitious idea to attempt to add something of depth to our understanding of one of the greatest pairs of lovers in modern history, it was an essay in futility.  Again, the narrative is flat, often cliched, and it adds nothing to what is better encountered in Nadezhda's own works.The third novella, fictional (though it has enough material in it to offer evidence of the model for the character of the poet), gives us again an interior monologue, this time more in the manner of some other modern writers (Colm Toibin, Colum McCann and John Banville come to mind, but with Virginia Woolf lurking in the background), and also, this time, in a very different tone.  This widow is at her seaside cottage on the north coast of Ireland to carry out her dead husband's wishes by emptying his ashes into the sea from a jetty near the cottage.  She has persuaded their two daughters, both living in London, to join her for the ceremony their father had specified, or perhaps demanded.  She is obsessed with the absence of their son, who died somewhat mysteriously in Morocco at an early age.  In this case, the relationship is far from that of Catherine or Nadezhda to their husbands--this widow feels intense ambivalence, at best, extreme resentment at worst, at the memories of her life with her poet husband, a man whom she and her daughters both remember as self-centered, unconcerned for anything except his career, and unfaithful in his marriage on numerous occasions.  The wife feels profound mistrust and doubt about the veracity of her husband's poems, suspecting that he has merely written what is understood to be appropriate feeling in his poems--never expressions, so she thinks, of true feeling about anyone but himself.  So the idea of honoring his wishes and memory by carrying out this sea burial is hardly a positive one from her perspective.  The feelings and interactions of the three women when they are together in the cottage, which is filled with memories of the poet, including a final manuscript which the wife has read but has not admitted even exists--suggesting the possibility that she might hide it or even destroy it, but she knows in her heart that she will not betray his legacy, but will deliver the work to his publisher--are uneasy and necessarily tentative.  Some moments of direct feeling and communication do occur, but each must work to reconcile herself to participation in the ritual.The third novella, therefore, reverses the pattern of relationships between the poets and their wives: in the first two, both wives are totally devoted to the work and to preserving the memories of their husbands; in the third, Park creates a wife who not only does not love her dead husband, but who has serious doubts about the quality of the work she might be responsible for preserving.  Unlike Mary Shelley, for example, who devoted her life to preserving and protecting the reputation of her husband, this wife (and her daughters) would like nothing better than to empty the urn into the sea and blot out his memory entirely.  Or at least, that is her wish at some points--at others, ambivalence takes over and she re-thinks her feelings and the reasons for them.  At the center of her problematic feelings is always her lost son.The third novella ought probably to have been published by itself.  It is psychologically more complex and as fictional drama, more intense and engaging than either of the other two.  As a fiction (at least nominally) it has the freedom to explore experiences and emotions in ways not constrained by the known facts of the other two lives. Even so, the prose often droops into the prosaic or cliched, and the narrative plods at times.  That is not a positive quality in a brief novella that needs to make its effects quickly and consistently, never allowing the reader to feel that things are dragging.This is far from the only recent novel to attempt to reconstruct aspects of the lives of known persons, and it is certainly not the worst of them, but neither is it in a class with the powerful works that succeed in convincing us that we have not only a narrative that conforms to what is known of the person's life, but one that suggests a deeper and more comprehensive understanding of that person's life.  (I think, for example, of Colm Toibin's The Master, and of Bruce Duffy's The World As I Found It, and Joanna Scott's Arrogance.) In this case, the writer seems not to have been able to think deeply enough about his subjects' lives, nor even in the fictional narrative has he been able to create a narrative that resonates or evokes sympathy.  I cannot recommend this book.

This novel disappoints on so many levels that I am tempted to drop to two stars, but in fairness, the ambition of the project is worthy of praise and the fact that the author has made so many awkward choices or plain missteps does not detract entirely from its very limited merits.D'Aguiar sets out to provide a fictional account of a well-known recent outrage--the massacre of a large number of people who were variously duped or mentally controlled by a charismatic "preacher" who insists on being called "Father" and who is revealed (repetitively) to be a scheming and delusional, self-centered manipulator focused on his own aggrandizement.  The historical figure--"The Reverend" Jim Jones, may have shared many such qualities and certainly was responsible for taking his followers into a jungle environment where he subjected them effectively to slave labor conditions and extreme mental and emotional abuse.  It seems that D'Aguiar has aspired to create a portrait both of the perverse leader and of the more or less pathetic souls whom he has recruited or manipulated into following him, perhaps in an attempt to provide insight (or even answers) into the questions so many have asked about how and why he could gain such control over so many people.In pursuit of his novelistic goal, D'Aguiar focuses on several characters--a young girl, Trina, being the most prominent, a gorilla named Adam being the most improbable.  Trina's mother and a riverboat captain who falls in love with her are also prominent, with the Preacher himself being the other major character.  (Several peripheral characters, including two young men who are close friends, perhaps lovers, and who are guards in the compound, become recognizable, but most of the characters are interchangeable.)  Among the missteps by the author, the choice of reporting the internal thought processes of the mother and Trina, as well as of Adam.  Yes, Adam is presented to us (perhaps with the hope that recent research into primate thought processes might make this characterization almost plausible) as a creature who is gradually gaining reasoning power and even language.  I do not deny the impressive possibilities exhibited by some primates in research situations, nor do I ignore the likely fact that Adam's "character" is part of the structure of "magical realism" that is the other major misstep by D'Aguiar.  Whatever the case, there is little to be said in favor of inserting what becomes a deus ex machina of sorts in the form of a gorilla into this narrative.  Nor is the preternatural wisdom of Trina presented convincingly.  We are to experience her mind and her behavior as representative of a very lively, courageous, intellectually precocious child, and all those things are credible in her sections of the novel, as are the growing strength and determination of her mother as she realizes more fully how evil and destructive the Preacher has shown himself.The characterization of the Preacher seeks complexity--he is selfish, self-indulgent, prone to irrational tantrums, ruthless in controlling those around him even if it means physically abusing or even killing them, and obsessed with what he believes is the persecution he experiences at the hands of any officialdom he cannot control with bribes or fabricated shows of benevolence and order.  D'Aguiar includes many moralistic passages--repetitive, flat, prosaic--that add nothing to the depth of the characterization but shield him from any suspicion that he is using this "villain" for sensational purposes in his fiction.The novel is also larded with extensive descriptions of the jungle environment, especially as contrasted with urban and impoverished areas from which most of the "believers" have come.  The descriptions take on an almost mechanical predictability--if there is a glimpse of the jungle--a trail, the trees, animals or birds emerging from or disappearing into the area, just a walk along a path from the compound to the pigsty--there will be lush colorful passages evoking images rather like those of Le Douanier Rousseau's paintings.  Some of these passages are effective and convey the wonder experienced by the former urban dwellers, but the repetition finally makes them feel like padding and they are added to the plodding passages of moralism that also seem simply to extend the novel to no good purpose.The spasms of violence increase as we near the end of the novel, but for much of the final section we are left uncertain whether we are reading the hallucinations of characters who are actually dying of the effects of the cyanide administered to them, or that they might just possibly be experiencing the chances for escape or rescue that could be real if they are not dreams.  While there are ways in which this approach can work effectively, here the final sections of the novel seem merely evasive.Neither realistic nor convincingly poetic or magical, this novel finally fails to cohere or to convince, and the times when the reader pauses with an exasperated "come on!" may seem much too frequent. A work of this kind seeks to deepen or extend our understanding of complex historical and personal events, but there is neither depth nor illumination to be had--just a sense of a writer grasping for intriguing or, in some cases, familiarly formulaic, variations on the possibilities, with little to say beyond the cleverness.  D'Aguiar is a respected and accomplished writer, but here the weight of his subject has been more than he could carry.

I had not heard of, nor read the work of, Patrick Modiano before the announcement of his Nobel Prize for Literature.  Curiosity ensued.  My first encounter has been with this curious book (both an odd work and one that explores deeply the nature of human curiosity), a cross between novella and brief, focused memoir.  The voice of the narrator lets us know early that a determined search for information about the fate of a young woman, Dora Bruder, identified as being "missing" from her school in Paris, according to a notice posted by her parents in Paris-Soir on December 31, 1941 is to follow.  Indeed, the narrative persists in a search through printed records, possible eyewitness sources and whatever else may reveal or bring to light the situation and circumstances of Dora's life after her flight from her school.  Early in the work, the narrator states: "Il faut longtemps pour que resurgisse a la lumiere ce qui a ete efface.  Des traces subsistent dans des registres et l'on ignore ou ils sont caches et quels gardiens veillent sur eux te si ces gardiens consentiront a vous les montrer.  Ou peut-etre ont-ils oublie tout simplement que ces registres existaientt"  And he concludes the thought with what might be the governing idea or at least a guiding motto for this narrative, "Il suffit d'un peu de patience."  (Please excuse the absence of the proper diacritical marks.)The narrator mixes details of his own life, both his youth and his recent history, with the details he uncovers and discovers from the various sources about the life (and death) of Dora and, for that matter, of both of her parents and vast numbers of others rounded up and deported to death camps by the occupying Germans.This powerful exploration of, one might also say meditation upon, the possibilities of ever knowing with certainty what has happened to others, especially in the past, as well as whether what one remembers about oneself is real or accurate, and whether or how one may interpret the "evidence" of photographs, printed records, identity papers, etc., appears to be one of the recurrent themes of Modiano's fiction.  It is, perhaps, most precisely focused here (though I will have to read much more of his work to feel confident of this) because he has chosen a specific person who is not personally known to him, but whose fate he nonetheless wishes to establish.  In the process, he recovers information about a number of other persons, also deported or otherwise destroyed by the "univers de boucherie et d'apocalypse" that was the European experience during the Second World War.The narrator reflects on the art of fiction and the use, in classic novels, of coincidence, of the possibility of a kind of prophetic clairvoyance arising in a novelist who expends intense imaginative concentration on events--possibly actual events, possibly those only imagined:  "cela fait simplement partie du metier:  les efforts d'imagination, necessaires a ce metier, le besoin de fixer son esprit sur des points de detail--et cela de maniere obsessionnelle -- pour ne pas perdre le fil et se laisser a aller a sa paresse -- toute cette tension, cette gymnastique cerebrale peut sans doute provoquer a la longue de breves intuitions "concernant des evenements passes ou futurs"  (p. 53).  And that is a pretty good description of the narrative procedure of Dora Bruder.  It is a fascinating sojourn with the mind of a master detective, a profoundly intuitive and ratiocinative mind, devoted to exploring the nature of human experience in times of extremity.  The very nature of human identity--challenged by fear and oppression, forced into disguise and self-denial in the face of threats, transforming the self from a familiar to an alien entity while retaining some degree of consciousness of the necessary deception and the underlying truth--all these are aspects of Modiano's narrative, and all contribute to the emotional and intellectual impact of this wonderful work.

First novels are usually worthy of publication (some editor and publisher must have thought so) and sometimes offer promise of a novelist who will offer excellent work in the future--maybe she or he will even be among the great novelists of our future.  We always hope for a few.  Mr. Weil's novel offers many familiar elements, starting with a dystopian society (victim of a combination of uncontrolled technological "advances" providing both some benefits and also dependence on some of the familiar ruthless agencies of control that dystopian planners inevitably find necessary to prevent "regression").  Familiar, also, is the pair of twin brothers, one energetic, intelligent, determined to make his way upward in the vertically organized society that has developed in his lifetime, the other a dreamer, also intelligent but devoted to memories of the rural world he grew up in, wishing to save enough money (partnering with his brother) to buy the land on which his childhood and youth were spent in rural pursuits.  Several other almost predictable elements are deployed (some very violent men and women whose ruthless behavior is both "political" and self-serving; a Russian oligarch, head of the tech company that intends to transform the world, ruthless also, in his own way, and determined to control the elder brother; a mother declining into dementia.)  Not so familiar, but appropriate in the particular environment of this novel, a rooster that lives in the apartment of the dreaming brother and his mother.The "great glass sea" is set in a part of the former USSR, now essentially under the control of a corporation started by the oligarch that is constructing a combination of satellites and receptor mirrors and solar panels designed to transform the climate and the ecosystem of the area of Ukraine (it seems) for the sake of maximal crop production.  This "development" is one of several burdens on the novel that finally drag it down.  The complexity of the "science" and the industrial transformation of the country requires far too much exposition and seems to drive the author to recapitulate material and situations over and over, even when the "point" has been made.  At the same time, even a very attentive and patient reader, going back over already read sections to try to clarify the situations as they develop, may find that the nature of the industry is never entirely clear nor comprehensible.Similarly, while the relationship between the twins is deep and complex and credible, and emotionally compelling at many points, it is also predictable and finally not very satisfying.  Neither are the relations that develop between the dreamer and the violent resisters (really not revolutionaries, though they imagine themselves in that role now and then) nor the practical brother's relationship with Bazarov, the oligarch, which has layers of mutual manipulation, some hints of homoerotic connection, and plenty of menace, but not much is revealed or resolved that, again, could not have been predicted.  Nor, and this is painful, do I feel that the main development in the life of the dreaming brother--his discovery that he can recite classics of Russian poetry--especially Pushkin's Bronze Horseman--to admiring and enthusiastic crowds, finally inspiring many of them to rebel against the constraints of the new society that provides none of the values nor rewards of the classic (only partially remembered) society of pre-Revolutionary Russia--never achieves its full symbolic nor fictional status in the work.  Of course, he is thwarted and exploited and threatened with personal destruction, but like his brother's nearly abortive effort to achieve within the society, his efforts lead only to further destruction and death.I do not mean to suggest that Weil is merely borrowing standard tropes from similar dystopian narratives, but there is a tendency here to depend on familiar, almost archetypal, situations, and because the novel is set in Russia, there are also moments reminiscent of some of the great Russian writers of speculative fiction, Evgeny Zamyatin, for example, and Mikhail Bulgakov, but especially the Strugatsky Brothers, who make use in many of their novels of characters and narratives derived from the peasant traditions and folklore of rural Russia.  Allusions to Baba Yaga and other such characters are occasionally overt, at many points implicit in Weil's novel.But I must here exercise a kind of turn.  While I have emphasized the predictable content of the novel, and would also suggest that the repetition leads to a feeling of padding, of added pages that offer no further clarification or revelation of the importance of the events, I want to conclude with words of praise.  After all, I read this novel all the way through, and I did so without worrying about the repetitions and familiarity because there were, at so many points in the narrative, wonderful (and I do mean "full of wonder--and beauty!") passages of prose poetry--as though Weil suddenly were possessed by the muse and launched writing that, as truly brilliant prose--sometimes lyrical evocations of the land, of childhood experiences, of the sheer beauty of the night sky, at other times powerful dramatizations of the inner conflicts of men and women trying to be honest with themselves while trapped in a system that forces evasion and dishonesty, and sometimes the aching power of love, especially unrequited or hopeless--far surpasses and outweighs all the plodding plot elements.  Whenever one of these passages was under weigh, I felt the presence of a writer of true power and imagination, and I was forced to acknowledge that though this novel is finally not successful, it certainly does show the promise of a writer with the ability to produce great work.  He will need to be more willing to cut excesses (and trust his reader to get the points implied) and maybe to work beyond the kinds of plot turns and set scenes (some of the scenes of violence, especially, which are not gratuitous but add little of the power that violent narrative may bring to a novel).  I am reminded in this way of the works of China Mieville, some of them massive (Perdido Street Station) and brilliant, but others (The Kraken) excessively and tiresomely padded, whereas his shorter and tighter and sometimes more difficult works (The City in the City, Embassytown) provide both the imaginative power and the sense of artistic rigor that the best such works can offer.  It seems to me that Weil may give us work of the latter quality and I look forward to it.

I am no connoisseur of pillows.  A pillow is either comfortable or not, as far as I am concerned.  When I stay at one of those hotels that offers a buffet variety of pillows of many shapes or sizes (the last hotel bed I slept in had six pillows of slightly different shapes piled on it--to no particular end as far as I was concerned), I am interested mainly in the display.  Then I pick a pillow and go to sleep.  So I may not be a well qualified reviewer for this pillow, but I will venture to say that I appreciate its yielding firmness, find that it is about the right degree of thickness to support my head at a proper angle, and allows me to sleep without worrying about whether it will swallow me or shove me off the bed.  Yes, it is comfortable and lets me sleep, and if it provides some of the other promised services (holding something about me in its "memory," preventing migraine, etc.), that's fine.  Yes, it is a good pillow, seems to be well made of sturdy materials.  I will use it and if anyone asks, I will recommend it.

I haven't counted how many times John Gallaher mentions John Cage (and Silence: Lectures and Writings by John Cage) in the pages (among the poems) in his new book, In a Landscape, starting as he does with an epigraph—quotation from John Cage--and another from John Ashbery—but  I am sure it is quite a few, and every such reference (there are not so many direct references to Ashbery, but one  might say the whole collection is in some sense a continuing allusion to Ashbery—one might, and one hopes that is not offensive, since it is not intended to be, but quite the contrary) every such reference, I say, is a welcome reminder.  [Cause/Effect statement:  Reading In a Landscape caused me to, among other things, dig out from its obscurity my very old copy of John Cage's Silence and indulge the pleasure of reading it again.]  Indulging pleasures (as well as sometimes ruing unpleasantnesses) is not only an effect of reading In a Landscape, but also a subject of a fair number of passages in the LXXI segments  of this continually surprising book: "Have you had a good life?"  Good question.  In the grand scheme of things, we're all fairly equal.  We just travel in varying degrees of comfort. "  (from number LIII)I also have not figured out exactly at what point in my reading that the thought – "something's going on here"—popped into my head, forcing me to stop briefly and consider what that might have meant.  The "something" was the troubling realization that the voice of these poems had cunningly taken over my own inner voice, replacing the tiresome hectoring that I usually treat myself to with a kind of quiet musing and meandering tone and procedure, not to mention syntax and vocabulary, not to mention plenty of references to things I might think I have in common with the voice/mind invading my voice/mind via these pages of long-lined (some short, to be fair) poems, numbered with Roman numerals (also a topic of queries and explanations, some humor,  some dread) and continuing, as we are told, to our relief, past their original ending point, which was to have been  XLI or possibly XLII, but "I changed my mind.  I was going to stop writing this poem, but now I'm not, because I heard someone say, in the hallway earlier, that she had changed her mind, and it seemed a lovely idea, the way it struck me, to 'change my mind.'"  (from number XLII)and so he goes ahead all the way to LXXI.In this connection, and in passing, let me mention that reading the CONTENTS page of this volume is a fascinating experience in itself, though perhaps only after one has actually read through the whole book.  The CONTENTS lists the poems by their full first lines, each attached to its Roman numeral.  No, it does not form a coherent poem (that would be a neat trick), though it makes every bit as much poetic sense to read the opening lines in sequence as it does to read some pages of John Cage's Silence.What is it like to read these poems?  As already indicated, it is like having one's mind invaded and occupied by a quirky ambling mind, moving more or less through free association from topic to topic, image to image, narrative to commentary, exposition to homily, or sometimes to a shrug ("So there you are," rather like Gail Collins pausing in her quest for reasons why Republicans still exist, contrary to all evolutionary expectations or simple common sense).  And in case anyone wonders, it is an experience that I have found enjoyable and definitely in the realm of what I think of as poetry.It's always dangerous to offer comparisons or associations with other poets when talking about a specific poet's new book, but I don't care.  He took over my mind and it reacted by popping up every now and then with associations of its own.  Some are painfully obvious—those pages filled with long lines—are we in Whitman territory here? No.  Christopher Smart? No.  Ashbery?  Sometimes.  How about C.K. Williams?  Not really.  At some moments, Thomas McGrath?  Definitely, though rarely as belligerent.  David Antin?  Different style.  John Berryman?  (How about "The earth, friends, is doing fine."  Well I think so.)  But Gallaher's lines are finally his own.  Reading through this book in a long sitting, I have felt that he has found a cadence and rhythm (if those are distinguishable) perfectly suited to the manner of thinking of these poems.The "voice" prompts some other, maybe less pertinent (not intended to be impertinent) associations.  A touch of Andy Rooney here and there, or (many folks are too young to remember this) the late night radio monologues of Jean Shepherd from Cincinnati or later WOR, or even, now and then, Bob and Ray.  Drawing the past into the present and fitting them comfortably together has to be one of the aspects of these poems that I find particularly fascinating.  Many questions, some answered, many not.  Lots of invitations—  "A moment of silence then  where my stories that are not being told  can mingle with yours.  Let's drive across the state.  Let's go over the river.  Let's run off  into the woods with them."  (from number LVII)Sometimes deep questions combine with tentative reassurances :  "We want to feel that our lives  have meaning, and the easiest way to ascertain meaning  is to look behind one for signs of having been  there.  The legacy starts now."  (from number LII)And there can be passages that stop us dead in our tracks:  "First warm day after a series  of cold days.  Guessing at intentions and inner lives  has always left me standing on train platforms late at night,  in winter, inappropriately dressed."  (from number LXII)In years past, I have been interested, amused, engaged by John Gallaher's earlier volumes.  In some ways, they anticipate this one, but I would say that In a Landscape seems to me a kind of breakthrough, a fulfillment of the promise of those two books, but more importantly a break with them.  They offer many pleasures, but they also have seemed to me consistent with fashion—not a bad thing, necessarily, but prompting anticipation.  And here, for example, in LIV, we have "Where's the line between what constitutes repetition and what constitutes change? Right now I'm thinking forgetfulness  is just as good as careful planning, similar to how doing nothing  is usually just as helpful as quick, decisive action.  Chance actions.  John Cage made detailed plans on chance."Indeed.  We might shiver at an echo of Paradise Regained here, or a glance at Prometheus Unbound, but what we have is Gallaher, in the company of Cage once again, raising those questions about tradition and change, about influence and independence, about daily life and transcendence (or adaptation) that every poet must face.  The pleasure of the company of a mind exploring and recounting, and practicing the art of poetry with subtlety and clever craft—all things making this book worthy of strong recommendation.  Do read it.

The author of this novel (memoir? fantasia?) worked hard to keep any prospective reader from feeling comfortable or confident that she or he could depend on previous reading experiences to aid in navigation through the "letters" that compose the parts of the text.  Not only is the reader invited to read the parts in any order whatever, but that challenge, it becomes obvious very soon, offers an unnecessary further "complication"--the letters are not, in any case, chronological, nor are they written/spoken/narrated by the same "voice," nor is it always apparent that the same narrator is "present" in all the letters.  One can start with the premise that though names and genders shift and relationships, such as they are, may be fluid or imagined, fantasized or distorted by the shifting moods of the narrator of the moment, the narrative voice is always the same, only putting on alternative masks.  But that is a question--at any given time, the voice of the narrator may be congruent with that of the author, but the rapid shifts of attitude and tone regularly move the reader to wonder whether, in fact, this narrator is truly a "divided person," one with multiple personalities or one driven into fragmentation by the extremes of her own emotional reactions to the friends, lovers, helpers, enemies with whom (or toward whom) the letters are to be exchanged. For the most part, the letters all appear to be intended for one particular faraway lover, Xu, even though some are addressed to Yong, and other characters are named, even addressed, even in the context of the letters supposedly addressed to Xu.The narrator(s) is/are writer/artist/university student/Taiwanese citizen/Parisian flaneur on occasion/underground person, and more.  Sometimes generous--seeking presents to give, offering loving thoughts; otherwise, grasping, demanding, insistent on having her own way on her own terms.  Sometimes female, occasionally male, lesbian, heterosexual, queer-asexual.  Through the many transformations of consciousness and -- if we dare use the word -- identity, we nonetheless "hear" the voice of a young person desperately seeking love, reacting hysterically or angrily or with despair to perceived rejection, refusing the love of those who offer it, demanding love of at least one who runs from her because of her demands and, perhaps, her instability.  One oddity of the novel--the narrator is undoubtedly a fractured personality, and by comparison, those around her seem stable, well put together, able to function in a "normal" society, though she suspects (and diagnoses) that they have found stability only through espousing false, fake, artificial personas, assumed because they perceive them to be socially acceptable.The narrator's letters often reach a crescendo of conflicted emotions--"So my desire became unhinged and my pain excruciating.  When you stop wanting me--withdrawing your eros--I go insane, truly insane.  I've reached an apex of insanity (ha ha).  Why am I laughing?  Because I have a fatal, mortal, terminal passion for you.  Ultimately I have no choice but death: an unconditional allegiance, an eternal bond to you.  (The ultimate rule of desire/eros is this: At their peak, "sexual desire" [erotic desire], and "desire for death" [the death wish] are the same.)  I'm a passionate person, and as you're someone I would die for, death seems inevitable, though it's still painful thinking about it."  This heightened rhetoric and nearly hysterical tone are characteristic of the language and substance of many of the letters.  As a result, this reader, at least, frequently felt that I was being harangued, subjected to a self-indulgent rant by a person who, in the best of times, is self-centered, selfish, and probably destructive (not only self-destructive).  And that is when one, as a reader of this narrative, must retreat into thinking of it as, after all, a literary construct.  This incessant hyperemotion is not a person talking to me on the phone, but a character (or is she?) in a fictional (albeit heavily autobiographical, apparently) narrative.  But that takes us back to the beginning--the author has done her best NOT TO ALLOW us, as readers, to experience this as a literary artifact.  In this sense, the book may be reminiscent of some other experimental writings that do their best to force defamiliarization and alienation as the primary reading experiences.  (I think of, for example, Djuna Barnes's Nightwood, a far more conventional work in some ways, but also demanding of the reader, or the strange and alienating narrative by Anna Kavan, Ice.  One might even add E.A. Poe's The Narrative of Arthur Gordon Pym, or Sterne's Tristram Shandy.)To the extent that there is a "story" here, it includes the death of a pet rabbit and its burial, encounters with a famous woman scholar and writer, journeys back to Taiwan and Japan and then returns to Paris, "quiet days in Clichy," though not so quiet as all that, and some visits to art galleries and performances. Names of some artists and writers, and especially movie directors, are dropped.  I don't mean to mock this--the author makes no pretense of constructing a coherent narrative, though the reader (this reader, at least) is likely to indulge the lifelong habit of constructing coherence where it is not apparent, weaving a plot line where none exists, working to frustrate the author's apparent wish to create a work without a plot and with no characters in the conventional sense of those terms.  As a kind of mental wrestling match between the reader and writer, this book is arguably fascinating.One might mention that the focus on what is crudely called gender-bending, or more recently "queering" relationships, is pervasive and in a few passages generates some erotic fascination.  While readers who are phobic about such subject matter might avoid the book, one can say that there is little in it to shock or dismay the reader who is familiar with the explorations of alternate sexualities in so much of modern literature.I did not take the challenge of reading the chapters randomly (I had enough of that when I faithfully followed the printed and then the proposed alternative order of chapters in Cortazar's Hopscotch many years ago), but the challenge itself, of course, put me on notice that there would not be a linear narrative, and indeed, the chapters might be said to spin around each other, creating not a plot nor stable characters, but a kind of galaxy of interacting (if not illuminating) parts, related but not kept in order.  I did several times return to re-read earlier letters, and that was interesting enough as the re-reading revealed perceptions I had not realized during the first reading--that, in itself, might be a strong argument for randomly re-reading the whole.  But I think I will not.If it were possible, I would probably give this 3.5 rather than 4 stars, but 3 seems a bit too stingy.  There is much to admire in the energy and imaginative ingenuity of this work, whether or not we want to call it a novel.  But the hectoring and ranting tone of many of the "letters" finally becomes irritating (as it would in "real" life), and as a reader, I found it distracted me from whatever kind of admiration I might be constructing from the shards of the experience..

Readers familiar with David Vann's earlier fiction (Legend of a Suicide, especially) already know of his extraordinary ability to render physical sensations--the feeling of moving in stressful situations, the power and pain of a punch or a knife penetrating the skin, the pleasures of the many sensations when one is alert to the scents, the breezes, the movements of the natural world around us.  And more--Vann explores the the conflicts and pleasures of human relationships, especially as they begin to collapse into violent confrontation or rise to the ecstasies of loving encounters.  And always, Vann explores the intricacy of the psychological and moral challenges experienced when behavior leads to disaster or death.In Goat Mountain, we are party to the re-telling of a horrific childhood experience by a narrator who lived it and has grown older, scarred by the aftermath and still uncertain of the full significance of what he did at the time and what the longterm effects of what he did have actually been.  The basic situation is simple:  the boy, his father and grandfather, and a close friend of his father, go on an annual deer hunt that takes them to land in a wilderness area owned by his family.  The boy is 11 years old, ready to kill his first buck and "become a man."  These elements, so baldly iterated, make the story sound familiar and even hackneyed.  The story Vann tells us, however, spins off into extreme violence and horror of a kind that Vann is very skilled at telling.Not to give away too much, the boy shoots a stranger--a poacher on their land.  This killing occurs very early in the novel, and its impact on his father and grandfather and their friend, as well as on the boy himself, is the story that unfolds with frequent allusions (characteristic of Vann's narrative style) to other murders--the story of Cain and Abel being most often mentioned.  Thinking back on the significance of the murder he has committed, the boy examines his understanding of the story of Cain--a view of the story that is not traditional:  "It may be a long time before he brings that stone down, and it's in this moment we can know Cain.  The momentum of his life, everything out of control, everything misunderstood and recognized too late, that's how we are descended from Cain.  All that was instinctual suddenly bearing consequence, our animal nature betrayed by consciousness."  And much later, realizing that he has not understood the behavior of his relatives:  "I didn't know them and they didn't know me. All familiar things can become unfamiliar.  One of the tricks of this world is the feeling that we belong."That is the voice, of course, of the adult man, thinking back many years (we don't know how many) to the traumatic experiences of his eleventh year.  Though Vann drops a few clues about what might have happened to the boy as he grew to manhood, they are only hints and may be misleading, so the focus remains on the adult's memories of his eleven-year-old consciousness.  The boy is from a Cherokee family, and the teachings of his tribal elders are present (if not settled) in his mind, though he finds it easy to set them aside.There are some problems with this narrative, perhaps already indicated in what I have written here.  It sometimes seems that Vann is stretching far, overreaching in order to force us, as readers, to recognize and think about the powerful themes he is exploring--the nature of human violence, the relation between morality, social behavior, religious belief, and the violence that we seem sometimes to choose without thought or pause--as though all the teaching and rules we know simply disappear in the moment of excitement (of whatever kind) that leads to the dominance of the "Cain" that Vann suggests is present in all of us.The novel is intense, painful to read at times, and occasionally overwrought--but I can recommend it for anyone who is willing to share the experience of great physical stress and pain, of moral uncertainty, and the fear of abandonment that becomes very real to this boy as the aftermath of his action becomes increasingly desperate and destructive.

I have found myself more frequently discussing this novel as though it were a work of cultural criticism or even anthropology, rather than a work of fiction.  The Ruins of Us is impressive as a portrait (from several differing perspectives) of a social and cultural milieu that very few American readers will have had direct knowledge of--the private worlds of family and business and daily life in Saudi Arabia.  Because we know that Ms. Parssinen has lived for many years in that country, we are inclined to read with some confidence that she has the authority to interpret the customs and attitudes of her Saudi characters, as well as those of her American characters.  Because of this, the book provides the pleasure (which has been a main value of many fine novels) of immersion in a foreign or unfamiliar cultural environment, satisfying our curiosity and, I think, correcting some misconceptions and false stereotypes, while confirming (with sympathy and understanding) our sense of the radical differences between western secular customs and attitudes and those held (even, it must be said, enforced--by morals police) among traditional Saudis.At the same time, and this will lead us to the particular drama of her plotline, Parssinen shows us the tensions and conflicts that occur when a traditional culture such as the Saudi encounters and chooses to interact with a very different--corrosively different--culture, such as that of the 21st century western world.  In order to do business with U.S. and western European governments and corporations, the Saudis must, with reluctance, open spaces within their sovereign nation to accommodate (even to allow if not endorse) customs and behavior that are anathema to their Islamic traditions and laws.  That this creates deep divides and dissonances in the lives of their people is vividly dramatized by Ms. Parsinnen's central characters--a wealthy Saudi businessman, his American wife, and their children, all conscious of the divisions between their Saudi and their American relatives and heritages.  When these conditions are exacerbated by the husband's choice to take a second wife, as allowed by Islamic law, resulting in traumatic emotional responses from both his first wife and (in different ways) both his children, the plot develops and the differences in character, belief, and loyalties become apparent.Ms. Parssinen, then, makes good use of personal relationships to embody and dramatize social and cultural conflicts, and the unfolding of the essentially melodramatic (and quite familiar) plot turns will allow the reader to understand and sympathize with the several different points of view among the main characters.  But though this is an effective literary device, it also must be seen as a weakness in the overall planning of the novel.  The familiar domestic drama is dressed in unfamiliar cultural costumes, but is nonetheless a story we know, and so is predictable in a number of ways that make the middle of the novel feel overly long and unnecessarily drawn out.  We understand that the several characters need time to absorb the situation and to contemplate their responses.  (Ironically, several of the minor characters feel underdeveloped in part, I think, because so many pages are devoted to the ruminations of, especially, the teenage son as he confronts his mixed love and hatred, his wish to assert himself as a true Saudi man and proper heir to his admired grandfather, while also recognizing his love for his mother, whose behavior he must, in his Saudi self, reprehend and repudiate.)One result of the familiarity of the plot is that the genuine interest of the portrayal of the layers and complexity of Saudi society becomes the dominant positive quality of our reading experience.  While any reader will be engaged and concerned about the outcome of the final confrontations that lead to the denouement of the plot, that probably will not be the main memory carried away from the book.  But one thing seems clear--Ms. Parssinen is a very good writer--her style is strong and consistent, and she knows how to create engaging and fascinating characters.  I would hope and expect that she will write and publish more novels, and that they will continue to be superior, even better.

I would not say that this is the worst novel I have ever read, but it is certainly the least successful of any that I have read in recent years.  There are reasons why one would have hoped this would be a deep and powerful exploration of a world seldom encountered in fiction, though recently at least on display in some novels and films--the world sometimes described as "queer nation," a world of challenged or repudiated gender roles and sexual identities, bisexual, transsexual, as well as homosexual.  Unfortunately, the novel Ms. Schrag has written, while it takes us into the upscale parties and the sleazy sex clubs, as well as into the worldviews of several persons who live the lives (because one point of the novel is that very few people of any persuasion live similar lives--every life is importantly different), is finally not much more than one of those "romcoms" that we see opening with some regularity at the local multiplex--some sophisticated, some sentimental, some just terminally stupid.  Adam, as a novel, is a mix of those qualities.  What makes this novel different from, for example, John Rechy's pioneering City of Night, with its excursions into what was then a deeply hidden, secret, closeted world of menace and blackmail, is that the setting in 2006 allows the characters to assert and explore their identities with public defiance of the repressivenorms that made Rechy's world so much darker; the gay, queer, transsexual demands for equality (in this case, a rally for marriage equality occurs in New York at a significant point in the narrative) are part of the growing openness about and acceptance of gender differences in our society.  There are, of course, as we are reminded several time, dangers in the form of gay bashing and other forms of violence, as well as discrimination and various self-inflicted wounds that affect or even destroy the lives of queer people.At the center of this novel is a seventeen year old California high school junior, Adam Freedman (get it?), who is (as is apparently universal among teenagers) uncertain of his social standing with his "friends" at school, uncertain of his ability to have a successful sex life, uncertain of what he wants in his future, uncertain of how to spend the summer, uncertain about his feelings toward his parents, his sister, even toward the young woman he would like to identify as his girlfriend and sex partner.  He knows how to use the standard technological devices (computer, smart phone, social media) but is not always successful in getting what he really wants from them, rather than just the information about what he wants, which may be no help.  The main action of the novel occurs when he decides to spend the summer in New York, living with his lesbian sister and her roommates, looking for his own possible sexual enlightenment or maturation.  Adam is characterized as something of a cross between Candide, Holden Caulfield, Alexander Portnoy, and several characters recently played by Michael Cera in films by Jason Reitman and others.  Naive, but not innocent; bright, but not aware of how to use his intelligence; not bad looking, but sexually uncertain and unsuccessful; shy, sometimes sensitive, but unable to act on his best impulses.  On the whole, a familiar type.Adam's problem in New York is that he falls in love with a young woman who self-identifies as lesbian and who is attracted to him because she mistakenly believes he is a tran--a woman who is in transition to being a man.  The complications for Adam (building a relationship on a set of lies that could be revealed at almost any moment and the desperate efforts he makes to re-construct himself as the person Gillian imagines him to be) are the bulk of the narrative.  We spend a lot of time inside his head as he calculates or just desperately sorts through the pros and cons of his alternatives--he wants to tell Gillian the truth, but every attempt is deflected or interrupted by their activities or by his fear that the time for openness and honesty is not quite right, so he must wait till next time.  When Adam is not reminding us of a Michael Cera character, he unfortunately stumbles into Adam Sandler territory.My references to popular movies are appropriate in part because much of the language and conversations in the novel involve references to the popular culture images and popular phenomena that would, of course, be the normal currency of adolescent conversation.  Even though Adam is mostly (at 17) the youngest of the characters, who are more his sister's age (22-28, maybe), we are immersed in the kinds of enthusiasms and simple cynicisms of high school and college upper middle class kids.  Well and good, if Ms. Schrag were able to probe and explore these characters with anything more than surface observations and some pop psychology.  True, when Adam is trying hard to validate his impersonation of a transsexual, he does some online "research" that allows Ms. Schrag to fill some pages with facts and definitions and explanations about such matters as "top surgery," "bottom surgery," "T" and other details of the transformative processes and experiences of her characters.  But beyond some fairly bald and simple "explanations" of how and why her characters are living as they do, we find little insight and little beyond some formulaic plot turns to get us through to the entirely predictable ending.Many will find this novel entertaining, perhaps, or even revelatory if they have no prior knowledge of the inner lives and behavior of the characters portrayed.  But finally, the plot is too familiar and the characters and details hung on its somewhat frayed line are not enough to rescue the book.

Any translation of one of the Homeric epics is a massive undertaking, presumably attempted only by scholar/poets who revere and love the work and feel moved to make it available (as the translator experiences it) to readers unable to read the original Greek.  Whether by Chapman, Pope, Rieu, Lattimore, Fitzgerald, Fagles, or any of the several more recent authors, such work must at least be given the respect due to serious effort in pursuit of a noble goal.  Emeritus Professor of Classics, Barry B. Powell, now offers his translation of the Odyssey (which was preceded by his Iliad), and it comes to us with a variety of attractions:  helpful explanatory footnotes with definitions or convenient identifications of unfamiliar names; reproductions of classical art works--paintings, decorated pottery--to exemplify and make concrete the imagery of the poem; useful maps and an informative introduction.  All these commend the volume to the student or novice reader of the epics, and certainly they are welcome.The translation itself is another matter.  Homer's poetry is notoriously "beautiful" and notoriously "untranslatable," especially into English, since the prosody of the Greek poem is not easily imitated in English--long lines tend to feel either cumbersome or broken-backed in English, and they often plod, especially when the vocabulary and syntax try to reproduce the original phrase by phrase.  Does Powell do this?  Yes and no.  His work is loosely called "free verse," which is to say that his line lengths vary quite a bit, but tend toward length--12 to 15 or even more syllables per line, with usually, as he tells us, five stresses per line.  He also states freely that "I hope to convey the sense of each word and phrase in the Greek, without prettifying or embellishing.  I am not concerned with sounding 'poetic' or beautiful or clever, because that would be to falsify the plain style of the original Greek."  He follows this stated principle, and so we readers can feel confident that he has made at least an honest effort at giving us an "accurate" translation, as near as possible in sense, if not in sound, to Homer's original.
