The result is, unfortunately, many lines that creep across the page, flatfooted or lame, and though every translation I have read (those mentioned above and a few more) has suffered at some point from those ills, I have to say that this one has more flat and more stumble than most.  There is very little sense of the beauty of Homer (which, for what it is worth, I do find in both Fitzgerald and Fagles, and most certainly at many points in Chapman and Pope), though we do find a story told well, if in somewhat plodding language and at a pace that will leave many modern readers wondering what all the fuss is about this ancient epic.I can imagine that this translation would make a good textbook for undergraduate introduction to the work as an important monument of western civilization.  I wish I could offer more praise, but it is just not a version that I would pick up if I wanted to read and remind myself of the power and beauty of Homer's works.  There is always something to gain in publishing a new translation--opportunities for new insights or transformed aesthetic experiences, but in this case, I cannot see any reason to prefer this over any of the earlier outstanding offerings.

At almost every point of Francine Prose's ambitious narrative, there is something interesting to encounter, almost always the realization of one's hope that there will be more learned about the characters she portrays.  Prose manages impressively to "present" a number of disparate characters, using letters home, an autobiographical memoir, a biography written by an uncertain and self-critical author, a written record of the life of one who asserts that her documentation of herself must be destroyed at her death, though it obviously has not been, and the self-revealing essays of an American expatriate describing his life in Paris during the 1930s. There are also chapters of third-person narrative, though they have no greater "authority" nor credibility than the first-person or derived narratives of the others.  The voices are distinctive, so that we feel we are in the presence of several different persons and we experience the sometimes sharp differences in their understandings of their overlapping experiences.Some of the characters are readily recognizable as based on known figures from the period:  Lionel Maine is surely a portrait of Henry Miller; Gabor Tsenyi has several clear connections with the great photographer, Andre Kertesz, and others (Lily de Rossignol, Yvonne, and others) can also probably be traced to known "originals," though that is finally not a satisfying exercise.The narrative begins with a letter from Gabor Tsenyi to his parents and that launches us into the Paris of 1932, especially the sometimes louche, sometimes criminal, but also fascinating and seductive underworld of the Chameleon Club (and related venues), where men and women may go to live their social lives according to their self-chosen genders, cross-dressing if wished for, romancing persons of their own or indeterminate gender, and so on.  The entertainment at the club is full of the purposeful transgressive and satiric songs, dances, skits, even acrobatic performances that reflect the preferences and wishes of the patrons.  And of course, some patrons are only there to observe the oddities (from their perspective) of the regulars.  All this shows us that the novel is both constructed of multiple perspectives--the same events and experiences seen/felt through the eyes of very different participants, and also it is very much about those multiplicities.At the heart of the narrative is a woman, Louisianne Villars (or just Lou), who prefers to dress as a man, who pursues a career as a auto racing driver at a time when women are either excluded from, or confined to roles as curiosities, in the international racing world she wants to dominate.  But the more extended and disturbing development in her life--the question that seems to drive her biographer, Nathalie Dunois, to write is how such a woman could have become not just a Nazi collaborator, but a passionate devotee of Adolph Hitler and an active participant in the torture of French citizens active in the Resistance by the SS.  It's a daring effort on Prose's part to portray in sympathetic terms a character who becomes a moral monster yet retains the readers' interest and some degree of sympathy.  Prose does this, in part, by creating a complex shield between herself and Lou, in the person of Nathalie Dunois, the biographer who cannot resist putting herself prominently into the story of the woman whose life she has researched and is dedicated to explaining through the biography she attempts to write.  I say "attempts," because we are reminded that she recognizes her own failure, and at the same time, we see that the failure is, perhaps, a kind of authorial complicity.  By putting Dunois between herself and Lou, at least fictionally, Prose avoids the problem of eliciting the readers' condemnation for treating a dedicated Nazi with sympathy.  (Jonathan Littell works mightily toward the same end in his magnificent Les Bienveillantes, a novel that presents the first-person narrative of a high-level SS officer.)  While the goal seems to be to show how a "normal" person could be drawn into the Nazi worldview, and the portrayal of that process is certainly convincing up to a point, it is not clear to me that we have any deeper understanding of Lou as a Nazi once we have read the novel.The other characters, the Baroness and her homosexual husband, the Hungarian photographer and his devoted French wife, the American writer, the Chameleon Club owner, and several others provide interesting variations on our sense of what is going on and how the period from 1932 to the invasion of France by the German armies and beyond has affected the lives of Parisians and French citizens in general.  It is a period in modern history that has been written about extensively, both in recent memoirs and in a number of important fiction works of recent times.  Francine Prose provides insights and dramatic interactions that often seem to extend our understanding of the period and the actors in it, but at about two-thirds of the way through the novel, I found myself being disappointed and even distracted--as though the work had lost momentum and fallen into unnecessary repetition or even excess elaboration.  Of course, the relationships are complicated, the social and political (and military) conflicts are complex, and so much needed to be explored and possibly made explicit.  Nonetheless, as my title for this review indicates. I came away feeling that some judicious editing would have helped to strengthen the overall impact of the work.  It is ambitious and it is in many ways fine, but just a shade too long for its own good.

I have a few areas around the house and yard that I have wished could besquirrel-free, gopher-free, and snake-free, and I thought this product mighthelp.  It's too early in the spring to have much to do with the snakes (I don't wantto eliminate them, just discourage them from setting up housekeeping on myfront porch), but the gopher(s) do seem to have moved along since I sprayedtheir main area (at least, where I know they have been), but I have no ideahow long the discouragement will last.  The squirrels seem to be, as usual,immune to all efforts, and I am not surprised at that.  ON the whole, this seemsto be a good product and, I have to say, one of the best characteristics of itis that it does not produce the choking and unlivable stench that two otherproducts unleashed when I tried to use them last year.  It is not scentless, butwhat it produces is mild and bearable.  On the whole, tentatively, I recommend it.

Having greatly admired and enjoyed several of Jean Echenoz's novels (1914, Running, Ravel, especially), I approached Je M'en Vais with high expectations.  I cannot say that I was disappointed, but neither was I impressed.  The novel is entertaining and very cleverly crafted, certainly indicative of the skilful and disciplined methods Echenoz has offered in his other fictions.  But where the other three I have mentioned have all been deeply serious, Je M'en Vais is much more an entertainment--a light and often funny crime caper novel, with ironic twists and characters that require little profundity in the writing (as is found, certainly, in the three others mentioned).  It is as though Echenoz set out to show that he could write a very good example of genre fiction, with suspense, a cold and calculating murderous villain, and he could combine that with some sharply observed satire of the pretensions and falsity of the contemporary art market--perhaps internationally, but certainly in Paris.The central character, Ferrer, is the owner of a fashionable art gallery in Paris; he caters to wealthy collectors, regularly seeking the new "hot" artists and sponsoring their works, promoting their reputations while profiting from the eagerness of his regular customers to purchase good examples of the latest "big thing" in contemporary art.  Ferrer is not merely a cynical profiteer, however; he actually cares about art and does make an effort to find work that is not merely chic and exploitative.  He has no interest in cheating his customers, but he is well aware that the tides of fashion have little to do with artistic merit and much to do with the eagerness of some who can afford it to be in on the latest popular trend.The novel begins with its title:  that is, Ferrer says in the opening sentence, "Je m'en vais" as he collects his suitcase and belongings on the way out the door, telling his wife "Je te quitte; je te laisse tout mais je pars."  And he goes. It does not take long to discover that this Ferrer is not going to be without female companionship for long--in fact, he is a relentless chaser and seducer, always on the lookout for an available woman who fits his preferences.  So his departure from his wife sets up a sequence of encounters of varying degrees of success with other women. Not long after, we learn that his gallery is having cash flow problems and his business has been off, so that he needs a quick financial boost, but has no luck dealing with banks, none of whose financial officers care to advance him the needed loans.  Next (all this is early in the novel), he learns of a possible cache of valuable native American artworks, stranded in a derelict ship iced in near the North Pole, and the "caper" aspect of the novel moves into full swing.  He makes the trip, arduous and dangerous, to the North Pole, finds the ship (this is still early in the novel), and the reader will surely anticipate that there is, really must be, a plot afoot to deprive him of his financial cushion--surely when he returns, the precious artifacts will be stolen.The second main character in the novel is Baumgartner, cold, clever, obsessive, elegant and ruthless, and determined to have the artifacts Ferrer has gone to such trouble to acquire and smuggle back into France.  And that is as much of the story as one is willing to tell--the thriller, complete with mysterious women and cold-blooded killing--moves rapidly to its conclusion.The satiric scenes that punctuate the thriller segments are all based at the gallery or in the company of artists and art customers.  The pretensions and delusions of the artists are carefully manipulated by Ferrer and his assistants and the scenes of their conflicts and negotiations, as well as those of Ferrer persuading his wealthy customers of the desirability of the art he has for sale, are genuinely funny.This, then, is a neatly composed and elegant example of the kind of artistry it satirizes--fashionable, consistent with popular taste, but created with the highest level of craft and fashion consciousness.  And it is good fun, though not a candidate for the upper level of Echenoz's canon.

"Hide long enough from your fear,/Mother said,/and you too disappear."The above sentence may or may not be the central idea around which much of this "novel in verse" might be said to revolve, but it's a good candidate.  The narrator and main character, Henryk, has many reasons to want to be invisible or to disappear, and for the most part, those involve his retreat from what he fears.  In the "present" of the novel (which is 1968) he fears induction and shipment to Vietnam; in the earlier periods of his life that he invokes as he shifts backward in time to his early childhood in Poland (1941) through his adolescent years in Chicago and his later graduate program (seeking an MA in philosophy with a thesis on the thought of Ludwig Wittgenstein) to a series of part-time jobs (taxi driver, maintainer of vending machines, teacher of English as a second language) until he reaches the basement of the California Department of Social Services building in San Francisco, where he has become the Head Clerk of Closed Files, working in a subterranean environment that qualifies him as a cross between "underground man" and Kafka-like bureaucrat, he experiences many kinds of fear.About that childhood in Poland:  Henryk as a child lives in Jedwabne, site of one of the more horrific pogroms during the Nazi occupation of the area.  Henryk's Polish mother attempts to hide and rescue some of their Jewish neighbors, concealing them in a hole under the stalls in their barn; Henryk, as a small child, witnesses atrocities against his neighbors, knowing that the Polish townspeople had herded the Jewish citizens of the town into a barn which they then set on fire, incinerating hundreds.  And more.  In the course of this novel, the adult Henryk attempts to translate into English the volumes of his mother's eyewitness descriptions of the atrocities kept in diary form and carried along on their flight from Poland.  These provide, one might say, one extremely violent and horrific "bookend" for the chronology of the novel, the other end being Henryk's perceptions of the Vietnam war which he hopes to avoid, though he has no way of evading the violence of our society at the time and is unable to forget or cut loose "from a vast personal history/of defeat and occupation,/of anger and despair,/among other things."Along with the war, 1968 was the time of assassinations (RFK, MLK, among others) and, in San Francisco, the rampage of the Zodiac killer, as well as the widening "movement" of resistance, rebellion, rejection of mid-American manners and values and violent backlash against the resisters.  And along with the violence that swirls around him, Henryk must deal with his memory of his own inadvertent killing of his best friend – a killing for which he was absolved of guilt or legal responsibility, but for which he cannot forgive himself and certainly he cannot forget.This is a novel, then, that explores the mystery of human violence and hatred by forcing attention to particularly egregious examples of it, instances that cannot be explained or justified by any of the usual analytical, statistical, ethical or philosophical methods one might use in discussing them.  Whether it is the ringleaders of the Jedwabne pogrom, the individual demented killer who taunts the authorities with his riddling letters invoking astrology, or the "best and the brightest" insisting on the need to rain napalm on Vietnamese peasants who have no ships, no planes, no prospect of invading the United States, but must be defined as threats to US national security, Henryk tries to understand, using narration and observation as the only tools at his disposal, though often, he harks back to his study of Wittgenstein, who appears regularly as "Ludwig":  "'What does it mean to know who is in pain?'/Ludwig asked himself./What criteria determines what can be tolerated/in any one place and time?"  Trying to confront these kinds of questions, Henryk mixes his past, his present, and "awakened/at four in the morning/by my radio screeching a cabbie/was found in the Oakland Hills,/shot straight through the back of his head,/I finally understood such sundry vulgarities/as the Tet Offensive, Sleszynski's barn" and other atrocities.There is more to the story, of course; Henryk's sexual liaisons with the wife of his thesis adviser, Betty, and with the "free spirit" Heddie, his encounters with veterans of Vietnam in his English language class, his exploration of the remains in and around the Clerk's office of his predecessor's work.  All of these and the nature of his final job, itself, filing away the documents and evidence of appeals from desperate (or fraudulent) applicants for social welfare funds, in effect, disappearing their memories by placement in closed files.  And always, we are aware of the title—"Wherewithal"—an odd word, referring in some contexts merely to financial stability – having the wherewithal to get by, or perhaps to get ahead, based on the ability to pay – but also metaphorically to mental capacity – having the wherewithal to understand a situation, to pursue a goal, to achieve or to surpass -- and we are reminded that Henryk is almost always financially distressed, and in his own mind, at least, almost always perplexed and inadequate when faced with even the more ordinary sources of embarrassment, humiliation, pain, or even positive experiences such as being desirable to a beautiful woman.The novel is divided into six segments, each one preceded with an illustration—one of the famous "Carceri" of Piranesi—elaborate imaginary prisons, vast and complex visions of multistory buildings with columns, many rooms and sub-rooms, dungeons and cells, torture machines and shackles.  In Henryk's office in the basement, there is a reproduction of one of these designs, tacked to the wall, and that prompts several specific references to Piranesi's imaginative projections of prison but possibly refuge.  Each of those six sections is further divided into sixteen parts.  Those parts shuffle chronology, so each section may have part of the mother's Jedwabne diary, part of the account of Henryk's accidental shooting of his beloved friend, Rossy, part of his description of his work as a cab driver in San Francisco, part of his experience refilling vending machines on the U.S.S. Constitution aircraft carrier, and so on.  These are not necessarily in chronological order, but there is no problem as a rule, in keeping track of the narrative.And of course, this is a poem.  We notice that the epigraph to this review, with its interpolated attribution ("Mother said") is split by slashes, indicating line divisions, indicating that this sentence is part of a poem. Other quotations in this review have had similar indications that the sentences are not continuous and the margins will not be justified on both sides.  As every page of Schultz's "novel in verse" reminds us, the experience of reading poetry is different in important ways from reading prose.  The supple and variable free verse of the work could probably be printed continuously, like prose, and readers would read it as prose, perhaps.  And what would be lost?  A great deal.The idea of a "novel" in verse has been with us on and off for centuries, preceded by the long narrative poems (epics, chansons de geste, Ovidian tales, and more).  It has had its moments of seeming popularity, as seems to be the case now, since a number of contemporary poets have offered novels (as well as memoirs, even biographies, and other nonfiction forms) written in verse, with varying degrees of success.  The success of Philip Schultz's novel is in its power, and that power rests comfortably in the verse form.We read poetry differently.  We read it more slowly in most cases; we pause with it; we are more aware of the language and punctuation, of the often multiple connections among words and phrases that would be obscured in a prose layout.  We may be more likely to notice repeated words or phrases that take on multiple connotations, or images that recur and become multivalent.  All this happens in this novel, to considerable effect.  And so, if there is sometimes a question as to whether there is an advantage or "value added" to a novel written in verse, the answer in this case is decidedly yes.  Schultz uses free verse most of the time, though there are some interpolated prose passages (the letters from the Zodiac killer, for example, and some news stories), and the verse is irregular but always has a noticeable rhythm and important shifts of emphasis where the emotional tone or temperature of the narrative benefits from them.Finally, however, it is the profundity of the material that has a great impact on the reader of this work. It is a brave writer who takes on the Holocaust, especially in first-person narrative, as he does with the mother's diaries; it is a challenge for any writer to take on the crosscurrents of the social and political upheavals created by resistance to the Vietnam war.  In a very different realm, creating a character who is obsessed with Ludwig Wittgenstein's ideas and finds many occasions to apply them—at least speculatively—to his own daily life (which is what Ludwig would have wanted, of course), is also a considerable challenge, and again, Schultz succeeds.The Wherewithal is complex, bringing together not only verse forms and novel forms, but  graphic art forms, and history (some still disputed), anthropology, philosophy, and more—all to set out without preaching or dogmatizing, the perplexing human experience of painfully familiar human behavior.  It's a powerful book and highly recommended.

It is dangerous to use the word "facile" in connection with a writer's work unless one really wants to denigrate that work, and that is not my intention here.  Peter Ackroyd has a long career as a writer of fiction and non-fiction.  His novels are set in London in various periods of the city's history; they are carefully researched so as to re-create the layout of the city, its atmosphere and customs in the period set; Hawksmoor, Chatterton, The Lambs of London are particularly good examples.  He has also written readable and respectable biographies of London literary figures, including Chaucer and Shakespeare and William Blake, as well as Isaac Newton.  Both the novels and the non-fiction works are of uneven quality (The House of Dr. Dee, for example, is a disappointment by any standard, and the biography of Blake, though readable, is not to be recommended for accuracy).  But always, and here comes that word again, Ackroyd makes the job of writing the work look easy, even though none of these can have been easy to write.  His prose style is smooth and nicely adapted (by vocabulary and syntax and rhetoric) to the periods portrayed, and his plots run smoothly.In these senses, Three Brothers: A Novel qualifies as "facile"--the plot is neatly constructed so that the fortuitous intersections of the lives of the major characters seem both inevitable and predictable, without undermining the pleasure of the narrative.  What seems easy, that is to say, need not be considered inferior.  The three brothers--left by a disappearing mother to be brought up by a near-absentee father--emerge in London in the late 1960s to develop quite separate lives in different "levels" of London life: the eldest, Harry, moves from being an errand boy in a newspaper office quickly up through a reporter's status to editor in chief and moving toward editor/publisher.  Daniel, one year younger, by dint of serious, even obsessive study and self-discipline, manages to find a place at Cambridge University while living the life of a closeted and desperate homosexual in a time when his personality would have been considered criminal and subject to many dangers.  The third, by far the most interesting, is the youngest, Sam, a kind of "holy fool," in an almost Dostoevskian mold (think Prince Myshkin and Alyosha Karamazov), a child-man whom some women and some men feel moved to adopt and protect, a near-mystic who finds refuge in half-understood religion and who behaves with greater charity and kindness toward others (or at least, he thinks and wishes he should and could so act, when sometimes prevented by circumstances from doing so) than do most who have public or professional "roles" that are assumed to be directed toward helping their fellow human citizens of London.These three are all, in various ways, affected by the presence--invisible to them, though they are not invisible to her--of their disappeared mother, who is, in various ways, linked to people who are directly involved with her sons.  Their fates are all worked out, again with seeming facility, with results growing from their connections to her.There are also several other female characters, including Harry's mother-in-law and his wife, as well as a somewhat mysterious nun, and others, but the focus of the novel is directly on the brothers and a few other men who are either involved in a business way with Harry or in a romantic way with Daniel, or as possible destroyers of the innocent Sam.And so, like most of Ackroyd's novels, this is an enjoyable read--patterned in a satisfying way, informative about some odd bits of history of London, evocative of sympathy where merited.  It is not a profound novel, but it would be unfair to dismiss it for that.  It has no ambition to profundity, but it has something serious to say, and it says it in the course of entertaining us.  (One might say, for example, that Eleanor Catton's much admired Booker winning novel, The Luminaries, is more ambitious and more effortful only in that it is so many times longer, and it is similarly entertaining and evocative, but hardly profound at all, and that is not intended to be a negative statement. Ackroyd's novel has similar virtues, but in far fewer pages and with fewer characters to keep track of.)  It is probably worth more than three stars, but not so many as four, which is about what I would award to most of Ackroyd's work--maybe excepting Hawksmoor and Chatterton.

Edward Hirsch has offered a one-man version of the venerable Princeton Encyclopedia of Poetry and Poetics, now in its fourth edition, and for many, perhaps most, readers, Hirsch has made an offer we should not refuse.  I have valued the Princeton volume since it was first published.  It is packed with information about all aspects of prosody, poetic traditions in English as well as most of the other languages of the world.  It has the scholarly authority and gravitas not only of its publisher but of the crowd of scholars and critics who supplied the individual encyclopedic entries.  One would not want to discard it, but for the pleasure of reading and thinking about poetry, the lively, more personal, and generally more engaging volume Hirsch has produced would probably be the choice of most readers.  For quick reference and information, the Princeton volume is valuable; for the fun of reading about one's favorite topics, Hirsch is both dependable and a fine entertainer.As the book's title suggests, this is a "glossary," a vast collection of terms and labels and concepts, organized alphabetically from "abecedarian" to--700 pages later--"zeugma," with hundreds of entries informing us of the shapes and backgrounds of obscure poetic forms in Sanskrit, Arabic, French, Yoruba, Japanese,  indeed most of the languages in which poetry can be known.  Whether one needs to know the meaning of "qasida" or "reverdie," "ekthesis" or "cynghanedd," Hirsch offers etymologies, contexts, sometimes examples, always in a genial and understated manner.  The pleasure of browsing the book is finding unfamiliar but always fascinating new terms, many from non-anglophone traditions (the Afghan traditional form, "landay," has recently become familiar thanks to Poetry (Chicago), and Hirsch provides helpful background); anyone who cares about poetry at all will want to add these new concepts to her or his memory bank, while seeking out more examples where possible.Hirsch also, of course, provides definitions and details about the more familiar terms and practices of the Anglo/American and European traditions:  scansion, verse forms, schools, movements, revolutions and fads.  Typical of Hirsch's charm and restraint is the big one--his "definition of "POETRY"--where he essentially adheres to the tradition that poetry is the use of language that we cannot define, though we know it when it hits us--"an inexplicable (though not incomprehensible) event in language"--and he then goes on to offer quotations and paraphrases of variations on the same "definition" from a couple of dozen poets ranging across many centuries and traditions.  The modest and yet dependably well-informed tone and procedure of the many entries reassure the reader while maintaining an inviting and enjoyable reading experience.Most of us do not, of course, read a reference book--especially not one half seriously described as "having something of the madness of a Borgesian encyclopedia--from cover to cover.  It is a book to be sampled, though it is likely that most readers will be drawn to do just what I did when I first opened it--start reading here, turn to there and there and more and more beyond--"what does he say about scansion? what does he think of L=A=N=G=U=A=G=E poets? is there an entry for "dissociation of sensiblity? (yes) or "poetry slam" (yes), and so on.  It was easy to spend a good part of an afternoon and then an evening just flipping back and forth in the book, cross-referencing or just randomly fishing for eye-catching words.  At the same time, it is certainly useful for people who just want to find a quick definition of a term of art related to an art form they care little about (but for that, of course, the internet offers even quicker, though usually less valuable, definitions).Other poets have offered poetry dictionaries, collections of terms, guidebooks, and those by John Hollander and John Ciardi, Paul Fussell and Mary Oliver and other venerables will remain useful and helpful, but Edward Hirsch, respected poet and scholar himself, has added a more comprehensive, more engaging work that all lovers of poetry will find valuable.

Scholars of literary modernism, of twentieth century American literature, of Paris in the Twenties, and some other specialties will have many reasons for reading this book.  In one sense, they are the proper reviewers of it, since it is a meticulously edited scholarly edition of the letters of Ernest Hemingway written during a brief but extremely important period of time, from 1923 to 1925, important both in Hemingway's development (he was writing some of his most important fiction, including The Sun Also Rises), and in the history of literary modernism.  Hemingway's friends and associates--Ezra Pound, William Carlos Williams, F. Scott Fitzgerald, Gertrude Stein, Robert McAlmon, Sylvia Beach, and many others are central to the literary developments of that period, and there are letters from Hemingway to those friends, mostly worth reading.  The scholars will find the work to be a valuable addition to the Hemingway record, or they will judge it from their positions of authority for the quality of its editing and presentation.For the rest of us, for those who are Hemingway fans or just admirers of some of his fiction, but not professionals, the interest is nonetheless pervasive in the collection, and the editors have made it all wonderfully accessible by providing careful annotation, informing us of the identities and relevance of many obscure and some famous persons, the locations and qualities of many places, even the meaning of some of Hemingway's playful slang and neologisms.  (It's a comfort, for example, to find a note explaining his sentence to Ezra Pound":  "It was good to lamp the underwooding again.  I thought you were offa me."  The editors remind us of that brand of typewriter.)  That kind of scholarly detective work is what we may all be grateful for, even as we wonder whether Hemingway might have been spending time with James Joyce.For many readers, an interest in biographical details or, especially, the kinds of trivia that fill many (though definitely not all) pages of personal letters is considered trivial, maybe evidence of celebrity worship replacing serious literary experiences.  To some extent, this can be true--knowing how Hemingway reacted to his first bullfight in Spain is interesting, but should not replace the experience of reading his fiction and nonfiction accounts of bullfights, nor should one assume that one understands the fiction better from reading such letters.  But they are not entirely ephemeral or worthless.  For one thing, the evidence of the author's style as it develops in these informal writings may provide a sharper insight into her or his artistry; the emotional reactions to lived experiences may suggest motives for fictional re-creations of those experiences, and so on.  So long as one does not assume the letters "explain" the literary works, one can find interest and even some insights into the author's character and creative processes.  Certainly these letters are no substitute for Hemingway's fiction (though a few are much more enjoyable reading than his lesser self-parodying works); this volume, in particular, must be especially interesting because of the crucial time period it covers.  Even one who does not value Hemingway's fiction may find interest in the insights into his friends, his associates, his rivals and enemies, his milieu during one of the most important periods in modern literary history.

Readers familiar with Peter Matthiessen's earlier novels will find some qualities that they already value, but in many ways this is a new direction for Matthiessen, an uncompromising and occasionally fierce exploration of the ways human evil flourishes, as well as the bewilderment, even despair, those who try to oppose evil may experience at their repeated failures.  Matthiessen quotes a poem by Anna Akhmatova as an epigraph--it begins "Everything is plundered, betrayed, sold,/Death's black wing scrapes the air," and that is fair warning.  A visit to Auschwitz--the most notorious in some ways of the Nazi death camps--is not an opportunity to salve one's personal guilt, nor to plump up one's easy conscience and self-esteem, as the central character, Prof. Clements Olin, discovers, to his pain but also, perhaps, toward his enlightenment.There is nothing simple about this narrative, though the situation can sound simple:  Prof. Olin, a student of modern Slavic literature with a special interest in the works that emerged from the Holocaust, arrives in Poland on his way to Auschwitz, where he is to join (more as an observer than participant, or so he thinks) an ecumenical religious group planning to spend days on the selection ramp, meditating and witnessing on behalf of the murdered millions.  Olin (whose family name has a history as that of an aristocratic family, Olinsky, who held property in the vicinity of Oswiecim) is also, secretly, in search of information about his mother, who did not leave for America when Olin's father and grandparents fled.Olin encounters a wide variety of people--a "Nordic-Jew" as his roommate; a group of Zen meditators; Jewish groups from Israel and America, German descendants of SS officers, a Polish priest, a pair of novices aspiring to be nuns, a defrocked monk, and more.  The uneasy interactions among these disparate people, occasionally bursting into heated argument as their stereotypic assumptions and prejudices emerge to contradict the official reasons for their presence--to atone for the sins of the Holocaust and to forge unity among the various religious and social views they bring with them.  In the cold and oppressive environment of the remains of the death camp, the psychological impact of the memories--both stimulated by documentary films and museum exhibits and also evoked by the feelings of the "presence" of the millions of dead--is heavy and unsettling.  Olin, who expects to be engaged at a scholarly or academic level, even in approaching his search for evidence of his mother's fate, undergoes strong challenges to his sense of his self--more than just "identity crisis," the near collapse of his sense of who he is and why he continues to live.Matthiessen has presented intense and powerful characters in earlier works--Far Tortuga, Killing Mr. Watson, especially--but here he is probing deeper and more painfully into the fundamental questions of the relation between our "selves" and our responsibility for behavior--both our own behavior and that which we witness and either condone or try to ignore or, under some circumstances, stand up, oppose, resist, even attempt to prevent or stop altogether.  Part of the testing of those human characteristics in this novel comes from the presence of a Mr. G. Earwig (an assumed name, of course) who purposely separates himself from all the others, mocking, reprimanding, denouncing, deeply insulting the others, calling into question all of their values and characters and assumptions.  He is, in this way, a person in the mold of Thersites, the mocking cynic and nihilist who appears in Homer's Iliad, but also, even more destructively, in Shakespeare's Troilus and Cressida.  He becomes the dark side of Olin as the narrative progresses, and his presence, and then his life story (which may or may not be true) serve as catalysts for Olin's own crisis of identity.There are other elements of Olin's story that are better left for the reader to discover.  But as my title for this review indicates, there are no easy ways out of the moral challenges and dilemmas these characters face, and no simple resolution.  This novel leaves this reader shaken and impressed.  Yes, some parts of it are open to question or criticism, but the quibbles are unworthy of mention.  Yes, Olin himself reminds us that many have felt that there is an impropriety, an inauthenticity, even an outright dishonesty in writing about the Holocaust by anyone who did not experience and survive it.  From that perspective, all others should be silent.  But Matthiessen makes a powerful case for the honest and wrenching effort to confront that history, even as one who comes at it from a position of privileged distance, comfort, abstraction and analysis.  Certainly this is a novel worth reading, and more than once.

Teju Cole's Every Day is For the Thief is the kind of book that reminds the reader of the comforts provided by awareness of genre.  It is much easier to discuss a book if one knows what kind of book it is--a novel, a memoir, an autobiography, a travel narrative, a collection of essays.  All those are possibilities in this case, and in some ways one might consider that the indeterminacy of the work's generic identity might qualify as an interesting challenge, even an advantage--some might claim that it is an adventurous effort to blur generic conventions, to reject the cliches of narratives about young men returning home after some years away in a very different cultural environment.  That--the return home--is on one level exactly the kind of narrative we find, when we find narrative, in this book.We also find in -- or on -- this book, the assertion that it is "a work of fiction," with the usual assertion that any resemblance to real persons or places is purely coincidental.  We are also assured, in promotional information included by the publisher, that the author's earlier book, Open City, received high praise, nominations, and prizes as an excellent "novel."  But at no point do we see this book referred to as a novel--though we are assured that it is a fictional narrative.I make these points because I have had to struggle with my impatience and disdain, my outright annoyance, with the way this book proceeds.  I know that Teju Cole has published essays, including travel essays, because I have encountered some of them in periodical publications.  If I were to say, therefore, that this book consists of a number of essays more or less pasted or stitched together, each of them expressing the author's responses to the changes in his native country--especially the city of Lagos, Nigeria, on his return to that place after fifteen years (or whatever period actually may have passed), and that those essays are written in a bland, cliched, and surprisingly voiceless prose, with details repeated for no apparent reason, I think the description would not be totally unfair, though it would be admittedly somewhat reductive.Consider this chapter opening:  "One sign of the newly vital Nigerian economy and one of the most apparent, is the proliferation of Internet cafes.  There had been none when I left home.  Now there are several in every neighborhood and there must be hundreds in Lagos alone.  The Internet cafe is symbolic of a connection to goings-on in the larger world, an end to Nigeria's isolation."Or this:  "The proliferation of new eateries designed on the American fast-food model surprises me.  When I left in the early nineties there was just one, Mr. Bigg's.  Now there are several, many of them operating on the franchise system, in every neighborhood of the city."  And so on.Yes, in the chapters following these openings, we are give interesting descriptions.  In the first, we learn that the famous e-mails from Nigeria, offering us the opportunity to receive a fortune from a deposed general if we will send his widow a sum of money (or many variations on that), are actually being produced by young men working frantically in the internet cafes the narrator mentions.  In the second, we learn that the system of franchised fast-food restaurants has grown, but not according to the expectations we might have of McDonald's or Burger King--in fact, the narrator goes out to one to have his favorite meal of "peppered snails and stewed spinach with peppercorns"--a meal I would be interested to try myself.  The problem here, however, is that these chapters, and those describing the narrator's visits to the National Museum, to a privately funded music conservatory, and even to the homes of old friends, are all told in a style consistent with travel essays we might expect to encounter in the Sunday NY Times Magazine or some glossy magazine devoted to interesting new places to visit.Even the descriptions of the perils of not knowing the local assumptions about giving bribes to almost anyone who stops one and indicates the expectation of "payment" for nothing but permission to continue where one is going, or the accounts of the epidemic of home invasions and burglaries, or the horrific descriptions of the effects of belief in various kinds of witchcraft or spirit possession, all tend to read like the observations of a nonfiction writer, intent on picking up the "vibrant" local details and behaviors for the sake of the reader who might want to be "in the know" about what to avoid on the streets or in the markets of Lagos.  In other words, by far the majority of pages of this "fiction" read like the work of a modestly talented travel reporter.The narrator of this "fiction" is a young man who had left his home in Lagos after a number of conflicts with his family and the failure of his expectations about his future in Nigeria.  He has lived in the U.S. for a number of years.  He wonders what he will find; he thinks about the ways his expected encounters with old familiar places are disappointed; he marvels at the increase in corruption--the incessant demands for money from every petty official, policeman, even casual passerby, the assumption that all business will be conducted with only the immediate profit of the seller or contractor in mind, with no expectation that the customer will receive or be satisfied with what he or she has paid for, and no recourse, since complaints to police or other officials will be met with further demands for money under the table or behind the back.  He is both impressed and appalled by the changes he encounters.This nameless narrator also gives us some glimpses into family life through encounters with his aunts and uncles, nephews and nieces, with some old friends.  These narratives have more of the feel of a novel, and one might want in fairness to conclude that they do provide enough fictive context to frame the obviously nonfiction writing as part of the narrator's responses.  But really, nothing helps.  This is not a novel, not a collection of short stories, not a memoir; it is a collection of fairly interesting essays about the situation in Nigeria in the early 21st century.  Cole could have (perhaps did) publish them separately in any number of periodicals, "spicing" them with his fairly frequent, but not very useful, allusions to writers he admires--Michael Ondaatje, Gabriel Garcia Marquez, others.  But he has not done the work of a fiction writer, he has not produced a novel nor, I would argue, even a hybrid form that would qualify as experimental.  I find this book to lack literary value, though it has some interesting anecdotes and some entertainment value.  But the voice of the narrator--listless and confused--is all too appropriate to this poorly conceived work.  I do not recommend it.

In the second section of Virginia Woolf's To the Lighthouse, she narrates the passage of a number of years in a relatively brief few pages, describing in precise and evocative detail both the persistence through time and the changes through time that happen in and around the summer house that had been the location of the opening section.  Among the details about the house, which becomes the central character in that section, Woolf drops bits of information about the lives of the human characters who had inhabited the house during section one, some of whom would return in section three.  The account of the passage of time, as symbolized by the changes in the house, is poetic, powerful, disturbing.In chapter three of John Steinbeck's The Grapes of Wrath, he describes, with the feeling of an epic journey, the effort of a large turtle to cross a hot dusty highway.  This memorable description stays with the reader throughout the novel, and is enhanced by other interpolated chapters, not all similar, but all designed to convey a sense of both the permanence of the natural world and the fragility, the brief temporality, of physical objects—especially human beings--in that world.  The turtle's journey is a straightforward metaphor for the  trials of the Joad family on their trip from Oklahoma to California.I mention these familiar narrative strategies--many other writers have used variant versions to create a sense of continuity or to assert a kind of universality--because we find similar gestures in Jenny Erpenbeck's brilliant novella, Visitation.  Interestingly, she opens the story with a brief "Prologue," printed in italic in the edition I have read, describing the passage of "approximately twenty-four thousand years" in the area immediately adjacent to the house that will become her version of that house belonging to the Ramsey family in Woolf's novel.  Erpenbeck wants us to be aware of the very large and long "history" affecting the space surrounding the vacation home that is the location of her extended narrative.  She opens with a condensed anthropology of the lives and customs of the people who live in the immediate area, describing superstitions and rituals of birth, growth to maturity, marriage, death and burial.  From there, we have the context for the coming stories of the owners, lessors, inheritors, visitors and vacation renters, who will inhabit the house during a period of years.First, however, we meet "The Gardener," a man whom almost no one knows:  "No one in the village knows where he comes from."  But many become aware of his presence, of the work he does, of the support he provides the inhabitants of the vacation house--indeed, of his essential contributions to keeping the house in repair, the grounds and accessories to it well groomed and functional, the trees growing, pruned, cut down and chopped up for firewood when necessary, and so on.  The gardener is the permanent, persistent presence, providing continuity and a degree of memory.  He knows what needs to be done to keep the house going and he does those things, without complaint, nearly without compensation; "he lives alone in an abandoned hunting lodge at the edge of the woods, he has always lived there," where he is a familiar sight and presence and source of help and information, but no one knows his name.  He is, for this novel, the metaphor taking the role of Steinbeck's turtle.  He appears in short chapters between the longer chapters devoted to the people who come to live (for varying lengths of time) in the house he maintains.  Erpenbeck uses repetition--subtly varied descriptions of his work with the grounds, the woods, the crops, the dock on the lake, and so on--to emphasize both the continuity and the subtle but inevitable forces of change.As we read, we become aware that the narrative has settled in time of war--specifically of the period leading up to the Second World War and through it; allusions to the changing fortunes of the people (some of them Jewish, others not, and so not in the same jeopardy) who have owned and used the vacation house; we learn indirectly or by allusion of their fates--being herded into cattle cars and sent to final destinations, and so on.  The pain--and there is great pain in this novel--is that we know that we already know what has happened, what will happen, to so many of these people, and we know the guilt that may or may not be consciously present in the minds of some of the other people, the responsibilities acknowledged or ignored.  We have lived with these images so that we don't even need to have them presented explicitly--passing references to tiny details are enough to trigger what we have always already known because we are creatures of the twentieth century, with all its horrors.  Perhaps this novel will require notes and explication in the future, for readers who have never experienced the particulars of this history, but for now, the impact on memory and on conscience cannot be ignored.Jenny Erpenbeck's skillful deployment of these literary devices--metaphor, allusion, evocation of small details that combine to contribute a sense of inevitability as well as continuity, the exercise of what might be called institutional memory--is comparable to the enormous power of her narration in The Book of Words, a novella that feels more like a fable, in part because the central consciousness of it is a child (or a woman reconstructing her sense of the world when she was a child), and so works even more by hints, allusive details, clues, and abstractions that allow us to generalize from the situation of that child to larger historical contexts.  Visitation is, I think, marginally less powerful than The Book of Words--more dependent on familiar sentiments, even certain cliches of fictive narrative, but the margin is so small as to be unworthy of much attention.  This is a powerful work by an author of extraordinary depth and compassion.  I am eager to read ever more of her fiction.

It's not a book review, nor is it really literary criticism.  Neither is it a straight memoir, though it is certainly close to that.  We have had a number of similar books recently--explorations of the relationship between a reader and a particular book.  Dawn Potter's wonderful Tracing Paradise: Two Years in Harmony With John Milton, which I reviewed here a few years ago, comes to mind.  (The "Harmony" of that title is the name of Potter's hometown, Harmony, Maine, by the way.)  Similar accounts--some only essay length, others as ambitious and detailed as Sarah Bakewell's How to Live:  A Life of Montaigne in Twenty Questions, which does for Montaigne's essays what Mead does for Middlemarch--makes it a book one immediately wants to sit down and read.  Rebecca Mead has lived with and valued George Eliot's Middlemarch since she was seventeen years old, rereading it, visiting the places associated with Eliot's life, and generally allowing herself to "live into" Eliot's world while exploring the ways that Eliot's masterpiece has helped to form herself and the world as she experiences it.Mead's book describes both her reading experiences and the ways they fit into (or interrupted) her own life, as well as her efforts to learn as much as possible about the life of Mary Ann Evans/George Eliot, at least as much as was in any way pertinent to Eliot's composition of Middlemarch.  Mead visits Eliot's notebook in the rare book collection of the New York Public Library, and many places in England associated with the life (daily life, especially) of the author.  In all these passages, Mead offers intelligent and empathetic links between Eliot's experiences and characters and events in the novel.  She does not suggest simplistic cause and effect relationships, but traces where possible analogies and inspirations, suggesting ways that they illuminate Eliot's purposes (not "intentions") in developing the novel as she did.We know that works of literature can have great impacts on readers--especially young readers.  John Keats's first encounter with George Chapman's translation of Homer's Iliad is immortalized in one of the best known poems in the English language.  Many other writers have provided testimonials to the power of a novel or drama or poem by writing introductions to new editions or essays that combine the deep observation of the significance of the work in itself with careful observation of the ways that work has influenced the writer.  Some of the greatest literary criticism is close to this kind of writing, but the recent examples of such memoirs have made a bid to establish it as a genre all its own.  Potter and Mead have offered splendid models of how such books may be written, and suggest that they can, by themselves, have much the same kind of impact as they are describing.  (Of course, and sadly, one might also suspect that they are appearing at this time--a time of concern among many over declining numbers of serious readers and the fear that such experiences will cease to be part of most people's lives.)This book has received much praise, with prominent reviews by famous reviewers (front page of the NY Times Book Review, written by Joyce Carol Oates, for example), and there is not a lot I could add to the praise it has already received, except to say that as one who spent 40 years teaching literature, and who always hoped that by sharing the wonder and enthusiasm and joy that great works such as Middlemarch have given me, I might encourage younger people to join me in the experience of reading.  Mead refers at the end of her work to "a landscape changed by books, reshaped by reading," and that is a fitting conclusion to her fine reconstruction of the life of Eliot though careful attention to Eliot's greatest work, always acknowledging that she has filtered all this through her own responses to that work--coming to us with honesty and clarity and offering the best she can--the invitation to join her in reading an unparalleled masterpiece of the human spirit and the writer's art. Anyone who loves reading will enjoy this vicarious tour; all may benefit from the wisdom Mead has gained from her reading and telling.

The world of The Book of Words is both a dreamworld of poetic fascination and a nightmare world that suddenly reveals itself as the narrator's attention shifts from, perhaps, a real present toward memories of a real but dreamlike past: "I  walk into my room and there she is standing at the window gazing at the mountain.  I see  Marie, and at the same time I  look right through her at the mountain, and the mountain, for which the window-frame was always too tight a fit, now has  plenty of room inside Marie's body. I pull a chair up the the table so she can sit down beside me, there's already a plate of cake there. Your housekeeper brought it for me, Marie says.  But eating isn't so easy for me anymore, she says, and only now, when she turns around, do I see she no longer has any hands, they've been cut off just above the wrist." The girl gazing out the window  at the mountain, the mountain seen through the girl, the mountain too large for the window but comfortably framed within the girl's body--a succession of images consistent with certain surrealist artists' practices, both in poetry and in visual representations, and then the conventional moment--polite chat about a plate of cake explodes into the horror of the girl's missing hands. We learn bits and pieces of the background of this story, scattered through the pages of fragmentary and disjointed memories, presented in a kind of stream-of-consciousness narrative that includes recurrent (some will say repetitive) phrases or whole sentences that crop up just as, in all our conscious self-narratives, certain images and ideas, words, phrases, pop up either as prompted by similar events or feelings, or seemingly inadvertently and out of place, but still comprehensible with some thought, maybe disturbingly tied to what otherwise seems an innocent or insignificant moment--making that moment humorous or portentous, grotesque, horrifying. The poetic power of this passage is characteristic of the experience of Jenny Erpenbeck's brilliant novella, which begins with the narrator telling us that her eyes "see but see nothing," her ears "hear but hear nothing," and she must struggle to deal with "all this strangeness in my head."  This narrator seems at first to be a troubled child ("Father and mother.  Ball.  Car.  These might be the only words that were still intact when I learned them"), but as we readers allow this voice to enter, we realize that she is a timeless, ageless consciousness, often a small child perceiving a father who is "a man who stays taller than you for a long time," but always a mind talking to itself, telling itself the kinds of stories that we all tell ourselves about ourselves, though most of us are fortunate not to share the kinds of details this mind has to integrate into her stories about her own past. Time passes as the narrative progresses, but it passes according to its own system of measurement, according to a calendar superposed to replace the "normal" calendar.  The dislocations and contradictions--we are never sure where we are, what country (though it seems to be somewhere in South America in a country in decline, governed by increasingly desperate and ruthless dictators, who appear as dinner guests of the narrator's parents or as statues in a park) or what time period.  These uncertainties contribute to the surreal and nightmarish qualities of the story which is told, however, in a nearly affectless tone by the voice who begins as a small girl, seems to mature to at least late adolescence, but who may be reconstituting her life story in this narrative from the perspective of an older woman attempting to understand the accumulated falsehoods and distortions--the betrayals of language and feeling and human decency--that make up her experiences during her childhood--experiences characterized by euphemisms and platitudes, easily seen through but hard to replace with any sense of clarity or understanding.  We readers recognize the hints about the actual circumstances in the narrator's city--the disappearances, the tortures, the drastic measures, the decline of all services and amenities, even of basic necessities, the ability of her parents to accumulate to themselves and in their household all the "fine things" that are taken from those who either do not need them any more, did not deserve them in the first place, or simply are not around to take care of them or assert ownership Other writers have used the device of presenting a story through the mind of a child or young person who sees and experiences, but is either too young to understand the implications or, as she grows older, is prevented by adults from drawing her own conclusions, developing her own understanding, of the "adult matters" that are concealed or distorted by euphemisms and outright lies.  The consequent distortions of consciousness may well create the kind of surrealist nightmares that we find in this narrator's telling of her tale and of her rescue from, at least, the circumstances of it, if never from the memories, which gradually come into focus, though never become acceptable.  We might think of Henry James's What Maisie Knew, or even Holden Caulfield in Catcher in the Rye. But seldom has an author captured the poetic power of a consciousness dealing with the eternal return of the almost musical phrases--even leitmotifs--of horror as effectively as Jenny Erpenbeck has done in this tiny but mesmerizing and unforgettable novella. It should be said, in addition, that too often the translators into English of works in languages we readers may not know are left unmentioned.  Not here.  I have not seen the German text of Erpenbeck's novella, but I feel confident that Susan Bernofsky's translation has given us a faithful and impressive experience that must be comparable to the original work.  She has captured the poetry and the horror with evident skill and artistry, and her work should be honored. It may seem odd, even perverse, to encourage readers to enter a labyrinth of horrific experience, even filtered through a profoundly poetic sensibility, but this novella makes us mindful of the realities of lives lived under the power of vicious and murderous tyrants--men of impeccable manners, fine dressers and connoisseurs, who know how to deal with the question, "what to do with the material?" That there is no such simple answer as the one the narrator's father imposes is only one of the things we must learn from this powerful work.

Imagine a character more domineering and more brutal than Miss Jean Brodie (of the famous Prime); a teacher who fishes and probes her students' lives, drawing out their secrets and using them to give herself some degree of control over their behavior; a teacher who openly mocks, patronizes and satirizes the parents, especially the mothers, of her students when they come for a "conference" or to ask advice; a teacher who both denies all personal feeling about or for her students, and grasps at them with fierce possessiveness when she wants responses to her advances.  That would be "the saxophone teacher" (otherwise unnamed) who is at the center of one of the main plot lines of this novel.  Early in the novel, she asks a mother, rhetorically:  "I ask my students . . . is your life a gift worth giving. . . . Of course it isn't, and the reason for that is that they simply haven't suffered enough to be worth listening to."  This comment indicates an aspect of the saxophone teacher's view of her own role--it is in part to protect but more, to make sure that her students experience some instructive suffering--and tell her about it.Imagine a young man, 18 or 19, beginning his studies to become an actor at a prestigious, highly selective, dramatic academy, where he encounters teachers and fellow students who regularly undermine or obliterate his sense of himself, of his aspirations and emotions.  He is told in one class "You cannot mime what you don't understand.  You cannot penetrate death, or God, or a woman.  To attempt any of these things is to aim for sincerity rather than truth.  Sincerity is not enough for students of this Institute.  Sincerity is a word for hawkers and hacks.  Sincerity is a device, and we do not deal in devices here."  He is asked to link this view with the related assertion, by the Head of Acting, that "an untrained actor is a liar merely.  . . . you are all liars, not calm persuasive liars but anxious blushing liars full of doubt."  The truth of his art is what the young man seeks, but he finds there are no convincing models either among his fellow students or his teachers.  That would be Stanley, the central character of the second plot line of this novel.  One of the recent graduates of the Institute, who stops in to give words of encouragement to the first year aspirants, says "Remember that anybody who is clever enough to set you free is always clever enough to enslave you."  This comment, very early in Stanley's career, has a certain prophetic power, though it is not exactly predictive.While Stanley is being initiated into the secrets and techniques of avoiding sincerity and never lying, a scandal erupts at the neighboring high school when a male teacher is accused of having "raped" one of his female students.  This scandal, with the inevitable arrival of a "counselor" assigned to "save" the young women of the school from the traumas of even hearing about such a terrible event (what many of them know or suspect is a consensual sexual affair between the young woman and the teacher), happens to involve the younger sister of the victim of the rape, as well as a couple of other young women, all of whom are students of the saxophone teacher.  And at a certain point, Stanley becomes "involved" with Isolde, the younger sister, with unsettling consequences.Eleanor Catton's novel is overtly about the relationships between art and truth, between art and neurosis or emotional disturbance, between sexuality and personality and identity, all of which problems are explored in sometimes comic, but always threatening ways as the two plot lines work their way out.  The lines between "reality" and fantasy, between the real self and the invented or fantasized self, whether in the body of the actor or in the behavior of the young women who "perform" in various ways for the saxophone teacher, will blur.  Who influences whom​?; who controls whom?; is the controlling one actually in charge, or is she a prisoner of her own fantasies of control?  Catton complicates the scenes where these questions are explored by mixing chronology.  Each section of the novel is labelled either with a day of the week or with a month; the months are Stanley's life; the days of the week are the saxophone teacher's and her students' days.  Sometimes these are jumbled out of sequence so that we realize we are reading an event that happened earlier than several that we read about many pages before--and the newly revealed past moment offers a new perspective on what we thought we knew had happened on earlier pages.I won't reveal more about the plot lines because it would be too easy to spoil surprises.  It is enough to say that the "progress" of the two lines--which finally draw together because of the connection between Stanley and Isolde--is unsettling, uncomfortable.  There are many uncertainties for the reader, not least of which is how much to believe of the saxophone teacher's view of her own behavior and of her interactions with students and parents; on the whole, one would certainly have to conclude that she is an uncommonly untrustworthy narrator whose notion of what is happening at any one moment is probably a much-distorted version of what the other participants might have believed was going on.  On the other hand, Stanley is mostly trustworthy, if only because he openly fails to understand what we, as readers, will surely understand by fair inference--precisely because we know how those things work and we can see that he has not yet suffered enough to understand them as we do--which, of course, puts us in the shoes of the saxophone teacher (or of one or another of the several teachers at the dramatic arts institute) as cynical viewers of the naivete of the young.Eleanor Catton has recently triumphed with her second novel, The Luminaries, and so has confirmed the talent demonstrated in her first work, but The Rehearsal is a novice work, full of the flash and ingenuity of a very smart and clever writer who apparently enjoys showing off her skills.  There is a cold and calculated manner of presentation that sometimes leaves her characters underdeveloped and caricatured (as though performed by the novice actors in Stanley's class), and like many contemporary fictional narratives, there is a kind of slippage to and fro, leaving the reader uncertain of the genre of the work--at times a sharp and biting satire, almost Juvenalian (as in the portrayals of Stanley's father, a psychiatrist, and of several of the mothers, but also of a few of the students at the high school), but at other times an adolescent coming-of-age story, more or less realistic in its presentation of the confusions caused by burgeoning sexual drives and the social dynamics of teenage social divisions into cliques and hierarchies, bullying crowds and confiding pairs of friends--at least for now.  A different kind of slippage occurs in the characterization of the saxophone teacher, as the reader begins to realize just how untrustworthy her descriptions and claims about her experiences really are.On the whole then, I doubt I would have read this novel through if it were not for my curiosity about how Catton performed in her first major effort.  I am impressed that she made such a massive jump from the level of this work to the level of The Luminaries.  We can hope that the second novel is a more accurate antecedent for any future novels she may give us.

Late in this memoir, Gary Shteyngart alludes to the work of "one of my favorite contemporary writers, Chang-Rae Lee, telling us that Lee's work shows "what fiction about immigrants can get away with."  Specifically, "scenes in Native Speaker that are not teased out with . . . laughter and hairy ethnic weeping but shouted, with anger and resignation, at the sky, scenes that make me question the relative insignificance of what I am trying to do with a 'comic' novel . . ."  In other words, Lee's works do not depend on the tricks that Shteyngart himself has used.  A few pages later, he admits "On so many occasions in my novels I have approached a certain truth only to turn away from it, only to point my finger and laugh at it and then scurry back to safety.  In this book, I promised myself I would not point the finger.  My laughter would be intermittent.  There would be no safety."  Along with one much earlier comment ("We Soviet Jews were simply invited to the wrong party.  And then we were too frightened to leave.  Because we didn't know who we were.  In this book, I'm trying to say who we were."), these stated commitments set a high bar for success, ambitious claim to a high seriousness and deep human sympathy to be carried through this narrative of, roughly, the first forty years of his own life, and the 60 to 70 plus years of his parents' lives.It's not easy to assess the success or failure (I would say there is a mix) of this book in fulfilling Shteyngart's ambitious project.  He manages some undeniably readable accounts of his earliest years in Leningrad and then in Queens.  His descriptions of his high school years are recognizable and evoke sympathy.  His account of his dissipated and sometimes riotous college career at Oberlin can be funny if one is not (parent-like, older-generation-like) too deeply saddened by the waste and damage done by his frantic efforts to live down to his most cynical views of what he wants from college and how he believes he can get it.  His painful (but not all that distinctive) efforts to succeed sexually with women are comical, but not unusual in an era of letting all hang out.  Throughout, we are kept aware of the very painful and conflicted relationship with his parents--Russian immigrants to Queens who bring with them attitudes and beliefs that prompt a kind of "assimilation" into American culture in the Reagan era that may suit them but must be, finally, more damaging to young Gary than even he realizes as he is growing up.  He is something of a momma's boy (because his mother provides a refuge from his father's temper), but he passionately wants acceptance, admiration, and especially love from the father who nastily calls him "Snotty," along with other denigrating nicknames.Gary learns that being the joker in the room provides cover and some immunity from the bullying and mockery that he inspires in his classmates in elementary and high school.  That same kind of japery, mixed with bouts of competitive drunkenness and efforts to be the biggest "head" on the Oberlin campus, where he has strong competition for that status, are part of his continuing development and, arguably, decline.  When he finally discovers that the psychoanalysis he enters with smirking irony, hostility, disdain, actually 'works' for him, helping him out of both the depressions and discombobulating confusions that make success (especially success as a writer, which is what he most wants to achieve) ever more remote, the narrative settles down, resulting in a moving and unusually straightforward account of his taking his parents on a homecoming trip to St. Petersburg, where they visit the scenes of his childhood and effectively resolve many of the conflicts that have made their lives often miserable, occasionally chaotic.Shteyngart achieves an impressive literary feat in his manipulation of point of view--his own--in this narrative.  He manages to give us Gary from about 5 to high school age in a voice that is consistently "true" to a boy that age, including all the misimpressions, compulsions, confusions, and comical mishaps that go with that age range, and he does it with no hint of cuteness.  (In fact, one term that may often apply to such childhood narratives, cute, could never be attached to any part of this book.)  As he moves us into the high school and then college years, the persona changes, grows, becomes more cynical and "knowing," more defiant but also more painfully self-conscious and ferociously self-critical at the same time that it is more and more assertive of the certainties that an adolescent and young adult may carry with him until they are shattered by experience.  This control of style, this deft manipulation of differing narrative voices, must be said to be the ground of whatever success this work achieves in carrying out Shteyngart's stated goals.  The book is funny, irreverent, a long standup monologue by a very clever and sometimes witty comedian whose sense of timing is excellent. At times, however, it feels reminiscent of the stale patter of a comic who depends on repetition of familiar jokes--take my punchline, please!The strengths of the book are undeniable, and yet ----.  Perhaps I should say that I have not been a fan of Shteyngart's fiction--especially not Super Sad True Love Story, which I reviewed some time ago.  Though I am not sorry to have spent the time reading that book and this one, I find myself still being less than enthusiastic.  The self-display, especially during the stories of the Stuyvesant and Oberlin years, is regularly undercut by the self-deprecating humor, and we are reminded that there is pain behind the mocking grimaces.  It would be hard, however, to give this book much credit at all, even with the masterful manipulation of tone and perspective, if it were not for the final section devoted to the trip to Leningrad/St. Petersburg.  But good as that section is, it also feels suspiciously convenient--so many bits and pieces, images and motifs, are neatly tied together that it feels like a package produced way before and saved in the attic until it's ready to come out with a TA-DA!  Fixed!Shteyngart is funny and bright, and I probably will read his next and the next after that, but I hope this represents the settlement with his past that will let him get on with his creative future.

I have never had a chance to use a French Coffee Press until this one arrived.  The instructions are easy to follow and the Press is an elegant and easy to use machine.  My first attempt at using it was a bit awkward and I think I miscalculated the amount of coffee to put in, so it was not perfect, but the second batch was fine--a rich coffee flavor and on the whole a very smooth drink.  I am sure I will enjoy using this whenever I have the time to do so, and I can recommend the Press to anyone who is curious to try it.  Since I am not a coffee connoisseur (just an avid drinker of many kinds of coffee, quite a lot every day) I won't presume to pronounce on the overall quality of the results.

I am really uncertain why this book has annoyed me as much as it has.  I have admired several of Paul Auster's novels and would rate them high; I have enjoyed reading his essays in periodicals when I have encountered them.  I know that he is admired and awarded as a writer. But this book has struck me as so tiresome and trivial that I had a hard time finishing reading it.The memoir purports to describe Auster's childhood and early adult years.  The opening paragraphs offer a charming child's view of the world around him, not really reminiscent of Joyce's similar self-portrait in Portrait of the Artist as a Young Man, but having some of the same naive appeal.  But in the opening paragraph, Auster begins what is one of the narrative tics that he continues throughout the book--the narrator separates himself from the subject (himself as a younger person) by addressing that younger person as "you":  "The face of the clock was a human face, each pea in your bowl had a different personality, and the grille on the front of your parents' car was a grinning mouth with many teeth."  And later:  "There was no problem in believing that the man in the moon was an actual man.  You couild see his face looking down at you from the night sky . . ."Of course, it is true that a 65 year old man is in many ways NOT the same person as the toddler or even himself as a 22 year old writing to a lover, soon to be lost.  The span of this memoir is from babyhood to about 22 (1947 to 1969), and Auster frequently reminds the reader that he has no records--no photos, no letters, no documents--to support the claims he makes about his experiences.  He bases his narrative on his memory, and we all know that memory is untrustworthy--gapped, inclined to fill in or even fabricate what we would like to have had happen, whether it did or not, and so on.  So Auster constantly asks us to remember his "authority" as a narrator by asserting his honesty in saying that these may be false memories, though he is doing his best to tell the truth as he remembers it.  But then in part three, "Time Capsule," he reports that his former wife has returned a batch of letters to him, those he had written to her over a period of several years, including his time at Columbia University in the late 1960s, when the turmoil of the rebellious student takeover of the campus occurred--part of his own experience, reported at that time.All through the memoir, Auster speaks to "you," then, as though the younger self were a separate entity, even though he acknowledges and hopes we will agree that his memories of that other self are part of himself now.  The subject of thememoir is the problem of writing memoir--one does or does not have documentation to support the validity of one's memories; one is or is not the same person one remembers being at an earlier time; one is or is not the product of the earlier experiences, feelings, readings, viewings, fights, romantic crushes, and so on.  And what if the truth is that one is NOT a product of the past, but a constantly evolving new entity--if that were so, what would be the point of repeating all those stories, which have no relationship or outcome.  Of if one is the same person, why would one write a memoir as though it were a letter of advice and interpretation to the "you", the separate person, who lived these experiences and is now being reminded of them from a voice separated by many decades.
