And so on and on.Part Two of this memoir is devoted almost entirely to detailed scene-by-scene recapitulations of two movies that had a powerful impact on the earlier Paul Auster. The first, "The Incredible Shrinking Man," and the second, "I Am a Fugitive From a Chain Gang";  both movies are thought-provoking and emotionally engaging in ways that Auster makes clear--both in terms of their impact on his earlier self and, by describing them in detail, showing that they still have the power to challenge and move viewers.These movies are two titles among many--Auster tells us of many of the books he read during his youth and college years, and speaks often of influential movies.  Anyone who grew up in the 50s and 60s will recognize the titles, probably will have read and seen many of them during the same period.  A reader might well agree that Diary of Anne Frank and On the Beach and many of  his other titles were formative in one's own experience.  And there is part of the problem.Auster effectively disowns the effort to claim or to portray the power and the fascination of his early experiences.  They all happened to the "you" he addresses, often in sympathetic tones.  It certainly makes sense to treat with some skepticism the attitudes, enthusiasms, tastes, and supposed experiences of a much younger person, especially if one is not confident that the earlier person can be trusted as a construct of oneself.  But how is that of interest to a reader?  At one point, Auster tells us that he started to write a journal when he was 18, but quit because he could not see the point of writing about what he knew had just happened, and he concludes that his self at that time did not understand that the audience for that journal was his older self.  Indeed.The final section of this memoir is a collection of drawings and photographs, mostly still shots from the movies he has mentioned, a few news photos, especially of the Newark riots and the Columbia University insurrection, and for the most part, the photos are impersonal, except that they are all related to details narrated earlier in the book.  They do not include pictures of Paul Auster.I shared many of the experiences Auster describes, including much of the reading and many of the movies mentioned, as well as living near many of the dramatic events (even having been involved in a few) described.  So why would I not be interested in reading Auster's account of them.  It's very odd, but I was repeatedly bored and irritated and had to force myself, as I have already said, to continue to the end.  I have no idea who the audience for this book might be--except for Paul Auster.

Patterns. Repetitions. Rules. Freedom. Mastery.In her essay "On Beauty and Being Just," Elaine Scarry poses a question:  "What is the felt experience of cognition at the moment one stands in the presence of a beautiful boy or flower or bird?  It seems to incite, even to require, the act of replication.  Wittgenstein says that when the eye sees something beautiful, the hand wants to draw it.  Beauty brings copies of itself into being.  . . . Sometimes it gives rise to exact replication and other times to resemblances and still other times to things whose connection to the original site of inspiration is unrecognizable."  Scarry has much more to say about the experiences of beauty in our lives, but her constant point is that beauty is not useless and not escapist--that beauty moves us to make better lives, a better world, not just for ourselves, selfishly, but for all humanity.Readers of Richard Powers's novels have become accustomed to his challenges--to the layered and complex issues his narratives raise and force us to consider, maybe contemplate, while we follow the fortunes and misfortunes of his characters.  In his most recent novel, Orfeo, the composer/chemist hero, Peter Els, confronts many challenges to his youthful belief that making music is creating beauty--a belief that is decidedly out of fashion during his days as a student and young adult.  When the novel begins, he is a retired teacher living with his aging Golden Labrador and engaged in a hobby based on his first college major, chemistry:  that is, he is doing research into gene splicing because he is interested in whether music (the making of music, responses to music) is genetically determined.  If humans (and some animals) have similar responses to certain chord progressions or melodies, does that fact indicate a genetic predisposition?  And could that suggest that DNA programs are chemical music?  Could genes be composed like musical phrases?In the midst of one such experiment, Els realizes his beloved dog, Fidelio, is perhaps dying; he calls 911 and sets in motion the calamitous series of events that constitute the crescendo finale of his life.  But interspersed in the narrative of his painful encounters with what we know as the "surveillance state," we have the narrative line portraying Peter's childhood and youth, up through his marriage and the birth of his daughter--and along with that, the descriptions of his obsession with music, his lesser interest in chemistry, and the complications in his personal relationships brought on by his efforts to create music inspired especially by his romantic attachments.  Along the way, he encounters composition teachers and other musicians who are all angrily seeking the new and revolutionary art forms, whether musical or theatrical or graphical, that will convey the reality of the world of the 60s, 70s, 80s of our era--periods of senseless wars, assassinations, brutal repression of protest and assertions of freedom, claims of the right to take off one's clothes (thanks to the Living Theater), to participate in happenings that embody the idea that random and un-ruled and spontaneous behavior creates art of the instant, ephemeral (who needs permanent monuments, they are repressive) and mind-blowing.  A mistake-free culture fueled by John Cage's aphorisms, including prominently and repeatedly "A 'mistake' is beside the point.  Once anything happens, it authentically is."  This, and comparable though diverse comments from Harry Partch, George Crumb, Milton Babbitt and other thinkers struggling with the question of the purpose of art and the problem, confronted by Peter Els, "Music is awareness flowing in through the ear.  And nothing is more terrifying than being aware" are scattered in boldface type through the text. [I did not notice Schoenberg's comment:  "The laws of art consist mainly of exceptions."  Perhaps too subversive of the main argument.]The story of Peter Els's advances and retreats in the world of musical composition intertwine with the description of his flight from the agents of the security state--the year is 2011 and the panic that engendered the Patriot Act is in full cry.  In this respect, parts of Powers's narrative feel as though they could be reports on yesterday's events, as mutatis mutandis, they are.  One of the aphorisms was true in the 80s:  "I wanted to believe that music was the way out of all politics.  But it's only another way in."  It's true today, differently.Because the central character lives in a world of music, there is a great deal of very informative and even inspiring commentary about music--especially about pieces Peter listens to during his lifetime--and so readers are treated to lucid and even revelatory analyses of Messiaen's Quartet for the End of Time, Steve Reich's Proverb, Peter Lieberson's Neruda Songs (written for and performed by his wife, transcendent mezzo-soprano Lorraine Hunt Lieberson), and several other works, including Peter Els's own imagined opera and his Borges songs, works that might as well be (maybe Powers has composed them and will let us hear them someday?).  There is also a fair amount of discussion of gene chemistry, of the strategies of avant-garde theatrical directors, and other technicalities related to Peter's life and work.  The novel never lets us forget that artistic creation is part of the social and political fabric of the world in which we live, both transformative in some ways, but vulnerable, even victimized, when the forces "in charge" turn their baleful eyes of death in its direction.  This last comes home to us in the deep commentary on Shostakovich's Fifth Symphony, written ostensibly as an "apology" to the Russian people for his sins against the reality of the Soviet, though perceived, perhaps rightly, as a gesture of defiance to the moustached leader crouched in the Kremlin.As may be apparent, I am impressed and enthusiastic about this novel, but must admit that it may not be popular with all readers.  Some may find that it assumes a degree of familiarity not only with music but with the art scene that such readers may find "elitist," or exclusionary.  My recommendation--find recordings or performances of those works--listen, then re-read.  The novel is fascinating, enlightening, and deeply moving.

[Full and open disclosure:  I have been acquainted with the author, Phong Nguyen, for a number of years, have been aware that he was working on this book, and have awaited its publication with great curiosity and high expectations.]On some simple level, almost everyone at some time in life will construct "alternate history."  It may be as simple as fantasizing about how much better everything would feel if only one had managed to make that basket at the buzzer, to hit that high note perfectly without the crack, to have remembered the familiar formula that stubbornly remained blank in mind when the question appeared on the exam.  We can imagine how it might have been, just as a number of popular writers have shown us versions of what the world would be like if the Confederacy had won the Civil War, or the Axis Powers had defeated the Allies.  Imagining the ways society, government, some individual lives might have been different if past choices or phenomena had moved in different directions is a kind of mirror version of the speculative science fiction that projects into the future the developments arising from a recent scientific discovery, or from a striking change in society as a result of social or political shifts that portend either utopia or dystopia.  We may think of recent works--Harry Turtledove's novels about the victorious Confederacy, Philip K. Dick's The Man in the High Castle about the aftermath on the American continent of the victory of the Axis powers, Margaret Atwood's Handmaid's Tale about the takeover of America by fundamentalist Christians, and many more.Phong Nguyen's chapters present alternate versions of the lives of important men and one woman, focusing not so much on large social or political changes, but on the ways the lives and characters of these people would have been different if they had responded to influences or impulses, ambitions or just circumstances, that led them in directions other than those we believe (from conventional history) they actually followed.  What if Judas did not betray Jesus?  What if Joan of Arc was not condemned and burned, but lived to become a mother?  What if Ben Franklin, as his mother wished, did become a clergyman in the style of Jonathan Edwards?  What if Ho Chi Minh had traveled to live in Harlem and had "revolutionized the food industry and ushered in a new era of packaging and distributing edible goods," specifically "Uncle Ho's Ready Bake Frozen Dough."In most of these chapters, the alternatives are not developed in large-scale societal or political terms, though we can infer that the paths these famous people have taken in these stories must imply significant changes in the world around them by contrast with what we believe we know happened in their "actual historical" lives.  There is a sly and effective, but low-keyed humor running through this book, as the great achievements of these historical figures are wiped out of history, replaced perhaps by actions or accomplishments of less historical interest, but perhaps psychologically fascinating to themselves and by extension to us.  Joan's discovery of her sexuality--still wearing inconveniently located parts of her armor as she learns what it is not to be a virgin warrior--leads to her fulfillment of her prophecy that she will be the mother of three sons.The opening sentences of Chapter 9, "Napoleon Invades Louisiana" offer a sample of the mixture of humor and subversion typical of Phong Nguyen's development of his alternate histories: "Napoleon Bonaparte, Emperor of West America, nearly lost his colonial empire when his navy  was threatned by a slave revolt in the colony of Saint-Domingue ('Hayti' to the locals).  It was only by means of an alliance with their leader, the former slave Toussaint L'ouverture, that  Napoleon was able to invade Louisiana and establish West America, keeping his continental  colonies from being sold off to East-American President Thomas Jefferson."In this we can see that changing the behavior of one "great man" will inevitably shift the histories of other great men with whom the first one interacts, and further and more dramatically as one extrapolates from the first move.  Among other things, putting alternatives into play has the effect of undermining, even discrediting, the tired old "great man theory" of human history (and Thomas Carlyle turns in his grave).  As the rest of this chapter proceeds, the story becomes more complicated and dramatic, more humorous and satirical, and the reader is treated to the mental exercise of imagining an East/West split on the American continent (not an impossibility, just what did not happen in the "actual history") instead of North/South, with Western expansion.Scenes and dialogue of confrontation and instruction occur in most of these chapters, providing the human interest as well as the humor as we observe historical figures acting "in character" but according to alternative circumstances that lead them to relationships and goals not previously recorded in official accounts of their lives.  In a few cases--Jesus and Judas, Napoleon and Toussaint, Einstein and Leo Szilard--one is tempted to wonder which of the two is the real focus of the chapter, or more likely, whether the significance is not found more in their interaction than in anything attributed to the "big name," either in this alternate or in the "actual" history of the lives.  It won't do to offer spoilers here.Th frame of this novel is presented by a nameless computer nerd who works for The Workshop, a company that specializes in recovering data from damaged hard drives; he manages to detect and identify a massive text--"a terabyte full of images and text--more than two billion words, with half a million maps and timelines" on a badly damaged circuit board belonging to one Obediah Lister.  This text is the alternate history most of which is subsequently lost, though the narrator has managed to copy a couple of hundred pages, which he smuggles away from The Workshop and arranges to publish.It is fair to say that this book does not conform to expectations one might have had, thinking of it as alternative history.  For one thing, the chapters are brief and most focus on only a few moments in the great lives, so there is not a sense of a "sweep" of history, though individual anecdotes of these kinds can and do imply much wider significances.  Neither do the alternative events seem to offer either utopian or dystopian outcomes, or not in all cases.  The reader is invited, rather, to think through the possible meaning of these alternate lives, and is provided at the end of each chapter with "Suggestions for Class Discussion" that sometimes are oblique and gnomic, sometimes seemingly out of touch entirely with any possible meaning of the story, but all signal to the reader the need to consider ways of understanding.  Further questions may pester us--is there a common thread running through the narratives that, if detected, would offer a means of drawing together the separate chapters into a coherent whole, perhaps with a single (though complex) message?  Is there a reason for the inclusion of the particular names presented--a principle of selection at work that might also enlighten us if we could tease it out?  These are, I suppose, questions for discussion if not grounds for hot debate.Phong Nguyen's book offers many pleasures and some challenges to the reader.  I recommend it enthusiastically.

It's not exaggerating to say that this is one of the strangest books I have ever read, and I have read a whole lot of books, many of them pretty strange.  (Consider, maybe as a benchmark, E.A. Poe's The Narrative of Arthur Gordon Pym of Nantucket, or Lewis Carroll's The Hunting of the Snark or Anna Kavan's Ice.)  Atlas has won the Science Fiction and Fantasy Translation Award as the best 2013 work in long form (i.e., novel, or maybe novella), and that is a fact that might well lead a number of readers into an unexpected and disorienting reading experience.  Of course, that is what many of the best works of science fiction aspire to do, but this one works differently.Most science fiction is grounded in one or more familiar sciences--physics, biology, chemistry, anthropology, even economics or political science  when we explore dystopias.  In the case of Atlas, we have a novel that emerges from (and explores, analyzes, defines and re-defines) cartography--the art of mapmaking.  Fifty-one chapters, mostly no more than 3 pages long, some only 2--divided into four sections:  Theory, The City, Streets, Signs--the novel seems to be narrated by a single voice, though at some points there are suggestions of new voices entering.  From the beginning, the narrative is about the island city of Hong Kong.  The narrative is not chronological nor sequential--rather, each chapter has reference to a number of maps produced over many centuries by people of different nationalities and races, different perspectives (both visual and political), different motives or agendas, and so on.  If a reader has believed that there is something solid and dependable about the information gained from looking at a map, that belief will be thoroughly and inexorably demolished by reading this work.What is the relation between a map and the territory it purports to represent?  How large does a map have to be, with what degree of conformity to the size of the territory before it is trustworthy or sufficiently informative?  What is the relationship, cognitively, between the signs on the map and the reality of the places it ---- identifies? names? acknowledges or establishes as "real"? What if the same place (or group of places, as in an archipelago near a mainland) presented on different maps, drawn by different cartographers from different backgrounds and different periods of time, seems to be shaped differently, named differently, juxtaposed with its neighbors at different angles or with different topographical relationships?  What if the map represents the topography of an earlier period, whereas the topography has changed radically in the historical period since the map was made?  Consider  Canal Road East and Canal Road West on Hong Kong Island: It was the fate of Canal Road East and Canal Road West (as with so many other places in Victoria) for a separation  between sign and reference to take place in the course of successive stages of time and space.  A more thorough deconstruction would be to take the argumenent one step further, that is, when the signifier for the sign "canal" no longer had a natural connection  with its signified, then only the phonetic form remained in "canal," acting as a plac-name, while the content of "canal" was abandoned.  The underground waterway no longer existed in reality, no matter whether on a map or in people's comprehension.  The street name not only made it impossible for anyone to trace its source, it actually tells us how the city deconstructs itself in its unceasing growth.  (p. 98)Notice the reference to "Victoria"--that is the name of the city founded by British colonialists on Hong Kong Island, a city that can be located on a map of Hong Kong, but which serves as a reminder of the unstable and complex "identities" of the place represented:  British architecture, British customs, British allegiances, British military and commercial interests, superimposed on native Chinese language, Chinese people (coolies, servants, tailors, rickshaw men, etc.) along with place names that may have several different meanings, even exist in different languages, so conveying different information about the character of the places, and so on.  You will notice also in that passage the vocabulary of Saussurean structuralism juxtaposed with Derridean postmodern theory, both at the service of an analysis of the fleeting quality of cultural and social meaning in a colonized world.  These are themes that float and transform and occasionally illuminate the chapters, which also draw on Foucauldian archaeology (as the book's title suggests), constantly reminding us of the relationships of power (not always obviously consistent with the surface appearances) and even the tectonic shifts and volcanic eruptions that may affect the lives and security of the inhabitants.As the chapters accumulate in the reader's mind, the suspicion that there is an agenda along with all these mindbending (and sometimes very frustratingly opaque) analyses of very old maps (16th century, 18th century, 20th century and more) of Hong Kong, Kowloon, Macao, and the New Territories.  Indeed, it appears from comments (on the dust jacket, for example) that these chapters are a compilation of interpretations and analyses by cartographers far in the future, attempting to reconstruct the cities of Victoria/Hong Kong and surroundings, following a catastrophic decline of the whole area, the nature of which is never explained.In other words, the whole book is an examination of what we can know, if anything, about a place by examining a map of it.  Is the map in any sense at all comparable to the territory--or is it merely a mental construct, an idealized or degraded "picture," corrupted away from "reality" by the intrusion of human intentions, human myths, human fairy tales, human human interest stories?  Many of the streets and locations have such stories attached to them, perhaps signalled by texts or even "legends" attached to the maps.  So also the whole island and the complex culture of it.  As we learn at the beginning of Chapter 16: The legendary city of Victoria was, like Venus, born from the waves of the sea.  It is not known  how it disappeared in the end.  The legend thus brings us face-to-face with an archaeological question:  by what means can we verify a city's existence?The book is about all that.  It must be said that the opening chapters, especially, require patience and persistence of the reader.  The numerous names flood the brain, the shifting theoretical and philosophical perspectives purposely disorient and confuse.  And there is very nearly no payoff for all the effort it takes--while there are anecdotes along the way, there is no plot line, no set of knowable characters.  The experience is of a massive mind game and provides all the pleasures for the brain of working out whatever can be known from thinking about dozens of maps one has not even seen, but only known through verbal descriptions that are themselves full of uncertainty.  For the right reader, it is a heady pleasure, but it certainly feels at the end as though one has finally found that boojum, and one is nowhere as a result.  And happy to be so.

Written in 1946, during the last year of Victor Serge's life, and not published in Europe until 1971, this novel was finally translated into English and published in 2008.  In spite of age and neglect, Unforgiving Years must be considered a major, if belated, addition to twentieth-century literature, and especially to the shelf of works that portray unevasively and incisively the nature of the tyrannies that flourished and nearly prevailed during the years leading to the Second World War and through the Cold War years afterward.  There is no lack of tyranny and danger in the present, but the effort to analyze and understand the several evils characteristic of National Socialism and Stalinism is ongoing and still necessary.  Not that the purpose of a novel is necessarily to expose or even comment about specific political or social evils--it may well do that, but there is in the best novels a greater dimension of understanding and empathy with the passion, the suffering, and the humanity even of the people who may espouse those worldviews, however evil, but especially those who see and understand and have the courage to live to resist the power of evil.Serge divides this novel into four sections of unequal length.  The first section, "Secret Agent," is set in Paris during the period leading up to the German invasion; the world the characters experience is one of intense anxiety, constant suspicion or near paranoia, as they feel themselves under constant observation, subject to arrest or abduction and assassination because of their imagined deviations from the party line.  The atmosphere feels very much like the gloom of movies such as The Third Man or Touch of Evil, with the menace all too real as the four characters (Sacha, Nadine, Daria, and Alain) encounter each other and others while attempting to arrange flight from France.  Each of these characters will appear under different names in the later sections of the novel.The second section focuses on Daria as she tries to carry out her political duties--keeping records of communications of all kinds--during the siege of Stalingrad, surrounded by starvation, madness, and the "discipline" of military officers, gradually declining into hysterical adherence to patterned behavior.The third section occurs during the final days of the Third Reich, focusing on ordinary Berliners dealing with the collapse of order, bombardment day after day, near starvation, rapacious marauders and rapists.  The portrayal of a whole city gradually dying comes into focus with the reappearance of Daria (at this time calling herself Erna), working as a nurse among people trying desperately to survive, clinging to, or reacting skeptically to, the absurd reports of fantasized victories, new overwhelming weapons that will guarantee victory, even as the allied bombers pass over, pulverizing whatever remains standing in the city.The final section is set in Mexico; Daria arrives at the remote Mexican village where Sacha and Nadine using the names Carlo and Noemi Battisti,  are settled in an isolated area, farming and trying to make a life undetected by the agents of the government that continues systematically to try to track down and kill them.  Serge, as a former Trostkyist, knows exactly how this feels; the contrast between the almost idyllic situation they have found for themselves in Mexico and their awareness that there is no such thing as security for them, leads to probing discussions of the nature of freedom and creativity.This novel is intense, often painful to read as we gain and then lose hope for the welfare of these characters, formerly idealists committed to making a better world, but who have recognized that though they tried to improve the world, they forgot to include humanity.  The dialectical thinking of Sacha and Daria, especially, conveys the anguish of committed revolutionaries who see the perversion of their ideals in the political and economic machinations--and the culture of wanton destruction--they have inadvertently created.  This final work from Victor Serge is a masterpiece of fair warning.

Hikmet's Life's Good, Brother is a poet's novel.  That is, along with being a novel by a writer who is renowned as a great poet--according to many, the "Father" of modern Turkish poetry--it is also a novel that uses, effectively, many tactics associated with his narrative poetry.  Readers familiar with Hikmet's magnificent "epic novel in verse," Human Landscapes from My Country, will experience moments that remind them of  Hikmet's use of the kinds of striking juxtapositions, based on sharp, tight observations of human character and behavior as well as physical objects and environments, that let him create multilayered and complex scenes that illuminate rather than obscure or complicate the social and political conditions he is concerned to portray in the lives of his characters.  To say that it is a poet's novel is not to say that it is lyrical in any conventional sense; rather, it features the rhetorical and imagistic gestures of the poet in the service of a narrative that reveals the human struggles, the brutality and heroism, that went with the revolutionary efforts of people in many areas of the world during the 20th century, focusing especially on the transformations of Turkey as a nation.The novel is, we are told by its translator, substantially autobiographical, and may be said to have only two underlying characters -- Hikmet, himself, and the "nation" of Turkey as a collective self -- but those two are divided into several voices with different names and situations.  This allows Hikmet to focus variously on aspects of the revolutionary history of Turkey that he experienced.  As a committed Marxist, he was persecuted, arrested, censored, finally exiled during his lifetime, but he never lost (as is obvious from his writings) his deep love for Turkey and his fellow Turks--even those who were his political enemies and persecutors.The narrative of Life's Good, Brother shifts both places and times; one of the main characters, Ahmet,is a journalist and activist who goes into hiding at the beginning of the novel, hoping to establish a clandestine press where he can print and distribute news about political change in Turkey; the authorities are determined to prevent any such publications, so he hides in a remote rural area, but his situation is complicated by his being bitten by a stray dog that is very likely rabid; isolated and forced to stay in hiding, Ahmet and his friend, Ismail, find that the incubation period for rabies is 40 days, and so they begin to count, watching Ahmet closely for any signs of the symptoms of the onset of rabies.  During this time, Ahmet triggers memories of time spent in Moscow as a student during the 1920s, witnessing the early stages of the development of the Russian soviet era, encountering students from other areas of the world (China, France), and falling in love with a revolutionary woman, Anushka.  Scenes in Russia are interspersed with his hiding and waiting for the symptoms to appear; he has told his friend, Ismail, that if he does develop rabies, Ismail must shoot him and bury him secretly. He keeps track of the waiting period by drawing a line in chalk on the door of their hideout, and the chapter divisions are identified by the line numbers as the two watch and wait.Ismail is the second most prominent character and his story picks up later in the 1920s, when he is arrested for illegal political activities (including his involvement with Ahmet and the printing press), and he realizes that Ahmet was right to believe that almost no one could be trusted in the turmoil of political conflict that set natural allies against each other when they needed to protect themselves from the authorities; everyone mistrusts everyone else, even close friends and lovers.  Ismail is tortured horrifically in prison, scenes that are particularly painful reading and run parallel, in a sense, to the growing tension as each day passes in the wait for Ahmet's body to declare whether he does or does not have rabies.  In the meantime, the political activities, the negotiations, the schemes and the failures of the revolutionaries go on.This novel is uncommon in its structure and narrative, powerful in its portrayal of committed revolutionaries, moving in the exploration of the interplay of public and private commitments and emotions.  It is a work I recommend highly.

Brian Payton has worked as a journalist and has published several nonfiction works as well as one earlier novel.  His experiences as a journalist and nonfiction writer, combined with his ambition to write novels, would account for both the strengths and the weaknesses of his new novel, The Wind is Not a River. The broad historical context of the story is the little-known Aleutian campaign of the Second World War.  The Japanese had invaded and established bases on parts of the Aleutian Island chain, which was United States territory.  The U.S. military command suspected this was an effort to create a launching area for an invasion of the American mainland.  There was little knowledge of the characteristics of the sparsely populated islands, but the military moved quickly to evacuate ("for their own protection") the indigenous inhabitants of the territory, interning them on the mainland in much the same way Japanese/American citizens had already been interned.  The military launched an effort to destroy the Japanese bases and eject their troops.  This operation was problematic because of the lack of familiarity with the extremely hostile environment and terrain of the islands; it was also kept secret as much as possible (to protect the element of surprise in the counterinvasion), so that strict censorship was imposed on the press and on personal communications from the area.The fictional component of Payton's novel focuses on a journalist, John Easley, who has made a career writing especially about the environment and wildlife, with contributions to the National Geographic, and his wife, Helen.  Easley had been working in the Aleutians before the war, documenting bird and animal migrations and plant life, and he knew the terrain--rough, barely able to sustain life, raked by intense storms.  When he realizes that the islands have been invaded by Japanese (but with almost no details to support the story), he is determined to return there to tell the story of the war.  Having no luck getting a press pass, he masquerades as his own brother, an officer in the Canadian Air Force who has been killed in Europe.  John counts on that information not having reached the American authorities and successfully joins an Air Force group (as an observer) in the Aleutians.  As the novel begins, in April, 1943, he has been forced to parachute into the sea as his plane crashes, killing all aboard except himself and one very young American airman who also manages to make it alive to the small island where they are forced to undertake heroic measures to survive--no food, no water, no shelter, hostile Japanese encampment on the other side of the island.  Because John is there under an assumed name, no one knows where he is nor who he is.In the meantime, John's wife, Helen, realizes it has been too long since she has heard from him and begins to search for information about his whereabouts.  She finally manages (with another act of masquerading) to join a USO troupe that is going to Alaska to entertain the troops.  She has no experience as a singer or performing in public, but manages to fake it and finally arrives in the Aleutians, determined to find her missing husband.The main body of the novel, then, alternates the narrative of John's increasingly desperate efforts to remain alive in the hostile environment and Helen's gradually successful efforts to get close enough to where he is that she might have some hope of finding him.  There are moments of real emotional power, and the revelation of the meaning of the title is affecting.  But there are problems.Payton's characterizations both of his two main characters and several secondary characters who are recognizable and sympathetic are effective, and the reader is drawn into the adventure and drama of the situations.  Payton's prose style, however, which is a sturdy journalistic style, is not well suited to the kind of adventure and love story that he has chosen to tell about his main characters.  Frequent shifts from a reasonably effective fictional narrative style into the plain expository prose expected in a substantial feature story in a serious magazine (such as National Geographic or the Sunday New York Times magazine) are jolting and on occasion very unwelcome.  The emotive power of the fictional narrative dries up for a while and we feel we are being lectured, even hectored, by a writer who has a determination to set straight the faulty or incomplete story of the Aleutian campaign for readers who do not know or appreciate the importance or value of the sacrifices made by the military forces involved.I have no doubt that it is better to have an authoritative account of this part of the war effort, and it seems likely that many readers will feel themselves much better informed about it after reading the novel.  But as a novel, the work falls short.  Some of the later surprises feel contrived, the tendency to demand sympathy and understanding feels supererogatory, and one may finally wish that the author had decided to write a substantial article correcting the deficiencies of earlier journalistic and historical accounts, rather than attempting a romantic adventure narrative that finally feels flat and unconvincing.

Just about halfway through The People in the Trees,the hero, who has been narrating his own account of the adventures and observations that have led to his receiving a Nobel Prize in Medicine, describes his efforts to understand a phenomenon he has observed among the people of a previously "unknown tribe" in a remote area of Micronesia.  The evidence seems to suggest that these people have had contact with something that significantly prolongs their lives, and he is trying to find out what might have caused this and what its effects might mean.  As he analyzes, he also begins to think about the idea of immortality and the different ways people react to the idea of it.  At the time he is writing, he is in his 70's, and he makes the following comment:  "There is a point--for me, it arrived perhaps a few years ago--when, without even realizing it, you switch over from craving more life to being resigned to its end.  It happens so abruptly that you cannot help but recall the moment itself, and yet so gently that it is as if it comes to you in a dream."  This idea of acceptance of mortality as a given of human life comes in the context of his realization that the immortality of these Micronesians is "a curse."Why would indefinitely extended life be a curse?  It is, in fact, one of the oldest stories in the human literary tradition: the names Tithonus and Struldbruggs come to mind, tied to the realization that physical life, even with relatively good physical health, is no guarantee of continued mental competence, wisdom, or spiritual enlightenment.  Tithonus becomes, finally, a cricket, endlessly scratching out his complaints about being ever older and lesser.  The Struldbruggs may live forever, but they age like any other humans, becoming increasingly infirm and miserable as the years pass--and they are isolated from human society as being accursed in this way.  As Dr. Norton Perina discovers, the Ivu'Ivuans who have acquired physical longevity (as much as 300 years, with no necessary limit at least to continued physical life) have no hope of retaining mental acuity, passing through stages that are parallel to the known progress of Alzheimer's, though that disease is never mentioned in the novel.  Even the word "dementia" appears only once or twice.  The mental deterioration of the pathetic Micronesians inspires pity and appears to be irreversible, incurable. As a continuing theme in the novel, the questions of the meaning of life and death are explored if not with Montaigne's lighthanded complexity, then with a degree of seriousness.Dr. Perina arrives on the island as a junior member of a team of researchers led by a famous and charismatic anthropologist, Paul Tallent; he and his assistant are the lead researchers, while Perino having recently gained his M.D., is mostly along to do medical tests and observations of the physical condition of the "subjects."  This expedition, by the way, takes place during the 1950s, well before the scandalous revelations about experimentation with human subjects that led to the creation of the National Commission for the Protection of Human Subjects of Medical and Biological Research, and the treatment of the subjects in this case would provide more evidence of the need for such an oversight committee, though Tallent and Perina are, for the most part, portrayed as both well-intentioned and benevolent.  But of course, it is Perina for the most part, doing the portraying.This novel comes to the reader in the guise of Perina's written narrative, composed while he is in prison, about the expeditions and subsequent research; the main narrative is framed by an introduction by Perina's research assistant, Ronald Kubodera, who also provides frequent and detailed footnotes, either supplementing or even correcting statements made in Perina's narrative.  This gives the novel the appearance of a nonfiction work, a memoir with scholarly apparatus, even including a glossary of some words in the language of the Ivu'Ivuans.In addition to the trappings of scholarly publication, the prose of the narrative is dense with the kind of detail--in this case, imagined, and testifying to the fertility of the author's imagination--that an observant scientist would want to include in a report on such an expedition.  Perina actually mocks the writing of Esme Duff, Dr. Tallent's other assistant, as being pedantic and repetitive, focused on minutiae that make her descriptions unreadable; even so, Dr. Perina's own descriptions are graphic, detailed, somewhat repetitive, and may inspire a degree of impatience in the reader.  The lush prose describing the treks through the jungle, with the imaginative creation of unknown and fascinating flora and fauna in that jungle, will either fascinate or annoy.  In addition, a certain coyness about the details of the activities of the several characters may also either intrigue or exasperate the reader, depending on that reader's interests.There is much more in the novel than the description of the expedition and discovery.  The psychological and sexual peculiarities of both Perina and Tallent, for example, are hinted at and finally given some dramatic relevance.  The disastrous aftermath of the publication of Perina's discoveries--the descent on the fragile island and indigenous peoples by rapacious researchers, especially those financed by several of the major international pharmaceutical companies, the insistent and finally successful destruction of the native culture by missionaries of various sects, especially Mormons--are all presented in detail.  Some of these dramatic events--especially the impact on the lives of the native peoples by not just contact with Western culture, but the imposition of Western consumerism and religion (hand in hand) -- have been portrayed in the nonfiction accounts of some famous writers--most prominently, perhaps, the British travel writer, Norman Lewis--and so there is a sense of verisimilitude added to the fanciful narrative about the immortality gained by the natives.The profusion of materials in the novel, in fact, provides both some of the kinds of interest one can enjoy in reading a nonfiction narrative and, unfortunately, some of the factors that make the work a less than fully successful novel.  If we think of the story of Perina's life as the main line of the fictional narrative, which becomes dangerously complicated when he both arranges to bring a few of the "immortals" back to a laboratory in the United States while, at the same time, adopting some children from the Ivu'Ivuans and taking them into his own home to raise them as Americans, then we are forced to wonder whether the intrusion of the many side issues and "scholarly" materials are really justified as part of the work.  Most novels include, even attempt to illuminate, issues that are related to but not central to the life of the main characters.  In that sense there is nothing wrong with a novelist trying to broaden the scope and relevance of her novel, but in this case, there is a feeling that some of the materials are pasted in, added on or just included because they seem interesting or came to mind as the author was composing and seemed, perhaps, too good to be left out.  But they create a degree of confusion, of lack of focus, as the reader is likely to wonder just what the book is actually "about."While it is too long in ways that should have been edited out, this novel is rich in fascinating detail and frequently prompts serious thought about serious issues--even leading to re-reading passages to see how they fit into the ongoing narrative.  A patient reader will find much to enjoy, much to think about, in this novel.

Whether we think of Lot leading his family away from the ruins of Sodom or Noah gazing over the limitless waters, the diminishing group of survivors in Shute's On the Beach, or Bruce Dern in Silent Running leaving behind a declining ecosystem, or the many other efforts by many writers, especially in the late 20th century until now to portray the decline or collapse of human civilization, the destruction of the life-supporting elements of the physical world or the elimination of the social and financial institutions that sustain what many understand to be normal life, or combinations of all of the above, we know that the imagination of disaster has flourished in some creative minds throughout the recorded history of human artists to portray the unthinkable -- the end of life as we know it.  For some, the blame is on the scientists who create the instruments of destruction (for an excellent example, see Angela Carter's Heroes and Villains); for others, the destruction of the liberal social contract and imposition of various tyrannies (Margaret Atwood's Handmaid's Tale, or the not-so-famous Arslan, by M.J. Engh), not to mention countless movies about intrepid heroes attempting to survive against invasions or plagues or  universal sterility or uncontrolled metamorphoses.  The bleakest and most relentless of these visions remains, I think, the concluding sections of H.G. Wells's The Time Machine--confronting almost infinitely in the future the death of the universe itself.In The Last Man Standing, Davide Longo gives us a somewhat limited but nonetheless horrifying vision of the end of society--the society of Italy, so far as the characters and the reader can know, since among the earliest casualties of the collapse is "the news," and so all we know about what may be happening in the rest of Europe, during the time that Italian law and order, military units, banks and financial systems, supply lines, and most of the infrastructure that makes possible the genteel life of the main character, Leonardo, is that the French and the Swiss have closed their borders and refuse to allow refugees from Italy to cross.  The result, first vigilante actions by local peoples to protect themselves from "outsiders" (anyone not Italian, it would seem, immigrants, gypsies, etc.), followed by increasingly violent and effective marauding by self-selected gangs of young people who arm themselves and ruthlessly take whatever they want, slaughtering livestock and humans whenever it suits their whims.As the novel opens, we meet Leonardo, a formerly successful novelist and teacher of writing whose career has been destroyed by a highly publicized trial for sexual harassment and abuse of a student, who has accused him of forcing her into a sexual relationship in order to advance her academic career.  There are never many details about the nature of the charges, but we learn that the outcome is his loss of his teaching position, divorce from his wife and separation from his beloved daughter, and a general retreat to a small town where he lives in seclusion as the society begins to crumble around him.  As the situation becomes more dire, people in the town are fleeing and urging him to flee; his wife arrives with their daughter and a stepson, asking him to care for them while she goes to try to find her second husband, who has disappeared.  Of course, she does not return for the children and Leonardo is left to care for them and try to survive the desperate and violent situations that ensue.On the whole, the opening sequences of this novel feel familiar, even formulaic, for anyone who has read more than a few novels about the collapse of society (or even, one might say, accounts of the deteriorating circumstances for Jewish and other peoples in Germany during the 1930s--the efforts to "make the best" or even to live in denial of the coming catastrophe are similarly familiar from memoirs of that period), but Longo tells the story well and has created, in Leonardo, a character that may be appealing especially to avid readers who will be familiar with many of the literary allusions that occur throughout the novel as Leonardo, well-read as well as widely published, remembers and finds (for a while) some solace in the hundreds or thousands of stories he has read both for pleasure and for professional reasons.  The famous story by Gustave Flaubert. "Un Coeur Simple," becomes almost a leitmotif, certainly a repeated point of reference for Leonardo as he confronts the arrogance, greed, cruelty, and destructiveness of many "survivors" of the collapse.  There are many other such references, though few--except for the fascination of one character with the novels of Thomas Bernhard--have as much relevance to the emotional and moral development of the novel as the Flaubert story.  (Leonardo's loss of career, marriage, reputation, has parallels also in a number of novels and plays, including David Mamet's Oleanna, J.M. Coetzee's Disgrace, and John Williams's Stoner, to name a few.)It won't do to repeat many of the events of the plot.  The novel does not depend on surprise for its power, but surprise has its pleasures; the predictable elements of this kind of story--shortages, thievery, survival efforts, chases, extreme cruelty, torture, rape, near-death experiences--all occur more or less on schedule, escalating as the desperation increases.  This is not to say that Longo is merely borrowing and imitating, though there are some parts of the novel that will remind the reader of other works--including, oddly enough, the novels of Yann Martel: toward the end, Leonardo, who already has a dog, acquires an elephant--no secret, since it is portrayed on the cover illustration.  It is at that point that the suspicion that this very tough and uncompromising narrative may be about to go soft and sentimental, which is often what happens with these stories.  The plot has to end somehow, the ending probably will suggest either that humanity is indeed doomed and about to be extinct or, on the other hand, may have begun to show signs of political and spiritual enlightenment of a kind that might result in resurrection, restoration, even redemption.  (One thinks of the concluding sections of Walter M. Miller's great A Canticle for Leibowitz.)  While The Last Man Standing continues to be compelling reading right to the end, the more positive formulas do prevail, though there are surprises right to the final paragraph.Longo's novel has pretensions of straddling the boundary between genre (the familiar after-the-disaster narrative) and literary fiction (a character study of a man struggling to recover from an experience that seems to destroy everything he has supposed himself to be and to believe); it is not fully successful as either, but it is fascinating, engrossing, recommendable.

Desire.  Possession.  Plenitude.  Desire wants always to have the person or object desired, totally; or in the mirror, Desire wants to be had, to be engulfed by the desired one, consumed or transformed into the essence of the desired one.  Desire wants to possess or be possessed by, and can only be satisfied by the totality, the plenitude of possession.  Desire may be the driving force behind feats of creativity or acts of self-obliteration.  When desire transforms, there may be no self left as it disappears into the desired, or there may be no desired left as it is subsumed into the desiring self.  Boundaries, definitions, genres are blurred or erased; there are no limits, psychically, between self and other, between male and female, between human and not human.  Desire may dehumanize--the person has no name, no character, only the desired attributes--blonde hair or red or black, breasts or genitals of this or that size or shape, scents whether appealing or repulsive, degrees of tumescence or flaccidity, welcoming or forbidding orifices.  The one desired may be armed or unarmed.In one of his greatest sonnets, Shakespeare offered a conclusion about all this, perhaps too pat and somewhat evasive, but perhaps definitive: "All this the world well knows, yet none knows well To shun the heaven that leads men to this hell."In The Fata Morgana Books," Jonathan Littell offers four short works (the fourth being long enough to be called a novella; otherwise, short stories of varying length); these narratives are spoken by a voice, though there may be several speakers, who may be called the "desirer" except when he or she feels no desire; the desirer may or may not be able to see the images in the mirror of the desired and the desiring self  (mirror images are a constant motif--leitmotif​?-- in these stories).  The desirer may or may not have the key, may open the door to the right room or the wrong one.  The person waiting in the room, or the persons encountered on the street or at the swimming place (swimming is a constant motif, along with showering), may or may not be the objects of desire or, conversely, the threatening "eyes" pursuing (with evil intent?) the narrator.  The elaborate parties and sexual encounters may or may not be dreams:  "my desires floated freely, coming to bear on everything and nothing, settling only to take off and settle on their opposite, before coming back or going elsewhere, and I no longer knew if I was man or woman, unless someone told me." The children encountered, playing, swimming, endangered, threatened, may or may not be related to the narrator.In the realm of desire, objectification, dehumanization, may drain characters of individuality; they are A or B or the woman with the artfully arranged blonde hair or the men in dark coats under umbrellas.  This has the effect, in fictional narrative, of focusing "interest" on the actions and the anticipations of the narrator, and the appeal of the narrative may depend on whether the narrator inspires interest; if he or she is no more than Desire, the appeal may be limited.  There is a coldness and impersonality to these stories that forces readers to pay attention to the ebb and flow of desire, while wondering whether any of the actions, observations, or feelings of the narrator have any significance at all.  Does it matter if the speaker feels hungry, ill, drunk, hungover, rejuvenated, lustful, sated, fearful, battered.  Seldom do these feelings have consequences in the narratives.  But that may be the point of desire.Jonathan Littell is best known for his massive Prix Goncourt-winning novel, Les Bienveillantes/The Kindly Ones.  This much shorter volume, seemingly organized like the four movements of a symphony,  offers a very different kind of narrative, reminiscent of some other writers who focus on erotic subjects--Georges Bataille, for instance, in Story of the Eye or Blue of Noon, Samuel R. Delany in his Mad Man, Michel Houellebecq, or recently, Nicholson Baker, whose House of Holes might be seen as a comic mirror image of Littell's work.  As with their ancestor, Marquis de Sade, these writers describe sexual activity in graphic detail, for which the reader should be prepared.  Beyond that, in Littell's stories (though I would suggest that the narrator is always the same and the stories are segments of an ongoing story--perhaps a kind of symphonie fantastique), the activities of the narrator always suggest serious or portentous events, though the reader soon realizes that this is because they are formulaic scenes from literary narrative, used to suggest impending significance only to be drained of it by shifting focus, returning us to the ever-problematic desire.This is a difficult book to "grade":  it is hard to like, easy to admire, up to a point.  One is inclined more to warn potential readers, rather than to recommend it to them.  What to say?  The writer is a genius and the book is fascinating, but definitely special, in a troubling sense.

This lyrical and almost dreamlike novel has an uncanny similarity to a short story, "Queen of the Pacific Tides," by Rose Whitmore, which was published about a year ago in the Missouri Review, and Danticat's novel also occasionally feels reminiscent of the wonderful movie, Beasts of the Southern Wild.  The connecting element among the three stories is the young girl--in the case of Danticat's novel, the title's Claire, in the Whitmore story, Ruby, the daughter of a Pacific coast fisherman lost at sea, and in the movie, Hushpuppy, who also lives beside and often on water.  For Claire, it is her mother who is missing, and her father who agonizes over the challenges of raising a daughter in poverty and uncertainty; for Ruby, her father is gone, washed overboard in a storm, though she is not convinced he is dead, since his body has never washed up on the beach she constantly patrols, looking for him and encountering other bodies, human, mammals, fish, that wash up in his stead.  Hushpuppy has an ailing father and a determination to hold on to the life and the place where she lives, the people she knows.  Because of these heroines, and because each of them has a semi-mystical sense of identity with the sea and with almost mythic creatures, the lyricism of the narratives is sustained through contact with the girls' thoughts, perceptions, emotions, and perhaps even their visionary experiences of the world around them.I could extend the list of narratives (novels, stories, films) that feature children of varying degrees of innocence and fresh perception as they try to interpret, understand, survive the people and events surrounding them, often threatening them,sometimes sustaining them.  In the case of Claire, several adults are involved with each other in ways that impinge onher life.  Her father has thought it would be good for her if he were to send her to live with a woman who would know better how(and be better able to afford) to raise her.  That woman, and several other characters (the proprietor of the private school where Claire has been a scholarship student, his son, a woman who has been raped and made pregnant by that son, and more are entangled in conflict and even murder.All this happens in a beautifully described area of the south coast of Haiti.  The fishing village where Claire and her father live is adjacent to a small but growing town that has begun to suffer all the woes of pollution, corruption, crime, delinquency associated with big cities that have no political stability, no infrastructure.  In the village, life seems almost idyllic and more like a pre-twentieth century world than the present, but as characters move to the nearby city for business or entertainment, the calamitous effects of random and unregulated modernization become apparent, and the vulnerability of the village to the destructive elements nearby is apparent, so that the world around Claire divides into the somewhat nostalgic and perhaps disappearing simplicity of the village and the destructive forces of struggles for dominance among competing gangs, as well as the pressures to conform to modern life that distort the feelings and identities of the other characters.  Sexism, homophobia, political corruption, gang violence are all factors in the world Claire is growing into.  There is a sense that the powers of tradition and traditional beliefs have no hope of surviving, and Claire's sense of connection with her dead mother, which has been part of her sense of self, is sorely tested.While there is beauty in this novel, and dramatic power, it feels incomplete and unrealized as the story closes.  That is why I have left it at 4 stars, rather than 5.  I understand the strategy that juxtaposes a series of fragmentary scenes, evokes broken relationships, and leaves the reader with unresolved mysteries, unanswered questions.  In this case, however, the wish for "more" seems to me a legitimate one--the fragments do not shore up against the ruin.

A few pages into this new Doctorow novel, I was reminded of one of his regular narrative strategies--that is, he often begins his novels by creating confusion in the reader's mind.  The narrator's voice shifts, the chronology is confusing or just random, the location of the action (or discussion) is unclear, and so on.  The characteristics of narrative that give the reader a sense of where and who and what and why are scrambled.  It takes a while for the attentive reader to sort them out.  This happens at the beginning of Andrew's Brain, but it's not a longterm problem with the novel.  As it happens, the reader soon learns that the voice of Andrew is speaking to (or in some cases writing to) his analyst, an unnamed presence who responds with questions (often left unanswered) and occasional comments about Andrew's state of mind, motives, good or bad choices.  Andrew tells the analyst about the failure of his first marriage and his panicky effort to have his first (now former) wife take over the care of his infant daughter by his second wife, who is deceased.  We learn all this if we read attentively through the first sections of the novel.  I would add that there are no spoilers here.With reference to spoilers, I have to say that I hesitate to tell much of anything more about the events Andrew narrates to his analyst, other than that he tells the story of how he meets and marries his second wife.  Beyond that, it would be unfair to reveal the sequence of events that form the main body of the narrative of this uneven but finally very powerful novel.  (I started early thinking it might be a 2 star, as I was exasperated by the triviality of much of Andrew's narrative and the too-clever devices Doctorow was using to mix the chronology and the characters to sustain uncertainty and suspense.  But once the latter half of the narrative was under weigh, I was ready for a 3 star and even considered 5 star at some point near the end, but 4 seems reasonable.)Andrew, by the way, is a "cognitive scientist," and he is talking with a psychoanalyst.  Early in their discussions, he comments:"Your field is the mind, mine is the brain.  Will the two ever meet?"  This question underlies much of the speculation that Andrew attempts in his professional research and in his teaching, about which we learn a bit as the novel continues.  Andrew is interested in the ways the brain works, how its constitution and structure affect the thought and actions of human beings and other animals, and so forth.  Further, Andrew is convinced that he is, in some way, a person who causes disasters--from the trivial, such as breaking a piece of chalk as he is trying to write his name on the chalkboard, to the fatal, as in his conviction that he was in some ways personally and causally responsible for several deaths, as well as some serious accidents.  This conviction is based on his observations of his coincidental presence at, or involvement with, the fatal events.  But this novel is in no sense a mystery thriller, as I have seen it incorrectly described.  It is a drama of perception, precise and distorted, clarified or confused.  Andrew is, as we learn early, driven to distraction, possibly to what we would call madness, by the cognitive dissonance that occurs when he realizes his well-intentioned or entirely innocent, or just casual actions result in calamity, usually for others.Doctorow unleashes some of the most dramatic and traumatizing writing of his career in this novel (yes, I have read all his other novels and some short stories), and that is what must be reserved for the reader to find out.  Having said that, why not 5 stars?  It would be nice to be able to rank the novel at that level, but the deficiencies of the first third, nearly first half, of the novel are real, and very disappointing.  But it is a very good example of a novel that should NOT be treated according to the "rule" that many people cite, that if a novel does not "catch" one in the first paragraph (sometimes the first few pages), then it is not worth continuing.  This one may be more annoying than engaging in the first few chapters, but persevere.  It's not a long novel, and the rewards kick in soon enough to carry you breathlessly to the end.

I was very fond of fountain pens when I was a kid, and always preferred them to ballpoints, even though I almost always blotted some ink somewhere when I was writing with a fountain pen.  I haven't used one for a number of years, but thought this would be an interesting experiment.  I am very pleased.  This is a nicely designed, attractive looking, pen that works with a replaceable ink cartridge.  The nib provides a smooth and dependable (so far) writing process, and I am very happy to have it and to be able to expect to use it for some time to come.  I don't know whether the same brand's ballpoints and pencils work as well, but since this seems to be very high quality, I would guess that they would.  Recommended.

The epigraph to this novel signals the source of the title--it's an excerpt from lyrics of a song by Antony and the Johnsons, with the same title.  "For today I am a boy" carries with it both a kind of concession--as in, "okay, I will cooperate this time," and at the same time a gesture of defiance--"today, yes, but I decide what I want from now on."  And that conveys the ongoing dramatic conflict of the narrative, between the forced acceptance of "his" gender identity, as assigned by his parents and most folks around him, and the conviction in Peter Huang's self-consciousness that he is actually she, that the father's chosen name for his son, "juan chaun," which means "powerful king" in Cantonese, is just one of the many errors made by the narrator's parents, relatives, and neighbors about this child's identity.  As we sometimes hear in discussions of transgender persons, this is a girl in a boy's body, a woman in a man's body.  So this novel joins a number of others (Eugenides' Middlesex, Irving's In One Person are two recent examples) exploring the lives and consciousnesses of men and women who live in the wrong sex's body.  Or, in some fortunate cases, manage to choose the changes needed to correct the problem.Kim Fu's novel is written in a straightforward narrative voice, the voice of Peter Huang who may become (may have become, since the story is told retrospectively) Audrey.  Peter has three sisters and would have preferred to be the Huang's fourth female child, though Peter's father was determined to have a son and for a while, determined to impose masculine identity on Peter.  This near obsession on the father's part had severe emotional and psychological effects on Peter, which are narrated in a calm but emotionally compelling manner through the whole novel.  The story proceeds chronologically, though with a few skips forward or backward in time to add pertinent details.  Peter experiences some bullying and violence from boys at school, then breaks loose from the family and the small town in western Canada to move to Montreal, finding work in a restaurant and beginning, through observing others, interacting with fellow workers, as well as experimenting with cross dressing and other experiences, to explore the possibilities of sexual and emotional life previously denied.  Several other characters, including Peter's sisters and his mother (after the death of the father, her husband) also develop as they explore alternatives to the lives defined by traditional (Chinese) social and gender roles.Kim Fu's approach to this narrative is almost more didactic than artistic--the reader is always aware that the story is telling us about the tyranny of traditional patriarchy, about the misguided assumptions patriarchal societies impose on developing children, about the narrow and destructive limits on behavior and expression, even thought, imposed by societies.  Peter chooses not to be limited either by those who want to force masculine roles or by those who understand and want to help Peter toward self-identification.  But by the time we reach the end of the narrative, these points have been made repeatedly and dogmatically.  The reader realizes that the novel is almost more a tract than a fiction.  It's not bad--just predictable.  For many readers, perhaps, living through Peter's experiences, sharing Peter's perspective and emotions through Peter's feelings and words. will be a way of gaining understanding of the differences among humans--perhaps these will be new and surprising revelations to them, but while the novel is nicely put together and Peter's voice is distinctive enough to keep us reading and hoping for a better outcome, it is finally a work that has little to say.  The table is set, the meal is served, it is good enough, but there is not really much beyond the initial taste to take with us.  There is value in what Kim Fu has to offer, but there is no sense that the novel has anything to say about it.

Among the many remarkable (as in "worthy of comment") achievements of Eleanor Catton's superb novel (some of which will be discussed below), one is particularly interesting:  in a long and complex narrative involving the lives and a few deaths of a large cast of characters (only three of whom are women), by far the most sympathetic and engaging characters are also in some senses the most remote, alien, "different" others--two men from China and one a Maori of New Zealand.  The rest of the characters are all Caucasian, of European background, mostly young.  To varying degrees, they are speakers of English (or its dialects), and only one, Benjamin Lowenthal, is Jewish--indeed, an observant Jew--while the others are at least from Christian backgrounds. The two Chinese men, Quee Long and Sook Yongshen, have, one might say, washed up in northwestern New Zealand, the first a goldsmith and prospector, the second, proprietor of an opium den that caters to the needs of men and women most of whom work in the gold fields of that part of New Zealand, hoping for a strike that would allow them to pay their way home, wherever that might be.  Neither man speaks English well nor hears it with any great comprehension, though Sook (contemptuously called "Johnny Sook" by the European citizens of Hokitika, a town existing entirely to cater to the needs of the prospectors, "Johnny" being the term of convenience that white men use to address all the Chinese workers they encounter, not unlike the "Boy" used by white men with African slaves in the South) has a better sense of the language than Quee, and that is significant to the plot. The Maori man, Te RauTauwhare addressed as Ted, is, of course, indigenous ("native") to the land these people inhabit, and their government has designated certain parts of the land as belonging to the Maori (in practical terms, only so long as it is convenient for the white men to leave it so), and the Maori are most definitely "different"--Tauwhare's extensive body and facial tattoos are a permanent and striking reminder to everyone who encounters him of the great differences between his cultural and religious background (very little understood by the whites) and their own.  Tauwhare pursues, so far as possible, the ways and customs of his ancestral people, but is treated with more respect by the white men, perhaps because of his more or less protected status, perhaps because he is dignified and formidable, perhaps just because the need of the whites to condescend to or oppress those they choose to perceive as their inferiors (and to exploit through indenture rules little less owned than slaves) is satisfied by their treatment of the Chinese men among them. These three men, I would suggest, are the most sympathetic and emotionally appealing characters (to somewhat different degrees) in this novel, and that strikes me as a major achievement by its author.  Her descriptions of them, including passages in which they speak their native languages with little translation provided, and including detailed and vivid descriptions of their feelings and the distinctive ways they perceive the world around them--notably different from the ways the whites perceive that same world--offer the reader insights and expanded perceptions not available through the eyes or minds of the more familiar white European characters.  Tauwhare, in particular, because of the religious traditions of the Maori people, with their ancient and profound sense of identification with the natural world that sustains them and that they protect and preserve, worshiping its sacred character, provides a window onto the world we might not otherwise have access to.  (I make no judgment about the accuracy of Eleanor Catton's portrayal of the Maori or Chinese worldviews--I believe she has taken trouble to reconstruct them based on both information and sympathetic understanding, but accuracy is not relevant to the point I am making--that these characters are successfully "other" and provide a major part of the pleasure of reading this novel.) None of this is meant to say that the white characters are all unpleasant or evil, nor that there are none whom we might like or even identify with.  The first character we meet in detail--Walter Moody, is on the whole a very sympathetic character--a decent man who finds himself more or less invited to become part of an inquiry--or one might say a conspiracy--to uncover the answers to several interlocking mysteries that have roiled the town of Hokitika, including a mysterious death, the disappearance of a prominent citizen, the possible suicide attempt of a recently arrived prostitute, the calamitous outcome of a much-promoted "seance," all having occurred along with the wreck of a barque that had arrived in port the same day as many of these events occurred. It will not do to offer any details about these complicated interactions--a disappeared trunk perhaps lost at sea, a frightening apparition on board a foundering ship, possible forged documents, and so forth.  For that is another great achievement of this novel--the creation of a richly intertwined series of events, gradually revealed through the activities of a number of different characters, each of whom is introduced to the reader in detail, with careful analyses of his or her personality and outlook, moral and philosophical views, and when appropriate, revelations about past behavior that affect the reader's view of the person and his or her likely future behavior.  There is the prosperous hotel owner and pimp, a second hotel manager, the proprietor of a pharmacy who deals in opium (not illegal), men involved in various aspects of shipping industry (very important to this mining town on the New Zealand coast), the editor/publisher of the local newspaper, a banker, a magistrate, a politician engaged in an election campaign, various gold prospectors, the Governor of the Hokitika Gaol (an institution that would incorporate the functions of almshouse and asylum), and the clergyman destined to be the Chaplain of that Gaol. among others. Three women--Lydia Greenway/Wells/Carver (a woman of various identities), Anna Wetherell, a young prostitute and opium addict, and Margaret Shepard, wife of George Shepard, the Governor of the Hokitika Asylum and Jail, a woman perceived by most to be pathologically shy--perhaps agoraphobic, though the term is not used.  Each of these women is (as we learn over many pages) admirable in various ways, whether for intelligence and determination, sensitivity and emotional commitment, loyalty, perhaps even love for others.  Each is also complex and imperfect in important ways.  And it is fair to say that though they are all white, European, they are also, in this environment, entirely "other" and so comparable in some ways to the Chinese and Maori men. One aspect of the novel that requires acknowledgment is the pervasive role of astrology as a point of reference.  As I am not familiar, except in the most superficial way, with the arcana of this traditional "science," I have to say that the many "charts" and references to the influences affecting the various characters are mostly closed to me. Of course, one knows about the Zodiac and its signs, and the general beliefs of this ancient worldview are familiar in many contexts, especially literary, but thefiner points of the differences of influence are not familiar to me.  As it happens, each of the twelve major divisions of this novel is introduced with an astrological chart "locating" twelve of the major characters for the period during which the action takes place, and we know that several of the characters, most prominently Tauwhare, take seriously the influence of the stars, or at least are willing to exploit belief in those influences.  The author's introductory "Note to the Reader" offers the suggestion that stubborn adherence to a known error is characteristic of "persons born during the Age of Pisces, an age of mirrors, tenacity, instinct, twinship, and hidden things."  That description of the qualities of the Piscean age would also make a very nice summary of the qualities of this narrative, all of which make it so fascinating. It is right to call The Luminaries a thriller, and I would suggest it is a thriller of a traditional kind.  If it had been published in weekly chapters in a periodical, like the novels of Charles Dickens or Wilkie Collins or many others of the late 19th century, its way of proceeding and its regular approach to what we would call cliffhangers would perfectly suit it to that genre.  While many might invoke the memory of Dickens as comparison for this novel, I think its intricacy and rapid movement make it more akin to Wilkie Collins's best work, The Moonstone, perhaps, or Woman in White, though it also has affinities with late Dickens, Mystery of Edwin Drood, especially.  I also am inclined to speculate that we might anticipate a sequel.  While certain parts of the plot are "solved" and the problems resolved, there are several characters and situations notably left hanging, with uncertain outcomes, and those would more than supply material for a following novel, if the author chooses. Long works of prose fiction ("big books," or maxi-novels) such as this can provide many different kinds of pleasure.  In this case, the fascinating characters, the exotic setting, the constant twists and turns of the plot, the uncertain identities and surprising revelations, all contribute to a narrative that pleases by confounding the reader, who is compelled, indeed propelled to keep on reading, even at the risk of missing pertinent details.  I found myself checking back to earlier chapters, preceding bits of dialogue or description, time and again, to assure myself that I was not entirely lost or wrong about developments.  This was not a fault or a failure of the narrative--it was one of its genuine rewards.
