While this novel has important things to say about human relationships, it is not profound; we do not keep reading in hopes of the depth of a Dostoevsky, the refinement of a Henry James, the historical sweep of a Tolstoy; we are rather entertained and moved, and we feel satisfied.

Just about four-fifths of the way through The Museum of Innocence, chapter 69 is called "Sometimes."  It is six tightly printed pages long (most of the chapters in this novel are fairly short--some as few as two pages, few more than eleven or twelve), and its title is significant.  In this chapter, every sentence begins with the word "sometimes" and every sentence reports events small or intense, emotions familiar or surprising:  "Sometimes we'd see lightning in the distance, and the sky would rumble."  "Sometimes I would help take the dirty plates into the kitchen,"  "Sometimes I was absolutely positive that life itself wasn't somewhere else, but right there, at that table."  The reported events or feelings are not grouped chronologically, nor according to any particular sequence of types or characteristics; they are not grouped logically, nor contrasted by degrees of significance.  They are, or are intended to create the impression of, randomly remembered moments. And the chapter in many ways reinforces the reader's sense that this is a novel about time.The narrator, Kemal, refers several times during his detailed and minute description of roughly ten years of his life to Aristotle's writings on time--in particular, the view that the present is made up of many isolated moments, experienced as "now," and "time" is the line that connects all of them to make up our past and our sense of duration.  Since each person experiences the "now" differently, with different combinations of the discrete moments that make up the present, the "past" which is all such moments connected by our sense of their sequence and duration will be different for each person.Kemal, in fact, talks incessantly about aspects of time and the way time impinges on our consciousness, even including a chapter about the ways technology--from primitive timekeeping mechanisms to increasingly precise clocks and watches, to the presence of radios and then televisions which usurp the place of timepieces in determining our sense of the passage of time--has changed our consciousness of time, even inducing forgetfulness and the obliteration of time.  As Kemal tells us at one point, "Sometimes I would forget Time altogether, and nestle into 'now' as if it were a soft bed."With time as a major theme, the questions of identity, of relationships, of the possibility of knowing anything for certain, of the roles of social and political change in individual lives, of religious belief and superstition, of the possibility of stepping outside of time and most importantly, of the role of love and its effect on the meaning of time in anyone's life--are all (and this list is not comprehensive) important aspects of Kemal's meditations on his experiences and his efforts to retain evidence--by collecting objects--of what has happened and to whom in his life.  In that sense, the title is the giveaway--in this novel about obsession (or at least about an obsessive character, Kemal)--we participate in the evolution of the museum of Kemal's life and loves, which he assembles and then attempts to create and open to the public so that "visitors to my Museum of Innocence must compel themselves, therefore, to view all objects displayed therein--the buttons, the glasses, the old photographs and Fusun's combs--not as real things in the present moment, but as my memories."Of course, the novel is not really "about" time, but tells a story of hopeless love:  Kemal is engaged to marry a cultivated and socially prominent woman whom he loves, but he falls in love with a "shopgirl," a very beautiful and ambitious young woman (Fusun) with whom he has a torrid sexual affair while involved in planning for the engagement party and subsequent wedding to his fiancee, Sibel. This situation forces consideration of the many social and moral tensions in Turkey brween 1975 and 1985, the main duration of the narrative; Turkey, with its proud commitment to secular republican values and ambitions to modernize and become more European is nonetheless wracked with dissension because of the growing power of the traditionalist Islamists and their commitment to restoring the social control and political power of the religious traditions they value.  So "time" is also about the fissures between traditional custom and modern thought, between women wearing headscarves and long dresses and others wearing European dress, bikinis, smoking, driving cars and openly showing affection (necking in public with their boyfriends), which contrasts (as we know in our own society) force awareness of the changes that go with the passage of time. The problems are further complicated by the class divisions of which Kemal (as the son of a wealthy businessman, who has led a life of privilege and almost no financial anxieties) is painfully aware, both because of Fusun's much lower social and economic standing but because of his involvement with a number of friends who represent various levels of, and attitudes toward, the economic disparities in Istanbul, as well as the contrasts between the urban and rural cultures.Stories about obsessions, especially about obsessive characters who are mostly unaware that they are behaving obsessively, can become tiresome--obsession involves repetition, after all, and at some point repetition becomes boring or even exasperating.  At some early stages of my reading of this novel, I wondered whether that would become a serious problem.  I have read and greatly enjoyed most of Orhan Pamuk's novels, and have learned to be intrigued and pleased by his metafictional games as well as by the depth of the characters (in more traditional senses) that he creates.  In this case, the early worries were not borne out.  The novel is repetitive in some ways, but the repetitions enhance the power of the narrative as the variations on familiar themes and the plot twists (involving a number of other characters, such as Kemal's mother and brother, Fusun's family, various business associates) keep the story moving, though admittedly at a deliberate and constantly self-examining pace.  (Orhan Pamuk is, himself, a character in the novel, appearing as a guest at the engagement party and in a more important role later which I will not specify for fear of creating a spoiler.)Late in the novel, perhaps inevitably, Kemal alludes in passing to his having found solace in reading Proust and Montaigne.  The overt references to two writers who are unquestionably antecedents to the themes and narrative strategies of this novel is typical of Pamuk, both as an acknowlegment and as a challenge:  we must consider whether he has lived up to his literary ancestors.  While The Museum of Innocence has much of the rich and deep qualities of those writers' works, and I have greatly enjoyed reading it, I have to conclude that as compared with the best of Pamuk's own works (My Name Is Red, Snow, The Black Book), it is not quite on the same level.  By almost any standard, it is a very fine work and I do recommend it enthusiastically, but the danger of writing obsessively (even with comic intent) about an obsession is not entirely avoided.  I hope, however, that many readers will try it for themselves, as it offers great rewards.

It seems almost churlish to complain about Billy Collins's poetry; he works so hard to be ingratiating while maintaining the appearance of effortless composition.  He is popular in several senses--among contemporary poets, "popular" meaning appealing to a large and varied audience, is a rare quality, and yet to all appearances, Collins has gained and maintained an uncommonly wide readership.  To his fans and his critics, this is attributable to his approach to poetry--he writes what any reader would agree is "accessible" poetry--poems about chance encounters with familiar objects that prompt odd thoughts or responses, providing new perspectives or witty comments about the familiar; or recognitions of unfamiliar objects or experiences that somehow impinge on his consciousness and force him to reconsider the ways the new perceptions force rearrangements of the old and the familiar.  The reader is treated to the shared recognition of that feeling of comfort and familiarity, or the feeling of oddness and possible shock, only to be reassured that the new fits with the old, if only through the exercise of some witty transformation or transition.  And there is always wit.  Perception and wit, clever verbal manipulations of ideas and feelings--what else could we want from poems?Yet, the repetition of pretty much the same method -- a sharp perception or evocation, a clever move toward defamiliarizing, and comforting reversal returning us to the familiar -- many of the poems reproduce this pattern and suggest to the reader who is traversing many pages of Collins's poems that his work is better read in moderation, a few poems at a time, with long rests between.This is because the patterns so often seem to be the only excuse for the poem.  Collins depends on his sharp senses and his witty manipulation of words to keep the readers' attention while entertaining and reassuring them that they have enjoyed a good poem.  That is often true, but "good" is about as much as one can say for them.  They are well crafted, they amuse or entertain, on a very few occasions, they may prompt serious thought or deep feeling, but mostly they skim surfaces and allow easy exits.Collins is very aware of these reservations from his critics.  In this collection, we find several poems, a few from years back, a couple from the "new" section, wherein he comments on the "problems" with poetry and with being a poet.  "The Suggestion Box," for example, is especially relevant.  He humorously describes a day during which several people tell him that he "could write a poem about that."  People who know he is a poet offer "subjects" for poems--a waitress spills coffee in his lap, there is a fire drill interrupting classes, he encounters a man with a face full of tattoos, and so on.  He jokes that people expect him to write about quirky experiences, and he suggests to himself "Maybe I should write a poem/about all the people who think/they know what I should be writing poems about."  And so the cute and witty turn--he is writing a poem about writing a poem in the context of  readers' expectations.  And that poem entertains, especially with its final image of a pair of ducks emerging from the water, in exactly the way the people expect.  It also, to some extent, gets Collins off the hook, since he is acknowledging that there are some who think his poems are shallow while, simultaneously, and justifiably, claiming that there is a difference in depth and significance between his poems about objects and occasions and the triviality of the subjects offered by his readers--he is better than they think, he claims, and that is true.In another such poem, "No Things," opens with a reference to "This love for everyday things," and mounts a defense of finding the poetic wonder in what another poet called "the stuff of what happens," while giving a backhand to the poets of "no," with Philip Larkin's name prominently displayed as a poet of everyday life who finds darkness, misery, even despair, in the elements of an ordinary day's encounters.  Collins's ironic attack on poets who are always "banging away on the mystery" is both a pointed critique (sometimes the doomsayers can be as repetitive and seemingly mechanical in their poetic procedures and Collins is accused of being, but on the negative side) and a pointed self-defense--he values "the firefly,/the droplet running along the green leaf,/or even the bar of soap sliding around the bathtub" and implicitly refuses to be forced to see the dark sides of such images.The ongoing battle in the American poetry business between the champions of the "accessible and audience-friendly poem" and those who insist that such work is mere versifying at best, kitsch at worst, and certainly not poetry, who assert the superior value of poems as language machines, deep images, surreal or dreamlike experiences (poems are not about anything), leaps of imagination, inspired nonsense, etc., continues and is unlikely to abate, though neither side can produce convincing arguments for the exclusive superiority of their preferred poetic modes.  Collins is a high level practitioner of the charming and accessible poem that is both thoughtful and witty, even occasionally moving and enlightening.  He is unlikely ever to be ranked with the great poets, because our aesthetic tends to value the dark and serious and probing over the light and charming and amusing.  So be it.As for this volume, it offers a generous selection of Collins's earlier poems and a similarly generous selection of previously uncollected poems. It seems to me to be an excellent introduction to his work for a new reader, a pleasant set of additions for anyone who already knows the earlier works.  While there are several very strong poems among the new ones, there is little difference from his earlier work--which is perhaps his strength for those who like his work, though it probably also confirms the negatives for those who do not.  The concluding poem in this volume, it must be said, is a departure--"The Names: (for the victims of September 11 and their survivors)" is an uncommonly serious poem--an expression of respect for the grief, the pain, the loss, carried forward as a kind of litany/catalogue of names linked with images of time passing, life ended and life going on.  As it really had to be, this was and is an exceptional poem in Collins's body of work.

Since the earlier "review" included with this title is of a different book entirely and should be deleted since it is irrelevant, I wouid like to say that this lovely book, edited by Edward Hirsch, is certainly worthy in its own right of a 5 star rating.  The selection of poems that either address, comment on, or mention in passing the presence and significance of the nightingale is wide-ranging and worth reading, individually and in concert with the stated theme of the book.  There are a few surprising omissions (one Latin poem, in particular, that seems to me the most beautiful about nightingales, but perhaps Mr. Hirsch was unable to find a satisfactory translation of it), but the excerpts and complete poems included are all worth reading and contemplating.  Obviously, I recommend the small volume to anyone who loves poetry and birds.  (Of course, there are no nightingales in the USA, since the species is not native to this continent, which may possibly lend a special poignancy to Keats's line, "heard melodies are sweet, but those unheard are sweeter".)

From my first encounter with Robert Stone's work--the great Dog Soldiers--through all of his novels since, I have been consistently impressed and moved by his complex characterizations, powerful plotting, and maybe especially his ability to create convincing environments where his characters would live out the dramas that grow from their actions and personal struggles. Not only Dog Soldiers, but Children of Light, Outerbridge Reach, Damascus Gate, and the others have been deeply satisfying works.Death of the Black-Haired Girl?  Not so.  This traditional college campus story of a dangerous romance between a married  professor and one of his students feels forced, cobbled together, and though the characters are complex as well as familiar (from other literary works), they are not finally particularly interesting nor convincing.  Maud, brilliant mind and talented writer who is still emotionally and socially immature; Jo, idealistic former nun working as a counselor and still trying to work out her conflicted relationships with people encountered in her former life; Edward Stack and Lou Salmone, retired cop and Maud's father, still working cop and old friend of Edward--both steeped in the mixture of commitment to the ideal of the cop in service to public safety while caught in morally suspect or underhanded relations; Steven Brookman--the professor who finds himself involved with his student while wanting to protect and preserve his marriage, especially because his wife, Ellie, is finally pregnant with their hoped-for second child.  There is plenty of potential drama here, and much of it works out more or less as one would expect.  The accidental death of Maud in complicated and ambiguous circumstances, seen from different angles by different witnesses, produces a variety of versions of who did what, who should be held responsible.  If Steven Brookman was not directly responsible for Maud's death on a physical level, was he perhaps nonetheless morally responsible for creating the circumstances that brought them together and precipitated the accident.  Moral ambiguity, complexity of character, yes.  Convincing and powerful drama, not really.While no one would want to confine a writer of Stone's excellence to the same territories he has explored in other works, one can wish that he had not decided to tackle the "academic novel," especially in the wake of the several far more successful works in that sub-genre--as far back as Gerald Warner Brace's The Department, John Williams's superb Stoner, or the more recent masterpiece, Disgrace, by J.M. Coetzee, not to mention David Mamet's successful drama, Oleanna. Stone could have surpassed these, of course; it's not that no one could write a better work than Coetzee's or Williams's, but that Stone never manages to lift this novel to their level.  The most effective moments are in the scenes with Eddie Stack, as he tries to work out his desire for revenge when he believes his daughter has been sacrificed to the selfishness and arrogance of Steven Brookman.  But the novel never feels fully realized and the sense of a work forced to its finish overwhelms any strengths it may have in specific scenes.  This is not the Stone I have admired. It feels like a made-for-screenplay composition rather than the kind of committed fiction we value from Robert Stone. It's not a terrible book--just not a book that can stand together with Stone's much finer achievements.

Someone must have neglected to suggest to Ms. Fenn that it may not be a good idea to remind readers of the great masters of the genre in which one is attempting a first effort--in this case, a ghost story thriller that has as its title a direct reference to Edgar Allan Poe (and the very ill-judged choice by the narrator of calling a resident ghost "Poe"), and at several points in the novel, open allusions not only to Poe's greatest works, but to Stephen King's, as well.  King may not be on a level with Poe, but he is pretty formidable and not the best choice for a point of comparison with the story in progress.This may suggest that I do not have much patience with this novel, and that would be correct.  It is clever on a low level, it makes use of materials from classics of its genre, and it attempts to stand on the shoulders of the masters--with little success.  A great part of the problem with this novel is the narrator--supposedly a writer--working on what is a "1000 page novel about Rasputin" and working for a smalltown newspaper (how King-like!) writing obituaries. Assigned to "cover" a seance at a local "haunted house" (the ruin of a family mansion partially burned and left to moulder, but definitely NOT in a class with the House of Usher) the narrator becomes involved in a convoluted and occasionally amusing series of ghostly events, with bloody consequences for several characters.  It is not worth summarizing the plot, but it needs to be said that the narrator, Dimitri Petrov, at no point provides evidence that he is intelligent enough to be the writer he wants to be, and at no point does he manage to avoid the kind of "action" that prompts audiences at low-rent horror films to shout "don't open that door" at the screen as the silliest person in the film inevitably does open it onto some totally predictable horror.  Dimitri is, of course, the "puttery mind" of my title.  He casts about for this or that, examines his conscience occasionally, survives some very unpleasant encounters, but at no point comes to life nor inspires interest.  Nor do any of the "characters" he encounters in this small-town story going nowhere near Poe territory, staying far from King land, managing a few Lovecraft moments, but on the whole wasting the time and patience of the reader who almost never fails to anticipate (pages in advance) each of the shocks and thrills.  I cannot imagine who would have chosen this novel for a "breakthrough" award.  It is the modest first effort of a writer who should have left it in the drawer along with the novel about Rasputin and gone ahead to write what she probably will later accomplish--a reasonably good novel.  One hopes.

Although there are some philosophically oriented English/American writers about movies, they tend not to be among those most recognized by anglophone movie fans.  Some very fine writers--James Agee, Andrew Sarris, Pauline Kael, Dwight Macdonald, Murray Kempton,and many others--have produced readable and insight-filled commentaries on specific movies and the art form in general.  It is uncommon, however, in English language writing about movies, to encounter the kind of complex and sometimes almost incomprehensible prose produced by the philosopher-critics of the French tradition.Alain Badiou, as we are reminded in the introduction to this collection, has been writing about CINEMA for more than fifty years.  This collection offers a number of fascinating, sometimes impossibly arcane, sometimes disappointingly boring, commentaries, usually about genres or directorial oeuvres more than about particular movies.  In other words, though Badiou has strong opinions about the importance, indeed the deep relevance, of cinema to western culture, he is not a movie reviewer and does not bother with thumbs up or down, numbers of stars or popcorn tubs, and so on.  As an unreconstructed (though somewhat reconfigured over the years) Marxist, his analyses tend to focus on what he considers the fundamental issues and orientation of the films he discusses, and he shows a strong preference for the kinds of politically oriented films that we associate with Jean-Luc Godard or, in Badiou's case, the surprising examples of the films of Jacques Tati.  He strongly denigrates some of the most famous and revered French directors and their "quality" films, which he considers to be mummified museum pieces rather than living works of art.For a reader willing to navigate the sometimes jargon-turgid prose, these essays are often rewarding.  One major drawback for many American readers will be the frequent references to political activities and even politicians indigenous to France and the intricacies of French politics, as well as other distinctly parochial francophone interests.  Some notes--not really copious enough for non-French readers--help to clarify some of those points, but a few essays are really worthless to us because of their arcane nature.  I found, therefore, that reading selectively and being willing simply to skip ahead if an essay became too opaque, was the way to go with this.  From that, I found enough of interest to make the book a worthwhile encounter.

Bob Shacochis is admired for his excellent collections of short stories, mostly about life in the Caribbean, an area of the world he knows well.  For his massive new novel, The Woman Who Lost Her Soul, he has taken us back to Haiti, but the more pertinent predecessor to this work is his firsthand reporting of the American occupation of Haiti during the 1990s, The Immaculate Invasion.  That book, a scarifying account of the diplomatic, military and bureaucratic follies of that effort publicly described as intended to rescue the Haitian people from their political chaos, provides all the "background" one might want to clarify the action of the new novel.  But rest assured, the novel can be read on its own, and the reader will probably then wish to read the nonfiction work afterward, just because Shacochis is such a good writer and the subject is important.I was initially a bit dubious about this novel.  After the first fifty pages, I wondered if it would turn out to be a romping action novel, with lots of exotic local color and very tough men exercising all their muscles and mechanical equipment to beat up on the bad guys--Rambo Meets Vodou, or some such thing.  But I felt sure I could expect better, if only because of the presence of the epigraph at the beginning by Fernando Pessoa: "It is no secret that souls sometimes die in a person and are replaced by others."  That plus an accompanying passage from Czeslaw Milosz, and another from Winston Churchill, seemed bona fide assurances that there would be depths, and there are. It's not that I always assume an epigraph is a guarantee, but it is a kind of promise, and that is fulfilled. As I should have expected from Shacochis.The novel is divided into five sections of unequal length, with locations in Haiti, Croatia, Turkey, various U.S. military and CIA locations, including several famous golf courses, and the Outer Banks.  At the center of the novel, a father-daughter pair (dangerously paired), Stephen Chambers/Stjepan Kovacevic and Dorothy (Dottie) Chambers/with several AKA names; the father is a high official in the Foreign Service with influential connections in many of the "black" operations known or not known to have been ongoing during the 70's, 80's, 90's.  Stephen Chambers has more than connections--he has uncanny authority and uses it to bypass whatever obstacles (including legal prohibitions against, for example, assassination), as well as to pursue a goal of revenge against men involved in the death of his father during the Second World War in Croatia.  His daughter, preternaturally beautiful and intelligent, and deeply involved in conspiracy and spying (more or less at the instigation of her father), is the woman of the title.  We learn very early in the novel that she has been killed in an ambush in Haiti, and much of the rest of the book includes, though is not primarily focused on, efforts to identify the reasons for her death and the identity of her killers.Dottie Chambers, known by several other names, is important in her own right, and the third section of the novel is devoted to her teenage years at school in Turkey, where the reasons for her loss of her soul begin to appear, though they are only fully developed later.  Her importance in the structure of the novel is apparent because she is the center of attention of many men, but especially of the several main male characters, Tom Harrington, Eville Burnette, and her father.There is plenty of action in this novel, which need not be previewed here.  What is important about the novel is its rich exploration of a number of important ethical and psychological challenges to the behavior of men and women involved in international "relations," with special reference to the motives that move some to encourage or even generate international or interracial or other forms of conflict in the effort to achieve personal political ends--revenge of a father's death, for example, or defeat of a rival held in contempt, or even sexual rivalry.  The morality (or the rejection of the relevance of morality) of the plotting and enactment of the overthrow of governments or simply the elimination of inconvenient political actors (or criminal elements, such as narco-traders) is explored in depth.  The personal impact on the agents or actors in these activities--the destruction of relationships, the loss of faith or even the ability to trust, the collapse of any sense of self--all these afflict the main characters in Shacochis's narrative, and they lead us to realize that at some point, love may have a redemptive effect, but it may also be just a complicating factor that unravels carefully laid plans and leads to the death of people--some innocent (though almost no one is innocent in this web of intrigue), some beloved but faithless, some possessed of multiple identities and, in traditional noir fashion, equally involved in both or all of the conflicting "sides" of these international conflicts.In other words, this substantial, complex, brilliantly written novel is worth your time.  I would say thatit competes on a level with another massive novel of similar complexity, Jonathan Littell's  Les Bienveillantes (The Kindly Ones), and then points of comparison might need reference back to some of the classic novels of international intrigue and warfare.  I recommend The Woman Who Lost Her Soul without reservation.
